articles.subtitle: The greatest international organisation in the world
articles.name: FN

text.text:
BACKGROUND
Attempts had already been made before the First World War to create an international organisation that would be able to bring about peace between nations. The League of Nations was therefore established after the war, partly because of American initiatives. This turned out to be rather fruitless, as many superpowers were not members. The organisation was unable to prevent numerous wars in during the years between the two world wars, or the conflicts that led up to the Second World War. The first notions of a “United Nations” were put forward by American president Franklin D. Roosevelt. This was already the official title in 1942 for the allied powers who were fighting alongside each other during the Second World War.
When the war ended a number of conferences were held, the largest and most important of these being the 1945 San Francisco conference, which was attended by delegations from 50 different countries to draw up the UN Charter. The 111 articles of this charter are the foundation of the United Nations, serving as a kind of constitution. The charter describes the various main institutions of the UN, their role within the UN and globally, where decisions are made and the role of regional institutions within the UN. It also states how conflicts can be resolved, which has been crucial to more recent UN missions.
The charter was undersigned by Denmark and 49 other nations on 26 June 1945, Poland soon following , before being ratified by the participating nations. Everything was finally in place on 24 October. With 51 participating member states, the United Nations was now the largest international organisation in the world. Its purpose then, as it is today, was to end war and to promote peace, justice and a better way of life for all humanity.

ORGANISATION
The UN has six principal organs that together comprise the upper echelons of the organisation.
First and foremost of these is the General Assembly, in which all member states are represented, each having a single vote. This is where budgets are adopted, new members accepted and the General Secretary elected. Since the Uniting for Peace resolution was adopted in 1950, the General Assembly has been authorised to deploy peacekeeping forces after an emergency meeting, if the Security Council is unable to act because one or more of its members has exercised veto. General Assembly resolutions are not legally binding, however, and it is up to member states whether they wish to abide by them.
The Security Council is comprised of five permanent members and ten alternating members selected by the General Assembly. The Security Council is the only organ that is able to adopt legally binding resolutions. According to Chapter VII of the Charter, the Security Council is tasked with evaluating and condemning threats to and violations of international peace. It is therefore the Security Council that is competent, through the adoption of resolutions, to mandate sanctions or international interventions in conflicts and therefore establish UN observation missions and operations.
The Secretariat is led by the General Secretary and is responsible for the UN’s administration, servicing the other organs and preparing the budget before it is sent to the General Assembly for a vote on its adoption. It is also responsible for planning and preparing conferences and drafting studies and reports for the agenda, as well as possible options for action.
The Economic and Social Council, or ECOSOC in short, has 54 members selected by the General Assembly. The main purpose of this council is to promote the development of economic and social conditions through international partnerships.
The Trusteeship Council was established in 1945 by the UN Charter, under Chapter XIII, to provide international supervision for 11 Trust Territories that had been placed under the administration of seven Member States, and ensure that adequate steps were taken to prepare the Territories for self-government and independence. By 1994, all Trust Territories had attained self-government or independence. The Trusteeship Council suspended operation on 1 November 1994.
The International Court of Justice, or ICJ, is the UN’s judiciary. Its 15 members are also selected by the General Assembly. Its purpose is to resolve conflicts through legal channels. Only states are able to present cases to the ICJ. The UN’s own organs are, however, entitled to ask for legal evaluations.

THE RIGHT OF VETO
The 15 members of the UN Security Council are not equal. The five permanent members are the victorious powers of the Second World War: the USA, United Kingdom, France, China and the Soviet Union. When the Soviet Union disintegrated its place went to Russia. To persuade these powerful nations to accept the role of the UN and not stay outside it, as happened with the League of Nations after the First World War, they were given a special role within the organisation. The five permanent members therefore have the right to veto within the Security Council. Each resolution requires not only a majority, but the agreement of all five powers, or abstention. There have been many situations where it has been difficult for the UN to take action, as the five permanent members often have conflicting interests. It was difficult to reach agreement during the Cold War because of rivalry between the Soviet Union and USA. Despite optimism that we had entered a new era of collaboration during the 1990s this has again been a problem in recent years, including when an intervention in the civil war in Syria was made impossible because of the Russian veto. Although the Uniting for Peace resolution was intended to be a solution to such occurrences, it has seldom been applied with any effect, as the veto of the five permanent members often represents powerful interests.
The five permanent members no longer represent a broad cross section of the world as it is today. The Security Council’s structure was designed in 1945, when it made better sense as large parts of the world were French and British colonies. Nowadays it seems strange to many that France and, more recently Britain and, in some regards, Russia have a seat at the table, while an enormous country like India does not have representation. It has also been criticised that Africa, South America or the Arabic World are not represented among the permanent members of the Security Council. There have therefore been multiple attempts to reform the Security Council, by proposing additional permanent members or by abolishing the right to veto, but these have come to no fruition.

ORGANISATIONS
Below the five main organs of the UN are numerous different organisations, offices and agencies, all of whom operate within the framework of the UN to promote peace, justice and development throughout the world. Some of the larger ones include the World Health Organisation (or WHO in short) and the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), which are both examples of practically-oriented organisations that combat disease and famine. Others, such as UNESCO work to promote culture, education and knowledge. Others are even older than the UN. The International Labour Organization (ILO) was founded as part of the League of Nations in 1919, but has been absorbed into the UN. The oldest is the International Telecommunications Union (ITU), that was founded in 1865, but is now a UN agency.
The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) is one of the larger organisations that is most frequently in contact with the Danish Emergency Management Agency when it is deployed on behalf of the UN. Examples of close collaborations with the UNHCR include AFOR (deployed in Albania during the refugee crisis that arose from the conflict in Kosovo) and UNPROFOR (deployed in the former Yugoslavia).
Humanitarian aspects are important areas in which the UN takes action during all conflicts and catastrophes. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) was set up to coordinate the numerous initiatives. During all its years of operation Denmark has actively participated in these with the various deployments of the Danish Emergency Management Agency.
There are also various organisations that are not directly part of the UN but that were set up as a result of UN resolutions or conventions that were negotiated within the UN. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is the most famous example of such an organisation, typically acting together with the UN and reporting to the General Assembly annually. The same applies to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), on whose advice the Security Council adopted resolutions that led to the Danish commanded RECLIB and RECSYR operations.

CHALLENGES

The UN has changed a lot since it started in 1945. The 51 founder members have been joined by another 142 nations, making a total of 193 member states. Two more states/areas have observer status. Many of the “new” members were colonies that gained their independence during the decades that followed the Second World War. This was not always an easy process and UN blue-helmets were seen in many parts of the world as former colonies became independent nations. UNMOGIP was set up when India declared independence from the United Kingdom and split into India and Pakistan. In 1960 the fighting that followed independence in the Congo led to a major UN operation known as ONUC.
One of the first challenges to be faced was the division of Palestine when the British colonial power decided to pull out of the region. The UN attempted a division plan but this was never implemented. The conflicts that followed led to the UN’s most extensive and longest duration observation mission, UNTSO, which has been followed by numerous others over the years.
The Cold War between the USA and the Soviet Union began soon after the UN was founded, both nations having veto rights as part of the Security Council. The UN was therefore unable to intervene in a long list of conflicts, as one side or the other used their right of veto. When the Communist Party was the victor of the civil war in China, 20 years would pass before the People’s Republic of China was given a seat on the Security Council to replace the Republic of China, which ruled only over Taiwan and was far from being the superpower that is now represented on the Security Council. This situation led to the communist Soviet Union boycotting the Security Council in support of China. This would come back and bite the Soviet Union in the tail. When the Korean War broke out in 1950, the Soviet Union was unable (because of its boycott) to veto a UN force that fought on the side of South Korea.
The Korean War is what led to the adoption of the Uniting for Peace (UFP) resolution by the General Assembly. If the Security Council has been paralysed by the right of veto this resolution allows the convening of an emergency meeting of the General Assembly to mandate peacekeeping operations. During the Suez crisis in 1956 in which France and the United Kingdom used their right of veto, the General Assembly convened and decided to deploy its first actual peacekeeping force, in the form of UNEF. It is seldom that the UFP procedure is used, however, as there is normally insufficient manpower and political will to take action if the powerful nations who are permanent members of the Security Council are in disagreement about how to proceed.
The end of the Cold War gave the UN better options. It was with a UN mandate that Operation Desert Storm was able to drive Iraq out of Kuwait during the first Gulf War and that UNIKOM was created to monitor the peace that followed. The UN would now face new types of conflict, however. There would seldom be wars between actual nations, like those that the UN was created to prevent. Instead, challenges would come from civil wars and nations that collapsed within their own borders.
The former Yugoslavia was where the UN would face one of its biggest crises, as UNPROFOR was unable to secure and bring about peace using the so-called “safe zones” that had been set up during the war. The massacre at Srebrenica and the siege and shelling of Sarajevo are examples of conflicts that the UN was unable to solve. When peace did eventually lie on the horizon, the UN had an important role to play in bringing stability to the region, including in the form of UNTAES and UNPREDEP.

It seems likely in the new millenium, however, that a new cold war will paralyse the Security Council once again. Despite an effective intervention in Libya in the form of Operation Unified Protector, the Arabian Spring and the conflicts that followed it have revealed differing approaches by Russia and the West. The conflicts in Syria and the Ukraine are two examples of how the right of veto has prevented the UN from bringing about effective resolutions. Nevertheless, UN operations such as RECSYR and RECLIB have been essential to reducing the use of chemical weapons in ongoing conflicts.

MISSION TYPES
When personnel from Danish Defence, the Danish Police and the Danish Emergency Management Agency are sent out to serve under the UN it can be on various types of missions. The four types listed here often overlap or are linked in various ways. What they all share in common is that the UN has no military or police of its own that it can deploy. It must instead ask member states to contribute by providing the necessary personnel.
Observer or monitoring missions typically involve a smaller team of officers or police personnel, who can be deployed with light armaments in areas where there are existing or prior conflicts, or where there is a risk that conflict will break out. In other words, these personnel are the UN’s eyes and ears on the ground. As such, they are not mandated to prevent a conflict, only to observe and report about what is going on. UNSMIS was one such recent observer mission to which Denmark has contributed recently, where the team was charged with monitoring a ceasefire that had been negotiated by the UN special envoy.
Peacekeeping missions often work closely alongside observer missions and it is not always possible to distinguish the boundaries between where one starts and the other ends. These are typically Security Council initiatives that involve large military units who may not, as a general rule, use force for purposes other than self-defence. In an ideal world they are peacekeepers, because a ceasefire or peace agreement has been negotiated. The purpose of missions of this type is to keep the combatants apart, to implement the return of occupied areas or to patrol demilitarised zones along a border. Their operation is normally only with the clear acceptance of both conflicted parties. It is not the intention that they should force a peace. UNEF was the first peacekeeping mission and was also the first in which Denmark deployed personnel to a mission of this type.
Peace enforcing missions are more clearly differentiated from observer and peacekeeping missions, as they can only be initiated by the Security Council, have heavier armaments and do not necessarily require the consent of the parties to the conflict. By contrast, the purpose of peacebringing missions is to force a ceasefire or peace agreement in scenarios where one or more parties is unwilling to accept a peace that is based on the expectations of the international community. Operations Faraway and Desert Storm were peacebringing missions, as they involved maintaining an embargo and actual military action aimed at ending the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, using force if necessary.
Humanitarian missions cover widely diverse concepts, which can be closely affiliated to the above types of mission, or completely isolated from them. Peacekeeping and peacebringing missions often have humanitarian traits, as troops participating in the mission are also involved in the distribution and securing of emergency aid, or the protection of civilians against attack. Some missions are entirely humanitarian, for example where there are earthquakes, famines or other disaster. Here, the presence has no decidedly military purpose and serves only to provide emergency aid, even though a military presence may be necessary for security reasons.
There have also been humanitarian interventions where the UN has intervened in a conflict to protect a civilian population, often against the will of the sitting government. One such example was Operation Unified Protector in Libya.
Responsibility to Protect is the UN tenet behind its humanitarian interventions in which military force is used to prevent a state from commiting crimes against humanity.

text.text:
BACKGROUND
The Cold War was a period of hostility between the Soviet Union and the USA. The 1970s were therefore characterised as a period of de-escalation between the two superpowers that became known as the détente (which is French for “easing of tension”). A number of treaties were signed during the détente and the two sides began to cooperate, including on setting up a Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) in 1973. The conference was intended to be a multi-national diplomatic forum that would serve as the backdrop for increased dialogue between the European states, the USA and Canada. The conference meetings culminated in the drafting of the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, also known as the Helsinki Accords. This document was signed in 1975 by the USA, Canada, the Soviet Union and all European states except Albania and Andorra.
Its provisions can be divided in to three “baskets”. Basket 1 concerns political and military relationships and the establishment of mutual security and confidence, including respect for each state’s sovereignty and borders. Basket 2 concerns economic and environmental cooperation. Basket 3 concerns initiatives to do with cultural and technological exchange and respect for universal human rights.
The Helsinki Accords were an agreement on policy. The provisions they contained were therefore far more wide-reaching than would otherwise have been possible at that point in time. Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev considered the accords to be a political victory, consolidating the territories the Soviet Union had acquired during the Second World War. The accords became considered, however, as legitimisation for the various dissident movements and human rights organisations that began to sprout in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union in their wake.
When the Soviet Union and Communist Eastern European régimes collapsed, it was decided that CSCE's role would be extended, making it an institution that would serve to integrate the newly-independent states within the context of Western Europe. The Charter for a New Europe (also known as the Charter of Paris) was signed in 1990. In 1995 CSCE was renamed the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE).
With 57 members, OSCE is now the largest international security organisation in the world. The Helsinki Accords continue as the basis for OSCE focus areas, with their political/military, environmental and economic/environmental aspects.

DECISION
Denmark had already put forward the idea of a European conference on security as early as in 1966. It was therefore a perfectly natural development that Denmark would become part of the OSCE partnership in 1975, when the organisation was founded on the basis of the 1973 security conference. Denmark has been an active participant in CSCE/OSCE for many years, not least with regard to its work towards increased respect for human rights. A meeting on human rights was held in Copenhagen in 1990 and Denmark held the position of OSCE chair in 1997.

ORGANISATION
When it was restructured during the 1990s, OSCE transitioned from a loose structure based on diplomatic meetings between its member states into a classical international organisation, with its own bodies to make decisions and to exercise them.
Its supreme organ is the periodic summits between OSCE member states’ heads of state and government. The summits contribute towards establishing a common political direction for OSCE to follow in future. Summits are held as and when the need arises.
OSCE’s Ministerial Council, comprised of member states’ foreign ministers, is the organisation's central decision-making and governing body. Ministerial Council meetings are held once a year.
During periods between meetings of the Ministerial Council and Summits, the OSCE’s decision-making and negotiating competences lie with the Permanent Council in Vienna. This is comprised of ambassadors from OSCE member states, who meet on a weekly basis to discuss actualities.
In addition to the decision-making bodies, OSCE also has a number of administrative institutions These include the Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (ODIHR) in Warsaw, the High Commissioner on National Minorities (HCNM) in the Hague and the Representative on Freedom of the Media in Vienna.
ODIHR’s task is to support member states through democratisation processes and to promote respect for human rights, including by assisting in and monitoring elections in member states.
HCNM’s task is to react to and report on ethnic tensions and minority population issues in member states before they develop further. If a member state is unable to live up to its international obligations, the High Commissioner will assist by providing analyses, recommendations and guidelines.
The work of the Representative on Freedom of the Media can be divided into two areas:
1) Observation of media developments in member states and
2) Reporting on areas where there is room for criticism.
One of the representative’s tasks is to assist states in their fulfilment of obligations with regard to freedom of speech and freedom of the media.
Finally, there is a Parliamentary Assembly, comprised of MPs from OSCE member states, which meets twice annually. The assembly functions as a forum for parliamentary diplomacy and debate, leading election observation missions and as a stakeholder towards increasing international cooperations to maintain political, security, economic, environmental and human rights obligations. The secretariat of the Parliamentary Assembly is in Copenhagen.

MISSIONS
The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe works towards stability, peace and democracy through political dialogue about common values and “on the ground” work in member states. Field missions include observing elections, advice, rebuilding, observer/ recording missions in wartime and crisis management.
OSCE work areas can be divided into three dimensions: 1)political/military, 2)environmental/economic and 3)humanitarian.
For the political/military dimension the OSCE works in areas such as ensuring increased openness and transparency among its member states. This includes areas such as arms control and de-escalation, reforms to the various member states’ security sectors, the prevention of conflict, as well as crisis management, police training, defeating terrorism and border controls.
With regard to the environmental/economic dimension, OSCE supports member states in good government and the maintenance of basic principles of law and order, increased focus on the environment, stamping out corruption and the management of hazardous waste. OSCE also facilitates increased economic collaborations, safe energy and sustainable development.
Finally, for the humanitarian dimension, all members agree that sustainable European security cannot be achieved without respect for human rights and the function of democratic institutions. OSCE therefore assists member states in areas such as strengthening their democratic institutions, conducting elections that are legitimate, transparent and democratic, and the promotion of equality, freedom of the media, property rights, the rights of minorities and law and order.

IN THE FIELD
OSCE missions are highly diverse, depending on the situation in the country where they are deployed. As a general rule, any deployment must be based on a UN mandate. In areas where there is a risk of violent clashes, missions involve: the prevention of actual hostilities, the prevention of conflict, the documentation of actual acts of war and breaches to agreements, as well as the negotiation of peaceful solutions. One example of this is when OSCE appointed a Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) with regard to the Ukraine conflict. Its task was to observe and report on the situation and to promote dialogue between the opposing sides. Denmark has provided about 20 observers to OSCE SMM. Another example was the mission to Moldova, where OSCE is leading negotiations towards a peaceful resolution between Moldova and the separatist Transnistria region.
Many OSCE missions also provide assistance in rebuilding countries after conflicts. These assignments involve assuring peaceful, stable development through measures to promote democracy and support for free and legitimate elections. Examples of how this is achieved include: advice, expert support and partnership projects with the host countries themselves. Kosovo and Bosnia-Herzegovina were examples of such missions, where Danish police officers have participated on multiple occasions to support rebuilding and other assistance. The Danish Police have assisted in the introduction of democracy to Albania and Montenegro, supported the rebuilding of East Slavonia in Croatia and trained local police officers in Macedonia. Danish Defence and the Danish Police have also deployed observers to the Ukraine.
OSCE has occasionally organised multi-national peacekeeping operations, mandated by the UN Security Council. One example of this was Operation ALBA in Albania in 1997, which was deployed to bring peace to the country after unrest that was the result of economic collapse. Danish Defence took part in this operation.

BACKGROUND
In 1951 Belgium, France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands formed the European Coal and Steel Community, followed in 1957 by their formation of the European Economic Community. At its heart lay a desire for partnership and economic integration between its member states, intended to serve as the basis for a stable, wealthy and peaceful Europe. Two terrible wars in Europe had been a lesson. Together with the European Atomic Energy Community of 1957, the three organisations merged in 1967 as a supra-national organisation called the European Community (EC), which aimed for increased economic, political and legal integration in Europe. The first expansion of the European Community was in 1973, when Denmark, the Republic of Ireland and the United Kingdom joined.
In the 1993 Maastricht Treaty, 13 EC members formed the European Union (EU), in which the EC was the first of three political “pillars”. The two other “pillars” were a Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP)
and a partnership on policing and criminal law.
The goal of the EU is to promote peace and democratic liberal values, as well as the welfare of its populations. The Maastricht Treaty included the creation of a joint economic and monetary union, the purpose of which was to secure the inner market among its member states.
The formation of the EU was thus the first time that foreign affairs and security policies became part of the process of European integration, despite the fact that it had already been a subtext of the original ideas, in which partnership, mutual trade and integration were to help to prevent wars and other hostilities. Because Denmark had opted out of the defence provisions of the Maastricht Treaty, it does not take part in decisions or actions that impact EU defence and security policy. Furthermore, Denmark no longer takes part in military missions, but has been a strong contributor to EU civilian missions. The Danish EU opt-outs therefore have no impact on Denmark’s competence or willingness to participate in EU civilian and police missions. Denmark has thus prioritised its alliance with NATO as its main guarantor of defence and security.

INITIATIVES
The development of an independent security policy was not relevant during the Cold War, during which the NATO alliance was the most important organism with regard to EU member states’ security policies. When the EU was formed in 1993, several of its members wanted to develop an independent security policy, with a view to minimising the EU’s dependence on the USA and strengthening Europe. With the 1997 Amsterdam Treaty, the EU took a further step towards an actual external security policy that would include humanitarian and rescue duties, peacekeeping missions, military resources in crisis management and peaceenforcing.
As stipulated in the Amsterdam Treaty, the European Security and Defence Policy (ESFP) was launched in 1999 and was intended to serve as the framework for the development of capacities to permit the independent management of security-related objectives. The development of a European Rapid Reaction Force was part of this policy. It was in accordance with ESFP that EU Battlegroups were created, comprised of 18 multi-national battalions, each comprised of 1,500-2,000 soldiers. These units report to the Council of the EU and must be able to deploy within 5-10 days after a unanimous decision of the Council. All EU states except Denmark and Malta contribute to EU Battlegroups. A number of non-EU states also take part, including two NATO states (Norway and Turkey) and the Ukraine, Macedonia and Serbia. Although these units have been organised since 2007 they have never been deployed at full strength because of a lack of political decision-making and finance. The most recent developments in the EU have led to a number of questions being asked about the operation and composition of these units.
One area that in particular has led to tensions about the EU’s military capacities has been the relationship with NATO and how dependent on the NATO alliance ESFP should be. The nations only have one set of reserves at their disposal and very few countries have earmarked units for deployment to a specific organisation. EU crisis management initiatives are often also impaired by the requirement for there to be agreement in the EU Council, where member states’ foreign affairs and security policies have not always been led by a common viewpoint and interest in the desire for a joint course. Furthermore, the military operations are financed by and receive contributions from the individual member states on an individual basis. This means that missions are relatively small-scale, which has led to the EU’s international initiatives often being characterised as lacking in ambition.
Since its beginnings, ESFP has therefore moved away from grand visions of a joint EU defence and more towards civilian crisis management initiatives. This includes initiatives to build capacity through missions that are more civilian in nature, focusing on areas such as policing, public administration, observation, the rule of law and the protection of civilians in conflict zones.
In 2000 the Committee for Civilian Aspects of Crisis Management was appointed as an advisory body to relevant ESFP organs about civilian dimensions, including the planning of new missions and the development of strategies for civilian crisis management and civilian capacities.
One important step towards an independent civilian dimension was the creation in 2007 of the Civilian Planning and Conduct Capability (CPCC), CPCC is the operational headquarters for EU civilian missions, for which it performs planning and and operational support. The CPCC’s director is the commander in chief for all missions concerning civilian crisis management and is thus responsible for the strategic planning of EU civilian missions.
In 2009 the EU’s pillared structure from 1993 was replaced as part of a major structural reform that was based on the Lisbon Treaty. Amongst other things, the treaty created the post of High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, whose task is to coordinate a common approach for the EU on these issues. ESFP changed its name at this point to the Common Security and Defence Policy and was expanded in various areas, including collaboration on defence.

DEFENCE PARTNERSHIPS
In the 2009 Lisbon Treaty the EU adopted a number of initiatives towards increased defence integrations, including a Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) which was launched in 2017. PESCO’s membership is comprised of all EU members except Denmark (the defence opt-out) and Malta (neutrality clause). PESCO’s purpose is to increase defence partnerships among its member states, allowing them to develop capacities to be able to participate in EU military operations. PESCO facilitates increased coordination and collaborations on issues such as investments, the acquisition of materials, the development of capacity and operational readiness. PESCO is unique when compared to other EU defence initiatives, as decisions adopted within the PESCO cooperation are binding on its member states. Projects so far include areas such as: The development of a European Medical Command (EMC), military mobility, cyber capacity and increased interoperability and standardisation among the over 178 weapons systems used by the member states.

RELATIONSHIP WITH NATO
The EU and NATO have many members in common and are thus frequent partners. The security relationship between NATO and the EU is described in the Berlin Plus agreement. This allows the EU to draw on a number of NATO assets and structures and stipulates increased operational partnerships between the two organisations. The agreement also permits the EU to act autonomously from NATO in scenarios in which NATO has declined to intervene. Approval of the use of assets by the EU must be unanimously approved by NATO states. The EU is therefore complimentary to NATO, rather than actually replacing it. NATO will thus continue to be the most important security organisation in Europe.
The EU has performed two missions with NATO: Macedonia in 2003 and Bosnia-Herzegovina in 2004.

MISSIONS
The decision to establish missions and operations outside the EU’s borders is part of a broader strategic initiative to bring security and stability to a number of countries in the Middle East, Africa, Eastern Europe and the Caucasus, and to assure maritime security on important routes. Reacting to external conflicts and crises is intended to improve partner states’ capacity to manage their own security, which will ultimately also protect the EU and its citizens.
Between 2003 and 2017 the EU has initiated 33 operations and mission on three different continents. Of these, 22 were civilian missions. 11 were military. The deployment in Darfur was a combined civilian-military operation. Of the 33 missions, 16 of them are ongoing ESFP operations, of which 10 are civilian and 6 military. The EU has therefore carried out (and continues to do so): police missions in countries such as: Bosnia-Herzegovina, Congo, Palestine and Afghanistan; military operations including in. Macedonia, Bosnia, Chad and Somalia; rule of law missions including in Georgia and Iraq; observer missions in border zones at the Gaza Strip and between the Ukraine and Moldova; observer missions during the ceasefire in Georgia; missions where the EU assumes public administration responsibilities in non.member states, here including the Congo; and finally missions to reform the security sector in non-member states in Guinea-Bissau, Congo and Palestine. In addition the Union take part in many humanitarian operations.

FORMATION
NATO was created in the years that followed the Second World War, during which the ideological future of a war-torn Europe was in doubt. Fascism had been defeated. The victors that were still standing were Soviet Communism and liberal democracy in the West. Communism was strong in several European states, including Italy, Greece and France. The isolationist course that was being followed by the Soviet Union and its undemocratic control over its neighbours led to Winston Churchill’s famous “an iron curtain has descended across the Continent” speech at Fulton in 1946. When the pro-democracy government in Czechoslovakia was toppled by a Soviet-backed coup in 1948, US president Harry S. Truman launched a number of measures towards an increased American presence in and in support of Europe. One result of this was the Marshall Plan; an economic aid programme that was offered to all countries in Europe that had been ravaged by war. The Soviet Union refused the Marshall Plan,however, and prevented its satellite states from receiving aid from it. The defensive North Atlantic Treaty Organisation was formed the following year (1949), with Denmark as one of its founder members.
NATO’s original purpose was not worded quite so explicitly, but its purpose was to minimise Communist influence in Europe and to deter any potential Soviet attack. In a popular remark, NATO's first secretary general, Lord Ismay, said that the purpose of the alliance was “to keep the Russians out, the Americans in and the Germans down”.
When West Germany joined the alliance in 1955 the Soviet Union and its satellites formed the Warsaw Pact to counterbalance to the NATO alliance. The balance of power between NATO and the Warsaw Pact turned out to be highly stable and led to a tense, but long-lasting period of peace in Europe, known as the Cold War. The ideological conflict between the Soviet Union and USA was fought elsewhere, in “proxy” wars: Korea, Vietnam and Afghanistan.

STRUCTURE
The NATO alliance is based on the idea of collective responsibility. An attack on one member state is an attack on all member states. This is also known as the “musketeer” oath and is firmly established by Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty,. Article 5 only applies, however, to members’ territories north of the Tropic of Cancer. This means that Hawaii and the Falkland Islands are not covered by Article 5. Another bearing characteristic of NATO is its ideological foundation, which is based on liberal, democratic values rather than any common territorial interests.
NATO is divided into a civilian and a military structure to which each member state provides national representation and delegations.
The North Atlantic Council is the most important body in NATO. This is the supreme political organ and is where member states’ representatives reach consensus about any political decisions that need to be taken. The chairman of the North Atlantic Council is NATO’s Secretary General (who is elected by the member states). The chairman’s role is to serve as the visible face of the alliance, and to lead and coordinate NATO's international workforce and committees, with the exception of NATO’s Military Committee.
A number of civilian committees operate under the auspices of the North Atlantic Council. One of these is the Civil Emergency Planning Committee (CEPC), which is the top NATO advisory body for the protection of civilian populations and critical infrastructures like transport, public health and communications. The Danish Emergency Management Agency is a member of this committee. Another important committee is NATO's Conference of National Armaments Directors (CNAD), which is tasked with promoting cooperation among member states on armaments. CNAD is therefore in charge of bringing about increased interoperability across the alliance. NATO also has a large number of committees whose role is to be the “glue” of the alliance: politically, civilian and military.
NATO’s Military Committee is comprised of the various countries’ defence chiefs and their representatives. Its main task is to advise the North Atlantic Council on issues to do with military policy and strategic issues. The two strategic commands; Supreme Allied Commander Europe (SACEUR), with headquarters in Belgium and Allied Commander Transformation (ACT) in the USA both report directly to NATO's Military Committee.
Despite its name, SECEUR is responsible for the overall command of all NATO operations globally. Unlike the position of Secretary General, SECEUR is traditionally always an American. ACT was created in 2002 and is responsible for the alliance’s military developments in the 21st Century. ACT is therefore in charge of the continued transformation of NATO forces and capacities towards greater efficiency in organisation, with better planning and an increased state of readiness. This is important because there are no fully applicable standardised guidelines among the member states. NATO itself has only very few military capacities, functioning rather as a command structure that facilitates interoperability between the many different national militaries that comprise the alliance.
Another important body is NATO’s Parliamentary Assembly, an institution autonomous from NATO in which representatives from parliaments of member states and partnership countries meet to discuss NATO-related issues. The assembly is therefore an important component to strengthen the internal cohesion of the alliance and its democratic links externally.

POST 1990
When the Warsaw Pact was dissolved and the Cold War ended at the beginning of the 1990s there was a large degree of uncertainty about the alliance's continued existence. With no enemy in the East, the big question was “A defensive alliance against what? And which missions?”
The Partnership for Peace (PfP) programme was therefore created in 1994 to create confidence and cooperations between NATO and European non-member states. NATO uses partnership programmes to strengthen its relationship with non-members through policy-based and practical military cooperations such as training exercises, catastrophe planning and reactions and environmental partnerships etc.
In 1996 US president Bill Clinton established that NATO would form the basis for a common European architecture on security that would be able to produce a peaceful, united, democratic continent. This meant the reawakening of NATO’s “Open Door” policy, whereby a unanimous NATO can invite aspiring nations to become part of the alliance.
Since then the alliance has expanded eastwards over four instalments, integrating 13 former members of the Warsaw Pact and the former Yugoslavia, the most recent of these being Montenegro in 2017.
The NATO-Russia Council was created at the NATO summit in Rome 2002, its purpose being that of an official diplomatic forum in which questions about security and joint projects can be discussed. Its goal is to serve as a forum for consultation and joint decision making, as well as to increase collaborations in a number of areas. This has resulted in several areas in which the two parties have collaborated, including joint initiatives to combat terrorism, military exercises, as well as partnerships in Afghanistan etc. Despite the early success of the Russia Council, mutual disagreements and a worsening relationship between Russia and NATO has caused problems and made partnerships impossible in recent years.
Because of the extensive cross-membership between the EU and NATO and their shared values, the two organisations work closely together in a number of areas. At NATO’s 2016 summit the two organisations agreed to increase collaborations with regard to challenges faced by both, such as hybrid threats, increased robustness, building capacity, cyber defence, maritime security and improved military and civilian infrastructure mobilisations during crises.

OUT OF AREA
NATO’s main area of focus during the Cold War was to secure its borders against armed attack, notably from the Soviet Union. It became clear during the wars in the former Yugoslavia that instability outside NATO’s immediate area also impacted stability within the alliance. In an increasingly gobalised world, crises and nations inside and outside Europe can have an impact on the security of the NATO alliance. These include: terrorism, the spreading of ballistic and nuclear capacity, rising extremism in member states, human trafficking and the smuggling of arms and narcotics, trade route disruption, cyber attacks and climate-related challenges. All these issues can be destabilising, both globally and within the alliance.
This realisation led to the alliance initiating “out-of-area” operations for the first time, initially in Bosnia and later in Kosovo. After the attack by terrorists on New York in September 2001, NATO announced that this was an Article 5 attack on an ally, and invoked military contributions from member states to the war against terror in Afghanistan and the deployment of NATO surveillance aircraft in the USA. This was the first time NATO had carried out operations outside Europe.
In addition to its operations in Afghanistan, the alliance has also taken part in a broad range of missions in the form of: emergency aid operations, combating piracy, enforcing no-fly zones and naval blockades, all at global level.

THE PRESENT DAY
The NATO alliance covers a large territory. The various member states have differing agendas with regard to security considerations. This means that the alliance operates within a large number of areas, such as combating terrorism and a general reinforcement of alliance capabilities. As new members join the alliance and it takes on increasing numbers of missions it has had to modernise itself and its structures so as to perform its new tasks in a quick and efficient manner. This has led to changes to NATO’s organisation towards an increasingly streamlined and efficient command structure that is able to quickly deploy the forces required. The alliance is also working to improve its capacity against unconventional forms of aggression, such as cyber attacks, information warfare and attacks on critical infrastructures and energy supplies.
The relationship between Russia and NATO has deteriorated so badly since the 2013 annexation of the Crimea by Russia that the NATO-Russia Council collaboration has broken down completely. Although the risk of a conventional attack on the alliance remains low, a number of initiatives have been launched in order to increase alliance cohesion and its willingness and readiness to react in the event of an act of aggression against a member state. These include NATO’s Enhanced Forward Presence, which involves four multi-national battalions, each 1,000 strong. These battalions are stationed in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland. Here, Denmark since 2018 provided personnel (up to apr. 200) to the multi-national force.

text.text:
DESCRIPTION
The island of Cyprus lies at the meeting point of three continents (Europe, Africa and Asia). Through history, it has in turn been dominated by: Ancient Rome, the Byzantines, the Crusaders, the Ottomans, Britain and others, and by an ongoing dispute between Greek and Turkish Cypriots that has been ongoing for many years. Before and after the formation of the Republic of Cyprus, the island has been characterised by tensions between the two population factions and notions of a union with Greece. The ongoing conflict led to the creation of UNFICYP in 1963, invasion by Turkey in 1974, the deployment of Danish UN forces between 1964-1992 and Danish police between 1964-1975. In the next four chapters you can read all about these events, the history that preceded them and events on the island. Each chapter covers its own period.

A DIFFICULT START
Following hundreds of years of ethnic tensions in Cyprus, a minor civil war broke out on 21 December 1963 between Greek and Turkish Cypriots. The conflict was rooted in fundamental disagreements as to the implementation of the constitution of newly independent Cyprus. These disagreements included the diametrically opposed national aspirations of the two groups.
Fighting broke out in the Turkish region of the capital Nicosia, which quickly developed into an attempt by Greek Cypriots to force submission by the pro-Turkey section of the population. The conflict spread to other parts of the island and even after just a few days approximately 100 Turkish Cypriots and 80 Greek Cypriots had been killed and numerous civilians had been taken prisoner. Since independence in 1960 both sides had been stockpiling arms and organising rebel groups.
The situation in Cyprus was dire. Britain, the island’s former colonial overlord, then convened an emergency meeting between Greece, Turkey and the government of Cyprus. When Cyprus declared independence, the United Kingdom, Greece and Turkey had obligated themselves to intervene if Cyprus was to attempt the formation of a union with another country. This meant the stationing of smaller Turkish and Greek contingents on the island, Britain retaining sovereignty over the two military bases.
The United Kingdom invited Turkey and Greece to establish a joint peacekeeping mission. This proposal was fruitless, as the Greek and Turkish contingents on the island directly supported the respective sides in the fighting, which meant that the United Kingdom was the sole contributor to the peacekeeping mission.
It was then decided that a neutral zone would be established in Nicosia when the Greek-Cypriot and Turkish-Cypriot units were withdrawn to a ceasefire line that had been determined. This became known as “the Green Line” after the ceasefire line that had been actually drawn in green pencil on a map of Cyprus. British troops would also be posted along the length of this line to keep the two populations apart.
The two groups were still very keen to continue fighting, however. A political solution was vital. This arrived on 4 March 1964, in the form of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP).

Mandate
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 186 on 4 March 1964, in which the government of Cyprus was encouraged to use all necessary means to bring the extensive bloodshed to an end. It also required both sides to show restraint. The Security Council in the resolution called for a UN-administered peacekeeping mission (with consent from the government of Cyprus). The composition and size of the mission was to be decided by the UN Secretary-General in consultation with the governments of Cyprus, Greece, Turkey and the United Kingdom.
The peacekeeping mission had a fragile mandate to prevent further fighting and, if necessary, to contribute to the restoration of law and order on Cyprus. The mission could use armed force only in self defence.

Decision
On 30 April 1964, a unanimous Danish Parliament approved the formation of a permanent Danish UN emergency force that could be deployed upon request from the UN and upon an assessment of the overall situation. With this approval, the Danish government was authorised to deploy Danish troops to UN peacekeeping missions. In practice, this was after discussion in the Danish Foreign Affairs Committee, followed up by ministerial authorisation of the requested funding. The Danish Parliamentary decision does not specifically mention the deployment of a police unit, but the decision in that regard should be considered as a natural consequence of the wording of the UN mandate and the Secretary-General’s decision of 12 April.
Shortly thereafter and upon consultation with the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government decided to send a Danish contingent to the UN peacekeeping mission in Cyprus.

Contribution
DANCON, the Danish contingent, was deployed to “the Green Line” in Nicosia from 1964-1970. The contingent initially numbered about 1,000 personnel. Their mission was to prevent the two sides from further fighting. DANCON and the other UN contingents played an important role in preventing fighting from breaking out once more.
In 1968 UNFICYP was able to create a political willingness on both sides to begin negotiations. As a result, UNFICYP could be significantly downscaled and DANCON’s deployment was reduced to about 300 personnel. The contributions from the various countries were reorganised at this time, with DANCON assuming responsibility for the mountainous Lefka District on the north-western region of the island. This area was made up of several larger Turkish enclaves and smaller Turkish villages.
DANCON was now based at camps Kokkina, Liminitis, Skouriotissa and Xeros. The Danish military and civilian police also had a base in Dansborg near Xeros.
The UN Secretary-General decided on 12 April 1964 to establish a UN police force on Cyprus (UN-CIVPOL). Its role would be to assist Cypriot authorities with many police-related tasks that were the result of the civil war, including murder, hostage-taking and missing persons. Initially, Denmark contributed DANCIVPOL, a police contingent of 40.

Mission
DANCON’s mission was to observe both sides’ military forces, as mutual distrust was leading both to maintain a status of high alert. The mission was performed by manning a number of observation posts and by intensive patrolling. During the period, Danish troops were able to keep both sides apart with no notable episodes.
DANCON also arranged communication between the Greek and Turkish Cypriots. Many civilian-type duties were performed, such as fixing water and electricity problems, allowing farmers to work in their own fields even though they were in the zone controlled by the other side and safeguarding Turkish Cypriots as they returned to the abandoned villages.

Duration
The many violent clashes between 1964 and 1968 were largely due to the return to the island of the former leader of the Greek Cypriot EOKA rebels (General Grivas). He was given command of the Greek Cypriot National Guard that had recently been set up by the government. Greece had also stationed troops on the island, with a combined strength of about two divisions.
The situation between the two populations was so tense that there were periods in which open war was imminent between Turkey and Greece. These included the August 1965 Kokkina blockade, during which Turkish aircraft dropped bombs on Greek Cypriot positions and villages. The other side then carried out the Famagusta incident, in which Greek Cypriots launched and offensive on the Turkish Cypriot area of the town of Famagusta, which led to intense fighting. Both episodes led to numerous fatalities and injured.
The crisis peaked when General Grivas and his National Guard attacked two Turkish Cypriot villages in 1967. This episode led to direct negotiations between Turkey and Greece, with Turkey restraining an invasion of the island and Greece reducing its forces on Cyprus from 10,000 to 950 personnel. General Grivas was also recalled to Greece, which brought new hope that that situation would de-escalate.
Finally, the UN-led negotiations between the two conflicted parties began to make some progress. It became clear, however, that a political solution to the conflict would not be able to result in enosis (unification with Greece). This caused Greek Cypriot supporters of enosis to start attacking the more moderate wing of their own side. The moderates were led by the sitting Greek Cypriot leader, Makarios, who supported cooperation with the Turkish Cypriot population. The situation led to a scenario that began to resemble civil war, heightened by the attempted assassination of Makarios by Greek Cypriots in 1970 and the return of General Grivas to the island in 1971.
These events thus signposted the start of the second phase of the conflict.

INVASION
At the beginning of 1970 there had yet to be any notable developments in the negotiations between the Greek and Turkish elements of the population of Cyprus. The negotiating situation had been static since the 1964 crisis and the best result that UNFICYP had been able to achieve had been to prevent the worst of the open fighting between the two sides.
In the Greek Cypriot surprise landslide victory of 1970, the Communist party won 37% of the vote. This caused the island’s president, Makarios, to take advantage of the Soviet Union’s increased interest in Cyprus. Upon his return from a state visit to Moscow in 1971, it was announced that he was willing to accept aid from the Soviet Union if other countries were to interfere in the internal affairs of Cyprus. This development was of concern to both Greece and Turkey.
Political developments on Cyprus caused the Junta in Athens to send former Greek Cypriot rebel leader General Grivas back to the island to build a resistance movement (EOKA B) to try to topple Makarios from power. Grivas, as a dedicated supporter of enosis, had a different point of view to the Junta in Athens, who only wanted to see Makarios removed from power. This difference of opinion would soon be unimportant, however, when nationalist Dimitrios Ioannidis took power in Athens in 1973 after a military coup.
This period was characterised by several bombings, attempted assassinations and political killings carried out by EOKA B and supporters of Makarios, both movements belonging to the Greek Cypriot majority. Internal unrest among the Greek Cypriots led to the ongoing negotiations being delayed and led to a general sense of unease among Turkish Cypriots.
On 15 July 1974, with support from Greece, a carefully planned coup d’état was executed against Makarios and the sitting government by EOKA and members of the Greek Cypriot National Guard. Turkey considered this coup to be an attempted annexation by the expansionist Junta in Athens. On 20 July 1974 Turkey launched an invasion of Northern Cyprus, which it claimed had a legal basis in the 1959 Treaty of Guarantee.
The Greek Cypriot National Guard immediately mobilised an army of up to 40,000 men and fighting broke out in the many enclaves on both sides of the Green Line. The peacekeeping UN forces were caught in the middle, with no mandate to do anything about the military events going on around them.

Mandate
The mandate continued as an extension of Security Council Resolution 186 of 4 March 1964, which encouraged the government of Cyprus to use all means necessary to stop the bloodshed and requiring the parties to show restraint. The Security Council, with the consent of the government of Cyprus, encouraged the creation of a UN peacekeeping mission. The composition and size of the mission was to be decided by the UN Secretary-General in consultation with the governments of Cyprus, Greece, Turkey and the United Kingdom.
The peacekeeping mission had a fragile mandate to prevent further fighting and, if necessary, to contribute to the restoration of law and order on Cyprus. The mission was therefore only mandated to use force as a means of self-defence.
When Turkey invaded Cyprus in 1974 the UN Security Council issued the follow-up Resolution 353, demanding the withdrawal of all foreign military forces from Cyprus and the commencement of peace negotiations by Greece, Turkey and the United Kingdom. The Turkish invasion led to several other resolutions that condemned the unilateral invasion of Cyprus and expressed concern about the fate of the many refugees.

Contribution
In DANCON’s sector, the day of the invasion was spent making preparations for the eventuality that fighting would reach the Danish area of responsibility. During the evening of 20 July, the Greek Cypriots fired artillery and mortar rounds at the Turkish Cypriot enclaves of Lefka, Limnitis and Kokkina. The enclaves received air support from Turkish aircraft carrying napalm canisters and machine cannon. Much of the incoming fire landed in the DANCON camps, but the preparations that had been made provided effective protection.
The day after the invasion the UN withdrew from its observation posts, which was extremely difficult and there were casualties.
The Turkish Cypriot enclave of Lefka had to submit to Greek Cypriot pressure but the two sides were successfully brought to the negotiating table. The Greek Cypriot National Guard then took control of Lefka under DANCON’s supervision. DANCON was later able to obtain similar written agreements between three smaller Turkish Cypriot towns and the National Guard.
DANCON also provided medical aid to over 100 injured and wounded civilians and military personnel, from both sides. That the fighting did not develop into wholesale attack and mass-murder is largely attributable to DANCON’s management of the situation.
As Cyprus found itself in a new situation, the UNIFICYP force was upscaled from approx. 2,300 personnel to 4,400. The same applied to the Danish contingent, which was increased from 220 personnel to 430 over just a few days.
The Danish DANCIVPOL civilian police contingent was wound down in 1975 after a decade of service on Cyprus. This was the first ever police peacekeeping mission. Danish police provided about 500 personnel.

Mission
The situation was now significantly different after the ceasefire of 16 August 1974. In particular, the Danish camps in Kokkina, Limnitis, Lefka, and Xeros were now in an area controlled by Turkey.
In addition to the mandate from 1964 that was still applicable, the UN Secretary-General had also directed UNIFICYP to: 1) monitor troop deployments by both sides, 2) maintain the status quo in the demilitarised zone, 3) monitor the ceasefire, 4) facilitate activities across the ceasefire boundary, 5) provide humanitarian aid all over the island and 6) cooperation with Turkish Cypriot and Greek Cypriot police, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and the UN Development Programme (UNDP).
A Danish UN Volkswagen bus drove over an anti-tank mine as the observation posts were being remanned after the ceasefire, leading to the deaths of two Danish UN soldiers and another two being wounded.

Duration
The political objective of Turkey’s invasion was to prevent enosis and, after subsequent negotiations, to implement a federal solution on the island. Its military objective was to conquer Kyrenia and Nicosia airport. UNFICYP took over responsibility for the airport, however, effectively ending the fighting for this objective.
The men who came to power through the Greek Cypriot coup stepped down on 23 July 1974 after pressure from their backers. Makarios, who was now exiled in England, was returned to the office of president. Simultaneous to all these events, the Greek Junta of army officers also collapsed, partly because of what had been happening on Cyprus. It was replaced by a democratic government in Athens. Negotiations towards a ceasefire were able to begin between 25-30 July in Geneva.
The ceasefire was short-lived, however, being marred by the gradual expansion by Turkish invading forces of their western bridgehead, while also taking on reinforcements. During the peace negotiations, Turkey presented an ultimatum that involved a cantonal (or local) federation. This was a solution that Greece and the Greek Cypriots were unable to accept.
Turkey therefore continued its invasion on 14 August, Turkish forces successfully conquering and controlling about 40% of the island after just three days. Turkey now assumed control of many of the enclaves that had been controlled by the National Guard, including Lefka and Limnitis where DANCON was based.
The invasion sent nearly 160,000 Greek Cypriots fleeing toward the southern part of Cyprus. Many of them had been forcibly evicted by the invading Turkish forces.
With Turkey’s military gains, the parties entered into a new ceasefire on 16 August 1974. The demilitarised UNFICYP Green Line zone was expanded - the so-called status quo. The Green Line is still a de facto border between Northern and Southern Cyprus.
Fighting cost the lives of 9 UN personnel, with another 65 injured. Many war crimes and crimes against humanity were committed by both sides. Thousands of civilians were killed and mistreated during the invasion.

STABILISATION
The demographic composition of the population of Cyprus was rather different after the Turkish invasion in 1974. The many Greek Cypriots who had previously lived in the northern half of the island had fled southwards. Soon after the ceasefire and agreement was made to relocate Turkish Cypriots who still remained in the South to the North if they so desired.
Turkish Cypriots had therefore achieved their desired “taksim” - a formal division of the island, with Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots on their own side of the UNFICYP-controlled Green Line. Northern Cyprus then declared independence as the Turkish Federated State of Cyprus. Turkey immediately began to colonise the area, with an estimated 120,000 Turks being relocated to the island from mainland Turkey. This was a clear breach of the Geneva Convention. Turkey also stationed 30,000 soldiers on the island, in breach of the London-Zurich agreement and supplementary treaties as concluded in 1960 by Turkey, Greece, the United Kingdom and political leaders of both the Greek and Turkish Cypriot factions.
Turkey had justified its invasion of Cyprus using the Treaty of Guarantee, which forbade Cyprus from forming a union with other states and that compelled Greece, Turkey and the United Kingdom to intervene to reassert the 1960 constitution of Cyprus if such a union was formed. After the 1974 military coup on Cyprus, Turkey used the Treaty of Guarantee as a basis for intervention. Its continuation of the invasion and de facto division of the island was a unilateral violation of the Treaty of Guarantee, however. This was also the general consensus view in the international community, which condemned Turkey’s annexation of Northern Cyprus. To this day, the UN and the international community only recognise the Republic of Cyprus as the rightful sovereign state for the entire island.

Mandate
The mandate continued as an extension of Resolution 186 of 4 March 1964, which encouraged the government of Cyprus to use all means necessary to stop the bloodshed and requiring the parties to show restraint. In this resolution the Security Council called for a UN-administered peacekeeping mission (with consent from the government of Cyprus). The composition and size of the mission was to be decided by the UN Secretary-General in consultation with the governments of Cyprus, Greece, Turkey and the United Kingdom.
UNFICYP was also tasked with monitoring the recent ceasefire between the two parties and assisting in the maintenance of a status quo.

Contribution
Since 1975, the number of shooting incidents and advances between Turkish and Greek Cypriots has significantly decreased. UNFICYP and DANCON were therefore massively downscaled in 1976. DANCON’s area of responsibility was also moved west when Finland pulled out of the mission in 1977. In addition to DANCON's area of responsibiity in Lefka District and its bases in Kokkina, Limnitis, Skouriotissa and Xerox, DANCON would also have a periodic presence in parts of Kyrenia District and Paphos District after the Finns had left.
The status quo was now maintained by surveillance and patrolling of the demilitarised buffer zone.
In 1992, Denmark decided to recall its contribution to UNFICYP in light of an assessment that recent conflicts in the former Yugoslavia were of higher priority.
In total, about 23,000 Danish soldiers have served in 57 teams in Cyprus from 1964 to 1992. From 1990 to 1992, the Chief of Staff position was held by a Danish brigadier general. A Danish staff officer worked at UNFICYP from 1993 to 1994, after which the mission was over for Denmark. This makes it Denmark’s largest contribution to a UN mission to date.
The position of UNFICYP Head of Mission, the diplomatic chief of the mission, was held by a Dane from 2006 to 2008.

Mission
The Danish mission was responsible for 17 observation posts in the demilitarised buffer zone, from where both ceasefire lines could be observed. Observation from the observation posts was supplemented with patrols of the Danish area of responsibility. Despite the ongoing conflict, DANCON’s deployment on Cyprus since 1975 was characterised as calm, with no major incidents.

Duration
On 15 November 1984, the northern part of Cyprus declared independence as the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. Turkey approved the declaration of independence the same day. The UN Security Council responded by issuing Resolutions 541 and 550, in which it stated that the declaration was illegal and requested that no other sovereign states recognise the Turkish-Cypriot declaration of independence.
Several unsuccessful attempts have been made by the EU and the UN to resolve the conflict since the Turkish invasion in 1974. Ever since, any solution to the conflict has been stranded politically. There have been changes on the island since 2003, when border crossings between Northern and Southern Cyprus were opened for the first time since 1974.
The UNFICYP mission has therefore not succeeded in resolving the underlying ethnic tensions driving the conflict. That said, the mission was justified as it curbed aggressions between Turkish and Greek Cypriots and was able to maintained the ceasefire. Thus, UNFICYP has created the preconditions for reaching a long term peace accord between the two parties on the island.
The UNFICYP mission is still active.

BEFORE 1964
Since antiquity Cyprus has been a disputed territory that has been occupied by changing régimes. This is largely due to the island’s strategic position as the meeting point of three continents: Europe, Asia and Africa. This is why Cyprus became known as “the island at the crossroads of history”.
Cyprus has been populated by Greeks from the Aegean archipelago since antiquity. In 58 BC Cyprus became part of the Roman Empire, later becoming part of the Byzantine Empire, when Greek Cypriots converted to Orthodox Christianity.
The Byzantine connection was interrupted when Cyprus was occupied by Crusaders in 1192, after which the island was ruled by Roman Catholics. This situation endured until 1571, when it was conquered by the Ottoman Empire. Immediately upon their victory, the Ottomans began their colonisation of Cyprus, sending 20,000 Turks there from Anatolia.
Under Ottoman rule, Greek Cypriots were under greater liberty to practise their Orthodox Christian faith than than had been the case under their previous overlords. Except for a special tax on religious minorities, Christians were treated well under the Ottoman system, provided that they did not rebel. The latter was made explicit during the Greek War of Independence in 1821, when the Greek Orthodox Bishop of Cyprus, other religious figures and many Greek Cypriots were executed, purely on the basis of dubious evidence for a conspiracy with mainland Greece.
In 1878 the Ottoman régime reluctantly allowed the British to administrate Cyprus on a temporary basis after a major conflict with Russia. In return, the British agreed that it would support the Ottomans both diplomatically and militarily against Russia if the need arose.

Greek and Turkish Cypriots generally lived in segregation from each other in their own village. Children attended Greek or Turkish schools and intermarriage was rare. The 19th Century saw the clear development of Hellenic nationalism among Greek Cypriots who felt that they were entitled to rule over the island. The basis for this claim was that Greek Cypriots could trace their roots far back in history, and that they were still a majority population. The British were therefore met with Greek Cypriot demands for enosis, the notion of union between Greece and Cyrus.
Despite a number of initiatives in support of liberalisation and increased Cypriot autonomy, the ambitions of Greek Cypriots were, however, opposed by the United Kingdom which was, at that time, under obligation to return Cyprus to the Ottomans.
When the Ottoman Empire allied with the Central Powers during the First World War, the British decided to annex Cyprus in 1914. The following year, the United Kingdom offered Cyprus to King Constantine the First of Greece, in return for Greek participation in the war. This proposal was rejected, however.
When the Ottoman Empire fell, Turkey and the Entente Powers (which included Britain and Greece) concluded a peace treaty in which Turkey renounced all rights to Cyprus. In 1925 Cyprus became an official Crown colony of the United Kingdom.

Greek Cypriots’ hopes of enosis were renewed after the war. Enosis was taught by Greek teachers in schools and movements that supported union with Greece began to appear, which led to nationalist unrest in 1931.
Turkish Cypriots, who had concluded an informal alliance with the British administration to dampen Greek ambition, viewed this with some concern. The antipathy of pro-Turkey Cypriots to enosis was based on the history of the previous union between Greece and Crete, in which the Turkish minority had been driven out as part of a population exchange between Turkey and Greece in 1923.
Turkish nationalism began to grow during this period, in particular among young Turkish Cypriots who were inspired by the secular Turkey of Atatürk. The growing national identity of the two groups led to increased internal rivalries about the future of Cyprus.
After the Second World War, decolonisation became part of the international agenda. Based on the prospect that Britain would withdraw from Cyprus, Turkey began once again to show an interest in the island that was of such strategic importance. The Cypriot Orthodox Church held an unofficial referendum on enosis in 1950. 96% of Greek Cypriots, who at this point were 80% of the population, voted in favour of union with Greece. The referendum and increasing calls for enosis led to Greece raising the issue of Cyprus’s independence with the UN. This led to Ankara issuing a warning to Britain that any change to the sovereign status of Cyprus that did not take Turkish interests into consideration would force a reaction from Turkey.
After elections on Cyprus, the notion of achieving enosis through violent means began to flourish on a broader basis among Greek Cypriots. In 1954 Cypriot-born Green nationalist army colonel Grivas formed the EOKA resistance group, which trained Greek Cypriots in guerilla warfare. The following year EOKA gained broad support when Archbishop Makarios III of Cyprus permitted the commencement of attacks on British military installations on the island.

Four years of guerilla warfare followed, during which EOKA launched terrorist attacks on colonial authorities, including the Cypriot police. In its fight against EOKA, the British had recruited Turkish Cypriots into the police to such an extent that they now dominated the force in terms of numbers. A counterpart to EOKA was set up in 1958, when Turkish Cypriot Rauf Denktaş founded the paramilitary TMT organisation. This response to the Greek EOKA fought towards “taksim”, a division of Cyprus into regions for pro-Greek and pro-Turkey Cypriots.
The direct fighting between EOKA, TMT and British troops and a pro-Turkey police led to strong levels of hostility and rioting, with the two Cypriot factions fighting not only each other, but also the British colonial powers.
As the rioting and unrest escalated, Britain, Turkey and Greece had been trying to produce a joint solution to the Cyprus problem. Turkish-Greek relations deteriorated further in 1955, when the Greek minority population in Istanbul was subjected to systematic attacks that were apparently the work of Turkish security services.
After several failed attempts to agree upon a solution, both sides had to accept that neither taksim nor enosis would be achievable. A solution was found in the 1959 London-Zurich Agreement between Turkey, Greece, Britain and Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot political leaders (Archbishop Makarios III and Dr. Fazıl Küçük, respectively).
The Agreement included a plan for Cyprus’s independence that focused on the island’s two ethnic groups. Examples were that the office of President would be occupied by a Greek Cypriot, with a Turkish Cypriot Vice President, both of whom would have veto rights. A number of supplementary treaties were later added to the London-Zurich Agreement, including the Treaty of Guarantee, in which Cyprus was forbidden from joining a political or economic union with other states, and which obligated Greece, Turkey and the United Kingdom to intervene if Cyprus broke this commitment. The treaty also allowed Britain to retain two military bases on Cyprus, namely Akrotiri and Dhekalia. The supplementary Treaty of Alliance allowed Greece and Turkey to station two small military contingents on the island.

The Republic of Cyprus was proclaimed on 15 August 1960. Makarios III was made President and Dr Fazıl Küçük was Vice President. The new Cypriot constitution was not well-received by Greek Cypriots, who felt that the division into two ethnic groups, in which pro-Greeks represented 80% of the population was unjust.

Three years after independence, the relationship between Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots in government reached a low point. In 1963 it was apparent that there was a mutual unwillingness to achieve political results, which was considered by each faction as part of a strategy to undermine the existing power structure. To resolve the political stalemate, Makarios tried to implement constitutional reforms, which were considered by Turkish Cypriots as a move towards enosis.
The massive hostility between the two factions was visible in the secret Akritas plan of 1963, which had been formulated by the Greek Cypriot minister of the interior. The plan contained a number of internal and external strategies to reduce the influence of Turkey and Turkish Cypriots in the country. The objective was still enosis and, in the event of protests by pro-Turkey Cypriots, these were to be quickly and effectively suppressed before foreign powers were able to intervene.
There was tumult on 21 December 1963, after a Greek Cypriot police patrol performed a routine check on a Turkish Cypriot couple who were travelling in a taxi. A hostile mob of Turkish Cypriots formed around the police officers, who felt the need to call in reinforcements. Two Turkish Cypriots were killed in the rioting. News of the episode quickly spread across the island and violent fighting broke out between the two communities, often led by the rebel TMT and EOKA groups. In certain areas the fighting turned into a direct massacre of civilian populations, with cultural heritage defaced by both sides. An estimated 360 Turkish Cypriots and 170 Greek Cypriots were killed during the conflict, which lasted a few months.
The actual significance of the Akritas plan in relation to events at the end of 1963 is the subject of debate. Makario’s role in formulating the plan and whether it was ever actually implemented remains uncertain.
The violence of late 1963 resulted in the deployment of the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP), which continues to operate at the time of writing.

DESCRIPTION

Iraq is a country that will be remembered by thousands of Danes for many years to come. Known as Mesopotamia during antiquity and located between the rivers Tigris and Euphrates, it would later become part of the Ottoman Empire and a British area of mandate comprised of three different provinces as decided in 1919. It is a country of tensions; between Sunni and Shia Muslims and Kurds, where oil production is increasing. It gained independence in 1932, surviving the Second World War. It transformed from monarchy to republic and would later be dominated by the Ba’ath Party and Saddam Hussein.
It is an area of unrest and extensive internal conflict and Saddam Hussein’s takeover brought no calm.
