Instead, it brought domestic rebellion, gas attacks against his own population, and a war with Iran that consumed massive resources and cost many human lives. Another disaster was when the life-giving marshland near Basra became arid. Saddam invaded Kuwait in 1990, in an attempt to salvage Iraq’s economy. It led to the First Gulf War and the expulsion of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. This war marked a new stage of Denmark’s military commitment to international initiatives. Royal Danish Navy Corvette Olfert Fischer was deployed to the Gulf and represented a new approach to participating where required, heralding a new era in which Danish forces would be in demand. It is impossible to talk about Iraq without mentioning weapons of mass destruction, UN mandates, UN inspections, the oil for food programme, no-fly zones and emergency aid to groups like the Kurds. Ultimately, the situation evolved into the Second Gulf War, in which Denmark again participated, this time providing a submarine, a corvette and doctors. The Ba’ath Party and Saddam Hussein are no longer around, but there was still no calm in Iraq. An international security force arrived, with Danish troops serving in the Basra Province together with British troops. Unrest evolved into actual civil war, with improvised explosive devices left on roadsides, rocket attacks on the international forces and their camps and the massive challenge of reasserting Iraq‘s control over its own country. The training of Iraq's military and police became an area of focus, towards enabling them to take over security. The last American troops may well have left the country in 2011, but...
Many countries (including Denmark) returned to Iraq as part of the war against ISIL, providing air support to the Kurds as they fought ISIL on the ground, training Iraqi security forces, rebuilding programmes, police missions etc. Danish men and women are still serving in Iraq at the time of writing.
You can read about this in further detail in the following seven chapters. They make interesting reading.

HISTORY

Iraq has a long history. Ancient Mesopotamia between the rivers Tigris and Euphrates was the place where agriculture was invented and where the first written languages appeared. The Sumerians and Babylonians established some of the very earliest civilisations. The area was central to the Persian Empires and a centre of the Medieval Islamic World, Baghdad being the site of the largest libraries in the World. It was not, however, until after the First World War that Iraq was defined as a country, with borders that were determined more on the basis of British and French interests than the circumstances of the local population. Iraq has three large and a number of smaller population groups and is, at the time of writing, a country plagued by unrest after decades of conflict, sanctions and instability.

Between the two world wars: The Ottomans and the Mandates
Iraq was formed as the unification of three provinces which had been part of the Ottoman Empire for centuries. The three provinces were each named after their largest towns: Mosul to the North, Baghdad in the centre and Basra to the South. Kuwait had been linked to Basra, but was given independence with support from Britain in 1913. The First World War broke out the following year and forces from British India were landed near Basra.
At the end of the war, most of Iraq was occupied by British Indian troops. To gain their support during the war, the British had promised the Arabs a united state. They had also promised a colony in Syria to the French, which would include Mosul. In the meantime, the war had led to a realisation of the importance of oil. Mosul had large oil deposits and the British were no longer keen on the idea of giving up the area. After discussions during the Versailles negotiations, an agreement was reached with France that allowed Mosul to remain in British hands for the time being. The USA (President Wilson) pushed for self-government, however. The solution thus became that the Arab areas were not given an official status of colonies, but were instead mandates that were assigned to a superpower until they were deemed ready to govern themselves.
The three provinces became the British mandate for Mesopotamia in 1920. They had already been under British military control for years and the Iraqis were unhappy about being a colony in all but name when they had been promised an Arab state. Discontent turned into rebellion during the summer of 1920 and was beaten down by the British.
The rebellion in Iraq had given the British a nasty shock, however. They therefore brought in Prince Faisal of Mecca, who had helped them during the First World War, with the intention of making him King of Iraq. It was hoped that he would, as a well-known Arab nationalist, be able to satisfy the population. Faisal could not just be place on the throne, however. Iraq was a mandate territory after all, not a colony, so a referendum was held to find out who would be King. Faisal won a massive 90% of votes cast, after one of his two opponents was arrested by British troops and sailed to Sri Lanka and the other was disqualified by the mandate administration because of his age. Faisal was crowned in August 1921 and the mandate was dissolved in 1932. Britain retained a large number of special entitlements and military basis in the country. A British company also had exclusive rights to oil.
It was not an easy state to rule. The three Ottoman provinces that became Iraq had seldom been ruled as a united whole. Neither were the new country’s borders designed on the basis of local conditions, but to suit the interests of the colonial powers. 75% of the population were Arabs. 15%-20% were Kurds and the remaining people were Turkmenian and Assyrian minorities. The majority (about 60%) were Shia Muslims. 35% were Sunni Muslims and there were also smaller groups of Christians and Yazidis. The Kurds in particular wanted to be independent rather than part of an Arab-dominated Iraq. The Shia Muslims had historically been more closely connected to Persia to the East. Faisal was himself of Sunni Arab descent and his natural allies were thus Arabic Sunni Muslims. Half of Iraq’s Sunnis were Kurds, however. With some success, Faisal was able to create a narrative of Iraq as a secular Arab state in an attempt to bring about good relations within the country across the boundaries of religion. This was not well-received by the Kurds and other ethnic minorities.

From Kingdom to Republic - Coup and Counter-Coup
The West did not view the large mixture of ethnicities and religions as a problem. The fact that there was no clear majority meant that compromise was required, that the various factions would have to share power, and this seemed to be going relatively well. Iraq was known as the “model mandate”. Its formal independence in 1932 was the first and only time that a League of Nations mandate would be replaced by a new member of the league. This was in important victory for the independence movement in Iraq, despite the fact that British influence remained pivotal.
Beneath the surface the situation was tense, however. Although Faisal and his supporters referred to themselves as secular, Iraq was dominated by the Sunni Muslim Arabic minority. There was also division with regard to the role of Britain. The history of Iraq that followed was dominated by military coups. The first of these took place in October 1936, but its leader would himself be assassinated the following year. Prior to this, there had already been several uprisings by minorities and desert tribes who did not recognise the government. The next coup took place in 1941 and was led by a fascist group that wanted to end British influence, with support from Nazi Germany. Instead, Iraq was occupied once again by British forces and those responsible for the coup were toppled in favour of a pro-British government.
After the Second World War, and despite its formal independence, Iraq was still a monarchy with a government propped up by the British. A new treaty was signed in January 1948. This reduced British influence but still guaranteed an alliance and a number of rights to the British military. It was met with demonstrations that were based on a conflict that was smouldering between the Jews and Arabs in Palestine, which was still controlled by Britain.
During the 1950s Iraq was the cornerstone of the Baghdad Pact, which was an alliance of states in the Middle East that was sponsored by the USA and Britain as a check against the Soviet Union. With the decolonisation process, the Israel/Palestine conflict and the Suez war in Egypt, Iraq’s close relationship with the West became increasingly tense. States of Emergency were declared several times because of resistance against the royal family, the government and pro-West policy.
Things went wrong in 1958, when Syria and Egypt agreed to form a common Arabic union. This led to a wave of revolution throughout the Arab world. When Jordan was affected by unrest the Iraqi army was ordered south. But when the units that were on their way to the border passed Baghdad on 14 July, two army officers carried out a coup. Roads into the city were closed. The royal family was assassinated and Iraq was declared a republic. There was looting. Supporters of the régime were lynched and the corpse of the former prime minister was dragged through the streets of Baghdad.
The new post-revolution government was a mixed bag of Iraqi and pan-Arabic nationalists, a strong Communist party, Kurd and Shiite stakeholders and a wide variety of ideologies. After four coups in a decade, the Ba’ath party came to power. A young man named Saddam Hussein ended up in charge of internal security and, as vice chairman of the Revolutionary Command Council, the supreme authority in the party and, thus, the country.
Saddam spearheaded the nationalisation of the oil industry just before the 1973 oil crisis led to rocketing oil prices. The huge revenues were used to establish free school attendance and to build new hospitals. Large amounts were invested in the military to turn Iraq into a regional superpower, to ensure loyalty to the new government and as a means of suppressing all opponents. Saddam quickly became a popular decision-maker, even though he did not win the presidency until 1979.

War, Rebellion and Gassing
The ideology of the Ba’ath Party was a united socialist state for all Arabs, regardless of religion. This did not suit the Kurds, but Saddam Hussein’s approach to the issue appeared pragmatic. Anyone could be a member of the party, regardless of ethnicity or religious background, but all Saddam’s opponents were suppressed or put down. Even though Kurds and Shia Muslims were represented in Saddam’s government and in senior echelons of the party, it was still apparent that all the really important positions were occupied by Sunnis. Large elements of the Republican Guard, a large military unit whose role was to prevent military coups, came from Saddam’s home town of Tikrit. Officially, there was room for everyone, but by giving his fellow Sunnis and tribal associates the most important positions and placing them in charge of the suppression of his opponents, Saddam made them an implicit part of state leadership to such a degree that they were bound to the survival of the régime itself.
Saddam Hussein had not been president for long before he threw Iraq into the first of several wars that would become failures. The precise land border between Iran and Iraq had long been the subject of disagreement. The two countries had periodically supported opposition groups in the other, but attempts to resolve problems had largely been conducted at the negotiating table rather than on the battlefield. The 1979 revolution that deposed Iran’s Shah and made Iran an Islamic republic would seriously test the relationship between the two countries.
Iran wanted to export its revolution, most notably to other Shia Muslims and Iraq’s large Shiite population was an obvious target. To Saddam Hussein and his secular régime, Iran under the Ayatollah represented a threat. Although Iran was a larger country and, on paper, had a larger army than Iraq, Saddam exploited the period of instability that followed the revolution. Hoping that Iran's Arab population would rebel an topple the theocratic régime in a fast and effective war, Iraq invaded its neighbour in September 1980.
Iraq won some early victories but would eventually be pushed out of Iran during the eight years of the war, as fighting turned into difficult trench warfare with massive casualties and economic costs to both sides. Iraq was supported by the international community, most obviously Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, who helped finance some of the expenses incurred by the war, but also by the USA, the Soviet Union and the United Kingdom. To break the deadlock on the front line, Iraq used large amounts of chemical weapons on various occasions. These were not used only on Iranian troops, however. When Kurds in Northern Iraq tried to exploit the conflict to strengthen their own self-rule, Saddam’s forces forcibly evicted and murdered thousands of Kurds. The attack on the Kurdish town of Halabja, in which 5,000 Kurdish civilians were killed with mustard gas, became the symbol of Saddam Hussein’s callousness and disregard for his own countrymen.
The war ended in 1988 with the same borders as when it started. Both countries lay in ruins and over a million people had been killed. Oil production in both countries was badly affected and Iraq’s economy in particular had collapsed because of the expense of the war and the lack of oil revenue.

THE FIRST GULF WAR

The war between Iraq and Iran ended with no clear victor. The biggest difference between the time before the war and the time after it was the death toll that exceeded a million, massive destruction in both countries and devastating economic costs, made worse by the loss of eight years of oil revenue. Saddam Hussein came up with a way of fixing Iraq’s financial problems; Kuwait, his tiny neighbour, with all its oil.

What caused the conflict
Purely formally, the reason for Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait went back about a century. Kuwait had been ruled during certain periods as part of the Ottoman province of Basra. In two agreements from 1899 and 1913 Britain had made an alliance with the local sheik, making Kuwait a British protectorate during and after the First World War. The official stance in Iraq was therefore that Kuwait was historically part of Iraq, that it had been stolen by the colonial power and that it should be returned to the Iraqi state. Iraq had previously made official claims to Kuwait in 1937 and 1961, using the same argumentation. It seemed to the pan-Arabic and traditionally anti-imperialist Ba’ath Party that now faced a crisis in Iraq, that a victory over one of the remnants from the grand era of imperialism would be a way to regain some of the support it had lost in the Iraqi population.
In reality, there were also a number of economic reasons underlying Saddam Hussein’s invasion of Kuwait. Iraq was in massive debt after eight years of war with Iran. And as peace returned to the Gulf, oil prices began to fall too. If Saddam was to have the slightest hope of repaying Iraq’s war debts and rebuilding the country’s economy, he needed oil prices to remain high. In OPEC (Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries), Kuwait was one of the opponents of reducing oil production to ensure a return to rising oil prices. During the war they had loaned and granted large amounts of money to Iraq as they also feared the Iranian theocracy and now wanted to earn the money back by selling oil, even at a low price.
Saddam Hussein demanded that Kuwait cancelled all Iraq’s debts from the war and loan 10 billion dollars to Iraq to rebuild the country. He also accused Kuwait of slant drilling into oil fields on the Iraqi side of the border.

The invasion of Kuwait.
Despite ongoing negotiations about Kuwait’s oil production and the exact border between Iraq and Kuwait, Iraqi forces crossed the border into Kuwait early in the morning of 2 August 1990. The entire country had been occupied before the end of the day and Kuwait’s royal family had fled to Saudi Arabia. According to Iraqi propaganda, the Kuwaiti people had risen up against their traditional monarchy and Iraq fully supported the uprising. Finding Kuwaitis who would speak out to support this representation was extremely difficult, however. Kuwait had been annexed as Iraq’s 19th province before the week was over.
Saudi Arabia and other states in the Gulf now felt threatened by Iraq’s experienced military and feared that it would continue to advance, with a view to seizing oil fields on the Saudi side of the border with Kuwait. Osama bin Laden even gave the Saudi king the offer of activating his network of Mujahideen to drive Saddam out of Kuwait. These were the same jihadis who had driven the Soviet Union out of Afghanistan just a few years previously. Instead, he sought support internationally, and particularly from the USA, to guarantee that the invasion of Kuwait was universally condemned and that the borders of the Gulf states were not threatened. Operation Desert Shield began just a few days later, as the Americans began to muster troops in Saudi Arabia.
All resistance to the Iraqi state in Kuwait was viciously stamped out. As the military looted Kuwait and took war booty back to Baghdad, even peaceful opposition was met with torture and public executions. To prevent excessive resistance to the Iraqi invasion, Saddam Hussain appointed his cousin Ali Hassan al-Majid (better known as “Chemical Ali” because of the atrocities committed against Iraqi Kurds a few years previously) as governor of the new province.

Response from the International Community
Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait was the first major crisis that the international community had faced since the end of the Cold War and Saddam Hussein had seriously miscalculated. Iraq had previously been a close ally of the Soviet Union and he now expected the Soviet Union to use its veto in the UN Security Council to prevent an international action against Iraq. Mikhail Gorbachev had taken the Soviet Union in a new direction internationally and was not looking for a confrontation with the USA. Instead he allowed US president George H.W. Bush to gain the support of the UN to form a coalition against the occupation of Kuwait.
A long list of resolutions was adopted in the Security Council, condemning Iraq’s invasion of its neighbour. Resolution 661 (1990) adopted a number of sanctions against Iraq and was followed up by Resolution 665 (1990), which mandated a naval blockade in the Gulf to enforce those sanctions. Denmark's contribution was the deployment of the naval corvette Olfert Fischer as Operation Faraway, which was the first time a Danish warship had been deployed so far from Denmark since the colonial era.
The pivotal resolution was Resolution 678, which was adopted at the end of November 1990. This resolution ordered Iraq to pull out of Kuwait completely before 15 January the following year. Non-compliance would mandate all states, in support of Kuwait, to use all necessary means to drive Iraqi troops out and liberate Kuwait. The USA began to assemble a broad coalition to fight the war that would follow if Saddam Hussein failed to comply with the requirements of the resolution. There was a particular desire to unite as many Arab states as possible, to prevent the alliance from being presented in Iraqi propaganda as an attack by foreign powers.
Saddam tried to associate the Kuwait conflict with other issues in the Arabic world. He tried to present the willingness of President Bush to fight a war to enforce a UN Resolution that condemned the occupation of an oil-rich country like Kuwait as bare-faced hypocrisy because of the USA’s uncritical support of Israel, despite the latter’s occupation of the Palestinian West Bank and the Southern Lebanon, as well as permitting the presence of Syrian troops in the Lebanon, which had also been condemned by the UN. Yemen, Sudan and the PLO therefore sided with Iraq, but did not contribute to the war, while Jordan tried to find a neutral position as a diplomatic negotiator. A number of Arabic states took part in the coalition, however. Saudi Arabia and the smaller Gulf states were keen participants. Morocco, Egypt and Syria also contributed, despite massive protests within their own populations.

Desert Storm
Iraq did not comply with the UN resolution and when the deadline expired on 15 January Kuwait was still occupied by Iraqi troops. The first phase of Operation Desert Storm commenced the following day. The US-led coalition began a massive air and artillery bombardment of targets in Kuwait and Iraq. The first attacks were on anti-aircraft batteries and Iraqi air force bases, in order to gain air supremacy. Next to be bombarded were command posts and electrical stations to prevent communications between Iraq's military leaders and front-line units. The final part of the air campaign focused on the Iraqi troops themselves, before commencing the final offensive to free Kuwait from Iraqi occupation.
Saddam Hussein still wanted to drive a wedge between the members of the coalition, however. To show that his war rhetoric was serious, he fired a number of SCUD missiles at Israel in the hope that Arabic members would feel the need to pull out and in the hope that Israel would be provoked into getting involved. The missile attacks caused no serious damage in Israel, as they were not precise over longer ranges. The Israeli Air Force was prepared to launch a number of retaliatory attacks on Iraq, but the US leadership was able to talk Israel out of doing so, as direct Israeli participation would potentially isolate the Egyptian and Syrian contributions from the rest of the coalition.
SCUD missiles were also fired at civilian and military targets in Saudi Arabia. The governments of Israel and Saudi Arabia both distributed gas masks to their civilian populations in case Iraq used chemical weapons. Iraq also attempted a land offensive and took the oil fields and refinery at Hafji on the Saudi side of the border with Kuwait, but was forced to withdraw back to Kuwait after a two day long counter attack by Saudi and US forces.
On 24 February, after a five week bombardment, the coalition began a major offensive along the Saudi border with Kuwait and Southern Iraq, to finally drive Iraqi forces out of Kuwait. In response the Iraqis set fire to oil wells and pumping stations in Kuwait as they retreated from the coalition attack. Images of the many oil fires became one of many international symbols of the war.
The withdrawal from Kuwait while under attack by the coalition was disorganised, out of control chaos. The motorway between Kuwait and Basra in Southern Iraq became known as “the Highway of Death” when large numbers of Iraqi troops were trapped in a traffic jam of tanks and retreating soldiers while under coalition fire.
A ceasefire was declared on 28 February, just 100 hours after the offensive had begun. The Iraqi army had been forced out of Kuwait and had also been defeated in Southern Iraq. Although various members of the coalition wanted to continue onwards to Baghdad and overthrow Saddam Hussein, the UN mandate expressly permitted only the liberation of Kuwait, not the invasion of Iraq. It was instead hoped that the complete and utter defeat and continued sanctions would lead to a coup against Saddam by dissatisfied generals, or a popular revolt that would topple him.

IRAQ IN THE 90S

The end of the war for Kuwait was not the end of Saddam Hussein’s problems. Over the decade that followed, he faced several uprisings by his own population and the introduction of no-fly zones over parts of the country. And meanwhile, Iraq continued to face a number of sanctions from the international community. The long and ongoing debate about whether Iraq still possessed weapons of mass destruction would lead to the war that followed in 2003 and that would be the final death blow to Saddam Hussein and the Ba’ath Party.

Defeat led to rebellion.
The Ba’ath régime was on shaky ground after the liberation of Kuwait and the defeat of the Iraqi army. In addition to the problems that were the result of the years of war against Iran, that were supposed to have been fixed with Kuwaiti oil, Iraq was now in an even worse state after another expensive war during which the country’s infrastructure had been bombarded and large amounts of military hardware had been destroyed. Radio stations sponsored by the USA had also encouraged thoughts of revolution in the Iraqi people, with half promises of military aid if they toppled Saddam.
The USA had probably expected to see a coup carried out by dissatisfied generals or the inner circle of Saddam's government, rather than popular rebellion by suppressed elements of Iraq's population. Shia Muslims in southern and eastern parts of the country and Kurds in the North both began militant rebellions against the Ba’ath régime in Baghdad. The anticipated support for the rebels did not initially appear, as the USA feared that a successful Shia rebellion would increase Iranian influence in the country, while Turkey (a member of NATO) opposed anything that remotely resembled an independent Kurdish territory (so as to prevent an escalation of Turkey’s conflict against its own Kurdish minority).
Iraq’s army had suffered a massive defeat in Kuwait, but still had elements that were battle-worthy. After a quick reorganisation, combat-ready units were deployed against the two rebel movements. During March and April 1991, civil war raged between the Iraqi régime and rebels to the North and South. The régime was known for taking extreme action to put down internal resistance, especially after its use of chemical gas weapons against Kurdish towns at the end of the 1980s. Saddam Hussein was able to defeat the rebellion in the South, partly by draining large areas of marshland that had been used as a base by the rebels and that was the local population’s basis for existence, while fighting in the Kurdish regions to the North continued to drag out. Even though the Shia Muslims had been left with no influence in Iraq, this fighting was the first time that they had been directly targeted by the régime’s armed forces.
No-fly zones were set up to protect remaining rebels and refugees at the instigation of the British and Americans during 1991, in both the northern and southern regions of the country. The poison gas attacks on Kurdish areas in 1987-88 had been carried out by the Iraqi air force. Nobody wanted this to be repeated, so airspace was patrolled by Western aircraft, preventing Saddam’s air force from carrying out attacks on the rebels. In practice, the air support from the West also covered a Kurdish area in northern Iraq that finally was able to gain self-government after many years of fighting against the Iraqi state. Baghdad was unhappy about this situation and tensions in the borderlands between Kurdish and Iraqi areas remained high. When the Kurds ended up fighting amongst themselves, the Iraqi army attempted an offensive in 1996 that was quickly responded to by a number of American cruise missiles fired at Iraqi targets.

Sanctions and inspections to find weapons of mass destruction
Iraq had been pushed out of Kuwait. A UN observer mission called UNIKOM was deployed to make sure that the Iraqi army stayed on the right side of the border. Iraq was still subject to a large number of sanctions, primarily those mandated after the invasion of Kuwait in Security Council Resolution 661 (1990). These sanctions required of UN member states that they blocked all trade with Iraq, except for the humanitarian supply of medicines and food. Iraq was barely able to purchase these essentials, as all export out of Iraq was also prohibited by the resolution, which meant that it was unable to pay for medicines etc.
When the war ended the UN Security Council adopted another resolution to maintain the existing sanctions. This resolution (687 of 1991) also included a new demand that Iraq should pay war reparations to Kuwait. If the sanctions were to be lifted, Iraq would have to hand over and destroy its entire arsenal of chemical and biological weapons, all rockets and missiles with a range exceeding 150km and guarantee that it would not develop atomic weapons. The United Nations Special Commission (UNSCOM) was set up to monitor compliance with these demands, alongside experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). The Iraqi authorities were required to grant the commission’s inspectors free access and to cooperate in full.
Wording at the end of Resolution 687 would turn out to be of pivotal importance. In the final paragraph of the resolution, the Security Council decided to “take such further steps as may be required for the implementation of the present resolution and to secure peace and security in the area”. This would be interpreted (an interpretation that would also be criticised) as a mandate to intervene if Iraq retained weapons of mass destruction.
Large quantities of chemical and biological weapons were discovered, handed over and destroyed. Several installations where such weapons were being manufactured were also visited by the inspectors and subsequently destroyed. Saddam Hussein and his régime were not always cooperative and it was feared that Iraq was still concealing depots of poison gas or production facilities. The Ba’ath Party also criticised UNSCOM’s use of Israeli and American experts to analyse some of the material that had been discovered and air photographs of possible installations, as both countries were enemies of Iraq and would be able to use this information for the purpose of espionage.
When UNSCOM reported that its inspectors were being denied free access and that Iraqi authorities were not always willing to cooperate, the United Kingdom and USA launched Operation Desert Fox in 1998. This was a four-day bombing campaign against Iraq, carried out with cruise missiles and aircraft. President Clinton’s official announcement was that the targets had been development and manufacturing facilities for weapons of mass destruction and that they had now been destroyed. Iraq denied this, claiming instead that the targets had been barracks and the headquarters of Saddam Hussein’s elite Republican Guard units. UNSCOM’s personnel had been evacuated before the attacks were launched. In response, Saddam Hussein decided to stop cooperating with INSCOM and did not allow the inspectors to return. A new United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission (UNMOVIC) was set up, but Iraq’s government continued to grant them access to the country.

The Effect of Sanctions: Oil for Food
The continuation of sanctions after the 1991 ceasefire was intended to pressurise Iraq into reporting its weapons of mass destruction to the inspectors and to convince army generals or the Baghdad inner circle to perform a coup against Saddam’s government. What actually happened was that the ordinary population bore the brunt of the sanctions, not the leadership of the régime. Parts of Iraq lay in ruins after many years of war and the country’s economy was highly dependent on continued revenue from oil exports. The sanctions made it impossible to generate income to fund the rebuilding of a broken country.
Trading with Iraq was forbidden, but the long borders through the Syrian desert to the West and the mountains of Iran and Turkey to the East and North were hard to keep under check. The Iraqi régime was not particularly interested in preventing cross-border smuggling either. The Bedouin tribes have always moved freely across the desert and, thanks to illegal trade, some tribal leaders had made enormous profits and Shia leaders with contacts in Iran were able to use them as a means of trade. When Iraq’s welfare state collapsed after war and sanctions, many people were able to find not only community but also security and economic aid from religious communities and tribes instead of the state.
The sanctions were broadly criticised, as organisations like UNICEF reported on wide famine and malnutrition in Iraq and a tripling of child mortality rates. In 1995 the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 986, launching what is often referred to as the “Food for Oil” programme. This program allowed Iraq to export a fixed quantity of oil and to use the revenue to purchase food for the Iraqi population.
The programme began at the end of 1996. From 1997 the first oil revenue began to return to Iraq. The funds would not go to Iraq directly, however. The UN administrated the oil revenue, allocating funds for debt repayment, war reparations to Kuwait and payment for the UN operations in Iraq. Iraq was allowed to use what was left to pay for food and other essentials. All imports had to be approved by UNSCOM, to be sure that Iraq was not importing arms or similar products.
What ended up happening was that the régime saw most of the benefits, which only reached the population to a limited extent. It is believed that Saddam Hussein and his inner circle earned a large amount of money from the programme. The food and medicines that were imported were never going to be enough for Iraq’s large population as it was. The first people to receive anything were the régime’s most loyal supporters and people in cities. People in rural communities received significantly less. Those who the government considered “suspicious” were completely neglected.

THE SECOND GULF WAR

As Iraq suffered under sanctions, the discussion about weapons of mass destruction continued. After the attacks on the USA on 11 September 2001, there were new grounds to fear a hostile régime that might be in possession of dangerous armaments. There was extensive debate in Denmark and the international community about whether UNSCOM had destroyed all Saddam’s weapons of mass destruction and whether the Iraqis had presented sufficient documentation that everything had been destroyed. Another subject of discussion was whether previous UN resolutions mandated further intervention. There was also a discussion of whether the USA and its allies could unilaterally invade Iraq, despite a lack of support for such action in the Security Council, and of if and how Denmark should contribute to such action, with or without a direct resolution.

The Fear of Weapons of Mass Destruction
In response to the 11 September 2001 attacks on New York and Washington, President George W. Bush declared a war on terror. In addition to toppling the Taliban régime in Afghanistan and launching Operation Active Endeavour in the Mediterranean, this led to renewed debate about whether Saddam Hussein still had access to weapons of mass destruction. Many feared that a hostile dictator like Saddam would be able to supply such weaponry to terrorists. He had, after all, had no hesitations when it came to using chemical weapons against his own population during the 1980s.
UN and IAEA UNSCOM inspectors had destroyed large quantities of weapons of mass destruction during the 1990s, but the Iraqi régime had failed to cooperate unconditionally, so it was feared that it still had hidden arms depots or production facilities. Inspectors had been unable to enter Iraq and it was possible that production had commenced anew, despite the sanctions which prevented non-covert imports of production materials. During 2002 there was therefore a broad debate about what could and should be done.
President Bush and his government appeared certain that Iraq was still concealing weapons of mass destruction and that the Iraqi régime was in contact with al-Qaeda. Saddam Hussein denied all allegations, but continued to prevent the entry of weapons inspectors into Iraq due to fear of espionage and resentment about having been attacked in 1998.
The official argument for a war against Iraq was the fear that it was still concealing weapons of mass destruction and that it had failed to cooperate unconditionally on their destruction. Official US policy since 1998 had, in practice, been to try and force a change of régime in Iraq, which is what many people viewed as the de facto reason. Many people envisaged the possibility of a new administration that was more friendly and would assure stability in the Gulf.
President Bush already had several allies on whom he could rely. The first and most important of these was British prime minister Tony Blair, the United Kingdom being the USA's closest ally and partner. Other European leaders, were also willing to support Bush, including the Danish Government. The EU was divided on this issue, however. France and Germany in particular both opposed the eventuality of a war in Iraq.

The Role of the UN
The global community was divided, as was the American government. Even accepting that Iraq was concealing weapons of mass destruction and represented a threat, there was some discussion as to whether an intervention would actually be legal. Previous Security Council resolutions had legitimised the use of force in relation to Kuwait and, after the war, the destruction of weapons of mass destruction was linked to the ceasefire conditions in Resolution 687. Was a new resolution even required, bearing in mind that Saddam Hussein had failed to fully cooperate with the weapons inspectors?
President Bush had the support of US Congress to use all necessary means to assure Iraq’s disarmament, which also included an invasion. Members of his government were not very keen on using the UN resolution as justification and wanted to obtain a new resolution that would definitively legitimise such an invasion. Encouraged by Blair and US foreign minister Colin Powell, it was decided that an attempt would be made to gain the support of the Security Council.
The Security Council adopted Resolution 1441 on 8 November 2002. Prior to this, there had been extensive debate about finding the right wording to gain the approval of all members of the Security Council. The resolution required Iraq’s unconditional cooperation with the inspectors that would return to the country. This was adopted unanimously, but only after France, Russia and China had stood firm that the wording would not automatically trigger a war if Iraq failed to comply with the resolution, but that there would be “serious consequences”. The resolution did not explicitly specify what these “serious consequences” would be, so there was some discussion of the legality of an invasion if the Security Council had not decided in advance that this would be the consequence.
Regardless of all this, the weapons inspectors returned to Iraq. Led by Hans Blix from Sweden, the inspectors prepared several reports about Iraq’s disarmament during the months that followed. Each report documented that the Iraqis were cooperating, but that the process was slow and obstructive. These reports were interpreted differently. According to opponents of a war they showed that disarmament was underway and that all that was needed was a little more time. According to Colin Powell the reports proved simply that Iraq was unwilling to cooperate.
As the Americans mustered troops and prepared for war, it seemed as though war was inevitable. On 10 March UN Secretary General Kofi Annan announced that a war that was not supported by the Security Council would be a violation of the UN treaty, while the Americans maintained that the previous resolution was adequate justification, while conceding that a new resolution would be the best scenario. An attempt was made to obtain a new resolution, but when this failed Bush announced on 17 March that Saddam Hussein had 48 hours to leave Iraq, or war would be declared.

Denmark’s discussion
There was a similar discussion in Denmark; in the media, in parliament and among government ministers. Joining a war in Iraq was a big decision, especially when there was no direct UN mandate to do so. Denmark had already taken part in Operation Allied Force just a few years previously, with no mandate from the UN (air bombing by a united NATO against Serbia, while it was carrying out ethnic cleansing in Kosovo). Certain politicians deemed that the bombing of Serbia was not the same as an invasion to force a change of régime in Iraq on the basis of claims about the presence of weapons of mass destruction.
In mid-November, when Denmark and a number of other countries were asked to contribute to a potential war, the Danish Prime Minister was generally inclined to agree, even though it was uncertain whether or not the war would happen and whether or not there would be a UN mandate. At a meeting of the Danish Foreign Affairs Committee a few days later, the Social Democrats, Radikale Venstre (the Danish Social Liberal Party) and Dansk Folkeparti (the Danish People's Party) gave their approval to the government for a Danish contribution to put pressure on Saddam Hussein. This was based on the assumption that there would be a new ruling from the UN.
Like their British and American counterparts, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark prepared a memo stating its interpretation that Resolution 1441 in combination with previous resolutions was sufficient mandate for the use of force against Iraq. This was in opposition to Kofi Annan’s assessment and it would therefore be difficult to obtain a broad parliamentary majority that would support Danish participation.
The Danish Prime Minister tried to persuade the opposition to form a broad majority, but for a downscaled deployment. He thus proposed a contribution that would be comprised of the submarine Sælen and the corvette Olfert Fischer, which had participated in 1991, and a team of doctors. The opposition did not accept this as they did not consider an invasion to be legal under international law.
On 18 March 2003 the government put proposal B118 on Danish military participation to the Danish Parliament. Although the debate that followed was very much about whether Iraq actually had any weapons of mass destruction, the proposal and its commentary did not specifically state that this was the justification for the war. The reason for the intervention was that Saddam Hussein was failing to cooperate with the weapons inspectors and was not complying with the requirements of the decade old ceasefire and the UN Security Council resolution.
There was massive debate on the issue in parliament and in the population at large. Eventually the proposal was passed by the Danish Parliament on 21 March, after an emergency reading. With 61 votes in favour and 50 against, the Danish Parliament had narrowly approved a Danish contribution to the coalition mission in Iraq. The war had already begun the previous day, on 20 March 2003.

The Coalition of the Willing.
Bush and Blair stated that even though the whole world was not willing to take part, a coalition could be formed of countries that were willing to do so. Over 40 countries joined this Coalition of the Willing, including Denmark. In practice, the invasion force itself was comprised of forces from the USA, the United Kingdom, Australia and Poland, in partnership with Kurdish militias from northern Iraq.
The original plan was to simultaneously invade Iraq from the North via Turkey and the South via Kuwait. The situation surrounding the UN mandate meant that Turkey’s government did not permit an invasion through its territory. Special forces units were deployed in northern Iraq to support the coalition’s Kurdish allies,while the main force launched its attack from Kuwait.
The war began officially on the morning of 20 March, shortly after the deadline President Bush had given Saddam Hussein had run out. As special forces units were already deployed inside Iraq, with an extensive attack on Iraqi positions from the air, a Kurdish offensive in the North and with the overall combined manpower of the coalition force attacking from the South, there was little the Iraqi army could do by way of resistance. Since 1990 it had been virtually impossible for Iraq’s military to acquire new military hardware or even spare parts to service what remained, much of its material having been lost in the retreat from Kuwait in 1991.
It took just three weeks for coalition forces to defeat the Iraqi army on the road from Kuwait to the North. Baghdad was taken in early April, by which time most of Iraq was under coalition military control, although fighting continued at various pockets of resistance in different locations. As the régime lost control of Iraq, Saddam’s palaces, government buildings and even hospitals were looted. Baghdad Museum of Antiquities was completely stripped of items of value. Of greater concern to the future of Iraq was the looting of numerous arms depots as their guards fled or deserted.
Looting was not the only thing shown on the World’s TV channels. Firdos Square in central Baghdad was the site of a famous 12-metre tall statue of Saddam Hussein, which had been erected a year previously to celebrate the dictator’s 65th birthday. A chain was fixed to it and, pulled by an American armoured vehicle, the monument was toppled. Saddam himself had disappeared and his most loyal forces continued to battle coalition forces.

After the Invasion.
On 1 May 2003, in front of a large banner displaying the words “Mission Accomplished”, President Bush held a speech on board the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln. In the speech he declared that the war had been won, that major combat engagements were concluded and that the coalition was ready to start rebuilding Iraq.
The war in Iraq was not over, however. Saddam was still at liberty and the Ba’ath Party that had governed Iraq with an iron fist for decades would have to be replaced by a democratic system that had space for all of Iraq’s ethnic and religious groups. Meanwhile, no weapons of mass destruction had been found, despite steadfast attempts to locate them.
The power vacuum that led to looting was not filled immediately by coalition forces, who were neither trained nor had the manpower to act as police officers. Meanwhile, decisions about Iraq's immediate future would be made by the American administration. Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) was set up in May to govern Iraq during the transition period until it was possible for elections to be held.
With American diplomat Paul Bremer in charge, CPA dismissed every single Ba’ath Party member, in complete disregard of the fact that party membership had, for many, been more about being able to work in state administration rather than any particular political convictions. The Iraqi army was then officially disbanded, instead of using the 400,000 soldiers to maintain law and order in the country. Finally, he cancelled the local elections that had initially been planned, instead setting up a government that was mainly comprised of Iraqi exiles. For Iraq, this decision meant that its local leaders had lost all influence, that 400,000 young men with military training were out of work, and that large numbers of dismissed officials now had future prospects or salaries to feed their families. All this, in a country that now had a massive power vacuum.

2004 TO 2011

With Saddam Hussein and the Ba’ath Party out of the picture and large parts of its infrastructure in ruins, Iraq was thrown into a power vacuum. The state was no longer able to guarantee security or welfare and the coalition forces were viewed by certain factions as an occupying power. Many people in Iraq found security within their more traditional networks. As an extended family, clans were able to help their members. Religious and ethnic groups came together as the most important unifier, as opposed to life under the secular welfare state that the Ba’ath régime had created using oil revenue. The invasion force was replaced by a stabilising force and a democratic Iraqi government was gradually put together.

CPA & The Multinational Security Command
As no weapons of mass destruction or evidence that Saddam Hussein had been in contact with al-Qaeda were discovered, the coalition instead decided to prioritise the democratisation of Iraq and liberation from the Ba’ath Party dictatorship. Many Iraqis saw this as somewhat hollow. When the British invaded the area during the First World War, the also came as “liberators”. Instead, it turned out that they pushed out local resistance and made Iraq a very thinly-disguised colony using the mandate system.
Under CPA a new Multinational Security Command was set up, rather than an occupation by former invasion forces. Iraq was divided into four zones. Two of these were administrated by the USA, one by Poland in partnership with various other countries and one by the United Kingdom. The Danish forces were deployed to the British zone. A total of 40 countries were members of this force. In addition to Denmark and the three countries with their own zones of responsibility, contributions came from countries as diverse as Thailand, Mongolia, Japan, the Czech Republic, Spain, Italy, Australia, Kazakhstan, the Ukraine and elsewhere.
The Danish Parliament decided in 2003 that Denmark would contribute to the Multinational Security Command. Although there was still no UN mandate, this proposal had a broader parliamentary majority than the original proposal on participation in the war two months previously. The Danish contingent was deployed near Basra in the British zone, an area that was believed to be relatively peaceful, as its population was largely Shia Muslims who had been suppressed by Saddam’s régime. A smaller contribution from Lithuania was attached to the Danish contingent.
The initial period was characterised by instability in the regions north of the British zone. One of the reasons for this was that the leadership of the Ba’ath Party had been dominated by Sunni Muslims like Saddam himself. And in areas where there was a Sunni presence the coalition forces were broadly unpopular. Loyal remnants of the Ba’ath Party and Iraqi military continued the fighting, largely employing guerilla tactics.
In Resolution 1483 of May 2003, the UN Security Council recognised the coalition as a occupying power under international law, with CPA as a legitimate transitional government. The many sanctions that had been imposed on Iraq since 1990 were also lifted and the coalition was required only to use oil revenue from Iraq for the benefit of the people of Iraq. United Nations Assistance Mission in Iraq (UNAMI) was also set up in August 2003 (in Resolution 1500). Its task was to support the process of democratisation, to advise Iraqi authorities and to coordinate humanitarian work in the country. Just five days after it was set up, UNAMI’s headquarters in Baghdad was car bombed in an attack that killed 22 people, including the UN’s special representative to Iraq. Much of the work that was being done by the UN and its personnel was then relocated to Jordan.

Independence during imminent civil war
The Iraqi Governing Council (IGC) was under CPA’s control and was mainly comprised of Iraqis who had lived in exile. In practical terms, most power was still in the hands of CPA, but IGS was responsible for certain key areas. One of their tasks was thus to put together a constitution for Iraq to enable an election. IGC also represented Iraq in the UN and the Arab League.
Initial resistance to the occupation mainly came from the remnants of the secular Ba’ath Party that was supported by Sunni Muslims who feared suppression in a democratic state by the Shia majority. Over time, this resistance turned into more tangible conflicts that had become sectarian and were supported by al-Qaeda fighters who had entered Iraq, with attacks on Shia Muslims and religious sites.
The Shia Muslims were far from innocent in this regard too, although they were initially more open to the coalition forces. A Shiite religious leader called Muqtada al-Sadre proclaimed as early as July 2003 that the transitional government was a puppet of the occupying powers and officially began to form a militia. During the previous looting after the fall of Saddam, his supporters had made their presence known in Baghdad’s slums by organising local Shiites to patrol the area and maintain a form of law and order. There were similar patterns at various other locations in Iraq, apparently being organised within religious communities or extended family networks.
In parallel to all this was a number of criminal organisations, who did not want to see a strong central authority. Some of these had roots in the border smuggling of the sanctions era, while others had appeared in the wake and chaos of the events that followed the invasion. Numerous Iraqi soldiers and officials were expelled by CPA, giving the criminal groups, religious militias and clan communities a large recruitment base. Despite hopes that resistance would ebb out when Saddam Hussein was finally captured in December 2003, Iraq remained unstable and attacks continued on coalition forces in the country.
CPA and IGC were replaced by an Iraqi transitional government in June 2004. Although elections and a new constitution were not yet ready, Iraq was at this point officially an independent sovereign state. Coalition forces maintained their presence in Iraq, however, as the situation was far from peaceful and there was a fear that the new government would collapse if coalition forces were withdrawn. Their presence was also at the formal invitation of Iraq’s own government, rather than having the status of an occupying force.
The conflict escalated over the years that followed. Despite this, the first ever free elections were held in Iraq in January 2005. Over 100 polling stations suffered armed attacks on election day and some stations had voting rates of less then ten per cent. International observers deemed the election to be legitimate, however, and the new transitional government was authorised to write an actual constitution, which would be finally passed in the autumn of 2005.
Although coalition forces helped as best they could, Iraq’s government found it difficult to recruit personnel, and particularly police officers. This was not particularly because of hostility among the population, but was rather due to the fact that al-Qaeda, the remnants of the Ba’ath Party and other groups were willing not only to attack civilian targets, but often specifically targeted police officers and their families. They were unable to defeat coalition forces militarily, but had the capability to maintain instability in the country, thus signalling to the population that collaboration with the government and the coalition could have serious consequences.

The Surge and The Long Road Home.
Assuring stability and battling opponents were not the only tasks of the international forces in Iraq. One of their most important missions, particularly in the long term, was to train and prepare local security forces to be able to assume control so the multinational force could be recalled. This was easier said than done.
As American troops fought a tough battle to control the town of Fallujah and other areas in the “Sunni Triangle” north of Baghdad, the Danish and British troops in the southern part of the country spent a long time dealing with problems other than direct combat engagements. The problem in this zone was local criminals and the new Shia-dominated Iraqi police corps.
On 22 February 2006 a bomb detonated inside the al-Askari mosque in the town of Samarra. Al-Qaeda in Iraq had carried out this attack, which caused the dome to collapse on one of the most important holy sites to Shia Muslims. Conflict had already smouldered between these groups and the Askari bombing was the spark that triggered a civil war. The conflict deteriorated over the next two years, with numerous attacks on militias, civilians and the international forces. The conflict was not just between two religious factions, but often between rival militias who were involved in infighting, despite belonging to the same religious faction.
Conflict also escalated in the mainly Shia area that comprised the Danish and British area of operations. Rocket attacks on bases became more and more frequent. The threat of improvised roadside explosive devices and ambushes was greater than it had been previously. In the first few years of the war, locals would often wave when the troops rolled out to visit schools etc. that were being renovated as part of the work towards rebuilding the region. Now, sallies of this type were only performed if necessary. The coalition was beginning to lose control of Basra and other important towns to al-Sadr’s militia.
After years of war and conflict, several countries began to pull out of Iraq. The first withdrawals already took place in 2004, but from 2006 in particular, the increase in fatalities became part of the agenda in all the participating countries. On 21 February 2007 both Denmark and the United Kingdom announced that they would be withdrawing their combat troops. Danish forces would be recalled in August that year and British forces would be massively reduced over the years that followed. Just before these announcements, President Bush had announced that the American presence would be massively reinforced in a “surge” to stabilise Iraq before the Americans too would pull out.
The withdrawal had to a certain degree been at the request of the Iraqi government, who wanted to assume greater responsibility for the security of its own country. Although the situation only deteriorated during the months that followed the British and Danish withdrawal, Iraq’s central government was able, with American support, to regain control of the Basra region after a major offensive in 2008.
“The Surge” turned out to be highly effective. The increased numbers of American troops helped to increase stability. Dialogue was also extended with a number of clan and militia leaders, who were paid economic aid and offered a role in the Iraqi state in return for ending their rebellions and helping instead to defeat al-Qaeda and other extremist factions.
Iraq was now a “relatively” calm country, compared with previous years which had resembled civil war and the final withdrawal agreement was negotiated. The agreement between the Iraqi and American governments was concluded in 2008, leading to a gradual phasing out of combat units starting in towns with a deadline of 30 June 2009. All American troops were to have left the country by the end of 2011. The final combat units left Iraq on the orders of President Obama on 19 August 2010. The remaining American troops in Iraq would only assist in the training of the Iraqi army until they too departed at around Christmas 2011.

2011 TO ISIL

When the last remaining international forces left Iraq at the end of 2011 it had been through invasion followed by civil war to finally gaining a semblance of stability. There were still several armed groups that were not under direct state control and others that continued to fight against the government. Shia Muslim prime minister Nuori al-Maliki was viewed by many Iraqis as a sectarian who always sided with Shiites and wanted to suppress the Sunni minority, whose militias were behind most resistance against the state. There were still celebrations, however, when Iraq was once again free of international forces. Events in the region and in neighbouring Syria in particular threw Iraq into another civil war that necessitated the return of a new international coalition to Iraq.

The Arabic Spring and Islamic State
The final American forces left Iraq in 2011. It would be a fateful year for the entire region. Protests broke out in Tunisia in December 2010 which led to régime collapse in early 2011 and the introduction of democracy to the country. Inspired by the success in Tunisia, protests spread to large areas of the Arab world. Egypt’s president was deposed in February 2011 by the military after massive popular pressure. Demonstrations began soon afterwards in Libya, which led to a civil war in which Denmark provided air support to the rebels as part of an international coalition. In other countries: Jordan, Morocco and Saudi Arabia, protests were met with promised reforms and ebbed out. In Bahrain demonstrators were beaten when the state received support from neighbouring countries. In Yemen the president stepped down but the country would eventually end up in a state of civil war.
Things would be different in Syria. Initial protests were dealt with in a tough manner by the military, which led to further protests that were met by tougher suppression by the régime. As violence spiralled, the first protests developed into a civil war in Iraq’s neighbouring country that would go on for years. Despite several attempts by the UN, it was not possible to gain the support of the Security Council for an international intervention in the civil war in Syria.
Like Iraq, Syria was divided across several different religious faction and was ruled by the official secular Ba’ath Party. Unlike Iraq, Syria was dominated by its Alawi minority. Alawi is a branch of Shia Islam, but Syria’s broader population was massively dominated by Sunni Muslims. Although the rebellion in Syria initially involved a number of different groups who had united as the secular Free Syrian Army, the rebellion would, over time, become dominated by various Sunni Islamist groups who enjoyed economic support from abroad and were joined by Islamists from other countries who wanted to fight in the civil war.
One of the rebel factions was based in the Iraqi branch of al-Qaeda, which had been one of the first and most enduring resistance groups after the fall of Saddam Hussein. Initially, Al-Qaeda in Iraq had been mainly composed of Islamists from other parts of the Islamic world who had arrived to fight the American occupation of Iraq. When it became clear that the Ba’ath régime in Iraq would never return to power, a number of former officers joined the group as a way of continuing the war against the coalition. After disagreements on religious doctrine and military strategy, parts of the Iraqi branch dealigned themselves from Osama bin Laden and al-Qaeda’s leadership in 2006. Shortly afterwards, al-Qaeda in Iraq announced the creation of a new organisation called the Islamic State in Iraq (ISI).
During the civil war in Syria a new wave of foreign Islamists entered the country and many Sunni Muslims became radicalised after years of fighting against the régime. Meanwhile, ISI grew in strength and took advantage of the conflict in Syria, where they could operate to the same degree as in Iraq. They therefore changed their name in 2013 to the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant, or ISIL. Unlike other Islamist terror organisations, ISIL’s focus was not so much on generating instability and toppling a government. ISIL was instead trying to conquer territory and form an extremist state.
By 2014, everyone was talking about them. ISIL was gaining ground in Iraq. They were able to conquer large parts of the town of Fallujah in January. In June they took Mosul, the third-largest town in Iraq, as the Iraqi army withdrew without offering much resistance. From Mosul, ISIL declared the foundation of a global caliphate under their leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. Building on their success, ISIL would soon control a large swath of eastern Syria and north western Iraq. This was mostly thinly populated desert areas, but included several cities such as Fallujah, Mosul, and Tikrit in Iraq and towns like Raqqa and Palmyra in Syria. Condemned by the global community and Islamic religious leaders, a few extremist groups elsewhere pledged allegiance to ISIL. These included Boko Haram in Nigeria.

Operation Inherent Resolve - Air Support and Training.
Their success on the battlefield was not the only thing for which ISIL became notorious. They decided to remove all signs of pre-Islamic civilisation in the areas they had conquered.Sites of the most ancient Mesopotamian ruins were blown up or destroyed by other means. Mosul and the surrounding areas were home to some of the oldest Christian communities and the Yazidi minority. Both groups attempted to flee, as ISIL relentlessly executed prisoners, including the many prisoners they had taken from the Iraqi army when fighting to gain control of the region.
Almost 50,000 Yazidis had fled to Mount Sinjar when ISIL advanced and were trapped there in late summer while ISIL apparently waited for them to die from hunger and heat. On 7 August, US President Barack Obama therefore announced the first step in a return to Iraq by the USA. This involved an air bombardment of ISIL to protect the Yazidis and air drops of emergency aid for the many refugees. With air support from the US, forces from Iraqi Kurdistan forced ISIL to retreat, allowing them to rescue the many Yazidis who had been trapped on Mount Sinjar.
A new coalition was formed to fight ISIL. Participants included the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Jordan, Morocco, and Denmark. It was officially launched in October as Operation Inherent Resolve. Rather than to deploy ground troops, the goal of the operation was to defeat ISIL from the air. Participating countries sent a number of individuals to Iraq to advise and train its army for the battle ahead. Some countries did, however, deploy ground troops in Iraq to fight ISIL directly.
The Iraqi army was largely unsuccessful in 2014, being defeated or retreating from the ISIL offensive. The training missions were therefore very high priority. The many militias in Iraq were also brought together under a state-sponsored umbrella organisation called Popular Mobilization Forces (PMF). With international air support, a retrained army and the new PMF, Iraq was eventually able to launch a successful offensive against ISIL.
After a number of defeats, it looked in 2017 as though time was running out for ISIL. While being hit by air strikes by several international coalitions, ISIL was attacked in Syria by just about all of the many fractions in the civil war, and the regrouped Iraqi army and forces from the independent Kurdish territory sent it into retreat. ISIL was driven from Mosul during the summer, and lost its capital Raqqa in Syria in October.
On 9 December 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the Islamic State had been definitively defeated in Iraq and that all its territory had been retaken. Remnants of ISIL have, however, been able to carry out isolated terrorist attacks, such as the suicide bombings in Baghdad in early 2018.

A Future for Iraq?
After the defeat of ISIL, it seems that Iraq may be heading towards a more stable future. Prime minister Haider al-Abadi and his government are generally viewed as more driven by compromise than their predecessors and have regained official control of the entire country. The bringing together of the many militias under PMF and putting them on the state payroll suggests that the state finally has the support of all significant armed groups within the country. If they can be integrated into the official army or as a form of home defence, one major threat to Iraq’s stability will have been avoided. It is quite possible that several of the militias that form PMF have loyalties elsewhere, such as individual parties, movements and even the theocracy in Iran, which has long been a supporter of several of the Shia Muslim militias.
One major challenge is the issue of the Kurds in the northern region of the country. Since Iraq was formed after the First World War, the Kurds have wanted their own independent state that would be able to unite with Kurdish minorities in neighbouring countries. The Kurds have been the victims of severe suppression, especially by Saddam Hussein who had no hesitation committing acts of genocide or using chemical weapons against them. Since 1991 the Kurds have effectively had self-governing status, which was formalised after the invasion in 2003. As a self-governing region, Kurdish forces are not part of PMF but were among the most effective in the war against Islamic State, and the Kurds were able to occupy a larger territory than previously, including the important oil fields near the town of Kirkuk. A 2017 referendum on independence revealed that 92% of Kurds wanted to have their own state. The question was raised once again, but Iraq’s central government in Baghdad was unwilling to enter negotiations. They therefore sent the army north and after a short engagement the Kurds withdrew from Kirkuk. Demonstrations in neighbouring countries in support of the Kurds were suppressed and any official declaration of independence would be met with hostility, not only by the government of Iraq, but by Turkey and Iran.
Corruption is still widespread in Iraq and various interests in the country are dissatisfied with the government. After the wars against Iran and Kuwait and the rebellions and sanctions of the 1990s, after Saddam Hussein’s divisive policies, the invasion of 2003 and the sectarian civil war, many Iraqis still feel a closer affiliation to their clan or religious community than they do the government as a whole. There is hope, however, that the united resistance against ISIL will serve as a unifier and the 2018 parliamentary elections proceeded in good order. If Iraq is able to generate stable economic development, a peaceful solution to the Kurdish issue and absorb PMF into the actual armed forces, it could transition from being one of the least stable and ungovernable regions in the world to becoming a functioning state once again. The period after the fall of Saddam Hussein has not been an easy time for Iraq and the country’s future remains uncertain.

DESCRIPTION
Afghanistan is a country of mountains, steppes and desert and lies at the crossroads between the power centres of India, China, Central Asia and the Middle East, on the Silk Road that connected China and the Far East to the Middle East and to Europe. It is home to countless peoples and tribes. Very few external powers have ever been able to seize control of this country. It is a land that is deeply characterised by the rise of Islam and the caliphates’ rule over the people and tribes of the steppes. It would later become an area of conflicting Russian and British interests, but achieved independence in 1919. The following 60 years would bring modernisation, but were also a time of increased rivalry between the Soviet Union and the USA. This was a time of coups d'etat, of weak leadership and disagreement between central and local structures, a time that would ultimately lead to a communist régime and intervention by the Soviet Union in 1979. The Mujahideen appeared and in 1988 the Soviet Union withdrew from an Afghanistan that had reached boiling point, as the various factions fought over power.
A new puritanical movement rose up; the Taliban, who would occupy Kabul and seize power in 1996. Al-Qaeda under the leadership of Osama bin Laden set up facilities in the country, from where a number of terrorist attacks were planned and coordinated. One such attack targeted the USA directly on 11 September 2001. A USA-led coalition attacked Al-Qaeda and the Taliban in Afghanistan. In 2002 the Afghan tribal council appointed a new government. This government would require massive amounts of international support.
From 2001/2002 onwards, names and notions like ISAF, Kabul, Helmand, Feyzabad, Chaghcharan, opium, the education of women and girls, women’s rights, the rebuilding of civic structures, the training of security forces, IEDs, the Green Zone, OMLT and many others would have a long-lasting impact on the thousands of Danes and others who were deployed to Afghanistan to perform numerous roles.
If you would like to learn more, then please read one of more of the following chapters. It is interesting reading indeed.

HISTORY
At first glance Afghanistan may seem like a country far away from history’s great power centres. Its location, however, is at the crossroads where they all meet. Afghanistan lies right in the middle of the Silk Road, which was the main trading artery between China and Europe for millennia. This has made Afghanistan an important objective for Kings and Emperors for centuries. Its people, however, are strong-willed and difficult to govern. Rulers who were able to govern Afghanistan with any degree of success had to take their time, or actually live there.

The melting pot of antiquity
Afghanistan has always been an important crossroads for traders and rulers. Geologically, Blue Lapis Lazuli stone is found hardly anywhere other than northern Afghanistan, yet it has been found in jewellery and burial chambers in Mesopotamia and Ancient Egypt.
During antiquity, what is now known as Afghanistan was part of the Persian Empire. Afghanistan’s links with Iran have been a common thread throughout it’s history. The Persian Shahanshah, King of Kings, ruled over large areas of Afghanistan as the easternmost area of his empire, an empire which stretched all the way to Greece at various points in history. The Persian Empire was not eternal, however, and was ultimately conquered by the young Alexander the Great during his campaign of conquest in the East. Alexander made it all the way to India before being forced to turn back. Before his campaign in India, Alexander had spent years in Afghanistan defeating local tribes and fortifying the hillsides with his loyal Greek followers, who remained in the area to maintain it under his authority.
Alexander died at a young age in 323 BC. As his empire collapsed and was parted out among his generals, the Greek troops remained in Afghanistan, founding the Kingdom of Bactria, the capital of which was modern-day Balkh in northern Afghanistan. Isolated from the Hellenic world by a reawoken Persian Empire, Bactria’s culture was an unusual hybrid, taking influences from its local population, Greek settlers, trading connections with China and from Buddhist and Hindu migrants who arrived from India. Over time, Bactria would collapse into smaller states. Nomads from the steppes of central Asia immigrated and became part of the Greco-Buddhist towns in the area.
This melting pot of cultures would endure for centuries thanks to the wealth from the Silk Road. It would carve out the world's largest statues of the Buddha in the hillsides of Bamiyan in central Afghanistan. This was not a united state, however. Rather, it was a number of smaller principalities and tribes who were, at different times, partially ruled from Persia, India or by the various steppe peoples. All three groups fought over power and control of what was then an area of great wealth, and over control of the mountain passes and trade roads that joined China, India and Persia; and thus the route to the Middle East and to Europe.

The arrival of Islam
During the seventh century, a new superpower would try to conquer Afghanistan. The caliphates that followed the death of the prophet Mohammed conquered Persia, whose final empire from antiquity collapsed after being defeated by the Arabs in 651AD. The first expeditions into Afghanistan by Muslims had already commenced a decade previously.
The legends of the Pashtun people narrate how their ancestral chieftain Quais travelled to Mecca during the time of Mohammed, converted to Islam and took the name Abdul Rashid. Quais then returned home, where he and his sons disseminated the new religion, forming the basis for the tribes that became the present day Pashtun. Quais does not appear in Arabic sources and converting the Pashtun or the rest of Afghanistan to Islam did not happen overnight. This process took hundreds of years.
At first glance, the Islamic expeditions into Afghanistan appear to have been a success. Towns like Herat and Kandahar were conquered, but as soon as the invading army departed the locals rebelled, denounced Islam and went back to their previous ways. Kabul and Peshawar continued to be ruled by Hindu princes for centuries, even though they did convert temporarily to Islam after their defeat, a conversion which only lasted until the Muslim army had departed. It was not until 1010 that all of modern Afghanistan fell under Islamic rule, with the exception of a single mountain valley in the East that was known for many years as Kafristan, which loosely translated means “the country of the infidels”. Converting this region to Islam took many centuries of persistence, as the population would return to its previous customs as soon as the invaders had departed. Kafiristan did not convert to Islam until the end of the 19th Century, when it was renamed Nouristan (which means “the land of light”), by which name it is still known today.

About the people of the steppes and the Great Mughals
Large areas of Afghanistan are dominated by the western Himalayas, from where melted ice forms the rivers that bring fertility to certain regions of the country. To the North, the mountains become great open plains, stretching throughout Central Asia, from China in the East to the Ukraine in the West. Typically, these areas have been dominated by equestrian peoples like the Turks and Mongols. Horses were a necessity of life for these peoples, who were constantly on the move in search of new grazing areas. The point at which the Afghan steppes end and other states begin has not always been entirely clear. People from the steppes have often occupied parts of Afghanistan, and vice versa. They have also immigrated in waves to the area at various points through history.
Genghis Khan was the greatest of the steppe people, and Afghanistan was part of the Mongol empire for many years. In terms of this history of Afghanistan, Genghis Khan was actually not the most important of the steppe warlords. Instead, this was Turkish-speaking Timur Lenk who, during the 14th Century, founded a kingdom whose capital city was Herat in western Afghanistan. From Herat, his successors governed a powerful state that included Persia, Pakistan and northern India, as well as large areas of steppe to the North.
Known as the Timurid Empire, it was ruled for centuries by the descendants of its founder, but would gradually lose control over the more remote areas. Babur, one of Timur’s heirs, had to reconquer Kabul at the start of the16th Century. He made Kabul the capital of his kingdom and soon became involved in Indian politics. From Kabul, he led an Afghan army through the Khyber Pass that connects Afghanistan with what is now Pakistan and India. Once there, he occupied Delhi. In English his realm became known as the Great Mughal (or Mogul) Empire.
The Great Mughals would, however, lose Herat and Kandahar in western and southern Afghanistan to a revived Persia, and Afghanistan would once again be divided between multiple states. Meanwhile, the Great Mughals had managed to annex most of India. Babur and his successors were responsible for impressive constructions like the Taj Mahal. It was during this period that the Danish colonies of Trankebar and Frederiksnagore in India were founded as trading stations by agreement with the Great Mughal's vassals.
The country that would eventually become present-day Afghanistan first appeared during the middle of the 18th Century. As the Great Mughal Empire was slowly undermined by structures like the British East Asia Company, Nadir Shah ruled a powerful Persian state and western Afghanistan.
