With many Pashtun tribal warriors in his army, Nadir Shah was able to conquer the whole of Afghanistan and even invaded India, where he plundered the Great Mughal’s capital city, Delhi. Nadir was assassinated upon his return to Iran and his empire was broken up. Ahmed Shad, the first king of the Durrani dynasty and leader of the Pashtun warriors, took power in 1747.
As time went on Ahmed Shah Durrani would conquer even greater areas of land and would rule an empire that was centred in Afghanistan but stretched into modern-day Iran, Usbekistan, Turkmenistan, Tadsjikistan, Pakistan and north western India. The Durrani Empire is considered the beginning of modern Afghanistan and Ahmed Shah is now celebrated as the country’s founder.

The Great Game: Afghanistan between two superpowers
As generals and leaders, Ahmed Shah’s successors were not as effective as their ancestor and parts of Afghanistan would be lost over the years. The late 18th and early 19th centuries brought many years of instability, with attempted coups, rebellion and civil war. Various members of the Durrani clan, often brothers and cousins, warred against each other to occupy the throne and the title of Shah. Out of this anarchy rose the Barakzai dynasty, which originated in the same Pashtun tribe as the Durrani. Afghanistan was ruled by the Barakzais until 1978.
The first Barakzai ruler was Dost Muhammed, whose title was Emir of Kabul. No longer the empire that had been ruled by the Durrani, Afghanistan had, by the time he became ruler, become a small and unstable state that was part of a high-stakes political game that was being played by European powers. Russia had expanded into Siberia and was beginning to encroach upon Afghanistan from the North. By this time, India had also become part of the British Empire. Although the Great Moghal and other princes were the theoretical rulers of India, this was only because this suited British interests.
The British feared that Russian influence in Afghanistan could cause the British control of India to come under threat. A British-Indian army was therefore mustered to place the previously deposed Shah Shuja on the throne, which would ensure that Afghanistan had no close links to Russia. The First Anglo-Afghan War began in 1839 and initially went well for the British. They won battles, conquered towns, imprisoned Dost Muhammed and put Shah Shuja in Kabul. But what had happened to others, the same would happen to the British. After their army had withdrawn and only a small garrison had been left behind, rebellion broke out. Despite the promise of free passage if they withdrew, and of a force of 4,500 soldiers, only a few survivors made it back through the Khyber Pass to British territory. A new British-Indian force made an attempt to invade but Shah Shuja had been assassinated. The war did not end until 1842, when Dost Muhammed was released and set pack on the throne after he pledged goodwill to Great Britain.
There was another British invasion of Afghanistan in 1878, when Emir Sher Ali received Russian diplomats but denied the presence of a permanent British representation in Kabul. Once again, the British won quick victories and the signature of a peace treaty in 1879, this time with Sher Ali’s son after his father had died. A British ambassador was then posted to Afghanistan. But once again there was rebellion and the ambassador and his guards were murdered. The war ended two years later, when Sher Ali’s nephew, Abdur Rahman, took the rest of the country with his own Afghan army and agreed to adopt a foreign affairs policy that was compatible with the interests of the British administration in India.
Afghanistan has always had fluid borders and the ability to adapt to whoever was able to enforce authority, provided that they had the loyalty of the local tribes. This “system” did not suit the British “Raj” in India, who favoured a permanent demarcation of the border. Fortunately, Abdur Rahman was not just willing to collaborate with the British, but became known as the “Iron Emir” as he wiped out all resistance while creating an effective central power base that was able to control the entire country, making it possible to establish a permanent border demarcation.
The new border was named “the Durand Line” after the English diplomat who had negotiated on behalf of the British administration in India. Although this agreement was signed by Durand and Abdur Rahman, the border has been a matter of conflict ever since. It traverses the inaccessible mountains of the Hindu Kush, which means that it cuts through the Pashtun tribes, who have had traditionally equally close links to towns and people both north and south of the Durand Line.
Afghanistan remained neutral throughout the First World War, but Amanullah Khan inherited the throne in 1919. Because of British war fatigue and the post-war demobilisation of the Indian army, Amanullah saw an opportunity. Like the Great Moghals and Durranis before him, he led an army through the Khyber Pass and invaded India. He was also able to persuade many Pashtun from the southern side of the Durand Line to rebel and join him.
The Third Anglo-Afghan War would proceed somewhat differently to its two predecessors. The British-Indian army pushed Amanullah’s forces back and a Royal Air Force bombing campaign was very successful in scattering an army that was comprised of rebel tribesmen. The British had learned some lessons from the previous war, however. There was no prospect that they would try to reoccupy Afghanistan. As Russia collapsed to revolution and civil war, Afghanistan no longer had strategic importance as a buffer state. A peace treaty was signed, in which Afghanistan gained full independence and control over its own foreign affairs policy. As the British in India faced a years-long battle to defeat the Pashtun tribes south of the Durand Line, Amanullah returned to an independent Afghanistan to establish a modern state.

THE ROUTE TO THE MUJAHIDEEN
When Afghanistan gained full independence 1919 it was very much still a traditional tribal society. Over the following 60 years its various monarchs considered it important to modernise the country, with all the consequences that would entail. Factions within the country saw this process of modernisation gradually eroding their power or status and opposed it, as the rest of the world headed into the Second World War and the subsequent Cold War. “The Great Game” that was played by Russia and Great Britain in Central Asia during the 19th Century would eventually be replaced by rivalries between the USA and the Soviet Union. This would have serious consequences for Afghanistan.

Modernisation among superpowers
After the Third Anglo-Afghan War, Amanullah decided that it was time to modernise his kingdom. Electricity and more advanced infrastructures were introduced, but the process of modernisation was not only in the form of technology. All of Afghan society was to be restructured as a Western-style nation state, taking strong inspiration from the processes that Mustafa Kemal Atutürk had been introducing in Turkey during this period. Amanullah had himself crowned using the Persian title of Padshah (Great King), instead of Emir like his predecessors. He formulated Afghanistan’s first constitution and gave up absolute monarchy in favour of a constitutional one. Afghanistan's population would no longer be considered subjects or tribal people, but citizens of a modern state, wearing Western attire and receiving a secular education. The first steps towards the liberation of women would be taken too, with the abolition of laws that required women’s faces to be covered.
The reforms process was introduced to the population in 1924 at a Loya Jirga, a traditional tribal council that had been used previously to unite the nation’s tribes to swear allegiance to a new king. Just as the absolute monarchy had been legitimised by Islamic rules, Amnunallah also used religious arguments to support the new state and the new form of government. New state-controlled madrasas (religious schools) would be set up to assure governmental control of the religious elite and of subjects that were not related to religion.
Not everyone was happy about the process of modernisation and, as they saw their power eroded, religious leaders began to rebel. Amanullah was deposed in 1929 and was replaced on the throne by a Tadsjik rebel, who would himself be deposed soon afterwards by a coalition of Pashtun tribes, who crowned one of Amanullah’s relatives, Nadir Shah, after another Loya Jirga. A new constitution in 1931 secured the power of religious leaders in the Jamiat al-Ulema, the council of the wise, who would check that all new legislation was in accordance with religious requirements.
Nadir Shah would be assassinated just two years later. His son, Zahir Shah, then became king. Appointing relatives as prime ministers one after the other, he ruled Afghanistan through a long period of stability. Especially after the Second World War, Afghan development and economy would progress with rapid industrialisation, statutory schooling for all (even though this would seldom be the case in rural areas) and increased numbers of women in employment and at university. Zahir and his advisors were more cautious than Amanullah in the speed at which they introduced new reforms. Reforms would initially be rolled out in Kabul, from where they would spread on a gradual basis, while ensuring that taxes and military conscription were only increased at a rate to which even the most conservative tribes would be able to grow accustomed.
When the British left the region and the colonies became independent states in 1947, the Durand Line continued as the border between Afghanistan and Pakistan. The area on the Pakistani side of the border was named North-West Frontier Province (NWFP). Here, the Pashtun tribal areas would often act as if they were to all intents and purposes independent. At times this would lead to tensions, as Afghan governments thought that this region should be reunited with Afghanistan as a united homeland for the Pashtun.
Formally, Afghanistan was part of the Non-Aligned Movement and was thus aligned with neither side during the Cold War. Instead, the Afghan administration tried to play the two superpowers against one another. The northern border with the Soviet Union meant that the bulk of development aid that was received by Afghanistan initially came from the Soviets, who would soon become Afghanistan’s largest trading partner. The USA increased investment in Afghanistan in order to prevent it from becoming fully integrated within the Soviet sphere Afghanistan’s largest motorway (a circular highway connecting most towns) was built half by Soviet engineers and half using American funding.

The coup d’état and communism
Slowly, the process of modernisation and development would produce a new middle class. Even though illiteracy remained widespread and most of the population were subsistence farmers, a growing number of intellectuals would graduate from Kabul University. These would become the army’s professional officers, the middle managers of Afghanistan’s flourishing industry and bureaucrats within its expanding administration. Everyone had new ideas about how the country should be governed and wanted to influence its administration.
There were multiple attempts to create a democratic system with an elected parliament and free press. 1949 onwards was a relatively liberal period until King Zahir’s cousin, Daud Khan, was appointed prime minister and abolished the democratic experiment in 1953. Daud Khan would have to step down as prime minister in 1964, after a new constitution was introduced at a Loya Jirga. Even though Afghanistan now had an elected parliament, Zahir would still appoint the government and set the tone. Parliament was able to debate as much as it liked, but had no practical power and political parties remained illegal.
As time went on, the politically active class (who were mainly in Kabul) would split into two highly opposed factions: a revolutionary communist left wing and a conservative Islamic right. Disagreements were particularly vehement at the universities and clashes between the two factions were far from unusual.
Daud Khan was unhappy about being sidelined and began to seek support from communist elements within the People’s Democratic Party of Afghanistan (PDPA). With a political scene in a state of chaos, a famine that had been caused by drought and Zahir Shah out of the country, Daud executed a coup, abolished the monarchy and established a republic with himself as president. At first glance this appeared to be a radical break with the past, but as the cousin of the king, Daud was actually only continuing the monarchy under the Barakzai dynasty. The only thing that was really new was the title of the head of state and that the factions that supported him were neither tribal leaders nor traditional Islamic savants.
It became quickly apparent that President Daud was no communist, even though he had received support from PDPA during the coup. He was instead an authoritarian who tried to eliminate all rivals. One attempted rebellion by the new Islamic movement was easily defeated in 1975 as it had no popular support. As Daud tried to break with socialist policy and purge PDPA members, the party triggered an ad-hoc coup to get rid of him, led by a number of officers with left-wing sympathies. Daud was killed and PDPA took power. This much was true... in Kabul.

The Soviet Union - an invited guest becomes an invader
The communists in PDPA may well have toppled Daud and formally taken power in Afghanistan, but they continued to face a number of problems. Having a communist party in control was a radical change in government style and legitimacy instead of monarchy or Daud’s presidency. It was also the first time in 150 years that the Barakzai clan was not in control of the country. PDPA may well have had the support of the educated urban middle classes, but most of the population found the new government distant and alien.
PDPA had also been split into two rival factions since 1967: the Khalq (or “the masses”) and Parcham (which means “banner”). The two groups were united by party and ideology, but had very different ideas about methodology and leadership. Although they had, during the coup, agreed upon a joint government that would be led by President Taraki, the Khalq began to purge Parcham leaders from positions of authority by posting them overseas as ambassadors, thus ensuring that they were without influence at home.
PDPA intended to revolutionise society. Not only had they changed land ownership and written off peasants’ debts, but a number of laws had been passed that were intended to establish new social norms. This included fundamental change to gender roles and inheritance law, two areas that were completely central to the self-perception of large numbers of Afghans, both in terms of religion and ethnic identity. Before long the new communist régime would face broad popular rebellion.
The communist administration asked the Soviet Union for help to put down the rebellion. Aid was sent, initially in the form of military hardware and advisors. The situation boiled over when Hafizullah Amin, the leader of Khalq, arrested and murdered President Taraki to seize power for himself. Tensions increased between Moscow and Kabul and a large Soviet force crossed the border between the two countries on 27 December 1979. According to the Soviet Union, this was in support of their ally and was completely legitimised by the numerous requests for an intervention of this type. Hafizullah Amin was killed. His government was replaced with figures who were more Soviet-friendly and Babrak Karmal, one of the leaders of the Parcham faction, was inserted as president.
Many Afghan army units deserted and what Moscow had intended to be a quick reassertion of law and order in a neighbouring country transitioned into a war that would last for years. Instead of stabilising Afghanistan, it became a holy war against a hostile invasion.
Although the modern Afghan Islamists came from the same towns and universities as the Communists, they quickly found themselves at the forefront of the rebellion in the country. Not only were they the only movement with a cohesive ideology, but they were also a party that had already attempted armed rebellion. They were also the only faction to possess the necessary organisational capacity. After the failed revolution in 1975, many had become exiles in Pakistan. They received plenty of support from abroad, provided exclusively by the Pakistani Intelligence Agency ISI. Collectively, the scattered groups of rebels became known as the Mujahideen (singular, Mujahid) - those fighting jihad, or holy war. These fighters were as alien to Afghanistan’s rural population as the Communists, but they spoke a familiar language and had the necessary means to fight the Soviet forces for the following decade.

A PATCHWORK
As the crossroads that links India, China, Central Asia and the Middle East, Afghanistan is characterised by the numerous different factions who have tried to control the area throughout the country’s history. Controlling the area requires an understanding of its geography. Throughout their history, the Afghans have therefore been skilled at exploiting the mountainous terrain and turning hostile powers against one another to their own advantage.

About mountains, desert and rivers.
Afghanistan is split into three parts: inaccessible mountains, open steppes and desert, and the fertile river valleys. The western Himalayas, known as the Hindu Kush, dominate eastern and central Afghanistan but also branch off in all directions. They are divided into smaller groups, including the Spin Ghar mountains which became famous in 2001 when it was believed that Al-Qaeda had gone into hiding in the Tora Bora cave complex. Throughout history the mountains have always been the most difficult part of the country to govern. Apart from making payments to the tribes that controlled the most important mountain passes, and the Khyber Pass in particular, many kingdoms and governments have chosen to leave the mountains and their residents in peace. There was no permanent border between Afghanistan and its neighbours to the south-west until the Durand Line was established in 1893.
The north, west and south are generally more open. The steppes to the north continue almost endlessly, continuing through neighbouring Usbekistan, Tadsjikistan and Turkmenistan. They have been home to various nomadic peoples, sometimes subject to Afghan rules and sometimes these peoples conquered Afghanistan. Afghanistan is therefore home to large minority populations who are descended from its neighbours and the various steppe peoples who immigrated or conquered their way into the country. Nowadays many of them are farmers and large areas of steppe land in northern Afghanistan are used to grow crops. To the south and west the steppes become more and more arid, before finally turning into desert. Traditionally, only the toughest tribes have been able to exist here, and even these tribes have not lived there on a permanent basis.
The entirety of Afghanistan is traversed and irrigated by a number of rivers of various sizes, each with a source in the melted glacial ice from the peaks of the Himalayas. They often cut through the mountains, creating fertile valleys and highland plains, where towns like Kabul have been built. The rivers flow through even the most arid areas of desert, creating lines of greenery. “The Green Zone” along the Helmand river was familiar territory to the Danish troops who were stationed in the area. Through history, the river valleys and the towns that depend on them have been the key to Afghanistan. Kandahar, Herat, Kabul and many other towns are often the centres that foreign powers have tried to conquer, and from where power was centralised for the local states.

Afghanistan - a country of many peoples
Many different peoples live in Afghanistan. The most important common denominator in addition to an Afghan passport is that all of them are Muslim, be they Sunni, Shia or one of the various Sufi faiths. The two most common languages are Pashto and Dari (a Farsi dialect) but numerous other languages are spoken there. Because of unrest, inaccessible terrain and a frequently weak central power structures, a full population census has never been carried out in Afghanistan. An estimated 35 million people live in Afghanistan but this figure, as well as figures pertaining to the size of the various population groups, are ultimately impossible to confirm.
The Pashtun are the largest and most important group, comprising about 40% of the population and have governed the country for most of the last four centuries. They are the majority population in the south and east and have a presence in all large towns, where they are also often the largest group. The Durand Line crosses right through the Pashtun heartland and more Pashtun live in Pakistan than in Afghanistan. They are a minority population in Pakistan, however. Pashtun are normally defined according to three parameters: speaking Pashto, being descended from a Pashtun founding father (thus belonging to one of the clans) and following Pashtunwali, which is a kind of tribal law or code of honour. Pashtunwali places great importance on honour and reputation, which are typically gauged on the basis of courage and hospitality. A man’s honour also depends on the conduct of the women in his family. There are many people in larger towns who identify as Pashtun, even though they only speak Dari, are not members of a clan and do not follow Pashtunwali. Ethnicity is always a fluid consideration.
The next-largest group is the Tadsjiks, who represent about a quarter of Afghanistan's population. As their name suggests, they are related to the population of neighbouring Tadsjikistan where, paradoxically, fewer Tadsjiks reside than in Afghanistan. They typically live close to the border in the north east, and in the towns where they have historically been the majority population in many places. Their language is Dari. Because Dari is the traditional language of the administration and the Tadsjiks were town-dwellers, they have occupied important roles as traders, bureaucrats and scribes, though they have seldom occupied the positions of real power.
The Hazara people are the third-largest group, representing 10-15% of the population. The Hazara are Shia Muslims and mainly live in the central highlands as mountain farmers in an area known as Hazarajat. Here, they were all but independent until Abdur Rahman ,the Iron Emir, conquered the area towards the end of the 19th Century. Although they speak Dari, they are (according to their own histories) descended from Genghis Khan and his Mongolian horse tribes and often viewed with condescension by other Afghan tribes because of their race and religion.
About 10% of Afghans are Usbeks and about 5% are Turkmenians. Both groups are Turkish-speaking Sunni Muslims with close links to neighbouring Usbekistan and Turkmenistan. They live near the borders in the north and north west and are descended from the equestrian tribes who have invaded, plundered and conquered Afghanistan over the years. Usbeks and Turkmenians also comprise the majority of the nomads who still have a presence in the country.
The Chahir Aimaq are another Turkish-speaking nomadic people who live north and east of Herat. They differ from the Usbeks and Turmkenians by being clearly divided into four different tribes and represent less than 5% of Afghanistan’s population. There are also a number of smaller groups. The Nurustani and Pashai are two such groups and live in the mountains to the East. The Quizbash are a third group. They are Shia by faith but are traditionally accepted as part of Kabul’s elite. The Baluch live in the southernmost desert, have their own language and are closely related to Baluch in Iran and Pakistan. Finally, Afghanistan has historically been home to minority Arabs, Sikhs, Hindus and even a Jewish community. Most of these groups have fled the country, however, as a result of the constant warfare since the 1970s.

Foreign powers.
Since their independence in 1947 there has been a constant struggle between Pakistan and India about where the border between the two countries should lie. Because Afghanistan has its own border dispute with Pakistan, the Afghans have collaborated with India on occasion, in the hope of a reassessment of where border boundaries should lie. The two superpowers during this period were the Soviet Union and the USA, who Afghanistan also tried to play off against each other. As a monarchy it was very successful in this regard until a Communist government aligned Afghanistan too closely with the Soviet Union, who intervened in 1979 because of unrest in the country.
During the Cold War the USA feared that the invasion of Afghanistan was a Soviet attempt to continue to expand southwards towards the Indian Ocean. No matter what the Russians’ true objective was, Afghanistan was an opportunity to inflict a defeat on their rival. Large sums of money and, not least, advanced technological weaponry was sent through Pakistan to aid the rebels. Especially after 1986 the Afghans received large quantities of hardware (including Stinger missiles) for use in the fight against the Soviet occupying forces.
The Saudi viewpoint was that an atheist communist state had invaded an Islamic nation. This was at a time when the Saudis themselves were facing internal pressure from extremist factions who did not consider the kingdom to be sufficiently Islamic. Money from oil began to flow in and the extremists were able to fight a holy war far from home, where they posed no threat to the Saudi king. Many Saudis and other Arabs travelled to Pakistan to join the Afghan resistance as volunteers. The most famous of these was Osama bin Laden, who used this network of volunteers as the base for the creation of al-Qaeda.
General Zia ul-Haq had seized power in Pakistan through a military coup. To ensure popular support he stood at the forefront of an Islamisation process within Pakistan. When he and his ISI intelligence agency became the intermediary for sending money, volunteers and hardware to Afghan rebels, he therefore favoured the Islamic factions. This allowed him to show the people of his country that he was a good Muslim, the Americans that he was anti-communist and, perhaps at some time in the future, an Afghan government would come to rely on him and permit the movement of the Durand Line to a position that favoured Pakistan.
The Mujahideen would muster at bases in Pakistan, where they would be equipped and trained before continuing on to Afghanistan to fight against the Soviet Union. The many refugees from the war who now lived in Pakistani towns like Quetta and Peshawar were an obvious source of recruits. Many were also schooled at Saudi-sponsored Islamic madrasa schools, which were often the only education option available to refugees. Young men would be radicalised and encouraged to join the Mujahideen. Local rebel groups inside Afghanistan also felt the need to align themselves with one of the Islamist groups in order to receive a share of the international aid.

Civil war and collapse
As time went on, it became obvious to Moscow that the war in Afghanistan was unwinnable. It has often been called “The Soviet Vietnam” because of terrible losses during a tough guerilla campaign. This happened at the same time as a new Soviet leader came to power; Mikhail Gorbachev, who was far more interested in domestic reforms than military campaigns abroad. A treaty was negotiated in 1988 that led to the withdrawal of the last remaining Soviet forces from Afghanistan in the spring of 1989.
The Communist régime in Afghanistan managed to survive for another couple of years, partly because it still received large amounts of economic aid. This aid evaporated with the fall of the Soviet Union and the Communist régime fell apart in April 1992. The resistance had no overall leadership, however, and none of the various Mujahideen groups were strong enough to dominate the others. The years that followed were characterised by lawlessness and civil war between various warlords, each of whom wanted to control the country.
Where the conflict had previously been limited to rural areas it now spread to the towns. Kabul was thoroughly devastated and represented the prize that everybody was trying to win.

TALIBAN
When the Soviet Union departed from Afghanistan in 1989 it was the country in the world with the largest number of circulating firearms. The various rebel factions, who had fought against the Communists more or less as a unified force, would be able to topple the Communist régime in the years that followed. The rebels were, however, unable to agree about who should govern Afghanistan afterwards. And as the Cold War came to an end, the global superpowers were no longer interested in Afghanistan. It would collapse during the 1990s and be divided up between various warlords, who had now started fighting each other. A new puritanical movement arose in refugee camps in the Pashtun heartland, one that wanted to return order to Afghanistan.

Communists, warlords and chaos.
After the Soviet Union had recalled its troops, the Communist régime in Afghanistan was able to remain in power under the leadership of President Najibullah, even though many people anticipated that it would collapse. The various rebel factions attempted to occupy larger towns, but had no unified command structure or combat experience other than guerilla warfare in inaccessible areas. Taking a fortified town was a completely different type of mission and elements of the Afghan military remained loyal to the régime.
Many local rebel groups were also willing to fight as paid militias on behalf of Najibullah. Najibullah’s survival was still dependent on Russia, however. Even though the Soviets had withdrawn their forces from Afghanistan, he continued to receive large amounts of funding and materials from Moscow. When the Soviet Union collapsed at the end of 1991, he lost the support of a superpower and and the funding to pay the militias dried up. Najibullah's régime was toppled the following April.
The militias were autonomous once again and the remnants of the régime would more often than not join them. Attempts were made to broker an agreement and the leaders of the various factions who had organised the ongoing conflict gathered in Peshawar, were they were able establish a provisional government that united the largest factions. The party leaders in Peshawar were distanced from the Mujahideen leaders who had fought the war in Afghanistan, however, and they saw this as their opportunity to take control or lose everything that they had built.
The provisional government quickly collapsed. President Rabbani and Prime Minister Hekmatyar were both politicians who had sat out the war from Pakistan. Both were supported by their own Mujahideen and militias and soon ended up warring against each other over control of Kabul. Meanwhile, the last vestiges of authority in the country collapsed and forces that had previously had a formal loyalty to one or other faction took affair autonomously over their own local communities. The various warlords tried to defeat each other, or formed alliances with former enemies to gain any necessary advantage. None of them were able to unite the country, however and the superpowers were no longer interested. Only Pakistan continued to have a commitment, supporting Hekmatyar but unable to secure power on his behalf when Iran supplied the Rabbani faction with armaments.
Accordingly, Afghanistan continued over the years that followed to be deadlocked in a bloody civil war in which local warlords each ruled over their own districts with an iron fist, while continuing to war against each other. They became wealthy through plunder and by charging taxes and tolls on all traffic through their territories, while being free to murder, rape and otherwise suppress their local populations at their whim.

Taliban: A Pashtun student movement.
It was out of all this chaos that the Taliban would rise. Countless numbers of Afghans lived in refugee camps in Pakistan, where many young men had been born or grown up since the days of the Soviet Union's occupation of Afghanistan. Their only point of reference was stories about their homeland and the quasi-mythical Mujahideen who were courageously fighting a jihad to defend Islam against the atheists from the Soviet Union. Many of these refugees had, as children, only received one kind of schooling in the underfunded camps, at the Islamic madrasa schools, which were often funded by Saudi Arabia and where they were taught a very puritanical version of Islam.
The heroes of the Mujahideen had now become the warlords who raped, pillaged and destroyed their own homeland with their constant infighting. The disillusioned young men from the refugee camps therefore united around a movement, the core membership of which was comprised of Pashto-speaking refugees who had studied at the madrasas. They gave themselves a simple name, “the Students. Or in Pashto, Taliban.
The original roots and formation of the Taliban have almost mythological status. It is very hard to discern what is fact and what is fiction What is known is that the movement first saw light (and perhaps was founded) as an actual organisation in 1994, in a number of actions in and near to Kandahar. A one-eyed veteran of the war against the Soviet Union, known as Mullah Omar, ran a small madrasa in the desert in the southern region of the Pashtun territories. Like many others, he was horrified by the way that the Mujahideen had wasted the potential of their victory over the Soviet Union because of their infighting. When two young girls were kidnapped and raped by a local warlord, Mullah Omar assembled a dozen volunteers. Despite being poorly armed, they stormed the warlord’s home, liberated the girls and hung the warlord from the gun of his own tank.
This became a form of branding for Mullah Omar and the Taliban. Many warlords and militia commanders would end up dead. By carrying out actions like these and reopening trade routes in the areas where they had killed the local warlords, the Taliban quickly found popularity as a party of “law and order”. For many Afghans, the Taliban’s promise of peace and stability weighed far heavier than their radical interpretation of Islam.
By the end of 1994 they had taken Kandahar, from where they governed most of the Pashtun territories in Afghanistan. There was a flood of volunteers, many of whom were young men from the refugee camps. Many local Pashtun militiamen also left their militias to join the Taliban. After Hekmatyar’s previous failed attempts to occupy Kabul and govern the country, Pakistan decided to change tactics and began supporting the Taliban, who benefited from Pakistani arms and military advisors.
The civil war continued, even though the Taliban had begun to get involved. With an enormous basis for recruitment in the refugee camps, support from Pakistan and fighters with the conviction of their faith, they made massive progress and took town after town over the years that followed. They were often welcomed as heroes bringing a long-awaited peace, but it would not be long before rumours began to circulate about how the Taliban’s peace was administered. The difference was particularly noticeable in areas outside the Pashtun region, where the population was more ethnically diverse, where the common language was Dari and where there was a more international outlook. Despite tough resistance, the Taliban were able to gain control of most of Afghanistan. The remaining Mujahideen and warlords united in the Northern Alliance and remained in control of a few regions which the Taliban would never be able to occupy.

The Taliban régime
When Kabul was taken in September 1996, it seemed that the Taliban had won and that they had managed to succeed where the Mujahideen and the warlords had failed. They ruled most of the country and declared the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan as a united Islamic state. Only in the northern regions of Afghanistan were the remaining warlords able to continue their resistance against the Taliban fighters.
The Taliban régime introduced a number of reforms and laws that not only reversed the process of modernisation and women’s rights that previous Communist régime and the monarchy had tried to implement, but went a lot further. To the rest of the world, the Burka became a symbol of Afghanistan, when Afghan women were forced to wear them. Men were also required by law to grow a beard that was at least the length of a clenched fist on their chins. Banned books were burned and music, television and photography were forbidden. Traditional play activities for children such as kite flying and pigeon racing were also impacted. Other religions were no longer tolerated and many historic treasures were destroyed. The most famous of these were the world’s largest statues of the Buddha, two statues carved into the hillside at Bamiyan, which were blown up despite attempts by leading Islamic scholars from all over the world to convince the Taliban to preserve them.
The legal system was based on an extreme interpretation of Sharia, with a strong dose of Pashtunwali, the code of honour of the Pashtun tribes. Penalties such as stoning, chopping off hands and other similar punishments became standard practice in Afghanistan for the first time in centuries. Only the most radical Pashtun elements in the Taliban movement found this satisfactory. Most people found this system repugnant and repressive. Members of other ethnic groups viewed this as the extreme code of the Pashtun, yet even many Pashtun; and particularly town dwellers, were also hostile to this system in a variety of ways. Many minorities experienced persecution, most notably the Shia Muslim Hazar people, who were viewed as heretics by the puritanical Sunni Muslims of the Taliban.
Internationally, the Taliban régime was only recognised by Pakistan, Saudi-Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. It was never given a seat at the UN. It was instead highly criticised and sanctioned by the international community, notably because of the régime’s human rights violations and its exploitation of the illegal production and trafficking of opium as a source of state funding.
During the war against the Soviet Union, Afghanistan’s Mujahideen had accepted many volunteers from elsewhere in the Islamic world who wanted to take part in the fighting. From this base of volunteers sprang the al-Qaeda network, led by Osama bin Laden, who declared a worldwide jihad against the West. Few Afghans, Taliban or otherwise, took part in al-Qaeda operations but the régime did allow them to use Afghanistan as their base, as they had on occasion for other Islamic groups from other countries.
After al-Qaeda members set off two bombs at American embassies in Tanzania and Kenya, causing over 200 deaths, the international community began to take the threat of al-Qaeda and its bases in Afghanistan a lot more seriously. Even after the Americans retaliated by launching a cruise missile attack on al-Qaeda's camps in Afghanistan, Mullah Omar and the Taliban leadership refused to expel Osama bin Laden for international prosecution. Their response was that hospitality is an extremely important aspect of Pashtunwali and that a guest should enjoy the protection of their host, no matter what. Their unshakeable resolve to allow bin Laden and al-Qaeda to operate with impunity from Afghanistan would lead to the fall of the Taliban a few years later, after al-Qaeda made its biggest attack on the USA in 2001.

AFTER 11 SEPTEMBER
The Taliban régime would not be in power in Afghanistan for many years. Only five years after the Taliban took Kabul, al-Qaeda carried out the biggest terrorist attack the world had ever seen on 11 September 2001. The attack had been orchestrated at camps in Afghanistan. A US-led international coalition in which Denmark took part entered Afghanistan and toppled the Taliban régime. Removing the régime was only the first step, however. Although the Taliban was almost eliminated as an organisation after its defeat, its remnants continued to fight a drawn-out guerilla war against the new Afghan government and international forces in the country.

The 11 September attacks
Four passenger planes were hijacked in US airspace on 11 September 2001. Two of them flew into the twin towers of the World Trade Center, the two tallest in New York and an international symbol of free trade and America. One hit the Pentagon, headquarters of the U.S. Department of Defense. The fourth plane crashed in a field in Pennsylvania when passengers had subdued the hijackers. The plane was believed to be headed for the White House or another target in Washington D.C. These attacks took the lives of nearly 3,000 people and shook Americans and the international community. The attacks were masterminded from bases in Afghanistan by the international terrorist organisation Al-Qaeda, led by Osama bin Laden. Soon afterwards US President George W. Bush declared an international war on terror. The goal of this war was to defeat Al-Qaeda and similar terrorist groups and to punish states that supported them or allowed them to operate in their territories – primarily Afghanistan, where the 9/11 attacks had been planned.
The UN Security Council convened on multiple occasions during September and unanimously voted to adopt Resolutions 1368 and 1373 (2001). The resolutions were a confirmation that the UN considered this action to be an attack on the US and a threat to international peace and security. They recognised the right of the US and its allies to independent and collective self defence and encouraged all UN member states to cooperate in bringing the culprits to justice and to oppose all organisations with links to international terrorism. NATO member states also held a summit to activate Article V of the North Atlantic Treaty, which is also known as the “Musketeer oath”, as an attack on one member state is considered an attack on all member states.
A number of initiatives were set in motion, including allowing intelligence agencies to operate at higher intensity and at greater levels of mutual collaboration. The large-scale NATO Operation Active Endeavour commenced patrols in the Mediterranean. Danish ships also took part in this operation at various times. One single demand was presented to the Taliban régime - that it should hand over Osama bin Laden and al-Qaeda. As before, Mullah Omar refused, referring to the Pashtunwali code of hospitality. He did concede that if it could be proven that bin Laden had indeed planned the attacks, then he had himself breached this code and could justifiably expelled. The Americans dismissed this as delaying tactics. Meanwhile, Mullah Omar issued a reminder of Afghanistan’s status as the graveyard of empires. According to the Taliban, the Americans would suffer the same fate as the Russians and British who had preceded them.

Operation Enduring Freedom and The New Afghanistan.
The USA refused to be intimidated by the Mullah’s threats. On 7 October 2001, American and British aircraft commenced a series of air attacks against Taliban positions in Afghanistan, in coordination with an offensive by the Northern Alliance. These would be followed up by special forces. Already on 19 October, the first couple of hundred American troops arrived from bases in Usbekistan, followed by British special forces the following week.
Mullah Omar had promised that the graveyard of empires would also stop the Americans, but just ten weeks after the first attack, the Taliban was in full retreat throughout Afghanistan. Their first defeats came in the North and West, where they had never consolidated their power. In these areas the local Usbeks and Tadsjiks were overjoyed by the arrival of the Northern Alliance. Kabul was liberated on 13 November, with virtually no Taliban resistance. The Taliban had withdrawn from the town, hoping to regroup in their Pashtun-dominated core territories in the South and East. Pashtun clan leaders saw this, however, as an opportunity to take back their traditional power. The Taliban were driven out of Kandahar, their most important town, by local Pashtun tribes led by Hamid Karzai. Mullah Omar and the remnants of the Taliban fled to the mountains to the East and crossed the border to Pakistan.
This time, the Afghans did not rise up to drive the foreign troops out of their country, as many had otherwise expected. After constant wars and instability since the 1970s, most Afghans wanted Afghanistan to be a peaceful country that could make economic progress and hoped that the Americans would be able to bring this about. Meanwhile, huge numbers of refugees and their children returned from neighbouring countries.
The UN then organised a major conference in the German city of Bonn in December, which was attended by prominent leaders from the various Afghan factions. It seemed at the beginning of the conference that ageing ex-king Zahir Shah, who had lived as an exile since the 1973 coup, had the greatest amount of support. The result, however, was that Pashtun clan leader Hamid Karzai was appointed the leader of Afghanistan’s provisional administration, alongside a number of ministers who would govern until a more permanent solution could be implemented. Karzai is a descendant of Ahmed Shah Durrani, the founder of Afghanistan in the 18th Century.
While the conference was proceeding in Bonn, discussions were also underway about the planning of the first Danish contribution. The newly-elected Danish Prime Minister, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, was absolutely determined to provide a Danish contribution to support the Americans and the British, as soon as possible. Parliamentary proposal B37 was given an emergency reading and was put forward, discussed and adopted by a broad majority in the Danish Parliament on 13 and 14 December. The Danish Parliament hereby consented to Denmark’s provision of special forces, a C-130 Hercules transport aircraft and four F-16 fighter aircraft to the operation in Afghanistan.
The first Danish Jaeger troops arrived in Kandahar just a week later, on 21 December. This was an advance unit that would perform reconnaissance and make preparations for the remainder of the force. The Hercules they flew in on was already operating the following day, flying transport missions for the Americans. The rest of the force arrived in January and was comprised of approx. 100 Danish Jaeger soldiers and men from the Frogmen Corps. They took part in a number of missions in collaboration with the American forces, including Operation Anaconda in the Shahi-Kot mountains, which would be the final actual battle against the Taliban and al-Qaeda in Afghanistan. After this engagement, most of these groups had fled to the Pashtun tribal regions in north-west Pakistan.
Now that the Taliban had been driven out, a national Loya Jirga was held in June 2002. A Loya Jirga is a traditional tribal council that, throughout Afghan history, has legitimised important decisions or sitting governments. It adopted what had been agreed at the conference in Bonn and a new transitional government was appointed to prepare a constitution and democratic elections, headed by Hamid Karzai.

ISAF, NATO and Denmark in Afghanistan.
Soon after the conference in Bonn, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1386 on 20 December 2001. This set out the framework for an international military force that would support the provisional government, led by Hamid Karzai. The UN wanted to combine a large-scale force with a legal mandate under international law that would be able to guarantee security during the building of local Afghan military and police forces. This was given the name “International Security Assistance Force” (ISAF).
ISAF’s initial focus for the 5,000 strong deployment was to make the area in and around Kabul safe, broadening its presence to the rest of the country over various phases. The first Danish contribution to ISAF was primarily army sappers/engineers who would clear mines and unexploded munitions that could be found everywhere after decades of war. The Danish contribution also included liaison and logistics officers, as well as a Civilian-Military Cooperation (CIMIC) team.
During this time ISAF command rotated every sixth month among the participating nations who had volunteered support. The force was therefore commanded at various times by countries which included the United Kingdom, Turkey and Germany. Finding someone who was willing and able to assume command was not always an easy task, however. As most participating countries were already members of NATO, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1510 in October 2003, transferring the operation to NATO. The resolution also expanded ISAF’s mandate to cover the whole of Afghanistan. This was necessary, partly due to a reduced US involvement in the country after its invasion of Saddam Hussein's Iraq, and partly because the Taliban who had been driven out in 2002 had regrouped in the border territories and had returned to Afghanistan with renewed strength.
The expansion took place over four phases. During the first phase, ISAF expanded to cover northern Afghanistan from December 2003. The second phase was launched in February 2005, covering the western part of the country. The third phase began in July 2006, when ISAF assumed control of the southern provinces, where the Taliban had their strongest foothold. Finally, the eastern provinces came under ISAF control in October 2006, which meant that the operation now covered the whole of Afghanistan. The greatest resistance was seen during phases three and four, when the operation moved into the Pashtun homelands where the Taliban had originated and had now reasserted control in certain regions.
All the various methods that were applied by ISAF can be grouped under two overriding principles: Light Footprint and Afghan Face. Common to both principles was the intention that ISAF should not be considered an occupying force similar to the one deployed by the Soviet Union during the 1980s. Light Footprint meant that only a few armed units would be stationed in the area whenever possible. Instead, Provincial Reconstruction Teams (PRT) were deployed, combining and integrating military and civilian support that would help to rebuild the broken country. Afghan Face was all about making the various projects around the country Afghan projects rather than international community projects. The Afghans would thus themselves be responsible for the performance and selection of the various projects, receiving only funding and advice from the international community.
Denmark contributed various different types of support to ISAF at many different locations in Afghanistan. The first of these was the deployment of army engineers to Kabul. As part of the first (northern) phase, Denmark deployed 45 personnel to the German-commanded Fazabad mission. As ISAF expanded west, Denmark's contribution included a smaller contingent to a Lithuanian PRT in Chaghcharan. Denmark’s biggest contribution took place during the third phase, in the south of Afghanistan. An initial deployment of 200 personnel (that would eventually increase to 700 Danish troops at one time) was sent to the Helmand province. This was one of the most unstable regions of Afghanistan and the deployed troops would be involved on several occasions in difficult combat engagements against the Taliban, while facing a constant threat from roadside explosive devices (IEDs). In addition to these pronounced contributions, Denmark also deployed Operational Mentoring and Liaison Teams (OMLTs) on multiple occasions. These are small teams whose role was to train, advise and mentor Afghan army units, with the aim that Afghan security forces would eventually be able to gain full control of the region.
At its peak in 2010 the international military contribution numbered approximately 150,000 troops. This number would gradually decrease. ISAF formally withdrew from Afghanistan in 2014, as security had been transferred to Afghan army and police units throughout the country. At the request of the Afghan government, Denmark and the international community continued to maintain their commitment in Afghanistan, however. Denmark continued to provide support to Afghanistan as part of Resolute Support Mission (RSM), a mission that does not involve combat units. The priority here was to train security forces and officials so that Afghanistan will be able to assume responsibility for its own national development.

DEVELOPMENT
The Taliban régime was toppled at the end of 2001. A provisional government that would be headed by Hamid Karzai was agreed at the Bonn conference. Not only was Afghanistan in ruins after decades of war, but it had never actually even had a modern infrastructure, schools and hospitals outside its cities. Its population had no real experience of democracy, beyond the traditional tribal council and corruption was rife. Rebuilding Afghanistan has been a massive task ever since, both in terms of the physical aspects and when it came to setting up robust institutions and security forces that would be able to govern the country going forward.

From Loya Jirga to referendums.
Hamid Karzai and the provisional government that had been appointed at the conference in Bonn sat for half a year until a Loya Jirga (a traditional tribal council) was convened to appoint a new transitional government. Over the course of one month during the summer of 2002, approximately 1,600 delegates from the various tribes, clans, communities, ethnicities and regions discussed the course of future events. At the Loya Jirga, a broad cross-section of Afghans accepted the decisions that were made at the Bonn conference, on Afghan soil. Karzai and his government were thus given a mandate to continue for up to two years, with a view to drawing up a constitution and conducting democratic elections.
Another Loya Jirga was convened in December 2003. This time it was attended by 500 delegates from various groups and factions, one quarter of whom were women. The purpose this time was to adopt a constitution. The biggest issue was a discussion of the degree to which power should be assigned to a president in Kabul, or whether it should be increasingly delegated to the individual regions and provinces. The final constitution was adopted, with a strong presidential powers but with provincial councils to take care of local issues. Karzai continued as president in the transitional government that had been appointed to get things ready for actual presidential elections. When these were held the following year, they proceeded relatively peacefully. Karzai was elected to the position as the first democratically elected head of state in Afghanistan’s history.
In the meantime, the Taliban had resurfaced. After being driven out at the beginning of 2002, they had regrouped in the uncontrollable Pashtun border territories, primarily on the Pakistani side of the Durand Line. During 2003 and 2004 they returned, particularly in the south of Afghanistan where the roots of the movement had been established. Formally, the area was under the control of the Afghan government and American troops. Because of the US invasion of Iraq in 2003, many American units had been withdrawn, as many Westerners believed that the Taliban had been completely defeated rather than scattered.
The first parliamentary elections were held in 2005, after being postponed for a year. The Taliban and other opposition groups had sworn to prevent the elections from being held, but things proceeded relatively peacefully, regardless. Even though Karzai had been quick and willing to organise the presidential elections that would cement his own position, he was not all that keen on the idea of parliamentary elections that would establish another power within the state. Arguing that the population perceived political parties to be part of Communism, Karzai banned them for the elections and forced every candidate to stand as an independent, rather than as a block that would be able to oppose him. Parliament became a power factor anyway and was able to block some of Karzai’s decisions and to reorganise the legal system and judiciary that had been appointed by Karzai and the transitional government.
Karzai’s presidency was due to end in May 2009. Because of the highly unstable security situation the election was postponed by three months, during which he continued to sit as president despite serious criticism. He won the August elections a second time, but over 2,000 complaints were filed about fraud or voter intimidation. After a long investigation, a rerun was called, but his opponent and former foreign minister Abduallah Abdullah decided to step down. Hamid Karzai’s presidency came to a definitive end in 2014, as the constitution forbade him for standing for a third term. This made him not only the first democratically-elected head of the Afghan state, but also the first in over a century to step down without being assassinated or forced into exile. Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah were the main candidates for the presidential post after Karzai. The elections were characterised by a lively and pluralistic media debate. Many Afghan defied Taliban threats and cast their vote anyway. About a third of all votes cast were cast by women. The elections were close, so close in fact that one candidate won at the first count and the other after a recount. After a short period of inertia a solution was found, whereby Ghani would be president and Abdullah would serve in a newly-created “administrative director” position, which is often compared with that of prime minister.
There would be parliamentary elections again in 2016. Before these could take place a new voter-registration system had to be set up, which turned out to be easier said than done. The elections were therefore postponed several times, but a new system was eventually introduced and the elections were finally held in 2018.

Security forces, stability and problem areas.
Initially, Afghanistan’s security forces were comprised of people from the Northern Alliance and other armed factions who had foreseen the overthrow of the Taliban and who had got out while they still had the chance. There had been no real government in large areas of Afghanistan for a long time and even before the wars of the late 20th Century, police and local officials had been more interested in lining their own pockets than helping the Afghan population. This meant that the task of building a robust and credible police force, army and state institutions that would be worthy of the population’s trust would be immense.
Afghanistan’s security forces were officially formed by a presidential decree in 2002. Recruits began to be accepted for training that would establish a new core force. Initially, the various armed groups would at times end up on the official payroll but would be gradually integrated into an actual police force and armed forces. The Afghan National Army (ANA) and Afghan National Police (ANP) are the two de facto security forces in Afghanistan.. A number of specialised police units also exist.
The police and armed forces have seldom been well-paid career options in Afghanistan and, even though salaries have been raised, corruption continued to represent a serious challenge. Rising to a senior position was as likely to be based on having the right contacts as it was to actual suitability. Small decisions were often sent all the way to the top, especially if they involve supplies and fuel.
The security forces were making some progress, however. Not only have their wages increased. The force also increased in size from virtually nothing to approximately 350,000 personnel when the police and armed forces were combined. Professional standards were also far higher now than previously. More and more personnel received training abroad or from the international training missions in Afghanistan, or by colleagues who have been trained internationally. The police had largely transitioned away from tasks such as guard duties and fighting insurgents towards operating as a more “normal” police force. The Taliban and other militant groups remained a challenge, especially in rural areas and in the south and east, but dealing with them was largely been left to the ANA. Negotiations were also conducted in parallel with Taliban and other militant groups that oppose the state.
Illiteracy continues to be a serious problem in Afghanistan, as only about half of all men and a quarter of all women are able to read. Despite multiple attempts at modernisation during the 20th Century and investment in education and compulsory schooling, education never became widespread outside the larger towns. This means that finding qualified recruits was a major challenge, not just for the ANP but also for the administration and the political system. Many of Afghanistan's political leaders were therefore Afghans who spent the war years in the West, often attending prestigious universities. This weaked their legitimacy with regard to how they were viewed by the broader population.
Women’s rights also continued to be a problem. Men and women have equal status by law and all forms of violence against women are specifically forbidden. Yet in many places, and especially in the Pashtun areas where the Taliban originated, women’s rights continued to be face pressure from conservative forces. A woman’s virtue is a central concept of Pashtunwali and a man's honour is highly dependent on it. Arranged marriages continue to be the norm in many places. A woman often has not other choice than to abscond from the wedding, which can lead to revenge attacks by the offended clan if no compensation is paid or no other woman is found to marry the young man. Progress was being made, however. Several women's rights groups and refuges for women who have suffered violence were set up. More and more women received education, taking up political positions and, as stated previously, were more likely to vote in elections than was expected by many.
The Afghan state has always been strongest in the towns, growing weaker the further you go into rural areas. This continues to be the case. The international contribution also reflected this in its “Inkdrop” strategy, in which there was focus on a single market town (as was the case with the Danish mission in Gereshk), creating a safe environment and development that locals were able to really feel and notice, allowing it to gradually spread to larger and larger areas.

Afghanistan - now and in the future
Afghanistan was undoubtedly a far better place than it was in 2001. About a third or more of Afghanistan’s population still lives below the poverty line and certain regions are still unsafe, but Afghanistan saw stable economic growth over recent years. About 70% of the population is less than 25 years old and the labour force is growing by about 400,000 a year. If no jobs are available and the young population is unable to see that it has a future, it will be far more likely to join groups like the Taliban or get involved with the illegal but lucrative opium trade, in which Afghanistan continues to be the biggest manufacturer.
The vast majority of the budget (almost 90%) was in 2020 financed by foreign aid. State institutions remained weak and were having difficulty collecting taxes, as the country is generally poor and parts of the economy are lost to corruption. Aid from the international community continues to be important, both in terms of financing the Afghan state until it can achieve full autonomy and in terms of combating corruption and developing its national institutions. The Taliban have been battling the state for years and, continue to have a serious impact on peace and stability. There was plenty to suggest that the best way to bring the war and unrest to a close would be through a negotiated solution in which the Taliban and other factions were able to occupy a legitimate role within society.
If Afghanistan is to achieve real stability and a well-functioning state system there is still a lot of work that remains to be done. It still needs aid and support from a world that has a past record of forgetting about it when it is no longer essential to the strategic interests of the world’s superpowers.

SETBACK

Hope for Afghanistan was finally extinguished in 2021.
Through two decades, the Taliban fought a comprehensive guerrilla war against the international forces in Afghanistan and its elected government, as well as setting up bases in neighbouring Pakistan. The West attempted to establish peace in Afghanistan by entering into agreements with the Taliban in the hope of ending the war. In February 2020, the USA successfully negotiated a peace treaty with the Taliban that would ensure a peaceful transfer of power when international forces moved out of the country during 2021. The president of the USA, Joe Biden, announced in the Spring of 2021 that American armed forces would be out of Afghanistan before 11 September of the same year. This was a symbolic date, as it was exactly 20 years after Al-Qaeda launched its terrorist attack on the USA, which was the reason why the USA invaded Afghanistan.

The announcement by the USA of a full withdrawal was the beginning of the end of the protracted war in Afghanistan, but also gave the Taliban fresh hope that it would be able to achieve its own ambitions and intended course for the country. As international forces withdrew from Afghanistan, the country’s government and military collapsed completely, partly because the Taliban had regained territory at a much faster rate than had been predicted.
On 15 August 2021, the Taliban moved into the capital city, Kabul, as the last of Afghanistan’s larger key towns, and President Ashraf Ghani fled the country. At the same time, almost all nations began to evacuate their personnel, journalists and other foreigners, as well as select Afghanis who had recently worked for the international forces and embassies. August 2021 saw the Taliban declare itself as the victor of the war as Western diplomats and local Afghans fled the country in fear of the consequences of the Taliban’s return to power after 20 years of war.

The Taliban have now taken power and declared that the war is over. As yet, it remains to be seen what the future has to offer the population of Afghanistan.

DESCRIPTION
The Balkans are a patchwork of ethnicity and religion with very deep roots in history. They are the borderlands between the Ottoman and Habsburg empires, with a fluid population and ambitions of power and domination. The seeds of nationalism were sown and would grow into new problems and new opportunities. More recently this would result in the formation of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, united by a strong centralised power figureheaded by Tito.
It became a popular tourist destination and hosted the 1984 Winter Olympic games in Sarajevo, but beneath the surface the ever-present tensions continued to simmer. How could it be possible to hold a federation together that was comprised of six republics and two autonomous provinces whose names we know today because of the events of the late 20th Century? Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Kosovo, Serbia, Montenegro and Macedonia.
Yugoslavia and the Balkans broke apart in and around 1990. After 1992 we begin to learn new names and concepts: ethnic cleansing, siege, massacre, Srebrenica, war crimes, UNPROFOR, white-painted Danish Leopard tanks, IFOR and SFOR and the Dayton Agreement. Thousands of Danes from Danish Defence, the Danish Police and the Danish Emergency Management Agency would serve in this corner of Europe between 1992 and 2005 as part of UN forces, UN police deployments, OSCE, UN emergency aid services etc. or as part of the post-1995 UN presence, continuing to assist in the EU commitment that followed it.
This is a complex period of European history. If you would like to learn more about it, read the chapters that follow. They are very interesting reading .

UP TO THE 1980s
The Balkans have long been an area where many different cultures have been able to come together as friends or face each other as competitors and warring factions. A number of tribes migrated to the region from the North and East during the early Middle Ages. The common denominator of these tribes was that they all spoke dialects of the Slavic language that was also widespread in what is now Russia, the Czech Republic and Poland. As the southernmost Slavic people, they would over time become known as the Southern Slavs, or Yugo Slavija in Slavic. Although they were able to communicate with each other, there were regional differences between the Yugoslavian dialects, varying from Slovenian in the North to Macedonian in the South. The various regions would shift between warring, making alliances and trading among themselves and with their neighbours. As time went on, they would unite as various principalities and kingdoms and missionaries would arrive from neighbouring countries to convert the pagan Slavs to Christianity.
The orthodox patriarch in Constantinople and the Catholic Pope in Rome both tried to convert the people of the region to their own differing interpretations of Christianity. Eventually a vague boundary line would be drawn through what is now present-day Bosnia-Herzegovina. North and West of this line, Croats and Slovenians were baptised as Roman Catholics and learned the Roman alphabet. Groups in the South and East like the Serbs and Montenegrins were, conversely, baptised by missionaries who had been sent from Byzantium. These regions therefore use the same Cyrillic alphabet as is used in Russian and they are part of the Orthodox Church. Despite the differences in religious observance and alphabet there were no major problems. Even today, a Serb and a Croat can understand each other’s conversation, even though they may find it difficult to understand each other’s writing.
As the Middle Ages drew to a close the independent South Slavic principalities came to an end too. The Ottoman empire had grown powerful in the East and the Serbs found themselves besieged by the Ottomans in 1389 at Kosovo Polje. After this battle large areas of the Balkans would be absorbed into the Ottoman Empire. During this period the Croats and Slovenians would also gradually submit to Hungarian rule.

Between Istanbul and Vienna.
The population was not only divided between two different interpretations of the Christian faith, but they were now being ruled by two of the greatest superpowers in Europe, who also happened to be one another’s greatest rivals. Countless wars and smaller conflicts raged in the Balkans for centuries between the Habsburg Monarchy (or Empire) that was ruled by its monarch in Vienna and the Ottoman Empire that was ruled by the Sultan in Istanbul. This meant that the southern Slavic peoples often found themselves on different sides during warfare and were influenced by two different cultures. The Ottoman Empire was multi-ethnic and multi-faith. Because it was a mainly Muslim empire, however, there were a number of social and economic benefits available for those who belonged to the Muslim faith. Many of the Sultan’s subjects therefore decided to convert to Islam, even though most European provinces in the Ottoman Empire remained Christian. Well-functioning multi-faith societies arose, especially in the vicinity of large towns that also functioned as administrative centres, like Sarajevo and Mostar. Many people did, however, decide to leave their homes or had to flee as a result of war and oppression. Thousands of Serbs therefore migrated north during the 17th and 18th Centuries, where they were given land as settlers in otherwise Croat, Slovenian and Hungarian regions that were ruled from Vienna. There was one requirement, however. They would have to continue living in the militarised borderland regions and assist in their defence. In Croatia they therefore became known as Krajina Serbs. “Krajina” means “border” in Serbo-Croat. In areas like Vojvodina that were otherwise Hungarian and near the Croatian town of Knin, Krajina Serbs would become a majority population.
What would eventually evolve into Yugoslavia was therefore an area of highly diverse ethnicity and faith. Protestants, Catholics, Orthodox and Muslims; Romanians, Hungarians, Turks, Italians, Albanians, Greeks and Bulgarians, in addition to Serbs, Croats, Bosnians, Slovenians, Macedonians and Montenegrins. Although rebellion against Istanbul or Vienna was planned on various occasions on the basis of arguments like ethnic or national oppression, it is worth remembering that the various religious and ethnic communities were able to co-exist on an everyday basis without serious friction. The various groups co-existed in perfect harmony until the 19th Century. Conflicts were seldom due to ethnicity and were instead wars of “big politics” between and Emperor and a Sultan or between local princes and the central authority.

World War and Revolution.
During the 19th Century the region was therefore divided into various important cultures that were each headed in their own direction. Some looked to Istanbul for leadership, while others looked to Vienna. The region has harsh mountainous terrain and with war and flight a constant reality, its people had become tough and independent.
Nationalism finally arrived in the region and people began to view themselves as part of communities that were based on language, ethnicity, faith or some other factor. The Serbs eventually won self-rule from the Ottoman Empire at the beginning of the 19th Century and would later achieve full independence. The Croats and Slovenians had meanwhile also been able to attain a greater degree of autonomy within the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
Bosnia, which had been an Ottoman province, was occupied by Austro-Hungarian forces in 1878 during the same period as its neighbouring country had begun to envisage a Kingdom of Greater Serbia and others had begun talking about a Yugoslavian Union. At the end of the 19th Century the Balkans were therefore considered to be the powder keg of Europe, where there was potential for armed conflict as the Ottoman Empire collapsed. As the Balkan Wars were underway in the early 20th Century, the participating nations: Bulgaria, Serbia, Greece and Montenegro hurried to occupy Ottoman regions to ensure a stronger competitive basis against each other. During the summer of 1914 a group of young Bosnian Serbs with nationalist ambitions for a united Greater Serbia was successful in its attempt to assassinate Duke Franz Ferdinand, the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, during his visit to Sarajevo. The diplomatic crisis that followed initially escalated into a war between Austro-Hungary and Serbia but would soon, after interference by European superpowers (for a variety of motives) evolve into the First World War.
Both the Emperor of Austro-Hungary and the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire would see their empires collapse. States took their own chunks from what was left, while the nationalist movements in each empire fought to secede as independent states in the new world order that would rise from the ashes of world war. Even though Serbia had been under Austro-Hungarian occupation for most of the war, it found itself on the winning side and the king of Serbia was declared King of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenians, which would later be renamed the Kingdom of Yugoslavia. This first united version of Yugoslavia was, however, characterised by the fact that it had been founded by and was governed from Serbia. The populations of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Montenegro, Kosovo and Macedonia were considered to be Serbian, whether they liked it or not. The Croats and Slovenians wanted a more federal state. This first Kingdom of Yugoslavia was therefore unstable and saw military coups, political assassinations and various attempts to reform its internal political system. When a government under pressure came out on the side of Germany in 1941 during the Second World War, the people responded by demonstrating and a coup d’état was executed. Yugoslavia was invaded by Germany and Italy soon afterwards.
The Croatian Ustashe fascist party now occupied power in the puppet Independent State of Croatia and was responsible for attacks on Serbian minorities and the establishment of concentration camps. During the war various resistance organisations fought against the Croatian Ustashe state and the military occupation. There were so-called Chetniks, who were primarily Serbian and nationalist elements from the Yugoslavian army who continued to see themselves as loyal to the royal family and the former state. The largest resistance movement was the partisans, however. These were led by Josip Broz Tito and the Communist Party. The partisans tried to break down ethnic barriers and fought for a united socialist Yugoslavia after the war. The two groups had mutual issues and engagements between Chetniks and partisans were almost as common as engagements against occupying forces. As the war drew to an end, the partisans were clearly in the strongest position. They were able to liberate large areas of the country from its occupier before the end of the war. After the war Yugoslavia was established as a federal socialist republic under Tito’s leadership.

Tension in Yugoslavia
The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia was divided into six republics, each of equal official status. From North to South these were: Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro and Macedonia. Kosovo and Vojvodina were also part of the Federal Republic. There were two self-governing provinces with large ethnic minority populations, both of which were part of Serbia. Yugoslavia was governed for many years by Josip Broz Tito, who was the country’s founder and president and the leader of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia. The party itself was also divided into the League of Communists of Slovenia, the League of Communists of Serbia and so on. Although both state and party were divided federally by ethnic group, it was a taboo subject to talk about ethnic and religious boundaries and the mobilisation of nationalist movements was in breach of the constitution. All languages also had equal official status. Under the Yugoslavian state’s official “Brotherhood and Unity” motto, its people were expected to work together to modernise their country and represent a positive role model for others, including Communist dictatorships further East. Although nationalist tendencies were officially dead and buried, a number of issues remained that, after Tito’s death in 1980, would lead to increased nationalism and the collapse of the federation a decade later.

After Tito? Tito!
With Tito and the former wartime partisans at the forefront, nationalist leaders were either executed or forced into exile at the end of the Second World War. Once the Chetniks and Ustashe were dead or exiled Yugoslavia tried to unite the various factions, hoping that the various peoples of Yugoslavia would, over time, be able to see themselves as one united Yugoslavian people.
