Nobody lives for ever. And neither did Tito. The party met in 1974 and wrote a new constitution in preparation for the country’s governance after his death, The “After Tito? Tito!” slogan made Tito president for life. A joint presidential office was set up to succeed him, which would appoint eight members, one from each region of the country. Each of the members would alternate as president. Major decisions would require agreement within the council of presidents and, because agreement was not always achievable, this led to instability in government. Each of the republics was also given greater autonomy. Many Serbs were unhappy about this development. As the largest republic, and being the ethnic grouping of which the largest numbers resided in other parts of the country, Serbs would have preferred to see a powerful, centrally-governed Yugoslavia under Serb leadership.

Financial crisis
There had been large differences in the state of the economy in Yugoslavia’s various regions. Slovenia and Croatia had already industrialised during the 19th Century and had better-developed economies than the autonomous or Ottoman regions of Yugoslavia in the South and East. After the Second World War, these were largely agricultural societies in which a large proportion of the population had received no education. The northern and western states had also benefited from European tourism, which had boomed during post-war years.
A financial crisis during the 1980s became heightened when international economic organisations like the IMF and the World Bank were no longer willing to lend unless Yugoslavia was willing to implement structural economic reforms. Macedonia, Montenegro and, to some extent, Serbia were worst affected and the reallocation of funding from the wealthier North to the more impoverished South turned into a political conflict between the republics.

Ethnic Problems
Ethnic problems continued to exist, despite the official stance of burying nationalism and creating a common Yugoslavian identity. As nationalism increased during the late 1980s and Slovenia and Croatia declared independence, the notion of ethnic cleansing began to rear its ugly head once again. During the Second World War the Croat Ustashe régime had been responsible for some of the worst acts of “cleansing” in the region, with an official policy that one third of Croat Serbs should be liquidated, a third deported and a third converted to Catholicism and “turned into” Croats. The term “ethnic cleansing” is a direct translation from the Serbo-Croat term "etnicko ciscenje" and entails an attempt to create an ethnically “pure” region. This can be achieved by genocide, as was seen during the Holocaust in Nazi Germany, and by forcibly converting and/or deporting a population or by using violent means and threats to force a population to leave. The destruction of cultural and historic monuments like churches and mosques can also be used when trying to erase the history of an ethnic group within the population. Genocide and ethnic cleansing are not entirely synonymous, as the intent that underlies the actions are different. Both are, however, considered by the UN and international conventions as war crimes and crimes against humanity.
Croatia was still home to a large Serb minority, the so-called Krajina-Serbs, who had settled in the area when it was part of the militarised borderlands of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, the capital city being Knin in southern Croatia. This was also true in Slovenia. As nationalism was on the rise at the end of the 1980s, Serbs in both regions feared for their future and attempted to declare independence.
Bosnia-Herzegovina was the most ethnically-diverse region of Yugoslavia. This was home to the majority of Yugoslavia’s Muslims, who were considered an ethnicity. Bosnian Muslims were often the most active supporters of a common Yugoslavian state and identity. Many Serbs and Croats also lived in the state, however. These factions wanted to belong to a Serb or Croat state if Yugoslavia was to be dissolved. Some villages in Bosnia-Herzegovina were populated by a single ethnicity, whereas others were mixed, sometimes with districts that were divided by ethnicity. Especially in the larger towns, people would live and intermarry, making no distinction about ethnic affiliations.
Serbia was one of the most ethnically distinct regions, being home to a majority population that was undeniably Serb. The two autonomous provinces of Kosovo and Vojvodina were part of Serbia, however. Over half of the population of Vojvodina was Serb, but during the 1980s somewhere between 10 and 20% of the population was ethnically Hungarian. Romanians and Roma also lived in Vojvodina, which was autonomous and had a seat in the council of presidents. Kosovo was home to a large Serb minority population and, as the heartland of medieval Serbia, Kosovo has played a major role in Serbian identity politics. During the 1980s, however, about 80% of Kosovo’s population spoke Albanian and the vast majority were Muslims, which was why Kosovo had been allowed to self-govern and had a representative in the council of presidents. Many Kosovo-Albanians wanted Kosovo to be a republic with equal status within the Yugoslavian Federation, but complaints about discrimination and harassment by Albanians contributed to starting the conflict that would eventually spread throughout Yugoslavia.

Propaganda and the quest for power.
Alongside the many ethnic, economic and political problems, nationalism began to become an increasingly important factor during the 1980s. Certain factions and politicians continued to stoke the flames by mobilising the population’s sense of national identity, as they attempted to gain power or get their own way. The cracks had already begun to show as early as 1969-1971, during the so-called "Croatian Spring”. Encouraged by its leaders, Croatia had blossomed both culturally and nationally, which before long led to demands for increased self-rule for the republic. Tito and the Yugoslavian régime considered this to be a nationalist move, which led to increased controls and several Croatian politicians found themselves in court.
It was, however, in Serbia that the problems would really come to the surface, with regard to its relationship with Kosovo, where there were demonstrations in 1981. The Albanians who lived in Kosovo wanted to see Kosovo as a republic with equal status, rather than a self-governing province of Serbia. The Serb-dominated Yugoslavian police and military cracked down hard on the demonstrations and order was restored with no change to Kosovo’s status. Just a few years later, in 1986, a memorandum was published that would be of major importance to the years that followed. This text concerned the crisis in Yugoslavia, viewed from a Serbian perspective. Instead of presenting proposed solutions, it criticised the 1974 constitution’s decentralisation and blamed Croatia and Slovenia for the poor state of the economy. It also claimed that Serbs in Kosovo, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina were victims of oppression and of political and cultural attacks that the memorandum went so far as to characterise as genocide.
Because of the massive tension in Yugoslavia, Serb politician Slobodan Milosevic was sent to Kosovo during the spring of 1987 to listen to the population’s grievances and calm the situation. During this visit, he made his famous announcement to Serb demonstrators who had gathered in protest at Kosovo Polje “Nobody will beat you ever again.” Later the same year he would depose the Serbian president and take the position himself. In the time that followed Milosevic would place supporters in charge of Vojvodina and Montenegro, and removed Kosovo’s right to self-govern. As it now controlled four of the Communist Party’s eight divisions, the other republics feared increased centralisation of power around Serbia and Milosevic. An attempt was made to resolve this conflict at a major party congress in 1990. Milosevic, however, brought the votes from Serbia, Kosovo, Vojvodina and Montenegro to bear to vote down all proposals towards a federal state or for the various republics to self-govern. Eventually, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Macedonia walked out of the congress. The League of Communists of Yugoslavia was thus dissolved and democratic multi-party elections were held over the course of 1990 in the various republics, nationalist parties winning the elections in most areas.

A PATCHWORK
The Balkan peninsula has historically been a meeting place for many great cultures. Its population has been divided by various factors over the ages into numerous groupings since the days of the original inhabitants of the region known as Illyria by the Roman: the migration of Slavic peoples to the region, conversions to Greek Orthodoxy and Roman Catholicism, influences from Venetian merchants and the rule of Austro-Hungarian and Turkish Ottoman overlords. Each factor has had an impact that has pulled one way or another. Migrations, deportations, refugees, religious converts and attempts to create a common supranational identity made the former Yugoslavia an area that was home to many different ethnic and religious groups, but an area where it was difficult to map out the borders. People from the various groups lived scattered in mixed areas. The six republics and two self-governing provinces that comprised Yugoslavia were therefore ethnically mixed, composed not only of people from the various Yugoslavian population groups but also people of other nationalities, primarily from neighbouring Balkan countries and the countries that had controlled the region during earlier periods of history.
The financial situation of each of the geographic areas meant that economic development in the various regions progressed at different rates. This, combined with the varying levels of friendship and hostility between the different regions and populations, combined with affiliations to ethnic groups in neighbouring countries outside Yugoslavia, would result in serious tensions within the federation.

Slovenia
Slovenia was the northernmost region of the former Yugoslavia, which meant that it was historically a little isolated from the rest of the country. As a language, Slovenian is different to Serbo-Croat, partly because of its origins and partly because it adopted many words from neighbouring Austria and Italy. Historically, the Slovenians are Catholic and use the Latin alphabet. Slovenia was one of the most economically developed regions. As part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Slovenia was industrialised during the 19th Century and had railway links to both Budapest and Vienna. As part of Yugoslavia, Slovenia’s tourist industry would boom because of the natural beauty of its mountains and its short distance and historical relationships with Italy and Austria.
Unlike the rest of Yugoslavia, Slovenia had no large minority populations. The biggest ethnic groups apart from the Slovenians themselves live in the border regions where Slovenia meets Italy, Austria and Hungary. Because of an influx of refugees from the bloody conflict that resulted from the breakup of Yugoslavia, Slovenia now has bigger Serb and Bosnian minority populations that it had when Yugoslavia was still a federation.
Because the Slovenians were major contributors to Yugoslavia’s federal economy, they would eventually tire of the redistribution of wealth from North to South, especially when they too were affected by a financial crisis during the 1980s. The desire for increased self-rule led to a confrontation with Milosevic and his attempt to centralise Yugoslavia at the 1990 party congress. Their representatives walked out and Slovenia would be the first region to declare independence. The conflict and fighting with the Yugoslavian army that followed would only last for ten days, after which Slovenia became independent.

Croatia
In terms of economy, history and religion, Croatia is very similar to its Slovenian neighbour to the North. The Croats are also predominantly Cathollic, were ruled by Austro-Hungary and have a relatively well-developed economy, with industry and tourism. The Croat language also uses Latin letters, but this is also the greatest difference between Croat and Serbian, as both are otherwise dialects of the same language. As the next-largest group after the Serbs, there has often been rivalry between Serbs and Croats in Yugoslavia.
Croatia was also home to large minority populations, including in particular the Krajina Serbs, who had arrived as refugees from the Ottoman Empire and were settled and armed by the Austrian administration to protect the region against Ottoman pillaging raids. Croats in the pre-Second World War Kingdom of Yugoslavia considered themselves to be the victims of oppression by the kingdom’s Serb élite. Between the two World Wars Croat self-government was long a topic of disagreement and would culminate during the Second World War, when the Independent State of Croatia, led by the fascist Ushtashe party, was responsible for concentration camps and attempts to ethnically cleanse the region of its Serb minority. The Ushtashe régime was defeated by Tito (who was actually a Croat) and his Communist partisans. During the Communist era in Yugoslavia the Croats often stood alongside the Slovenians in the fight for a more federal system. When the Slovenians walked out of the 1990 party congress, they were immediately followed by the Croats. Croatia declared independence soon afterwards, headed by the nationalist Franjo Tudjman as president and the Serb minority feared that there would be a regression to the horrors of the Ustashe régime. Yugoslavia’s Serb-dominated army initially attempted to occupy Croatia in its entirety, but was unsuccessful. This resulted in a declaration of independence by Serb-populated areas with support from Yugoslavia, which became known as the Republic of Serbian Krajina. This led to a long war, during which the first UN troops (UNPROFOR) were deployed to Yugoslavia.
Many Croats also lived as minorities in Bosnia-Herzegovina. When Croatia declared independence, Bosnian Croats were divided between those who supported an independent Bosnia-Herzegovina and those who wanted to secede from the multi-ethnic country in the hope of unification with Croatia. This meant that Bosnian Croats would sometimes work alongside Bosnian Muslims in opposition to the Serbs. This was not all that happened, however. There was also fighting and ethnic cleansing among Croats and Muslims in Bosnia-Herzegovina. Since their independence, Croatia and Montenegro have disagreed about the Prevlaka peninsula, which was occupied during the Croatian War of Independence by Yugoslavian troops operating on behalf of Montenegro.

Bosnia-Herzegovina
Bosnia-Herzegovina was the most divided of the republics that jointly comprised Yugoslavia and is located in the middle of the former federation. Bosnia-Herzegovina was often trapped between two powerful Yugoslavian rivals; Serbia and Croatia. Its population all spoke Serbo-Croat, but was largely split into communities along religious lines. The Catholics saw themselves as Croats, whereas the Orthodox population identified as Serb. The largest groups in the country were its Muslims, however, and had been considered an ethnicity since 1960s. During the conflict of the 1990s these Muslims began to be called "Bosniaks” instead of simply “Muslims” or “Bosnian Muslims”. Bosnia-Herzegovina has historically also been at the heart of events. The area was occupied by both the Ottomans and the Austro-Hungarians. Between the World Wars it was dominated by its Serbs and during the Second World War it became part of the fascist Independent State of Croatia. When it was part of Tito’s Yugoslavia, it was in the multi-ethnic towns that most people identified as Yugoslavian. When the federation broke apart its Muslim leadership tried stubbornly to maintain Bosnia’s status as a mixed state, while both Serbs and Croats worked to split the country between Serbia and Croatia or into independent ethnic states.
Bosnia-Herzegovina was one of the least economically-developed regions when Yugoslavia was founded, as it had only been a province on the periphery of the Ottoman Empire. The area was characterised by constantly having to adapt, one example being an extended occupation by Austro-Hungary before it was integrated into the empire as an actual province. During the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, much of the country was overlooked by the Serb-dominated government, which would also be the case during the beginnings of Communist Yugoslavia. When Tito broke with the Soviet Union, the Bosnian economy was developed thanks to large investments that were made in the state.
When Croatia and Slovenia left the Yugoslavian Federation, Bosnian leaders feared that Bosnia-Herzegovina would be marginalised as part of a Serb-dominated state. Despite valiant attempts by its multinational leadership, the country’s new parties would be on the basis of ethnic affiliations. The referendum on independence was boycotted by the Serb population. Before long the Serb areas declared their own independence as Republika Srpska (loosely translated, the Serb Republic) and established paramilitary forces that were armed and supported by the Yugoslavian army. A similar movement was in motion in Croat areas, supported by the newly-independent Croatia. When fighting began in the form of a major Serb offensive, Bosnian Croats fought alongside the Bosnian Muslim army. Bosnia-Herzegovina would be the area of the former Yugoslavia that was longest and most badly impacted by the breakup, suffering countless cases of ethnic cleansing and massacres and the besieging of its capital, Sarajevo, which lasted almost four years. Various UN initiatives were attempted to stop the war, which would not be brought to an end until NATO carried out an extensive air campaign.

Serbia
Not only was Serbia the largest of the republics that comprised the former Yugoslavia, it was also the one in which the population was most broadly distributed. Large numbers of Serbs lived, in particular, in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina and these Serbs wanted to be part of a state of Yugoslavia or a greater Serbian state rather than live as a minority in another nation state. The Serbs have been the dominant group in Yugoslavia historically, not only because they were the largest group but also partly because it led the Kingdom of Yugoslavia as an independent state after the First World War. Even though Serbia was not as prosperous as Croatia and Slovenia during the 1980s, the republic did have one of Yugoslavia’s stronger economies, based on agriculture and industry. Not only was Belgrade the capital of Serbia, but of the entire Federation of Yugoslavia, which attracted many politicians and officials to the city, who brought jobs and investments with them.
Like their neighbours in Macedonia and Montenegro, the Serbs had converted to Orthodox Christianity during the Middle Ages. Because of their shared history, these three states would often stand together within the Federation of Yugoslavia. This would not always be problem-free, however. In the Serb national discourse during the days of the Kingdom of Serbia and the Kingdom of Yugoslavia between the two World Wars, Montenegrins and Macedonians were viewed as Serbs who spoke with a bit of a dialect. Many Montenegrins and Macedonians took issue with this.
Serbia itself was largely populated by Serbs, but both of the autonomous provinces of the former Yugoslavia were inside Serbia and each had their own ethnic characteristics. In Vojvodina there was a Serb majority population, but the largest minority population spoke Hungarian. When Slobodan Milosevic came to power in Serbia, he used his support among Serb minority populations to put his own man in charge of Vojvodina. Despite, or perhaps because of, its multi-ethnic nature, Vojvodina continued to be part of the former Yugoslavia and is now a self-governing region of Serbia. Because of the strong levels of Serbian nationalism, many people from the minority populations left the region, which was instead populated by Serb refugees from Croatia and Bosnia. The region continues to be ethnically diverse at the time of writing. Kosovo, however, has an Albanian majority population but has a large role in Serbian identity as the capital of medieval Serbian kingdoms and the site of their defeat by the Ottomans. It was here that Slobodan Milosevic’s journey to the presidency gained tempo when he made himself the spokesman of Kosovo’s Serbs and promoted the agenda that they were oppressed and subject to violations by the Albanian majority. Milosevic and the Serbs were able to maintain a relative state of peace in Kosovo during the wars in Croatia and Bosnia. After conflict and a NATO air campaign at the end of the 1990s Kosovo’s self-governing status was returned. A UN peacekeeping force was deployed and Kosovo later declared independence.
Although Serbian nationalism was robust and was one of the reasons for many of the conflicts, Serbia did not officially leave the Federation of Yugoslavia until it was formally dissolved and replaced by a federation that was comprised only of Serbia and Montenegro. Serbia instead continued to follow the long narrative of a united Yugoslavia when the other states began to leave the union and deployed the Yugoslavian army in attempts to prevent the secessions.

Macedonia
Macedonia was in the south-east corner of the former Yugoslavia. It was the poorest of the republics and, from the beginning to the end of the Federation of Yugoslavia, it received funding that came from the wealthier republics in the North. The language of Macedonia is also a dialect of Serbo-Croat, even though it is linguistically more closely-related to Bulgarian. Serbs and Bulgarians both consider Macedonians to be part of their own people. An actual Macedonian national identity did not appear until the beginning of the 20th Century, as a contrast to Greek, Serbian and Bulgarian demands. Macedonia was thus the last part of the former Ottoman Empire to become part of Yugoslavia and it was not until Tito’s Yugoslavia that the Macedonians were regarded as an independent people. Many Macedonians therefore supported the notion of a united Yugoslavia, as this was economically advantageous to them and prevented neighbouring countries with former stakes in the country from piecing out Macedonia among themselves.
Macedonia’s largest minority had no affiliation to any of the other republics. Macedonia’s large Albanian population wanted at various times to leave the union and join the independent Albanian state or gain independence on its own behalf. These desires led to serious conflicts in Kosovo. It was not until the new millennium that these would turn into combat engagements in Macedonia, after which it was generally possible to find compromise solutions that gave equal status to the Orthodox Macedonian majority and the Albanian-speaking Muslim minority.
Despite the fact that Macedonia had tried very hard to maintain the federation, it would eventually secede from the union. A referendum was held when it became clear that Slovenia and Croatia would declare independence. The result also produced a majority for independence. As a contrast with the events that transpired in the other states, where there were civil wars and ethnic cleansing, Macedonia’s declaration of independence as a sovereign state in September 1991 was relatively peaceful.

Montenegro
Montenegro was the smallest of the republics. Like the Serbs and Macedonians its people were orthodox Christians who wrote using the Cyrillic alphabet. When spoken, the Montenegrin dialect has more in common with Croatian than Serbian. Like the population of Macedonia, Montenegrins were considered to be part of the Serbian people by many Serbs. And, like Kosovo, Montenegro was part of the cradle of Serbian culture. Montenegro had, however, seen the rise of a sense of independent national identity because, unlike its neighbours, Montenegro had never been part of the Ottoman Empire and had been able to continue as a more or less self-governing state. Local conditions were the reason why a small country like Montenegro had been able to survive, despite being surrounded by the vast Turkish empire. A large army would starve in the small impoverished mountainous terrain and a smaller one would have been defeated by the country’s rugged mountain folk. There was, however, a fluid border of sorts which determined whether somebody was Serb or Montenegrin. Both republics also viewed themselves as the heirs to the medieval Serbian kingdoms and would therefore often work together closely within the confines of Yugoslavian politics.
Montenegro’s small and mountainous terrain on the outer limits of Yugoslavia made it a poor region. It had an underdeveloped economy and the bulk of its population were peasant farmers and herders. As with Macedonia, large amounts of funding were therefore diverted to Macedonia from other parts of Yugoslavia. The region continued to be extremely inaccessible and at the borderlands of Yugoslavia, which meant that development continued to progress very slowly. It was not until the country was discovered by foreign tourists during the 1980s that economic developments began to accelerate.
At the end of the 1980s Milosevic and the Serb nationalists successfully positioned their supporters in leading positions in Montenegro, which lead to Montenegro voting in support of Serbia and against Slovenia at the party congress in 1990. As other states seceded from Yugoslavia, Montenegro remained in the federation like Serbia. Montenegrin soldiers also fought in the Yugoslavian army against the secession of Croatia and Slovenia. Many Montenegrins also initially took part in the conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The Montenegrin identity continued to dominate, however, so Montenegro withdrew its units from the Yugoslavian army in protest against the conduct of the Serbs in Bosnia-Herzegovina. When the Federation of Yugoslavia was finally broken up, Montenegro joined a federation that was comprised solely of Serbia and Montenegro, until it declared independence after a democratic vote in 2006.

Kosovo
Kosovo is a small, mountainous region in the south-west of the Balkan peninsula. Its population is divided into two main groups: Serbs and Albanians. The current population of Kosovo is 90% Albanian and 8% Serb. This has not always been the case, however. Kosovo's history is full of stories about migrations, the meeting of religions and dramatic events that have given the region a changing population and a close relationship with its neighbours.
There was no Albanian state during the Middle Ages. On the contrary, the Albanian people lived in various tribes in clans spread over an area that encompassed not only present-day Albania, but also Kosovo and parts of other neighbouring countries. The Serb population was also well-distributed but came together during the Middle Ages to create a kingdom that was the strongest power in the Balkans during various periods. The mountain valleys of Montenegro and Kosovo were the heartlands of the first Serbian kingdoms and are the sites of numerous old churches, monasteries and ruins from the greatest period of Serbian history. Western Kosovo is therefore called Metohija by the Serbs, which translates to “the land of monasteries” as it was owned by the Serbian church. As the cradle of Serbian culture, many Serbs therefore consider Kosovo to be the very heart of Serbia. A pivotal battle in Kosovo also contributed towards making the area part of the Serbian national identity. A battle was fought between the Serbs and the Ottomans at Kosovo Polje in central Kosovo in 1389. It ended with Serbian defeat which, in the Serbian national consciousness, has stood as a symbol of the end of Serbia’s greatest era and the beginning of what they consider to be centuries of oppression.
Serbia won back its independence during the 19th Century and Kosovo was once again absorbed into Serbia when the Ottoman Empire was divided. After the First World War, Kosovo would therefore become part of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia. During the Second World War Albania was occupied by fascist Italy, who annexed Kosovo into their Albanian province. When the war ended and a new Communist Yugoslavia was founded under Tito’s leadership most Kosovo Albanians wanted to continue being a part of Albania. This idea was quickly dismissed and Kosovo became a self-governing province in Serbia, the largest state in the Federation of Yugoslavia. Albanian was once again a permitted language and Kosovo’s institutions and political leadership became gradually more dominated by Kosovo Albanians, especially after the 1968 student uprising. Conversely, the Serb proportion of the population also continued to decrease over the years.
When a new Yugoslavian constitution was introduced in 1974 Kosovo’s rights to self-govern were greatly augmented. Although Kosovo was formally still a province of Serbia, to all practical intents and purposes it had equal status with the republics that also comprised the Federation of Yugoslavia. Kosovo therefore had a member of the presidential council and was represented in federal institutions with full right of veto on an equal footing with the actual republics.
Milosevic took power in Serbia as the spokesman of Kosovo’s Serbs and in spring 1989 he and the Serb parliament took away Kosovo’s right to self-govern. During the summer, on 28 June that year, he brought together thousands of Serbs at Kosovo Polje. Here, Milosevic spoke of how the Serb people once again faced a pivotal battle, even though no weapons had been used at this point. Before long Kosovo’s public sector employees would be required to pledge allegiance to Serbia and Serbian curricula were introduced in schools. The political and institutional world was also dominated by Serbs.
This did not stop the Kosovo Albanians in their tracks. 4In 1991 they declared independence and set up a “shadow state” with an elected parliament in Kosovo. The conflict escalated in 1998, with combat engagements between Serb forces and the Kosovo Liberation Army. Thousands of people became refugees and the UN tried in vain to come up with a solution, as the UN Security Council was unable to reach agreement. NATO, however, was not willing to simply stand by and watch. An international air combat group was put together from October 1998 and Milosevic was given the choice of a ceasefire that would be monitored by international observers or aerial bombardment. Negotiations broke down on 18 March 1999 and NATO activated the air task force on 24 March. The air campaign produced an agreement with Milosevic, which included provisions for the deployment of a large task force that would be called KFOR. Tensions continued in Kosovo, but as time passed and with the support of the UN, NATO and EU, the situation improved. The parliament in Kosovo was able declare independence in 2008, which was recognised by a large number of UN, EU and NATO member states.
After long negotiations between Kosovo, Serbia and the EU, Kosovo and Serbia were finally able to reach their first agreement in 2013. The “Brussels Agreement” contains a number of items relating to conditions for the Serb minority in Kosovo and its ability to collaborate with Serbian institutions in northern Kosovo, including with regard to the law.

BREAKUP
The Choice of the Nation.
The large party congress in January 1990 was intended to fix Yugoslavia’s problems. Slovenia and Croatia tried to transform the state into a voluntary federation, but Milosevic and his allies in Kosovo, Vojvodina and Montenegro voted down all proposals. Finally, the Slovenian, Croatian, Macedonian and Bosnian delegations walked out. This would mean the end of the combined party that had ruled Yugoslavia since the Second World War.
The following year would see the very first multiple party elections in the various Yugoslavian republics. The nationalists won power in Croatia and Slovenia during the spring and began to work towards secession as states with their own constitutions. The Croatian flag with its red and white chequerboard emblem instead of the Yugoslavian star appeared at the end of July 1990. The chequerboard emblem had been a Croat national symbol since the Middle Ages, but for the Serb minority it was reminiscent of the last régime to use it, the fascist Ushtashe (who had made war on the Serbs during the Second World War). Soon afterwards the Serb majority in the area surrounding the town of Knin declared their own autonomy, formed militias and blocked roads into the area. Serbs in other parts of Croatia followed suit later, jointly setting up the Serb autonomous region of Krajina, which generally covered the same area as the former Austrian military border, which had been populated by Serb refugees. The Krajina Serbs were determined that if Croatia left the Federation of Yugoslavia they would leave Croatia.
When elections were held in Bosnia-Herzegovina during November, national parties also won a majority. Unlike Croatia and Slovenia, there were three national parties in Bosnia-Herzegovina: a Serb, a Croat and a Bosnian Muslim, each of whom received a vote that roughly corresponded to their share of the multi-ethnic population. An attempt was made to form a coalition government headed by Alija Izetbegovic, a Muslim, but in the months that followed it would become more and more difficult to work with the Serb party that was led by Radovan Karadzic.

Independence and War
Almost a year would go by with the tense situation after the Serb unrest began in Knin and Krajina. What had many had foreseen would finally take place on 25 July 1991. Croatia and Slovenia declared independence from the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. Belgrade responded in turn and deployed the federal Yugoslav People's Army. Two days later the Slovenian War of Independence began, also known as “the Ten Days War”. The war was over quickly. A ceasefire was concluded and Slovenia gained its independence while the Yugoslavian People’s Army (JNA) pulled out of the country. Things would not be quite so easy in Croatia. Here, Serbian Krajina declared independence and the JNA was at its gates in August before the Croats were able to assert control in the entire country. The fighting in Croatia was long and bloody. Towns like Dubrovnik and Split that had previously been popular tourist destinations were bombarded by artillery and Vukovar lay in ruins after a long siege.
The war was condemned by the international community. The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 713 (1991) in September, implementing a complete embargo on arms from anywhere in the former Yugoslavia. American Cyrus Vance was also appointed as special envoy in October and given the task of negotiating and restoring peace. After a number of attempts by the European Community it was finally possible to negotiate a sustainable ceasefire in the beginning of 1992, after which the UN Security Council (via Resolution 743 in 1992) set up a peacekeeping force called the United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR), which would be the first of many UN measures in the former Yugoslavia. Croatia and Slovenia were recognised by the EC and a number of other countries, but almost a third of Croatia was still occupied by the JNA and paramilitary forces from Serb Krajina.
In the meantime, tensions in Bosnia-Herzegovina had reached boiling point, partly as a result of the conflict in Croatia. With Slovenia and Croatia on their way out of the union and as Serb nationalism increased, Bosnian Croats and Muslims feared that they would be stuck in a Yugoslavia with no ability to counter the Serbs. In the Bosnian parliament Bosnian Muslims and Croats had discussed a memorandum about sovereignty and neutrality in the Croatian war, which led to Serb members of parliament walking out of parliament in October 1991. Autonomous Serb areas were established in Bosnia-Herzegovina during the autumn, similar to what had happened in Serb Krajina in Croatia, while Bosnian Croat areas in the western part of the country did the same. Each of the three ethnic groups in Bosnia-Herzegovina formed their own paramilitary forces at the same time. Serbs, Croats and Muslims.
Only a short time would pass after the ceasefire in Croatia entered into force before war broke out in Bosnia-Herzegovina. After Slovenia and Croatia were recognised as independent states by the international community in 1992 an independence referendum was set in motion in Bosnia-Herzegovina. At the end of February it seemed that there was a large majority in favour of independence. The referendum was boycotted by the ethnic Serb groups and many people were prevented from voting in the autonomous Serb areas. Nonetheless, there was a majority in favour of independence. President Izetbegovic declared Bosnia-Herzegovinan independence on 3 March, the decision being ratified by parliament the same evening, Serbian MPs refusing to participate.

Civil War in Bosnia
Things would fall apart completely in Bosnia-Herzegovina during March. Fighting was reported in several places in the country during the weeks after independence was declared, with Bosnian Serbs who were sometimes supported by JNA troops, Krajina Serbs and groups from Serbia itself on one side and Bosnian Croats, Bosnian Muslims and armed Croats who had crossed the border on the other. The earliest days of the civil war were mostly characterised by a breakdown of law and order. The ethnic parties and their militias made attempts to fill a power vacuum and took control of strategically important locations to ensure a stronger position in future fighting.
Although massacres and the expulsion of populations based on “undesirable” ethnicity had already occurred during the war in Croatia, they fade in comparison to would be seen in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The first large massacre carried out by a paramilitary force from Serbian Bosnia-Herzegovina to receive media attention took place in the very beginning of April in the town of Bijeljina in the eastern part of the country. Large proportions of the Muslim population were murdered or expelled. Peace demonstrations in Sarajevo attended by participants from all the town’s ethnicities were fired upon by Bosnian Serbs.
Soon afterwards Bosnia-Herzegovina was recognised as an independent country by the EC, who were quickly followed by the USA. The country was already in a state of civil war by this point. It was decided on 15 April that an official Bosnia-Herzegovinan army would be created to combat the Bosnia-Herzegovina breakaway areas.
On the same day as Bosnia-Herzegovina’s independence was recognised by the EC, its capital Sarajevo was bombarded by Serb artillery. This would be the first bombardment in a siege that would last for years. The war proceeded across the country for the first year with Bosnian Serb military successes in spite of the fact that the Bosnian Croats and Muslims initially presented a united front. No matter who was the victor, a victory would often be followed by operations in which the “undesired” civilian population would be murdered or forced to flee the area. The siege of Sarajevo and ethnic cleansing elsewhere defined the brutality of this war and were largely the reason why attitudes in the global community became hostile to the Serbs.
The alliance between Croats and Muslims in Bosnia-Herzegovina collapsed in 1992 and the following year the war would become a war involving three different protagonists: 1) The official Bosnia-Herzegovina which was primarily comprised of Muslims and those who were unwilling to side with an ethnicity, 2) Bosnian Croats who were supported by Croat groups who crossed the border and 3) Bosnian Serbs with extensive support in Serbia and from the JNA until the army officially pulled out of Bosnia-Herzegovina in May 1992. Many JNA troops would subsequently, however, join one of the sides in the war. The most famous example of this is Ratko Mladic, a JNA officer who stayed in Bosnia-Herzegovina as the leader of the Bosnian Serb army and who would later be convicted of crimes against humanity. There was also a fourth military force in Bosnia-Herzegovina; the troops deployed by the UN to the various missions. UNPROFOR was created during the war in Croatia as a peacekeeping mission but was given an extended mandate to also cover Bosnia-Herzegovina. UNIPROFOR’s main objective for most of the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina was humanitarian and took the form of ensuring that emergency aid was able to get through to its destination. “Safe zones” would be set up later in 1993, where the UN was able to protect civilians and refugees. A naval blockade was imposed in 1992 which was expanded on an ongoing basis. A no-fly zone was enforced from the following year, as well as a NATO-led air campaign, initially in the form of air support for UN troops but ultimately carrying out bombardments of Bosnian Serb targets during 1995.

SARAJEVO
The eyes of the entire world had already been on Sarajevo in 1984, when the city was the venue for the massive Winter Olympics with a large newly-renovated stadium (that would later become a base for Danish forces) and a newly-build Olympic village. The tourist boom that followed in the second half of the 1980s put the city on the world map, attracting large numbers of visitors who came to see the beautiful combination of European and Ottoman architecture in the old district, where mosques and cathedrals stood side-by-side. The next time the eyes of the world fell on Sarajevo would be because of events that were altogether different.
The referendum on Bosnia-Herzegovina's independence was the trigger for the conflict in Sarajevo. Although the referendum itself proceeded peacefully, taking into account the intense ethnic tensions in the country, a Serb wedding in the city was fired upon the day after the referendum, resulting in two fatalities. The following morning Serb groups had barricaded several streets in Serb-dominated neighbourhoods. After a cross-section of the city’s inhabitants protested for peace the situation became even more tense. Bosnia-Herzegovina's declared independence despite all of this.
Although fighting broke out in various parts of the country during March 1992, Sarajevo itself was relatively calm for most of the month. It was not until April that the years-long battle for the capital finally began. President Izetbegovic ordered the mobilisation of all police officers and reservists in Sarajevo on 4 April. On the same day the Bosnian Serb SDS party secretly advised all Serbs in the town to leave. Soon afterwards, on the same day as the country’s independence was recognised by the EC (6 April) the first artillery shells would be fired over the city, from the Serb-populated hillsides that surrounded the city.
Even though it would be a little longer before the city was surrounded, this was the beginning of the siege. The years-long siege of Sarajevo defined the brutality of this war and were largely the reason why attitudes in the global community became hostile to the Serbs. Lasting three years and four months, this was the longest a town had been under siege in modern history.

The battle for Sarajevo’s airport
The long siege of Sarajevo led to many fatalities, not just from artillery or sniper fire, but from hunger and disease as it was difficult to supply the hundreds of thousands of people who lived in the city with food and medicine. The Bosnian Serb forces made strong progress at the beginning of the civil war. With Sarajevo surrounded and under artillery bombardment the Serbs tried to take parts of the city by storm on 2 May, in an attempt to split the besieged areas in two. The attackers were repulsed, however, as the paramilitary “Green Beret” Muslim forces and the city’s mafia were able to stop the assault.
President Izetbegovic returned home the following day after attending peace negotiations in Lisbon. In the weeks leading up to this attack he had been demanding that the Yugoslav People's Army withdraw from the country or submit to the command of the civilian government. As the situation involving Izetbegovic and the JNA became increasingly hostile, JNA troops at Sarajevo’s barracks would be besieged inside the besieged city. Upon his arrival at the airport he was kidnapped by a group of JNA officers who intended to use him to guarantee free passage out of the city for all JNA troops. Despite the presence of a UNPROFOR escort and Izetbegovic himself, the JNA convoy was attacked by Bosnian Muslim paramilitary forces from the city. Although the number of fatalities was low, all parties left with a bitter taste in their mouths and regaining mutual trust would be difficult.
On 27 May 1992 people queueing for bread were hit during an artillery bombardment, with many civilian fatalities as a result. Three days later the UN Security Council imposed a number of sanctions against what remained of Yugoslavia. There were several other similar events during the siege, which turned attitudes against the Serbs. The JNA had in the meantime handed over Sarajevo’s airport to the Bosnian Serb forces who were besieging the city. Because of shortages of food and medicine supplies for the city’s civilians the UN attempted to negotiate the reopening of the airport to aircraft carrying humanitarian aid. This would become a crisis during June, when a ceasefire that was intended to allow the airport to be handed over to the UN was broken by both Muslims and Serbs. UN General secretary Boutrus-Ghali gave the Serb forces an ultimatum to hand the airport over to the UN within two days. Eventually the Serb forces handed the airport over to UNIPROFOR peacekeeping forces on 29 May. Although the siege of the city continued, supplies airlifted in the following year would be critical to the city’s population and the media were also able to enter the city and report on conditions.

The Markale massacres
Sarajevo was completely surrounded on several occasions, with all roads into the city blocked by the Bosnian Serb forces until negotiations led to control being assigned to UN troops, after which emergency aid convoys were able to enter the city. Artillery bombardments would impact international attitudes to the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina on multiple occasions, the attack on the bread queue leading to sanctions and international focus on the situation involving Sarajevo’s airport.
The two most critical attacks both hit an old market square in Sarajevo’s central Markale neighbourhood. On 5 February 1994 a mortar shell hit the busy market square during the early afternoon. Killing 68 and injuring 144 civilians, this was one of the bloodiest artillery bombardments of the war. Although there was uncertainty about who was responsible for the attack, it led to a harder approach by the international company to the Bosnian Serb siege of the city. NATO demanded that “exclusion zones” were established, no artillery positions being permitted around Sarajevo. It was also decided that NATO’s air power would be used to support UNPROFOR and to protect the UN.-guaranteed “safe zones” in Bosnia-Herzegovina. NATO combat aircraft were deployed just a few weeks later, shooting down four unidentified aircraft that breached the UN no-fly zone.
The same market square was again fired upon by artillery just over a year and a half later on 28 August 1995. 43 were killed and 75 injured during this attack and the massacres in Srebrenica followed soon after. NATO and the rest of the world’s patience with the Bosnian Serbs ran out. Although an air campaign had already been planned, this attack was the official justification for NATO’s full intervention in the war. Just two days after the attack NATO therefore commenced Operation Deliberate Force on 30 August. Aircraft from NATO countries carried out bombing raids on Bosnian Serb targets during the following month, the primary objective being to force them to the negotiating table to bring about peace and end the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina. When a joint simultaneous offensive involving Bosnian Muslims and Croats pushed the Bosnian Serbs back, the international community was finally able to produce a peace agreement at Dayton in the USA.
Because of the offensive and the NATO air campaign a ceasefire was concluded in October 1995, after which Sarajevo again had water and electricity supplies. The siege of the city was not declared officially over until February 1996 when the last Bosnian Serb forces vacated their positions encircling the city.

ATTEMPTED PEACE
There were numerous attempts to find a long-term solution to the conflicts that followed the breakup of Yugoslavia. As a particular consequence of the many expulsions and massacres that took place in Bosnia-Herzegovina a number of conferences were convened in 1994 and 1995 and a contact group was created to bring about a long-lasting peace after the war.
The first UN troops were deployed in the form of UNPROFOR during the Croatian war of independence. When the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina began the UN would quickly get involved, with a number of Security Council resolutions, including sanctions and arms embargoes, an extension to UNPROFOR’s mandate to include humanitarian aid in Bosnia-Herzegovina and eventually the creation of “safe zones”. European states represented the vast majority of UNPROFOR’s personnel in Bosnia-Herzegovina. After November 1993 the EC - EU would try for a long time to take the lead in peace negotiations. A permanent solution could not be found until NATO implemented Operation Deliberate Force - the actual air campaign against Bosnian Serb targets.

Baby steps: 1992-1993.
When the first unrest broke out in Bosnia-Herzegovina during the March 1992 referendum the UN was sceptical about the deployment of armed forces to the country. With the spread of the humanitarian crisis, the first massacres, the siege of Sarajevo and the shelling of people queuing for bread, the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina became the subject of serious concern from the international community, with subsequent sanctions against what remained of Yugoslavia and the continuation of an arms embargo.
A conference was held during the summer of 1992 at which the international community met the warring factions in the hope of bringing about an agreement. The various factions were still unwilling to engage with each other and no solution was possible. Instead, American Cyrus Vance was appointed by the UN and British Lord David Owen was appointed by the EC to continue negotiations and hopefully come up with a long-term solution.
The Vance-Owen plan that was put forward in January 1993 was the first large-scale proposed solution to be brought to the table. It proposed a federal Bosnia-Herzegovina with self-governing provinces divided on the basis of ethnicity. It was rejected by Bosnian Serbs as the peace plan would entail Serb withdrawal from large areas they had taken during the war. Cyrus Vance stepped down and was replaced by Norway's foreign minister, Thorvald Stoltenberg.
During the following period negotiations were conducted not only with Bosnian parties but also with Serb leaders from Yugoslavia and the Croatian government, who each supported their own part of the conflict. These negotiations resulted in the Owen-Stoltenberg plan, which proposed the division of the country into three zones, one for each of the ethnic groups. The proposal was rejected by Bosnia-Herzegovina's Muslim president Alija Izetbegovic, who was unwilling to move from a stance that the solution should leave Bosnia-Herzegovina as a country with no ethnic divisions. At the same time, the Serbs and Croats wanted to see Bosnia-Herzegovina divided up between Croatia and Serb-dominated Yugoslavia, with little thought for Bosnian Muslims.
In parallel to the various negotiations, attempts were also made to negotiate a number of local ceasefires. The ceasefires would quickly be broken and patience with the negotiations process evaporated. At the same time the common ground between Bosnian Croats and Muslims had broken down and all three factions were now warring against each other. The international community also found itself conflicted. The mainly European countries who had ground personnel in UNPROFOR were on one side, whereas the Americans, who were unwilling to participate in the mission until a long-term peace agreement had been negotiated, were on the other.

Safe Zones and the Dual-key system.
In addition to the UN and EC-led peace negotiations, the UN Security Council had in 1993 made resolutions to set up so-called “safe zones” in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The first of these was the town of Srebrenica, which was a refuge for many civilians as a result of fighting and ethnic cleansing in the region. General Morillon, the French commander-in-chief of the UN forces was the first to introduce the term “safe zones” when he arrived in the town and saw what conditions were like there. Srebrenica’s Muslim defenders were hard pressed by Bosnian Serb forces in the area, but agreed to disarm in exchange for assurances for security from UNPROFOR.
A number of other concentrated zones were set up during the time that followed: Zepa, Gorazde, Tuzla, Bihac and Sarajevo, the besieged capital. All these zones were in Muslim areas with large numbers of civilians who were threatened by Bosnian Serb forces or by the Serb area in Krajina. The safe zones would be under the control of UNPROFOR peacekeeping forces, distributing emergency aid to civilians and ensuring their safety. Although UNPROFOR personnel was seldom heavily armed or able to protect the areas against a determined attack, it was hoped that their mere presence would suffice to deter attacks and ensure safety for the badly-affected civilian population. It was not calm in the “safe zones”, however, as these were often areas from which Muslim forces were launching attacks on the Serbs, which would lead to incoming fire from the Bosnian Serb forces. The UN Security Council also set up a no-fly zone above Bosnia-Herzegovina and mandated NATO to enforce it. Resolution 836 (1993) mandated NATO aircraft to provide air support to UNPROFOR if ground forces were attacked.
Neither NATO or its ground forces had the final say when it came to authorising the deployment of NATO combat aircraft to provide air support. A so-called “Dual Key” system was in operation, which meant that UNPROFOR had to request air support, which then had to be approved by both NATO and the UN before pilots could be ordered to fire on a target. The intention here was that the use of force should remain in the UN’s hands, but in practice this was difficult to manage and often led to reaction times that were too slow to serve any useful purpose. When Bosnian Serb forces were attacked from the air it was seldom a deterrent. Instead, they began taking UNPROFOR soldiers as hostages in response to air attacks.

Conferences about massacres.
Negotiations began to make some progress in 1994. US president Bill Clinton was able to get the Croat and Bosnian Muslim leaders to meet and negotiate an initial ceasefire and then a federal structure. The Washington Agreement of 18 March 1994 was signed by Croatian president Tudjman and his counterpart from Bosnia, president Izetbegovic and brought one component of the conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina to an end. It produced a federation of Bosnia-Herzegovina’s Muslims and Croats, who would then be able to form a united front against the Serbs.
The Contact Group was also set up the same year. When formal negotiations conducted by the EU, UN and OSCE had not led to peace, a more informal forum was created in the form of the Contact Group, partly as a consequence of the crisis that followed the attack on a marketplace in Sarajevo in February 1994. The group was comprised of the powers that had a strong influence in the Balkans: the USA, Russia, France, the United Kingdom and Germany who would jointly negotiate with the warring factions. Despite the rejection of its first proposal by Bosnian Serbs, the Contact Group continued to play an important negotiating role up to the final peace that was concluded in the Dayton Agreement of 1995.
The events in Srebrenica were pivotal to subsequent negotiations. The area surrounding Srebrenica was under the control of a Dutch UNPROFOR contingent after the town's Bosnian Muslims had disarmed. Bosnian Serbs attacked the town in spite of the UN presence. Despite its population being under UNPROFOR’s protection, the Dutch UN troops were overrun in July 1995 and air support was repeatedly refused, until a few bombs were eventually dropped. The bombs had little effect and not to a degree that was able to stop the advancing Bosnian Serbs who murdered men, raped women and burned houses on their way to the town. On the night of 12 July many people tried to flee the area on foot through the mountainous terrain to Tuzla, but were attacked en route, the vast majority ending up dead. In the town men and women were split up. The women and children were packed into buses and transported to the nearest Muslim area but the men were executed in fields, woods and warehouses at various locations in the town. Over 7,000 people lost their lives in the worst massacre in Europe since the Second World War. The Srebrenica massacre was a wound that would not heal in many countries, most notably in the Netherlands.
Because of these atrocities a new conference was convened in London. 16 nations met on 21 July to discuss how to proceed. Among other things, this led to the Dual Key system being scrapped, making NATO military command the sole decision-maker about when to provide air support. Agreement was also reached in principle about the option of carrying out a large-scale air campaign against the Bosnian Serbs if they continued to attack UN forces and persisted in their unwillingness to conclude a peace agreement. There was extensive focus at the conference on the crisis involving the Gorazde safe zone that was besieged by Bosnian Serb forces. During previous incidents at Gorazde NATO had only carried out so-called pinpoint attacks with the aim of deterring Bosnian Serbs. At the conference in London it was announced that a tougher approach had now been established and that the Americans were ready to deploy massive and overwhelming force. Shortly afterwards, on 1 August, NATO committed to the deployment of its air power, not only to protect Gorazde, but also Bihac (where the UN force had a Danish commander), Sarajevo and Tuzla.

NATO AND DAYTON
In 1995 the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina had continued for three years and parts of Croatia were still under the control of the Republic of Serbian Krajina. Ethnic cleansing and attacks on civilian populations continued to horrify the entire world, while peace plan after peace plan was rejected by the various parties. This would be the last year of the war, however. The international community was no longer willing to stand by as the rules of war were violated, ceasefires were broken and UN peacekeepers were taken hostage.

NATO's air operations.
In Resolution 78 the UN Security Council had already set up a no-fly zone over Bosnia-Herzegovina in 1992. This would be expanded the following year with Resolution 816, which authorised UN member states to enforce the no-fly zone by military means. In practice, NATO would be responsible for enforcement as part of Operation Deny Flight, which led to the first shooting down of combat aircraft that violated the ban in February 1994.
During the same year several UN safe zones in Bosnia-Herzegovina were also attacked by Bosnian Serb forces. The town of Gorazde was besieged during the spring of 1994, despite its status as one of the safe zones. NATO carried out a number of bombing attacks on the advancing Bosnian Serbs to stop the attack. Although it slowed down the offensive it led to about 150 UNPROFOR soldiers being taken as hostages. Many were chained to potential NATO bombing targets to prevent them from being bombed. The Gorazde crisis was fortunately resolved through negotiations led by Yashushi Akashi, the personal representative of the UN's Secretary General, but the weakness of NATO and the UN was exposed for all to see. This would be far from the last time that UNPROFOR soldiers were taken hostage. Threats and actual hostage-taking were also used to prevent heavy bombing attacks when the Bosnian Serbs advanced upon Srebrenica. During the massacre that followed the Dutch soldiers in the town were taken as hostages to prevent NATO from taking measures and to prevent any involvement of UN forces. This situation caused deep scars in the Netherlands and exposed the UN’s impotence and lack of options.
Patience had almost run out. After the massacre in Srebrenica it was decided to increase options for extensive air attacks on Bosnian Serbs. UNPROFOR was also expanded and restructured to have a stronger and more mobile force that would be better able to withstand Bosnian Serb aggression. Patience finally ran out after civilians were again shelled at a marketplace in Sarajevo. NATO launched Operation Deliberate Force in 30 August 1995. This was a major bombing campaign against Bosnian Serbs that aimed to drag them to the negotiating table and finally bring the civil war to an end.

The ground campaign
1995 in Bosnia-Herzegovina actually began with a ceasefire that had been negotiated by former US president Jimmy Carter. It was broken on various occasions by both sides, but the first months of the year were relatively peaceful. The ceasefire was used to regroup, particularly by the Bosnian Muslim army that became a far stronger armed force than had been the case previously. After the previous year’s Washington Agreement, they now fought side by side with Bosnian Croats, supported by the Croatian army. Since the 1991 war of independence, the Croatian army had transitioned from militias and home guard units into a proper military, including with support from a number of western nations. The Bosnian Serbs, however, were now receiving less and less support from Milosevic’s Yugoslavia that was suffering under UN sanctions. Milosevic himself had also run out of patience with the Bosnian Serbs, who had even rejected the peace proposals that Milosevic himself had helped to negotiate.
Despite the UN presence in the form of United Nations Confidence Restoration Organization in Croatia (UNCRO in short), the Croatian army was able in two operations called ”Flash” and ”Storm” to defeat and expel/cleanse Krajina Serbs from most of Croatia. Croatia was thus therefore able to provide increased support to both Bosnian Croat and Muslim forces in Bosnia-Herzegovina and to deploy its own personnel to combat engagements. An important supply line was also opened to the Bihac pocket, which had long been besieged and under fire by Bosnian Serbs, despite its status as one of the UN’s “safe zones”.
The Bosnian Serbs who had won rapid victories earlier in the war and were unwilling to give up the smallest piece of ground in peace negotiations found themselves hard pressed by a combined Croat-Muslim offensive, simultaneous to the start of NATO's air campaign in the autumn of 1995. The Bosnian Serbs agreed to a ceasefire on 12 October 1995 and negotiations began soon after in Dayton, Ohio, where the final peace agreement was to be finalised.

A peace agreement for Bosnia-Herzegovina.
The civil war finally came to an end as 1995 drew to a close. Negotiations became possible after increased pressure form the international community in the form of the Contact Group and individual nations, while NATO’s air campaign and an offensive of Croats and Muslims were putting the Bosnian Serbs under military pressure. Although the war ended with the Dayton Agreement, it would not be the end of international commitments in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The post-war commitment was in fact greater than ever before, with the creation of new international missions to ensure implementation of the agreement and that the country got off to a reasonably stable start.

The Dayton Agreement
An actual NATO commitment in Bosnia-Herzegovina had long been difficult to set in motion because of disagreements between the European states that had contributed to UNPROFOR and the USA that wanted to lift the arms embargo and initiate an air campaign. The USA had opposed a peacekeeping mission as long as the war continued, but had changed its attitude, partly because of the fact that Croat and Muslim forces would be jointly able to combat the Bosnian Serbs. The international community had no longer been able to stand by after the massacre in Srebrenica and other attacks on civilians. Operation Deliberate Force, in combination with a land offensive in Bosnia-Herzegovina by the Muslim-Croat federation, resulted in a ceasefire on 12 October, after which negotiations could commence.
After weeks of back and forth diplomacy American vice foreign minister Richard Holbrooke was able to bring the parties to negotiations at an American air force base in Dayton, Ohio. Unlike previously, the Bosnian Serbs and Croats were not at the negotiating table. There were instead represented by Serbian president Slobodan Milosevic and Croatian president Franjo Tudmander who, together with Alija Izetbegovic the Muslim president of Bosnia-Herzegovina, would try to find a solution to the conflict. Of the three, only Izetbegovic favoured a unified state, whereas Tudjman and Milosevic wanted to divide Bosnia-Herzegovina’s Croat and Serb areas among themselves. After long, hard negotiations, during which Holbrooke was persistent despite opposing proposals and stubborn negotiators, and he would eventually achieve success. The compromise that was eventually reached was based on a plan that had previously been put forward by the Contact Group. Bosnia-Herzegovina became a single state, but a federation divided into two sub-states: a Serb republic in 49% of the country and a Croat-Muslim federation that was comprised of the remaining 51%. The division brought peace, but a divided country that largely reflected the war’s ethnic cleansing which had attempted to produce ethnically “pure” areas. The appendices of the Dayton Agreement also stipulated a number of requirements for issues such as the return home of refugees, how the political system would function with a three-way presidential office in which all groups were represented and an international high commissioner who would be able to dismiss politicians who worked counter to the agreement.

IFOR and SFOR.
When the Dayton Agreement was signed in Paris on 14 December 1995 the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina was officially over. It had cost the lives of over 100,000 people and driven over half of the country’s population into flight, either as internally displaced persons or as refugees abroad. Two international missions were set up to implement the agreement and prevent the conflict from escalating again. These were known as IFOR and, later, SFOR. Both were under NATO command, most contributions coming from NATO countries but with participation from other states. Russia’s involvement was particularly important, as Russia had often stood alongside the Serbs during the conflict. The Russian contribution was therefore important if the international force was to be perceived as neutral. There were also contributions form a number of Muslim states. The collaboration between Russian and NATO troops was considered an important step towards a peaceful future, just a few years after the fall of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War.
IFOR or Implementation Force was the first of the international missions that followed the Dayton Agreement. As its name implies, its purpose was to monitor the implementation of the agreement and ensure that things proceeded in a peaceful manner. Its role was initially to keep the two warring sides apart with a demilitarised strip through the country dividing the two sub-states. IFOR and its successors were also to help with the arrest of individuals who were to be prosecuted for war crimes and to provide general support for the international political commitment in the country. The mission commenced under NATO command on 20 December 1995 soon after the Dayton Agreement was signed. Almost 60,000 soldiers took part in IFOR. About 1,600 Danes were deployed to the force as part of a joint Nordic-Polish brigade called NORDPOLBDE, in almost the same area as that for which the Nordic UNPROFOR contingent had been responsible.
IFOR was only present in Bosnia-Herzegovina for a year, after which its missions were assigned to SFOR, or Stabilization Force. After the calm election of a new government in September 1996 it was assessed that the peace had been implemented, but that the presence of an international force was still required in Bosnia-Herzegovina to ensure stability. SFOR’s initial deployment numbered 32,000 personnel, i.e. just over half that of IFOR but this would be downscaled as the peace was assessed to be more and more stable and after Bosnia-Herzegovina’s own police and military were able to take charge of several of SFOR's responsibilities. SFOR was officially wound down after eight years. Its missions were assigned to the EU on 2 December 2004, when a joint European force was deployed.

THE EU TAKES OVER
In December 2004 peacekeeping forces in Bosnia-Herzegovina were transferred from the NATO mission to EU command. This was the culmination of a longer process that would once again involve the EU in the peace process, over a decade after the breakup of Yugoslavia. The states of the former Yugoslavia are now more or less stable, some even having become members of the EU. A number of EU missions continue in the Balkans, however, in which NATO continues to work in Bosnia-Herzegovina via the EU.

Early EC and EU commitments in Yugoslavia
At the beginning of the wars in Yugoslavia the then EC led attempts to resolve the crisis through negotiations. Many saw this partly as a conflict in the EC's own back yard and partly that it was necessary for Europe to deal with the conflict on its own behalf. The EC had to be able to show the world that it was able to assume the role of a new international stakeholder who could occupy an increased role in the new world order after the fall of the Soviet Union. The EC tried to resolve the conflict during the war in Croatia, which did not come to an end until after a peace plan had been formulated by a special UN envoy, however. European states were at the forefront of moves to recognise Croatia and Slovenia and independent states in January 1992. This was important in terms of disassociating the war from what still remained of Yugoslavia and making it an internal conflict between the Krajina Serbs and Croatia.
The UNPROFOR peacekeeping force that was initially deployed in Croatia and then in Bosnia-Herzegovina was a UN project. European states provided most of UNPROFOR’s personnel and the EC still had a special envoy alongside the UN representative, who was at the forefront of negotiations between the protagonists of the Bosnian conflict. The Contact Group was also supported by the EU, with representation from the United Kingdom, France and Germany that constituted three fifths of its membership. Many of the group’s meetings were also observed by representatives of various EU institutions.
As such, the EU was not responsible for ending the war. It was instead the Contact Group’s plan that formed the basis for the final US-sponsored Washington Agreement that brought two of the protagonists together. NATO and its many EU members carried out the air campaign which finally brought the last remaining party to the negotiating table. The EU continued to be represented during negotiations and the final signature of the Dayton Agreement in Paris (at the request of the French president) took place with the EU as official witness.

EUFOR.
Both IFOR and SFOR were provided with large proportions of their personnel by EU member states but were officially NATO missions. SFOR was wound down on 2 December 2004. The EU officially took over in the form of European Force Althea (or EUFOR Althea in short) that would carry out its missions in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The transfer was largely symbolic, as about 80% of SFOR personnel continued under EUFOR Althea. This mission has been responsible for the international contribution in Bosnia-Herzegovina since 2004 and is still active at the time of writing. Its primary missions are to train the Bosnian army, continue hunting war criminals, providing support to the international high commissioner in the country and thus ensure continued compliance with the Dayton Agreement.
There was also a military EU mission in Macedonia, called EUFOR Concordia. Fighting broke out in 2001 between the Macedonian government army and separatists from the country’s large Albanian minority. Macedonia had otherwise managed to get through Yugoslavia’s breakup relatively peacefully, but the large number of Albanian refugees from the 1999 Kosovo conflict had increased tensions between the Albanian minority and the Macedonian state and large numbers of arms had arrived in the country after the fighting in Kosovo. The EU-sponsored Ohrid Agreement officially brought the fighting in Macedonia to an end and a NATO force was initially deployed to monitor the peace that followed. This role was transferred to EUFOR Concordia on 31 March 2003, which has since contributed to creating a safe and stable environment for the implementation of the Ohrid Agreement.

EU Police Missions
The EU has also been involved in a number of police-related missions to the countries that emerged from the former Yugoslavia. Their purpose has been to help with the performance of police duties and, in particular, to train the local police corps. Places like Bosnia-Herzegovina had seen an almost total collapse of law an order and the war had led to extensive “black markets” and corruption. The EUPM/BiH or European Union Police Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina was therefore set up and had an active presence in Bosnia-Herzegovina from 1 January 2003 until 31 December 2011.
The EU police missions have also provided support to Macedonia, initially in the form of EUPM Proxima, which worked alongside EUFOR Concordia from 2003 to 2005. After 2005 there was a half-year deployment of police officers from the EU in the form of EUPAT – European Union Police Advisory Team, which continued to advise the local police force.

The former Yugoslavia in the present day
At the time of writing the many conflicts have been either resolved or put on ice. Slovenia and Croatia have gained membership of the EU. Serbia, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Kosovo and Bosnia-Herzegovina are at various stages of the route towards membership of the EU or NATO or are perhaps already members, provisional upon reforms etc. for several of them.
Many of Yugoslavia’s former republics continue to maintain close relationships with each other in which they are each other’s biggest trading partners and have a number of mutual agreements. The terrible fighting of the 1990s has not been forgotten, however. Bosnia-Herzegovina continues to be divided into Serb and Croat-Muslim sub-states and Serbia refuses to acknowledge Kosovo despite it having gained independence. The economy is struggling in many of the countries and the process of rebuilding the broken countries has been difficult. Despite all this there has been peace for many years. Relationships between most states are normalised and the contributions provided by the UN, NATO and EU have helped to bring increased stability to the Balkans over the last decade and hopefully for years to come.
