text.text:
BACKGROUND
Populations always need assistance when they are affected by natural disasters, diseases, crop failures, conflicts and war. Since its first deployment in 1953, the Danish Emergency Management Agency’s employees and materials have provided and continue to provide a large contribution in close collaboration with other aid organisations (e.g. Red Cross and DanChurchAid) and international organisations (such as the UN and EU). The missions have been very diverse, including transportation, emergency aid, hospitals, providing drinking water, advisory services, pumping water away after floods, support during epidemics, building refugee camps etc. You can read about what was involved in each deployment by clicking on each mission. You will be surprised how many different missions we have been involved with.

missions.title: ONUC Congo
missions.subtitle: Chaos in Congo
missions.name: ONUC Congo
missions.descriptiveName: Opération des Nations Unies au Congo

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Decolonisation of the European colonies in Asia and Africa began after World War II. The transition of the Belgian Congo from being a colony to being an independent state took place quite suddenly in June 1960. The Congolese people lacked the resources necessary to govern a country of 2.3 million square kilometres (1.2 million square miles) – four times the size of France. As a result, chaotic conditions affected the population of about 13 million including 140,000 whites. Separatist groups declared independence for the province of Katanga, giving rise to hostilities between separatists and the newly formed Congolese army, Armée Nationale Congolaise (ANC), whose practices included mutiny, murder, and looting. The conflict worsened after several attacks on the remaining Belgian civilians and troops. Belgium then intervened militarily in the crisis in July 1960 by deploying 12,000 ground troops.
Under these circumstances, the Congolese government on July 12 requested assistance from the UN to counter foreign aggression.
Moise Tshombe, Mobutu, Lumumba, Dag Hammarskjöld, and the Luba peoples became familiar names during this period.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
On 14 July 1960, the UN Security Council decided that the Belgian troops must leave Congo as soon as possible. At the same time, the UN mission Organisation des Nations Unies au Congo (ONUC) was established. The goal of the mission was to maintain law and order, provide technical assistance to the inexperienced Congolese government, train the Congolese army and police force, and persuade the separatist groups to reverse their secession. The mandate was expanded in February and November 1961 to include protection of the political and territorial integrity of Congo, prevent civil war, and ensure the removal of all foreign troops not under UN command – including mercenaries and paramilitary forces – if necessary by using military power as a last resort. With this expanded mandate, the UN mission changed from being a peacekeeping effort into exercising a peace enforcement function.
During this mission, UN Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjöld perished in an aviation accident.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: In 1960, Denmark’s participation was approved by the government after submission of the proposal to the Foreign Affairs Council.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: About 900 Danes from the three armed forces participated in ONUC during the years 1960-1964. They started arriving in Congo in August 1960 as did personnel from many other nations (28 countries). Denmark’s principal contribution to the mission was logistics and technical personnel, including aircraft and helicopter crews for an S-55 helicopter, military police, transport control personnel, vehicle technicians, sanitation workers, and observers and staff officers (a few of whom had been transferred from the Middle East). During 1963, a regular transport unit was deployed for a brief period. Danish transport planes were made available for extended periods, and the sanitation workers provided assistance to civilians.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: ONUC extended from 1960 to June 1964. Danish troops were present for the entire period. In 1963, the mission succeeded in reintegrating the Katanga region and thus in re-establishing the territorial integrity of Congo, whereupon the UN troops were phased out. By the end of 1964, the mission had accomplished its mandate and then departed. ONUC ended up being the largest and most costly UN mission so far with over 70,000 military personnel, 4,200 civilians, and 2,724 administrators.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Denmark’s principal contribution was logistics and technical personnel, including aircraft and helicopter crews, military police, transport control personnel, vehicle technicians, sanitation workers, and staff officers.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In the 1945 constitution of the Federal People’s Republic of Yugoslavia, Kosovo with a population largely made up of ethnic Albanians, was granted a special autonomous status as a province of the state of Serbia. While Serbian President Slobodan Milošević was in power the Serbian parliament revoked this independent status in 1989. During the breakup of Yugoslavia in the 1990s, Kosovo was at first relatively peaceful, but in 1996 a conflict broke out between the paramilitary group the Kosovo Liberation Army (UCK) and Serbian police and military in the area. As was happening elsewhere in the former Yugoslavia, the war was characterised by attacks on civilians and ethnic cleansing. As a consequence, NATO initiated airborne attacks on Serbian targets in March 1999 in an attempt to stop the conflict and force the Serbian-Yugoslavian forces to withdraw from Kosovo.
A large proportion of the population, from both the Serbian and the Kosovo-Albanian areas, had already fled because of the armed engagements and numerous attacks on civilians. The fighting and Serbian deportations of civilian Kosovo-Albanians meant that neighbouring Albania and Macedonia were, during the spring of 1999, receiving refugee numbers that had not been seen in Europe since the Second World War. The two already-poor countries therefore had problems guaranteeing refugees’ living conditions and safety and performing civilian emergency aid work.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In April 1999, Albania requested aid from NATO to help manage the situation, both as a military force to establish a safe environment for refugees and the performance of emergency aid work. This request was granted by NATO’s council and a plan was prepared to deploy an international force, that would be named Albanian Force (AFOR). Based on the Albanian request, the Danish Parliament considered this deployment an international collaboration that was based on a national agreement. Military force should only be applied to ensure safety, the free movement of the force itself and in the event of emergencies. The UN High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) accepted an offer from NATO in April to provide military support for their work to aid refugees from Kosovo who had fled to Albania and Macedonia.
The Danish Emergency Management Agency contributed to aiding the humanitarian disaster by sending personnel to perform many different tasks and missions (see Danish Emergency Management Agency, Albania 1999).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Denmark’s contribution to AFOR was put before Parliament as proposal B116 on 8 April and adopted after its second reading on 13 April 1999, by a vote of 107 in favour and 3 opposed. The purpose of the deployment would be to secure emergency and humanitarian aid and ensure safety for the large number of refugees in Albania. When the proposal was put forward, approximately 285,000 Kosovo-Albanian refugees were in Albania because of the fighting between paramilitary forces and the Yugoslavian (Serbian) army and because of ethnic cleansing.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Government wanted to deploy a reconnaissance unit of up to 200 men, as well as personnel for NATO command structure and joint support units. The deployment consisted of an approximately 140-strong reconnaissance squadron from the Bornholm Guards (Bornholms Værn), a National Support Group from the Træn Regiment in Aalborg and 10 men for the multi-national NATO headquarters. The reconnaissance squadron would be equipped with its standard hardware, including 15 “Eagle” wheeled armoured vehicles. There would also be an option for air support from the F-16 aircraft and their crews that had already been deployed as part of the NATO operation in the Kosovo conflict itself.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The Danish and international deployments as part of AFOR lasted from the beginning of April 1999 to August 1999.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The primary mission was to ensure emergency and humanitarian aid for the many Kosovo-Albanian refugees that were in Albania (and in particular northern Albania) at the time. The unit would, at the same time, establish and maintain safe conditions for the refugees, Albanian authorities and humanitarian organisations that were working in the area. During the operation, the number of refugees in Albania rose from 285,000 in April to a peak of 435,000. The mission would later support refugee transportation back to Kosovo after a peace treaty had been negotiated and the war was over. According to UNHCR, approximately 430,000 people returned home safely after the war ended in June.

missions.title: UNMOT Tajikistan
missions.subtitle: A Successful UN Mission
missions.name: UNMOT Tadjikistan
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission of Observers in Tajikistan

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The fall of the Soviet Union in 1991 led to the emergence of several new independent nations including Tajikistan. Immediately after the declaration of independence for Tajikistan, power struggles arose that evolved into a civil war between various ethnic factions.
By mid-1993, the civil war had taken 60,000 lives, most of them civilian. With the aid of the UN, the warring parties succeeded in negotiating a ceasefire. It was agreed that the UN was to assist in enforcing the ceasefire. That was the impetus for United Nations Mission of Observers in Tajikistan (UNMOT).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UNMOT was set up by UN Security Council Resolution 968 of 16 December 1994. The decision was based on a report from the UN Secretary-General, S/1994/1363, dated 30 November 1994. The mandate was limited to a military observation mission whose objective was to monitor an agreement for a temporary ceasefire between the government of Tajikistan and its opposition.
The mandate of the mission was expanded by Resolution 1138 of 14 November 1997. That resolution came about as a result of statements in the Secretary-General’s report S/1997/686 to the effect that the military and the civilian elements of the mission both needed to be bolstered. In the case of the civilian element, this could be accomplished by providing expertise in police work.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision to provide support from Denmark was made by the government upon a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee on 11 February 1993.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
From January 1993 to May 2000, Danish Defence contributed 20 military observers and, for a time, a brigadier general as commander of the observers and a colonel as second in command (though not at the same time).
The police mission was initiated on 14 November 1997. Upon the completion of national elections in February and March 2000, the mandate expired at the end of May 2000.
The mission had its moments of drama. On 20 December 1996, a Danish UN observer and his team were taken hostage by a Tajik rebel group. With some negotiation, the observers were however released the next day.
During February and March, one more hostage taking incident occurred, not involving any Danes. In total, 22 persons were taken hostage including military observers, UN civilians, and workers in humanitarian aid organisations. All were released after negotiations.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The UNMOT mission extended from 1993 to 2004; Denmark took part from 1993 to 2000. In addition, Denmark provided a brigadier general to command the observers from 1999 to 2002.
The participation of Denmark ended upon the completion of a successful observation mission culminating in a peace agreement with the opposition in Tajikistan. The mandate carried on, without participation from Denmark, with the objective of monitoring the implementation of the peace agreement. The mission was terminated in 2004 when a successful peace process in Tajikistan had been accomplished.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The military observers in the mission were tasked with monitoring, reporting to the UN, and assisting in compliance with and execution of the peace agreement between the Tajik government and the rebel forces.
The police mission was intended to provide expertise in educating local police authorities with respect to new legislation, human rights, etc.

missions.title: OAF & BAO Kosovo
missions.subtitle: Air Operation in Kosovo
missions.name: OAF & BAO Kosovo
missions.descriptiveName: Operation Allied Force and Balkan Air Operation

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In the 1945 constitution of the Federal People’s Republic of Yugoslavia, Kosovo with a population largely made up of ethnic Albanians, was granted a special autonomous status as a province of the state of Serbia. While Serbian President Slobodan Milošević was in power, the Serbian parliament revoked this independent status in 1989. During the breakup of Yugoslavia in the 1990s, Kosovo was at first relatively peaceful, but in 1996 a conflict broke out between the paramilitary group the Kosovo Liberation Army and Serbian police and military in the area.
In February 1998, the conflict in Kosovo escalated, and as in other parts of Yugoslavia, attacks on civilians and ethnic cleansing were common. Thousands of refugees spilled into neighbouring countries. NATO stationed military forces to maintain security and provide humanitarian aid. Although the UN Security Council urged cessation of hostilities, the conflict was not resolved by diplomatic means. The Yugoslav government refused to accept NATO personnel as peacekeepers as it was feared that doing so would give rise to an independent nation of Kosovo. The view in Belgrade was that Western nations had had a hand in the loss of Yugoslav territories in other parts of Yugoslavia near the existing UN missions in the area.
After several rounds of international negotiations, particularly in Rambouillet in France, it was realised in March 1999 that the conflict could not be resolved by diplomatic means. At that time, NATO had assembled an air force for the purpose of putting pressure on the Yugoslav government, and shortly after the breakdown of negotiations, it was deployed on missions in Kosovo and Serbia.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Due to Russian and Chinese opposition in the Security Council, it was not possible to establish a UN mandate for Operation Allied Force However, Resolution 1199 (1998) ordered all parties to the conflict to cease violence, permit international observers, and find a peaceful resolution.
On 13 October 1998, at a meeting of the NATO North Atlantic Council, it was decided to issue activation orders – ACTORD – for an air campaign against Yugoslavia to ensure compliance with Security Council Resolution 1199 (1998). Still, it was hoped that a diplomatic resolution would be possible. The air campaign did not start until March of the following year (1999) when the negotiations had broken down.
Although this activity was based on Resolution 1199 (1998), the resolution did not provide a mandate for a regular military intervention. However, NATO still decided to proceed with the operation when President Slobodan Milošević refused to accept the Rambouillet accord that was supposed to put an end to hostilities. That was the first time military operations were carried out by NATO without a clear mandate from the UN. For that reason, the operation was met with significant international criticism. The NATO view, however, was that in light of the ethnic cleansing, there was an obligation to intervene in order to force Milošević to accept an accord that would end the conflict and prevent further attacks on civilians and thus ensure compliance with the UN resolution.
The Supreme Allied Commander in Europe requested that Denmark contribute four F-16 fighter jets to the overall effort.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 7 October 1998, Denmark’s Minister of Foreign Affairs introduced a proposal (B4) to provide a military contribution from Denmark to NATO. In this proposal, the government stressed the humanitarian crisis, the fact that Yugoslavia did not comply with UN resolutions, the fact that the conflict might impact the overall security situation in the region, and the fact that military force would be used only when all diplomatic avenues had been pursued.
Quite a debate ensued as this contribution would be the first deployment of the Danish armed forces without a UN mandate. Opponents of the proposal pointed out, among other things, that the humanitarian problem could not be solved with bombers. It was stated in addition that without a clear mandate from the UN, any action would constitute an attack without legitimacy in international law – and thus would undermine the international system. Furthermore, it was pointed out that no intervention had been made in the Algerian Civil War or in Sri Lanka. Supporters of the proposal stressed that efforts were being made to issue a UN resolution and that the only reason for the Security Council not to issue a direct mandate for military intervention was Russia’s veto power. The majority of political parties were of the opinion that it was necessary to set an example to demonstrate that ethnic cleansing of a country’s population by its own government is unacceptable. Experience from Bosnia, where military force or the threat of it had been necessary, was felt to be relevant. The discussion whether fighter jets would be able to bring peace took up much of the debate, and it was stated that in all likelihood ground troops would be necessary at a later stage.
Proposal B4 was dealt with on an urgent basis in Parliament, and it was approved the following day, 8 October 1998, with 92 votes in favour and 28 votes opposed. That majority was among the slimmest in modern times to approve the use of Danish military forces.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Upon the request from NATO and the approval by Parliament, initially four F-16 fighter jets and two extras were sent from Fighter Squadron 730 in Skrydstrup along with 115 air crew to participate in the international NATO deployment in Operation Allied Force. Three additional F-16 jets and their air crew were sent in April 1999. All in all, about 480 Danish military personnel and nine F-16 fighter jets took part in the operation.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
On 13 October 1998, the fighters took off from the air base Skrydstrup to take part in the NATO operation based in Italy. However, NATO did not initiate the air strikes on Serbian positions in Kosovo until 24 March the following year. Seventy-eight days later, on 9 June 1999, the conflict officially came to an end when Milošević entered into a so-called Military Technical Agreement with NATO. Then, the UN Security Council approved Resolution 1244 (1999) to establish the Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo. On 10 June, the Serbian soldiers and police officers left Kosovo to let international forces take over. Denmark provided military personnel for this mission as well. Additional information is presented in the material on KFOR (Kosovo Force).
To ensure that Milošević complied with the agreement, three Danish F-16 jets with pilots and support personnel remained in Italy as part of a NATO force that was available also to support the operations in Bosnia. They were jointly referred to as the Balkan Air Operation. In June 2000, it was decided to recall the jets and most of the personnel to Denmark. The last of the Danish personnel in Operation Allied Force and Balkan Air Operation returned to Denmark in September 2002.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The Danish and Norwegian jets were based at Grazzanise Air Base in Italy and flew their missions from there during the entire operation. NATO carried out a number of air raids on military targets, mostly in Kosovo, but targets in Serbia proper were bombed as well in an attempt to impose a peace treaty. NATO was criticised several times for hitting non-military targets in Serbia. In particular, the bombing of a Yugoslav TV station and the Chinese embassy in Belgrade drew significant criticism and created tensions between NATO, Russia, and China.
For security reasons, jets were not permitted to land on the Italian Grazzanise Air Base or on the aircraft carriers used as bases by other nations if they were carrying live bombs and missiles. Therefore, special dump zones were designated in the Adriatic Sea between Italy and the Balkan Peninsula. Ordnance was dropped here on the way back from a mission to Kosovo or Serbia. Later, NATO initiated Operation Allied Harvest with vessels to perform mine clearance and prevent live ordnance from floating freely. Here, too, Denmark took part with two ships from the Royal Danish Navy.
For most of the operation, the Danish jets were used primarily for escorts and air defence. At a later time, the Danish squadron was deployed in more aggressive operations, attacking Serbian ammunition depots, radar installations, and command centres in Kosovo. This was the first time the Royal Danish Air Force took active part in acts of war.
As a matter of interest, the allied bombardment of Serbian forces in 1995 lasted for 3-4 days while this operation lasted 80 days.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Between 1996 and 2006, Nepal was ravaged by a bloody civil war in which communist Maoists attempted to violently overthrow the Nepalese monarchy and establish a republic.  After 10 years of fighting and over 19,000 casualties, the warring parties in 2006 signed a peace accord to bring extensive political reforms to Nepal. In this environment, the Nepalese Maoists and the Nepalese government requested assistance from the UN in keeping the peace process going.
Since 1999, the Danish Institute for Human Rights has been working with the Kathmandu School of Law to achieve reforms in the Nepalese judicial system with a special emphasis on improving knowledge of human rights and their implementation in the judicial system.
An agreement was reached in 2015, in collaboration with the Danish Embassy in Nepal and the Kathmandu School of Law, to launch a program to identify and prevent human rights violations by security forces.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UNMIN was established on 23 January 2007 by UN Security Council Resolution 1740 with a mandate to monitor the process of disarmament between the two parties, to assist in monitoring compliance with the ceasefire, and to provide technical assistance in planning a free and fair democratic election for the newly constituted Nepalese parliament. Since then, the mission has been extended several times. It was terminated in January 2011.

All told, the UN force consisted of about 1,000 personnel including 242 observers from several countries including Denmark and Sweden.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish government decided in 2007, after a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee, to contribute observers.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 2015 decided that Denmark would participate in the human rights related work.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Six Danish UN observers were dispatched from 2007 to 2011, and four police instructors were dispatched from 2015 to 2018.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNMIN lasted from 2007 to 2011 and culminated in April 2018 when an election was held to fill the new parliament.  The UN played an important role in the peace process and in the successful transition from a monarchy to a republic. As of 2009, UN personnel in Nepal were phased out, and the mission ended in 2011.
The police training mission ran from September 2015 to February 2018.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Based on the UN Security Council mandate, the tasks of the observers were to monitor the retrieval of weapons from the warring parties and the return of soldiers under 18 years of age to their homes. In addition, the observers were to monitor compliance with the ceasefire.
The human rights project aimed to educate and thus strengthen the capacity of Nepalese officials in preventing and countering human rights violations perpetrated by the Nepal Police, the Nepal Armed Police Force (APF), and forest security guards. There was a special emphasis on good governance and leadership and on inappropriate use of violence and torture. In particular, the job of the Danish police officers was to assist in training 60 members of the Nepalese police who were to work as human rights protection facilitators. Their role was to serve as instructors and trainers in the police districts.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When Yugoslavia broke apart in the 1990s, the Albanian majority in the Kosovo province attempted to gain independence from the now Serbian-dominated federal republic. Serbian President Slobodan Milošević had revoked autonomy for the province, and that escalated in the late 1990s to a conflict between the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) and the Serbian military and police forces in the region.
As the conflict involved attacks on civilians and ethnic cleansing, NATO decided to mount an air campaign, using fighter jets and bombers against the regime in Belgrade. The purpose was to force it to leave Kosovo and to comply with UN Security Council Resolution 1199 (1998). The NATO campaign and the Danish contribution to it were referred to as Operation Allied Force.
To be safe, it was undesirable to land the aircraft with live bombs if these had not been dropped in Serbia and Kosovo. The bombs were therefore dropped in special dump zones in the Adriatic Sea between Italy and the Balkan Peninsula. When Italian fishermen caught bombs in their nets, a domestic political problem arose for Italy and put the alliance under pressure.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: No direct mandate existed for the Operation Allied Harvest mine clearance. The operation took place in Italian waters, and as a NATO member Italy automatically permitted the ships to operate there. One of the purposes of the operation was to prevent friction in the alliance as a result of unexploded bombs floating around in the water, posing a risk of fatal accidents for fishermen (especially Italian fishermen).

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark’s Minister of Foreign Affairs introduced a proposal (B146) in Parliament on 25 May 1999. The proposal included an earlier date for the routine dispatch of two ships, Makrellen and Lindormen , to the Standing NATO Maritime Groups, and the contribution of the corvette Peter Tordenskiold to the NATO embargo of Yugoslavia (Serbia). The proposal noted that the bombs to be cleared were ones that had been provided for use through a decision of Parliament. The two ships Makrellen and Lindormen were already slated to become part of the NATO minesweeping fleet; the proposal simply requested an earlier date for their dispatch.
The debate in Parliament focused primarily on the legitimacy of the embargo and on formalities related to information submitted to Parliament. There were only a few comments as to the scope and financing of the mine clearance. Opponents were against the embargo but had no objections to the mine clearance.
Proposal B146 on Denmark’s maritime contribution to NATO activities in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula was approved on 28 May 1999 with 86 votes in favour and 22 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution consisted of the ship Makrellen, a Standard Flex 300 vessel, FLYVEFISKEN class, equipped as a minesweeper. As a mine clearance vessel, it was fitted with a minesweeper drone, i.e. a remotely controlled smaller craft with a sonar, and a remotely controlled unmanned submarine armed with explosives. This enabled the localisation and detonation of mines without the need for manned ships to sail in dangerous waters.
Later, the ship Lindormen was added. Ironically, that ship was originally designed as a minelayer. This ship served as a command centre for the NATO minesweeping force in the Adriatic Sea.
The corvette Peter Tordenskiold was contributed for participation in the embargo of Yugoslavia (Serbia) as it had been during the Bosnia conflict. However, the Kosovo War had ended before the corvette arrived at the destination.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was initiated by Makrellen and the rest of the NATO force on 9 June 1999. NATO concluded the minesweeping operation on 24 August. Lindormen was used as a command vessel as of the second half of July and remained as such for the Standing NATO Mine Countermeasures Group known as MCMFORNORTH until 1 October.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The primary goal of the mission was to find and detonate the ordnance dumped in the Adriatic Sea between Italy and the Balkan Peninsula. In addition, mines were found that had been lying in the sea since World War II. Among the 93 mines and bombs found and detonated during this operation, Makrellen accounted for as many as 25, at depths up to 200 metres. This ship and its minesweeping system were thus by far the most effective in the NATO operation.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Ever since the monarchy was overthrown in a coup on 1 September 1969, Libya had been ruled by Colonel Muammar Gaddafi. He never officially became president, but he ruled the country as “Brotherly Leader and Guide of the Revolution” and claimed that it was a democracy governed by the people. The large oil reserves in the country enabled him to develop the country into one of the richest in the region, but he also devoted huge resources to the support of African dictators, Palestinian resistance groups, and the like. He is believed to have masterminded several terrorist attacks on Europe and the United States during the 1970s and 1980s.
In December 2010, demonstrations were held in neighbouring Tunisia to protest widespread corruption and the authoritarian regime. Large protests ensued and spread through the entire region as the “Arab Spring”. Demonstrations were held in Libya as well, but unlike the dictators in Tunisia and Egypt who resigned as a result of the popular uprisings, Gaddafi remained and ordered the military to crack down hard on any resistance. Some units of the army refused to fire at civilians, and before long the country was divided. An eastern part was led by demonstrators out of the city of Benghazi, and a western part was led by Gaddafi’s loyal soldiers out of the capital city of Tripoli.
During February, this situation developed into a regular civil war between the National Transitional Council of Libya, supported by military deserters and volunteers, and Gaddafi with the bulk of the country’s armed forces. On 22 February 2011, in a speech televised live, he described the rebels as rats and cockroaches and gangs of drunken drug addicts and swore to have anyone hanged who so much as raised a hand in protest against his regime. He succeeded in a brief offensive shortly thereafter, and his soldiers were closing in on Benghazi. In the international community, there were fears of a genocide in the event the forces loyal to the government were to occupy the city.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In an effort to prevent a defeat of the rebels and a potential genocide, the Arab League met on 12 March and requested that the UN set up a no-fly zone over Libya. It was hoped that support could be given to the rebels by preventing Gaddafi from using the air force and thus giving them a chance to defend themselves.
France, the UK, and Lebanon – as a representative of the Arab League – then made a proposal to the UN Security Council that became Resolution 1973 (2011). The resolution was adopted on 17 March with no opposing votes and few abstentions. Several sanctions were imposed on the Libyan regime. The most important sanction was the request that the international community establish a no-fly zone over the country and protect civilians by any means possible except deployment of occupation forces in Libya.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Based on Security Council Resolution 1973 (2011), the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs submitted a proposal (B89) to provide military assistance. In the proposal, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs interpreted the UN authorisation to protect civilians by any means possible to mean that a no-fly zone in itself cannot prevent attacks, and it requested authorisation to carry out air strikes against Libyan government forces. Comments on and questions about the proposal focused on a reluctance to deploy troops and on a desire to put pressure on the Gaddafi regime to accept a ceasefire and a peaceful resolution of the conflict. In addition, there was some concern about future developments in light of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
The proposal was dealt with on an urgent basis due to the seriousness of the situation. Introduced on 18 March, it was approved the following day with 110 votes in favour (all parties in Parliament).
On 30 March, however, the unity ended when the Red-Green Alliance withdrew its support of the mission. The Red-Green Alliance was of the opinion that while the UN had issued a mandate to prevent attacks on civilians, direct air support of the uprising would constitute participation in the civil war.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Fourteen NATO countries took part in the mission along with Jordan, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates. Denmark contributed a C-130 Hercules transport aircraft and four F-16 fighters plus two extras. Including pilots and the relevant support personnel, about 120 members of the Air Force were sent to the Sigonella Naval Air Station on Sicily.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The mission had started with French, British, and American aircraft on 18 March. The Danish contribution began with active participation on 20 March. Originally, France, the UK, and the United States each had a separate mission. The Danish aircraft operated as part of the American Operation Odyssey Dawn. On 30 March, the three missions were united in NATO’s Operation Unified Protector.
At the outset, no termination date was planned as it was unknown how the situation would evolve. When Gaddafi’s forces had been defeated in the autumn, and when he was captured and executed on 20 October, the UN decided on 27 October to let the mandate expire at the end of the month. Denmark took part in the mission until its end on 31 October 2011.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: First and foremost, the mission focused on providing protection of the civilian population under siege in Benghazi and in the eastern part of Libya. As Gaddafi’s soldiers used artillery and tanks to attack civilian targets, conventional air support was provided to retaliate against these soldiers, often in coordination with the Libyan rebels. The operation grew in step with the movement of hostilities and came to include air missions in the entire country when the rebels had liberated larger areas. Following on a major offensive in late August, the rebels entered Tripoli, and in October, the city of Sirte, Gaddafi’s birthplace, was taken. He was captured and killed here. In all, Denmark flew approximately 1,300 missions over Libya.

text.heading: Background
text.text: When Pakistan separated from India in 1947, the rulers of former principalities like Kashmir and Jammu had to decide which of the two countries they would be aligned with. Both countries claimed rights to Kashmir. This resulted in military conflict between India and Pakistan in 1965. The UN India-Pakistan Observation Mission (UNIPOM) was established 1965 with a mandate from the UN. Four Danish observers took part. Their role was to assist in the monitoring of the ceasefire that had been agreed between the two countries. The Danish observers were present from September 1965 to March 1966. They operated near the Kashmir border and on the Arabian Sea along the border between India and Pakistan. The Danish team collaborated with people who had been posted from 21 other countries, including Norway, Sweden and Finland. The war ended in 1966 with no clear victor.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: A request from the General Secretary of the United Nations for a number of Danish officers to serve with the UN observation corps in Kashmir was granted by the Danish Government.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: UNIPOM was set up by the UN Security Council in September 1965, with a mandate to monitor the ceasefire along the border between India and Pakistan.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark’s contribution was comprised of four military observers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Danish involvement lasted from September 1965 to March 1966.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Alongside observers from 21 other countries, the Danish UN observers were tasked with monitoring and promoting the ceasefire that had been agreed between India and Pakistan. The observers operated near the Kashmir border and on the Arabian Sea along the border between India and Pakistan.
The war ended in 1966 with no clear victor.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Lebanon has been beset by many conflicts internally and in its wars with Israel. The story of UNIFIL goes back to 1978 (during the Lebanese Civil War). The only party to the civil war not to lay down arms in the peace agreement of 1990 was the Hezbollah movement. It is a political party as well as a heavily armed militia. At that time, the southern part of the country was still occupied by Israeli troops, and the Lebanese people viewed Hezbollah as the strongest part of the resistance. Although Israel withdrew from Lebanon in 2000, smaller skirmishes have erupted between Hezbollah and Israel several times.
In the morning of 12 July 2006, Hezbollah fired rockets across the border and attacked an Israeli convoy, taking two soldiers hostage for later use in a prisoner exchange.  This led to a confrontation between Israeli military and the Hezbollah militia in Lebanese territory. Starting with bombs and rockets being fired across the border, it developed over the summer into an all-out invasion by Israeli soldiers and tanks into southern Lebanon. The Israeli government on several occasions stated that it was not in its view at war with the state of Lebanon, only with terrorists from Hezbollah inside Lebanon; yet government buildings and many civilian areas took serious hits, just as Hezbollah rockets did not distinguish between military and civilian targets in Israel.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The UN Security Council approved Resolution 1701 in August 2006. The primary objective of the resolution was to end the fighting by requesting that Israel withdraw its military from Lebanon while a 15,000-man force secured the area around the so-called Blue Line until the Lebanese army could assume control of southern Lebanon. In addition, an embargo was to be established so as to prevent arms materiel from entering the country over and above the amount authorised by the Lebanese government. This was an attempt to disarm Hezbollah or at least prevent its acquisition of new materiel.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Based on UN Security Council Resolution 1701, proposal B146 was introduced in the Danish Parliament on 7 September 2006. The government requested approval from Parliament for Denmark to contribute to UNIFIL and the execution of the resolution by providing a Niels Juel class corvette and/or 1-2 Flyvefisken class Standard Flex 300 ships. These ships needed a mandate to use force in self defence and in executing the tasks they might be given to assist in the arms embargo.
The proposal was approved at second reading on 14 September with 104 votes in favour and 3 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Three ships, Glenten and Ravnen and the corvette Peter Tordenskiold were sent off, initially to Wilhelmshaven to join the German ships commanding the maritime part of UNIFIL. However, the UN indicated that the corvette was not required. On 21 September, Glenten and Ravnen sailed to the eastern part of the Mediterranean off the coast of Lebanon. These two vessels were Standard Flex 300 patrol ships. Each had a crew of about 30 personnel. They were assisted by a 20-man logistics element from the navy mobile logistics support unit based in Limassol in Cyprus.
In December 2006, Viben (a ship of the same class) sailed to Cyprus to take over the mission from Ravnen and Glenten.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Ravnen and Glenten arrived in Cyprus on 3 October 2006 to start the mission. After the substitution of Viben, the mission was slated to continue until 31 March 2007. It was however extended by five months to the end of August. At that time, Denmark’s engagement in the UNIFIL naval operations ended. UNIFIL dates back to 1978 and is still active.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The ships were to carry out assignments related to surveillance, control, patrols, and intelligence gathering in an effort to support the Lebanese government and prevent the smuggling of arms to Hezbollah. Thus the mission might include interception and inspection of any ship without permission from the captain or the country of registration. The Parliament mandate authorised the Danish ships to use necessary force in executing the UN mission.
From its base in Cyprus, the naval force operated in the eastern part of the Mediterranean, primarily in an area 45 nautical miles off the coast of Lebanon.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
During the Lebanese Civil War, the Palestinian organisation PLO used Lebanon as a base for launching attacks on Israel. At the same time, Israel often attacked PLO positions in southern Lebanon with artillery and missiles. Subsequent to a major PLO action in March 1978, the Israeli army launched Operation Litani and occupied the entire southern part of Lebanon up to the Litani River aside from a small enclave around the city of Tyre. The next day, the Lebanese government submitted a protest to the UN Security Council over the invasion.
The first UNIFIL mission was then set up on the basis of UN Security Council Resolutions 425 and 426.  As a priority, Israel was ordered to cease all military action in Lebanon and to withdraw from that country. UNIFIL was established to ensure that the Israeli withdrawal did in fact take place, to maintain international peace and security in southern Lebanon, and to assist the Lebanese government in reasserting its authority over the area. The Israelis stayed put, and the Palestinian and certain Lebanese militias did not recognise the Israeli occupation or the UNIFIL mandate. Fighting continued. Later, Resolution 427 was approved. It increased the size of the mission to 6,000 men from 4,000, and the UN reiterated the order that all Israeli soldiers were to leave Lebanon. The ”I” in UNIFIL stood for ”Interim” – in other words, the hope was that it would be a short engagement and not a permanent presence that might get involved in the civil war. The UN Security Council since then has renewed the mandate as the mission could not be considered complete. This effort has since been named UNIFIL I. Denmark contributed 6 officers in 1978 when the mission started. They assisted in building the mission headquarters in Naqoura. UNTSO (UN Truce Supervision Organization) already had a presence in the region and provided these officers on loan. Denmark’s participation in UNIFIL I did not last long. When Israel withdrew from the occupied area in the summer of 1978, control was transferred not to UNIFIL but rather to an allied militia. Israel continued to supply weapons to this militia, its representative in the Lebanese Civil War.

When an assassination attempt was directed at an Israeli diplomat, Israel again invaded Lebanon on 6 June 1982. This time, the Israeli occupation culminated in a siege of the capital city of Beirut. The occupation continued even though an international agreement led PLO to leave Lebanon and go to Tunisia instead. After the massacres at the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps, massive international pressure caused the Israelis to withdraw. However, the Israeli army and allied militias maintained a so-called security zone in southern Lebanon where UNIFIL was operating. The Shiite movement Hezbollah now arose as a resistance group opposing the continued Israeli presence in the country.
The Lebanese Civil War ended officially with the Taif Agreement in 1989. Through this agreement, all militias were disarmed except Hezbollah. This group was regarded in Lebanon as a resistance movement against the occupation of southern Lebanon more than as a militia participating in the civil war. The Israeli security zone remained in Lebanon, in spite of attacks from Hezbollah, until Israel withdrew in 2000 without coordinating this move with the Lebanese government or UNIFIL. The situation remained tense, with isolated attacks across the border in a continuing conflict between Hezbollah and Israel.
In the morning of 12 July 2006, Hezbollah launched rockets across the border and attacked an Israeli convoy, taking two soldiers hostage. They were likely to be used in a prisoner exchange. This incident caused a major conflict that developed over the summer into an all-out invasion by Israeli soldiers and tanks into southern Lebanon. The Israeli government on several occasions stated that it was not in its view at war with the state of Lebanon, only with terrorists from Hezbollah inside Lebanon; yet government buildings and many civilian areas took serious hits, just as Hezbollah rockets did not distinguish between military and civilian targets in Israel.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UNIFIL got started by UN Security Council Resolutions 425, 426, and 427 of 1978. Later, the mission was extended by Resolution 1701 of 2006.
The UN Security Council approved Resolution 1701 in August 2006 as a result of the war between Hezbollah and Israel. The primary objective of the resolution was to end the fighting by requesting that Israel withdraw its military from Lebanon and to expand the UNIFIL force to 15,000 personnel. This expanded effort is known as UNIFIL II. As was the case previously, the international force was to move in and secure the area around the so-called Blue Line until the Lebanese army could assume control of southern Lebanon. In addition, the force was to remain in the country to prevent renewed fighting between Hezbollah and Israel and to act as liaison and coordinator between Israel and the Lebanese government.
An embargo was to be set up so as to prevent arms materiel from entering the county over and above the amount authorised by the Lebanese government. This was an attempt to disarm Hezbollah or at least prevent its acquisition of new materiel.
UNIFIL has a mandate to use force in carrying out its tasks and in ensuring that it is free to move around and generally is safe.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish engagement in UNIFIL I/1978 consisted of officers transferred from UNTSO. The UN in this case obtained permission from the Danish government.
Two decisions were made in the Danish Parliament with respect to UNIFIL:
Upon request from the UN, the Minister of Foreign Affairs submitted proposal B146 regarding a naval contribution to the expanded UN mission in Lebanon. It was approved at second reading on 14 September 2006 with 104 votes in favour and 3 votes opposed.
Again upon request from the UN for participation from Denmark, the Minister of Foreign Affairs on 5 November 2009 submitted proposal B41 regarding a ground forces contribution to UNIFIL.
In both cases, there was wide support politically. It was stressed that a very clear UN mandate had been issued, that the Lebanese and the Israeli governments officially supported the UNIFIL mission, and that this was an opportunity to contribute to stability and lasting peace in the region. A few questions were raised with respect to the political work of Hezbollah as a part of the then newly constituted Lebanese government. With reassurances that the Lebanese government still supported the mission of UNIFIL, all parties in Parliament were in favour of the decision.
The proposal was unanimously approved, without amendments, at second reading on 24 November with 108 votes in favour.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark contributed six officers (transferred from UNTSO) to UNIFIL I in 1978. They helped build the UNIFILheadquarters in Naqoura in southern Lebanon. The main portion of the Danish contribution to UNIFIL took place subsequent to the conflict in 2006.
The army and the air force have contributed to the ground troops engagement, based in the city of Naqoura in southern Lebanon, since 2009. All told, 735 Danish soldiers participated, organised in teams of about 150.
From 2009 to 2011, Danes were a constant presence (about 150 of them at a time) in Naqoura. The teams were replaced every six months. Five teams of Danish soldiers were sent. Teams 1 and 2 were provided by the air force while the army took over as of August 2010 and sent teams 3, 4, and 5. These teams typically consisted of five staff officers working at UNIFIL headquarters and a logistics company of about 135 soldiers. Military police have been a part of each team.
Between August 2010 and December 2011, personnel from the Danish Emergency Management Agency participated by building and operating fire fighting capacity in Danish military camps. Other tasks included non-military assignments supervised by the commander of DANCON. During this period, 50 personnel on contract from national, municipal, and private entities worked under the auspices of the Danish Emergency Management Agency.
In 2006, Denmark in addition supplied a naval force to maintain the arms embargo.
The total Danish contribution amounted to about 1,300 persons from across the army, the navy, the air force, and the Danish Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNIFIL was divided into two missions due to the different situations and UN mandates: UNIFIL I from 1978 to 2006 and UNIFIL II starting in 2006. The latter is still active in Lebanon. Denmark took part in UNIFIL II for two years between December 2009 and November 2011; Austria then took over the engagement. The last Danish soldiers returned on 8 December 2011.
UNIFIL is still active in Lebanon.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The work in UNIFIL II consisted primarily of handling logistics and transport related tasks on behalf of the entire mission. Planning for and procurement of supplies was done by the staff officers in UNIFIL headquarters, and practical tasks such as transportation by vehicle and maintenance were handled by the logistics company. Tasks such as relocation and rotation of soldiers and equipment from other participating nations were handled by the Danish contingent. With responsibility for the UN depots, it managed materials ranging from office supplies to construction materials and fuel for the vehicles in the force. Repairs, likewise, were the remit of the Danes. The military police officers took care of handling lost and found items, maintaining law and order with the respect to the UN soldiers, and providing support and reporting in cases of traffic accidents and other minor incidents.
Emergency Management personnel handled fire fighting response readiness during helicopter flights, standard emergency response readiness within and outside camps, fire inspections of internal installations, guidance with respect to transport of dangerous goods, maintenance of materiel, and assorted tasks related to overall security in the camps.
UNIFIL distributes humanitarian aid in southern Lebanon and supports the Lebanese army in maintaining control of the area. The force in addition clears mines and other unexploded ammunition and monitors the border between Lebanon and Israel to prevent cross-border attacks and a new escalation of the conflict. In so doing it works closely with OGL (Observer Group Lebanon), a part of UNTSO (United Nations Truce Supervision Organization). Denmark contributes here as well.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The independent republic of Liberia was declared in 1847 and, despite opposition from the country’s indigenous population, approximately 16,000 liberated slaves immigrated from the USA between 1822-1892. These immigrants became an upper class that dominated Liberia and its population. The party of the elite ruled the country without interruption from 1877 to 1980, as the country’s original inhabitants were not given voting rights. Liberia’s political instability started in 1980, with the assassination of President Tolbert and several members of the government. The following period was characterised by instability and decline. On Christmas Eve 1989 a guerilla group called “the National Patriotic Front of Liberia” (NPFL) crossed the border from neighbouring Sierra Leone. Fighting between the guerilla groups and the army developed into an ethnic conflict between different population groups. Civilian populations were attacked and thousands fled to neighbouring countries. During the summer of 1990 Charles Taylor’s forces had gained control of most of Liberia and murdered President Doe. A peace treaty was not concluded until July 1993 with the participation of the UN and the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), but the prospect of peace was distant. The elections in July 1997 saw Charles Taylor winning with a 75% share of the vote. The peace was short-lasting and new unrest erupted, leading to the elimination of political rivals and the appearance of new rebel groups. The United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) was a UN mission established in 1993 and headquartered in the capital Monrovia. UNOMIL was created as part of the Cotonou Agreement to support the efforts of ECOWAS in Liberia during the First Liberian Civil War 1989–1996. Its initial mandate was to monitor the implementation of peace agreements between the Liberian parties, investigate violations, assist in maintenance of assembly sites and demobilisation of combatants, investigate violations of human rights and to monitor the electoral processs.

Taylor stepped down from the presidency in August 2003 and went into exile. A coalition government took control but the fighting and attacks on civilians continued. In September 2003 the UN decided to send 15,000 soldiers, observers and police personnel into Liberia to reassert security and disarm the militias. ECOWAS troops were already present in Liberia and became part of the UN force, which was named United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMIL). A number of Danish staff officers and observers were deployed between 2003 and 2010. The last remaining Danish officer departed Liberia in January 2016. In June that same year, the responsibility for Liberia’s national security was transferred to the country’s own national security forces.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish Government wanted to make a contribution towards preventing conflicts and to Liberia’s development as a country. There was broad political support for the deployment of observers, staff personnel and police to Liberia. The deployment was set in motion in October 2003 after being put to the Danish Foreign Policy Committee.
Between 2003 and 2016 Denmark would send four observers and two staff officers from all three wings of the Danish military, as well as a number of police personnel, doing so every six months. The postings were of between six to 12 months duration, depending on their function. About 50-60 uniformed personnel were deployed. The observers were generally assigned to teams around the country. The staff officers served at the UN headquarters in Liberia’s capital, Monrovia. A Danish diplomat was the supreme commander of the mission between 2007-2011.

There was no Danish contribution to UNOMIL.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN's 2003 mandate involved support for the implementation of the ceasefire agreement and the disarming and demobilisation of militias etc. It also involved humanitarian aid to the population and for healthcare reforms, as well as a reconstruction of the courts of law and state institutions etc.
In September 2003 the UN UNMIL peacekeeping mission, which involved up to 15,000 soldiers, including 250 observers, staff personnel and 850 police personnel. 44 countries worldwide contributed to this force. The mandate was established in UN Security Council Resolution 1509 of 19 September 2003. The UNMIL mandate has been extended several times and remains active at the time of writing.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNMIL has been downscaled on an ongoing basis since 2007, as Liberia’s own forces become increasingly capable of taking responsibility. The plan was that the last remaining UN forces would be from African countries, allowing the UN to assign the various missions to partners in the region. The 2015 Ebola outbreak delayed the transfer of these missions. The mission was finally wound down in March 2018.

The last Danish staff officers were recalled in January 2016. In June the same year, responsibility for Liberia's domestic security was officially assigned to its own forces.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The Danish UN observers served as the eyes and ears of the UN mission, reporting issues and situations to headquarters, to which the two staff officers had been assigned. The mission is deemed a success now that Liberia’s own security forces have taken over their responsibilities. There were free elections in Liberia in both 2006 and 2011. Liberia remains one of the poorest countries in the world, however, and is plagued by gross inequality and unemployment etc.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The unrest in Sierra Leone started in March 1991 when opponents of the government attempted to come to power. This turned into a protracted civil war between the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) and government troops. Although Liberian troops at first intervened by defending the government in Sierra Leone, the final result was that these troops turned against it and helped overthrow it. RUF was now in power, but that did not put an end to the unrest. The civil war raged on, and the country was facing a humanitarian disaster.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The UN entered into the conflict in October 1999 with up to 6,000 soldiers including 260 observers under the United Nations Mission in Sierra Leone (UNAMSIL) – primarily to support the government and the parties in negotiating agreements under relatively peaceful conditions. Additional mandates from the UN came later, expanding the area of operations and boosting the number of soldiers (up to about 18,000). The mission was active from 1999 to 2005.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision to send Danish observers was approved by the government upon a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee. In all, 14 Danish observers were deployed, primarily from the Royal Danish Army.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The purpose of sending observers was mainly to monitor the ceasefires agreed between the government of Sierra Leone and its opponents. The Danish observers worked with observers from a total of 32 countries, primarily in the capital of Sierra Leone, Freetown, where UNAMSIL had its headquarters. The civil war ended in 2002 after 11 years, and peace efforts now succeeded, partly as a result of the support of UNAMSIL. The mission remained in the country until 2005. About 45 countries took part in the mission.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 2 August 1990, Iraq under Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on the pretext that Kuwait had originally been an Iraqi province that was separated by British colonial interests after World War I.  Hussein was pressed financially after the long war with Iran and hoped to solve such problems by taking over the small but wealthy oil producing nation. This invasion was the first major international crisis after the end of the Cold War.
The invasion was widely condemned internationally. When a former Iraq ally, the Soviet Union, no longer desired to confront the U.S., Iraq did not have any support in the UN Security Council. A total of 12 resolutions were approved between August and November 1990. They demanded that the Iraqi occupation must end and imposed a series of sanctions against Iraq. This all culminated in Resolution 678 (1990) demanding that all Iraqi forces leave Kuwait by 15 January 1991. Should this demand not be met, the resolution authorised all countries, in collaboration with the government of Kuwait, to use any means necessary to get the Iraqi forces out of Kuwait.
When Saddam Hussein refused to comply and maintained the occupation of Kuwait, a coalition led by the U.S. initiated air raids on Iraqi forces on the day after the deadline. Thus began the First Gulf War. The ground war started on 24 February, and Kuwait was liberated on 28 February. Denmark participated in the Gulf War as a part of the international coalition by sending a corvette.
A formal ceasefire was entered into on 3 April 1991 on the basis of UN Security Council Resolution 687 (1991).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UN Security Council Resolution 687 (1991) provided for a demilitarised zone along the Iraq-Kuwait border that was to be monitored by a unit of observers. This zone was set up a few days later through Resolution 689 (1991), approved on 9 April. UNIKOM was planned to consist of 300 unarmed observers. The resolution provided a mandate to monitor the border area and the river Khawr Abd Allah between the two countries. The resolution further provided that the mandate was to continue until all permanent members of Security Council agreed to its termination.
There were some minor episodes involving Iraqi soldiers moving through the demilitarised zone. The mandate was now expanded by Resolution 806 in February 1993 to include a battalion of mechanised infantry and authorisation for the use of force to prevent future infractions.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: It was decided by the Foreign Policy Committee that Denmark ought to participate in UNIKOM.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: All in all, 548 Danish soldiers served in UNIKOM. During the first 30 days of the mission, the operation was considerably larger than the 300 observers originally anticipated. This was a result of the need to establish security until a base could be built and until the observation tasks could begin. Consequently, Denmark redirected a company of soldiers from Cyprus (where it was working within UNFICYP). Later, the Danish contingent was reduced in 1994 to consist of 6 observers and a logistics unit numbering 45.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNIKOM was active from April 1991 to October 2003 and then was terminated. Due to the new invasion into Iraq in 2003, the mission was temporarily suspended in order to protect the personnel. In July of that year, the mission resumed on the basis of Resolution 1490 (2003), though with the elimination of the demilitarised zone. The termination date was set to 6 October 2003. In the last months of UNIKOM, the work consisted primarily of decommissioning, transferring the mission’s buildings to authorities in Kuwait, and generally terminating activities. Denmark took part from start to finish.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The priority job for UNIKOM was to patrol and monitor the demilitarised zone along the border and the Khawr Abd Allah river and its estuary into the Persian Gulf. Observation posts were set up in the area from a headquarters located in the city of Umm Qasr. Land and air patrols were dispatched from here. In addition, there was close collaboration with the police forces in the two nations operating on both sides of the border.
The Danish soldiers redirected from Cyprus early on were initially charged with maintaining security while the mission was being implemented. Thereafter, the Danish observers participated by monitoring the demilitarised zone. The logistics element handled the relevant tasks associated with vehicle transportation. When Iraq retreated from Kuwait, it set fire to a number of oil drilling sites, leaving the area in thick smoke. These fires were put out primarily by American teams. A few Danes were part of this effort.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When NATO came into being in 1949, Iceland was the only founder member that did not have its own defence. Iceland’s strategic location in the North Atlantic allowed it to join the defensive alliance on the proviso that there was no expectation that Iceland would form an army or air force. From 1951 to 2005 the USA was responsible for Iceland’s defence from 1951 to 2006., through its Iceland Defence Force (IDF).   As soon as the USA withdrew its defensive units from Iceland in 2006, Russian combat aircraft began violating Icelandic airspace. Iceland requested assistance from its NATO allies at the NATO summit in Riga in 2006, in the form of a presence and actual defence of Icelandic airspace.
The North Atlantic Council (NATO’s supreme decision-makers) decided in July 2007 that it would add Iceland to NATO’s Air Policing Program.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
NATO Air Policing is part of the NATO Integrated Air and Missile Defence (NIAMD), a permanent mission to protect NATO territories, populations, and military forces against air strikes and missile attacks. Within NIAMD, NATO Air Policing functions as a collective defensive mission during peacetime, with the objective of protecting the airspace of NATO allies. NATO members therefore contribute on a rotating basis to the mission to protect countries which, like Iceland, have no capacity to protect their own airspace sovereignty.
Air Policing aims to prevent and repel potential security threats in NATO airspace, including foreign acts of aggression, the hijacking of civilian aircraft and aircraft that are not abiding by international air regulations. Air Policing also involves assisting aircraft that are in trouble.
The official designation of the sovereignty protection mission over Iceland is Iceland Peacetime Preparedness Needs (IPPN).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision to make Danish forces available on rotation to NATO’s integrated air defence of Iceland was adopted on 9 December 2006 by a unanimous Danish Parliament.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Royal Danish Air Force set up Iceland Air Policing and Surveillance Danish Detachment (ISLAPS), which is composed of personnel from three Royal Danish Air Force units: Fighter Wing Skrydstrup, Air Control Wing and Combat Support Wing. Denmark’s contribution in 2009 was four F-16 fighters and 48 personnel.
The primary mission of ISLAPS-2009 was airspace surveillance and repelling intruders in the airspace above and around Iceland. Icelandic airspace was thus monitored for 24 hours a day.
The mission was not without event. On 25 March, Danish fighter pilots had to intercept Russian combat aircraft that were approaching Icelandic sovereign airspace.
On 1 April, after a deployment of just under a month, the Danish F-16s returned to their base in Skrydstrup, having flown approx. 111 hours of missions.
Denmark again deployed four F-16s and 52 personnel from 8-29 March 2010 to the Keflavik base in Iceland. The Danish fighters again had to take to the air as Russian combat aircraft approached sovereign Icelandic airspace.
2015 saw a third contribution to the rotation scheme, when four F-16s and 53 Royal Danish Air Force personnel were deployed to Iceland. There was another alarm on 10 September, when two “Blackjack” Russian bombers approached Iceland. The mission ended on 19 September 2015 after two weeks of air policing.
Danish F-16s were again deployed to the Iceland mission from April 2018 and from August 2022.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Iceland has been covered by NATO’s Air Policing program since 2007. To date, Denmark has contributed to the rotation scheme four times, in 2009, 2010, 2015 and 2018. Other contributors to NATO’s defence of Icelandic sovereign airspace are: France, USA, Norway, Germany, Canada, Portugal, Italy and the Czech Republic. Danish contribution is expected to continue.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The primary mission of ISLAPS is airspace surveillance and repelling intruders in the airspace above and around Iceland. The programme also involved frequent training missions. In addition to the airborne missions, there has also been a deployment of ground crew etc. Fighter Wing Skrydstrup’s engineers and technicians were responsible for servicing and maintaining the aircraft and replacing jet engines. Combat Support Wing’s security personnel patrolled the hangars 24 hours a day, keeping the Danish aircraft under surveillance. Air Control Wing was flight controller for the Danish fighter aircraft, operating from the Icelandic radar control centre.
