text.heading: Background
text.text:
After decolonisation, the Lebanese government established a system of division of power to ensure that the Christian population had most of the power while all religious groups still had a share.  Overall developments in the population during the 1950s however indicated that various Muslim groups were becoming a majority. In a time of considerable tensions in the region, rooted in the Cold War and in Arab nationalism seeking to unite the Arab states, that population growth made Lebanon a powder keg.
After the Suez Crisis i 1956, a large proportion of the population in all the Arab states viewed Egyptian President Gamal Nasser as a hero who would be able to unite the Arab states against Western imperialism and overthrow the conservative monarchies in the region.

President Chamoun in Lebanon pursued a pro-Western line, and he was apprehensive about the growing proportion of his own people having a preference for a Nasser-style approach. There was widespread fraud during the parliamentary elections in 1957, and it was expected that Chamoun would use his new majority to amend the constitution and secure another presidential term for himself after 1958.
Nasser’s February 1958 proclamation of the United Arab Republic, a union between Syria and Egypt, sent shockwaves through the region.  Ever since the election the previous year, unrest and riots had occurred. They grew more serious during the spring of 1958, and by May the situation approached a civil war with large areas in the northern part of the country being out of reach of the government. The army refused to carry out the president’s orders to crush the uprising and instead attempted to contain it and maintain some sort of neutrality between the opposition and the government.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
President Chamoun of Lebanon appealed to the UN. He believed that the fighting in fact was a result of Nasser smuggling weapons and personnel across the Syria-Lebanon border and that Nasser’s extraordinarily aggressive radio and newspaper campaign against him represented meddling in Lebanon’s internal affairs.
The UN Security Council therefore in June 1958 approved Resolution 128 with a mandate to set up a group of observers in Lebanon. The primary objective of the mission was to keep the roads into Lebanon under surveillance and to report on any movements of weapons and soldiers from Syria into Lebanon. The main task of the observers was to observe, but there was a hope that their very presence might deter illegal traffic.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government made the decision to contribute after a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark sent 67 Danes to work in UNOGIL. Of them, 14 were military observers, 5 were staff officers, and 46 operated the planes and helicopters used to monitor the border area. At its largest, the international group numbered about 590 in November 1958. In addition, the mission that month had 18 light planes and 6 helicopters at its disposal for performing air reconnaissance and surveillance.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The first observers came from the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO) that was already operating in the region. They started their work on 12 June, the day after the approval of the resolution in the UN Security Council. On 16 November, relations between Lebanon and the United Arab Republic had been normalised, and in its last report, UNOGIL indicated that its task could be considered to be completed. The last participants in the mission left Lebanon on 9 December 1958.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The task was to detect whether there was illegal smuggling of weapons and personnel from Syria into Lebanon. Patrols were carried out on the roads leading into the country. In addition, permanent observation posts were set up by the major roads as bases for the patrols. Surveillance of the area was carried out by air as well.
The mission soon ran into difficulty performing this task. At the outset of the operation, opposition groups at first were unconvinced that the mission was impartial. Hence it took over a month to persuade the opposition that the mission was in fact impartial so as to gain access to the relevant areas.
There were further complications ahead for the mission. The union of Egypt and Syria had given revolutionary and nationalist groups in the region a boost. A coup was staged on 14 July 1958 to overthrow the monarchy in Iraq. This was hailed by the opposition in Lebanon with street celebrations and escalating attacks on the government army. As the United Arab Republic and the revolutionaries in Iraq were supported by Russia, President Chamoun invoked the American Eisenhower Doctrine committing assistance to countries under threat from international communism. More than 10,000 American marines arrived in Beirut in the following days to ensure that the Lebanese government remained in power and did not fall into the control of the new union. Jordan, too, experienced unrest, and like Lebanon it complained to the UN about meddling in its internal affairs by the United Arab Republic. The UN Security Council could not reach a consensus on the matter. Jordanian royalty instead requested British assistance. The British sent parachute troops to Jordan.

Once more the observers found it difficult to prove impartiality as the American intervention raised questions as to the intent behind sending foreign troops to Lebanon. Still, some degree of trust on the part of the opposition was achieved, and access was given to the relevant border areas. No signs were found that a coordinated effort was being made to supply arms; rather local armed groups were moving back and forth in the border area.
Revolutions and Western interventions led to a series of meetings in the UN Security Council and General Assembly dealing with the crisis in the Middle East. However, no solution was found that would satisfy the Soviet Union and the United States and resolve the situation on the ground. In the end, the Lebanese themselves found a resolution to the crisis in Lebanon. Parliament appointed General Fuad Shihab to the presidency. He hailed from the largest inter-religious group in the country and was already known as a man of compromise. Earlier in the year, he had attempted to keep the military neutral when fighting broke out. Given that the conflict had been triggered in part by President Chamoun’s election fraud and his attempts to modify the constitution, the situation calmed down when Shihab took office, especially when he set up a government with opposition leaders in key positions under the slogan “no winner, no loser”.
The last UNOGIL report dated 17 November 1958 stated that as there was peace in Lebanon and there were normal relations with neighbouring countries, the mandate had been completed.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
After World War I, Britain was given control of Palestine, much against the wishes of the population, by the League of Nations (a precursor to the United Nations). Driven by the national aspirations of Zionism and increasing attacks on Jews in the time between the two world wars, many European Jews immigrated to Palestine. The Palestinians often felt unfairly treated by the British authorities, and the immigrant Jews typically had better financial support and more resources with which they purchased land. Considerable unrest occurred in the years 1936-1939, most often as Palestinian protests that at times ended up in attacks on the Jewish residents and the British soldiers.
During World War II and in the years immediately following, there was considerable immigration to Palestine of Jews having escaped or survived the Holocaust. Given the events in Europe, there was a strong desire to create a Jewish state with charge of its own security in the future. Zionist paramilitary organisations were set up, and an armed campaign of bombing and guerrilla attacks was launched against the British forces.
As the large colonies in India and elsewhere were being relinquished, the British view was that it made little sense to retain the Middle East possession. When in the summer of 1946 a bombing attack was aimed at the largest hotel in Jerusalem, the British government looked for a way out.
By 1947, the British government handed over control of the area to the newly constituted United Nations and announced its departure from the area on 14 May 1948 regardless what happened. In an effort to prevent anarchy and war, the UN struck a working group named UNSCOP (United Nations Special Committee on Palestine) for the purpose of finding a solution. This group worked out a partition plan that was approved later that year by the UN General Assembly. The plan was heavily criticised, particularly by the Palestinians and other Arab states, because it allocated 55% of the land to Israel in spite of the fact that the Israelis made up only a third of the population and owned just 20% of the fertile land in the area.
The situation in Palestine now resembled a civil war, and attacks on civilians were common. In particular, the April massacre in the Palestinian village of Deir Yassin stirred fear in the Palestinian population. Many now fled. On the day after the departure of the British, Israel was proclaimed an independent nation on 15 May 1948. The Arab nations of Egypt, Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, and Jordan refused to recognise Israel and attacked it in spite of the fact that Israel had been authorised and established by the UN.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council approved Resolution 50 on 29 May 1948. It contained a demand that all acts of hostility in Palestine were to cease and appointed Swedish Count Folke Bernadotte to mediate among the parties. At this time, military observers were sent to Palestine to check that the ceasefire was respected. This was the first ever peacekeeping mission with the name UN Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO)undertaken by the UN.
The Security Council decided to expand the mandate by Resolution 73 (1949) while agreements were being negotiated by Israel, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, and Egypt. This expanded the scope of the mission and moved the observers from their single headquarters in Jerusalem to several positions in neighbouring Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, and Egypt. As a result, UNTSO had a presence in five countries in the region. At the same time, the mission was given greater independence from the UN and its peace negotiators. It thus became an independent entity led by a military chief of staff.
The security Council subsequently approved a number of resolutions in light of the fact that wars and unrest did not end with the ceasefires in 1949. However, the fundamental mandate and structure of UNTSO as an independent and unarmed observer mission has not been altered substantially.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government decided to participate in UNTSO upon a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution in modern history began with UNTSO in 1948 – the first ever UN observation mission. In latter years, teams of 10-15 Danish officers were deployed. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs indicated that in 2017, 11 Danes were deployed in the mission. A total of 1,300 Danes served in UNTSO since Denmark committed to the mission in 1948. In addition, Denmark has made contributions to related missions such as United Nations Emergency Force (UNEF) in which Danish soldiers after the Suez war in 1956 kept Egyptian, British, and Israeli soldiers separate in the areas of Port Said and Gaza.
UNTSO has operated permanently since 1948, and its personnel has often been called upon to step in when the UN set up observation missions elsewhere, especially in nearby areas. In this way, mobilisation was fast, without the need to create new missions from scratch, when new conflicts arose nearby. As examples, UNDOF and UNIFIL got started in this manner.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched in May 1948 as the first ever UN observation mission, and it is still active. At over 70 years of longevity, the mission is the earliest and also the longest lasting UN peacekeeping mission. At times, UNTSO met with challenges, especially in connection with the wars waged between the countries after the initial peace agreements made in 1949. Still, the presence has been maintained (though no specific ceasefire existed) in order to attempt mediation between the parties to the conflict.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The UNTSO, first and foremost, was to attempt to set up ceasefires and a peace plan for Palestine, Israel, and the neighbouring countries. From a headquarters in Jerusalem, mediation was attempted between the parties, and proposals were put forward for peace agreements to replace the ceasefire proposal stemming from UN Security Council Resolution 50 (1948). The first mediation attempt failed, and a second proposal was rejected as members of a Zionist militant group in September murdered Swedish Count Folke Bernadotte who had been appointed by the UN to take charge of the mediation process. When the ceasefire expired shortly thereafter, fighting continued. As Israel got its footing, UNTSO in 1949 negotiated ceasefires between Israel and each of its neighbouring countries.
In the following year, the primary task for the mission was to ensure that agreements were kept and to mediate between the parties in case of e.g. border crossings or other problems. Observation posts were set up along the borders, and offices were set up, in addition to the headquarters in Jerusalem, in Gaza, Amman, Beirut, Damascus, and Ismailia in Egypt. The UN tasks were made more difficult when during the wars of 1956, 1967, and 1973 there were not always ceasefires to observe. Still UNTSO has been extended several times as it acted in a meditating capacity and attempted to keep minor incidents from escalating. Egypt in 1979 initiated a peace process with Israel, and since then peace agreements have been made among Israel, Egypt, and Jordan. The Amman post was therefore closed. The Egyptian post in Ismailia then focused on the Suez Canal, Sinai, and Gaza.
Today, UNTSO continues to work on monitoring compliance with ceasefires and other agreements among the countries in the region. It is still active in attempts to find a peaceful solution to the strife in the Israeli-occupied areas in Palestine. In addition, there is close collaboration with other local missions such as UNIFIL. Today, as in the beginning, UNTSO has headquarters in Jerusalem and branch offices in Beirut and Damascus. A number of smaller offices and observation posts in other towns and locations near the border were set up, such as Observer Group Golan (OGG) in the Golan Heights between Syria and Israel, and Observer Group Lebanon (OGL) on the border between Israel and Lebanon.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Early in the 1960s, the Arab World was divided into two main parts. In one were older monarchies such as Saudi Arabia and Jordan; in the other were new republics with strong nationalist sentiment. The latter looked to Egyptian President Gamal Nasser and his effort to create a united Arab republic.
One week after the death of the king of Yemen, Ahmad bin Yahya, a military coup was carried out on 26 September 1962 against his young heir Imam Muhammad al-Badr. A republic was proclaimed, with support from Egypt, and al-Badr managed to flee from the capital city of Sanaa. Saudi Arabia supported the royalists controlling the northern part of Yemen, and a civil war ensued.
Although Egyptian solders were sent to Yemen to support the republic, they were not able to prevail. The royalists were supported by Saudi Arabia and secretly received arms and financial aid from the UK. The British still controlled Aden and an area along the southern coast. The international community therefore feared that the situation would turn into a more extensive conflict involving other countries.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
During the summer of 1963, UN Secretary-General U. Thant negotiated an agreement for the Egyptian soldiers to withdraw from Yemen and for Saudi Arabia to end its support of the royalists. Further, a demilitarised zone was to be set up along the Yemen-Saudi Arabia border to prevent bases in Saudi Arabia from being used to attack the republic and to prevent the entry of weapons.
King Hussein of Jordan in 1962 had suggested that a UN observation mission be sent to Yemen. In order to secure compliance with the agreement between Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the UN Security Council approved Resolution 179 in June 1963 and thereby provided a mandate for the Secretary-General to initiate the dispatch of an international group of observers. They were given a much more modest mandate than those of other missions in that there was no ceasefire to maintain between the various groups in Yemen. The purpose was strictly to observe and report on the withdrawal of Egyptian soldiers and to verify that Saudi Arabia maintained the demilitarised zone and ceased supporting the royalists.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government made the decision to participate and subsequently briefed the Foreign Policy Committee. At the time, Denmark and Norway had a sizeable unit in Gaza named DANOR. Denmark having previously been engaged in UN peacekeeping missions, the Minister of Defence on 1 April 1964 introduced a proposal in Parliament that a permanent military force be made available to the UN for use as needed. The proposal was approved. The Minister stated that the government did not believe it would be necessary to request approval from Parliament each time a force was to be provided. A briefing would however be given to the Foreign Policy Committee in each case.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: At its largest, the observation mission consisted of an international group of 189 including 25 observers. Eleven countries contributed to the mission. Eleven Danish observers from the army served in Yemen during the mission. A few of these observers were transferred from other missions such as the ones in Congo and Gaza.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNYOM was active in Yemen from 4 July 1963 to 4 September 1964. The original mandate was set for just two months, but after that time, the agreement had not yet been met by the parties, and there was still a desire for the mission. The mandate was then extended several times.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The main task was to watch that Egypt and Saudi Arabia upheld their parts of the agreement and to provide reports to the UN. The Secretary-General’s reports to the UN indicated that none of the parties showed much interest in fulfilling their end of the deal. Later on, it was discovered that Saudi Arabia had kept its promise while support was smuggled to the royalists from the British colonies in the region. The British were not a party to the agreement. The mandate did not include supervision of the borders with British colonies. The Egyptian soldiers were slow to leave and often did so only when republican forces had gained a foothold in an area.
During the summer of 1964, some progress was made. Shortly after the termination of UNYOM in September, Egypt and Saudi Arabia entered into an agreement to work together to resolve the conflict. The conflict nevertheless resumed in the following winter, but the UN did not provide a follow-on mission.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Upon Japanese victory in the Russo-Japanese War in 1905, Korea fell under Japanese rule. After World War II, Korea was divided along the 38th parallel north. In 1950, North Korean troops invaded South Korea with military and financial support from China and the Soviet Union.  The UN Security Council in Resolution 83 recommended that UN members come to the aid of South Korea. This was possible because the Soviet Union in 1950 had boycotted the UN Security Council and thus did not have veto power. With the U.S. in charge, 22 nations joined the coalition United Nations Command (UNC). Denmark sent the hospital ship Jutlandia. The Korean war is regarded as one of earliest proxy wars between the Soviet Union and the U.S. during the Cold War.

That war ended in 1953 with a ceasefire agreement between UNC, the Korean People’s Army (North Korea), and the Chinese People’s Volunteer Army. This agreement still stands. The ceasefire agreement is purely a military agreement and does not involve the respective nations. In addition to provisions for a ceasefire, the agreement contains guidelines for the release of prisoners of war and for the establishment of a demilitarised zone across Korea (two kilometres (1.2 miles) wide on either side of the border). The parties agreed that they would seek a peaceful resolution at the national level within three months. No peace agreement has ever come about as a result, however, and thus the two nations are technically still at war.

The agreement provided for United Nations Command Military Armistice Commission (UNCMAC), headquartered in the village of Panmunjom situated in the middle of the demarcation line.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The primary purpose of UNCMAC is to monitor the ceasefire between North and South Korea in the 245-kilometre (152-mile) demilitarised zone and to act as a mediator if the agreement were breached or if other tensions were to arise.  A Joint Security Area was established near the former headquarters of UNCMAC. It is still the only formal diplomatic connection between North and South Korea though more measured relations between the two nations have gradually emerged. The demarcation line runs right through the centre along the length of a negotiation table. UNCMAC headquarters are now situated in Seoul in South Korea.

The mission is different from other UN missions in that the UN has given the U.S. command of it.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government approved participation.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark contributed to UNCMAC by sending observers (in the years 2008-2023, a total of about 45). As of 2009, Denmark took charge of a monitoring team tasked with patrolling one of the two rail and road border crossings in the demilitarised zone between North and South Korea. This patrol team prepares military analyses for the UNCMACoperational staff and maintains contact with the South Korean military units and civilian entities in the area. During 2018, officers were dispatched to perform tasks including monitoring mine clearance in the area.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The UNCMAC mission has been active since the ceasefire in 1953. The mandate for the mission gives it continuance until a peaceful political resolution may be found.  North Korea on several occasions has indicated that is wishes to withdraw from the ceasefire, and it has indeed violated it. The relationship between North and South Korea has been impacted negatively by the nuclear weapons program operated by North Korea. The mandate of UNCMAC may not be fulfilled for a very long time. Current discussions and contacts between North and South Korea may lead to positive results, and there are modest signs of some good will. North and South Korea have destroyed and removed 10 military border checkpoints (2018) along the demilitarised zone, and a civilian train was run, as a test, from South Korea to North Korea that year.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: UNCMAC is tasked with monitoring the ceasefire in the demilitarised zone. In addition, the task includes receiving North Korean escapees and providing them with a security clearance. The Danish contribution to UNCMAC includes vetting South Koreans wishing to enter the demilitarised zone for purposes of performing repairs, maintenance, and the like. North Korea has not wished to have a UNCMAC presence on its side of the demarcation line. The Danes, in addition, participate in monitoring of mine clearance work.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In response to Iraq’s illegal occupation of neighbouring Kuwait, a UN-authorised liberation by volunteering countries led by the U.S. began in August 1990. These events have since been given the designation the First Gulf War. At its end in 1991, ethnic unrest ensued, with uprisings by Kurds in northern Iraq and Shiite Muslims in southern Iraq. The Iraqi government cracked down hard on the rebels and on the civilian population, thus displacing a great many people from their homes. As a result, the UN Security Council issued Resolution 688 to demand that Iraq permit humanitarian aid organisations to enter the country. It further condemned Iraq’s oppression of its people. The Security Council asked that all nations contribute to the emergency aid work. The UK, the U.S., and France initiated a major humanitarian intervention to pave the way for humanitarian aid organisations in their work to help stranded refugees by providing such basics as food, shelter, medicine, and sanitation.

The United Nations Guards Contingent in Iraq (UNGCI) came about in this context.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The United Nations Guards Contingent in Iraq (UNGCI) mission was set up in 1991 by UN Security Council Resolutions 706 and 712. These resolutions authorised the UN Secretary-General to work with the Iraqi government to seek a solution to the difficulties in distributing aid supplies. Hence, the guard corps was set up as a neutral entity offering protection to emergency aid personnel and shielding materiel and transports in certain areas designated as secure areas. The guard corps in addition was to assist in repatriation of refugees.  The plan provided for a light-armed corps of 500.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon several submissions to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government decided in June 1991 to contribute to the guard corps. Personnel were recruited for individual contracts and transferred to the UN.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
From 1991 to 1999, Denmark contributed to the guard corps by sending 390 personnel from the armed forces and the police. From 1993 to 1996, a Dane had command of the UNGCI mission.
As Denmark was a regular contributor to the mission, Danish UN guards were frequently assigned coordinator roles. The Guard corps worked primarily in the northern part of Iraq. A smaller unit worked around the city of Basra in the southern part. The Danish contingent in the guard corps experienced several dramatic incidents including hostage taking, shooting, and bombing.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNGCI was active from 1991 to 2003. By Resolution 661 in 1990, the UN had set up a nearly comprehensive trade embargo against Iraq in retaliation for its illegal invasion of Kuwait. In 1996, the UNGCI mission became a part of the oil-for-food programme letting Iraq sell oil, regardless of the sanctions, in order to finance emergency aid to civilians.
With a view to providing safety for the guards during the Second Gulf War, the mission was terminated in 2003.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The guard corps helped secure the distribution of food, clothing, and medicine to Kurdish refugees. During the time of the oil-for-food programme, UNGCI provided essential border control services and protection for civilian UN workers in performing their functions. Finally, the guard corps monitored the security situation in Iraq and performed rescues during the frequent mishaps in the secured areas.

missions.title: UNGOMAP Pakistan
missions.subtitle: Conflict between Afghanistan and Pakistan.
missions.name: UNGOMAP Pakistan
missions.descriptiveName: UN Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Soviet Union in 1979 staged an invasion of Afghanistan to quell an uprising against the communist government. The rebels were Muslims of a conservative nature and were known as the Mujahideen.
The Afghan Mujahideen carried out quite an effective guerilla war against the Soviet troops, and with support from the U.S. and Pakistan, the rebels managed to prevent Soviet influence from spreading to the entire country. After nine years of war, the Soviet Union in 1989 decided to withdraw from Afghanistan. For one thing, the appetite for fighting was gone due to the heavy loss of life, and for another, a new Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, had come to power. He was focused on glasnost and perestroika, two phenomena with a potential to improve relations with the West as well as conditions inside the Soviet Union.
The Soviet retreat was a subject of the Geneva Accords, a UN-mediated agreement between the governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan with the Soviet Union and the U.S. as guarantors.  The agreement was intended to facilitate monitoring of the withdrawal of Soviet troops and the return of refugees as well as to enable a smooth political transition in Afghanistan.  The Mujahideen rebels were not included in the agreement and kept fighting for the ensuing years. This led to the establishment of United Nations Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan (UNGOMAP).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: United Nations Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan (UNGOMAP) came about with UN Security Council Resolution 622 based on the Geneva Accords. The mission was tasked with monitoring the agreement on non-intervention in the internal affairs of the parties (such as continued Pakistani support to the Mujahideen rebels), monitoring the retreat of Soviet troops, and supervising the repatriation of Afghan refugees from Pakistan. The mission thus had two headquarters, one in Kabul, Afghanistan, and one in Islamabad, Pakistan. The mission was set up with 50 observers from 10 countries.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Denmark’s decision to contribute to United Nations Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan was approved in Parliament in 1988 with 107 votes in favour.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark provided eight UN observers between 1988 and 1990.

Danish UN observers monitored the retreat of Soviet troops. This was not a straightforward task in that the Mujahideen resistance was based just 17 kilometres from Kabul and was in possession of Stinger missiles among other weapons. Interestingly, the task of monitoring the withdrawal of the very last Soviet troops fell to a Danish observer on the border bridge.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
United Nations Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan was active from May 1988 to March 1990 with a time frame of 20 months. This time frame was extended by two months by Resolution 647 in 1990. The mission ended in March 1990 when the various parties could not agree on a further extension. Throughout the active period, the mission encountered difficulties in executing its mandate due to underfinancing, the Mujahideen rebellion, and strife between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Upon the termination of the mission, the political work was assumed by Office of the Secretary-General for Afghanistan and Pakistan (OSGAP). Danish officers participated here as well.
Some of the Afghan Mujahideen rebels later became the Taliban and ruled Afghanistan until the 2001 invasion, led by the U.S., that was occasioned by the terrorist attacks in New York on 11 September 2001.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The 50 observers were tasked with monitoring the Soviet retreat from Afghanistan, monitoring the agreement between Afghanistan and Pakistan to mutually refrain from interference in internal affairs, and facilitating the return of refugees. These tasks were undertaken from Kabul and Islamabad and from a presence in certain other areas.

text.heading: Background
text.text: After many years of increasingly serious border conflicts between Iran and Iraq, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in 1980 decided to invade Iran.  This war, lasting eight years until 1988, was a particularly violent one that flouted international conventions. Iraq used chemical weapons, and civilians were constantly bombarded by both parties. The UN, without success, attempted from the beginning to mediate between the parties. The war affected merchant ships in the Persian Gulf, causing some nations to send warships as escorts. During one of these escorts, an Iranian passenger plane with 290 people on board was shot down in error. The UN Security Council in 1987 approved Resolution 598 calling for an immediate ceasefire, initiation of a fair peace process, and deployment of peace observers. Iraq gave the resolution a positive response and indicated a desire to work with the UN to reach a peace treaty with Iran. Iran, however, was not of a mind to cooperate. Just under a year of intense diplomatic negotiations between the UN, Iran, and Iraq in July 1988 produced consent from Iran to accept the resolution, and the ceasefire thus began. On this basis, the United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group (UNIIMOG) was established.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Denmark’s participation, initially with 15 men, was based on a formal request from the UN on 10 August 1988 and a subsequent government decision with an associated document dated 31 August 1988. Approval was granted on 13 September 1988. The document states: “… According to parliamentary approval on 30 April 1964 for making available a permanent Danish military force to the United Nations, the government, after assessing the overall situation and after having received a request from the UN, hereby approves providing observers to the UN for the purpose of monitoring the ceasefire between Iran and Iraq per Resolution 609 of 9 August 1988. The UN on 10 August 1988 has requested that Denmark contribute a total of 15 officers to the observer group, one lieutenant colonel and 14 majors/commanders. All will be stationed in Iraq. These officers are deployed as of 16 August 1988.”

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The United Nations Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group (UNIIMOG) was set up by UN Security Council Resolution 609 in August 1988 with a mandate to monitor the ceasefire and investigate breaches, to monitor the withdrawal of all troops to their home territory, and to monitor the internationally recognised border for violations of the ceasefire. The mandate was renewed in 1990. The objective was to monitor the last phase of the withdrawal, to assist in dealing with disagreements respecting the precise geographical location of the border, and to help the two parties set up areas on both sides of the border where they could agree not to deploy military personnel.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark sent about 40 UN observers from the army and the navy. Between 1988 and 1991, they worked on monitoring the ceasefire between Iran and Iraq. In addition, they participated in the final phase of the mission by monitoring the exchange of prisoners between the two countries and by monitoring Iraq’s withdrawal from the occupied territories in Iran.
The first commander of the mission was a Danish brigadier general.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNIIMOG was active from August 1988 to February 1991, receiving contributions from 26 countries. The UN mandate included, for most of that time period, a military force numbering 400 (including 360 observers). The mission had headquarters in Baghdad and Teheran.
Overall, the objective of getting the two countries’ military troops withdrawn was met. Thus, the mission had succeeded and was terminated in 1991.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission consisted of monitoring the ceasefire between Iran and Iraq, monitoring the withdrawal of soldiers, having a presence at prisoner exchanges, and assisting with the resolution of any new tensions between Iraq and Iran.

missions.title: UNOMIG Georgia
missions.subtitle: UN Mission in Former USSR Territory
missions.name: UNOMIG Georgien

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Union of Socialist Soviet Republics (USSR), as the name indicated, was a collection of administratively separate republics governed from Moscow. These Union republics were ethnically based pseudo-states intended to give people a sense of autonomy within the vast Soviet Union. When the Soviet Union fell, these republics were recognized as independent nations. However, the republics tended to have large minorities. That generated ethnic strife and demands for autonomy or for joining one of the other new states. Georgia was one of those republics. It became independent in 1991. The celebration was brief because separatist groups in the region of Abkhazia attempted to secede from Georgia. This led to a violent civil war between the Georgian army, supported by ethnic Georgian militias in Abkhazia, and Abkhazian separatists supported by Russia and by Russians and Armenians in Abkhazia.  The civil war was extremely bloody and involved extensive war crimes and acts of ethnic cleansing.

After several failed ceasefires, Russia in 1993 succeeded in striking a ceasefire between the warring parties. The UN was requested to provide assistance in maintaining this ceasefire. This is how the United Nations Observer Mission in Georgia (UNOMIG) came about.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: Originally, the mission was set up by UN Security Council Resolution 858 in 1993 with a mandate to monitor the ceasefire between Abkhazia and Georgia. However, Abkhazia breached the ceasefire in short order, leading to yet another ceasefire between the parties in 1994. This one involved peacekeeping troops from the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), the Russian counterpart to the EU made up of nine former Soviet republics. The mandate of UNOMIG was then expanded considerably by UN Security Council Resolution 937. It set out nine key security related tasks: (1) to monitor the ceasefire; (2) to monitor CIS operations; (3) to verify that Abkhazian and Georgian troops and military materiel did not get into defined security areas; (4) to monitor the storage of military materiel withdrawn from the security zones; (5) to monitor the withdrawal of Georgian troops from Abkhazia; (6) to carry out frequent patrols in certain areas; (7) to investigate breaches of the ceasefire and assist with resolving disputes between the parties; (8) to report to the UN Secretary-General on the implementation of the agreement; and (9) to coordinate operations with CIS peacekeeping forces and effect a safe return of displaced persons.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon a request from the UN, the Danish government decided, after a submission to the Foreign Affairs Council on 2 September 1993, to agree to provide Danish observers. Initially, five officers were dispatched for a period of 12 months. One of the observers was a Danish brigadier general who would serve as commander of the mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
From 1993 to 2009, Denmark provided 111 UN observers from the army and the air force. The mission was commanded by a Dane from 1993 to 1995. This was the first mission, a female Danish officer served as a UN observer. Danish Emergency Agency had in 2008 as part of EU ECHO experts in the mission.
The mission experienced regular hostage takings. Two Danes and three other UN observers were taken hostage in 2000 but were released after four days. In 2003, a Danish UN observer, two colleagues, and an interpreter were abducted in Abkhazia, but again the outcome was positive.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was active from 1993 to 2009. Throughout this period, increasing tensions between Abkhazia, Georgia, and Russia made it difficult for the UN observers to carry out their mandate. After the peaceful “Rose Revolution” in 2003, Georgia had pursued a pro-Western, NATO-oriented agenda. This was not acceptable to Russia because it considered Georgia to be within its sphere of interest. This situation culminated in 2008 when Russia invaded Georgia. By virtue of its permanent seat on the UN Security Council, Russia objected to an extension of the mandate, and the mission was terminated in 2009. Thus, UNOMIG got caught up in a larger political battle between Western-leaning Georgia and Russia.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: In addition to monitoring compliance with the ceasefire between Georgia and Abkhazia, the UN observers were to keep watch whether the Russian peacekeeping force remained impartial and acted within its mandate. Moreover, the observers worked to facilitate the repatriation of displaced persons and to improve living conditions for the population through humanitarian and police missions.

text.heading: Background
text.text: NATO has had an integrated air defence and surveillance system since the 1970s for the purpose of monitoring and, using the efforts of the individual member states, protecting air space above NATO member states during peacetime. Denmark has been responsible for protecting its own air space and, as a member of NATO, has helped other fully or partially integrated NATO member states. One of the ways this has been achieved has been by maintaining a presence in other nations’ air space to help them enforce their sovereignty. These missions take place in the three Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which do not themselves have the capacity to enforce the sovereignty of their own air space. The same also applies in Iceland, where Danish aircraft have also played a role.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: NATO’s mission in Baltic air space began in April 2004 when the Baltic states requested support, a request that was granted by NATO’s council in March 2004. The decision led to long-term surveillance of Baltic air space by a number of NATO member states and is performed on rotation. The surveillance is still being performed in the present day and has involved several Danish deployments.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The proposal for a Danish contribution to NATO's enforcement of sovereign air space over Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania was put to the Danish Parliament on 12 May 2004 as Proposal B210.
This was not the first time that the decision had been made to assist the Baltic states. Previously that year, the Government had, in consultation with the Danish Foreign Policy Committee, joined a ground forces contribution during the period in which Belgium (as the first nation) contributed to the enforcement of sovereignty in the Baltics.
Denmark made F-16 aircraft and personnel available to ensure that the Baltic states had the same sense of security as that of NATO’s other member states. Denmark had so far provided the Baltic states with considerable support in their attempts to gain membership of NATO and in building their armed forces. The Danish Government of the day therefore considered the contribution to protect Baltic air space as a natural progression. In its decision, the Danish Parliament also mandated the deployed aircraft to use force if necessary to enforce the integrity of these states. The proposal was adopted with 97 votes in favour and 1 vote opposed. 7 MPs abstained. 
After consultation with the Foreig Policy Committee in January 2022 it was decided to contribute with additional 4 F-16 starting in January and for three mounth.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark’s contribution in 2004 was four F-16 fighter jets, with a further 1-2 F-16 fighter jets in reserve. In addition to this was the 75-strong ground crew and materials to support the fighter jets. The deployment lasted three months, after which duties were performed by another NATO member state. Two Danish F-16s were deployed in 2009. 2011 saw the deployment of four jets and 50 ground crew and equipment to keep the jets in the air. In 2013, four aircraft and 45-50 personnel were once again deployed. 2014 saw the deployment of six F-16s and 50 personnel. In 2018, the mission ran for four months, starting in January. This time four jets and approx. 60 personnel were deployed. And that’s not the end of it. 2019 saw another deployment and there are likely to be more in future. In 2021 the deployment was from september to december. Because of the tensions in Europe between East and West additional 4 F-16 were deplyed to the Baltic states from January 2022. It was an additional deployment to the aggreed plan for rotation between contributing nations.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Danish missions to defend Baltic air space for many periods of time between 2004 and 2020. This NATO support to the Baltic states is expected to continue.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission has been to defend air space and enforce the air sovereignty of the Baltic states. The aircraft are tasked with escorting air space violators out of Lithuanian air space or to otherwise repel aircraft that are under suspicion and are unable to:
- provide correct identification
- communicate with air control personnel
- provide correct information about the aircraft’s flight path.
These missions are not only flown by Danish aircraft. Danish planes are in rotation with planes from a number of other NATO member states.

missions.title: MINURSO Western Sahara
missions.subtitle: An area with many problems
missions.name: MINURSO Vestsahara
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara

text.heading: Background
text.text:
West Sahara is in north-western Africa, bordering with Morocco to the north, Algeria to the north east and Mauritania to the south west and has long been the subject of territorial disputes. The area was a Spanish colony for almost a century from 1884 until 1976, when Franco’s Spain would not relinquish the area despite demands from the global community to do so. When Franco died in 1975 it became possible to conduct a referendum to find out whether West Sahara’s population preferred independence or to become part of another country. Morocco had a different view and demanded the whole area, based on historical relationships. The international courts in the Hague did not recognise this demand and recommended that the referendum should proceed as planned. Morocco did not accept the court ruling and occupied the northern part of the country in 1975. Mauritania occupied the south eastern area.
The local population had already formed a rebel group called Frente Popular de Liberación de Saguía el Hamra y Río de Oro (POLISARIO). This group had previously fought against the Spanish for territory in the western Sahara. The group now took up arms against the Moroccan and Mauritanian occupying forces. Mauritania had to accept defeat in 1979. Mauritania then withdrew from the war and has remained neutral ever since. Moroccan armed forces continued fighting, which continued to lesser or greater degrees for over a decade. During the war Morocco built a 2,500 long line of defence that now splits the area into two. Morocco continues to occupy the western part of the area, the remaining area being controlled by POLISARIO. The Saharawis live partly in the Moroccan-controlled area and partly in large refugee camps in Algeria close to the border with West Sahara.

After many years of war, the UN was finally able to persuade the two sides to agree to a ceasefire and begin preparations for a referendum about the area's future status and affiliation. 1991 saw the beginning of MINURSO, which had the role of monitoring the ceasefire and implementing the referendum.
It was expected that the mission would be completed in just a few months. Unfortunately, it would not be so simple. Because of the fluid border and the nomadic Bedouin tribes, there were political and practical challenges when it came to registering voters. The mission came close to fruition in 1999, but Morocco demanded the registration of a further 180,000 pro-Morocco people, which caused the UN to postpone the referendum indefinitely.
In recent years the UN Security Council has tried to bring about a peaceful politically-negotiated solution between Morocco and POLISARIO.   These negotiations have barely made any progress, which can be attributed in part to a failure to agree and a lack of support from the permanent members of the UN Security Council.

Denmark prepared to deploy a company of troops to West Sahara as a contribution to MINURSO in 1998. The proposal for Danish support for this operation was founded in UN Security Council Resolution 1148 of 26 January 1998, which enabled an expansion of the MINURSO mission. The Danish Government suggested that Denmark should, as part of this expansion, contribute to the UN peacekeeping operation in West Sahara. The purpose of this aid was to ensure a safe framework for the planned referendum and to allow refugees to return. The contribution would also assist in ceasefire monitoring and the surveillance and control of troop withdrawals and the supervision of selected arms depots. The Danish Parliamentary proposal was adopted with 102 votes in favour and 11 votes against. Soon afterwards, a team from Denmark carried out a reconnaissance mission in the area to prepare the deployment and to plan how the operation would proceed. The deployment did not come to fruition, however, due to the political gridlock in the area.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate for the UN’s MINURSO operation lies in UN Security Council Resolution 690 of 29 April 1991, based on the notion that Morocco and POLISARIO had, on 30 August 1988, accepted the proposal to resolve their mutual conflict. The mandate was intended to take the form of UN envoys who would have full control and responsibility for all aspects of a referendum in which the people of West Sahara would vote on a choice between independence or becoming part of Morocco. The mandate would also ensure that a ceasefire was agreed between the two rivals and that the Moroccan troop presence would also be reduced.
Even though the mandate is yet to open a path towards a referendum, it has nevertheless enabled the agreement to and compliance with a fragile ceasefire. During the period after 1991 there have been no deaths or combat engagements in the area. The threat represented by the approx. 6.5 million land mines and other unexploded munitions in the area has also been significantly reduced.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Parliament’s decision to deploy a Danish company to West Sahara to support the implementation of referendum and create a safe framework for returning refugees was never put into effect because of the lack of a political solution in West Sahara.
Denmark was, however, offered the opportunity to put forward a candidate for the position of MINURSO’s Force Commander. UN General Secretary Kofi Annan chose the Danish candidate from those that had been put forward. The Major General and his staff served in the area from September 2005 to September 2007. For part of this period he also served as the de facto commander for the entire MINURSO operation, including civilian police and logistics divisions. An unknown number of Danish civilian UN employees also worked as part of MINURSO.

The gridlocked political situation in the area was difficult to change, but the mission did at least bring about a number of improvements and quality improvements such as a rationalisation of staff structures and the testing of observers to produce better quality mission performances and increased patrols.
The most significant contribution, however, was that there was the successful setting in motion of mine clearance operations in the area. This was a political “hot potato” but the initiative was successful. There is now an official UN mine clearance programme in West Sahara, which is gradually reducing the risk of accidental explosions and resulting injuries.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: MINURSO was established on 29 April 1991. The operation is still ongoing at the time of writing. The Danish contribution lasted from 2005 to 2007.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission of the Danish envoys was to contribute towards ensuring compliance with the ceasefire between the two combatant parties and to help produce a basis for a peaceful resolution to the conflict. This was a partial success. It may well be that a referendum has yet to take place in West Sahara and that there is no short term prospect of a political solution, but the ceasefire is still holding. This means that nobody has been killed or injured as a result of warfare and the risk of landmine injuries is being reduced every year.

missions.title: MONUC Congo
missions.subtitle: Back to Congo
missions.name: MONUC Congo
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo

text.heading: Background
text.text: The genocide in Rwanda in 1994 resulted in the flight to the Kivu region of the Democratic Republic (DR) of Congo (then known as Zaire) of over a million Hutus, including some of those responsible for the genocide. This was problematic as the Kivu region was populated by ethnic Tutsis and other tribes. After their arrival, the Hutus wanted access to Zaire’s eastern natural resources and to ethnically cleanse Tutsis and topple the government of Rwanda (Rwanda's government was under Tutsi control). Because of the numerous attempts by Hutus to invade Rwanda, pro-Tutsi army commander Laurent Kabila decided to fight the Hutus in Zaire. In 1996 he received help from Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi, which is partly why the first Congo war is also known as Africa’s First World War. In 1997 Kabila and his Tutsi forces were able to gain control of Zaire's capital Kinshasha and renamed the country to the name by which it is known today (the Democratic Republic of Congo). 1998 saw the formation of rebel groups who opposed the sitting Kabila government and unrest erupted in DR Congo. Despite receiving military aid from Angola, Chad, Namibia and Zimbabwe the Kabila government lost control of large parts of the country to the rebel groups. A ceasefire was signed between the opposing sides in 1999. United Nations Organization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUC) was set up in 1999 to assist in the continued process. This mission was active until 2010, when it was renamed the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo(MONUSCO). Unrest is still a problem in DR Congo, and a UN military presence is still a necessity.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate was established in UN Security Council Resolution 1279 of 30 October 1999. The UN wanted to see a ceasefire agreement in the war torn country and the departure of foreign troops from DR Congo. The mandate also involved maintaining contact with all African states that were affected by the Lusaka Ceasefire Agreement and, for the long term, help to bring about a democratic referendum in DR Congo. The referendum was held in 2006 and is considered one of the most complex referendums the UN had ever taken part in.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Government reached its decision after Danish Foreign Policy Committee consultation in August 1999 and again in February 2000.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: From 2000 to December 2005 Denmark provided approx. 30 observers and a few staff officers from the army and air force.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The MONUC operation ran from 1999 to 2010. Most of the Danish contribution took place between 2000 and December 2005. A few Danes remained in the country from 2006 to 2010, after which the mission changed its name from MONUC to MONUSCO.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The Danish observers would monitor and assist in ensuring that the opposing countries and factions complied with the agreed ceasefire. The Danish contribution was part of a mission that involved approx. 68 countries.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The ”Standby High-Readiness Brigade” (SHIRBRIG) unit grew out of the need for the UN to have a high-readiness unit available for action in areas of conflict and disaster. In 1994, the UN decided to send 5,000 troops to Rwanda to end the genocide, but no countries were willing to contribute soldiers. Then, Denmark took the initiative, working closely with the UN, to create a high-readiness unit. Defence Minister Hans Hækkerup was a driving force. The concept had been set out in 1993 and 1995 at the UN in the report “An Agenda for Peace” (and its supplement) written by Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. In it, he argued for an ”instrument” for faster deployment of troops to conflict areas. The brigade was to focus on peacebuilding missions and to stand by in high readiness in case the UN had a need. Until then, the UN had set up peacekeeping forces according to a very time consuming model. There was a need to establish a brigade that could be deployed far more quickly than had been possible earlier. The basic concept was that the units of the brigade could be deployed to an area plagued by conflict, set up a UN mission, establish a headquarters, and pave the way for subsequent forces before withdrawing and leaving the specific tasks to them and to forces deployed later. The establishment of this brigade took only a few years. At the launch of this effort on 15 December 1996, the defence ministers of Canada, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Poland, Austria, and Denmark signed a declaration of political intent with respect to the brigade. These countries declared themselves willing to collaborate on building the brigade. Later, other countries joined, among them Ireland, Argentina, Italy, Lithuania, and Spain. Other nations signed up as observers. About 25 countries all over the world were more or less directly involved in SHIRBRIG as contributors to the unit or as supporters of the concept. The SHIRBRIG Brigade was formally launched at a 1997 parade at the Royal Guard Barracks in Høvelte, Denmark. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan was in attendance. SHIRBRIG and its units were to be deployed for a maximum of six months. The Brigade had its first test in Eritrea and Ethiopia under United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea (UNMEE). Parts of the Brigade (staff, headquarters, and an infantry battalion) were deployed for six months. At the end of 2000, a total of 14 countries had signed one or more of the agreement documents related to the collaborative effort and thus became formal partners. The Brigade headquarters, including a planning element, was housed at the Høvelte Barracks north of Copenhagen.
In 2005-2009, SHIRBRIG acted as ”midwife” for similar brigades in Africa in collaboration with the African Union. Among the achievements here were two brigade structures, one in the east of Africa (EASBRIG) and one in the west of Africa (ECOBRIG).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The establishment of SHIRBRIG did not require a mandate, but all operations in which it has been deployed had a UN mandate. Such mandates to deploy the unit have included UN Security Council Resolutions 1312 (Eritrea and Ethiopia), 1528 (Ivory Coast), 1509 (Liberia), and 1590 (Sudan), just to name a few examples of the far flung activities of SHIRBRIG. In those countries, the Brigade has participated actively with soldiers or has participated in the planning of the mission.
The Brigade was officially eliminated on 30 June 2009. Reasons for the closure included waning support and high operational costs. Denmark had in fact decided in 2008 to withdraw from the unit.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Participation by Denmark in SHIRBRIG was approved in several consecutive defence related political agreements made by a majority in Parliament.
The Danish contribution to the Brigade consisted of several staff officers, a headquarters company, a reconnaissance unit, and a military police element. On several occasions, Denmark held the commanding officer position. The headquarters unit was made up primarily of Danish soldiers, some of whom were on contract to be available for deployment on short notice.
Decisions regarding deployment of a Danish contribution to SHIRBRIG included proposal B33 on 31 October 2000 on participation in Eritrea and Ethiopia. Similarly, proposal B41 of 24 November 2009 pertained to Danish participation, via SHIRBRIG, in Lebanon (UNIFIL). Those two proposals were approved by Parliament. The former received 95 votes in favour and 9 votes opposed. The latter (UNIFIL) was unanimously approved. The deployment to Lebanon did not take place as the UN selected a different option in the end.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish portion of the SHIRBRIG deployment to Eritrea and Ethiopia included a headquarters company of about 200 soldiers, a national command and support element of about 40 soldiers, and during the setup phase an engineer detachment of about 80 soldiers.
The deployment in Liberia included about 20 staff officers, and the deployment in Sudan included about 45 personnel.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Denmark participated in UNMEE (Eritrea) from 16 December 2000 to June 2001. UNMEE was in existence from 2000 to 2008.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The engineer detachment in Eritrea was tasked, among other things, with building Camp Bifrost in Asmara. The Danish contingent and headquarters were dedicated to tasks encompassed within UN Security Council Resolution 1320:
- Monitoring compliance with the ceasefire agreement of 18 June between Ethiopia and Eritrea.
- Monitoring and verifying the withdrawal of Ethiopian forces.
- Participating in the effort to ensure that the parties lived up to their security related commitments in connection with the ceasefire agreement.
- Monitoring the temporary security zone stretching 25 kilometres (15 miles) wide and about 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) long along the border between the two countries.
The contribution helped support the peace negotiations between Eritrea and Ethiopia. These negotiations took place in a challenging environment that for some years necessitated the presence of UN forces in the country. UNMEE was terminated in 2008 when Eritrea had made conditions for the UN forces untenable.

missions.title: UNMEE Eritrea
missions.subtitle: SHIRBRIG in Eritrea
missions.name: UNMEE Eritrea
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea

text.heading: Background
text.text: Fighting broke out in May 1998 between Ethiopia and Eritrea. Disagreements about the border between them were the cause. The two countries agreed to let the UN help resolve the conflict, and the UN then persuaded Algeria to act as a mediator on behalf of the OAU (Organization of African Unity). In July 1999, the two countries accepted an agreement to withdraw troops from areas that had been occupied after 1998. There was to be an investigation into the exact placement of the border. Although this investigation was performed by neutral agents, tensions in the border area ran high, and hostilities might erupt at any time.  Many attempts were made to keep Ethiopia and Eritrea on their respective sides of the so far determined borders, but hostilities erupted again on 12 May 2000. Then, the OAU and the UN made efforts to craft solutions, and on 31 June 2000, the UN Security Council approved a resolution that would enable the deployment of up to 100 observers and provide the required assistance in and to the two countries. The conflict was resolved when on 12 December 2000 the two countries signed a peace treaty and withdrew their military forces. Since 2000, there have still been tensions between the two countries, and UN forces were still needed. The miussion UNMEE terminated in 2008 after adopting Resolution 1827.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Denmark’s contribution to the UNMEE operation was proposed to Parliament in item B33 on 31 October 2000. On 7 November 2000, Parliament approved, with 95 votes in favour and 9 votes opposed, the dispatch of SHIRBRIG and the establishment of DANCON (Danish contingent) including a headquarters company.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for providing observers and for deploying troops is given in UN Security Council Resolutions 1312 and 1320 from September 2000. United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea (UNMEE) was set up per Resolution 1312. This mandate was considered essential for any future peace agreement between the two countries. The mandates permitted the UN to work actively on getting both countries’ military forces out of territories occupied after May 1998 and on building a security zone for mine clearance. In addition, the UN envoys were to contact the military headquarters in both countries to gain insight into their activities and in so doing put appropriate pressure on the governments.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark provided about 400 soldiers, as follows:
- Military commanders and staff officers, including 6 staff officers for the UNMEE headquarters in Asmara;
- A staff and headquarters company of about 200;
- An engineering detachment (for the building phase) of about 80;
- Military police, about 35;
- Administrative staff in a command and support element of about 40; and
- About 44 observers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Denmark contributed actively in the two countries for as long as UNMEE existed, from 16 December 2000 to 2008. SHIRBRIG was dispatched on 16 December 2000 and left the area on 16 June 2001. Thereafter, the Danish observers were still needed in the area. They worked until 2008 when Eritrea made conditions so difficult for the UN force that UNMEE had to be terminated.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The missions in the area were many, and they were challenging. As an example, the force deployed within SHIRBRIGas an integral part of UNMEE was tasked with monitoring compliance with the ceasefire agreement of 18 June 2000 between Ethiopia and Eritrea. In addition, it was tasked with monitoring and verifying the withdrawal of Ethiopian forces, assisting in ensuring that the parties complied with their security obligations under the ceasefire agreement, and monitoring the temporary security zone stretching 25 kilometres (15 miles) wide and about 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) long in the border area between the two countries. When SHIRBRIG left the area on 16 June 2001, some Danish observers stayed on. Together with other UN observers, they were tasked with monitoring ceasefires and prevent unrest from resurfacing.

missions.title: UNMOGIP/UNCIP Pakistan
missions.subtitle: Un Unresolved Conflict
missions.name: UNMOGIP/UNCIP Indien/Pakistan
missions.descriptiveName: UN Military Observers Group in India and Pakistan

text.heading: Background
text.text:
India and Pakistan became independent nations in 1947. British India was divided into West Pakistan, East Pakistan, and India. The region and the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir, together more than five times the size of Denmark, now were to choose whether they wanted to join India or Pakistan. After an intervention by Indian forces, Kashmir became a part of India while Pakistan occupied the western state of Jammu. This led to extensive hostilities between the countries, and the UN intervened in an attempt to put an end to the fighting. The UN in 1948 initiated United Nations Commission for India and Pakistan (UNCIP) and dispatched observers to work toward reaching a ceasefire and monitor the overall situation. The outcome of discussions in the UN Security Council was a ceasefire line giving Pakistan about a third and India about two thirds of Jammu and Kashmir, the so-called Kashmir agreement.
The UNCIP observers were dispatched in 1949. This mission was replaced in 1951 by United Nations Military Observers Group in India and Pakistan (UNMOGIP). UNMOGIP took on the role of mediator between the two countries. The conflict turned more serious in 1957 when Kashmir became a state within India as a result of changes to the Indian constitution.

Not only India and Pakistan have fanned the flames. China and Pakistan in March 1963 entered into an agreement respecting their border; it granted China a sizeable portion of Pakistan-administered Kashmir to the north. Renewed fighting between India and Pakistan erupted in early 1965. A ceasefire was declared in July, orchestrated by the British. But peace was fleeting. In August, violent battles were fought until Soviet mediation put an end to them in September. There were quite a few players indeed.
In 1971, hostilities once again broke out. This time, the trigger was not Kashmir or Jammu but rather West Pakistan’s Operation Searchlight. Its objective was to battle East Pakistan, a country that wanted independence. (Today, East Pakistan is known as Bangladesh.) As India wished to divide Pakistan, it had an interest in supporting East Pakistan’s ambitions for independence. The support from India resulted in an ill-fated attack by West Pakistan on India. This attack went by the name Operation Genghis Khan. The war lasted two weeks. West Pakistan was forced to end the attack and accept the secession of East Pakistan as the nation of Bangladesh.
Upon mediation by the UN, a ceasefire was struck on 17 December 1971. It later led to the agreement referred to as the Simla Agreement. This agreement confirms that any decision respecting the future of Kashmir is to be made bilaterally between the two countries and stipulates that both countries must respect the “Line of Control” (the ceasefire line).
However, this was not the end. Fighting took place in 1989 over a piece of no man’s land at an elevation of 5,000 metres (16,400 feet), an area not included in the “Line of Control”.

Ever since then, unrest has characterised the area. There have been bombings, abductions, demonstrations, and armed clashes between militant rebel groups.
Fighting continued in 1999 with advances by Pakistan. The forces retreated in July, India having suffered significant losses. To this day, the relationship between the two countries has been tense and unresolved, as seen most recently in the air strikes of 2019.
There was and there still is a need for observers to mediate and monitor the situation and to help ensure that the two countries refrain from violating the ceasefire agreement. The UN mission UNMOGIP still deploys observers along the border between the two countries.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The first observers sent to Kashmir and Jammu, then becoming the core of UNMOGIP, were dispatched in January 1949 on the basis of UN Security Council Resolutions 39 of 20 January 1948 and 47 of 21 April 1948. First and foremost, the objective of the operation was to manage the negotiations respecting Kashmir and Jammu and to keep the situation from escalating further between the parties in the conflict. After the ceasefire agreement reached in 1971 between the two countries, the mandate of UNMOGIP was solidified by Resolution 307 of 21 December 1971. This resolution increased the number of UN observers. India and Pakistan have had mixed reactions to the UN mandate and the constant UN activities in the border area between them, but the mandate remains unchanged and is still active.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon request from the UN Secretary-General to supply a number of Danish officers to the UN observer corps in Kashmir, the Danish government agreed to do so. The mission is the subject of continued discussions among UN and the contributors, and it is still regarded as being a necessity.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Since 1948, Denmark has provided many observers to the mission, 567 in all.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNMOGIP is still active. Denmark’s participation stretched from 1949 to October 2009 when sixty years of engagement in and around Kashmir ended.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The UN observers were to assist in maintaining the ceasefire agreed between India and Pakistan. They did this work from “Field Stations” where they resided in teams of two or three along with local military assistants. These stations were their home bases from which they performed their patrols and monitoring tasks. Any violations of the ceasefire were to be reported not just to the UN but also to India and Pakistan.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Until 1990, the country we now know as Namibia was called South West Africa. After World War I and the 1919 Treaty of Versailles, it came under the control of South Africa. South West Africa had previously been a colony of Germany named German South West Africa. South Africa had sided with Britain during World War I and occupied the area in 1915. Per the Treaty of Versailles, South Africa now maintained control of the territory. It was to be administered on behalf of the League of Nations. The original intent was to put the territory under administration, but when the League of Nations was replaced by the United Nations after World War II, South Africa refused to prepare South West Africa for independence. The UN annulled South Africa’s mandate to administer South West Africa in 1966 and took direct control of the territory. It became the only territory ever to be controlled directly by the UN. It was decided in 1969 that it would be illegal for South Africa to carry out activities in the area or extract natural resources (as of 1974) while work was being done to establish an independent Namibian nation. It was then decided in 1976 that South Africa needed to accept preparations for a UN-supervised referendum in the area. South Africa did not; however that was no hindrance for the work done by the UN to hold a referendum including the setting up of United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG) in 1978. By 1988, pressure from the UN made South Africa agree to work toward referenda in South West Africa. With the participation of the 49 nations involved in UNTAG, South West Africa gained independence on 21 March 1990 and took the name Namibia. On 23 April 1990, Namibia became the 160th member of the United Nations.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate of UNTAG was set out in UN Security Council Resolutions 632 and 635/1989. The main purpose was to give Namibia independence via free and fair referenda supervised and controlled by the UN. In addition, the mandate was intended to provide for the withdrawal of external military forces such as those of South Africa, the release of political prisoners, and the unhindered return of Namibians who had fled.
Large forces from a great many nations contributed to the mission, and some units were on call in their home countries. There was no telling how guerrilla and rebel groups would react. An international police force numbering about 1,500 took part as well.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
After a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government on 15 September 1988 decided to send soldiers and observers to Namibia to work in UNTAG.
The government on 24 August 1988 received a request from the UN for an indication that Denmark, if necessary, would be prepared to offer a contribution in connection with the potential implementation of the UN peace plan for Namibia per Resolution 435. The government did make this preliminary commitment on 2 September 1988, and the Foreign Policy Committee was advised on 15 September in this regard. On 22 December 1988, the UN Security Council approved the Tripartite Accord by Angola, Cuba, and South Africa respecting the independence of Namibia. On 16 January 1989, the Council approved Resolution 435 in which the total size of the UNTAG force was set at about 4,650 and the date of deployment of UNTAG forces was set for 1 April 1989 in order to realise the pace plan. The Danish contingent of 120 left for Namibia on 15 March 1989. The mission ended on 31 March 1990 at the expiry of the mandate.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The tasks given to UNTAG included disarming the former rebel groups, monitoring the withdrawal of South African troops, and controlling the borders with neighbouring countries including South Africa and Angola.
During the period 1989-1990, about 304 Danes were deployed in a staff company of 120, including military police. They returned to Denmark in 1990 after the referendum. Per an agreement between the Danish and Namibian governments, the Danish fishery inspection vessel Havørnen [Sea Eagle] was transferred in 1993 to the new nation along with DKK 51.5 million to cover the costs of a core Danish crew and maintenance of the ship for up to five years.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Working with personnel from 49 other nations, the Danish staff company had charge of organising transportation, logistics, and maintenance for the UN force along with handling of incoming and outgoing mail. The fishery inspection ship Havørnen protected the fish stocks in the waters off the coast of Namibia.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Denmark’s contribution lasted from 1989 to 1990 when Namibia became independent and the Danish personnel could return.
