text.heading: Background
text.text: Somalia, a country in the Horn of Africa, has been beset by civil war for many years. It took a turn for the worse in 1991 when President Siad Barre was forced to resign. Supporters of Interim President Ali Mahdi Mohamed and of General Mohamed Farah Aidid then entered into armed conflict to declare one of them the ruler of Somalia. The United Nations launched several interventions to quell the hostilities in the country. One of them was the 1993-1995 United Nations Operation in Somalia II (UNOSOM II). At the end of this operation, the UN in 1995 established the WFP Somalia Country Office in Nairobi. Its aim was to deliver humanitarian aid to the Somalian people and to other populations in the Horn of Africa that had been impacted by crop failures for many years. It was estimated that about 11 million people needed aid – especially in Ethiopia and Somalia. The UN has been providing aid, and still does so, by ensuring that food aid is delivered safely to the country by freighters. In 2008, Denmark contributed to the protection of supply ships by sending the patrol vessel Thetis. To this day, Somalia experiences famine and instability. As a result, the WFP is still operating in the area. In 2011, Denmark again took part in the work of the WFP, this time by supplying personnel from the Danish Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate of the patrol vessel Thetis is based on UN Security Council Resolution 1772 of 20 August 2007. The UN sought to create stability in Somalia and to set up institutions to handle political strife. The mandate further included ensuring that the UN continued to collaborate with The African Union and The League of Arab States for the purpose of maintaining effective international cooperation. This collaboration was intended to provide humanitarian aid to Somalia and to impose stability and long term peace. In addition, the mandate provided for police and military forces in and around Somalia to reinforce the goals of the mandate.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution to the UN WFP was proposed to Parliament (item B32) on 15 January 2008. The decision to provide a Thetis class vessel was based on the UN Security Council Resolution of 20 August 2007 in which all member countries were asked to combat piracy. In addition to that UN request, France had asked Denmark to take over its former task of escorting ships to the coastal waters of Somalia. The proposal to provide the services of Thetis between January and 30 April 2008, including outbound and inbound transportation of personnel, was approved unanimously by Parliament with 106 votes in favour.
In 2011, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs approved the support of WFP by participation in a joint International Humanitarian Partnership mission with the intent of setting up a headquarters for WFP in the city of Dolo Addo at the border between Ethiopia and Somalia.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
In 2008, Denmark contributed the patrol vessel Thetis with security personnel from the Frogman Corps and the military police unit of the Royal Danish Navy. A total of 100 Danish officers took part. The vessel is one of four patrol vessels built for the Royal Danish Navy between 1986 and 1991 for service in the North Atlantic.
As a participant in the 2011 mission, Denmark provided camp facilities and offices for 15 staff in prefabricated buildings (PREFABS). Along with personnel from Sweden, Finland, and Germany, about 10 staff from the Danish Emergency Management Agency were a part of this project led by Sweden.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The contribution by Denmark in the form of the patrol vessel Thetis with security personnel from the Frogman Corps and the military police unit of the Royal Danish Navy was rendered during the period from January to April 2008. Support to WFP from the Danish Emergency Management Agency was provided between August 2011 and February 2012.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission was to protect ships sailing to Somalia against pirates. Thetis did not encounter serious difficulties with pirates. She escorted a total of 20,600 tonnes of emergency supplies to Somalia in the humanitarian aid effort. After this successful operation, the European Union assumed the escort of emergency aid ships.
The Danish Emergency Management Agency undertakings in 2011 included facility construction, communications, and a camp for the use of WFP and WHO.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
East Timor had been under Portugese colonial rule since the 18th Century but was annexed by Indonesia in 1975. The annexation was approved by Australia and the USA.  In 1998, however, Australia put the suggestion of independence for East Timor to the President of Indonesia, which was not received well.  Pro-Indonesian militias reacted violently, which led to a number of initiatives towards a UN peacekeeping force in the region. When East Timor voted for independence in a referendum in 1999, East Timor had its first opportunity since the failed declaration of independence in 1975 to democratically decide its own future as a nation. East Timor’s administration and organisation of the referendum was aided by the United Nations Mission in East Timor (UNAMET). The result of the referendum was a 78.5% vote in favour of independence.

UNAMET had no mandate to be responsible for security during the vote, which meant that Indonesia’s police and military were charged with the task. The stance of neither body was neutral with regard to the outcome of the vote. Violent pro-Indonesian militias had a free rein to cause havoc in East Timor, which led to large areas of the capital city being turned into ruins. Over 1,000 East Timorians were killed, and half of the country’s population had fled. Most of UNAMET’s personnel was evacuated from the region to Australia during the unrest.
The Indonesian Government was either unwilling or unable to stop the violence. After increasing pressure from the UN Security Council and the USA, Indonesia was finally persuaded to allow the deployment of an international force in East Timor.
Because of the slow and bureaucratic process that is involved when deploying a multi-national UN force, a solution of this type was not appropriate with regard to the emergency situation in East Timor. The UN Security Council therefore decided in September 1999 to authorise the formation of a multi-national force under a common leadership. Australia offered to lead a coalition of willing nations towards restoring law and order to East Timor. The mission, named International Force for East Timor (INTERFET), was already in East Timor just five days after the Security Council resolution was approved.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
INTERFET’s mandate came from UN Security Council Resolution 1264 of 15 September 1999, in which the Security Council authorised the formation of a multi-national force under a common command structure. INTERFET’s mission was to: Restore peace and security to East Timor, to protect and assist the UNAMET mission in its duties and to support humanitarian operations. The mission was limited to East Timor and was thus required to respect Indonesian sovereignty. INTERFET was also mandated to use all means necessary to fulfil its mandate, including force if necessary. Large numbers of troops were deployed, as well as ships, combat aircraft, army units and special forces from a number of countries, mainly including Australia, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, the USA and Canada. A number of other countries with interests in Eastern Asia also provided troops.
INTERFET’s mandate would endure until it was possible to deploy a UN peacekeeping force.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Danish INTERFET participation was decided by the Government of the day after concluding bilateral agreements between Australia and Denmark, after being put to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark's initial contribution to INTERFET was comprised of two liaison officers, who were later joined by two staff officers.
At its peak, the mission had approx. 11,000 ground troops from 22 nations, Australia being the main contributor.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
INTERFET ran from 20 September 1999 to 28 February 2000. Thanks to the mission in East Timor, the violent militias withdrew to West Timor, where there were few combat engagements. The force quickly regained control over the region and the refugees who had fled to other parts of the country were able to begin to return. The UNAMET mission was briefly re-established at the end of September 1999. Indonesia officially recognised the result of the independence referendum on 19 October 1999.
The success of INTERFET meant that it had also served its purpose, so INTERFET and UNAMET were formally replaced by a United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) on 25 October 1999. INTERFET continued to be responsible for security in East Timor until the UNTAET peacekeeping force was established in February 2000.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Korea had been under Japanese occupation since Japan won the 1905 Russo-Japanese war but, after the Second World War and the start of the Cold War that followed it, it was split into two countries along the 38th parallel. North Korean troops invaded South Korea in 1950 with military and financial aid from China and the Soviet Union. The UN Security Council recommended in Resolution 83 that UN members should provide aid to South Korea. That this was even possible was because the Soviet Union was boycotting the UN Security Council in 1950 and was thus unable to veto the decision. A coalition of 22 nations formed the United Nations Command (UNC), the USA being the main contributor and coalition leader.
At the request of the UN and USA, Denmark contributed a hospital ship, Jutlandia.
The Korean War is considered as one of the first wars by proxy between the Soviet Union and the USA during the Cold War.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In Resolution 83, the UN Security Council asked UN members to assist South Korea in its battle to push back the North Korean invading troops.
Jutlandia had a unique Danish mandate, as it sailed under three flags: Dannebrog (the Danish flag), and Red Cross and UN flags. The Dannebrog symbolised that the ship was Denmark’s contribution to the UN mission in the Korean War. The Red Cross flag symbolised that the practical workload of this expedition was carried out by Danish Red Cross and under its protection. The UN flag symbolised that the hospital ship was part of the UN’s military action in Korea.
Denmark's contribution was unusual, in that it was a civilian humanitarian contribution instead of a military one, as hospital ships are usually a military operation.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The decision to contribute to the US-led mission in Korea was adopted on 5 July 1950 by the government of the day, supported by the opposition. Because of the atmosphere of political tension that was a feature of the 1950s, the decision to contribute to the mission posed a dilemma. On the one hand, Denmark was unwilling to provoke the Soviet Union by contributing a military unit, while on the other, Denmark wanted to ensure continued political goodwill with it’s US ally.
Initially, Denmark offered to contribute medicines to Korea, followed by a proposal to contribute an ambulance unit from Danish Red Cross. The UN and USA wanted Denmark to provide a contingent of troops and considered both proposals to be insufficient. The Danish Government therefore decided on 18 August 1950 that it would make the ship Jutlandia available in a hospital ship role. The Americans were more satisfied with this solution, but would still rather have seen a contribution of troops from Denmark.
The ship was built at Nakskov Shipyard in 1934 as a cargo and passenger vessel. Nakskov Shipyard was also responsible for the conversion to a hospital ship, which required a reconfiguration of the ship to accommodate approx. 300 patients and the installation of five hospital wards and three operating theatres.
Jutlandia would eventually be able to sail for Korea on 23 January 1951.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
From 23 January 1951 to its final return home on 16 October 1953 Jutlandia sailed three missions to Korea. She returned to Europe twice during the mission, performing the role of transporting patients on the return journey. Upon her return to Denmark, the crew was replaced and problems with the ship were fixed. This included the fitting of a helicopter deck when she returned to Denmark for the second time.
For the first two trips the ship was docked at the harbour in Pusan, far from the front line. The final trip was somewhat different, with a deployment to the Incheon bay, close to the fighting.
Jutlandia’s work was particularly notable because of its civilian and humanitarian objective. The ship’s crew would therefore admit UN and Korean troops, as well as children and other civilians for medical treatment, which was unusual for military hospital ships. The USA and UN took a reserved stance to this and did not consider it to be a wise course of action, as they wanted the hospital ship to be ready for an emergency and preferred only a few beds to be occupied at a time (so the hospital could accept military casualties for treatment).
Ultimately, it seemed clear that far more civilians were treated than UN soldiers. This means that in practical terms, the expedition ended up having a rather different purpose to what was envisaged in the UN and US plan. This benefited the Korean population, who would be very appreciative of Jutlandia.
 A total of 630 Danes took part in the mission, including doctors, nurses, carers, administrative personnel and the ship’s crew. According to the ship’s own statistics, the hospital ship treated 4,981 patients. These figures only include UN soldiers, however. The commander of the expedition, Kai Hammerich, estimated that about 6,000 Koreans had been treated but actually thought that that figure should probably be tripled.
Because this was a civilian mission, the crew was also comprised of civilians who had been recruited on a voluntary basis and deployed under the auspices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark rather than the Danish Ministry of Defence. Expedition commander Kai Hammerich retained his ranks as a naval officer, however, so as to better be able to be part of the UN unit command for the sphere of operations.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The war ended on 27 July 1953, when a ceasefire was agreed between UNC, the North Korean People’s Army and the Chinese People’s Volunteer Army. This ceasefire is still in force today. The ceasefire is thus a pact between military forces and not the actual nations involved. The ceasefire agreement also contained guidelines on the return of war prisoners and the creation of a demarcation line through Korea, with a two-kilometre wide demilitarised zone on each side of the border. The two parties also agreed to find a peaceful solution at state level within three months. This agreement never produced an official peace treaty, however, which means that the two countries are technically still at war.
When the ceasefire was agreed, the good ship Jutlandia had done her duty as a hospital ship and was then able to sail for home. After she returned to Denmark a refit saw her returned to her original role as a cargo and passenger vessel, operating as such until she was sailed to Spain in 1965 for scrapping.
The ceasefire saw the establishment of the United Nations Command Military Armistice Commission (UNCMAC). Its main role was to monitor the implementation of the ceasefire between North and South Korea along the 245 kilometre long demilitarised zone and to act as a broker in the event of treaty violations or other tensions. Denmark has been contributing to the UNCMAC mission since 2008.

text.heading: Background
text.text: After the 2011 “Arab Spring”, a protracted civil war broke out in Syria. It brought instability to the entire region by sowing unrest in various ways in the neighbouring countries. As of 2012, several military clashes took place in the border regions between Turkey and Syria. These clashes culminated in October 2012 when Syrian government forces fired artillery across the Turkish border, killing 5 and injuring 10 Turkish civilians. Turkey was unable to defend itself against ballistic missiles and feared Syria’s capacity and intent to use chemical weapons. Concerned that the situation would further escalate, Turkey decided to request NATO assistance in defending Turkish air space. In December 2012, NATO granted the request by boosting Turkey’s defence capacity with Patriot surface-to-air missiles installed at the Turkish-Syrian border. These are able to shoot down short range and tactical ballistic missiles and enemy jet fighters.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Operation Active Fence (OAF) is part of the NATO Integrated Air and Missile Defence (NIAMD), a permanent mission to protect NATO territories, populations, and military forces against air strikes and missile attacks.
As in other NATO operations, member countries offer to contribute materiel or personnel to individual missions. These contributions then come under NATO command. The USA, Holland (replaced by Spain in 2015), and Germany contributed surface-to-air missiles to OAF. Other countries provided specialists who came under operational command of the Supreme Allied Commander Europe (SACEUR).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The government decided to send 10 members of the Royal Danish Signal Regiment to South Eastern Turkey to assist in setting up strategic communications in support of the NATO Patriot units. These Danes are part of a total Deployable Communications Module (DCM) contribution from NATO amounting to 50 personnel.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Between 2013 and 2015, Denmark contributed to Operation Active Fence on several occasions by supplying mobile communication units (Deployable Communication Modules, DCMs). The personnel belonged to the DCM company within the Royal Danish Signal Regiment in Haderslev. Their initial task was to construct the system to support the German missile batteries in Turkey. Since then, the Danish personnel have been responsible for delivering information and communication equipment such as telephones, computers, and data networks to the mission. They played an important role in the maintenance of strategic information and communication lines to enable NATO leaders to inform the missile units about upcoming air strikes and thus help them respond accordingly.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
As a NATO operation, Operation Active Fence has been contributing to Turkey’s air defence since 2012. In 2015, NATO assessed the risk of missile attacks from Syria as having decreased significantly. Germany and the United States opted to recall its contribution while Spain maintained its missile batteries in Turkey.
At the end of 2015, there were few signs that the Syrian civil war would end, and NATO made the decision to increase its support elsewhere by way of improved air patrols, enhanced intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance, and a strengthened presence in the eastern part of the Mediterranean.

missions.name: Active Endeavour Middelhavet Absalon
missions.descriptiveName: Operation Active Endeavour, Absalon & Esbern Snare

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 11 September 2001, two passenger aircraft flew into the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York. A third flew into the Pentagon, headquarters of the U.S. Department of Defense. A fourth crashed in a field, in all probability while headed towards the White House. Almost 3,000 people were killed in these attacks, that shook the world out of the optimism of the 1990s after the end of the Cold War. Over the following days, it was revealed that 19 hijackers were responsible for the attacks, which had been planned by the Islamic Al-Qaeda terror network, led by Osama bin Laden.
The organisation had been responsible for a number of attacks over the years leading up to the one on 11 September. Targets were Muslims that they considered kafir (heretics), and foreign nations that they believed had to much influence in the Islamic world. Their first attacks included bombing US embassies in Eastern Africa and an attack on an American destroyer, the USS Cole, off the coast of Yemen.
Shortly after the attack on the World Trade Center, President Bush declared an international war against terror. The primary goal was to defeat Al-Qaeda and similar organisations, as well as the countries that were supporting them or allowing them to organise in their territory, as Afghanistan had been doing under the Taliban regime. A large number of initiatives were set in motion, including: increased authority for security services and wider international partnerships between the security agencies of various countries, an invasion of Afghanistan to overthrow the Taliban and destroy Al-Qaeda’s training bases there and naval operations in the Mediterranean to prevent the transportation of arms to terrorists and to protect international trade. Naval operations in the Mediterranean were given the name Operation Active Endeavour.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council convened on multiple occasions during September and unanimously voted to adopt Resolutions 1368 and 1373 (2001). The resolutions were a confirmation that the UN considered this an international attack on the US and a thread to international peace and security. Accordingly, the UN accepted the right of the US and its allies to independent and collective self defence and encouraged all UN member states to cooperate in bringing the culprits to justice and to oppose all organisations with links to international terrorism.
After the attacks on 11 September, NATO’s supreme authority, the North Atlantic Council, decided that it, like the UN, considered the incident to be an attack on the US and that it qualified the triggering of Article V of the North Atlantic Treaty, also known as the “all for one and one for all” musketeer oath. An attack on one member of NATO should be considered an attack on all NATO member states. The US NATO representative confirmed that the attack was carried out by Al-Qaeda. This was therefore an attack by an external power and the US invoked Article V. To date, this is the first and only time that this part of the treaty has been triggered.
Barely a month after the attack, NATO announced on 9 October that it would be deploying a naval task force in the east Mediterranean to combat international terrorism at sea. On 26 October, it was authorised by NATO’s military committee under the code name Operation Active Endeavour, that the Atlantic fleet’s standing naval forces, STANAVFORLANT, would alternate with STANAVFORMED, in the patrolling of the eastern Mediterranean.

It was decided in 2004 that the operation would be broadened to cover the entire Mediterranean, not just waters in the East. After reorganisation, STANAVFORLANT and STANAVFORMED were renamed in 2005 to, respectively, Standing NATO Maritime Groups 1 and 2 (SNMG-1 & SNMG-2). The structure of Operation Active Endeavour was reassessed and amended in January 2010. After this time, fewer ships would be operating permanently on the Mediterranean, but the two naval task forces would be able to periodically transfer a large-scale naval force to the area for shorter periods.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
By way of contrast to previous Danish contributions to Operation Active Endeavour, it was not a direct decision to deploy Absalon and Esbern Snare as part of the operation. The Danish vessels would, as planned, be part of the standing naval forces as part of Denmark’s NATO obligations. The basis for participation in this operation comes from Danish Parliamentary proposal B59 from 2009, which mandated the two ships to hunt pirates off the east coast of Africa as part of NATO’s Operation Ocean Shield. The proposal also included Danish parliamentary authorisation for the ships to be part of this naval task force and to carry out the permanent missions of SNMG-1 under NATO auspices, and for involvement on the Mediterranean as part of Active Endeavour.
The proposal concerning Operation Ocean Shield and piracy off the coast of Somalia was unanimously adopted with 102 votes on 17 December 2009.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
In 2010, Denmark’s contribution to SNMG-1 and its Mediterranean operations took the form of two warships, Absalon and Esbern Snare. Both ships were ABSALON class command and support ships. The ships operated as flagships for SNMG-1, with one ship participating in the operation at a time. Absalon was deployed for the first six months, with Esbern Snare taking over for the second half of 2010. Denmark took part again in 2014 with Esbern Snare and for a third time in 2016 with Absalon. On both occasions they operated as command ships for SNMG-1 or SNMG-2.
As well as the ships’ regular crews of approximately 140 personnel, each of the ships was equipped with a Lynx helicopter belonging to the Royal Danish Air Force, military police deployed by the army and an assault team comprised of naval special forces, should it be necessary to perform boardings. Danish Defence Medical Command also deployed a doctor and two nurses, as well as two languages officers and an interpreter from the Danish Defence Academy. Last but not least, a command officer with a staff of 12 officers was also on board to command and coordinate the joint NATO naval force during this period.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Danish command of SNMG-1 lasted for the whole of 2010, led by Absalon from January to June, Esbern Snare taking over from July to December. The naval task force would only operate in the Mediterranean from April to June as a part of Operation Active Endeavour. Before and after the operation, the ships carried out a number of other missions, including combating piracy as part of Operation Ocean Shield and joint NATO exercises, as well as a deployment to Canada as part of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Canadian Navy.
After sailing the Mediterranean as the flagship of the UN RECSYR (removal and securing of chemical weapons from Syria) operation, Esbern Snare was redeployed to SNMG-1 from May 2014. The ship led the naval task force until 22 December the same year but was only involved in Active Endeavour for periodic deployments from 19 May to 13 June and again between 8 and 14 December. In the meantime, the naval task force served primarily as part of NATO's Ocean Shield.
Denmark contributed to the operation once again in 2016, this time when Absalon was deployed to SNMG-2. The ship had just completed operation RECLIB, which. like the aforementioned RECSYR operation had the mission of removing chemical weapons from unstable states in the Middle East, this time from Libya. Led by Absalon, SNMG-2 took part in Active Endeavour from September, until the Danish command ship left the naval task force on 21 November. This was the final Danish contribution to the operation, as it was wound down soon afterwards. Sea Guardian was commissioned in 2016 but this was no longer an Article V operation. Operation Active Endeavour commenced in 2001 and saw Danish involvement from the two command/support ships, patrol vessels, corvettes and the submarine Sælen.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
As command and flagship for Operation Active Endeavour, the primary tasks of Absalon and Esbern Snare were to serve as a platform for the task force commander, commanding and coordinating the other ships in SNMG-1, as well as other ships that were collaborating with or participating in the operation.
The objective of the operation was to manifest a presence and force in the war against terror by deploying a naval task force to the eastern Mediterranean. The task force would patrol the area, monitoring and inspecting seaborne traffic. A particular requirement was to stop and inspect traffic that may be related to international terrorism, such as arms trafficking.
When the operation was extended to also cover the western Mediterranean, the mission of participating ships now meant patrolling a very large area. During patrols, contact was made to the seaborne vessels that were encountered, these being interrogated about their route and cargo. Ships were also boarded and inspected if there was a suspicion that they might be somehow linked to international terrorism.

missions.title: GRITROCK Sierra Leone
missions.subtitle: The Ebola Epidemic
missions.name: GRITROCK Sierra Leone
missions.descriptiveName: An Unyielding Sandstone, not Giving Up

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Between 2013 and 2016, West Africa experienced the worst ever outbreak of Ebola. Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone were hit especially hard by the Ebola epidemic.
Prior to the outbreak, Sierra Leone had 140 physicians to serve a population of six million people. With 14,000 infected and 4,000 dead in the course of two and a half years, the health system of Sierra Leone quickly collapsed.
In 2014, it was estimated that with every passing hour, five new infections occurred. It was clear that a coordinated international effort was needed to contain the disease – for humanitarian reasons to be sure, but also to avoid contagion across the rest of the continent.
In August 2014, the World Health Organization declared the Ebola epidemic a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). In September 2014, the UN Security Council declared that the outbreak was a threat to international peace and security and urged all UN members and UN operational units to take the matter seriously and contribute additional resources to fight the epidemic. As part of the effort to fight Ebola in West Africa, the UK initiated Operation GRITROCK to combat and limit the spread of Ebola in Sierra Leone.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Operation GRITROCK came about as an extension of UN Security Council Resolution 2177 of 18 September 2014. The Resolution urged all UN nations to contribute to the eradication of Ebola in West Africa. The British Operation GRITROCK was a military and civilian effort that played a significant role in the fight against Ebola in Sierra Leone.
The operation was structured in three phases (phase 1: Containment and Protection; phase 2: Expansion and Influence; phase 3: Eradication of Ebola). The first phase made heavy use of military resources to create stability and order in the capital city of Freetown, construct treatment centres and train health workers, and set up an effective command structure for the fight against Ebola.
The second phase focused on eliminating the remaining outbreaks in the country and initiating the demilitarisation of the mission.
The third and final phase – with new cases occurring much less frequently – saw the mission further demilitarised. In order to deal with the last cases of Ebola contagion, the mission shifted to an intelligence based strategy for finding and isolating these last cases.
Operation GRITROCK began on 21 September 2014 and lasted for more than 14 months. Over 1,500 British military personnel took part. The mission concluded on 13 December 2015.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision to have Denmark participate in the British-led mission in Sierra Leone was made by the Danish government.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark took part in Operation GRITROCK from December 2014 to June 2015. This contribution included 83 personnel from the armed forces plus volunteers recruited by the Ministry of Health and the administrative regions for health services delivery in Denmark. Four teams were dispatched during the mission, each team working for about two months. The teams consisted of physicians, nurses, bioanalysts, medical equipment technicians, and team leaders from the armed forces. The Danish teams collaborated with GOAL, an Irish NGO.
Prior to deployment in Sierra Leone, the Danish teams went for mission training with GOAL teams. This training was delivered by British military personnel in York in the UK.
In early 2014, Danish Defence set up an emergency response unit capable of responding within 36 hours to evacuate Ebola-infected persons from West Africa.
In addition, on request from the UN, Denmark sent a transport ship, Ark Futura, to move materiel for humanitarian work in West Africa.
The Danish Emergency Management Agency assisted with the efforts to fight Ebola in Sierra Leone. Sixty-one team members were in charge of construction and maintenance of a camp for the health workers in Port Loko where the Danes were based.
Finally, the Danish Emergency Management Agency supported education and training of more than 5,000 local and international health and emergency workers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Denmark terminated the Ebola work in Sierra Leone in June 2015 when the epidemic had been successfully managed. In March 2016, WHO declared that Ebola in West Africa was no longer an international public health emergency.
In total, the Ebola epidemic infected 28,600 people (the number of registered persons), of whom 11,310 died. Ebola had spread from Africa to such places as the United States, Italy, Spain, and the UK, but in these countries, the disease could be contained effectively. One Danish nurse was sent back to Denmark from Sierra Leone due to a suspected infection. She was declared free of Ebola after a quarantine of 18 days.

missions.title: OSGAP  Afghanistan
missions.subtitle: Failure of Political Initiatives
missions.name: OSGAP Afghanistan
missions.descriptiveName: Office of the Sec. Gen, in Afghanistan and Pakistan

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Afghan-Soviet War was a conflict between the communist government in Kabul, supported by the Soviet Union, and a series of Islamic rebel groups collectively referred to as the Mujahideen. These rebel groups received significant support from Pakistan and the US. In 1988, a peace accord between Afghanistan and Pakistan involving the Soviet Union and the US was entered into. Known as the Geneva Accords, the agreement established the United Nations Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan (UNGOMAP). The primary work of this mission was to monitor the withdrawal of Soviet troops, to assist in a political solution to the problems in Afghanistan, and to deal with the return of Afghan refugees from Pakistan.
When the Soviet Union withdrew its military troops from Afghanistan in 1989, UNGOMAP had fulfilled one of those three mandates. Due to insufficient financing and lack of political will on the part of the parties to the peace accord, the mission was unable to fulfil the entirety of the mandate. The mission was terminated in 1990 for two reasons: There was a lack of political interest at the UN Security Council, and the mission was regarded as being ineffectual given the continuing civil war in Afghanistan.
The UN Secretary-General still wished to continue the mission based on the remainder of the mandate. The Secretary-General was able to obtain a single officer from each of 10 countries contributing to UNGOMAP, including Denmark. These officers were to assist the Secretary-General’s personal representative in Afghanistan; hence the mission was known as Office of the Secretary-General in Afghanistan and Pakistan (OSGAP).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mission of OSGAP was to work toward a political solution to the problems in Afghanistan and to assist the humanitarian efforts there. The overarching goal was to improve relations between Afghanistan and Pakistan. OSGAP included a special division of military advisers whose original purpose had been to plan a potential deployment of a UN force in Afghanistan. The advisers were in addition supposed to lend military expertise to the personal representative of the Secretary-General and to prepare regular security analyses of the situation in Afghanistan. Given that the situation in Afghanistan never did evolve to a point where the deployment of a UN force became relevant, the military advisers primarily worked to establish relations in the Khyber Pass area to ensure that emergency aid could reach Kabul without incident.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon an orientation to the Foreign Affairs Council in the spring of 1990, the Danish government decided to contribute one officer as an adviser to OSGAP. He served from March 1990 to the end of 1995.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Two Danish military advisers contributed to OSGAP from 1990 to 1992 when the mission’s military advisers were recalled. The overall organisation was modest in size. In fact, it included only 9 military advisers (from 9 countries) and a small international staff plus a few locals for additional support. Like UNGOMAP, OSGAP had offices in Kabul, Afghanistan and Islamabad, Pakistan.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
OSGAP was active from 1990 to 1995. The Danish contribution was active from 1990 to 1992..
After its military withdrawal, the Soviet Union continued to provide financial support and materiel to the communist government and thus enabled continued defence against the Mujahideen rebels. Upon the fall of the Soviet Union in December 1991, this support ended, and in 1992 the government lost Kabul to the Mujahideen rebels. Immediately after the fall of Kabul, a protracted conflict ensued among the various rebel groups vying for power in Afghanistan. As a result, the Taliban, supported by Pakistan, assumed power in 1996..
In such an environment, it became clear that the OSGAP mission lacked the necessary resources and the political power to have any real influence on the ever escalating Afghan civil war in which the agreements in the Geneva Accords had long been forgotten. OSGAP was terminated in 1995.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In colonial times, Timor was divided between Dutch and Portuguese rulers. After World War II, West Timor became a part of newly independent Indonesia while East Timor remained under Portuguese rule. After the Carnation Revolution in Portugal in 1974, the new government initiated a gradual decolonisation of its overseas territories. In the ensuing power vacuum in East Timor, a three-week civil war broke out in 1975 between the Timorese Democratic Union, a conservative party, and Fretilin, a leftist party.
The war was won by popular Fretilin. Immediately afterwards, the party declared independence for East Timor. Its marxist rhetoric caused concern on the part of East Timor’s neighbour Indonesia and Indonesia’s close ally the U.S. The prospect of a pro-Soviet regime in the heart of its national territory prompted Indonesia to invade East Timor just nine days after the declaration of independence. Indonesia occupied East Timor until 1999. During the occupation, frequent violent clashes took place between the Indonesian military and East Timorese rebel groups, especially Fretilin.
Indonesian soldiers in 1991 killed about 200 East Timorese activists. Documented and filmed by foreign journalists, the event gave rise to strong anti-Indonesian sentiment internationally. A major political upheaval in Indonesia in 1998 and continued pressure from the rest of the world persuaded the Indonesian government in Jakarta to agree to a referendum on independence in East Timor.
The UN Security Council then set up United Nations Mission in East Timor (UNAMET) to assist East Timor in holding this referendum.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UNAMET was established by UN Security Council Resolution 1246 of 11 June 1999. The objective of the mission was to organise and administer a free and fair referendum on the future status of East Timor as an independent nation or as a nation under continued Indonesian rule.
The UNAMET mandate provided for an international police force to train Indonesian police officers to manage the referendum. In addition, a staff of liaison officers was set up to maintain relations with the Indonesian military.
UNAMET was based in Dili in East Timor with an initial time frame of 11 June to 31 August 1999. That time frame was extended by Security Council Resolution 1257 to 30 September that year.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government decided to participate as a result of a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark initially provided two observers and in total five officers to the UNAMET mission.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNAMET was active from 11 June to 30 September 1999. The referendum in East Timor took place on 30 August. On that day, the turnout of eligible voters was 98%, and 78,5% of them voted for independence. The UNAMET mission encountered major tumult when pro-Indonesian militias began a series of attacks in East Timor during the referendum. Many of the mission’s personnel had to be evacuated. In an effort to contain the violence, an international force was stationed in East Timor under the name INTERFET.

missions.title: UNMISET Timor-Leste
missions.subtitle: A Short-Lived Success
missions.name: UNMISET Østtimor
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission of Support in East Timor

text.heading: Background
text.text:
United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) had been in charge of exercising government authority in East Timor since the time of unrest when a referendum for independence was held in 1999 until the presidential election in May 2002. After that election, East Timor still faced significant challenges in further developing public authorities and in building a competent police force. Moreover, it lacked adequate funding for enforcing internal and external national security.
Therefore, United Nations Mission of Support in East Timor (UNMISET) was created to assist in the ongoing nation-building and construction of government authorities in newly independent East Timor until public administration tasks could be transferred to the authorities of East Timor.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate was established by UN Security Council Resolution 1410 of 17 May 2002. UNMISET was mandated to support the central administration in East Timor with the objective of seeing to the continued stability in the country and the long term viability of the young nation of East Timor. In addition, UNMISET was charged with operating an interim police force, ensuring public safety, and providing assistance in developing a new police authority in East Timor.  Finally, the mission was mandated to contribute to the internal and external security of East Timor.
Initially, UNMISET was slated to last for 12 months with a potential extension. Given the considerable scope of the work, the UN Security Council three times extended and amended the mandate.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government made the decision to participate upon a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark contributed to UNMISET from 2002 until its termination in May 2005. Two Danish staff officers and two observers participated in the mission.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNMISET was active from 20 May 2002 to 20 May 2005. Though resources were few and the time frame was short, the UNMISET mission managed to support East Timor in moving forward. Stability was ensured, and an East Timorese border protection force was set up and trained. The mission worked intently to build solid collaboration between Indonesia and East Timor in terms of the continued stability of the shared border area.
The fast and effective work of UNTAET in helping the country along toward independence created optimism in the UN Security Council about the capability of the country to manage on its own in the future, not without reason. East Timor could be viewed as a small, cohesive, and politically manageable country made strong by its recent liberation. The UN had devoted a relatively large portion of its budget to a single country with a population of only one million, and the UN Security Council therefore decided to recall UNMISET in 2005, exactly three years after East Timorese independence.  

The termination of UNMISET would soon prove premature. Just a year after the recall of the mission, renewed and extensive violence and unrest erupted. The UN then needed to set up yet another mission, the UN Integrated Mission in Timor-Leste. Denmark did not participate in it.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 11 September 2001, two passenger aircraft flew into the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York. A third flew into the Pentagon, headquarters of the U.S. Department of Defense. A fourth crashed in a field, in all probability while headed towards the White House. Almost 3,000 people were killed in these attacks, that shook the world out of the optimism of the 1990s after the end of the Cold War. Over the following days, it was revealed that 19 hijackers were responsible for the attacks, which had been planned by the Islamic Al-Qaeda terror network, led by Osama bin Laden.
The organisation had been responsible for a number of attacks over the years leading up to the one on 11 September. Targets were Muslims that they considered kafir (heretics), and foreign nations that they believed had to much influence in the Islamic world. Their first attacks included bombing US embassies in Eastern Africa and an attack on an American destroyer, the USS COLE, off the coast of Yemen.
Shortly after the attack on the World Trade Center, President Bush declared an international war against terror. The primary goal was to defeat Al-Qaeda and similar organisations, as well as the countries that were supporting them or allowing them to organise in their territory, as Afghanistan had been doing under the Taliban regime. A large number of initiatives were set in motion, including: increased authority for security services and wider international partnerships between the security agencies of various countries, an invasion of Afghanistan to overthrow the Taliban and destroy Al-Qaeda’s training bases there and naval operations in the Mediterranean to prevent the transportation of arms to terrorists and to protect international trade. Naval operations in the Mediterranean were given the name Operation Active Endeavour.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council convened on multiple occasions during September and unanimously voted to adopt Resolutions 1368 and 1373 (2001). The resolutions were a confirmation that the UN considered this an international attack on the US and a thread to international peace and security. Accordingly, the UN accepted the right of the US and its allies to independent and collective self defence and encouraged all UN member states to cooperate in bringing the culprits to justice and to oppose all organisations with links to international terrorism.
On 12 September, just one day after the attack, NATO’s supreme authority, the North Atlantic Council, decided that it, like the UN, considered the incident to be an attack on the US and that it qualified the triggering of Article V of the North Atlantic Treaty, also known as the “all for one and one for all” musketeer oath. An attack on one member of NATO should be considered an attack on all NATO member states. The US NATO representative confirmed that the attack was carried out by Al-Qaeda. This was therefore an attack by an external power and the US invoked Article V. To date, this is the first and only time that this part of the treaty has been triggered.
Barely a month after the attack, NATO announced on 9 October that it would be deploying a naval task force in the east Mediterranean to combat international terrorism at sea. On 26 October, it was authorised by NATO’s military committee under the code name Operation Active Endeavour, that the Atlantic fleet’s standing naval forces, STANAVFORLANT, would alternate with STANAVFORMED, in the patrolling of the eastern Mediterranean.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Proposal B65 was put forward by the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs on 23 October 2001. The Government desired the Parliament’s consent to a naval contribution to Operation Active Endeavour, in compliance with Denmark’s NATO obligations when Article V was triggered after the 11 September attacks. According to the proposal, a Danish corvette with a smaller logistical element would join STANAVFORLANT. The proposal was adopted by Parliament two days later, with 101 votes in favour and 5 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Initially, the corvette Niels Juel was deployed to join STANAVFORLANT before taking part in STANAVFORMED’s missions in the eastern Mediterranean. She was part of this operation until 14 January 2002. In April 2002, Niels Juel’s role in Active Endeavour was taken over by the corvette Olfert Fischer, which provided the Danish contribution to the operation until July 2002. Both vessels were NIELS JUEL class corvettes, armed with a broad range of arms and munitions: anti-ship and surface to air missiles, a 76 mm cannon, depth charges and seven heavy machine guns. The standard crew for each ship numbered 90.
Two years later, in the spring of 2004, another Danish corvette of the same class took part in STANAVFORLANT. Peter Tordenskiold also became part of Operation Active Endeavour, while the NATO naval task force was still patrolling in the Mediterranean. During the same period, one of the Royal Danish Navy’s Lynx helicopters was also flying missions as part of the operation from German frigate Köln.
Denmark also contributed with a smaller team of staff officers, who set up a national logistical element at NATO’s Forward Logistics Site at the American naval base at Souda Bay on Crete. This would serve as a link between the Danish corvettes in the Mediterranean and the Royal Danish Navy’s Material Command in Copenhagen.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Niels Juel left Danish waters on 12 November 2001. Five days later, it arrived at Rota in Spain, where it met up with STANAVFORLANT. After a week of combined exercises, the full task force continued on to the Mediterranean to perform the mission that had been assigned to STANAVFORMED. On 14 January in the new year, the ship departed once again from STANAVFORLANT and arrived back at the naval base in Korsør on 29 January 2002.
It was later decided that the corvette Olfert Fischer would be deployed in the spring. After setting sail on 29 March 2002, the corvette arrived in the area of operations on 14 April, becoming part of Operation Active Endeavour on the eastern Mediterranean. The voyage home began on 9 June and she arrived back in Denmark on 15 July 2002.
Peter Tordenskiold joined STANAVFORLANT on 18 April 2004, then patrolling the Mediterranean as part of the naval task force. Almost a month later, on 14 May, the corvette had completed its mission and was on its way home. The Lynx helicopter’s mission lasted a little longer, in collaboration with a German frigate. It flew missions over the Mediterranean as part of the naval operation from 8 April to 24 May 2004.
Operation Active Endeavour began in 2001 and continued after the Danish corvettes had completed their missions. There were multiple other Danish contributions to the operation. This includes the participation in the operation over the years of patrol boats Viben, Ravnen and the submarine Sælen. It was decided at the end of 2016 that Operation Active Endeavour would be wound down in favour of Operation Sea Guardian, which no longer operates as an Article V operation.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The objective of Operation Active Endeavour was to manifest a presence and force in the war against terror by deploying a naval task force to the Mediterranean. The task force would patrol the area, monitoring and inspecting seaborne traffic. A particular requirement was to stop and inspect traffic that may be related to international terrorism, such as arms trafficking.
The three corvettes performed similar roles throughout the operation, despite being deployed at different times. After Niels Juel joined STANAVFORLANT, a number of joint exercises were performed before crossing the Straits of Gibraltar and entering the Mediterranean. Here, STANAVFORLANT divided into groups that alternated the various missions and rest periods where they were stationed at various Mediterranean ports. Niels Juel was part of a group that was initially tasked with carrying out patrol missions near the mouth of the Suez Canal in the Mediterranean. The operational area of the group then changed to the seas around Rhodes, where the Aegean meets the Mediterranean. In these two areas, all ships were hailed and required to present identification and route plans. Several ships were also boarded and inspected. This was an attempt to attain an overview of traffic sailing to and from the Mediterranean and would hopefully result in the apprehension of potential terrorists or arms traffickers.

missions.title: UNTAET East Timor
missions.subtitle: Independence for East Timor
missions.name: UNTAET Østtimor
missions.descriptiveName: UN Transitional Administration in East Timor

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When Indonesia accepted the result of the independence referendum in East Timor in October 1996, this new country slowly began a long transition period from being a region within Indonesia to being an independent nation. That period was characterised by challenges and problems. Large parts of the country had been ravaged by pro-Indonesian militias that after 1999 kept causing unrest in the border area near Indonesian West Timor. A great many East Timorese refugees needed humanitarian aid, and the population lacked any real experience with public administration. East Timor had yet to hold an election to install a legislative body that would create a constitution; hence no one held power. Moreover, the country lacked the resources for rebuilding.
The UN Security Council created the mission United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET), based in the capital city of Dili, to assist East Timor in this period of transition.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mission was set up by UN Security Council Resolution 1272 of 25 October 1999. The UN gave UNTAET an unusually detailed mandate. The mission had responsibility for the general administration of East Timor; in other words UNTAET was in reality an interim executive and legislative branch of government.
The mandate included six components: 1) Providing security and maintaining law and order in East Timor; 2) setting up an effective administrative apparatus; 3) assisting in the development of a civil service and social authorities; 4) managing the coordination and delivery of emergency aid, rebuilding assistance, and development assistance; 5) supporting capacity building toward East Timorese autonomy; and 6) assisting in the creation of the necessary preconditions for sustainable development.
UNTAET was divided into three administrative units: a) governance and public administration including a police department; b) humanitarian assistance and rebuilding following on emergency situations; c) a military department with up to 8,950 troops and 200 military observers.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Based on a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government decided that Denmark would participate.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark provided UNTAET with a total of 10 staff officers and military observers who initially were transferred from the earlier UNAMET and INTERFET missions. Subsequently, teams were sent on rotation from Denmark. In addition, Danish police school instructors took part in the police mission. This mission had such tasks as:
- Maintaining law and order in all of East Timor;
- Setting up a police force in East Timor and recruiting and training personnel; and
- Monitoring and seeing to the safe return of internally displaced persons and refugees.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
UNTAET was active from 25 October 1999 to 20 May 2002. As the UNTAET peacekeeping force had in practice assumed security related work from the INTERFET mission in February 2000, the situation in East Timor was relatively stable. That could not be said of the situation in the border area near Indonesia. The pro-Indonesian militia that had wreaked havoc in East Timor during the independence referendum was still carrying out cross-border attacks. The UN Security Council put pressure on Indonesia to work with the UN force in East Timor to contain the attacks and disarm the violent militia.
UNTAET thus was able to execute its mandate in a stable environment. A peaceful election for a legislative body to craft a constitution was held in 2001. Fretilin, the party declaring East Timor independent prior to the Indonesian invasion in 1975, won a decisive victory. The new national assembly, working closely with the UNTAET mission, crafted a constitution that took effect in February 2002. In the subsequent presidential election, former freedom fighter Xanana Gusmão won in a landslide. Upon his inauguration on 20 May 2002, East Timor became the first new country in the new millennium to proclaim independence. UNTAET had now fulfilled its mandate as a transitional governing body and therefore ended on that day.
UNTAET was replaced by United Nations Mission of Support to East Timor (UNMISET).

missions.title: OAE II Mediterranean
missions.subtitle: Submarine on Patrols
missions.name: Active Endeavour Middelhavet Sælen
missions.descriptiveName: Operation Active Endeavour - The Submarine Sælen

text.text: The Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs put forward proposal B109 to the Danish Parliament on 8 May 2002. As an extension of the Parliament’s decision of the previous year to sent the corvette Niels Juel to take part in Operation Active Endeavour, the Government wanted Parliament’s authorisation to also deploy the submarine Sælen, that had been requested by NATO to replace a Norwegian submarine. The proposal was adopted on 28 May 2002, with 93 votes in favour and 12 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish submarine Sælen was deployed to the area of operations in the eastern part of the Mediterranean and was based at Aksaz naval base on the south coast of Turkey. She was one of the three TUMLEREN class submarines that had originally been built in Germany for the Norwegian navy, from where they were sold to Denmark in 1990. Because of increased interest in the ability to deploy the submarine to international operations in warmer waters than those of the North Sea, Sælen was fitted with a cooling system in 2000. The main armament of the submarine was eight torpedoes. It was not expected that the torpedoes would be launched, however. The most important hardware for this operation was the submarine's sonar and electronic equipment that had been installed that could listen for communications and ship profiles in the area. The 24-strong crew of the submarine was replaced twice during its time with Operation Active Endeavour. A small-scale logistical support element was also deployed in Aksaz to maintain contact with the Royal Danish Navy's Material Command and other logistical support services.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Sælen sailed from the naval base in Frederikshavn on 10 June 2002 and arrived in the area of operations on 9 July, where it began its mission immediately. It was originally planned that the submarine would complete its missions on 8 December. This was postponed to 12 December. It did not sail straight back home afterwards. While the crew was preparing for the homeward voyage at the start of 2003, it received orders to sail instead to the Persian Gulf via the Suez Canal to provide a Royal Danish Navy presence in the area in preparation for the coming war against Iraq. A whole year would therefore go by after its departure before Sælen would return home.
Operation Active Endeavour began in 2001 and included the efforts of multiple other Danish contributions. This includes the participation in the operation over the years of patrol boats Viben, Ravnen and command ships Absalon and Esbern Snare. It was decided at the end of 2016 that the operation would be wound down in favour of Operation Sea Guardian, which no longer operates as an Article V operation.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The objective of Operation Active Endeavour was to manifest a presence and force in the war against terror by deploying a naval task force to the eastern Mediterranean. The task force would patrol the area, monitoring and inspecting seaborne traffic. A particular requirement was to locate, stop and inspect traffic that may be related to international terrorism, such as arms trafficking.
Sælen’s primary mission in the Mediterranean involved surveillance, early warning and gathering intelligence. As a submarine, Sælen could move around in the eastern Mediterranean without being detected, monitoring shipping and being able to communicate intelligence to the other NATO ships that were patrolling the area. A patrol typically lasted three weeks, followed by a week in port for maintenance and to give the crew a break from the confined conditions of the submarine. Life in the difficult and confined conditions of a submarine is demanding, both physically and mentally. The patrols produced results that were considered highly satisfactory by Danish and foreign commands and by the crew itself.
There were some problems with the cooling system, however, which failed in November. This led to a very poor indoor climate with high air humidity and temperatures exceeding 45 degrees Celsius (113 degrees Fahrenheit). Not only was this difficult for the crew, but it also damaged the sonar on the submarine that was now 38 years old. The planned patrol was completed, however, before the submarine returned to Aksaz naval base, where it was possible to repair the air conditioning system.

missions.title: OAE III Gibraltar
missions.subtitle: Task Force STROG
missions.name: Active Endeavour Middelhavet Viben & Ravnen
missions.descriptiveName: Operation Active Endeavour, Task Force STROG

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 11 September 2001, two passenger aircraft flew into the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York. A third flew into the Pentagon, headquarters of the U.S. Department of Defense. A fourth crashed in a field, in all probability while headed towards the White House. Almost 3,000 people were killed in these attacks, that shook the world out of the optimism of the 1990s after the end of the Cold War. Over the following days, it was revealed that 19 hijackers were responsible for the attacks, which had been planned by the Islamic Al-Qaeda terror network, led by Osama bin Laden. The organisation had been responsible for a number of attacks over the years leading up to the one on 11 September. Targets were Muslims that they considered kafir (heretics), and foreign nations that they believed had to much influence in the Islamic world. Their first attacks included bombing US embassies in Eastern Africa and an attack on an American destroyer, the USS COLE, off the coast of Yemen.
Shortly after the attack on the World Trade Center, President Bush declared an international war against terror. The primary goal of the war was to defeat Al-Qaeda and similar organisations, as well as the countries that were supporting them or allowing them to organise in their territory, as Afghanistan had been doing under the Taliban regime. A large number of initiatives were set in motion, including: increased authority for security services and wider international partnerships between the security agencies of various countries, an invasion of Afghanistan to overthrow the Taliban and destroy Al-Qaeda’s training bases there and naval operations on the Mediterranean to prevent the transportation of arms to terrorists and to protect international trade. Naval operations in the Atlantic were given the name Operation Active Endeavour (OAE).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council convened on multiple occasions during September 2001 and unanimously voted to adopt Resolutions 1368 and 1373 (2001). The resolutions were a confirmation that the UN considered this an international attack on the US and a thread to international peace and security. Accordingly the UN accepted the right of the US and its allies to independent and collective self defence and encouraged all UN member states to cooperate in bringing the culprits to justice and to oppose all organisations with links to international terrorism.
On 12 September, NATO’s supreme authority, the North Atlantic Council, decided that it, like the UN, considered the incident to be an international attack on the US and that it qualified the triggering of Article V of the North Atlantic Treaty, also known as the “all for one and one for all” musketeer oath. An attack on one member of NATO should be considered an attack on all NATO member states. The US NATO representative confirmed that the attack was carried out by Al-Qaeda. This was therefore an attack by an external power and the US invoked Article V. To date, this is the first and only time that this part of the treaty has been triggered.
Barely a month after the attack, NATO announced on 9 October that it would be deploying a naval task force in the east Mediterranean to combat international terrorism at sea. On 26 October, it was authorised by NATO’s military committee under the code name Operation Active Endeavour, that the Atlantic fleet’s standing naval forces, STANAVFORLANT, would alternate with STANAVFORMED, in the patrolling of the eastern Mediterranean.
It was decided at a NATO summit on 3 March 2003 that Operation Active Endeavour would be expanded to also include the Straits of Gibraltar. Task Force Straits of Gibraltar (STROG) would be set up to control the area and escort civilian shipping through the straits. These straits are very important to world trade and require ships to sail close to land. Because of this, an attack similar to the one on USS Cole a few years previously was feared.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The original legal basis, Proposal B65 was put forward by the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs on 23 October 2001. The Government desired the Parliament’s consent to a naval contribution to Operation Active Endeavour, in compliance with Denmark’s NATO obligations when Article V was triggered after the 11 September attacks. According to the proposal, a Danish corvette would join the STANAVFORLANT task force, together with a smaller logistical element. The proposal was adopted by Parliament two days later, with 101 votes in favour and 5 votes opposed.
After consultation with the Foreign Policy Committee, the Government decided on 4 March 2003 to deploy the corvette Olfert Fischer to the activities of Operation Active Endeavours near Gibraltar. Before its arrival, it was decided that the corvette would instead be sent to the Persian Gulf, where it would take part in the impending war against Iraq. After presenting the matter to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Government instead decided on 18 March to send two smaller vessels, Viben and Ravnen, to join Task Force STROG.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Two patrol boats, Viben and Ravnen, were deployed to the Straits of Gibraltar. After three months, the crews were replaced by crews from similar patrol boats. The boats were FLYVEFISKEN class patrol vessels, also known as Standard Flex 300. Using container modules, these can easily be modified to perform a wide variety of different mission types. For Operation Active Endeavour the vessels were kitted out as missile-armed combat boats, with a crew of 29.
A smaller national logistics element was set up at the Spanish Puntales naval base to support the activities of the two boats.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Viben and Ravnen departed on 28 March, arriving at Puntales naval base in Spain on 3 April, after which they took part in escort missions in the Straits of Gibraltar. After spending half a year in the area of operations, the voyage home to Denmark began on 30 September, finally arriving on 7 October.
Operation Active Endeavour began in 2001 and there were various other Danish contributions after this mission was over. Other vessels that had taken part in this operation over the years included the submarine Sælen and corvettes Niels Juel and Olfert Fischer. It was decided at the end of 2016 that Operation Active Endeavour would be wound down in favour of Operation Sea Guardian, which no longer operates as an Article V operation.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The primary role of Task Force STROG was maritime surveillance and to escort civilian vessels safely through the narrow straits between Africa and Europe. Based at the Spanish Puntales naval base close to Cadiz, Viben and Ravnen performed escort duties through the straits. Escort duties were performed as part of the multinational naval force, the Danish vessels carrying out their missions in collaboration with Norwegian and Spanish vessels.
NATO deemed that there was little threat on the open sea, but that ports and nearby waters were at greater threat from terrorism. The Straits of Gibraltar were deemed to be a choke point and were therefore given a higher threat rating than the open sea. The main threat was believed to be from smaller vessels or aircraft that might be loaded with explosives for rapid attack. Because this is an area of heavy sea traffic, there were many fishing and pleasure vessels which often sailed too close and had to be ordered away. It was therefore difficult to assess whether an approaching small craft was a potential hostile. All missions were therefore performed at full combat readiness, with weapons systems armed and crewed. No attacks were made on the patrol boats during the escort missions, however.

missions.title: RECLIB  Libya
missions.subtitle: Chemical Agents Out of Libya
missions.name: RECLIB Libyen
missions.descriptiveName: Recovery of Chemical Agents from Libya

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi had big ambitions for his country. He had a long track record of being an adversary of the West as he supported Palestinian resistance groups and is believed to have masterminded several terrorist attacks against Europe and the US during the 1970s and 1980s. As part of his plans to turn Libya into a superpower, he instigated a nuclear weapons project and the production of chemical weapons. Upon the collapse of the Soviet Union, Gaddafi however did seek to normalise relations with the West. Shortly after the fall of Saddam Hussein and the uproar over weapons of mass destruction, Libya in 2004 began to decommission its chemical weapons with support from the international Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW).
The production facilities and most of Libya’s chemical weapons had been destroyed by the time the Arab Spring began in early 2011. Unlike the developments in Tunisia and Egypt where government leaders resigned as a result of popular pressure and large demonstrations, Gaddafi remained and cracked down hard on the uprising. A civil war ensued for most of 2011. In the end, Gaddafi was ousted. The uprising received support from Operation Odyssey Dawn and Unified Protector. Danish fighter jets participated in this support.
Right after the fall of Gaddafi, Libya appeared relatively stable, with peaceful democratic elections for a congressional assembly to be set up in 2012 to craft a constitution and install a government. That was short lived. Subsequent to a 2014 election, many members of the previous congressional assembly refused to resign, and before long, Libya had two governments. Such a situation was not helped by the fact that the militias that had fought Gaddafi’s army were still armed and now declared loyalty to one or the other government unless, of course, they were loyal only to their own tribe. In this anarchy, several militias chose to proclaim themselves a part of the Islamic State and occupied several cities, Sirte and Derna among them

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
No one wanted the remaining chemical weapons to fall into the hands of the Islamic State or other such groups. The UN-supported national unity government therefore asked OPCW and the UN for assistance in getting the last of the chemical weapons out of the country.
On 22 July, the UN Security Council approved Resolution 2298 (2016). It stated that the Libyan chemical weapons had been assembled in a storage facility at the coast. The resolution provided a mandate for UN member countries to collect and destroy the weapons so that they would not fall into the hands of non-government players and thus turn into a threat against international peace and security.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: As Denmark had led the similar but much more extensive Operation RECSYR in 2014 (shipping chemical weapons out of Syria), OPCW and the US officially requested that Denmark assume leadership in the effort to ship chemical weapons out of Libya. On 15 August 2016, the Danish Minister of Defence therefore introduced proposal B197 with respect to a Danish contribution to RECLIB. The proposal was dealt with on an urgent basis and approved on 19 August by a Danish Parliament fully in favour (99 votes).

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contribution consisted primarily of two ships, the command and support ship Absalon and the chartered civilian ship Ark Futura. Absalon acted as the flagship from which the mission was directed by a Danish flotilla admiral and was part of the military escort to secure the chemical weapons during the transport. The civilian ship Ark Futura is a roll-on roll-off transport ship. While it is civilian, it is chartered by Denmark to serve in military transport projects, primarily for NATO forces. It handled the transport of the chemicals from Libya.
In total, the Danish contribution to the mission consisted of about 250 personnel. Over and above the regular ship crew, this number included chemical weapons specialists from Danish Defence Health Services and the Royal Danish Army, personnel from the Frogman Corps, and a helicopter with a crew from the Air Force. The Danish Emergency Management Agency contributed two experts from its chemicals unit plus special materials and sensor devices. In addition, a container scanner and associated operators were supplied by SKAT, the Danish Tax Authorities, to enable investigation of container contents without having to open them and risk exposure to the chemicals. Thus, the contribution was largely similar to RECSYR although smaller in scale.
On board Absalon was a team of Finnish staff officers, and the British ship RFA Mounts Bay participated as part of the escort.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Operation RECLIB was active from August to September 2016. Absalon set out from Denmark on 17 August, and the chemicals were collected on 27 August. They were delivered for destruction at a German facility in Bremen on 8 September.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission was to remove the remnants of Gaddafi’s chemical weapons stockpile. Libyan authorities and personnel from OPCW had already assembled the weapons in the port city of Misratah in northern Libya. The removal took but a single day, 27 August. As early as 5 am, contact was made with authorities on standby, and at 9 am, Ark Futura reached the port where local collaborators were ready to load the ship. Absalon and RFA Mounts Bay were ready close by in case of any trouble. A total of 23 containers filled with chemicals were loaded on board Ark Futura. Later that day, at 7 pm, she left Libyan waters. The convoy sailed from Misratah to Bremen in Germany where German police and emergency management personnel took delivery of the containers. During the entire journey, the containers were inspected daily by the Danish Emergency Management Agency and the specialists from Defence Denmark. The sensors had given a reading for some of the containers during the loading process. There were, however, no chemical leaks or any other risky situations during the transport.
