missions.title: RECSYR  Syria
missions.subtitle: Chemical Agents Out of Syria
missions.name: RECSYR Syrien
missions.descriptiveName: Removal of Chemical Agents from Syria

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Syrian civil war began as a continuation of the Arab Spring early in 2011. In Egypt and Tunisia, the governments had resigned, but Bashar al-Assad decided to crack down hard on the demonstrators. A chain reaction followed. The crackdowns led to even more protests that were in turn attacked even more violently, and before long the demonstrators carried arms. Army deserters had formed the Free Syrian Army and collaborated with other groups to mount resistance against the regime. The conflict evolved into a proxy war when a few NATO countries, Saudi Arabia, and their allies provided materiel and political support to the opposition while Russia, Iran, and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah actively supported the Assad regime.
When Gaddafi in Libya had crushed the rebellion in his country, a UN mandate was obtained, and a coalition was formed to protect civilians as a matter of priority. Over time, however, this developed into an air campaign in support of rebels agitating for democracy in the struggle against him. As the Syrian civil war spread and became more violent, there were frequent reports, some of them from the UN mission in the country, of attacks on civilians. There was widespread support for the notion that the international community ought to intervene militarily to protect civilians, put an end to the civil war, and possibly oust Assad and arraign him in a war crimes court. An international crisis was on the horizon when the West supported the rebellion while Russia supported the regime. Mostly as a result of Russia’s interests in Syria and its veto power in the UN Security Council, an international mandate for an intervention could not be obtained as it had been in the case of Libya. In light of experience from the long war in the neighbouring country Iraq and out of fear of an escalating conflict with Russia, there was no appetite in the US for intervening without a clear mandate. Nevertheless, President Barack Obama said in 2012 that extensive use of chemical weapons would change his mind about an intervention.
Reports came out several times that Obama’s “red line” on the use of chemical weapons had been crossed, and a year after it had been drawn, all doubt was gone. In the morning of 21 August 2013, rebel-controlled areas in Ghouta, a suburb of Damascus, were hit by rockets carrying the lethal nerve agent sarin. This was the most outrageous chemical weapons attack since the war between Iran and Iraq in the 1980s. In the following days, pictures of the several hundred victims went round the world. Reports from Doctors Without Borders and UN agencies confirmed that sarin was used – at a scale and with a method only the Syrian regime could muster. Assad and his Russian supporters doggedly insisted that the rebel groups themselves were responsible for the attack.

In early September, it thus looked plausible that an intervention would be made in Syria. While the West deliberated on who would take part and whether the scale of the intervention would be a massive one or a smaller one – in such a case just to make a statement that the use of chemical weapons is absolutely unacceptable – Obama requested approval from Congress to carry out an attack on Syria. The request was debated but never came to a vote because events got in the way. A journalist at a press conference asked U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry whether Assad in any way could avoid an American attack. He responded casually, seemingly half in jest, that the Syrian regime certainly might surrender all its chemical weapons for destruction by the international community, but that such a thing would of course never happen.
Many were surprised when Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov only hours later took Kerry at his word and proposed that Syria surrender all chemical weapons to an international group that would then destroy them. The Syrian government immediately accepted the proposal, and negotiations began as to how the surrender would proceed.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
On 14 September, Syria became a signatory to the Chemical Weapons Convention and thus committed to eliminating its chemical weapons and the associated facilities for development, manufacturing, etc. After intense negotiations, mostly between the US and Russia in the UN Security Council and with OPCW (Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons), an agreement was reached on 20 September as to the framework for the method and timing of the surrender of weapons. Shortly thereafter, on 27 September, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2118. It stipulated how the surrender was to proceed and provided a mandate for the UN and OPCW to inspect and destroy Syrian facilities and monitor the transport of chemical materials and for UN countries to jointly set up a mission to move them out of the country and destroy them. The biggest bone of contention in the UN Security Council negotiations had to do with consequences for Syria in the event it did not comply with the framework for the surrender of chemical weapons. The NATO countries in the UN Security Council pushed for an explicit statement that a direct military intervention would ensue from non-compliance, but Russia and China argued that a separate resolution could be passed later if it turned out that the agreement was being violated. The wording of the final agreement was vague, allowing for both interpretations.
In October, the Syrian government provided to OPCW a list of all its facilities for manufacturing and storing chemical weapons. UN and OPCW inspectors now began the process of identification and destruction of production facilities. The determination of the placement of the chemical weapons and creating an inventory with a view to transport and destruction was carried out. Simultaneously, work was being done to set up an international mission to remove, receive, and destroy the chemical weapons and such chemical materials as could easily be converted to use in weapons.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 6 September 2013, the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs submitted proposal B29 to Parliament. Based on a request from the UN, the government asked for parliamentary permission for Denmark to contribute maritime transport, escort, and mission leadership as well as a security team and air transport for the UN-OPCW inspection mission in Syria.
The proposal had strong backing in Parliament, and all parties expressed the opinion that Denmark ought to do its part to de-escalate the conflict in Syria, especially with respect to the use of chemical weapons, and to support work to establish a formal peace process.
Just one party had objections to the proposed security team inside Syria. It was feared that twenty or so Danish soldiers armed only with their service pistols would find themselves in an extremely dangerous situation in the midst of the civil war, their security depending on the Assad regime officially considered illegitimate by Denmark. This party made it clear that had the proposal been in two parts (it did not get divided that way), it would have been willing to vote for the maritime portion of the operation so long as Danish soldiers were not sent into Syria.
The proposal was approved on 19 December 2013. It received 97 votes in favour and 14 votes opposed. With this decision, Denmark became the lead nation in the operation to remove chemical weapons from Syria.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark was the most significant contributor to the mission and took on leadership and overall command. About 160 Danes worked throughout the RECSYR mission. Initially, the Navy sent the Danish command and support ship Esbern Snare. It provided escort and was the flagship from which the operation was managed. It then added the civilian ship Ark Futura, a roll-on roll-off transport ship. While it is civilian, it is chartered by Denmark to serve in military transport projects, primarily for NATO forces. Together with a Norwegian ship, it was to manage the transport of the chemical agents from Syria. A security team of 20 was assigned to the UN-OPCW inspectors working in Syria, and a C-130J Hercules transport plane was provided for any transportation of the inspectors. An army team of CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological or Nuclear) experts, Frogman Corps personnel, and two experts from the chemicals unit of the Danish Emergency Management Agency joined the mission. In addition, a mobile container scanner and associated specially trained operators were supplied by SKAT, the Danish Tax Authorities. This enabled investigation of the contents of surrendered containers without having to open them and risk exposure to the chemicals. All three of the armed forces, the Emergency Management Agency, and the Tax Authorities were represented in RECSYR, likely making it the most comprehensive dispatch of Danes in an international mission.
The commander of the Navy’s Danish Task Group had tactical leadership of RECSYR while the commander of the Admiral Danish Fleet had responsibility for the entire scope of the mission. This was the first time Denmark headed up an international operation of this scale. On 17 May 2014, the frigate Peter Willemoes took over the work of Esbern Snare when the command ship was transferred to the Standing NATO Maritime Group (SNMG-1) to participate in the Active Endeavour and Ocean Shield operations.
The total naval force in RECSYR was highly international with British, Chinese, Russian, and on occasion Syrian ships participating in the mission. An American ship with specialised equipment took delivery of the chemical weapons and destroyed them, some of the work being done in the UK and in Finland.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
For the UN and OPCW inspectors, work on the mission began in October 2013. The Danish contribution was approved by Parliament a little later, in December, and then the maritime portion of the mission, the transport of the chemical weapons, could start. The operation was officially launched by Denmark on 19 December, and the first chemical weapons left the Syrian port city of Latakia on board the Danish ship Ark Futura on 7 January 2014.
The original agreement signed by the US and Russia via OPCW and the UN stipulated that all chemical weapons must be out of Syria no later than 30 June. Though some discussion had addressed the feasibility of keeping to the timetable in light of how the conflict in Syria complicated the transport of chemical weapons to the coast, the mission was successfully completed within the deadline. The last collection of chemical agents from Latakia took place on 23 June 2014. On 11 July, Peter Willemoes arrived back in Denmark. The operation finally concluded on 20 July when the last delivery of chemicals arrived in Finland.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission was to transport chemical weapons from a Syria ravaged by civil war to places where they could be destroyed. The identification of the chemical weapons was performed by the UN and OPCW teams in Syria. The Syrian army handled transportation within Syria and preparations for shipping. The RECSYR mission was to receive the containers in the port of Latakia, verify their contents, and ship them to locations where they could be safely destroyed.
The Danish ships proceeded to Latakia from a base in Limassol on Cyprus to take the cargo on board. Here, the containers were examined by the container scanners of the Tax Authorities, Emergency Management, and the chemicals experts from the army before they were loaded on board the transport ships that were to deliver, under escort, the containers for destruction. The process of destruction varied in terms of place and method according to the type of chemicals. Many of the weapons were taken to Gioia Tauro, a port city in southern Italy, where the toxic chemicals were transferred to the American container ship MV Cape Ray. It carries equipment for hydrolytic breakdown of certain chemicals in the weapons. (Destruction was performed in international waters.) Chemicals that are more difficult to degrade were shipped to facilities in the UK and in Finland that had the expertise and facilities to carry out the task.
The first collection from Latakia took place on 7 January 2014. A total of 19 collections were performed, the final one on 23 June 2014. In all, 181 containers were collected by the two transport ships. The Norwegian ship Taiko collected mostly the ”less toxic” industrial chemicals that could be converted to use in chemical weapons while the Danish ship Ark Futura collected the chemical weapons and the five most toxic chemicals.
In spite of the difficulties encountered by the inspectors in Syria and the disruptions to the timetable for transporting chemicals to Latakia, the overall operation timeline was met. Much praise was given to the Danish contribution, and the collaboration with other participating nations was smooth. Later, Denmark took charge of a similar operation, RECLIB, whose task was to remove chemical weapons from Libya in 2016.
It has since come to light that not all chemical weapons were removed from Syria. There was swift criticism that the international agreement did not include chlorine. In addition to its industrial uses, it can be converted to chlorine gas. The civil war in Syria continued to flare unabated, with devastating human suffering in its wake. On 4 April 2017, the rebel-controlled town of Khan Shaykhoun was attacked by the Syrian air force. Chemical gases appearing to be sarin were used just as in the attack on Ghouta in 2013.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When the state of Israel was founded in 1948, it was immediately attacked by neighbouring Arab countries. When that war ended, Israel continued to be surrounded by hostile nations. The largest among them was Egypt. At the end of the war, it controlled Gaza City and a strip of land along the coast. The first UN observation mission, UNTSO, was initiated during the war. It took part in negotiating the ceasefire agreements between Israel and its neighbours. In spite of diligent efforts on the part of UNTSO, relations were tense, and ceasefire violations occurred frequently. Palestinian groups, especially, crossed the border from the neighbouring countries to carry out attacks inside Israel, often with the tacit consent of the Arab governments.

Losing the war to Israel was a blow to many in the Arab world, one that had repercussions especially in Egypt. Britain had been a colonial ruler in Egypt since 1882, and although the Egyptian king had been officially in charge of an independent nation since 1922, he served at its pleasure with limitations on his ability to act, in particular with respect to foreign policy, and with British troops stationed in Egypt. The British had military control of the area around the Suez Canal. This canal was crucial for the Empire as it provided the shortest possible route to the colonies in Asia.  After several years of protests against the king and the British, a group of officers carried out a coup in 1952 with popular support. The group forced the king into exile and turned Egypt into a republic.  The new government prioritised as one of its early objectives the disengagement from British influence. An agreement was reached whereby the British would leave Egypt after another two years of controlling the canal area.
Now that the British were on the way out of Egypt, two key challenges for the new regime was to modernise the country and to handle the conflict with Israel.  In the face of considerable international objection, the Egyptian government attempted to close the Suez Canal to block Israeli trade, and in 1953 it blocked the Straits of Tiran, Israel’s only access to the Red Sea. During this time, efforts were made to develop Egypt. One key project was a dam on the Nile to provide electricity for all of Egypt. The Aswan Dam needed expertise and money. Funding was sought from the U.S. in the form of a sizeable loan. Though the Americans were willing to provide this loan, they were not willing to sell arms to the Egyptian army in light of the continued conflict with Israel. When President Nasser then made the arms purchase through communist Czechoslovakia, the U.S. refused the loan. To raise funding, the Egyptian leaders now nationalised the Suez Canal. In 1956, it was still the property of European investors.

This met with disapproval in London and Paris. At a meeting in the town of Sèvres in France, the two old superpowers entered into a secret agreement with Tel Aviv. Prompted by the closure of the Straits of Tiran and the Suez Canal, Israel would attack Egypt on the Sinai Peninsula and advance toward the canal. This did occur on 29 October while Britain and France that very day issued an ultimatum for both parties to withdraw from the canal area so that it could be secured by a joint British and French force. Israel, still quite a distance from the canal, accepted the ultimatum as planned, but Egypt – having only recently gained control over the canal from Britain – refused.  On 31 October, the two European powers attacked Port Said at the Mediterranean mouth of the Suez Canal and occupied the area.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Prior to the attack by Britain and France in the morning of 31 October, UNTSO had requested that Israel withdraw and comply with the ceasefire established at the end of the war in 1948. That request was not met, and the matter came before the UN Security Council the same day. The U.S. and the Soviet Union both supported a resolution to have Israel withdraw per the UNTSO request. However, Britain and France vetoed the resolution, and no progress was made. At the instigation of Yugoslavia, the matter was transferred to an emergency special session of the UN General Assembly.
This was the first time such an emergency session of the General Assembly had been called. The Assembly met on 1 November and until 10 November approved a number of resolutions. The first one, Resolution 997, required Egypt, Israel, Britain, and France to cease all hostilities and withdraw troops from Egyptian territory. It further stipulated that vessels from all countries be permitted to sail in the Suez Canal and the Red Sea. On a request from Canada, Resolution 998 was approved. It charged Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjöld with preparing a plan for a UN security force to be set up and deployed for the purpose of separating the warring parties. When the plan was submitted to the Assembly, Resolutions 1000 and 1001 were approved. They authorised the chief of UNTSO to recruit personnel from UN member countries. In addition, the UN set up a committee to oversee and plan the work of the force. Given that four out of five members of the Security Council were either directly involved in or closely allied with one of the parties to the conflict, it was decided that the force would be made up of personnel from member countries that did not have a seat in the Security Council and had not actively taken a side in the conflict.

This is how UN Emergency Force UNEF, the first peacekeeping force set up by the UN, came into the world. It was directed by the then commander of UNTSO, the first observation mission operated by the UN. The mandate for the force was however quite narrow in comparison with later UN missions. According to the mandate, permission must be obtained from the country in which the force operated. Such permission was given only by Egypt. The force could not be armed with heavy weapons and could engage in active fighting only in self defence (and to a limited extent at that).

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The UN requested that Denmark provide soldiers for this international force working to separate the warring parties. The request was submitted to Denmark’s Foreign Policy Committee on 5 November 1956 while the UN General Assembly was still discussing the details. The Committee approved the request, and the very next day a proposal was introduced in Parliament by the Prime Minister and the Minister of Foreign Affairs.
Parliament approved, in the subsequent days, queries were sent to the soldiers in the 5th  Infantry Regiment (Vordingborg), the 7th  Regiment (Fredericia), and the Engineer Regiment as to their willingness to serve in the Middle East as part of UNEF. Denmark thus became a part of the first UN peacekeeping mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution to UNEF came from the army and was part of a joint Danish-Norwegian infantry battalion named DANOR numbering about 1,000 personnel. Soldiers with at least nine months of training in the military were asked to join.  Each was given the opportunity to decline if, say, a family or some other obligation made participation difficult.  Over 11,000 Danes served in DANOR while the mission was active. Teams were typically stationed in Gaza for six months at a time. In addition, 40 nurses served for a time at the UNEF hospital. The air force took care of getting supplies to the Danish soldiers in the mission.
The total international complement of UNEF was 6,000 at the beginning of the mission. Over the years, it was gradually reduced to 3,300 by the spring of 1967.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The first Danish soldiers arrived in Egypt in short order, on 15 November 1956. The mission carried on for 10 years until a new conflict began brewing in May 1967 between Israel and the neighbouring Arab countries. As the conflict became ever more serious, Egyptian President Nasser asked UNEF to leave Egyptian territory. The mandate from the UN General Assembly specified that the mission could operate only in areas where it had government permission to do so. Therefore, it was necessary to leave the positions in Egypt and Gaza. The Israeli government had never wanted the peacekeeping force to enter Israel, and UNEF was then declared at an end. The soldiers returned home.
Later, after another war between Israel and Egypt in October 1973, a second peacekeeping mission was set up in largely the same area and with the same guidelines. It was named UNEF II, and from this time onward, the earlier peacekeeping mission prior to 1967 was referred to as UNEF I. UNEF II was active until the summer of 1979 when Egypt’s President Anwar Sadat and Israel’s Prime Minister Menachem Begin entered into a lasting peace agreement that took the place of the ceasefire maintained by UNEF II.

Denmark did not contribute to UNEF II. Egypt objected to Danish participation in UNEF II when Denmark’s Prime Minister Anker Jørgensen on 5 November 1973 gave a speech in the town of Middelfart in which he stated that he would condone, to a considerable extent, the aggressive stance of Israel.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The primary task of UNEF I, the first peacekeeping mission, was to get in between the Egyptians, the British, the French, and the Israelis. The UN soldiers were to ensure, as much as possible, that hostile groups did not encounter each other but rather met only soldiers wearing the blue UN helmets. In the beginning, the main task was to handle the transfer of the areas along the Suez Canal from French and British troops to the Egyptian army. Then, it was Israel’s turn to be escorted out of the Sinai Peninsula. Thereafter, the job was to take over Gaza from Israel. As of spring 1957 when the last areas had been transferred, UNEF now went about monitoring and patrolling the long desert border between Egypt and Israel to prevent the two nations from engaging in conflict. As Israel was still not permitting UNEF to operate there, all the work took place on the Egyptian side of the border.

The first Danish soldiers arrived in Egypt on 15 November. During November 1956, the Danish force was deployed in British-occupied Port Said, a city situated where the Suez Canal meets the Mediterranean. The assignment was to move into the areas left behind by the British so that there would be no need for a direct transfer to the Egyptians. The situation in the city was tense, and British soldiers were frequently attacked by residents. But as soon as the British had left the area and UNEF had moved in, the situation improved.
Next, traversing the Mitla Pass and the Sinai desert while escorting the Israelis out, the Danes reached Gaza in March 1957. In the course of one week, 7 to 14 March, DANOR occupied Gaza City. Danish lieutenant colonel Carl Engholm held the position of military governor until an Egyptian governor arrived to assume command. A permanent base was now set up for DANOR east of the city on historic Hill 88 in a camp built by the British when they besieged Ottoman forces in Gaza during World War I. This base became the home of DANOR for the next 10 years. That is why UNEF Iis referred to in Denmark as the Gaza force. Then, the mission was to perform surveillance at the Israeli border and patrol the area.  The Danish soldiers were active especially in Gaza City and the areas to the north and east until the mission was terminated during the runup to a new conflict in 1967.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When popular uprisings against corruption and authoritarian dictatorships in the Arab world began in the winter of 2010-2011, many dubbed them “the Arab Spring”. After the resignations of the presidents in Tunisia and Egypt, many held the optimistic view that this wave of democratisation would spread to the entire region. At first, though, it did not appear to be reaching Syria. The Syrian regime under Bashar al-Assad was known for being one of the most brutal in the region. When bloggers called for demonstrations in Damascus in February, just as there had been demonstrations in Egypt, more security forces than demonstrators showed up.
Things got more serious in March 2011. In Daraa, a town in the south of Syria, some boys were arrested for having painted graffiti. Demonstrations quickly ensued. The army was called in. This violent crackdown led to further demonstrations demanding the ouster of the regime, and these were again attacked by the army. Protests spread throughout the country. During the spring and summer, the demonstrators took up arms and started firing back at the army. Army deserters joined the demonstrators.

During the summer of 2011, a government in exile was set up in neighbouring Turkey, and attempts were made to unify the various armed resistance groups in the Free Syrian Army. President Bashar al-Assad still claimed that his opponents were just Islamist terrorists and kept cracking down hard on any opposition. As the uprising grew, a civil war developed between the regime and the more or less unified rebel groups. Given that a similar recent situation had played out in Libya where a liberated city was besieged by the regime, the UN Security Council decided to provide a mandate for the international community to support the rebellion with air power. However, President Putin used Russia’s veto power in the UN Security Council to block an intervention in Syria. Russia had long been allied with the Assad regime and depended on a naval base in Syria for its activities in the Middle East.

By spring 2012, a year after the start of the conflict, things kept escalating. Tens of thousands had died in the violent battles in old cities such as Damascus and Aleppo and in smaller towns. There were reports of attacks on civilians; each side in the conflict blamed them on the other side. The number of civil war refugees in the neighbouring countries was nearing half a million, and the number grew at an alarming rate with internally displaced people trying to get away from areas of heavy fighting.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN and the Arab League jointly selected former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan to be their special envoy for negotiating peace and, it was hoped, end the civil war. In early April 2012, he believed there was consent from the Syrian regime and its opponents to enter into a ceasefire and attempt to implement a six-point peace plan he was recommending. With that, the UN Security Council approved Resolution 2043 on 21 April. It called for peace and compliance with Kofi Annan’s six-point peace plan, and in addition it provided a mandate for the establishment of an observation mission named United Nations Supervision Mission In Syria (UNSMIS). The purpose here was not to intervene directly to end the conflict but rather to send 300 unarmed officers from UN member countries to watch compliance with the ceasefire and determine who was responsible for breaches. The original mandate covered 90 days with the option for an extension. It was the intent that government forces, the Free Syrian Army, and other armed groups would recognise the mission and thus guarantee the safety of the observers and their freedom of movement.

On 20 July, it was decided, in Resolution 2059, to extend the mandate for another 30 days and to restructure the mission. The UN hoped for a greater focus on civilian projects and therefore cut in half the number of observers, to 150.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon request from the UN, the Danish government decided that Denmark would participate. The Minister of Foreign Affairs stated that this decision had been made without hesitation given that Denmark had long been working, through the UN, on finding a solution to the conflict. Work began to prepare Danish soldiers for their deployment to Syria as observers, and the UN was given permission to transfer the Danish officers already present in the region as part of United Nations Truce Supervision Organization (UNTSO).

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Ten Danish officers were dispatched to take part in UNSMIS. In the end it included 278 military observers and 121 civilian employees. Forty-two countries participated, including France, Russia (openly supporting several parties to the conflict), and several Arab countries such as Egypt (having recently experienced a revolution itself) and Morocco (having the previous year succeeded in quelling demonstrations by promising reforms). The purpose of the wide participation was to ensure, to the extent possible, an objective description of a conflict that very much divided the international community. Some of the observers were transferred from UNTSO, a mission that had already been present in the region since the first Arab-Israeli war in 1948. They were therefore familiar with local conditions, and as they were close by, they were able to begin their work in UNSMIS very quickly.

After a restructuring of the mission on 20 July to increase civilian engagement, five of the ten Danish officers returned to Denmark.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The mandate became effective upon approval of Resolution 2043 on 21 April 2012, and the observers began arriving from the various nations in the following weeks. The Danish observers joined the UN force on 27 May. By 30 May, the mission was fully staffed and had set up eight observation posts in Syria. This marked the fastest rollout of a UN mission in history.

When the mission was restructured on 20 July, half of the Danish soldiers were recalled to Denmark. At the same time, the mandate was extended by 30 days until 19 August 2012. As it turned out that the fighting continued and in fact got worse in terms of intensity as the summer wore on, the UN view was that there was no ceasefire to monitor. Moreover, it was now difficult to provide protection for the unarmed observers. The mandate therefore was not extended further, and the mission was terminated on 19 August 2012. On request from the UN, one Danish officer remained in Damascus along with a few other members of the mission so that they could share their experience for the purpose of setting up a UN Liaison Office.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The primary task for the observers in UNSMIS was to watch whether the ceasefire was being respected by all parties and whether Kofi Annan’s peace plan was being implemented. In addition, there was a desire to check whether the many reports of attacks on civilians were factual. It was hoped that the continued fighting would stop when UNSMISwas on patrol in the vicinity.
The mission was headquartered in Damascus and in eight observation posts in larger towns in Syria, allowing for wide patrol coverage and quick action. Observers depended heavily on contacts within the government army and within the rebel groups for mobility around the country. On several occasions, the observers were unable to carry out inspections, primarily for reasons of personal security but also because the army and various rebel groups blocked access.

The UNSMIS was constrained due to increasing difficulty and risk. As the armed clashes became more frequent and more intense over the summer, it was decided in June to suspend the mission temporarily for two weeks. The mission was then restructured, and the observation posts spread throughout the country were consolidated into fewer but more secure posts. On 20 July it was decided to extend the mission by 30 days and then to terminate it if there were not an effort by all parties to the war to end the fighting. As this effort was not forthcoming and the war in fact continued to escalate, the mission was terminated on 19 August 2012.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At the end of the Cold War, a revolution took place in Albania that made it difficult for the former communist state to maintain public order. 1991 saw the relaxation of various restrictions and a number of laws, one of the results being that the Albanian population was now permitted to own land. During a period of political transformation with shifts back and forth in the following years, unemployment rates began to increase in Albania. Simultaneously, Albania’s Greek minority population found itself in conflict with ethnic Albanians. The Albanian economy collapsed in 1996-97, including when popular “Ponzi schemes” were no longer able to pay out dividends. Many people lost millions. In 1997, there was a state of unrest in the country. The Albanian government lost control and its mandate disappeared. Albania was in a state of anarchy. The authorities no longer controlled Albanian military arms depots and these were looted by various factions. Albania was now in a state of national emergency and, in response, OSCE (Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, then under Danish chairmanship) set up Operation Alba in accordance with a UN mandate in 1997. The process of re-establishing order and bringing about a return to stability could now commence. In 1997, Denmark provided support by deploying troops under the command of Albanian Force Multinationale Protectione (AMFP).

The WEU was also involved when it was decided that a policing mission would be deployed. This was known as Western European Union Multinational Advisory Element in Albania (WEU/MAPE).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Many stakeholders were involved. On 15 March 1997, Italy and Albania requested an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council. The EU informed on 17 March that it was not willing to send military aid, but that it would concentrate on the provision of humanitarian aid. On 20 March, OSCE adopted a decision to provide aid to Albania but did not consider humanitarian aid to be the solution,. A week later on 27 March, OSCE approved the commencement of a permanent mission in Albania and the creation of an international force.

The following day, on 28 March 1997, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1101, which authorised the deployment of a limited temporary multinational protective force in Albania. This force would be led by Italy and was composed as a “Coalition of the Willing”. The UN mandate authorised this force to operate in accordance with chapter VII of the UN treaty, which meant that the force was authorised to used force if necessary. On 2 May 1997, Western European Unions (WEU) decided to deploy a policing mission, as described in the WEU’s Paris Declaration of 13 May 1997.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision that Danish troops would be available to a multinational security force was thus on the basis of a number of international decisions, including UN decisions. The Danish Government prioritised that the unit’s mission would be to safeguard the provision of humanitarian aid to badly affected areas in Albania. The Danish contribution was put before Parliament on 16 April 1997 as Proposal B123 and adopted on 2 May 1997, with 89 votes in favour and 20 opposed. The unit from Bornholm departed for Albania the following day. Later, after a WEU request for personnel to take part in a policing mission, the Government decided to deploy Danish police officers.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish AMFP force was 61 persons who arrived in the area on 7 May.  The unit’s primary mission was escort and guard duties, including the safeguarding of humanitarian aid. A number of Danish police officers also took part in the WEU policing mission in Albania.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: OSCE has operated in Albania since April 1997 and continues to do so in the present day and is still active in Albania. The Danish troops operated from May 1997 to the end of that July. The WEU/OSCE policing mission was launched on 15 May 1997 and wound down in August 2002.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission in Albania was performed by the reconnaissance unit from Bornholm. The unit served in a French battalion under the multinational AFMP force that was under Italian command. The Danes would ensure the safe delivery of humanitarian aid and assist in the establishment of safe conditions for the work of the international organisations in Albania.  The unit was equipped with wheeled armoured vehicles and personal protective equipment, which was all of the same type and standard as that used by the Danish forces in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The Danes worked alongside units from Italy, France, Greece, Romania, Spain, Turkey and Austria. The combined forces totalled approximately 6,500 soldiers who jointly prevented the escalation of the crisis in Albania into a full-on civil war.

The policing mission was primarily to provide advisory services with regard to public order, border controls and logistics. From 12 October 1997, the mission would also provide training for police officers and monitor and inspect police organisation, with particular regard to the impending local government elections on 18 and 19 June 1998.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Combined Task Force 150 (CTF-150) is a multinational coalition under the authority of the naval headquarters in Bahrain. This is the naval component of the American-led Operation Enduring Freedom, that was launched immediately after the 11 September 2001 attacks on the USA. Before 11 September, CTF-150 was part of the United States Naval Forces Central Command, which was tasked with patrolling the Red Sea, the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea.  In 2002, command of CTF-150 was transferred from the United States Naval Forces Central Command to Germany. The task of CTF-150 changed from patrolling the Red Sea, the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea to preventing seaborne terrorism by inspecting, stopping and checking suspicious vessels. This new mission would be performed at the Horn of Africa as a result of an increase in piracy in the area. Additional to preventing piracy and terrorism, CTF-150 was given the task of supporting the ability of the regional coastal states to maintain their own maritime security in the area.  A Danish contribution in 2008 which involved the command/support ship Absalon and the Royal Danish Navy’s Tactical Staff was incorporated into CTF-150. The Danish Staff was also assigned command of the combined force at this time. Command of CTF-150 alternates between the participating countries approximately every 4 -6 months. Countries which have led CTF-150 include Spain, the United Kingdom, France and Pakistan.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: CTF-150 was part of the framework of the American-led coalition that had been set up on the basis of Operation Enduring Freedom. The basis for this in international law was UN Security Resolutions 1368 and 1373 from 2001. Security Council resolutions 1814 and, not least, 1816 made it possible for forces in this area to operate within Somalian territorial waters. These resolutions set up mandates that had the general aim of reducing extremism and terrorism, which was a major area of focus after 11 September 2001.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision to join CTF-150 was adopted by the Danish Parliament. Denmark’s reason for doing so was that, because Denmark is also a seafaring nation, it also had an interest in combating piracy and terrorism so that trade shipping and vessels carrying humanitarian aid could sail in the Horn of Africa. The contribution was performed by command/support ship Absalon and its crew and by the Royal Danish Navy Tactical Staff. Specialists from the Royal Danish Navy’s frogman corps also took part. The Parliamentary proposal (B 33) was presented on 24 January 2008 and adopted with a majority of 103 to 2.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark contributed by deploying the command/support ship Absalon with its 100-strong crew. A Lynx helicopter and specialists from the Frogman Corps were also deployed. Danish officers joined the coalition headquarters in Bahrain and the approximately 40-strong Royal Danish Navy Tactical Staff took command of CTF-150. The Royal Danish Air Force also participated by deploying surveillance aircraft in 2017. Staff officers are still (2022) deployed to the HQ/Combined Maritime Forces.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: CTF-150 has operated at the Horn of Africa since 2002 and is still active. Even though CTF-150 commenced under the American-led Operation Enduring Freedom, that was active from 7 October to 28 December 2014, CTF would continue under Combined Maritime Forces (CMF) leadership. CTF-150 continued with other operations at the Gulf of Aden as Focused Operation “Sea Watch”, where the force helped to rescue boat refugees from sinking rubber craft off the Horn of Africa, an operation that began soon after Pakistan assumed command in 2017. In addition to operation Sea Watch, CTF-150 is also patrolling the seaway in the Gulf of Aden, known as ”Maritime Security Transit Corridor” (MSTC). The seaway was set up in the beginning of September 2017, for the purpose of allowing freight vessels to sail with guaranteed international protection. Denmark contributed to CTF-150 with Absalon from 28 August 2008 to the beginning of February 2009. The Royal Danish Navy’s Tactical Staff was in command of CTF-150 from 15 September 2008 to January 2009.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Absalon and its crew had many tasks: as a command platform for CTF-150, as part of the task force with duties such as surveillance, escort duties and combating all aspects of piracy. This was done by running daily sea and air patrols off the Horn of Africa. One major element of this mission involved boarding operations, including the deployment of the Frogman Corps. The Corps could be quickly and effectively deployed to the pirate vessels, where they could ensure the arrest of the pirates and the confiscation of their weapons. From Absalon, the Royal Danish Navy’s Tactical Staff was in command of CTF-150 and planned, coordinated and deployed ships from the multinational task force.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Combined Task Force 151 (CTF-151) is one of three forces operating as part of Combined Maritime Forces (CMF). CMF is a naval partnership involving 32 countries, including Denmark. Its role is to prevent maritime piracy and to work alongside local authorities in regions where piracy is a problem. CMF has been in action off the Horn of Africa, where Denmark has contributed on multiple occasions to dealing with piracy in the Gulf of Aden. CTF-151’s background came from the civil war in Somalia in the year 2000, which made it possible for foreign boats to exploit fisheries resources in the Gulf of Aden with no serious consequences. This led to locals deciding that it was a risk-free enterprise to sail out and abduct foreign fishermen and then demand the payment of a ransom. CTF-151 was set up in January 2009 to combat this problem, with a mandate that was specifically focused on a general prevention of piracy in the Gulf of Aden.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: CTF-151 works in accordance with several different mandates. These mandates state that if counterpiracy measures are to be effective a unit would have to be set up to focus on this issue. The creation and duties of CTF-151 are based on UN Security Council Resolutions 1816, 1838, 1846, 1851 and 1897. Except for 1897 (which was adopted in 2009) all these resolutions were adopted in 2008. Resolution 2316 of November 2016 was the basis for an updated mandate, stressing that counterpiracy operations are still a necessity off the coast of Somalia and in the Gulf of Aden. Even though the piracy problem was reduced since 2011, naval units were still required in the area to protect trade shipping.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
It was decided in 2009 that Royal Danish Navy ship Absalon would be transferred from CTF-150 to CTF-151, as Denmark also wanted to make a contribution towards fighting piracy in this region. The decision to assume command of CTF-151 in 2012 and the 2013 decision to deploy Danish naval vessels to the Gulf of Aden in 2014 were both based on the Danish Government’s anti-piracy strategy. Denmark's areas of focus were defined in a document titled “Strategy for the Danish counter-piracy effort 2011-2014”:

- combating pirates through periodic deployment of a naval contribution and a maritime patrol aircraft,
- identifying practical solutions to the legal challenges posed by counterpiracy efforts,
- promoting international coordination and focus on counter-piracy efforts, as well as strengthening regional and bilateral cooperation on counter-piracy efforts,
- building capacities in order to enable the countries in the region to take on the challenges by themselves in the longer term, including support for the creation of coastguard functions in the region, as well as prison capacity in Somaliland and Puntland,
- enhancing the international effort to target those backing the pirates, including initiatives to counter money laundering.

These points of focus were necessary because of the increased global threat from piracy and armed robbery at sea. As a seafaring nation, Denmark felt that it had a particular responsibility.  The overall purpose of this strategy was to contribute towards increased safety for international shipping in waters where global trade had significant maritime interests. Since 2008, Denmark had also been a member of an international contact group that had been set up by the UN. This group was comprised of a smaller group of countries that were being impacted and had the purpose of coordinating counterpiracy initiatives off the coast of Somalia.  In this context, Denmark assumed the chairmanship of a working group that dealt with legal issues, with particular focus on clarifying the legal basis for the arrest, handover and prosecution of pirates.

When proposal B 104 was put forward on 23 January 2024 by the Danish Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Danish Parliament decided to deploy a staff officer with a view to joining the offensive coalition against the Houthi movement's repeated attacks in and around the Red Sea since November 2023. The aim of the proposal is to reduce the Houthi movement's ability to threaten maritime security in the area. The proposal was approved with 90 votes in favour, 15 votes against and two votes undecided.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark has contributed by deploying the command/support ship Absalon and has twice deployed the Royal Danish Navy Tactical Staff to command CTF-151. A boarding team from the Frogman Corps was also deployed on Absalon. This command mission was in collaboration with personnel from countries such as New Zealand, Jordan, South Korea, Japan, the USA and Saudi Arabia. Since 2017 Denmark also send staff officers to CTF-151 and to CMF (Combined Maritime Forces). Latest in 2024 with officers to Operation Prosperity Guardian. 

Operation Prosperity Guardian is dedicated to improving the security and stability of shipping in the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden area, which is an area that was threatened by missile and drone attacks in 2023 that targeted civilian shipping off the coast of Yemen. The military actions were carried out by the United States and the United Kingdom. Australia, Bahrain, Canada and the Netherlands have contributed to this coalition in support capacities.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: CTF-151 was created on 12 January 2009 and is still active. The Danish ship Absalon took part from January-April 2009. The Royal Danish Navy Tactical Staff, aboard an American ship, assumed command of the naval task force for the period January-April 2012 and again from December 2013 to February 2014. Danish staff officers have been posted from November 2017.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission of the good ship Absalon was to patrol the Gulf of Aden and waters off the coast of Somalia, where it would report incidents of piracy and take counter measures if necessary. The ship and its crew would actively attempt to intervene in attempts to hijack trading ships and vessels carrying humanitarian aid. The task of the Royal Danish Navy’s Tactical Staff was the everyday operational command of CTF-151. In 2012, command was based on the American destroyer USS Halsey. In 2013-2014, command was based at CMF’s headquarters in Bahrain. Another mission for the task force was to assist coastal states in establishing the right conditions and basis for them to be responsible for their own maritime security and the protection of large volume of trade shipping. This was attempted in the form of the daily exchange of information and the planning of exercises and smaller-scale operations with local naval forces. The task of the Danish officer who was posted with CTF-151 until March 2018 was to command and coordinate counterpiracy intelligence measures.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The former French colony of Mali is in western Africa. Mali has long been plagued by issues such as corruption, human rights violations, rebellions and weak government. Internal conflicts led to certain military factions working towards independence for northern Mali. One such group is the National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad(MNLA). This group believed that Azawad in the northern region of Mali should be independent and conducted several attacks in the region, assisted by Al-Qaeda and others. These attacks drove Mali’s military out of Azawad and MNLA took control of the region and unofficially declared independence. Elements of Mali’s army were dissatisfied that Mali’s government had been unable to control unrest in Azawad and therefore carried out a coup d’état against Mali’s government. Unrest led to MNLA being able to gain full control of Azawad quicker than would otherwise have been the case. In 2013 the MNLA then tried to gain more territory in addition to Azawad, and the UN’s special representative to West Africa asked the UN to support Mali’s government authorities in the prevention of a humanitarian catastrophe in the country. The rebel groups were defeated in 2013 with assistance from the UN, the French army, Mali’s army and the African-led International Support Mission to Mali (AFISMA). Although control had been regained over large areas of Mali, terror actions continued, and the country was badly affected by unrest.  It was necessary for the UN to maintain a presence in Mali and the global community launched a peacekeeping operation in Mali in 2013, with a view to stamping out unrest in the country and helping Mali’s authorities to re-establish the country.

Mali is just one country where the international community wants to see stability. The entire Sahel region, which is comprised of: Burkina Fasco, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal and Sudan, constitutes an overall area to the south of the Sahara in which the security situation is a cause for concern because of the presence of terrorist such as Islamic State and Al-Qaeda. The region is broadly considered an area immediately adjacent to southern Europe. The security situation in the Sahel region is characterised by violent conflicts and the widespread presence of militant Islamist groups.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate for the UN’s MINUSMA operation lies in UN Security Council Resolution 2100 of 25 April 2013. The mandate’s overall purpose was to support the political process in Mali and to perform security-related tasks, including monitoring the ceasefire between the opposing sides.
Prior to Resolution 2100, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2085 in December 2012, establishing the framework for Operation Serval in Mali, which was mainly comprised of French contributions. In 2019 the Resolution 2480 stated the future mission which continued.
After the decision in UN Security Counsel by 30 June 2023 the mission will terminate by december 2023 after decision by the Mali government.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
After being contacted by the UN, a unanimous Danish Parliament agreed to contribute a C-130 transport aircraft and staff officers to MINUSMA. Danish Parliamentary Decision B28 was adopted on 19 December 2013 with 106 votes.
Another proposal for Danish participation was adopted on 17 November 2015. The decision included the deployment of a C-130 transport aircraft, a contribution of approx. 60 personnel and the option to increase the staff officer contribution that had already been deployed. It was also decided that an up to 30-strong force from the elite Jaeger Corps would be contributed. The proposal also stated that “the chief commissioner of the Danish National Police intended to deploy up to 12 police officers to MINUSMA”. The proposal was adopted with 74 votes in favour and 35 votes against.
After a French request in 2019, followed by consultation with the Danish Foreign Policy Committee and parliamentary authorisation (B7) on 24 October, it was decided that, for a six months period starting at the end of 2019, two transport helicopters including approx. 70 personnel would be deployed to the mission in the Sahal region as a military contribution to the anti-terrorism Operation Barkhader, under French command. Proposal B6 was passed at the same time, concerning a further six months renewal of the deployment of a C-130 transport aircraft and 65 personnel.

In resolution B 297, the Danish Government requested the consent of the Danish Parliament to deploy Danish military contributions in support of Operation Barkhane; notably Task Force Takuba in the Sahel region. The proposal was adopted on 25 May 2021. 83 votes were in favour of the proposal. 12 votes opposed it. There were no abstentions.
Task Force Takuba was a unique construction, which involved the successful creation of a European special operations force that ended up numbering approximately 1,000 soldiers from 11 European countries, with helicopters, specialist vehicles and other advanced hardware.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contribution in the area began in 2013, with the deployment of a transport aircraft to the French-led Operation Serval, which was a precursor in 2012-2014 for subsequent missions.
21 personnel were deployed in 2014 to the “All Sources Information Fusion Unit”
A Danish Major-General was MINUSMA’s Force Commander from March 2015 to December 2016.
Denmark contributed the same team as in 2014 from April to December 2016, accompanied by a special forces contribution to the mission in Mali which involved approx. 30 personnel. This contribution was comprised of personnel from the Jaeger Corps, supported by army logistics and intelligence personnel. The special forces contribution was part of a corresponding Dutch special forces contribution, operating in the Gao province in northern Mali.
In November 2017, Denmark's total contribution to MINUSMA numbered approx. 230 personnel, including half a dozen police officers who were involved in a collaboration with officers from 25 countries.
From the very beginning of the operations in Mali, Denmark had provided an ongoing contribution of personnel and materials, including staff officers, C-130 Hercules transport aircraft and crew, support and guard personnel (approx. 60 personnel) and guard personnel from the Danish Home Guard.
The Danish Government declared a statement of intent to redeploy a transport aircraft to MINUSMA, as an agreement had been concluded with Belgium, Norway and Portugal in November 2017 to extend the existing rotation of transport aircraft until November 2020.

In Operation Barkhane (in the Sahel region) Denmark provided a helicopter contribution to accompany approx. 4,500 French troops, a helicopter contribution from the United Kingdom and a guard unit from Estonia. The Danish military contribution in Barkhane should be seen as part of a more long-term development aid contribution in Mali, Niger and elsewhere to better enable those countries to take care of their own security, including with regard to challenges related to terrorism, migration and crime.

The Danish contribution adopted ( B 297) on 25 May 2021 was comprised of a special forces contribution, a team of surgeons, staff, a national logistical support element and the deployment of the Danish cyber capacity. 
The special forces contribution was approx. 60 personnel. The contribution can be temporarily increased by up to approx. 20 personnel. The team of surgeons was up to approx. 12 personnel. A staff contribution would also be able to be deployed to the region and would be comprised of up to approx. three personnel. A national support element of up to approx. 10 personnel was deployed.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Denmark has been involved in Mali since 2013, including contributions to the French-led contributions. The UN MINUSMA operation remains active and has been so since 25 April 2013. Danish contribution to Operation Barkhane was from end 2019 and one year.
Later (in 2021) the Danish contribution to Operation Barkhane is deployed until 2023. The special forces contribution will be stationed in the region for approx. 12 months, starting in around January 2022. The team of surgeons will be stationed in the region for approx. six months during 2022. A staff contribution would  be deployed to the region from mid-2021 to early 2023. A national support element will be deployed to Mali and possibly Niger from the end of 2021 to the beginning of 2023.
The Special Operations Force contribution was planned to be deployed for about 12 months from around January 2022. The surgeon team was to be deployed for about 6 months. A staff contribution of up to about three people was deployed from mid-2021 and was scheduled to last until early 2023, and for logistical support a national support element was deployed from the end of 2021 to the planned beginning of 2023 to Mali and possibly Niger. 

Just before command of the special operation force was transferred to Task Force Takuba, Mali’s transitional government (a military junta that had seized power during a military coup in August 2020 and again in May 2021) protested against the Danish presence in the task force and demanded that Denmark recall its contribution to the special force.
The recall was set in motion immediately afterwards.
Mali’s rejection of the Danish contribution to Task Force Takuba was not unique and its claims that there was no basis for the contribution were groundless. Other European countries were harassed or refused access. Mali was boycotted by the African Union and flight permits in Mali became problematic. The relationship between Mali and France deteriorated gradually, partly because the military junta began to work together with the Russian Wagner Group.  This turned into a diplomatic crisis that led to the recall of Task Force Takuba in its entirety and the withdrawal of all French units from Operation Barkhane from Mali in the middle of August 2022.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Staff officers: The Danish staff officers are responsible for planning, gathering, processing and disseminating operational and tactical intelligence to MINUSMA (which has headquarters in Bamako).
C-130 Hercules transport aircraft: The aircraft’s mission is to transport passengers and cargo and to evacuate the sick and wounded from Mali’s various regions.
EH-101 helikopters deal with transport of equipment and forces as part of Operation Barkhane.
Special forces: The unit’s tasks generally involve gathering intelligence, including from patrols, surveillance missions, and area analysis, as well as other activities such as dealing with direct attacks or threats.  The Danish special forces unit was part of a Dutch ”Special Operations Task Group” in the Gao region.
Home Guard: The deployed home guard were responsible for the surveillance and security of the Danish bases: Camp Bifrost and Camp Midgaard.
Police: Support for national and international attempts to rebuild Mali’s security sector, as well as helping with the rebuilding of Mali’s police and gendarme forces by providing technical assistance, building capacity, joint initiatives and mentor programmes.
The Danish military contributions from 2021 will carry out activities within the framework of Operation Barkhane, including Task Force Takuba, which includes the use of offensive force. The contributions is mandated to use force in self-defence and to protect other forces operating as part of Operation Barkhane, as well as to protect defence and security forces from Mali and Niger, including Malian partner units, and MINUSMA forces. The area of operation is expected to be the Mali and Liptako-Gourma region on the border between Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso, and may also include other parts of Niger and Burkina Faso.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Operation Ocean Shield (OOS) was a NATO operation to combat piracy off the Horn of Africa to ensure unhindered and safe passage for merchant ships and similar vessels. People living in the Horn of Africa had taken to using piracy as a source of income, and for some years the extent of the problem had steadily become more serious. As a result, merchant ships and ships carrying humanitarian supplies were hijacked, and their crew members were taken hostage. In 2008, the EU therefore sent a request to NATO for assistance in fighting piracy. NATO approved this request and became active in the area as of 2009. In OOS, Denmark has participated by providing the command and support ships Absalon and Esbern Snare, the frigate Iver Huitfeldt, helicopters, and surveillance aircraft. OOS is regarded as a success because the number of pirates near the Horn of Africa has dropped significantly since the inception of the operation in 2009. Denmark took part in the operation along with 12 other NATO countries and 17 countries that are not members of NATO.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: NATO’s Operation Ocean Shield is based on UN Security Council Resolutions 1816, 1838, and 1846. These mandates were intended to provide a constant presence of ships to protect merchant vessels and to form the basis for the protection of the World Food Programme convoys carrying humanitarian aid destined for Sudan and Somalia. In particular, Resolution 1816 was important for Operation Ocean Shield as the mandate stated that all necessary means were to be used to fight piracy at sea. Resolution 1816 is dated 2 June 2008; Resolution 1838 is dated 7 October 2008; and Resolution 1846 is dated 2 December 2008.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish Parliament unanimously approved a military contribution under the auspices of NATO. The motivation was that Denmark, as a seafaring nation, desired improved maritime safety given that shipping lanes in the area near the Horn of Africa are among the busiest in international maritime trade. Proposal B59 was approved on 17 December 2009 with 102 votes in favour.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: During OOS, Denmark started by sending the commando and support ship Absalon. In addition, the contribution included a Lynx helicopter, a maritime intervention unit, a national logistical unit, and staff management for a total of 180 persons. Subsequently the sister ship Esbern Snare was dispatched (approximately 150 crew members), followed by the frigate Iver Huitfeldt with about 100 crew members. All three ships carried ship boarding teams from the Frogman Corps. The Air Force has participated with Challenger aircraft in surveillance of large parts of the ocean area. The Danes took part in OOS along with 29 other countries such as Holland, the UK, and Norway.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
OOS was active from 17 August 2009 until 24 November 2016. Denmark took part from January 2010 to 23 November 2016. Other missions in the Gulf of Aden have had participation from Denmark since 2008. As an example, Denmark from January to April 2008 supplied the inspection ship Thetis to NATO’s Operation Allied Provider whose purpose was to escort World Food Programme ships carrying emergency aid to Somalia. In addition, Denmark took part in Combined Task Force 150 (CTF 150) as of 28 August 2008 until early February 2009 and in the US-led Combined Task Force 151 (CTF 151) when the command ship Absalon was transferred from CTF 150 to CTF 151 in February 2009. Absalon returned to Denmark upon completion of the mission with CTF 151 on 16 April 2009.
On several occasions, the Danish Task Group (DATG), part of the Royal Danish Navy, has led OOS. DATG led the operation from 5 August to early December 2010 and from June to December 2014.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Navy ships were tasked with protecting merchant ships and ships carrying humanitarian aid to the countries around the Gulf of Aden. Several times, they managed to foil hijackings, seize weapons, capture pirates, and burn pirate ships. In addition, the Danish ships were to transport pirates to countries and states in Africa so that they could stand trial. This has been a legal challenge in that it was not possible to send Somali pirates back to Somalia. The reason is that the legal system in Somalia is dominated by Sharia law in contravention of the laws of Denmark and of international conventions on human rights. Therefore, Denmark needed to find a different solution as the pirates could not remain, for example, on the support ship Absalon. Nor was it desired that the pirates be sent to Denmark to stand trial. Agreements were therefore set up with Kenya, Tanzania, and the Seychelles. These agreements were intended to ensure that pirates captured by the Danes could stand trial without being executed or having body parts cut off as punishment for their misdeeds.
The Air Force was tasked with periodic surveillance of the operational area using Challenger aircraft. In so doing it has had a hand in getting an overview of the situation and setting targets for and identifying pirate activity for the vessels in the area. The Lynx helicopters on the ships have been extremely helpful as they enabled quick deployment and thus made it possible to avert hijacking attempts.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Throughout the long history of Sudan there have been debates as to whether the southern part ought to be independent from the northern part. In 1955 – the year Sudan transitioned from being a British colony to being an independent nation – a rebellion arose in the southern part as there were fears of Arab-Muslim dominance from the northern part. The military took charge in 1958, but the unrest continued through the years, with various rulers and several instances of ethnic cleansing, until 1972. Trouble was brewing again in 1983 when the Second Sudanese Civil War erupted. The Sudanese government in the north (the Islamic and Arabic speaking part of Sudan) was opposed to independence for the south. The Second Sudanese Civil War was a continuation of the debate about independence for southern Sudan. The Sudan People's Liberation Army/Movement (SPLA/M) fought for autonomy in the south where most of the clashes occurred. The second civil war raged from 1983 to 2005 and is regarded as being one of the longest and bloodiest civil wars in the 20th century. This time period was one plagued by fundamentalist movements, violations of human rights, states of emergency, and the like. About 1,9 million civilians died, and more than 4 million became refugees. The civil war came to an end primarily thanks to a massive effort by the UN. In 2004, the UN set up a mandate to establish the preliminary operation UNAMIS. When UNAMIS ended, it was to be replaced by the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). The purpose with UNAMIS was to arrange contact between the warring parties and plan future operations. In addition, work was needed to prepare civilians for what was to come in terms of UN activity. This work, undertaken by the Sudan government, SPLA/M, the UN, and the African Union, enabled the warring parties to sign a protocol and peace accord on 9 January 2005 in neutral territory (the cities of Machakos and Naivasha in Kenya). Subsequent to the signing, however, the civil war continued in Darfur (a region in Sudan). Overall, the shared intent was to attempt a peaceful resolution with assistance from the UN and the African Union.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for UNAMIS was set out in UN Security Council Resolution 1547 of 11 June 2004. The objectives of the mandate were to ensure that human rights were not violated; that violence in the country diminished; and that information provided to the Sudanese people from SPLA/M and the Sudan government was correct so as to counter misinformation.  UNAMIS was given additional tasks by UN Security Council Resolution 1556 of 30 July 2004 when it had become clear that the western region in Sudan, Darfur, presented a special challenge. The resolution required that UNAMIS was to focus also on improving the situation for civilians in Darfur whose human rights had been violated during the civil war.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mandate for UNAMIS covered the period 11 June 2004 to March 2005 when United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS) assumed the remit. SHIRBRIG (Standby High-Readiness Brigade) operated in Sudan under UNAMIS from the end of July 2004 until the end of January 2005.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: SHIRBRIG was requested to take on the key planning tasks in UNAMIS . Six Danes from Brigade headquarters took part. The task was to plan and prepare the major UN mission UNMIS.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Throughout the entire history of Sudan there have been debates as to whether the southern part ought to be independent from the northern part. The matter reared its head again in 1983, the year in which the Second Sudanese Civil War erupted. The Sudanese government in the north (the Islamic and Arabic speaking part of Sudan) was opposed to independence for the south. This was also behind the First Sudanese Civil war starting in 1955, the year Sudan transitioned from being a British colony to being an independent nation. This civil war lasted until 1975. The Second Sudanese Civil War was a continuation of the debate about independence for southern Sudan. The Sudan People's Liberation Army/Movement (SPLA/M) fought for autonomy in the south where most of the clashes occurred. The second civil war raged from 1983 to 2005 and is considered one of the longest and bloodiest civil wars in the 20th century. About 1,9 million civilians died, and more than 4 million became refugees. Due to this situation in Sudan, the UN in 2004 set up a preliminary planning operation known as UNAMIS. It was intended to be replaced by the mission proper, United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). The objective of the mission was to resolve the conflict between the warring parties. This was achieved in 2011 when South Sudan became independent. Operation UNMIS was then terminated and was succeeded by United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (UNMISS). This latter mission was tasked with building peace and security in the new nation.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for UNMIS is found in UN Security Council Resolution 1590 of 24 March 2005. The mandate stipulates, among other things, that the implementation of the ceasefire in Sudan was to be monitored. In addition, UNMIS was to collaborate with the Sudanese government and the SPLA/M liberation movement in disarming the forces by retrieving and destroying weapons. A special emphasis was given to demobilising child and women soldiers. UNMIS also had the objective of providing a sufficient presence of human rights observers and protecting, per chapter VII of the UN Charter, UN personnel, installations, facilities, and equipment in Sudan – if necessary by use of force. The mandate indicated that the force was to number 10,000 military and 715 civilian officers. The latter were to train and rebuild local police forces and develop rule of law in the country.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government’s decision to assist the UN was made after the warring parties in Sudan had managed to negotiate a peace agreement in January 2005 that, on paper at least, ended the long Second Sudanese Civil War. With the task of rebuilding, Sudan faced immense problems related to dealing with large numbers of refugees and the need for food production capacity, health services, and an education system.  Such problems had the potential for giving rise to a renewed armed conflict, and Denmark wanted to help. The Danish Parliament unanimously approved participation in UNMIS on 29 April 2005 with 119 votes in favour. Proposal B71 to do so had been introduced on 12 April 2005.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The total Danish contribution to UNMIS in 2005-2006 was 55 soldiers. Initially, the Danish force consisted of 10 staff officers and a staff division of about 35 personnel  deployed under the Standby High-Readiness Brigade (SHIRBRIG). In December 2005, the latter personnel were recalled, and 10 Danes now joined the staff. In 2005-2006, they were part of a multinational collaboration involving 58 countries between 2005 and 2011. After the staff had returned to Denmark, Danish observers were sent to Sudan until the end of the mission.
Danish Police contributed about 15 officers between 2005 and 2008. All told, 40 member countries provided personnel to the police mission.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNMIS lasted from 24 March 2005 to 9 July 2011, and South Sudan then became an independent nation. Denmark participated from 29 April 2005 until UNMIS was terminated in 2011. When the next mission, UNMISS, was dispatched to Sudan, several Danish observers were a part of this new observer mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The 45 and later 10 Danish soldiers and officers worked at military headquarters as planners and staff assistants. They also worked as observers monitoring compliance by the Sudanese government and SPLA/M with the agreements they had entered into as to the ceasefire and the peace accord. This work on the part of the Danish observers continued until the end of the mission.

The police contingent was tasked with these objectives:
- Assisting the parties in rebuilding the police force of Sudan according to democratic principles, developing a training and assessment program, and supporting the training of police;
- Assisting the parties in building up a system of rule of law, including the courts, securing human rights for the population, addressing impunity, and helping with the development of a structure for national legislation; and
- Ensuring a suitable presence and expertise in UNMIS for the purpose of protecting human rights, providing security for civilians, and carrying out monitoring activities.
