missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission in the Republic of South Sudan

text.heading: Background
text.text: The Second Sudanese Civil War lasted from 1983 to 2005 and is regarded as one of the longest and bloodiest civil wars in the 20th century. About 1.9 million civilians died, and more than 4 million became refugees during this war. The war was triggered by the desire on the part of South Sudan, against the wishes of the Sudanese government, to become independent. A South Sudanese guerrilla force named Sudan People's Liberation Army/Movement (SPLA/M) was created in 1983. This force wanted to fight for independence. Violent internal hostilities involving attacks on civilians with significant loss of life led the UN to make a decision to intervene in 2004.  The 2004 UN Security Council mandate initially provided for a preparatory planning mission, operation United Nations Advance Mission in Sudan (UNAMIS). It was slated to be replaced by the mission proper, United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS). UNMIS was tasked with assisting the warring parties in resolving the conflict, monitoring compliance with agreements, and disarming the forces. The outcome was a peace agreement entered into in 2005 between the Sudanese government and SPLA/M. South Sudan then became independent in 2011, and UNMIS was terminated. The successor mission was United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (UNMISS), tasked with creating stability in the new nation, the Republic of South Sudan.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The UN needed an additional mandate for Sudan. It was provided in UN Security Council Resolution 1996 of 8 July 2011. In it, the assessment was that the situation in the new nation might present a threat to international peace and security. Therefore, the task was to assist the South Sudan government in getting established and in preventing escalation of conflicts, to provide help and assistance in dealing with the refugee crisis, and to protect South Sudan civilians from military groups. The mandate was slated for one year but has since been extended several times. Early in 2018, about 17,000 soldiers were working in South Sudan; they came from such countries as the UK, Holland, and Norway.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: In an orientation to the Danish Parliament, R5 of 8 December 2011, it is stated that Denmark had been in talks with the UN as to the feasibility of contributing to the new peacekeeping mission UNMISS. The Danish government stressed that Denmark must keep participating in traditional peacekeeping missions. The orientation states that Denmark would support the new UN mission, UNMISS, by supplying soldiers. The main objective would be to assist the new South Sudan government in its efforts to build a stable and democratic nation. Denmark’s contribution to the UN would be to provide up to 15 staff officers to the staff and liaison officers of UNMISS. The UN accepted this offer, and 12 Danish officers were dispatched initially.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Since the inception of the mission in 2012, the Danish contribution has consisted of 12-20 staff officers and observers, primarily in the area of the capital city of Juba. They worked also as liaison officers with respect to other areas of South Sudan such as Turalei. UNMISS had a Danish commander in 2015. In addition, Danish police officers have been sent to the area. Six Danish police professionals were dispatched as part of the EU Aviation Security Mission (EUAVSEC). EUAVSEC was active from September 2012 to January 2014. As is the case in all other missions during latter years, this one emphasised insight into local culture and social norms. The many different tribes and ethnic groups in South Sudan vary greatly in terms of culture and social norms. As an example, for one tribe, the Dinka people, friendliness and hospitality are a virtue, and gifts and services are offered to visitors. Anything less would be regarded as a breach of social norms and a sign of poor manners. In contrast, the Nuer people is not a tribe known for its openness toward outsiders. Hence it was essential for the mission staff to know a great deal about the habits of the specific tribe with which they were interacting.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Operating since 8 July 2011, UNMISS is still active but without danish participation. The last soldier (observer) left the mission i 2020. Danish Police worked within EUAVSEC, a mission operating from September 2012 to January 2014. The dispatch of the police officers covered the period from October 2012 to one month prior to the end of the mission (EUAVSEC) when the EU determined that it was irresponsible to leave personnel in Sudan.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The Danish staff officers worked primarily in the headquarters located in the capital city of Juba in South Sudan. The work here included provision of military police and education of the South Sudan police force (in collaboration with Cambodian UN police officers). In other areas, challenges included dealing with many competing armed tribes and gangs that harassed the local population by such acts as stealing cattle, often leading to loss of civilian lives. Therefore, crucial tasks – among local populations that were not always friendly – included Intelligence gathering, issuing alerts, gaining knowledge of the behaviour patterns of thieves, and having a preventive presence. 

The Danish police contingent was provided within EUAVSEC. A supervisory authority was set up in South Sudan to maintain aviation security in South Sudan and to educate public administrators.  The Danish police contingent delivered courses to South Sudanese officials to help them develop skills in administering transportation and airport control functions.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Large protests erupted in Ukraine in 2013 when President Viktor Yanukovych refused to sign an association and free trade agreement with the EU. The demonstrations, referred to as Euromaidan, led to the ouster of Yanukovych and his government. With the installation of a new pro-European government and the signing of the association and free trade agreement with the EU in 2014, counter-protests arose in East Ukraine, and an illegal referendum for independence, the Crimean status referendum, was held in Crimea, a peninsula within Ukraine. Partly out of fear that Ukraine might achieve membership in the EU and subsequently membership in NATO, the Russia decided to annex Crimea. The Crimea peninsula has strategic significance for Moscow as the Russian Black Sea Fleet is based in the city of Sevastopol in the southern part of Crimea. Prior to the crisis, a treaty between Russia and Ukraine gave Russia access to this area.
The Crimean crisis then spread to the eastern part of Ukraine where pro-Russian separatists, supported by Russia, declared the regions of Donetsk and Lutansk independent and initiated an armed revolution against the Ukrainian army.
Russia engaged in a number of destabilising strategies to create social unrest among the large Russian minorities in Crimea and East Ukraine. These strategies included propaganda, information warfare, financial and material support to rebels, organisation of pro-Russian and separatist protests, and the use of force by special units not wearing insignia.
The activities carried out by Russia have created unrest within the large Russian minorities in parts of the post-Soviet space along with considerable worry and insecurity in several of the countries bordering on Russia.
Therefore, NATO in 2016 decided to initiate Enhanced Forward Presence (eFP) in the eastern nations of the Alliance that feel particularly vulnerable to Russian influence.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The implementation of the eFP was approved at the NATO summit in Warsaw in 2016 The eFP consists of four multinational battalions, each with approximately 1,000 personnel. They are stationed in four NATO countries bordering on Russia: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland.
The primary objective of the eFP is to deter Russia from deploying regular or irregular forces in the neighbouring countries and to demonstrate solidarity in the Alliance along with the intent to adhere to Article 5 in the NATO Treaty, the so-called “Musketeer Oath” stating that an attack on one member nation is an attack on the others.

The logic behind the eFP is aligned with the so-called “tripwire strategy” in which a potential attack would have Russian soldiers engaging in battle with American, British, French, German, and Danish soldiers. That would constitute a direct attack on each contributor and on the NATO Alliance as a whole. The eFP is not intended to, and is not able to, withstand a full-scale attack from Russia; its purpose is deterrence. The advantage of this strategy is that there is no need to mobilise a large military presence at the Russian border that could unnecessarily escalate the conflict through a potential arms race in Russia’s border regions.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision to provide a contribution from Denmark to the NATO eFP in the Baltic states and Poland was made in Parliament on 23 May 2017 with 97 votes in favour and 9 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark sent about 200 personnel in 2018 and again in 2020. They became a part of the battalion in Tapa, Estonia, led by the UK. The contribution consisted of a combat unit, a logistics unit and Military Police.
The combat unit had three platoons: two armoured infantry platoons and a mechanised infantry platoon. The two armoured infantry platoons were equipped with infantry combat vehicles, and the mechanised platoon was equipped with armoured personnel carriers. The logistics unit provided supplies and repairs, sanitation, and associated communications systems. I 2022 a combat unit was deployded. From September 2022 and 6 months ahead a Tank Squadron was deployed  in the  mission.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The contribution from Denmark became part of the battalion in Estonia on a rotation basis as of January 2018 for 12 months. Denmark has committed to providing two sets of military personnel, each for six months. The government decided to provide forces for the eFP again in 2020. For an other six mounth periode in 2022 and again in 2023 danish units were deployed. In 2024 the battalion was deployed for four month.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Given that the risk of an invasion by Russia is likely quite modest, a large part of the mission of the Danish personnel focuses on training and military exercises performed with units from the other contributing nations, thus demonstrating a presence.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
As its population was made up for the most part of ethnic Albanians, Kosovo in the 1945 constitution of Yugoslavia was granted autonomous status as a province in the state of Serbia. Slobodan Milosevic came to power in Belgrade by leveraging the unrest in Kosovo and acting as a spokesman for its Serbian minority. During his term in office and while Yugoslavia was gradually falling apart, the Serbian parliament revoked Kosovo’s autonomy in 1989. During the wars in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina that ensued from the breakup of Yugoslavia, Kosovo was at first relatively peaceful. By 1997, a serious conflict erupted between the paramilitary group Kosovo Liberation Army and Serbian police officers and soldiers in the area.

By February 1998, this conflict escalated and, as in other areas of Yugoslavia there were attacks on civilians along with ethnic cleansing. Both parties were responsible for attacks on civilians, but the experienced and much more skilled soldiers from Serbia cracked down hard on anything that might be interpreted as Kosovo-Albanian nationalist sentiment. Hundreds of thousands of refugees fled to neighbouring countries, where NATO then deployed military forces to maintain security and provide humanitarian aid, some of it delivered by Albanian Force (AFOR). Although the UN Security Council urged a peaceful solution and sought to set up a mission to investigate whether ethnic cleansing was being perpetrated, diplomacy was not successful. The Yugoslav government refused to permit NATO soldiers on a peacekeeping mission as it feared that an independent Kosovo would be the result. Its stance was that the deployment of UN missions in territories such as Bosnia-Herzegovina the previous year had led to the loss of Yugoslavian territory. Belgrade did not want to see a repeat in Kosovo.

After several rounds of international negotiations, particularly in Rambouillet in France, it was realised in March 1999 that the conflict could not be resolved by diplomatic means. At that time, NATO had assembled an air force for the purpose of putting pressure on the Yugoslav government, and it was deployed on missions in Kosovo and Serbia soon after the breakdown of negotiations.
Despite having no clear mandate from the UN, NATO decided to carry out an air campaign against what remained of Yugoslavia to stop the attacks on the Kosovo-Albanian population. Milosevic capitulated after a 78 day bombardment under Operation Allied Force. A so-called military-technical agreement was concluded between Belgrade and NATO on 10 June on the withdrawal of Serb forces and the insertion of an international force to Kosovo.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
When Belgrade accepted an agreement after the NATO air campaign, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1244 (1999) on 12 June. The resolution required an end to hostilities , the withdrawal from Kosovo of all Yugoslavian military and police and mandated the presence of an international military force to assume control of the province. NATO was given the responsibility of the command of this mission, which was named Kosovo Force (KFOR).
The resolution also formed the basis for an international Kosovo administration until a permanent solution could be found and was thus the mandate for UNMIK, which was the UN’s administration in the area and the OSCE’s OMIK mission, both of which collaborated closely with KFOR.

In 2007 the EU decided to establish a mission in the area to assist in the development of a system of law and order in Kosovo, mandated by Council Joint Action 2008/124(CFSP) of 4 February 2008. The police mission was named European Union Rule of Law Mission in Kosovo (EULEX Kosovo).

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish contribution was decided when the Parliament adopted proposal B148, which was put forward on 16 June 1999. The Parliament consented to the deployment to Kosovo of a Danish battalion and support elements as part of KFOR, following the mandate and guidelines as set out in Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999) - and the military agreement between NATO and what remained of Yugoslavia. The Parliament also decided that Denmark would contribute personnel to an international police deployment.
The proposal was processed as a matter of urgency as NATO’s rapid response force in Europe was already on its way into Kosovo and was adopted with 97 votes in favour and five against. When it was adopted on 17 June, the Parliament also authorised the Danish aircraft that had been deployed to Operation Allied Force to also provide air support to KFOR within Balkan Air Operations.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The original Danish contribution was comprised of a downscaled 800-strong armoured infantry battalion. The battalion’s numbers were soon increased to 880, which was the largest number of Danish troops to be simultaneously deployed to the mission.  The Danish battalion was comprised of: a staff with associated staff company, two armoured infantry companies, a tank company, a logistics company and signals, engineering and military police units. Finally, a national support group and liaison officers were assigned to the French brigade staff, in whose sector the Danish troops were operating. The Danish battalion was named DANBAT. A force from the elite Jaeger Corps was deployed shortly before the deployment to gather intelligence. The Jaeger Corps were again deployed in 2004 as reinforcements.
Denmark and other contributors have since downsized their forces as the situation in Kosovo stabilised. When the mission celebrated its tenth anniversary in 2009, approximately 300 Danes were deployed as part of KFOR. The force currently numbers 35 soldiers deployed to guard duties and staff officers. The contribution has mainly involved personnel from the army and the Danish Home Guard, supported on various occasions by technicians from the Royal Danish Navy. A number of civilians have also occupied administrative positions. The Danish Home Guard deployed a guard platoon to Kosovo from February 2011 to June 2013. Denmark's presence in Kosovo numbers 35 soldiers and five officers from the army and the Danish Home Guard.

A total of over 10,000 Danish soldiers have served with KFOR over the almost 20-year long mission. This was for many years the biggest mission that Danish Defence had taken part in. As KFOR was downscaled and international efforts were diverted to other hotspots it was overtaken by the operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.
From an international perspective, KFOR was a mission of unusual scale. All NATO member states and 20 ”non-NATO states” contributed to the mission, which numbered over 50,000 personnel at its peak in 1999.

An approximate total of more than 300 serving Danish police officers have been deployed to UN, OSCE and EU missions in Kosovo. Police officers are still being deployed to the EU mission (EULEX Kosovo). The police mission numbers a total of 800 local and international personnel (2018 figure). Personnel have been deployed from all 28 EU countries, as well as Canada, Norway, Switzerland, Turkey and the USA.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The first NATO troops entered Kosovo on 12 June. These troops had already been deployed in Albania and Macedonia and were ready to quickly assume control of the area once the agreement with Milosevic and the UN mandate were in place. The Danish KFOR battalion was mustered in Denmark during June-July, arriving at the theatre of operations in Kosovo at the end of July and the beginning of August 1999. The entire Danish force was present at the camp and officially deployed on 10 August. DANBAT was thus the first force to be fully deployed in Kosovo that was not from one of the five ”lead nations” (USA, United Kingdom, Germany, Italy and France), each of whom was responsible for a single sector.
Since that time, many KFOR responsibilities have been transferred to UNMIK or to the local population. KFORcontinues today, but in a much smaller model. A small Danish contribution is still present in Kosovo at the time of writing.

The EU police mission was activated in April 2009, its mandate being extended on an ongoing basis.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The military mission
The deployment of the Danish battalion proceeded in good order as it took charge of its areas of responsibility as part of the French-led multinational force in northern Kosovo. This was an area where tensions were high, extending from the outskirts of the town of Mitrovica to the West to the border between Kosovo and Serbia. This was a multi-ethnic area which could quickly turn into a front line if fighting started again. It was therefore a constant task to appear to be impartial, so that neither group would feel neglected by the international KFOR troops. The Danish units were sent into action on multiple occasions in the Mitrovica area during confrontations between Kosovo-Albanians and Serbs, often alongside French, Belgian and Baltic units from the same sector.
Tensions were highest during the early period as the Danish troops arrived and shortly afterwards. Acts of retaliation were carried out in the area by the Kosovo Liberation Army and the many Kosovo-Albanian refugees during the vacuum before KFOR was able to take full control in the area,  The Kosovo Serbs did not all flee to Serbia, but gathered in the areas where they were the majority. Mitrovica was therefore split into an Albanian zone and a Serbian zone, each on its own side of the Ibar river that flows through the town. The bridges over the river often became conflict zones and had to be sealed off for periods by the troops from the international forces.

The Danish contingent’s general duties were to man permanent control and observation posts, to set up mobile checkpoints, to perform escort duties and to carry out raids to find illegal arms. Another duty was the general maintenance of law and order in partnership with UNMIK’s police division, in which Danish police officers were also serving. Today, the task of policing has now been transferred to Kosovo’s own police force. Protecting minorities and ensuring that attacks did not take place were also an important element of these duties. For example, Danish soldiers guarded a Serbian monastery in a mainly Albanian area for a long time. In certain areas, children would be escorted to school if they had to pass through an area populated by another ethnicity.
For the first months, disarming the Kosovo Liberation Army was a very central task for KFOR. Although it was officially dissolved in the autumn of 1999, large numbers ”disappeared” at the same time and it was estimated that the Yugoslavian troops had left weapons behind for the Kosovo Serb population. Danish KFOR troops found large arms depots several times during the ongoing raids. As time went by the raids were stopped. Since 2002 there has been an amnesty for people who hand arms in voluntarily. 

In March 2004 KFOR had to step in during the worst unrest that had been seen in Kosovo since the conflict began in 1994. The 327 Danes who were in Kosovo at the time were still stationed close to multi-ethnic Mitrovica. On 19 March a large group of Albanian demonstrators crossed a bridge over the Ibar river, despite the intervention of French riot police who tried to stop them. The Danish troops moved in and there was street fighting between Serbs and Albanians while the multinational force tried to keep the groups apart using tear gas and shields. During the night the Danish troops experienced that their command station was being shot at and they had to return fire. At the same time, there were rumours that 1,000 armed Albanians were heading for the town. Danish Defence deployed 96 men from the army and the Jaeger Corps as reinforcements. Other NATO countries also reinforced their KFOR forces. After three days of rioting throughout Kosovo during which several Serb monasteries were burned to the ground the situation quietened down. Over the following days, Danish, French and Baltic troops carried out thorough searches of houses in Mitrovica to confiscate weapons and arrest the instigators of the unrest.

The Danish troops lived for most of the duration of the mission at their own bases: Camp Olaf Rye & Camp Holger Danske near Mitrovica. Camp Holger Danske closed down in the year 2000, the forces being congregated at a single camp. The Danish contribution was further reduced from 300 to 180 soldiers when the 21st KFOR team left for home in February 2010 and Camp Olaf Rye.was also shut down. The Danish forces then relocated to the nearby French camp. The present day mission of deployed Danes primarily involves guard duties in and around the hard to pronounce French Camp Marechal De Lattre de Tassigny, which is more often called Novo Selo after the nearest town.

The police mission
The overall task of the police mission was to assist Kosovo’s institutions, legal authorities, police and customs in their evolution towards being able to perform their duties for themselves, including support in the development of an independent multi-ethnic judiciary and a multi-ethnic police and customs service.
In partnership with the other EU aid programmes, this mission would execute its mandate in the form of mentor schemes, monitoring and advice. The mission had been given various executive duties.

To achieve this, the mission would:

-monitor institutions in areas related to law enforcement (including customs authorities) and ensure the creation and development of law enforcement, public order and security,
-help to assure that Kosovo’s law enforcement system, also including its customs authorities, was free of political interference, and to ensure that cases involving war crimes, terrorism, organised crime, corruption, crime based on ethnicity and other serious crimes were investigated correctly, that prosecutions were made and judgements passed, and that judgements were in accordance with current legislation,
-promote collaborative relationships and coordination between police and state prosecutor, especially with regard to organised crime, corruption, fraud and economic crime, including support for the implementation of an anti-corruption strategy and a plan for operations,
-to ensure that all of the mission's activities respect international standards with regard to gender equality and human rights.

The mission’s headquarters were to be located in Pristina, with regional offices established throughout Kosovo and a support element in Brussels.

missions.title: UNMIK Kosovo
missions.subtitle: After the Kosovo Conflict
missions.name: UNMIK Kosovo
missions.descriptiveName: UN Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Given that its population was mainly ethnic Albanians, Kosovo in the 1945 Yugoslav constitution had a special status as an independently governed province in the state of Serbia. Slobodan Milošević came to power in Belgrade by taking advantage of unrest in Kosovo and by making himself the spokesman for the Serbian minority. During his time in office, the Serbian parliament revoked Kosovo’s autonomy in 1989 all the while Yugoslavia was gradually falling apart. In the beginning, during the wars in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo was relatively peaceful. By 1997, a serious conflict erupted between the paramilitary group Kosovo Liberation Army and Serbian police officers and soldiers in the area.
By February 1998, this conflict escalated, and as in other areas of Yugoslavia there were attacks on civilians along with acts of ethnic cleansing. Both parties were responsible for attacks on civilians, but the experienced and much more skilled soldiers from Serbia cracked down hard on anything that might be interpreted as Kosovo-Albanian nationalist sentiment. Hundreds of thousands of refugees fled to neighbouring countries where NATO then deployed military forces to maintain security and provide humanitarian aid, some of it through AFOR (Albanian Force). Although the UN Security Council urged a peaceful solution and sought to set up a mission to investigate whether ethnic cleansing was being perpetrated, diplomacy was not successful. The Yugoslav government refused to permit NATO soldiers on a peacekeeping mission as it feared that an independent Kosovo would be the result. The attitude in Belgrade was that the West in Bosnia and Herzegovina had contributed to the loss of Yugoslav territory due to the deployment of UN missions. A repeat of this scenario was not desired.

After several rounds of international negotiations, especially in Rambouillet in France, the hope of finding a resolution to the conflict was abandoned in March 1999. By this time, NATO had already assembled an air force for the purpose of putting pressure on the Yugoslav government. Shortly after the breakdown of negotiations, it was deployed in missions over Kosovo and Serbia.
In spite of the absence of a clear mandate from the UN, NATO decided, in the interest of halting the attacks on the Kosovo-Albanian population, to execute an air campaign against the rest of Yugoslavia. A bombardment lasting 78 days in Operation Allied Force led to a so-called military technical agreement between Milošević and NATO as to the withdrawal of Serbian troops and the transfer of control to an international force.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: Subsequent to the success of Operation Allied Force in getting Milošević to enter into an agreement, the UN Security Council approved Resolution 1244 (1999). In addition to providing a mandate for the international military intervention by KFOR under command of NATO, the resolution ordered the establishment of international public administration for Kosovo along with an international police mission. The Secretary-General was to collaborate with other international organisations in setting up a temporary administration to govern Kosovo, with extensive autonomy within Yugoslavia, until an election could be held. This administration in addition was tasked with drafting a constitution and building up the required institutions. This became the foundation for United Nations Interim Administration in Kosovo (UNMIK).

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The deployment of Danish officers in UNMIK as advisers, observers, and the like was authorised by Danish Defence upon a decision made by the government subsequent to a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee.  Danes working as civilians in the administrative functions of UNMIK were voluntary independent contractors hired by the UN. In practice, the decision was simply an extension of the parliamentary approval of proposal B148 of 17 June 1999 for deployment of Danish police officers.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in consultation with the Danish Emergency Management Agency, decided to offer the services of an experienced emergency aid expert.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Over time, Denmark provided officers as military advisers and observers, and about 30 of them have been deployed by Danish Defence in UNMIK. Similarly, Danish police officers have participated from the outset until the police mission was assumed by EULEX Kosovo (as of 2008). Here, Denmark provided correctional officers as well. The military work in Kosovo after the war, based on Resolution 1244 (1999), was named KFOR. Denmark sent a battalion of over 800 early in 1999, and more than 10,000 have served since then. About 300 Danish police officers have served in the mission.
Former Minister of Defence Hans Hækkerup served as Head of Mission of UNMIK from 13 January to 31 December 2001. He had been tapped by UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan to be at the helm of the administration during this fraught period of time. From 2004 to 2006, experienced diplomat Søren Jessen-Petersen served as Head of Mission of UNMIK when his predecessor had resigned after the unrest in 2004. Over the years, other Danes have worked in UNMIK as civilian contractors to the UN.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNMIK was set up in July 1999 by UN Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999) and by the establishment of KFOR in Kosovo. As local institutions have evolved and police work has been assumed by the EU mission known as EULEX, UNMIK has been reduced in size. It still exists, though at a smaller scale. Denmark contributed to UNMIK from the beginning and is still doing so.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The primary objective of UNMIK was to stabilise and administer Kosovo in collaboration with KFOR until an independent administration had been built and an agreement as to the relationship with Serbia had been reached. This objective was divided into four parts. 1) First, politically, a local democratic system was to be built to govern Kosovo. 2) Then, in collaboration with UN refugee organisation UNHCR, a huge humanitarian effort lay ahead as a result of the return of the many displaced persons from neighbouring countries. 3) In collaboration with OMIK, the OSCE mission, local institutions needed to be built with multi-ethnic personnel, hereunder an ombudsman, judges, and local police forces. 4) Last but not least, battle-scarred Kosovo needed rebuilding. This work was to be done in collaboration with the EU as the latter undertook fund raising and financial contributions.
The crafting of a legal foundation for the autonomy of Kosovo within Serbia turned out to be a major task. There was a need to craft a constitution setting out the framework for local governance in such a way that the Albanian majority and the Serbian minority were fairly represented. In this context, Kosovo was still officially an autonomous province within Serbia, and UNMIK has devoted a great deal of effort to addressing the relationship between the two.
For a long time, UNMIK was in charge of everything you would expect a public administration to handle. UNMIKundertook maintenance of roads and other infrastructure, hiring of garbage collectors, officiating at civil marriage ceremonies, and even issuing travel documents as Serbian passports were not available to the local population. Police work was undertaken jointly by KFOR, the police division of UNMIK, and UNCIVPOL. Danish police officers participated in the latter.

The police mission had two main tasks: It was to set up a temporary force dealing with law enforcement and to participate in the rapid building of a Kosovo Police Service that was credible, professional, and independent. In so doing it had charge of law and order in Kosovo; border controls; training, guidance for, and monitoring of local police officers; and developing a command structure for the police of Kosovo.

The envoy from the Danish Emergency Management Agency acted as Civil Affairs Officer in terms of building the Kosovo Protection Corps for the purpose of handling civilian matters such as establishing and managing fire fighting and emergency response and setting up a response team to deal with industrial and chemical contamination. In addition, work needed to be done with respect to setting up a search and rescue function, providing humanitarian aid to isolated areas, and offering administrative support for finding and destroying mines and other abandoned ammunition.

Under the leadership of Hans Hækkerup, the first all-Kosovo election was held in 2001. The party of pacifist Ibrahim Rugova enjoyed success in this election. This party had represented the Kosovo-Albanian community during the 1990s. Many had predicted that more aggressive parties arising from the newly dissolved Kosovo Liberation Army would gain ground, and Rugova’s success was thus a positive sign. It was likewise positive that the Kosovo Serbs voted on an equal footing with the majority.
Final negotiations on the future status of Kosovo began in 2006, chaired by Danish diplomat Søren Jessen-Petersen. These protracted negotiations with Serbia foundered in 2007, and next year, Kosovo unilaterally declared independence from Serbia. This declaration was met with significant opposition from Serbia and Russia and led to litigation in the International Court of Justice. The Court determined that the declaration did not contravene international law. In spite of some objections, Kosovo is now recognised as an independent nation by 112 out of the 193 UN member countries. The majority among the Serbs in Kosovo, Serbia itself, Russia, and some other nations still reject the independence and still consider Kosovo to be a part of Serbia officially. In 2013, the EU succeeded in negotiating the Brussels Agreement between Kosovo and Serbia. This agreement is a step toward a normalisation of relations between the two parties; but much remains to be settled.

Most of UNMIK has been terminated or significantly reduced since the declaration of independence in 2008 and the subsequent 2013 agreement. The government of Kosovo, over time, has assumed most of the administration of Kosovo. The police work performed by UNCIVPOL was assumed by a local force working with the EU police mission EULEX. EULEX is assisting Kosovo in building an independent and multi-ethnic police force.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
As its population was made up for the most part of ethnic Albanians, Kosovo in the 1945 constitution of Yugoslavia was granted autonomous status as a province in the state of Serbia. By leveraging the unrest in Kosovo and acting as a spokesman for its Serbian minority, Slobodan Milosevic came to power in Belgrade. During his term in office and while Yugoslavia was gradually falling apart, the Serbian parliament revoked Kosovo’s autonomy in 1989. During the wars in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina that ensued from the breakup of Yugoslavia, Kosovo was at first relatively peaceful. By 1996, a serious conflict erupted between the paramilitary group Kosovo Liberation Army and Serbian police officers and soldiers in the area.
By February 1998, this conflict escalated, and as in other areas of Yugoslavia there were attacks on civilians along with ethnic cleansing. Both parties were responsible for attacks on civilians, but the experienced and much more skilled soldiers from Serbia cracked down hard on anything that might be interpreted as Kosovo-Albanian nationalist sentiment. Hundreds of thousands of refugees fled to neighbouring countries where NATO then deployed military forces to maintain security and provide humanitarian aid, some of it delivered by AFOR (Albanian Force). Although the UN Security Council urged a peaceful solution and sought to set up a mission to investigate whether ethnic cleansing was being perpetrated, diplomacy was not successful. The Yugoslav government refused to permit NATO soldiers on a peacekeeping mission as it feared that an independent Kosovo would be the result. The attitude on the part of the Serbs was coloured by their experiences in Bosnia-Herzegovina, among other places, where, in their opinion, they had lost Yugoslav territory due to the deployment of UN missions.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In September 1998, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1199 in response to the clashes between the Kosovo Liberation Army and the Serbian forces. It was demanded that both parties permit international observers and guarantee their freedom of movement. Although Milosevic resisted any peacekeeping mission by NATO soldiers, he permitted the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) to set up an observation mission in October that year by the name Kosovo Verification Mission (KVM). It was later approved by the UN Security Council in Resolution 1203 (1998).
When the NATO air campaign Operation Allied Force concluded, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1244 (1999). It became the foundation for several missions in Kosovo. KFOR (Kosovo Force) was meant to ensure peace and military control of Kosovo, and UNMIK (United Nations Mission in Kosovo) was set up as a temporary international administrative entity in the area. According to that resolution, the OSCE Permanent Council adopted Decision No. 305 of 1 July 1999 to establish a mission in Kosovo (OMIK) that would take over from the temporary OSCE Task Force in Kosovo. The decision states that OSCE was to contribute to the stabilisation and development of Kosovo within the framework of the work of UNMIK, especially in the areas of development of institutions and support of democracy and human rights – three areas in which OSCE had considerable experience. The ensuing OSCE mission in Kosovo was dubbed OSCE Mission in Kosovo (OMIK).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon a submission to the Foreign Affairs Council, the Danish government approved the contribution of Danish observers in the OSCE Kosovo Verification Mission and the subsequent Mission in Kosovo.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contribution to KVM in 1998-1999 consisted of approximately 25 Danish observers stationed in Kosovo.
Five Danish instructors from the Danish Police Academy worked at the Kosovo Police Service School from September 1999 to November 2003.
As for OMIK, Denmark contributed primarily by supplying civilian personnel. Some were employed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; others were hired by OMIK directly. As an example, officer Finn Særmark-Thomsen assumed civilian status to take charge of the OSCE office in Mitrovica. Currently, OSCE employs a total of 503 staff in Kosovo.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
KVM and the associated Danish observers began working in Kosovo in October 1998. At this time, the ceasefire was quite unstable while negotiations took place in Rambouillet in France between Kosovo-Albanians, Serbs, and NATO. When the negotiations broke down and preparations began for a NATO air campaign, KVM was withdrawn on 20 March 1999.
When KFOR had gained control of Kosovo, OMIK began its work on 1 July 1999. That work continues to this day with support from Denmark.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
As an extension of Resolution 1199 (1998) demanding cessation of armed hostilities and attacks on civilians, KVM was meant to facilitate the return of refugees and a political solution to the conflict. Personnel working in the mission experienced difficulties and reported persecutions of Kosovo-Albanians. These persecutions led to attacks on Serbian forces by the Kosovo Liberation Army. In the morning of 20 March, OSCE recalled its observers from Kosovo, just a few days before the start of Operation Allied Force in which NATO bombed Serbian targets to compel a peace agreement. KVM found that Kosovo-Albanians in the province were the victims of an extensive and systematic program of persecution.
When OSCE returned, now as OMIK, a different challenge was at hand. KFOR had gained control and now was able to assure security, and UNMIK was tasked with setting up a administrative function for Kosovo. The original task for OMIK was to work with UNMIK on building local institutions such as an ombudsman, courts, and police, preferably with staff of multiple ethnicities. Since that time, OSCE has expanded its scope. Today, the work of OSCE in Kosovo encompasses such areas as gender equality, prevention of terrorism, cybersecurity, freedom of the press, and efforts to provide better opportunities for the youth of Kosovo. However, the “traditional” OSCE tasks still play a major role. The mission continues to work on developing the police and the judicial system and in addition focuses on human rights and democratic elections. As an example, observers are present at every election.

missions.title: UNTAES Croatia
missions.subtitle: Monitoring of Compliance with Agreements
missions.name: UNTAES Kroatien
missions.descriptiveName: UN Transitional Administration for Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Sirmium

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia had its roots in the desire for independence and in related acts of ethnic cleansing. There had been political tensions between the component states in Yugoslavia for years. Acts of war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation. A significant minority of Serbs lived in the border area in southern Croatia, near Bosnia. They were opposed to Croatia being independent from the federated structure. Armed hostilities erupted between Croat Serbs, supported by the Yugoslav army, and the Croats. The European Community attempted without success to end the fighting. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and worked to establish a foundation for a solution and, in 1991, to stop the flow of arms and ammunition to the area.  This did not bear fruit, and the next objective was a potential UN operation, initially to bring about a ceasefire. The UN in 1992 set up United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR). Its task was to reinstate peace and provide security in Yugoslavia with an emphasis on the unrest in Croatia. UNPROFOR I was sent to Croatia, UNPROFOR II was sent to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and UNPROFOR III was sent to Macedonia. UNPROFOR I was dissolved in 1995 when the Croatian government no longer permitted the presence of the force in the area. The UN Security Council then decide to restructure UNPROFOR I in Croatian to UNCRO. As successor to UNPROFOR I in Croatia, UNCRO was tasked with setting up a ceasefire between Serbs supporting Yugoslavia and Croats supporting independence for Croatia. The primary task of UNCRO was to establish a peace agreement. This effort was severely hampered when Croat forces in what is known as Operation Storm in the days of 4-7 August 1995 captured two of the four areas under the watch of UNCRO These areas were Danish-patrolled Sector North and Sector West. The Croats thus gained control of the Krajina area, the part of Croatia that had been occupied by Serb forces at the beginning of the war. With the retaking of the Krajina area, the UN forces were no longer needed, and UNCRO was dissolved on 15 January 1996. After the termination of UNCRO, the UN on the last day of work for UNCRO decided to set up an administrative mandate specifically for parts of Croatia.  The peacekeeping force charged with this mandate carried the long name of United Nations Transitional Administration for Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Sirmium (UNTAES). It was the remit of UNTAES to ensure that agreements entered into on 12 November 1995 between the Croatian government and local Serbian authorities in Eastern Slovenia, Baranja, and Western Sirmium were honoured. UNTAES was an observation mission whose main tasks were to monitor compliance with agreements, for example agreements to demilitarise the areas. UNTAESmaintained this mandate until 15 January 1998 when the mission was terminated and replaced by a police force by the name of United Nations Police Support Group (UNPSG). It was to carry out monitoring of and collaboration with Croatian police with respect to control of the areas, hereunder especially the work of registration and management of returning refugees.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The impetus for UNTAES was the desire to ensure that agreements between the Croatian government and local Serbian authorities were honoured, that demilitarisation continued in the affected areas, and that the return of displaced persons and refugees took place in an appropriate manner. The mandate was approved by UN Security Council Resolution 1037 of 15 January 1996 and was later extended to 15 January 1998. The resolution terminating UNTAES (Resolution 1145) included the creation of a police force of up to 600 civilian UN police officers to continue the work of UNTAES in the relevant areas.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark’s participation in UNTAES represented a continuation of the Danish Parliament’s 1992 decision regarding UNPROFOR I/UNCRO in Croatia. Proposal B95 was introduced by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and approved on 18 September 1992 with 95 votes in favour, 28 votes opposed, and 2 votes undecided.
As for participation of Danish police, the government made the decision after a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark contributed about 68 military observers and a number of police officers who joined personnel from 30 other countries such as Sweden, Norway, and Finland. The number of participants from Denmark included those observers transferred to UNMOP and UNCRO.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The UNTAES mission was active from 15 January 1996 to 15 January 1998.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The observers were tasked with monitoring the implementation of peace agreements between the Croatian government and local Serbian authorities, monitoring the demilitarisation of areas in which UNTAES operated, facilitating the collaboration between local authorities, and monitoring the return of displaced persons and refugees.
The police portion of the mission was tasked with setting up a temporary police force and determine its structure and size. This work included:
- Developing a training program for the police force and overseeing its implementation;
- Monitoring the management of criminals, the prison system, law enforcement, and compliance with human rights and
- Monitoring the border.

missions.title: UNCRO Croatia
missions.subtitle: In Crossfire
missions.name: UNCRO Kroatien
missions.descriptiveName: UN Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia was based on the desire for independence and on related ethnic cleansing. For years, there had been political tensions between the states making up Yugoslavia; when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation, war broke out. In the southern part of Croatia bordering on Bosnia, a significant local minority of Serbs opposed Croatia’s independence from the federated Yugoslavia. Hostilities erupted between the Croatian Serbs – supported by the Yugoslav army – and the Croats. The European Community then unsuccessfully attempted to put an end to the strife. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and made efforts to build a scenario for halting the unrest. In 1991, the UN in addition worked to block transport of arms and ammunition to the area. These efforts did not meet with success, and talks were held with a view to initiating a UN operation for the purposes of achieving a ceasefire. In 1992, the UN established United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR) with the aim of reinstating peace and providing security in Yugoslavia, especially in volatile Croatia. UNPROFOR I was sent to Croatia,UNPROFOR II was sent to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and UNPROFOR III was sent to Macedonia. UNPROFOR I was terminated in 1995 when the Croatian government no longer permitted the force to operate in the area. The UN Security Council then approved a restructuring of UNPROFOR into three forces: The United Nations Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia (UNCRO) in Croatia; the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP) in Macedonia; and UNPROFOR II in Bosnia and Herzegovina (until December 1995). Together, these three forces made up the United Nations Peace Force (UNPF). As successor to UNPROFOR I in Croatia, UNCRO was tasked with establishing a ceasefire between Serbs supporting Yugoslavia and Croats in favour of independence for Croatia. In addition, UNCRO was to monitor and report on all personnel, arms, and other reinforcements transported into Croatia during the conflict. The primary purpose of the mission, however, was to arrange a peace accord. Efforts toward this goal were initiated, but they were severely hampered when Croat forces in what is known as Operation Storm in the days of 4-7 August 1995 captured two of the four areas under the watch of UNCRO These two areas, Sector North and Sector West, were patrolled by the Danes. That capture gave the Croats control over the Krajina area, the Serb-dominated part of Croatia. With the retaking of the Krajina area, the UN forces were no longer needed, and UNCRO was terminated on 15 January 1996. The Danish contingent returned to Denmark starting in October 1995. The last Danish soldier departed from UNCRO on 1 December 1995.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for UNCRO was a new one although it was based on the work previously done by UNPROFOR I in Croatia. UNCRO was tasked with working toward a peace agreement and at the same time monitoring and reporting the extent of movements of personnel, arms, and other reinforcements across borders. Additional objectives were to provide security for civilians in the sector and to assist with humanitarian aid efforts, internal transports, and transports to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The mandate was approved by UN Security Council Resolution 981 of 31 March 1995 and was terminated on 15 January 1996.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: UNCRO was set up as a continuation of UNPROFOR I in Croatia. The Danish Parliament had authorised participation in the latter by approving proposal B95 on 18 September 1992 with 95 votes in favour, 28 votes opposed, and 2 votes undecided. The Danish forces sent to Croatia per this approval were known as The Danish Battalion (DANBAT). The forces were sent to Sector North in the then Serb-controlled Krajina area. Upon the termination of UNPROFOR, the Danish forces were transferred to UNCRO, still with Sector North as the target area. Danish police personnel also worked in Sector North.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: UNCRO consisted of a total of about 6,600 soldiers, 200 observers, and civilian police numbering 300. The Danish contingent consisted, on a rotation basis, of DANBAT 7 and DANBAT 8, each with about 800 Danish soldiers, and a small number of staff officers in the UNCRO headquarters in Zagreb. The precise number of participating Danish police personnel cannot be determined. These officers were among 700 personnel working in missions operated by the UN, the EU, and OSCE in Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Macedonia.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNCRO was active from 31 March 1995 to 15 January 1996. The contribution from Denmark extended from March 1995 to mid-October 1995 when DANBAT 8 was recalled.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
About 800 Danish soldiers, along with Lithuanian and Estonian platoons, were part of UNCRO in Sector North in the Krajina area at the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Here, DANBAT 7 and 8 were tasked with:

  • Monitoring the terrain and the warring parties in and around the border between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
  • Monitoring compliance with ceasefire agreements. This objective was met only to a limited extent due to certain restrictions imposed on the work.
  • Undertaking humanitarian aid work in Croatia. This objective was met in part.

In general, the work of police personnel was similar to the work of UNPROFOR. This work included:
- Ensuring that local police carried out their functions without discrimination against persons of another nationality and without violations of human rights;
- Monitoring the activities of the local police;
- Accompanying local police on their patrols and in their local activities; and
- Investigating information regarding discrimination and violations of human rights.

The work of DANBAT 7 in Croatia was complicated by the runup to and the execution of Operation Storm, an attack by the Croatian army that in August 1995 captured the Krajina area in a matter of days. One Danish soldier was killed, and several were wounded. The armed clashes were intense, and the Danish soldiers got caught in the line of fire between Croat and Krajina-Serb forces. The next contingent, DANBAT 8, similarly experienced hardship in the area. A new offensive and battles between Croats and Bosnian Serbs put Danish positions in the line of fire on 18 September 1995 with heavy shooting from positions in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In this hostile encounter, two Danes lost their lives, and many were wounded. DANBAT 8 concluded its decommissioning work in the Krajina area and returned to Denmark in October 1995. After that, Denmark sent observers to Croatia in 1996 within the remit of UN Mission of Observers in Prevlaka (UNMOP) and United Nations Transitional Administration for Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Sirmium (UNTAES).
