missions.title: UNMOP Croatia
missions.subtitle: The Prevlaka Peninsula
missions.name: UNMOP Kroatien
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission of Observers in Prevlaka

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia had its roots in the desire for independence and in related acts of ethnic cleansing. There had been political tensions between the component states in Yugoslavia for years. Acts of war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation. A significant minority of Serbs lived in the border area in southern Croatia, near Bosnia. They were opposed to Croatia being independent from the federated structure. Armed hostilities erupted between Croat Serbs, supported by the Yugoslav army, and the Croats. The European Community attempted without success to end the fighting. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and worked to establish a foundation for a solution and, in 1991, to stop the flow of arms and ammunition to the area.  This did not bear fruit, and the next objective was a potential UN operation, initially to bring about a ceasefire. The UN in 1992 set up United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR). Its task was to reinstate peace and provide security in Yugoslavia with an emphasis on the unrest in Croatia. UNPROFOR I was sent to Croatia, UNPROFOR II was sent to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and UNPROFOR III was sent to Macedonia. Within UNPROFOR I, UN observers in 1992 were sent to Prevlaka in the southern part of Croatia where they were tasked with informing and reporting on violations of human rights and with monitoring the demilitarisation of the Prevlaka area. UNPROFOR I was dissolved in 1995 when the government of Croatia no longer permitted the presence of the force in the area. The UN Security Council therefore approved a restructuring of UNPROFOR I in Croatia by setting up a new operation named the United Nations Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia (UNCRO) in which the UN observers continued their work. UNCRO was established on 31 March 1995 and soon ran into serious problems with the Croats who under Operation Storm retook two of the four areas included in UNCRO. These areas were Sector North and Sector West, patrolled by Danes. That is how the Croats got control of the Krajina area, the part of Croatia that had been occupied by Serb forces at the start of the war. The retaking of the Krajina area led to the dissolution of UNCRO on 15 January 1996. Although the UN soldiers were no longer required, there was still a need for the UN observers in Prevlaka who could no longer operate under the terminated UNCRO. An independent observation mission was set up on 15 January 1996 under the nameUN Mission of Observers in Prevlaka (UNMOP). During the time UNMOP operated in Prevlaka, the area remained secure and stable, and the mission was terminated on 15 December 2002.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The establishment of UNMOP was based on a continued need to monitor the demilitarisation of the area after the withdrawal of UNCRO soldiers from Croatia. The observers in addition were to patrol both sides of the border between Croatia and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro). UNMOP was set up on the basis of UN Security Council Resolution 1038 of 15 January 1996. UNMOP then operated in the Prevlaka area until 2002 when UN Resolution 1437 terminated it.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Denmark’s decision to provide a Danish observer to Prevlaka under UNMOP aligned with the general desire to contribute to the UN operations in the former Yugoslavia. The proposal for the decision, B95, was submitted by the Minister of Foreign Affairs. The proposal was approved on 18 September 1992 with 95 votes in favour, 28 votes opposed, and 2 votes undecided.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish contribution to UNMOP consisted of observers on rotation. In all, about 27 were sent to Prevlaka between 1996 and 2002 in collaboration with 21 other countries such as Ukraine, Russia, and Norway.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNMOP was active from 15 January 1996 to 15 December 2002. Denmark’s contribution lasted from the establishment of the mission until 1 October 2002.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The observers were tasked primarily with monitoring the demilitarisation of the Prevlaka Peninsula in Croatia. In addition, regular meetings were to be held with local authorities in order to strengthen collaboration, reduce tensions, and enhance security in the area. During this time, agreements were reached between Croatia and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia regarding the Prevlaka area through peaceful meetings; the UN observers were therefore no longer needed in the area.

missions.title: UNPREDEP Macedonia
missions.subtitle: USA and Denmark in Macedonia
missions.name: UNPREDEP Makedonien
missions.descriptiveName: UN Preventive Deployment Force in  FYROM

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The civil war in the former Yugoslavia had its roots in the desire for independence and in related acts of ethnic cleansing. There had been political tensions between the component states in Yugoslavia for years. Acts of war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation. A significant minority of Serbs lived in the border area in southern Croatia, near Bosnia. They were opposed to Croatia being independent from the federated structure. Armed hostilities erupted between Croat Serbs, supported by the Yugoslav army, and the Croats. The European Community attempted without success to end the fighting. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and worked to establish a foundation for a solution and, in 1991, to stop the flow of arms and ammunition to the area.  This did not bear fruit, and the next objective was a potential UN operation, initially to bring about a ceasefire. The UN in 1992 set up United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR). Its task was to reinstate peace and provide security in Yugoslavia with an emphasis on the unrest in Croatia. UNPROFOR I was divided into three parts: UNPROFOR I was sent to Croatia, UNPROFOR II was sent to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and UNPROFOR III was sent to Macedonia. UNPROFOR I was dissolved in 1995 when the government of Croatia no longer permitted the presence of the force in the area. The UN Security Council therefore approved a restructuring of UNPROFOR into three forces: The United Nations Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia (UNCRO) in Croatia, the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP) in Macedonia, and UNPROFOR II continuing in Bosnia and Herzegovina until December 1995. These three forces were collectively known as the United Nations Peace Force (UNPF). UNPREDEP, in reality the replacement for MACCOMD/UNPROFOR in Macedonia, was given the task of continuing the work done by UNPROFOR III to prevent the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia from spreading to Macedonia. The units were to patrol the western and northern borders and stabilise the security situation in Macedonia. UNPREDEP in addition was tasked with facilitating dialogue between the various groups at risk of getting into conflict with the others. MACCOMD/UNPROFOR and UNPREDEP were later praised expressly for creating dialogue and for reaching compromises with various segments of society in Macedonia.
When UNPREDEP closed itself down on 28 February 1999, Macedonia was still not without conflict. The minority Albanians felt that they were treated as second-class citizens. This brought on armed clashes between Albanians and Macedonian police. To dampen conflict, negotiations between the Macedonian government and Albanian representatives produced a peace agreement, known as the “Ohrid Framework Agreement”, on 13 August 2001. It stipulated that the Albanian resistance movement hand over up to 3,300 weapons for destruction.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for UNPREDEP may be seen as a continuation of the objectives set for UNPROFOR III and thus in reality as a continuation of MACCOMD/UNPROFOR: Work toward establishing a stable Macedonia, supervise the entry of persons into the country, and through dialogue make efforts to build Macedonia as an independent country. The mandate came about with UN Security Council Resolution 983 of 31 March 1995 and was then extended by Resolutions 1058 (1996) and 1186 (1998). It was terminated on 28 February 1999.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: UNPREDEP was established as a continuation of the UNPROFOR III (MACCOMD) mission in Macedonia that had received support from the Danish Parliament in 1993. Denmark joined Sweden, Norway, and Finland in setting up a Nordic force under Danish command. The Danish soldiers in UNPROFOR III would become part of the Nordic Battalion (NORDBAT 1), and then some of them would continue their work under UNPREDEP. Proposal B79 was introduced by the Minister of Defence and approved on 1 April 1993. The decision to assist the UN in Macedonia carried through when UNPREDEP was set up, and Parliament confirmed (during a question period) on 18 July 1998 that Denmark would continue to render support until the force could be disbanded.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: UNPREDEP from 31 March 1995 to 28 February 1999 consisted of 1,050 UN soldiers of whom about 90 were Danes. These 90 Danes worked in staff elements and smaller units.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNPREDEP was officially active from 31 March 1995 to 28 February 1999. China then vetoed an extension of the mandate for the mission. The Danish soldiers worked in UNPREDEP as of 31 March 1995, and the main portion of the Danish company returned on 23 March 1999.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: UNPREDEP tasked the forces with manning several observation posts and carrying out patrols along the western border with Albania. Reports were to be made to the UN with information about any hostile or otherwise suspicious behaviour at the Albanian border and about the refugee situation in the country. Although the Kosovo war renewed fears that the conflicts would escalate to Macedonia, the country remained stable and relatively peaceful throughout the time UNPREDEP was active. As a result, it has been described as a successful mission.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia was actually a series of wars of secession from Yugoslavia which involved ethnic cleansing. After several years of political tension between Yugoslavian states, war broke out in 1991 when Croatia and Slovenia left the Yugoslavian federation, soon followed by Bosnia-Herzegovina and Macedonia. War broke out in Croatia as the large Serb minority in the part of the country that bordered Bosnia was in opposition to Croatia’s independence and did not want to become part of the new country. This led to fighting between Croatian units and Croatian Serbs, who were supported by the Yugoslavian army. The same happened in Bosnia-Herzegovina, where Bosnian Serbs and the Yugoslavian army fought against Bosnian troops in an attempt to secure territory for Yugoslavia. While the UN tried to prevent the violent conflicts in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, the international community feared that the armed conflict would also escalate to include Macedonia. Macedonia had been able to steer relatively clear of violent confrontation after their referendum on the issue of independence. The UN had already set up the United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR), with UNPROFOR I stationed in Croatia and UNPROFOR II in Bosnia-Herzegovina. This led to the creation of UNPROFOR III in Macedonia, where the force was tasked with preventing an outbreak of hostilities. Unlike UNPROFOR I and II, UNPROFOR III was able to maintain stability in Macedonia. UNPROFOR III was also known as ”Macedonia Command”, the operation often being referred to as MACCOMD/UNPROFOR. UNPROFOR III kept the same designation until 1995, when it was renamed the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP), with status as an autonomous mission. When UNDPREDEP was wound down in February 1999 Macedonia was still affected by conflict. Macedonia’s Albanian minority felt treated like second-class citizens, which led to armed conflicts between Albanians and the Macedonian police. Action was required and led to a peace treaty known as the “Ohrid agreement”, concluded on 13 August 2001 by the Macedonian Government and Albanian representatives. The agreement meant that up to 3,300 weapons were handed in for destruction by the Albanian resistance.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: Aiming to prevent conflict spreading from Bosnia-Herzegovina to Macedonia, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 795 of 11 December 1992 on the deployment of a deterrent UN force to Macedonia to nip any conflict in the bud. It was decided that military and civilian administrative personnel would be deployed to Macedonia to increase the probability that Macedonia’s transition from sub-state to independent country would proceed peacefully. The mandate also included monitoring the borders between Macedonia, Albania and Serbia.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish Parliament approved Balkan aid, which now included Macedonia. Denmark worked together with Sweden, Norway and Finland to put together a Scandinavian force (Nordic Battalion(NORDBAT 1)) under Danish command. The Danish contribution to the Macedonia mission initially involved the deployment of eight personnel that would later be reinforced by a company from each country and a joint staff company. The UNPROFOR III  mission operated until and including 1995. The Danish Minister of Defence put forward Parliamentary Proposal B79, which was adopted on 1 April 1993 with 116 votes in favour, eight against and one abstention.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Before its 1995 transition to UNPREDEP i 1995 the Danish MACCOM/UNPROFOR mission numbered approx. 70 personnel who would operate as a deterrent. From 1994, 40 of these personnel served as part of Scandinavian Company (SCANCOY), which had been deployed as a rapid deployment unit as part of the joint Scandinavian NORDBAT 1 battalion.
What made MACCOMD/UNPROFOR unusual was that the force was reinforced by 300 American troops in July 1993, which would be the first time the USA had participated in a UN peacekeeping mission. It was also the first time that American forces were under the command of a non-American (the Danish commander).

The Danish police also contributed a number of officers to the mission in Macedonia.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: MACCOMD/UNPROFOR III was set up in December 1992, continuing until 31 March 1995, when UNPROFOR I andIII were restructured. This meant that UNPROFOR I/II/III was split into three forces: The United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP) in Macedonia,  The United Nations Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia (UNCRO) and UNPROFOR II, which continued in Bosnia-Herzegovina until December 1995. It would be replaced by NATO and EU missions as a result of the Dayton agreement. The three forces were known collectively as the United Nations Peace Force (UNPF). Danish forces served in UNPROFOR III from 22 January 1993 to 31 March 1995, after which the police mission was assigned to UNPREDEP.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The overall task of the mission was to prevent the outbreak of unrest because of the difficult conflicts that erupted when Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Macedonia seceded from the Yugoslavian federation. Similar to their role in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, the forces would report troop movements, ensure a relationship to Macedonia’s civilian populace and authorities, as well as dealing with any conflicts that might arise. UNCIVPOL police would monitor the Macedonian border police. Because there were no major problems in Macedonia when compared to the other countries, the mission was successful in stabilising Macedonia and ensuring that the process was relatively peaceful.

missions.title: ECMM/EUMM Yugoslavia
missions.subtitle: EU observers - known as “the milkmen”
missions.name: ECMM/EUMM Jugoslavien
missions.descriptiveName: EU observers in the former Yugoslavia

text.heading: Background
text.text: In the beginning of the 1990s a number of armed conflicts broke out in the former Yugoslavia, as several of the country’s regions wanted independence. These included Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Macedonia. Unrest rapidly escalated into armed conflict between the various population groups and soon Bosnians, Croats and Serbs were fighting against each other. After fighting broke out, the European Council negotiated an agreement in 1991 on the creation of an EU force of observers, who would monitor and work to support ceasefire agreements in the regions. This force was named European Community Monitoring Mission (ECMM) and was intended to operate as a neutral unarmed force that could promote dialogue between the various parties, promote the conclusion of treaties and to gather and analyse information about the situation in the various areas. Monitoring of human rights and the needs of the civilian population was given high priority. Initially ECMM was only mandated to operate in Bosnia and Croatia, but the mandate was extended in 1992 to include Bulgaria, Hungary and Albania. This extended mandate was necessary as there was concern that unrest and armed conflict would spread to these countries, where ECMM operated through the 90s and into the new millennium. ECMM was then renamed as European Union Monitoring Mission (EUMM) in 2000.  The mission ran until 2007.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate to operate in the former Yugoslavia was based on the July 1991 Brioni declaration. The declaration was an agreement between the EU and Yugoslavia, as well as its regions: Serbia, Slovenia and Croatia, who accepted the deployment of EU observers to the various regions. The declaration and mandate were intended to form a basis for negotiations between the conflicted parties. One way this would be achieved would be by concluding long-term ceasefire agreements, with the EU observers as intermediaries. The mandate would have particular focus on Slovenia and Croatia, as this regions were particularly affected by conflict at this time. Even though focus was on those countries, ECMM would also operate in Bosnia-Herzegovina. Here, it would perform tasks such as organising humanitarian convoy routes in and to Bosnia-Herzegovina from Croatia. In this regard, ECMM was authorised to request back up from UNPROFOR II if the presence of UN troops was required during the transport mission.  The mandate for the mission was extended in 1992 to also include Bulgaria, Hungary and Albania and was then extended again on various occasions during the 1990s (including an agreement in the Hague in October 1991) and during the 00s. The EU concluded its observation operations in the former Yugoslavia on 31 December 2007.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Danish participation involving personnel from Danish Defence, the foreign service, the Police and Emergency Management Services was based on a government decision from July 1991. The background was a request from the Dutch chairmanship of the EU to member states for contributions to the mission. The Government presented its recommendations for Danish participation to the Foreign Affairs Committee in July 1991. Danish participation initially involved 5-6 people and varied in size as the mission progressed. During the Danish EU chairmanship in 1992/93, approximately 60 Danes were serving with ECMM. In December 2000 ECMM changed its name to EUMM, with continued Danish participation until the mission ended at the end of December 2007.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark deployed 461 people, mainly from Danish Defence and the Danish police, to ECMM/EUMMs missions in the former Yugoslavia, including soldiers from the Jaeger Corps who operated as bodyguards. The EU observers were unarmed and all wore white uniforms, which is why they were nicknamed “the milkmen”. When ECMM was renamed EUMM, the total force was reduced to 160. The Danish contribution between 2000 and 2007 was 9 people a year.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: ECMM/EUMM was active in the former Yugoslavia from July 1991 to December 2007. Denmark was an active participant from 1991 until the end of December 2007, when the last person left the conflict area.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: One of the priority areas of activity for those deployed was to encourage the conclusion and compliance with ceasefires and to establish and promote dialogue between the conflicted parties. It was therefore important that ECMM/EUMM was and would be considered a neutral force that served only as a medium for setting up ceasefire agreements. As well as establishing a basis for ceasefire agreements, the observers would also try to reduce troop numbers in the conflict areas. In the beginning of the 1990s, these two primary missions would prove to be some of the most effective measures towards peace. Had they not been implemented, the horrors of this conflict would have been somewhat worse. ECMM would be assigned to many more varying missions over the years. These included providing humanitarian aid to civilians and refugees, acting as negotiators when handing over captured individuals and making protective arrangements for humanitarian convoys. Humanitarian aid for civilians and refugees was provided in collaboration with The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). Convoy protection duties were performed by The United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR).

missions.title: CSCE & OSCE Yugoslavia
missions.subtitle: Keeping an eye on the conflict
missions.name: CSCE & OSCE Jugoslavien

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The civil war in the former Yugoslavia arose from a desire for independence and led to ethnic cleansing. After several years of political strife between Yugoslavia’s various states, war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from federal Yugoslavia. There had already been ten days of fighting in Slovenia, but the violence was not as extreme as what would later be seen in the Balkans.

The Serbian minority in Croatia opposed becoming part of a Croatian state. Fighting erupted between Croats and Serbs living in the border area between Croatia and Bosnia. The Yugoslavian army actively participated in this war. The European Community undertook several initiatives to end the fighting, but to no avail. Parallel to this, the UN had become involved through a number of meetings with the opposing parties, while also having been able to introduce a number of restrictions in 1991 with regard to the transportation of arms and munitions to Yugoslavia. These meetings did not bear fruit, so a possible UN operation in Yugoslavia was discussed at the same time, focusing initially on a ceasefire. The international community's initial involvement in the Balkans largely took the form of observers who were deployed to inform and report on humanitarian issues and to try and minimise human rights violations.  It was also hoped that the conflicted parties would allow themselves to be demilitarised. Some of these observers were posted by the UN’s Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (CSCE/OSCE), which also saw participation by Danes. The tasks of the observers were very difficult, as the conflict between Serbs, Croats and Bosnians often led to violent confrontations between the opposing factions. These working conditions were far from optimal.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The CSCE/OSCE mandates evolved over the years, depending on the situation on the ground and the areas where the observers were deployed. One of the first mandates to support CSCE/OSCE operations in the former Yugoslavia was established in 1992 by The Committee of Senior Officials (CSO), focusing on operations in Kosovo. At that time, Kosovo was still part of Serbia. CSCE/OSCE observers arrived in Kosovo during September 1992, where they would gather information about human rights violations and other issues. They would also gain an overview of Kosovo’s minorities. It was also decided under the same mandate that the CSCE/OSCE observers would be deployed in Macedonia during September 1992. The primary objective here was to prevent the conflict in the former Yugoslavia from spreading to Macedonia, for example by observing activities at the Macedonian border with Serbia to see if there was any activity that might indicate a Serbian involvement in Macedonia. A similar mission was set up under CSCEauspices in Hungary, under British command and known as Sanctions Assistance Mission (SAM). The task of this mission was to monitor compliance with the trade restrictions that had been introduced against Serbia and Montenegro. The Danish tax, customs and excise authority provided observers for this mission. The Danish tax, customs and excise authority would later deploy personnel to Croatia, to perform the same duties. After these deployments, CSCE/OSCE was mandated by UN Security Resolution 1031 in December 1995 to assist with elections and ensure compliance with the Dayton agreement in Bosnia-Herzegovina.  In addition to the presences in Macedonia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, agreement was reached with the Croatian government that an OSCE mission would be established in Croatia from July 1996. But the CSCE/OSCE did not stop here. Kosovo was also covered by a new mandate under UN Security Council Resolution 1244 on 10 June 1999. The mandate was the basis for The OSCE Mission in Kosovo (OMIK) from July 1999. The missions in Kosovo concerned the broad but significant investigations of human rights violations, establishing elections and the monitoring of Kosovo as it demilitarised.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish decision to take part was the beginning of a contribution that would see Denmark engaged on many fronts over the years, supporting various organisations in the former Yugoslavia, including the UN, EU and OSCE. The Minister of Foreign Affairs put forward Parliamentary Proposal B95, which was adopted on 18 September 1992 with 95 votes in favour, 28 against and 6 abstentions.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Denmark sent 50 observers to the former Yugoslavia under CSCE/OSCE auspices.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
CSCE/OSCE was active in the former Yugoslavia from 1992 and is still active in the present day. The first mission in Kosovo ran from 8 September 1992 to 29 April 1993. The second mission to Kosovo, named The OSCE Mission in Kosovo, operated from 1 July 1999 to 10 December 2001. CSCE/OSCE was in Macedonia from 10 September 1992 and is still active in the present day, operating under the name OSCE-Mission to Skopje. CSCE/OSCE was active in Bosnia-Herzegovina from 29 December 1995 and is still active in the present day, operating under the name OSCE-Mission to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The organisation was active in Croatia from 4 July 1996 to 31 December 2007. The SAM mission in Hungary was active from the end of 1993 to the end of 1995.
Denmark participated in the period 1992-2000.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The observer’s duties were those you would expect of observers: to establish contact and engage in dialogue with the local authorities, documenting events (where possible) and to report about them and to monitor compliance with trade restrictions etc. by road and waterway. The observers would also be involved with the task of demilitarising the various areas and de-escalating the armed conflict.  Observers were part of the international community’s eyes and ears in the Balkans, a task that would be performed under difficult conditions because of the violent fighting and human rights violations.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The civil war in the former Yugoslavia had its roots in the desire for independence and in related acts of ethnic cleansing. There had been political tensions between the component states in Yugoslavia for years. Acts of war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation. A significant minority of Serbs lived in the border area in southern Croatia, near Bosnia. They were opposed to Croatia being independent from the federated structure. Armed hostilities erupted between Croat Serbs, supported by the Yugoslav army, and the Croats. The European Community attempted without success to end the fighting. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and worked to establish a foundation for a solution and, in 1991, to stop the flow of arms and ammunition to the area. This did not bear fruit, and the next objective was a potential UN operation, initially to bring about a ceasefire. The UN in 1992 set up United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR). Its task was to reinstate peace and provide security in Yugoslavia with an emphasis on the unrest in Croatia.

The plan for UNPROFOR was based on two key elements: A) Getting the Yugoslav People’s Army (JNA) out of Croatia (it was a key player in the conflict) and putting an end to the military conflicts; and B) supporting and helping local authorities and police in conflict-ridden areas to avoid a failure of local governance. To this end, the United Nations Protected Areas (UNPAs) mission was established, with UNPROFOR having a special mandate. The overall mandate permitted the UN force to disarm the warring parties, control the UNPAs, and support police in protecting human rights and preventing discrimination. In Croatia, the work was done by UNPROFOR I; UNPROFOR II was active in Bosnia and Herzegovina; and UNPROFOR III operated in Macedonia. UNPROFOR I was dissolved in 1995 when the Croatian government no longer permitted the presence of the force in the area. The UN Security Counciltherefore approved a restructuring of UNPROFOR into three forces: The United Nations Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia (UNCRO) in Croatia; the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP) in Macedonia; and UNPROFOR II continuing in Bosnia and Herzegovina until December 1995. These three forces were collectively known as United Nations Peace Force (UNPF).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The UN Security Council decided in Resolution 743 to set up UNPROFOR I with a military force, a police force, and a civilian component in an effort to reduce conflict in Croatia and demilitarise certain areas in the country. Since the establishment of UNPROFOR I, there were several expansions of the mandate, for example to give the force access to so-called ”pink zones”, areas of Croatia controlled by JNA (the Yugoslav People's Army) and populated primarily by Serbs.  These “pink zones” were outside the areas included in the UNPAs, and it was therefore necessary to approve a separate mandate under Resolution 762 of 30 June 1992 in order to allow the UN forces to operate in them. The mandate was further expanded in 1992 such that UNPROFOR I had authority to control the movements of civilians in and out of the UNPAs for the purpose of managing migration. These initiatives improved the situation temporarily, but new conflicts erupted in 1993 between Serbs and Croats. It was now necessary to intensify the attempts at securing a ceasefire between the warring parties, and yet another mandate was thus approved by Resolution 802 of 25 January 1993.  This attempt failed to bring about a lasting ceasefire, and fighting continued.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Proposal B95 for Denmark to participate in UNPROFOR was approved by Parliament on 18 September 1992 with 95 votes in favour, 28 votes opposed, and 2 votes undecided. The approval did include a stipulation that working in the mission be voluntary for Danish personnel. However, in some cases it might be necessary to order the participation of officers and commanders. In 1993, support to UNPROFOR I was increased by adding medical services personnel such as physicians, nurses, and nursing assistants. In addition, capacity was added in the form of armoured cars, armoured mortar sections, and an antitank rocket platoon with TOW missiles. This added capacity included 100 personnel. Proposal B79 was introduced by the Minister of Defence and approved on 1 April 1993 with 116 votes in favour and 8 votes opposed. In 1994, Parliament decided to contribute an air support coordination team to UNPROFOR I. The impetus for this was that the UN and NATO would be deploying air support in Croatia as indicated in the proposal: ”When the mandate for UNPROFOR was extended on 31 March 1994 (Resolution 908), the UN Security Council decided to expand the authorisation for providing air support for protection of UN troops during the execution of their mandate such that the authorisation includes Croatian territory”. It was the Danish government’s view that the team sent to Croatia ought to be given working conditions similar to those of the team sent to Tuzla in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Proposal B34 was approved on 16 December 1994 with 123 votes in favour and 14 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution in Croatia under UNPROFOR I included a total of 5,600 army personnel.  The contribution consisted, among other things, of:

- An air support coordination team,
- Staff companies,
- An infantry battalion,
- An antitank rocket platoon (TOW),
- Military police,
- An engineer detachment,
- Medical services (physicians, nurses, and nursing assistants) and
- Observers

The first 30 Danish police officers were dispatched on 22 March 1992 to be deployed in UNPA Sector North in the municipalities of Kostajnica, Petrinja, Dvor, Glina, Vrginmost, Vojnic and Slunj, plus the sector headquarters in Topusko. In July 2992, the Danish police contingent was expanded, and officers were now deployed also in Sectors South, East, and West.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNPROFOR I was active from 21 February 1992 to 31 March 1995 when it was transferred to the United Nations Confidence Restoration Operation in Croatia (UNCRO). It operated from 31 March 1995 to 1 January 1996. Denmark contributed to UNPROFOR I from April 1992 to 31 March 1995 when the Croatian government no longer permitted the presence of UNPROFOR I as it was constituted at the time. Therefore, the UN decided to terminate UNPROFOR I. The Danish soldiers continued under UNCRO as of 31 March 1995. UNCRO ran into serious difficulty when Croatian forces attacked it between 4 and 7 August 1995 in what is known as Operation Storm and took control of two of the four UNCRO areas. These areas were Danish-patrolled Sector North and Sector West. Croatia now had control of the Krajina area, the part of the country that had been occupied by Serbian forces at the beginning of the war. The retaking of the Krajina area obviated the need for the UN forces, and the Danes were recalled from UNCRO in October 1995. The last Danish soldier left the area on 1 December 1995. As for UNPROFOR II in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the operation continued until 20 December 1995 when it was terminated by the Dayton Agreement. UNPROFOR III in Macedonia ended on 31 March 1995. According to the UN, UNPROFOR III was terminated when Macedonia requested a restructuring of the existing size and makeup of UNPROFOR. UNPROFOR III was restructured, and the new operation was named the United Nations Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP). The Danes working in UNPROFOR III transitioned to UNPREDEP as of 31 March 1995. They stayed in UNPREDEP until 23 March 1999, one month after its termination.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The UN had divided Croatia into protection areas (UNPAs) in which, as an example, all weapons were to be collected in depots. The Danish forces were to work with forces from Nigeria and Poland in looking after the area known as Sector North/UNPROFOR). The key tasks were related to peacekeeping and included prevention of fighting, carrying out patrols, manning observation and control posts, maintaining contact with local authorities, and confiscating weapons and keeping them in depots. Coordination was at times a challenge due to language barriers and differences in culture among the international forces. Still, success was achieved in the first few months in terms of getting the Serbian militias to surrender many of their weapons, and overall, the level of threat was reduced in the time up until the end of 1992. Then, new fighting erupted, and the level of threat increased. In this situation, air support coordination teams were sent to Sector North to assist NATO planes in any action to protect NATO forces.

The police mission was to monitor local police work and see to it that human rights were upheld and that discrimination did not occur, plus assist in investigations.

images.title: En våd dag i Bosnien
images.caption: A wet and cold day in Bosnia

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia had its roots in the desire for independence and in related acts of ethnic cleansing. There had been political tensions between the component states in Yugoslavia for years. Acts of war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation. A significant minority of Serbs lived in the border area in southern Croatia, near Bosnia. They were opposed to Croatia being independent from the federated structure. Armed hostilities erupted between Croat Serbs, supported by the Yugoslav army, and the Croats. The European Community attempted without success to end the fighting. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and worked to establish a foundation for a solution and, in 1991, to stop the flow of arms and ammunition to the area.  This did not bear fruit, and the next objective was a potential UN operation, initially to bring about a ceasefire. The UN in 1992 set up United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR). Its task was to reinstate peace and provide security in Yugoslavia. Initially, UNPROFOR entered Croatia, but it was soon apparent that more was needed if there were to be any sustained hope of peace in a Yugoslavia plagued by civil war. Thus UNPROFOR was expanded to include Bosnia and Herzegovina under the name UNPROFOR II. There were many challenges here – key among them the clashes and hostilities between Bosnian Muslims and Croats and between these and the Bosnian Serbs who enjoyed significant support in the Serbian state within Yugoslavia, not to mention the critical humanitarian situation for civilians. As the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina did not improve, Denmark (and the UN) in 1994 for the first time decided to use heavy weapons, in the form of an tank squadron, in a peacekeeping mission. UNPROFOR II in Bosnia and Herzegovina was terminated in December 1995 upon the signing in Paris of the Dayton Agreement, a treaty between Bosnia, Croatia, and Serbia, on 14 December 1995. The goal had been to halt the armed conflicts in Bosnia and Herzegovina that had gone on for three and a half years. In an effort to cement compliance with the agreement, the tasks were now transferred to NATO in operation Implementation Force (IFOR).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UNPROFOR II was established as a continuation of UN Security Council Resolution 743 of 21 February 1992. Initially, the mandate was aimed at Croatia, but once UNPROFOR I was set up, it was expanded several times. When conflicts escalated from Croatia across its borders, the mandate was expanded to include Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Serbia, and Montenegro. UN Security Council Resolution 758 of 8 June 1992 included a separate humanitarian mandate to place the Sarajevo airport under UN control and protection. This airport was key to the mission in that humanitarian aid landed here for distribution to areas in need within Yugoslavia. The warring parties agreed to offer protection to the personnel distributing aid to civilians. One early achievement was an agreement to transfer control of the Sarajevo airport from Bosnian Serbs to the UN. This agreement was soon breached by fighting between Bosnian Serbs and Bosnian forces in the area around the airport. This was a complication for the overall UN effort and necessitated a significant presence of forces to protect the airport. The mandate came from UN Security Council Resolution 758 of 8 June 1992.

Humanitarian work was at risk of attack not just in the Sarajevo airport. Therefore, the UN Security Council approved a special humanitarian aid mandate (Resolution 776 of 14 September 1992) to enable UNPROFOR II to protect humanitarian aid organisations such as the United Nations Refugee Agency UNHCR and the Red Cross. The mandate further provided that UNPROFOR II was authorised to engage in self defence if it or the humanitarian convoys were fired on during transport of emergency aid.

Later, the UN approved a peacekeeping mandate (Resolution 787 of 16 November 1992) to have the borders of Bosnia and Herzegovina controlled by UN soldiers and observers for the purpose of seizing weapons and explosives before they entered the country.
By UN Resolution 824 of 6 May 1993, the so-called ”safe zones” were designated, primarily for the Muslim population, in the municipalities of Sarajevo, Tuzla, Zepa, Gorazde, Bihac, and Srebrenica in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish Parliament’s approval for providing personnel to the UN peacekeeping forces UNPROFOR I and II in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina included a provision that the participation by individuals be voluntary if possible. However, it might still be necessary to order the participation of some officers and commanders. Proposal B95 was approved at an extraordinary session on 18. september 1992 with 95 votes in favour, 28 votes opposed, and 2 abstentions.

Approximately one year after the first Danish contribution had been provided, Parliament approved an expansion of the Danish engagement in UNPROFOR II. Formal comments appended to the proposal noted that the impetus was an expansion of the mandate of UNPROFOR II within UNPAs (United Nations Protected Areas) around several mostly Muslim municipalities (the so-called ”safe zones”). UN forces would thus be authorised to use force to defend against attacks on the safe zones. The Nordic countries jointly offered the UN a Nordic force named NORDBAT II including a tank squadron numbering 115 personnel. In addition, personnel were offered to perform coordination of support from NATO planes. Proposal B107 was approved on 17 August 1993 with 105 votes in favour, 17 votes opposed, and 1 vote undecided.
That year, Denmark in addition decided to expand the headquarters company of UNPROFOR in Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to enhance its capacity in medical services and armoured transport and to improve the safety of personnel and the ability to mount close range defence. Proposal B79 was introduced by the Minister of Defence and approved on 1 April 1993 with 116 votes in favour, 8 votes opposed, and 1 vote undecided.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark contributed to the work in Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1992 to 1995 by sending about 1,700 personnel from the armed forces. Some of them were part of a company that was replaced every six months. Denmark’s contribution, made in various places throughout the country, consisted of:

- An air support coordination team,
 - A tank squadron with 10 Leopard 1 tanks (the well-known “Snow Leopards” painted UN white),
- A headquarters company,
- Infantry,
- Military police,
- An engineer detachment,
- A medical team (physicians, nurses, and nursing assistants) and
- Observers

The contribution included not only military on the ground but also C-130 flights carrying passengers and humanitarian aid to Sarajevo. The flights took place in warlike conditions presenting high risk.
When the Sarajevo airport was opened in July 1992, Danish police officers were deployed there.

Danish crewmembers were part of Operation Sky Monitor and Deny Flight with NATOs AWACS system.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNPROFOR II was active from 14 September 1992 to 20 December 1995. As of 8 November 1992, Denmark contributed a Headquarters Company (HQCOY) in Bosnia and Herzegovina to UNPROFOR II. Later, a tank squadron was provided to NORBAT II.   Danish forces remained with UNPROFOR II until January 1996 or were transferred to NATO-led operation IFOR. For example, the tank squadron was transferred to NATO at the end of December. The police mission ended in December 1995 and was replaced by United Nations International Police Task Force (UNMIBH).

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The Danes carried out many types of tasks in Bosnia and Herzegovina including protection of humanitarian convoys. In addition, the tasks included convoy operations and security, surveillance, retrieval of weapons, reporting on activities, and protection of the airport in Tuzla. As the general level of threat in Bosnia and Herzegovina rose during the first half of the 1990s, Denmark contributed a tank squadron as of 1994. This squadron will be remembered for “Operation Hooligan Bashing” in April 1994. The operation had a significant influence on attitudes toward future peacekeeping operations. When the airport in Sarajevo was opened, the police contingent was tasked with ensuring that only humanitarian aid arrived there.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
1 February 1953 saw the worst North Sea tidal waves that had been seen in modern times. These caused several dykes in the Netherlands to break, resulting in approximately 2,000 deaths. The extensive flooding in the South West part of the Netherlands resulted in the need to evacuate several thousand people and about 100,000 animals.
Dutch resources in the form of civilian and military organisations were primarily employed in securing the broken dykes. Additional to this, capacity was needed for the interior transportation of supplies to the populace. This mission was performed with aid from several European countries.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
Danish participation was granted by a decision made by the Danish government.
The Danish Ministry of the Interior gave the Emergency Management Agency the task of transporting emergency aid in the form of blankets etc. to the Netherlands and to then assist the Dutch authorities with interior transportation of supplies to the areas that were affected by the disaster.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Transportation of donated supplies to the Netherlands, followed by interior transport within the Netherlands.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 6 - 24 February 1953.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The task force, which was comprised of 17 vehicles and 35 men from the Emergency Management Agency was sent out from Haderslev Barracks with 40 tonnes of emergency aid in the form of blankets and other equipment for those evacuated.
The task force was also assigned the mission of transporting supplies from Amsterdam's airport to various warehouses in Rotterdam and onwards to the affected areas. Over the 18 day period, a total of 67,000 km (41,632 miles) was driven and 1,800 tonnes of food and medicines etc. were transported.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Hungarian Revolution began on 23 October 1956. Hungarian students began demonstrating to support Poland, where the Stalinist government had been forced to step down. Thousands of people joined the student demonstrations for better conditions in Hungary and the reinstatement of Imre Nagy as leader of the government.
Over the following days, the demonstrations grew in strength and fighting between the people and the authorities increased. Numerous people were killed when the army and Soviet tanks opened fire on those demonstrating. This led to increased demonstrations throughout Hungary.
On 1 November, Imre Nagy’s government announced that Hungary had cancelled its membership of the Warsaw Pact. On 3 November, the government and the Soviet authorities agreed that Soviet forces would leave Hungary by 15 January 1957.
At dawn on 4 November, Soviet troops invaded Hungary. Hungarian resistance ceased after a few days of fighting.
The consequences were mass arrests and approximately 200,000 people fled the country. Extreme measures were also taken that greatly reduced the population’s freedom of movement. Just a few months after the revolution all popular opposition had been crushed.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
A decision by the Danish government to send aid to Hungary by donating a fully-equipped aid hospital, including doctors and nurses etc.
The Emergency Management Agency was authorised via the Danish Ministry of the Interior to perform the mission of transporting and constructing the aid hospital, the running of which would then be assigned to the Danish Red Cross.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The aid hospital was in storage in Højrup on Funen and had to be prepared and transported to Odense for loading onto goods wagons for further transport by special train.
The transport departed from Odense on 1 November and arrived in Vienna the following day. It was not until 13 November that authorisation was granted to cross the border into Hungary, carrying limited resources in the form of food and medicines. During the wait time, the doctors, nurses and technical personnel were made available to assist refugees in the Vienna area.
A total of 68 people took part: officers, middle managers and conscripts.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 29 October to 11 December 1956. The team was able to return to Austria on 5 December and then came back home to Denmark.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Preparation, transportation, construction and operation of aid hospital in Budapest.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In Poland at the end of the 1970s, a struggling national economy led to goods shortages and high price rises for groceries and everyday items. This situation led to unrest and strikes. The unrest led to the formation of the Solidarity trade union. Solidarity and its demands for economic reforms, liberalisation and free trade unions would be pivotal to the future of Poland.
The communist regime intervened on 13 December 1981 and declared martial law. Borders were closed and public communications were shut down. Manufacture and electrical supply were reduced. After just a few weeks, supplies of everyday necessities and medicines were so low that it became necessary to request foreign aid because of the risk of famine, which would be fatal to children and the elderly.
On 18 December 1981, Danish Red Cross asked the Danish government and the Emergency Management Agency to provide vehicles and personnel for emergency aid transport shipments to Poland.

text.heading: Mandat & Decision
text.text:
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided to fulfil this request.
The Ministry of the Interior decided that the Emergency Management Agency and Danish Red Cross would perform this mission as a state donation by joint venture.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Transportation of emergency aid would involve three convoys.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: From 22 December 1981 to 24 January 1982.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Transportation of emergency supplies to Poland and internal distribution in the country as advised by the Polish authorities
Convoy 1 was comprised of four lorries and departed from Ysted on 23 December, headed for Swinousjcie and onward to Lodz in central Poland. It then headed to Radomska in the southern part of Poland. The emergency aid (2,000 blankets, 1.5 tonnes of medicines and hospital equipment and 5.2 tonnes of hand soap) was delivered according to schedule. The convoy returned to Denmark on 27 December.
Convey 2 was comprised of 11 lorries. On 2 January 1982, it departed from Ystad, headed for Swinoujscie, continuing on its route to Bydgoszcz and then Gdansk. The cargo was 6,000 food packages for the elderly, 1,000 kg (2,200 lbs) of penicillin and 2,000 woollen blankets. The convoy returned to Denmark on 6 January.
Convoy 3 was comprised of 11 lorries, departing from Frihavn in Copenhagen on 20 January and headed directly to Swinoujscie. The cargo was 4,000 food packages of 5 kg (11 lbs) for children aged 0-3 years and 3,000 packages for children aged 3-7 years. The packages were to be delivered to the towns of Bydgoszcz, Lodz and Chichanow. The convoy returned to Denmark on 24 January.
In total, the three convoys transported 91 tonnes of emergency aid on 26 lorries. The personnel involved were 20 officers (commissioned and non-commissioned) and 39 conscripts.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
By the end of 1992, the war in the former Yugoslavia had escalated to such a degree that it became necessary to send a humanitarian mission to support populations in isolated villages and rural areas.
The military and political situation in the Balkans is describe in UNPROFOR.
The European Commission contacted Denmark in the autumn of 1992 about the possibility of aid in the form of emergency transports to Bosnia’s isolated town populations.

text.heading: Mandat & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Government.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The establishment of a self-sufficient transport unit and the posting of emergency aid experts.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: December 1992 - April 1995.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
To build a transport unit, that would be called European Community Task Force (ECTF). The unit belonged under the EU but performed missions on behalf of the UN. It was based in the Bosnian town of Zenica.
The unit was comprised of 12 Mercedes Benz 911 lorries and two Toyota Landcruiser light vehicles. The unit also brought with it a complete workshop to support the operation and maintenance of the vehicle pool. When on convoy missions, the unit was escorted by British armoured vehicles. The smaller lorries turned out to be particularly well-suited to driving on the poor quality roads in mountainous areas.
Drivers were mainly recruited from recalled conscripts. Each team had 18 drivers. There was also a leadership group and a five-strong workshop squad. Personnel were recruited locally as required.
A new team of drivers and officers continued the transport mission at the beginning of May 1993. For the first month there were no notable problems apart from uncertainty about the military situation in the country.
1 June 1993 saw an atrocity that became a dark day in the history of the Emergency Management Agency.
The convoy that was sent from Zenica to the town of Maglaj was comprised of nine lorries, each packed with emergency aid for the UNHCR’s (UN High Commissioner for Refugees) stores, a convoy leader vehicle and two passenger vehicles. The unit was escorted by three British tanks. Maglaj had been shelled by artillery earlier that morning. The situation was now calm and the first two lorries and the convoy leader drove to the storage facility in Maglaj. The rest of the convoy was parked in a road tunnel approximately 5 km (3 miles) from the town. During unloading, the town was shelled and the population took cover.
Meanwhile, the vehicles in the tunnel came under fire before the personnel were able to reach safety in the escort vehicles. Two Danish drivers and a local interpreter were killed in this attack. Two people were badly injured and four of the other drivers received minor lacerations. The wounded were taken in the British tanks to the local hospital in Zenica where their injuries were treated. The wounded were later diagnosed by Danish doctors and were sent back home for treatment in Denmark.
Emergency aid convoy operations continued until mid-1995 after the security situation had improved greatly.
Two emergency aid experts were also sent from Denmark to support the UN and the International Red Cross. The Emergency Management Agency deployed a total of 173 personnel over the duration of the entire mission.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In the early 1990s, Yugoslavia broke apart. For many reasons, increasing tensions had arisen in the 1980s among the states making up the country. They culminated at the Congress of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia held in 1990 to address and solve the problems in the country. No agreement could be reached, however, and several delegations abandoned the Congress. During the year, a multi-party election was held for the first time. Nationalist parties achieved popular support. On 25 July 1991, Slovenia and Croatia declared independence. There was considerable unrest in the multi-ethnic state Bosnia-Herzegovina.
In August of that year, Slovenia won independence after a war lasting just 10 days. Meanwhile, Croatia found itself in a protracted war of independence fought against the Yugoslav government in Belgrade and against the minority population of Krajina Serbs who wished to remain in Yugoslavia. As the EC and the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) attempted to negotiate ceasefires, the international community watched with alarm as Bosnia-Herzegovina came ever closer to a total breakdown, Macedonia wanted independence, and the government in Belgrade tried to clamp down on the independence movements.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In hopes of preventing war, the UN Security Council unanimously decided to limit access to arms. Resolution 713 (1991) condemned acts of war, encouraged implementation of the ceasefire being negotiated by the EC, and prohibited all imports of arms and war materiel to Yugoslavia’s states and the remaining federation.
Although a ceasefire between Croatia and Yugoslavia finally came about at the beginning of 1992, a referendum in Bosnia-Herzegovina had resulted in a majority vote for independence. The referendum, however, was boycotted by the large Serbian minority in the country. In May, when the hostilities in Bosnia-Herzegovina escalated significantly, the embargo was extended by Resolution 757 (1992). It sanctioned the rest of Yugoslavia by prohibiting all imports and exports except for humanitarian aid, i.e. food and medicine.
Neither Resolution 713 (1991) nor the even more restrictive Resolution 757 (1992) contained a mandate to enforce the embargo. The Security Council imposed a demand on all UN member countries to cease trading with Yugoslavia, but did not implement any process to ensure compliance. That is why the UN on 15 June requested that NATO provide surveillance in the Adriatic Sea. The NATO Standing Naval Force Mediterranean, STANAVFORMED, was therefore deployed with Operation Maritime Monitor. In November, the mandate was further expanded by Resolution 787 (1992) authorising inspections and boarding of ships suspected of breaking the embargo. At that point, Maritime Monitor was terminated and replaced by Operation Maritime Guard.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: No explicit parliamentary approval was given in Denmark to contribute to Maritime Monitor. Denmark provides ongoing support to the NATO collaboration, partly by providing naval ships to NATO’s permanent forces. In September 1992, the corvette Niels Juel was a part of NATO’s Standing Naval Forces Atlantic, STANAVFORLANT, when it replaced STANAVFORMED in the operation.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The corvette Niels Juel took part in Operation Maritime Monitor as a component of her regular duties in STANAVFORLANT. A corvette in the Niels Juel class was armed with an extensive arsenal of anti-ship and surface-to-air missiles, a 76 mm cannon, depth charges, and 7 heavy machine guns. The typical crew on a ship of that type was approximately 90 personnel.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Denmark contributed to Maritime Monitor in September 1992 only, when Niels Juel was added as a matter of routine to STANAVFORLANT. The operation itself started on 16 June 1992 and lasted until 22 November, when the name was changed, in light of a wider mandate, to Maritime Guard. Denmark did not participate in it, but when the mandate and the operation were once more expanded and named Operation Sharp Guard, Danish corvettes in several iterations contributed to enforcing the embago.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: To prevent war materiel from reaching Yugoslavia and the newly independent countries, an embargo was set up in the Adriatic Sea between Italy and the Balkan Peninsula. The participation by Niels Juel in the operation, however, occurred under a relatively narrow mandate. The naval forces were permitted only to carry out surveillance and provide warnings to ships and were not authorised to board and inspect suspicious ships or to sail in the waters near Yugoslavia. As a result, it was difficult to succeed with the embargo. Niels Juel and the rest of STANAVFORLANT therefore took up position at the entry to the Adriatic Sea and hailed all merchant vessels to request information about their cargo and destination. Then, the ships were monitored to determine if they had provided accurate information. Should this not be the case, there was, however, no way to intervene physically. The only option was to inform the UN so that it could issue a protest to the countries in which the ships were registered. In time, the mandate was expanded, and Danish ships took part later in Operation Sharp Guard, where it was easier to enforce the blockade through the use of force against ships attempting to break the embargo.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In the early 1990s, Yugoslavia fell apart. For many reasons, tensions in the 1980s among the states making up the country had become more acute. They culminated at the Congress of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia held in 1990 to address and solve the problems in the country. No agreement could be reached, however, and several delegations walked out of the Congress. During the year, a multi-party election was held for the first time. Nationalist parties achieved popular support. On 25 July 1991, Slovenia and Croatia declared independence. There was considerable unrest in the multi-ethnic state Bosnia-Herzegovina.
In August of that year, Slovenia won independence while Croatia found itself in a protracted war of independence fought against the Yugoslav government in Belgrade and against the minority population of Serbs in the Republic of Krajina, a part of Croatia. This minority wished to remain in Yugoslavia. As the EC and the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) attempted to negotiate ceasefires, the international community watched with alarm as Bosnia-Herzegovina came ever closer to a total breakdown, Macedonia wanted independence, and the government in Belgrade tried to clamp down on the independence movements.
In hopes of preventing war, the UN Security Council decided to limit access to arms. Based on Resolutions 713 (1991) and 757 (1992), an arms embargo and sanctions against Yugoslavia and the seceding republics were initiated. NATO monitored the embargo through Operation Maritime Monitor. Denmark supplied a corvette.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
However, the NATO naval force had a mandate only to monitor maritime traffic in the Adriatic Sea, not to board suspicious ships or in any other way prevent ships from breaking the embargo. Hence the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 787 (1992) to permit inspection and boarding of ships suspected of breaking the embargo. Then, Maritime Monitor became Maritime Guard.
Later on, when the armed conflicts in Bosnia-Herzegovina intensified and the blockade was ignored by some, the Security Council adopted another resolution to expand the mandate. By Resolution 820 (1993) permission was granted for operations to be carried out in Yugoslavian waters. That made it easier to maintain a full blockade of maritime traffic with an exception for ships carrying humanitarian aid. Shortly thereafter, the NATO Operation Maritime Guard was combined with the similar Operation Sharp Fence operated by the Western European Union, to form Operation Sharp Guard on 15 June 1993.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Proposal B99 was submitted to the Danish Parliament on 1 July 1993 by the Minister of Defence. In comparison with the Danish contribution to Maritime Monitor, the mandate for Sharp Guard had greater scope and involved a greater requirement for using force. That necessitated an explicit parliamentary approval. The proposal was approved unanimously by Parliament a week later. The mandate now sent a Danish corvette to take part in the Adriatic Sea embargo.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
All three of the Danish Niels Juel class corvettes participated at varying times in Operation Sharp Guard. The corvettes carried an extensive arsenal consisting of anti-ship and surface to air missiles, a 76 mm cannon, depth charges, and seven heavy machine guns. The standard crew for each ship numbered 90. This number typically included a group of 15 volunteer conscripts.
For a total of seven stints of about three months each, the corvettes Niels Juel, Olfert Fischer, and Peter Tordenskiold sailed the Adriatic Sea to maintain the embargo along with the other NATO ships participating in the operation. Warships from 14 nations and 8 patrol aircraft took part. The fusion of the NATO and WEU operations had mostly symbolic and administrative value. France was the only country to participate in Sharp Guard without being a full member of NATO. France often had a fluid relationship with the Alliance, and its military forces were not under NATO command. The first and last Danish ship to take part was Niels Juel. It had also been part of Maritime Monitor the previous year.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution to Sharp Guard started with the arrival of Niels Juel on 14 June 1993 and ended just under three years later when she left the operation on 11 May 1996. From time to time, all three Danish corvettes were active on a rotation basis, and at other times there was no Danish presence.
The operation did not end until the Dayton Agreement was in place. It secured a peace accord for Bosnia-Herzegovina. Even though the Dayton Agreement came into force in December 1995, the fleet remained in the Adriatic Sea to be available if the conflict were to resume or if there were any other violations of the agreement. Such not being the case, the blockade was lifted partially on 13 March 1996. Everything went according to plan during the spring, and Operation Sharp Guard was suspended on 19 June and officially concluded on 1 October 1996 when the UN Security Council lifted the sanctions.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission of the Danish corvettes was in many ways similar to their work in surveillance of Danish waters. The primary purpose was to monitor maritime traffic in the Adriatic Sea. Of course, the overall threat level and the operating conditions were quite different given that the job involved keeping up an armed embargo in the waters off the coast of a country in the midst of a civil war. The scale of the operation was larger, too, in that there are not as many occasions to hail and board ships when patrolling the waters “at home” where there is no blockade to maintain. Recent experience gained by Olfert Fischer in Operation Faraway in the Persian Gulf came in handy. That mission had been similar and likewise featured close collaboration with other NATO ships.
Since the Danish corvettes did not carry helicopters as did many of the larger NATO ships, boarding was possible only by using a rubber dinghy. During a boarding, 8-10 men guarded the ship’s crew, secured the bridge, and searched the cargo. The corvette was oriented to ensure its weapons systems could cover the boarding team in case of difficulties.
In total, 629 ships were hailed by the three Danish vessels during the operation; 124 were boarded and inspected, and 10 were redirected. The corvettes did not discover any blockade runners. The overall operation discovered just 11. This result is likely due to the deterrent effect of the large and armed international naval force in Operation Sharp Guard

images.title: Korvetter i Sharp Guard
images.caption: Patrol vessels in OPN Sharp Guard

text.heading: Background
text.text: After the terrorist attacks on the US on 11 September 2001, NATO Treaty Article 5, the so-called “Musketeer Oath”, was invoked for the first time. An attack on one member was regarded as an attack on all members. A large maritime operation was launched as part of the work of the Alliance in the war on terror. NATO’s naval forces were deployed to the Mediterranean under the name Operation Active Endeavour to patrol the waters and monitor maritime traffic and thus prevent terrorist attacks or transport of weapons related materiel or of persons suspected of having contacts to international terrorism. Denmark has contributed to Active Endeavour several times with a variety of vessels. But after a decade, the situation in the Mediterranean had changed considerably, and the threat of terror was assessed as being lower than at the outset.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: At the NATO summit in Warsaw in July 2016, it was decided to terminate Active Endeavour and transition to a new operation no longer associated with Article 5 – just shy of 15 years after it was invoked. The new operation, named Operation Sea Guardian, was to replace Active Endeavour as of November 2016. It was to undertake many of the same tasks. The main goal was to maintain a secure and stable environment in the Mediterranean. The new operation continues the capacity building work that is made possible in part by experience gained in the constant collaboration between NATO ships.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish contribution to Sea Guardian was introduced for discussion in Parliament as proposal B49 by the Minister of Foreign Affairs shortly before Christmas 2017. The proposal indicated that Denmark could contribute to Operation Sea Guardian as of 2018 in various ways. Ships, planes, special forces, and mine clearance were mentioned as potential contributions. In addition, the proposal included a request for specific confirmation from Parliament that the Danish ships regularly participating in the Standing NATO Maritime Groups could participate in the operation. At the second reading on 16 January 2018, the proposal was approved with 89 votes in favour and 15 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark contributed to Operation Sea Guardian in the spring of 2018 with about 20 soldiers from the Frogman Corps on board the Dutch support ship Karel Doorman where they worked with special forces from the Netherlands and Belgium.
The Standing NATO Maritime Group (SNMG-1) was under Danish command in 2018, in the first six months with the frigate Niels Juel as flagship. In the last six months, the support ship Esbern Snare replaced Niels Juel. Technically, SNMG-1 is not a part of Operation Sea Guardian, but it will likely participate from time to time in the operation as was the case during Operation Active Endeavour

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The Frogman Corps soldiers were stationed on the Dutch ship from 4 April to June 2018 during the operation.
Operation Sea Guardian was launched in November 2016 and is ongoing without a specific end date. It is therefore likely that Denmark will be contributing to the operation again in the future, possibly in other ways.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The overall mission of Operation Sea Guardian is to monitor the situation in the Mediterranean, take part in strengthening collaboration and capacity building, and prevent and counter terror or terror related activities such as smuggling of weapons. The NATO ships in the operation patrol the Mediterranean, keep a watchful eye on the maritime traffic and the overall threat, pay visits to and inform civilian ships about the operation and the security situation, and in a few cases board suspicious ships.
In such boarding operations, personnel from the Frogman Corps took part. These types of tasks are among the specialities of the Corps in its function as a maritime special force. In addition, the Corps took part in general training and operational tasks. Training and collaboration are crucial parts of participating in the operation as they foster deep knowledge and exchange of insight among the forces supplied by each NATO country.
The operation takes place in the Mediterranean, mostly in international waters. The ships also operate in the domestic waters of individual NATO countries and of countries having granted permission. Given that NATO enjoys the collaboration of many countries in the eastern and southern Mediterranean, the ships are more or less at liberty to move around.
