text.heading: Background
text.text:
After the 11 September 2001 attacks, it was widely feared that a similar attack could be performed using chemical, biological or radioactive weapons of mass destruction. American President George W. Bush believed that Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein might see the potential of supplying this type of arms to terror organisations like Al-Qaeda. Hussein was hostile to the USA after it had driven the Iraqi army out of Kuwait in 1991 and had maintained sanctions and no-fly zones over Iraq ever since. The Iraqi dictator has previously been willing to use poison gas against his own population.
During the 1990s the UN’s weapons inspectors had been destroying Iraq’s weapons of mass destruction as part of the 1991 post-war ceasefire. Iraq had been unwilling, however, to fully cooperate with the weapons inspectors and there was therefore a suspicion that arms depots or production facilities were still in existence. It was a matter of great discussion in Denmark and the international community whether Iraq was concealing weapons of mass destruction, had links to terror and whether the UN resolutions from the 1990s mandated an intervention. A UN commission was sent to Iraq to investigate.
The commission found no weapons of mass destruction but reported a continued lack of willingness to cooperate, Because of the arguments about weapons of mass destruction, links to terror, the unwillingness to cooperate and a general desire to bring down Saddam Hussein and introduce democracy, a U.S. -led coalition was set up in 2003 called Operation Iraqi Freedom, in which Denmark would participate. It took only a few weeks to bring down Saddam Hussein’s régime, but a longer project lay ahead. The coalition set up a provisional government that came to be known by the acronym CPA (Coalition Provisional Authority). One of the things the CPA did was to dissolve the Iraqi army, which meant that a large multinational force was necessary to maintain law and order in the country until a new Iraqi government could be convened and local forces could be trained to take care of Iraq’s national security.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
There was some dispute as to the war's legality according to international law and, initially, of the subsequent occupation. The most recent UN Security Council resolution (1441 of 2002) had threatened “serious consequences” if Iraq failed to cooperate unconditionally with the weapons inspectors. Legal experts evaluated the mandate as being adequate, but others were in opposition.
On 22 May, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1483 (2003), which imposed responsibilities on the coalition forces as an occupying power under international law, repealed previous sanctions against Iraq and recognised the Iraqi governing council under CPA as Iraq’s legitimate representatives towards the international community.  On 16 October, a further resolution (1511 of 2003) recommended that UN member states should contribute to the international force in order to ensure security and stability in Iraq until the country had recovered.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Because the Danish ships had participated in the March invasion, it was already clear that Denmark would also provide a contribution to the international security force now that the régime had been overthrown. The decision was formally adopted by the Parliament in the form of Proposal B165 on 15 May 2003. When it was adopted after a vote of 89 for and 15 against, the Parliament approved the deployment of a Danish force of up to 380 troops in Iraq for up to half a year.
The case was debated once again half a year later. Because the original period was about to expire, the new UN Security Council resolution 1483 was this time named in the proposal and it was decided at the same time that the Danish contribution would be strengthened. Proposal B1 was adopted by the Parliament on 10 October 2003, with 94 votes in favour and 15 votes against.
The Danish contribution was already put to the Parliament once again the following month.  This was now based on Security Council Resolution 1511, which encouraged member states to maintain their contributions and Parliament decided to increase the Danish contingent (which was now 510 men) for another six month period in addition to the already-determined period.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contingent in Iraq (DANCON/IRAK) was originally 370 men, with 43 Lithuanian soldiers adjoined as part of the British-led division in Southern Iraq. The first Danish force was comprised of a light reconnaissance group, a medical platoon, a mine-clearing section and a so-called CIMIC unit for civilian-military collaboration. Also deployed were staff and liaison personnel, a logistics detachment and a national support team, as well as a smaller special forces detachment for bodyguard duties and to serve as reinforcements. A detachment of engineers was also deployed for a brief period to construct camps.
Because the security situation was not improving, the Government alongside the Foreign Policy Committee decided on 16 July to reinforce the Danish contribution by 40 personnel, mainly military police, an extra scouting section and extra personnel for the logistics unit. The force was increased once again in October 2003 with Proposal B1, this time by 90 men in the form of a reduced armoured infantry company, a detachment of engineers, five staff officers and ten soldiers with special training as bodyguards and two armoured civilian vehicles were provided for Danish civilian representatives in Iraq. The total Danish military contribution thus numbered 510 personnel. The contribution from Lithuania had, in the meantime, grown to 55 men.

Denmark sent 3 police advisers and 11 police instructors who were deployed in the same area as the military contribution near Basra. A Danish team of experts was also deployed to locate and map the location of mass graves.

Danish Emergency Management Agency personnel were also deployed during the period 21 April to 4 September 2003 to set up and equip various office facilities in Basrah for use by the UN Office for the Humanitarian Coordination in Iraq (UNOHCI) and to perform the office’s functions for a shorter duration during the start-up phase.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
DANCON/IRAQ was deployed to Iraq via Kuwait at the end of May and beginning of June 2003, where it received orders from the British on 12 June about its area of responsibility. The full contingent was finally in place at Camp Eden on 18 June 2003.  The detachment of engineers had already been deployed to prepare the base that was set up at a former Iraqi barracks. A team of elite Jaeger soldiers had already been deployed in April to reconnoitre the area that would possibly become the responsibility of the Danish contingent.
The occupation ended on 30 June 2004 when a sovereign Iraqi government was set up. The mission was not yet completed, and the Danish troops remained in Iraq as part of the multinational force, at the wishes of the Iraqi government and with a new UN mandate.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The main mission of the multinational force after the invasion was to re-establish law and order and to stabilise Iraq so that authority and control could be returned to the Iraqi people. An extension of this mission was to produce a safe framework for civilian authorities, the UN’s aid mission and rebuilding Iraq’s infrastructure. The 15-strong CIMIC unit also served as a liaison with emergency aid organisations and as a contact interface for local authorities.  The military police personnel who had been deployed trained local Iraqi police and security forces so that they would, ideally, be able to assume responsibility for security when it was time for the Danish force to return home.
As part of the British-led force in Southern Iraq near Basra, the Danes were assigned their own area of responsibility which covered approx. 3,600 square kilometres, centred around the town of al-Qurnah, situated where the Tigris and Euphrates rivers meet. According to local legend, this was supposedly the location of the biblical Garden of Eden. The Danish camp was therefore named “Camp Eden”. There was also a Danish Camp Yggdrasil which was part of the British Shaiba Logistics Base close to Basra itself, where the Danish logistics and liaison teams spent most of their time.
Regular duties were mainly to patrol the area, set up checkpoints and control posts and to maintain contact with local authorities/police stations. Additional duties included escorting representatives of a number of Danish or international authorities, including civilians working on the reconstruction. The forces were also deployed to support Danish, British or Iraqi forces if they faced a potential or actual attack. Finally, the contingent carried out various larger operations to search areas or a particular village to confiscate illegal weapons or to arrest known or presumed criminals.
During the initial period, an important task was to prevent looting or to get back objects that had previously been stolen or robbed. Many vehicles belonging to the authorities had been stolen when the régime collapsed. DANCON confiscated many such vehicles and returned them to the new authorities as they began to be set up. Another important task was to maintain the repaired infrastructure that was often vandalised and looted. Electricity pylons were often toppled by locals who stole the cables and sold the metal on the black market.
As part of the British-led multinational division, there was a close partnership with British forces in the area, extensive exchange of experiences and close coordination of missions in the area.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Under the name Operation Iraqi Freedom, a US-led coalition with Danish participation invaded Iraq in 2003 and toppled Saddam Hussein.  After the régime was overthrown, Iraq became very destabilised and, because Denmark had made a naval contribution to the actual invasion, it was decided that Denmark would contribute to the multinational security force that had been deployed to ensure stability while a democratic system was put in place by the Iraqi people.
For the first year, Iraq’s formal status was that of an occupied country, the coalition operating as the supreme authority and an Iraqi governing council that deferred to the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA). This situation was not sustainable. The intention was that Iraq should transition towards democracy as soon as possible and be responsible for its own security so that the multinational forces could be withdrawn. A longer process began, the first stage of which was to transfer Iraq to an independent government that would be able to implement a parliamentary election and draft a constitution.
When Iraq achieved formal status as an independent sovereign state with its own government on 30 June 2004, CPA was dissolved. The basis for the international mission in Iraq was thus altered to that of a force that was there by the invitation of the Iraqi state and backed by a mandate from the UN Security Council.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: As the transition to a sovereign Iraqi state approached, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1546 on 8 June 2004. This resolution was a recognition by the international community that the incoming Iraqi provisional government was completely sovereign and independent and marked the end of the occupation of Iraq by international forces. Based on an invitation from the Iraqi government and a statement from American Foreign Minister Colin Powell, the resolution also provided a mandate to establish the framework for a continued international presence in Iraq to assist with rebuilding the country, humanitarian aid and security. The coalition forces were thus present by official invitation and would assist the reformed Iraqi security forces in their efforts to guarantee peace and stability for the reconstruction and introduction of democratic processes that lay ahead. At the request of the Iraqi government, this mandate would be reassessed ever 12 months.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark had maintained a contribution in Iraq for over a year by the time the country was declared an independent state. The contribution had been determined, reinforced and extended several times over the course of the previous year. The most recent decision was based on Proposal B213, which was adopted by the Parliament on 2 June. Here, the Danish contribution was extended by a further six months and would continue at the same strength as previously, but with an additional five soldiers deployed for bodyguard duties to protect delegates from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The first decision about Danish participation in the multinational security force in an independent Iraq on the basis of Resolution 1546 was when Proposal B42 was put to the Parliament by the Minister of Foreign Affairs on 4 November 2004. The proposal was adopted three weeks later, with 97 votes in favour and 15 votes against. The Danish contribution was extended once again, by a further six months. This decision would be repeated on multiple occasions before the Danish troops finally returned home.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution in Iraq, when the country transitioned back to an independent sovereign state, was comprised of approximately 525 personnel. At this time the Danish forces were: an armoured infantry company, a light reconnaissance group, a staff and logistics company, a detachment of engineers, a detachment of military police, a medical platoon, a civilian-military collaboration group, a national support group and a staff and staff officers. Additional to this main contribution to the multinational division that was under British command, ten staff officers were also adjoined to a multinational division under Polish command. Finally, 17 soldiers with specialist bodyguard training were assigned to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark’s civilian representations in Baghdad and Basra. Danish special forces also took part in 2007 to reinforce the various units. The Danish National Police has also sent 11 police trainers to Iraq on an ongoing basis.
DANCON/IRAQ was split into teams that each served for a half year. After 2007, when the bulk of the troops were withdrawn, a small number of Danish soldiers remained as part of NATO’s training mission in Iraq. During the summer of 2007, this force was comprised of 10 trainers and seven bodyguards. When these were withdrawn as the final remaining contingent in December 2011, the contribution was six personnel for the training mission.
A contribution of 55 soldiers from Lithuania was assigned to the Danish forces in Southern Iraq. As part of the British-led multinational division, the Danish-Lithuanian forces often operated very closely with British and Iraqi units.
Danish Fennec helicopters and their 55-strong flight and ground crews were also deployed for various periods. The first helicopter deployment was during the 2005 elections, when the three helicopters provided support for the Danish forces. In the second half of 2007 four helicopters and 50 flight and ground crew were deployed to support coalition members after the Danish combat troops had returned home. Danish special forces were also deployed periodically to Iraq. One example of this was when 30 special forces troops were deployed in April 2007 to deal with a specific threat to the Danish camp.

More than 6,000 Danish troops had served in Iraq across the entire period from June 2003 to the end of 2011.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
DANCON/IRAQ had already had a presence in Iraq since June 2003. With the new UN Security Council resolution and Iraq’s independence, the Danish forces continued their presence after 30 June 2004 with a new mandate. The Danish presence was no longer an occupying force after this date, but an international security force that had been invited by the Iraqi government.
After negotiations with the United Kingdom in 2006/2007, the Danish Government announced in February that DANCON/IRAQ would withdraw from Iraq during the coming summer, alongside a gradual winding down of the British contribution. Apart from the bodyguard team that was still assigned to the Danish representation in Iraq and the contributions to NATO’s training mission, the final ground units withdrew from Iraq across the border with Kuwait on 7 August. The Danish helicopter contribution then began to fly surveillance missions on behalf of the British and American forces before returning home at the end of the year. The Danish contribution to NATO’s training measures in Iraq remained in place until November 2011, when the final Danish troops were recalled.
One Danish contribution had to return to Iraq 2014 under different circumstances, this time as part of the war against ISIL in Operation Inherent Resolve.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Although the mandate was new, the situation for Danish troops during the transition to an independent Iraq was essentially the same as before. The main objective was to establish security and stability so that the transition towards a democratic system and the various rebuilding projects could both continue. The main missions were to secure frameworks for civilian authorities, the UN aid mission, the rebuilding of Iraq’s infrastructure and, not least, to train Iraqi security forces. The CIMIC unit also served as a liaison with emergency aid organisations and as a contact interface for local authorities. The military police personnel were deployed to assist in training local Iraqi police to be able to work alongside the Danish forces in the area of operations and, ideally, assume full responsibility for security when it was time for the Danish mission to return home. Especially after the launch of the Danish “collaborative thinking initiative” in 2004, humanitarian and reconstruction work became a bigger task.
Regular duties were mainly to patrol the area, set up checkpoints and control posts and to maintain contact with local authorities. Additional duties included escorting representatives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and civilians from the international community who were working on the reconstruction. The forces were also deployed to support Danish, British or Iraqi forces if they faced a potential or actual attack. Finally, in coordination with Iraqi forces, the contingent carried out various larger operations to search areas or a particular village to confiscate illegal weapons or to arrest known or presumed criminals or insurgents. After the transition to a sovereign state, DANCON no longer was in command of Iraqi units and had to perform its duties through a process of coordination and collaboration with them instead.

The area for which the Danes were responsible increased dramatically shortly after the transition to Iraqi sovereignty. On 31 August 2004, Denmark was assigned responsibility for an area totalling 17,000 square kilometres. Two battalions from the newly-formed Iraqi national guard and periodically assigned British units were also under Danish command and coordination. Because the Danish Camp Eden was now located at the northern end of the area for which the Danes were responsible, the Danish forces relocated in September to a new base called Camp Danevang, which was an extension of the former Camp Yggdrasil. This was part of the British Shaiba Logistics Base, south-west of Basra. The British forces wound down the Shaiba Logistics Base in 2006 and the Danes relocated with them to Basra Air Station, where they set up Camp Einherjer.
The security situation did not improve, despite Iraq having formally declared independence. Ambushes and roadside IED bombings were still the most significant threat and they increased in frequency. Rocket attacks on the Danish base were becoming more regular, despite the fact that they seldom had any effect. As a countermeasure, the Danish forces and their allies carried out several operations which would involve encircling an area or a village and conducting house to house searches for illegal arms and where the Iraqis would themselves arrest those they suspected of being responsible for the attacks.

The Fennec helicopters that had been deployed mainly flew surveillance missions. Three helicopters were deployed to support the Danish forces for the first time during the 2005 elections. Four helicopters were deployed in 2007 at the same time as the Danish ground forces were being recalled. Their main mission was to fly surveillance missions for British and American supply convoys as they drove through Iraq from Kuwait.

text.heading: Mission

The nature and scope of the assignments vary considerably. Typically, the expert joins a team in a local coordination centre to work on aligning the activities of national and international authorities in the affected areas. This work may include administration, communications, coordination, logistics, transport, reconnaissance, and monitoring. Specific work in the many countries to which the experts have been sent is not described here.

In most cases, the Danish Emergency Management Agency is not aware of the actual nature of the assignment given that the local situation may change very quickly. Such changes necessitate adjustments to the assignments for the personnel in question.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Iraq was not in a healthy state in 2003. After the war with Iran during the 1980s, the invasion of Kuwait and the war against the American-led coalition in Operation Desert Storm, a number of rebellions and extensive sanctions against the country during the 1990s and the invasion that toppled Saddam Hussein in 2003, much of Iraq's infrastructure lay in ruins. Access to basic essentials was limited and a centralised government was struggling to get up from its knees. As a consequence of war, sanctions, looting and the former régime’s bad governance, the health and education systems were virtually non-existent in large areas of the country. Even essentials like clean drinking water were also in short supply.
A number of measures were set in motion at local and international level. The UN set up the UNAMI mission. Donor conferences were conducted, and a number of NGOs began to operate in Iraq. Countries that had been part of the coalition that had toppled Saddam’s régime and were now responsible for Iraq’s security now wanted to start a broad process of rebuilding and securing humanitarian conditions for the Iraqi people.
The UN’s mission in Iraq had already been hit by a large bombing attack in August 2003. The Red Cross headquarters in Iraq would also be bombed. Because of the unstable security situation, the multinational security force, including the Danish military contribution, was closely involved in both rebuilding projects and humanitarian work. This was initially in the form of protection and escort missions to protect civilians who had been sent to Iraq by states or NGOs and from CIMIC (the civilian-military partnership). The security situation continued to deteriorate and there were attacks on civilian aid workers. Many NGOs, state organisations and UN agencies withdrew their personnel from the country or concentrated them in a few secure zones, such as “the Green Zone” in Baghdad. The military forces found themselves with increased responsibility for the performance of a number of humanitarian and rebuilding tasks.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: On 22 May 2003 the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1483, which determined the UN’s role in the reconstruction of Iraq and humanitarian aid and encouraged all member states to assist with the humanitarian situation to the best of their abilities, as well as encouraging General Secretary Kofi Annan to appoint a special delegation to coordinate aid work. Numerous other resolutions concerning Iraq were adopted by the Security Council over the years. In most cases, these involved varying types of support for humanitarian aid and the reconstruction of Iraq.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish contribution to the international security forces in Iraq was determined when Proposal B165 was adopted by the Parliament on 15 May 2003. It was already emphasised in this first decision that the Danish contribution should not only be military, but that it should also promote security in Iraq and assist with the humanitarian situation and reconstruction, as well as the political process. DKK 350 million was assigned for the reconstruction of Iraq during the following year. The soldiers that were deployed would be able to support humanitarian work and the force’s CIMIC units would establish contact with aid organisations and local authorities and would itself complete smaller scale aid projects. It was intended from the very beginning that the Danish military and humanitarian contribution would focus on Southern Iraq, so that the various sections could support each other. “No reconstruction without security - and no security unless we rebuild.”

The subsequent proposal to extend the mission would see the reiteration of the same ideas, and the ongoing addition of further funding for the humanitarian mission. Because of the unstable security situation, many aid organisations had withdrawn and the military contribution had assumed increased responsibility for rebuilding and humanitarian aid.  The Danish Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs therefore launched the “collaborative thinking initiative” in 2004. With its full title, ”Collaborative Thinking for Civilian-military Missions in International Operations” established the framework for collaborations between civilian humanitarian organisations, Danish developmental aid and military forces, also including how advisers could be assigned to a military force and how funding could be assigned to the military to perform civilian tasks if the security situation did not permit civilian stakeholders to operate in the area.
Proposal B42 of 2004 was adopted by the Parliament on 25 November, with 97 votes in favour and 15 votes against. This extended the military contribution and, as an extension of the Collaborative Thinking Initiative, also increased the focus of the military units that had been deployed towards more traditional civilian missions. It was noted in the wording of the proposal that the security situation in Southern Iraq was making work difficult for the humanitarian organisations and that the military contribution would be involved in civilian missions to a greater degree than previously. The proposal also increased funding for humanitarian projects that were to be implemented in collaboration with local authorities and contractors. It was hoped that this would normalise conditions for the civilian population and this reduce resistance to the international coalition forces.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish military had a presence in Southern Iraq from 2003-2007 in the form of DANCON/IRAQ. A CIMIC team was assigned to the Danish mission from the very beginning and was originally comprised of approx. 15 personnel.
Reconstruction Unit Denmark (RUD), also had a presence. This was a military team comprised of up to 45 soldiers. The team was supported by civilian advisers (mainly from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs) and was charged with finding, prioritising and commencing reconstruction projects. A special bodyguard team of 17 soldiers from the Danish Defence was assigned to the civilians who had been posted to Iraq and were allocated to the various Danish representations and individuals who were involved with reconstruction work and humanitarian aid.  More traditional military-style support was provided by military units during the reconstruction work, such as when carrying out escort duties when members of the RUD unit was to visit local projects.
Between 2003-2010, total funding of DKK 895 million was awarded for reconstruction projects, emergency aid and Iraqi development. Not all this funding was spent by the Danish Defence mission. Much of the funding was directly awarded to civilian organisations, to the UN development fund for Iraq or to the Iraqi state.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The Danish humanitarian aid mission and reconstruction projects in Iraq commenced soon after the invasion in May 2003 and, in particular, when the Danish forces were actually deployed to their area of responsibility during June. During the period from 2003-2007 when DANCON/IRAQ had a fixed area of responsibility in Southern Iraq near Basra, the Danish reconstruction mission and humanitarian aid work were focused in the same area. After Danish combat troops returned home in the summer of 2007, focus shifted to the surrounding area of Baghdad. Here, the task would largely be performed by civilians who had been deployed with support from Danish Defence bodyguard teams.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The CIMIC unit and RUD were tasked with working towards improving humanitarian conditions in the Danish area of operations and with helping to rebuild the country. It was hoped that if the local population was able to experience improved social and economic conditions, then it would promote greater goodwill towards the presence of the international forces and bring about a long-term contribution towards the stabilisation process.
The funding from Denmark was used to start building new schools, water purification plants, healthcare clinics and to rebuild important infrastructures such as roads and bridges, as well as various workplaces that were particularly aimed at women. This all went on with as much collaboration as possible from local stakeholders. Local town councils and sheiks assisted in designating projects and local contractors were hired wherever possible to carry out the construction projects. By engaging the population in these projects, it was hoped that Iraq would have a better basis for continuing the process after the foreign aid had been downscaled or departed.
The CIMIC team initially coordinated activities with local stakeholders and international organisations from the Danish CIMIC building in the town of Al-Qurnah. This turned out to be somewhat risky as the security situation deteriorated. In May 2004 the Sheik who had been working closely with the Danish CIMIC unit was murdered. The culprits were in all likelihood militiamen who were trying to deter collaboration with the coalition forces. The CIMIC building was unfortunately taken down the following month.
In practical terms, RUD typically operated as two-person teams that drove out to visit projects that had been started with Danish funding or to coordinate issues such as selecting new projects with local dignitaries. The security situation necessitated escort duties that were performed by the reconnaissance group or the armed infantry units from DANCON. This was not always viewed positively by the locals. The CIMIC and RUD units both had to take a critical stance on what local leaders were recommending and when following up projects that had already been started. Numerous inspections were a necessity.
In addition to setting up numerous schools and healthcare clinics, the Danish reconstruction mission also helped to distribute food and medicines, set up a centre for torture victims in Basra, assisted returning refugees and implemented leadership training courses for newly-elected politicians and police commissioners.  Other tasks that were performed during this period included excavating mass graves, irrigation projects and supplying equipment ranging from hospital hardware to sewage sludge suction vehicles.

missions.title: OIR Iraq
missions.subtitle: The Battle against ISIL
missions.name: Inherent Resolve Irak F-16, Radar, m.m.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In 2014, the terrorist organisation Islamic State (ISIL) burst on the scene in Iraq and managed to capture large parts of the city of Fallujah. In June, Mosul, the third largest city in Iraq, fell to ISIL. Building on the success, it controlled a large swath of eastern Syria and northwestern Iraq – mostly thinly populated desert areas, but including several large cities such as Fallujah, Mosul, and Tikrit in Iraq and cities such as Raqqa and Palmyra in Syria.
Mosul and the surrounding areas were home to some of the oldest Christian communities and the Yazidi minority.
Close to 50,000 Yazidis had fled to Mount Sinjar when ISIL advanced and were trapped there in late summer while ISIL waited for them to die of hunger and heat. On 7 August, U.S. President Barack Obama therefore announced the first step in a return to Iraq by the United States. It involved a bombardment of ISIL in order to protect the Yazidis and an air drop of emergency aid for the many refugees.
A new coalition was formed to fight ISIL. Participants included the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Jordan, Morocco, and Denmark. Its work was launched in October under the name Operation Inherent Resolve (OIR) Rather than to deploy ground troops, the intent was to fight ISIL from the air. Participating countries sent a number of individuals to Iraq to advise and train its army. Some countries have had ground troops in Iraq to fight ISIL directly.
The clashes between ISIL and the coalition created a humanitarian catastrophe for the local population. Therefore, the UN requested support for an enhanced humanitarian effort in northern Iraq.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Via the UN Security Council, the Iraqi president on 25 June 2014 issued a general appeal to the international community for support – including military support – to combat ISIL and to protect Iraqi civilians and land areas.
On 20 September 2014, the Iraqi government reissued the appeal for international support, again via the UN Security Council. On this occasion, it expressed consent for the US to lead the joint international effort against the Islamic State. This invitation from Iraq constitutes the mandate for the coalition’s Operation Inherent Resolve in Iraq, led by the US.
Military operations within Inherent Resolve inside Syria’s borders are subject to the international law principle of collective defence. This means that Iraq and its allies may defend themselves against attacks launched from within Syria in case Syria is not able to or does not wish to contain aggressions originating inside that country.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
As one of 10 countries, Denmark attended a meeting arranged by the US in connection with the NATO Summit in Wales on 5 September 2014. The meeting addressed a future strategy for dealing with ISIL.
On 2 October 2014, Parliament approved proposal B123 (with 94 votes in favour and 9 votes opposed) to further support the effort to combat ISIL through a Danish military contribution. Previously, Denmark had provided a Hercules transport plane and a crew to the coalition led by the US.
This new contribution to the fight against ISIL would involve diplomatic, civilian, and military contributions and humanitarian aid elements for alleviating the current crisis. An F-16 fighter jet was part of this contribution, including liaison and staff officers.

In response to a request from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), the government decided to support the establishment and operation of refugee camps in Shekan in northern Iraq. This effort was part of the overall International Humanitarian Partnership contribution led by Sweden.

On 10 November 2015, Parliament approved proposal B8 (with 94 votes in favour and 16 votes opposed) to dispatch a radar for air surveillance and airspace control, staffed by up to 30 personnel. The dispatch was slated for 12 months, but was extended to January 2020.
On 19 April 2016, Parliament approved proposal B108 (with 90 votes in favour and 19 votes opposed) to further strengthen the military component of the fight against ISIL. This decision was made in response to a request from the US and on the basis of discussions with members of the coalition. The new contribution had three parts: Dispatch of fighter jets, troops including special forces, and a C-130J (Hercules) transport plane.
On 24 August 2018, the government received the support of the Foreign Affairs Council to send Danish IT and communications specialists as part of the new NATO training mission that had been agreed at the NATO Summit in July 2018.
On 6 September 2019 after consultation with the Foreign Affairs Council a medical team of doctors and nurses was sent to a US base in Syria.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Between 2014 and 2015, Denmark contributed the first of two F-16 fighter jets stationed at the Ahmed al-Jaber Air Base in Kuwait. The fighting force contribution consisted of four operational F-16s and up to three extras. In addition, the contribution included 140 liaison and staff officers, among them five persons based at the Combined Air Operations Center (CAOC) in Qatar.
When the fighter jet contribution was mobilised, additional personnel was dispatched temporarily to unpack and set up and then to establish communications facilities, maintenance facilities, and the like.
Initially, the Danish planes were deployed in the full gamut of air operations within Iraqi territory, hereunder collecting intelligence informations and conducting offensive air operations aimed at ISIL positions. At the conclusion of one year of service, the Danish planes were recalled to Denmark in October 2015 due to wear and tear. The Danish contribution flew 547 missions during that period and dropped 503 bombs.
In April 2016, Parliament decided to furnish additional F-16 capacity, this time at the Incirlik Air Base in Turkey. This extra capacity was similarly made up of four operational F-16 fighter jets and up to three extra jets plus crews numbering 110 personnel. The Danish aircraft, this time, were similarly active in the full gamut of air operations, however with a mandate to carry out operations against ISIL positions within both Iraqi and Syrian territories. The contribution was made from July to December 2016.
Denmark contributed a C-130J (Hercules) transport plane from June to December 2016 with a crew of approximately 60 persons. In addition, during the period 1 October 2018 to 30 March 2019, a transport plane and 30 personnel were provided to the Ali Al Salem Air Base in Kuwait.
Since January 2016, the Air Control Wing of the Royal Danish Air Force has contributed to Operation Inherent Resolve by providing a long-range mobile radar and associated personnel. The contribution includes 30 personnel, among them 10 technical specialists operating the radar. It is stationed at the Al Asad Air Base in Iraq along with other components of the Danish contribution. Approximately 20 operators are attached to the radar contribution stationed at the air operations centre at the Al Dhafra Air Base in the United Arab Emirates. With the radar, Air Control Wing supplies the primary and most operationally stable radar image of southern Iraq for the benefit of the entire OIR mission. As described above, the Danish radar operators coordinate the coalition’s flight operations, manned and unmanned, and handle overall flight safety in such activities as aerial refueling and maintenance of distance between aircraft to avoid collision. In 2017, the operational area of responsibility for the radar contribution was expanded to include the southern and central parts of Iraq and parts of eastern Syria. The mobile radar was deployed in the operation until April 2019.

A Danish special operations contribution (Task Force 61) from the Jaeger Corps was active in the fight against ISIL between August 2016 and November 2018. The contribution included up to 50 personnel plus the required support. These special forces were tasked with training and advising Iraqi units and supporting them through intelligence gathering and requisition of air support if necessary. In addition, the contribution has a mandate to provide escorts for operations performed in the border area between Iraq and Syria. The special forces were stationed at the Al Asad Air Base along with the Danish radar and capacity contributions.

The 22 IT and communications specialists from the Deployable Communication Module (DCM), a part of the command structure in NATO, were provided between late August 2018 and the end of December 2018 to establish communications capability between NATO facilities in Iraq and the NATO headquarters in Europe. These specialists have been on several tours in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Support from the Danish Emergency Management Agency included delivery and setup of facilities for storage of emergency aid supplies, providing supplies of drinking water, and supplying lighting for refugee camps. Emergency aid experts and environment experts have worked under the auspices of such agencies as the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA). Eleven emergency aid officers and volunteers handled these tasks. In addition, local labour was hired.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
International air support, a retrained Iraqi and Kurdish army, and a federation of the many independent Iraqi militias within the Popular Mobilization Forces enabled Iraq to initiate an offensive against ISIL.
Time was running out for ISIL. At the same time ISIL was hit by air strikes from several international coalitions, it was attacked in Syria by just about all of the many fractions in the civil war, and the reorganised Iraqi army and forces from the independent Kurdish territory sent it on retreat. In the summer of 2017, ISIL was driven from Mosul, and in October, its capital Raqqa in Syria was lost.
On 9 December 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the Islamic State was definitively defeated in Iraq and that all its territory had been retaken. Remnants of ISIL, however, have been able to carry out isolated terrorist attacks, for example with suicide bombs in Baghdad in early 2018. The effort to defeat ISIL through such means as Operation Inherent Resolve ended in 2019 when the last remaining pockets of the Islamic State had been struck down. Danish participation in Air Control Center was stations in UAE but was re- located to USA in 2021.
Personnel from the Danish Emergency Management Agency were provided from October 2014 to April 2017.

Building on the success, it controlled a large swath of eastern Syria and northwestern Iraq – mostly thinly populated desert areas, but including several large cities such as Fallujah, Mosul, and Tikrit in Iraq and cities such as Raqqa and Palmyra in Syria.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 20 January 2017, the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs introduced proposal B56 for Denmark to contribute, in the form of a frigate, to an American aircraft carrier group in support of the international coalition’s effort to defeat ISIL and in support of maritime security. On 9 February, Parliament approved (with 90 votes in favour and 19 votes opposed) the dispatch of the frigate. The frigate had a mandate to take part in the operations of the coalition against ISIL in Iraq and Syria as well as to support overall maritime security for the international maritime coalition forces known as Combined Maritime Forces.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
From 9 February to 5 May 2017, Denmark contributed the frigate Peter Willemoes to the American aircraft carrier group Carrier Strike Group 2. A carrier strike group consists of an aircraft carrier, six to ten cruisers and destroyers, and on occasion submarines. Peter Willemoes then became part of a carrier group organised around the aircraft carrier USS George H. W. Bush with approximately 70 operational aircraft on board and a crew of about 7,500.
Peter Willemoes sailed toward the Mediterranean at the end of January. There, it joined the American forces in a training mission while awaiting the decision of Parliament. She had previously, in 2016, been part of a training exercise with the American navy off the eastern seaboard of the US. Then, the frigate provided escort to the aircraft carrier group on the way to the Persian Gulf where the carrier was to support the fight against ISIL in Iraq and Syria and support the international maritime coalition forces known as Combined Maritime Forces.
It was a first for the Royal Danish Navy to provide a vessel to an American aircraft carrier group. In total, the Danish contribution included 131 personnel.
During the 94 days of the mission, Peter Willemoes covered 28,200 nautical miles (52,100 km / nearly 32,375 miles). More than 300 landings on deck were performed by maritime helicopters.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The primary area of responsibility for the frigate was to be a factor in the overall air operations of the fleet. This included coordination and control of air traffic, control of surveillance aircraft, helicopter operations from the frigate helicopter deck, and other tasks associated with air and surface defence. Peter Willemoes thus assisted in maintaining a joint and up-to-the-minute status assessment. In the event of a specific threat against the aircraft carrier group, the frigate had to be ready to deploy its weapons systems in defence of the force.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
International air support, a retrained Iraqi and Kurdish army (see also Operation SHADER), and a federation of the many independent Iraqi militias within the Popular Mobilization Forces enabled Iraq to initiate a successful offensive against ISIL. Time was running out for ISIL. At the same time ISIL was hit by air strikes from several international coalitions, it was attacked in Syria by just about all of the many fractions in the civil war, and the reorganised Iraqi army, the Popular Mobilization Forces, and forces from the independent Kurdish territory sent it on retreat. In the summer of 2017, ISIL was driven from Mosul, and in October, its capital Raqqa in Syria was lost.
On 9 December 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the Islamic State was definitively defeated in Iraq and that all its territory had been retaken. Remnants of ISIL, however, have been able to carry out isolated terrorist attacks, for example with suicide bombs in Baghdad in early 2018. The last remaining isolated pockets were eliminated in 2019.

text.text:
As one of 10 countries, Denmark attended a meeting arranged by the US in connection with the NATO Summit in Wales on 5 September 2014. The meeting addressed a future strategy for dealing with ISIL.
