The Danish contribution had already been increased in 2015 with the adoption of proposal B8 (adopted with 94 votes in favour and 16 against) on the deployment of a radar contribution. This was followed up in 2016 with the adoption of B108 (with 90 votes in favour and 19 against) on the deployment of F-16 fighter and C-130 transport aircraft with associated personnel. This decision was again approved in the form of B50 in 2018 (with 85 votes in favour and 19 against).

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Since 2015, Denmark has contributed soldiers for the training mission at the Al Asad Air Base in the Al Anbar province in Iraq. In 2016-2018, Denmark in addition sent training personnel from the Jaeger Corps. Training of Iraqi security forces is a significant part of the effort of Operation Inherent Resolve (OIR). The goal of the training mission was to build skills in the Iraqi army so that it would be able to counter and fight against Islamic State in Iraq.  Training, advising, and education of the Iraqis is referred to as Building Partner Capacity (BPC).

The Danish contribution, DANCOM OIR, completed the training in collaboration with American and then with British forces. Led by Danes, DANCON has shared the task of delivering the training with British soldiers since October 2016. In addition to the contributions from the UK and Denmark, instructors and trainers from Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania are attached to DANCON.

In May 2018, the UK recalled its contribution at the Al Asad Air Base, and DANCON took on responsibility for all training of Iraqi security forces at the base.
The education of Iraqi security forces covers such topics as the law of war, handling and use of weapons and firearms, basic infantry training individually and in groups, checkpoint duty (stationary and mobile), protective measures against roadside bombs (IEDs), and first aid. In parallel, Iraqi instructors are trained so that they may in future take over the training. Danish soldiers have trained more than 10,000 Iraqi soldiers, police officers, and border guards since 2015.

From October 2018 to April 2019, a team of 12 surgeons was sent to the American field hospital  at the AL Asad Air Base.

Each year since the inception of the operation, approximately 450 persons have been deployed. From 2021 it was reduced to app. 30 persons. 
The Danish contribution in terms of capacity building includes, over and above instructors, security and logistics personnel. In addition, Denmark provides support by supplying staff officers to coalition staff headquarters in Kuwait, Qatar, and Iraq. The provision of staff supports the planning and execution of the military operations of Operation Inherent Resolve in Iraq. This contribution amounts to about 15 officers.
Denmark has continued to participate ever since in the form of a liaison team, a logistical support unit and a contribution to the staff.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
International air support, a retrained Iraqi and Kurdish army (see also Operation SHADER), and a federation of the many independent Iraqi militias within the Popular Mobilization Forces enabled Iraq to initiate an offensive against ISIL. Time was running out for ISIL. At the same time ISIL was hit by air strikes from several international coalitions, the reorganised Iraqi army and forces from the independent Kurdish territory sent it on retreat. That summer, ISIL was driven from Mosul.
On 9 December 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the Islamic State was definitively defeated in Iraq and that all its territory had been retaken. Remnants of ISIL, however, have been able to carry out isolated terrorist attacks, for example with suicide bombs in Baghdad in early 2018. The last remaining pockets of the Islamic State were eliminated in 2019.

An unusual situation arose in January 2020, when the base (that was home to the Danish troops and personnel from other countries) was targeted by Iranian missiles during the Iran/USA crisis. Approx. 100 personnel from the OPN Inherent Resolve training mission and NMI were temporarily evacuated from the base to Kuwait. Nobody was injured during the Iranian attack. The units later returned to the base.

The Danish contribution to the capacity building mission at Al Asad Air Base remained active during spring 2020, but ended when Denmark took over NATO Mission Iraq (NMI) from Canada that same year.
The Danish aircraft and radar elements were later recalled, so the current Danish contribution (as of 2023) is comprised of 30 people. In 2021, operators from the radar element were transferred to the operations centre in the USA. and terminated in 2022.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In 2014, the terrorist organisation Islamic State (ISIL) burst on the scene in Iraq and managed to capture large parts of the city of Fallujah. In June, Mosul, the third largest city in Iraq, fell to ISIL.
As the Iraqi army retreated, Iraqi Kurds – who enjoy constitutional autonomy in northern Iraq – succeeded in stepping in to control the new power vacuum. Kurdish security forces, the Peshmerga, set up a line of defence against the area controlled by ISIL. They did not, however, expect that ISIL would initiate a two-front war with them and with the Iraqi army. In August 2014, ISIL began a new offensive against areas in northern Iraq controlled by the Kurds, and in short order it captured several strategic targets and cities including Sinjar, the Mosul Dam, and several oil rigs.
Mosul and the surrounding areas were home to some of the oldest Christian communities and the Yazidi minority. Close to 50,000 Yazidis had fled to Mount Sinjar when ISIL advanced and were trapped there in late summer while ISIL waited for them to die of hunger and heat. On 7 August, US President Barack Obama therefore announced the first step in a return to Iraq by the United States. It involved a bombardment of ISIL in order to protect the Yazidis and an air drop of emergency aid for the many refugees.
A new coalition was formed to fight ISIL. Participants included the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Jordan, Morocco, and Denmark. Its work was launched in October under the name Operation Inherent Resolve Rather than to deploy ground troops, the intent was to fight ISIL from the air. Participating countries sent a number of individuals to Iraq to advise and train its army. Some countries have had ground troops in Iraq to fight ISIL directly.
Operation Shader is the code name for the UK contribution to Operation Inherent Resolve.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Via the UN Security Council, the Iraqi president on 25 June 2014 issued a general appeal to the international community for support – including military support – to combat ISIL and to protect Iraqi civilians and land areas.
On 20 September 2014, the Iraqi government reissued the appeal for international support, again via the UN Security Council. On this occasion, it expressed consent for the US to lead the joint international effort against the Islamic State.
This invitation from Iraq constitutes the mandate for the coalition’s Operation Inherent Resolve in Iraq, led by the US, including the UK contribution to the coalition – Operation Shader.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
As one of 10 countries, Denmark attended a meeting arranged by the US in connection with the NATO Summit in Wales on 5 September 2014. The meeting addressed a future strategy for dealing with ISIL.
On 2 October 2014, Parliament approved a proposal (with 94 votes in favour and 9 votes opposed) to further support the effort to combat ISIL through a Danish military contribution. Previously, Denmark had provided a Hercules transport plane and a crew to the coalition led by the US.
This new contribution to the fight against ISIL would involve diplomatic, civilian, and military contributions and humanitarian aid elements for alleviating the current crisis.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark contributed to Operation Shader by sending 30 army soldiers. They and the British units were to instruct more than 600 Kurdish Peshmerga security forces in basic military skills such as first aid, handling of firearms, and protection against mines.
The 30 soldiers provided to Operation Shader were sent to Sulaymaniyah Province in northern Iraq for just over 3 months from November 2014 to February 2015. No further teams were provided in this effort. Instead, the Danish contribution of ground troops to Operation Inherent Resolve was further boosted by a 120-person training contingent based at the Al Asad Air Base in central Iraq.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
With air support from the US, forces from Iraqi Kurdistan made ISIL retreat and rescued the many Yazidis trapped on Mount Sinjar.
Time was running out for ISIL. Air strikes from several international coalitions and attacks from the reorganised Iraqi army and forces from the independent Kurdish territory paid off. In the summer of 2017, ISIL was driven from Mosul.
On 9 December 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the Islamic State was definitively defeated in Iraq and that all its territory had been retaken. Remnants of ISIL, however, have been able to carry out isolated terrorist attacks, for example with suicide bombs in Baghdad in early 2018. The last remaining pockets of ISIL were eliminated in 2019.
With the contested areas under Kurdish control, the Kurdistan Regional Government in 2017 held a referendum on Kurdish independence. In the referendum, more than 90 % voted for independence from Iraq. The Iraqi government declared the referendum invalid and initiated an offensive against the contested areas now under Kurdish control.
In the course of a few months, the Iraqi army regained control of the territory lost to the Peshmerga.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Although Macedonian governments had included ethnic Albanian parties in the years up to 2001, very few concessions were made with regard to what these parties were trying to achieve, namely political, social and economic equality relative to the Slavic Macedonian parties and population segments. Because Macedonia’s population was primarily comprised of Slavic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians, there was some concern among the various parties that there would be unrest if the Albanian parties’ demands for equality were not satisfied. These fears became reality when violent conflict broke out between Slavic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians in the second half of 2000. The opposing groups were, however, able to agree a ceasefire on 6 July 2001. After the ceasefire was agreed, the Macedonian government would reassert its authority in the whole of Macedonia, which would be achieved by measures such as a multi-ethnic police force and the handover of weapons by the various ethnic factions. European observers from Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe(OSCE) andEuropean Union Monitoring Mission(EUMM) were deployed to inspect compliance with the ceasefire and to assist in putting necessary structures into place in the country. On 19 September 2002, Macedonia’s President Crvenkovski, who had won the parliamentary elections earlier that month, requested NATO to deploy a small force to operate as additional security for the observers and other agencies. NATO granted the request and the operation, which was named Operation Amber Fox, performed its mission until mid-December. It would prove necessary for the NATO forces to remain in Macedonia to minimise the risk of destabilisation in the country. The task of this new NATO operation would be to gradually transfer full responsibility to Macedonia’s police and military. It was named Operation Allied Harmony and commenced on16 December 2002, lasting for six months. Operation Allied Harmony was viewed as the end of the NATO presence in Macedonia and began with Operation Essential Harvest/Task Force Harvest on 27 August 2001, with the participation of a total of 4,800 soldiers. The EU took over responsibility in the form of the Concordia operation for the return of security responsibilities to Macedonian authorities.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: It was intended after Operation Amber Fox that the EU would assume responsibility for NATO’s missions in Macedonia. When the operation ended on 15 December 2002, the EU was not yet ready to do so. A temporary mandate for Operation Allied Harmony was therefore established. This was based on Resolution 1371 of the UN Security Council, who had originally set up Amber Fox. The purpose of Allied Harmony was to follow the objectives of the resolution with regard to de-escalating the various conflicts, to prevent them from reigniting and spreading inside the country, including by working on an active basis alongside the Macedonian authorities. Resolution 1371 of the UN Security Council was adopted on 26 September 2001. Allied Harmony was mandated from 16 December 2002 to 31 March 2003, after which time the EU would be able to take over responsibility for the mission.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish Parliament had already agreed to assist in Macedonia when it decided to deploy Danish troops to NATO’s Operation Amber Fox. The basis for this decision was a continued desire to contribute towards stability in the Balkans in the form of an unambiguous extension to previous Danish contributions to operations in Macedonia. NATO’s request for a contribution to Operation Allied Harmony received a positive response. The force was deployed on 16 December 2002 and was comprised of three staff officers to serve at NATO's headquarters in Skopje and two light liaison teams, each comprised of two vehicles and their two-man crews, to perform surveillance duties in the local area and maintain contact to the Macedonian authorities. The original Parliamentary decision (B5) to assist NATO in Macedonia was proposed by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and was unanimously adopted in Parliament on 9 October 2001.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish contribution to Amber Fox was ordered to return home on 15 December 2002 and was replaced by a contribution to Operation Allied Harmony, which was composed of two light liaison teams and three staff officers who would operate alongside Norwegian and German troops. A total of 11 Danes were deployed. After 31 March 2003, the EU replaced the NATO force with a smaller military force that continued to perform the same missions as those performed by NATO. Because of the Danish defence waiver, the Danish contribution was recalled as this waiver does not permit Danish participation in EU military operations. When NATO replaced Operation Amber Fox with Allied Harmony, the number of NATO soldiers was reduced from approx. 700 to approx. 450.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Allied Harmony followed Operation Amber Fox from 16 December 2002 to 31 March 2003, after which the EU continued to perform the missions begun by NATO. The EU operation was named European Union Force Concordia (EUFOR Concordia). This was the very first EU military operation.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Denmark deployed three staff officers and two light liaison teams. The staff officers served in the operation headquarters in Skopje. The task of the two light liaison teams was surveillance in local Macedonian areas and to maintain contact with local Macedonian authorities.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Although virtually all Macedonian governments until 2001 had included ethnic Albanian parties, very few concessions were made with regard to what these parties were trying to achieve, namely political, social and economic equality relative to the Slavic Macedonian parties and population segments. Because Macedonia’s population was primarily comprised of Slavic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians, there was some concern among the various parties that there would be unrest if the Albanian parties’ demands for equality were not satisfied. These fears became reality when violent conflict broke out between Slavic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians in the second half of 2000. The opposing groups were, however, able to agree a ceasefire on 6 July 2001. After the ceasefire was agreed, the Macedonian government would reassert its authority in the whole of Macedonia. This would be achieved by measures such as a multi-ethnic police force that would be implemented on a gradual basis. Observers from Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) and European Union Monitoring Mission (EUMM) were deployed to assist and inspect compliance with the ceasefire and to assist in putting necessary structures into place in the country. On 19 September 2002, Macedonia’s President Crvenkovski, who had won the parliamentary elections earlier that month, requested NATO to deploy a small force to operate as additional security for the observers and other agencies. NATO granted the request in the form of Operation Amber Fox, which performed its mission until 15 December 2002.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for NATO’s Operation Amber Fox, as adopted by UN Security Council Resolution 1371 of 26 September 2001 was based on a desire that the conflict in Macedonia should not escalate or spread. Specifically, the operation would support the Macedonian authorities in their efforts to de-escalate the various conflicts. The original duration of the operation was three months but was extended at the request of the Macedonian government by a further three months, from 3 December 2001 to 26 March 2002. The mandate was subsequently extended several times but was finally dissolved on 15 December 2002. The subsequent Operation Allied Harmony mission was based on the same resolution and commenced in September 2001.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Proposal B5 was proposed by the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs and adopted unanimously on 9 October 2001. Danish participation was in line with the general desire to contribute towards increased stability in the Balkans and was an extension of previous Danish missions to Macedonia.  The initial contribution was approximately 40 Danish soldiers: a light reconnaissance group of approximately 30 men, a number of staff officers and a national support group.
At NATO’s request, Denmark also provided helicopters during the period August to October. This was comprised of three Fennec helicopters and the required support personnel. This contribution was considered as an extension of Proposal B5 and was operational from mid-August.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Approximately 1,000 NATO soldiers took part in Operation Amber Fox. Of these, the Danish contribution was initially 40 persons. 30 of the Danish troops were part of a light reconnaissance group, equipped with hardware such as EAGLE armoured vehicles. The remaining contribution was comprised of a number of staff officers and a national support group in Skopje. The reconnaissance group was stationed together with the German battalion in Skopje, which was providing logistics support. At NATO’s request, helicopters were deployed during August to October 2002. This was comprised of a helicopter detachment of three Fennec helicopters and six crew members, as well as a support group of 18 soldiers. A Danish major-general was also present in Macedonia as Commander of Task Force Fox. The major-general was also NATO’s Senior Military Representative towards the Macedonian authorities.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Operation Amber Fox was active from 26 September 2001 to 15 December 2002. Its successor was Operation Allied Harmony, which commenced on16 December 2002 and ran for six months. Denmark’s contribution to Amber Fox lasted from 9 October 2001 to 15 December 2002. The Danish Operation Amber Fox forces were replaced by a second Danish contribution to NATO’s subsequent Operation Allied Harmony and was now comprised of two light liaison teams and three staff officers, i.e. 11 soldiers.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission of the Danish force that was originally deployed was to support and show a presence in cases of unrest that the Macedonian government forces were unable to deal with themselves. The force was also structured and equipped to be able to perform an evacuation of the international observers, should the need arise. The Fennec helicopters mainly flew reconnaissance and liaison missions to support the operation.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Iraq’s war with Iran in 1980 was very expensive to Iraq. After the end of the war, Iraq was billions in debt. Iraq’s dictator, Saddam Hussein, believed that neighbouring Kuwait had been illegally pumping oil from an oilfield that was in both Iraq and Kuwait and had been selling oil and making huge profits during the war. The allegedly illegal drilling had, according to Hussein, resulted in Iraq losing huge sums of money. He therefore wanted compensation from Kuwait for economic losses, which Kuwait refused to pay. Baghdad considered this to be an act of aggression and, on 2 August 1990, Iraq started what would eventually become known as the First Gulf War. At this time, Iraq had the fourth largest military in the world and conquered Kuwait very quickly. Kuwait was occupied in just two days and Iraqi tanks were then deployed to the border between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. If Hussein decided he wanted to continue the war and seize the Saudi Arabian oilfields, he would be in control of half of the world’s oil resources. Both Saudi Arabia and the USA were alarmed by this and had already strongly condemned the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, which was a fully sovereign state and the USA, Saudi Arabia and 25 other countries decided to intervene, with a mandate from the UN. The American-led coalition was deployed at the border of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait and in the Persian Gulf off Kuwait. The mustering phase was named Operation Desert Shield and involved the assembly of an effective force that would be able to protect Saudi Arabia. This operation ran from 7 August 1990 to 17 January 1991. The coalition changed its strategy after January and transitioned to the offensive phase of the Gulf War, the ultimate goal being the liberation of Kuwait. This phase was named Operation Desert Storm. Denmark participated in both Operation Desert Shield and Operation Desert Storm with the corvette Olfert Fischer, which was deployed in Operation Faraway. The Danish corvette assisted in maintaining the UN trading embargo on Iraq and sailed reconnaissance and other missions in the Strait of Hormuz  The corvette’s status was that of “non-combatant”, which meant that Olfert Fischer was not permitted to engage in offensive action, only to defend itself against aggressors. The coalition finally liberated Kuwait on 28 February 1991.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 660 of 2 August 1990 with a view to stopping the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait, both of which were UN member states. This resolution condemned Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait and demanded that Saddam Hussein immediately withdrew his troops from Kuwait. When Hussein ignored the UN’s demands, the UN adopted Resolution 661 of 6 August 1990, which introduced economic sanctions against Iraq. In practical terms, this meant a trade blockade with a mandate to use armed force to maintain its integrity. Olfert Fischer was deployed under the resolution to enforce the objectives of this mandate. Maritime trade to Iraq was not the only trade that the UN wanted to limit. In UN Resolution 670 of 25 September 1990 it was decided that the embargo would also extend to air transport. This expanded embargo meant that aircraft carrying all other cargo than food, medicines or humanitarian aid would be denied entry to Iraqi air space.

At the end of the war the UN adopted Resolution 687 of 3 April 1991, which formed the basis of the ceasefire between Iraq and Kuwait. One of the resolution’s requirements was that Iraq should destroy its stocks of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, as well as any missiles with ranges longer than 150 kilometres. Iraq was in addition required to accept verification by UN inspectors from the UN Special Commission (UNSCOM) and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 13 August 1990 the Emir of Kuwait asked the Danish Prime Minister to take military action against Iraq so that Kuwait’s rights could be restored and to liberate the country. The Danish Parliament decided to send the corvette Olfert Fischer to the Middle East under a UN mandate that was intended to implement an embargo against Iraq. The ship was authorised under the UN mandate to stop all incoming and outward bound maritime traffic for inspection and verification of their cargo and destinations. The Danish national instructions determined that the corvette’s mission was to ensure the implementation of sanctions against Iraq in accordance with resolutions 661 and 665. The ship would remain under Danish command and, if it was attacked, was only authorised to use force as necessary for self defence, including the defence of its accompanying Norwegian supply ship.

Proposal B81 to deploy Olfert Fischer was adopted by 97 votes in favour and 25 against on 31 August 1990.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
There is no full overview of how many personnel and vehicles/vessels/aircraft were mustered by the coalition, but according to estimates the coalition had approximately 700,000 troops, 1,700 aircraft, 2,000 tanks and 190 ships at its disposal. One of these ships was the Olfert Fischer, which marked the first operation of a Danish warship outside Europe since the colonial era. The 92-strong crew was expanded to 100, with a doctor, chaplain, interpreter and various specialists and was not comprised of 16 officers, 11 non-commissioned officers, 54 male and 9 female marine constables, 8 conscripts, a chaplain and an interpreter.
The ship was slightly modified because it would face high levels of humidity and temperatures of up to 50 degrees Centigrade. The conditions that the Danes would be operating under in the Persian Gulf were somewhat different from usual. The corvette’s arms systems were also adjusted. Stinger ground-to-air missiles were fitted to supplement the ship’s normal Sea Sparrow defensive armament.
A decision was made in Norway on 31 August 1990 that coastguard vessel Andenes would be made available to Olfert Fischer as a supply ship, carrying spare parts and ammunition etc., with a Danish supply team serving on board. The two ships met on 19 October in the area of operation and were thus ready to take part in Operation Faraway. The Danish-Norwegian deployment operated in the Persian Gulf, with warships from seven other countries, including Canada, Argentina and Oman.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The actual Gulf War lasted from 2 August 1990 to 28 February 1991 after the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait was over. Olfert Fischer sailed from Copenhagen on 12 September, arriving at its destination in Jebel Ali in the United Arab Emirates on 3 October 1990. When the war ended, the ship set sail for Denmark and arrived back on 15 September 1991.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Corvette Olfert Fischer and Norwegian warship Andenes comprised what is known in internationally maritime terminology as a “Task Group”, the Danish commander aboard Olfert Fischer acting as “Task Group Commander”. This meant that he was in command of both units. Olfert Fischer’s task was to enforce the UN trading embargo against Iraq. In practical terms, this meant inspection missions where the ship tried to find cargo vessels that may be carrying goods that were not permitted to be introduced to Iraq. The cargo of suspicious vessels was searched and if any cargo was discovered that was covered by the embargo, ships would be escorted to port for unloading. The mission was originally deployed west of the Strait of Hormuz, covering the area where the Gulf of Oman joins the Persian Gulf. The corvette would eventually be ordered further up the Gulf towards Kuwait and Iraq, where the level of threat would increase. The ship was never attacked by Iraqi aircraft and, during its deployment, managed to check 337 trading vessels.

missions.title: Frontex, the Mediterranean
missions.subtitle: The EU’s external borders
missions.name: Frontex Middelhavet
missions.descriptiveName: The European Border and Coast Guard Agency

text.heading: Background
text.text:
1985 saw the introduction of a partnership between EU member states except the United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland to increase the freedom of movement for EU citizens across EU national borders. Belgium, France, West Germany, Luxembourg and the Netherlands met in Luxembourg in the town of Schengen, where an agreement was concluded to eliminate national border controls. Better know as “the Schengen Agreement”. This agreement meant that people from Schengen countries would be freely able to cross national borders, including when travelling by air and sea. Other countries joined the agreement later on, including Italy, Greece and Spain. Denmark signed up to Schengen in 1996 after an inter-governmental agreement between Denmark and the EU, with other countries joining during the 90s and 00s, as increased numbers of migrants and refugees were trying to get into the EU. Against this background, it was decided that border controls at the external borders of Schengen member states would be tightened. For this purpose, the EU set up the Frontex organisation, which became active in 2005. This is known under the same name in Danish, or as Det Europæiske Agentur for Grænse- og Kystbevogtning (European Border and Coast Guard Agency) and is responsible for coordinating operations and activities related to border controls. With the immigration crisis of 2015-2016 the EU’s external borders fell under immense pressure, including in Italy and Greece, it was decided that the Frontex mandate would be extended, becoming a full-scale border and coast guard agency. As well as issuing EU border security risk assessments, Frontex also published information about the potential for unlawful immigration and human trafficking to the involved EU countries. It also developed common training standards for border authorities, with a view to harmonising training within the Schengen nations. The operations in which Frontex was involved with coordination received further funding after the mandate was extended, allowing the operations to deal with larger areas. The Royal Danish Air Force and Danish police have contributed to border and coast guard operations in the form of surveillance/search operations for desperate boat refugees and migrants, the observation of smuggling operations and illegal fisheries. The Danish National Police has the overall responsibility for Danish Frontex participation.

FRONTEX is comprised of various elements, each focusing on its own special areas: EURPOL for police deployments, EASO for asylum cases, EFCAC for fisheries and EMSAC for maritime safety.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Frontex was set up due to the need for an organisation that would be able to plan and organise operations at Schengen’s external borders. One purpose of the organisation is to assist in the setting up of operations related to illegal immigration. This may involve border controls, surveillance of land and sea borders, the identification of forged documentation and the investigation of who may be responsible for the forgeries. Frontex is also tasked with the preparation of Schengen countries’ external border risk assessments with a view to revealing potential areas where there may be problems. When the EU began to experience the beginning of a major refugee crisis in 2015 with the arrival of 1.5 million illegal refugees, the EU pushed for an expansion of Frontex that would better enable the organisation to deal with the increased pressure. The augmentation of the organisation’s mandate was adopted in COM 671 final, which meant a tripling of the funding received by Frontex for the Triton, Poseidon and Themis missions, as well as increased funding to purchase equipment for small to medium-sized operations. Resources were also spent to further an increased partnership between Frontex and third world countries. The extended mandate meant 600 additional employees to accommodate the new workload.
European Commission Council regulation no. 2007 to establish the Frontex mandate was adopted on 26 October 2004, COM 671 final being adopted on 15 December 2015.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark did not participate in the decision to set up Frontex but did become a participant in the partnership in 2005. Denmark’s Frontex participation is on an inter-governmental basis, which means that if the EU proposes new laws that would change Frontex, the Danish Parliament would be able to adopt or reject the proposal, which would not be the case in a supra-national partnership.
Danish participation over various periods has been based on Government decisions after discussion by the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Since 2015, Danish Defence has contributed for various periods in the form of CL-604 Challenger aircraft, including engineers/technicians etc. These contributions have normally been 30 days in duration and have, in collaboration with the Danish Emergency Management Agency, involved 22 fingerprinting and registration officers and 11 civilian employees who were deployed to reception centres in Greece.

August 2019 saw the participation of a Defender-type surveillance aircraft and its crew from the Danish Home Guard in Operation Indalo, which involved the surveillance of the Spanish Mediterranean coast on the lookout for human traffickers and drugs smugglers.

After the informal EU summit in September 2018 and after discussion in the Foreign Policy Committee on 21 September 2018, the Government decided that it would again deploy Challenger aircraft and thermal coast guard equipment in 2019 to the Greek island of Kos and on a patrol boat that was part of Operation Poseidon. As part of the increased surveillance of the eastern Mediterranean, two of the new patrol vessels were also assigned to the mission during the autumn of 2019, 2021 - and in 2022, 2024 again the deployment of surveillance aircraft, coast guard equipment. The Fennec helicopter for the surveillance of coastal areas continued to participate in 2022. 
To date, Denmark has so far collaborated with 25 other European countries as part of Operation Triton.
Not only in the Mediterranean was there a need for surveillance. In December 2021 Denmark contributed with a Challanger surveillance aircraft in Operation OPAL COAST over the English Channel.
In April 2022 Danish Defence sent Fennec helicopters with crew to Slovakia, where they contributed to the surveillance of Europe's external borders. And again in 2023 to the Mediterranean.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Frontex was set up in October 2004 and remains active, being primarily engaged in and around the Mediterranean. Denmark has participated since Frontex was set up, initially in the form of contributions from the Danish Police and the Danish Immigration Service. Denmark has contributed Challenger surveillance aircraft on multiple occasions to Frontex Operation Triton in the Mediterranean, total 40 days in 2015 and 31 days in 2017. The aircraft were deployed three times in 2018 (January, June and November) and again in 2019 and 2020. In 202, 2022 and 2023 surveillance aircraft again was deployed. Patrol vessels (coastal pilot vessels) and coastal surveillance hardware would also take part. Futhermore surveillance Air Craft Defender was deplyed.
Danish Defence deployed 11 civilian employees from 30 October 2017 to 6 January 2018 to support the work of Danish police in Italy and Greece. A more recent contribution involved 22 fingerprints and registration offices deployed over five teams to Greece, Spain and Italy from March 2018 and into 2019. 
Contribution to Operation OPAL COAST was deployed in December 2021. 
The Fennec helicopters were deployed between April and Oktober 2022 and again in 2023 from June until November.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission of the Danish CL-604 Challenger aircraft is to monitor the EU’s external borders (sea) to locate boats carrying migrants, to locate and pursue boats used by traffickers and to inform about illegal fishing activities. During the execution of these duties, the aircraft would occasionally have Italian customs and exercise officials on board. The main area of deployment was off the coast of Italy and Malta in the central Mediterranean.  Other duties performed by the aircraft included general surveillance of maritime traffic.
The mission of the 11 civilian Danish Defence employees was to assist in the Danish Police contribution to Frontex in Italy and Greece by registering refugees and migrants, photographing them and taking their fingerprints, as well as performing administrative tasks.  The mission of the personnel deployed by the Danish Emergency Management Agency was to set up and operate facilities related to the reception centres in Greece. 
The mission in December 2021 over the English Channel was tasked with deteching and identifying vessels with migrants from France to United Kingdom. 
The task in April 2022 in Slovakia  covered various tasks for the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, Frontex.
The main tasks of the helicopter contribution were to detect, identify and report on any persons attemting to enter Slovakia outside the established border between Slovakia and Ukraine.

missions.title: Medical teams in the First Gulf War
missions.subtitle: Medical corps in full swing
missions.name: 1. Irakkrig Irak/Saudi Arabien & Holstebro
missions.descriptiveName: 1991 Medical team for UK and Holstebro field hospitals

text.heading: Background
text.text: When Iraq invaded Iran in 1980, the Iraqis believed that it would be a short and successful campaign. The war ended up lasting for eight years, costing both sides great human and financial expense. When the war ended in 1988, Iraq owed billions and Saddam Hussein believed that neighbouring Kuwait had been illegally pumping oil from an oilfield that was located in both countries and had sold the oil at an enormous profit while the war was going on. Hussein presented Kuwait with a demand for financial compensation, which was rejected. Iraq considered this rejection as an act of aggression and launched what would later be known as the First Gulf War on 2 August 1990. Denmark provided a humanitarian contribution during this war, sending doctors and medical teams to the Middle East and airborne ambulances that could fly the injured from the front line to military hospitals in Frankfurt and the Danish town of Holstebro. The choice of Holstebro was no coincidence. During the Cold War, Denmark had entered into an agreement with the USA that it would send reinforcements in the form of the 12th US Division that would be able to reinforce elements of the Danish-German corps in Slesvig-Holstein if an attack from the Eastern Bloc took place. The division would not bring its own hospital support but would be supported by an emergency hospital belonging to the US Air Force that had been set up during peacetime. This meant stockpiling medical equipment in Holstebro and making a number of modifications to the buildings of the Dragoons’ Barracks. When the USA, with Denmark as part of the coalition, entered the Gulf War, it therefore made good sense to activate the American emergency hospital in Holstebro with Danish personnel, including guards etc. The number of casualties incurred during the reconquest of Kuwait was, however, no higher than front-line field hospitals were able to cope with. The military hospital in Holstebro therefore ended up not being used.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The first UN mandate to end the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait is found in Security Council Resolution 660 of 2 August 1990. In this resolution, the UN condemned the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq and demanded that Saddam Hussein withdrew his troops immediately. The resolution was followed by other resolutions, including Resolution 678 of 29 November 1990. In this resolution the UN made it clear that the organisation’s member states were authorised to use all necessary means to ensure that Resolution 660 and all subsequent resolutions were enforced. As a result, the Danish Parliament decided that its participation would involve the corvette Olfert Fischer and the deployment of a medical team to the Middle East and the activation of the military hospital in Holstebro.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 2 January 1991 the British government asked several other countries, including Denmark and other Scandinavian countries, to provide medical aid if war was to break out in the Gulf. The Parliament responded positively to this request. It authorised the Danish Minister of Defence to deploy military doctors and a military medical team to assist British field hospitals in the Middle East. The Minister was also authorised to set up, staff and guard the American military emergency hospital in Holstebro using Danish personnel.  It was also decided that a Danish-crewed air ambulance would fly injured troops either to the American hospital in Frankfurt, or directly from the Gulf to the military hospital in Holstebro.

Proposal L63 was adopted unanimously with 132 votes in its third reading on 17 January 1991.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Parliament decided that it would contribute in the form of military doctors and a military medical team of 30-40 people that would be deployed to British field hospitals in Saudi Arabia and by setting up the military hospital at the barracks in Holstebro, where 41 doctors, 43 nurses and 150 other employees would be ready to accept up to 40 patients with injuries a day with seven wards and a total of 200 beds. A civilian Boeing 737 aircraft belonging to Maersk Air was also fitted out as an air ambulance with space for 40 stretchers. Finally, containers were acquired that would be able to equip a hospital ship if required. A Danish hospital ship was never set up in the Gulf.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The actual Gulf War lasted from 2 August 1990 to 28 February 1991, when Kuwait was liberated. The Danish military doctors and military medical team in Saudi Arabia were deployed shortly after the Danish Parliament decision of 17 January 1991. The team returned to Denmark in February 1991. The military hospital in Holstebro reported that it was in a state of readiness on 9 February 1990 with over 200 beds and was closed in February 1991.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The military hospital in Holstebro would have been able to accept soldiers who had been injured in the Gulf War and was designed to accept 40 wounded a day, with 24-hour operating capabilities in eight theatres, with all injured under full anaesthesia. A full-scale professional hospital. The mission of the chartered Boeing 737 was to fly injured troops to either the American hospital in Frankfurt or directly from the Gulf to Denmark, landing at Karup airbase and driving in convoy to Holstebro.  The Danish military doctors and military medical team for the British field hospital in Saudi Arabia was part of a collaboration on the staffing of 12 operating theatres in a 600 bed hospital. The team had plenty to do.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The International Conference on the Former Yugoslavia (ICFY) was established in London in 1992. The conference was led by the USA and the European Union (EU) and would serve as a framework for dialogues that would be able to bring peace to the Former Yugoslavia. The situation was critical. Croatia and Slovenia had left the Yugoslavian confederation. Croatia was home to a large Serb minority who opposed Croatian independence and who were actively supported by the Yugoslavian army, which led to armed engagements between Serbs and Croats. These conflicts then spread to Bosnia-Herzegovina. ICFY tried to manage these conflicts through dialogue between the involved parties, but to no avail. The failure to achieve results led to a UN decision to deploy a United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR) in Croatia, Bosnia-Hercegovina and Macedonia and to deploy observers with the aid of the European Union Monitoring Mission (ECMM). ICFY also deployed its own observers. There were many reasons for these deployments, including the violent conduct of the Bosnian Serb military and the sanctions that had been deployed against Serbia, which meant that it was no longer permitted to bring materials such as fuel and armaments from Serbia to Bosnia-Herzegovina.  These sanctions required monitoring by neutral observers, which led NATO to request stricter surveillance of the border between Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia by a third party in 1993. From 1994 to 1996, ICFY with observers from countries that included Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Norway, as well as France, Germany, Russia, the USA and the United Kingdom, was responsible for monitoring the border between Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia. A total of 18 countries contributed to this mission.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate was established in UN Security Council Resolution 943 of 23 September 1994. The deployed observers (about 200 people) would be entitled to monitor, inspect and patrol along a 600km border between Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia. They were also given diplomatic status.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: In 1993, Norwegian ICFY co-chairman Thorvald Stoltenberg met with Yugoslav President Milošević, where it was agreed that observers would be deployed at the Drina river. The Drina is located between Serbia and Bosnia-Herzegovina and fuel and armaments could be carried over its bridges from Serbia to its neighbour. Stoltenberg then contacted the Danish minister of foreign affairs and others, to hear if Denmark was willing to contribute about ten observers to be part of a Scandinavian unit under the auspices of ICFY. Denmark responded with a very clear “yes” within 24 hours. The decision to deploy Danish observers to the ICYF mission was presented to the Danish Foreign Affairs Committee. Denmark would initially deploy 15 observers to the mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: A total of 200 observers from 18 countries were deployed at the Bosnia-Herzegovinan/Serbian border, half of the observers being from the Scandinavian countries.  Denmark provided 15, approximately the same number as Sweden, Finland and Norway. 12 Danish officers were deployed over the period. Observers from Danish Defence and Danish Customs Services also performed monitoring duties.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The ICFY mission was active from 23 September 1994 to 31 January 1996. Danish observers participated for the entire duration.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The observers’ duties were concentrated in areas and roads near to and crossing the Drina river and involved the inspection and monitoring of transport between Bosnia-Herzegovina and Serbia, including that humanitarian aid was able to get through and that the sanctions that had been introduced were followed.  This meant stopping and confiscating all transports of oil and armaments that were trying to enter Bosnia-Herzegovina from Serbia at the border crossings of Zvornik, Kotroman, Propolje, Niksic, Banja Koviljaca and Loznica.  Observers were also entitled to perform checks at locations where vehicles were loaded, and to insist upon unloading. Because the observers were not themselves authorised to stop vehicles that were under suspicion of transporting illegal supplier, ICYF collaborated with NATO and the UN, who were authorised to do so. When the mission ended in January 1996, it was believed that the transportation of oil and arms into Bosnia-Herzegovina had been effectively stopped and essential humanitarian aid transport had been able to get through.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia involved wars of independence and ethnic cleansing. The first acts of war were when Croatia and Slovenia left the Yugoslavian confederation. There was fighting in Croatia, where a Serb minority did not wish to be part of Croatia. The European Community tried to stop the conflict, but to no avail. The UN then became involved and tried to end the fighting, introducing an embargo on the introduction of armaments and munitions to Yugoslavia in 1991. Negotiations were fruitless, so in 1992 the UN established the United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR), whose mission was to build peace and manage security in Yugoslavia. UNPROFORwas initially deployed in Croatia but it became quickly obvious that deployment in Croatia alone would not suffice. The force’s mandate was then extended to encompass Bosnia-Herzegovina. The situation there was complicated, with three ethnic groups: Bosnian Muslims, Bosnian Croats and Bosnian Serbs, all of whom were fighting against each other. The prospect of a ceasefire looked distant. After an air campaign in autumn 1995, a peace treaty was finally signed in Paris on 14 December 1995 by the presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia to end the 3½ year long war. This was called the Dayton Peace Agreement (DPA). NATO was the organisation that would be responsible for maintaining law and order and ensuring that the objectives of the peace treaty were implemented in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The Implementation Force (IFOR) was set up to perform this role. Despite having only a single year’s mandate, this was a large-scale mission that involved 54,000 soldiers, a number which totalled 80,000 if supply troops in Croatia, Serbia and Hungary are also included. The force would initially concentrate on separating the two opposing factions (the national Bosnian forces and Bosnian Serb forces), the confiscation of arms and extensive patrols along the 1,400km “border” between the two combatants and in the vicinity of the demilitarised zones. In the second half of 1996, NATO’s IFOR would change into The Stabilization Force (SFOR), which was set up on 20 December 1996.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: IFOR’s mandate was provided in UN Security Council Resolution 1031 of 15 December 1995. This was based on the Dayton peace treaty that had been signed, with the overall aim of stopping the conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The mandate also required the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe(OSCE) to set up programmes for referendums in the country. IFOR would also have authority and control over Bosnia-Hercegovina’s airspace and would, if necessary, use force to perform its duties. The mandate was subsequently extended to encompass policing and was named The International Police Task Force(IPTF). Personnel for the later would, after UNPROFOR was wound down, be transferred to IFOR, which was expected to operate for about a year. The mandate was expanded in UN Security Council resolution 1035 of 21 December 1995 and was active until 20 December 1996, the same day that IFOR was shut down and succeeded by NATO’s SFOR operation.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The annotations to the Danish Parliament’s decision to participate in IFOR state that the contribution was a natural extension to previous commitments in the Balkans and previous support for the peace treaty. The force was authorised by the UN Security Council and would operate under NATO command, performing its duties pursuant to the Bosnia-Herzegovina peace treaty. After IFOR was wound down, the Danish Parliament decided to allow Danish forces to join the follow-up force, SFOR.
The decision that Denmark would contribute to IFOR was made in parliamentary decision B60, that was presented by the Minister of Foreign Affairs and adopted on 15 December 1995 by 120 votes in favour and eight against.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution was considerable. It is sometimes called a “Battle Group” as it was composed of numerous specialists and a wide variety of units. Overall, the force numbered 1,600 troops. Including a brigade staff company, an air support group, national support groups, a liaison team and an intelligence group, as well as a downscaled armoured infantry battalion comprised of staff and a staff company, an armoured infantry company, a squadron of tanks (transferred from NORDBAT 2/UNPROFOR) and a logistics company. Elements from the supply services were deployed in Hungary. Danish staff personnel were also part of the NATO command structure. Reinforcements from the Jaeger Corps would also be deployed in 1995-96. The contributions would be part of a joint Scandinavian/Polish brigade of about 4,000 troops, which also included an infantry battalion from Poland. Overall, the combined force was part of an American division. Top priority was given to providing the soldiers with the best possible protection and options for effective action, so the force was assured artillery support from the American division and air support from NATO aircraft, in addition to its own armaments.
Denmark was one of 33 countries, including Canada, France and Turkey, that contributed forces to IFOR.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: IFOR operated from 20 December 1995 to 20 December 1996 and was followed by Stabilisation Force (SFOR) which essentially involved the same forces. Most of the Danish forces that were part of the previous UN UNPROFORmission in Bosnia-Herzegovina were recalled on 26 September 1995, but parts of this force (including the Danish tank squadron) were deployed to IFOR on 20 September 1995. IFOR ended on 20 December 1996, the Danish contribution continuing as part of SFOR (Danish Parliament decision B68 of 20 December 1996).

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The main duties of the IFOR force were based on the Dayton Treaty and aimed to ensure that the parties would withdraw their military forces to the agreed boundaries within the agreed deadline and that territory would be handed over as agreed. Where possible, the NATO force would also provide security for the other missions that were operating in the area. This involved protecting the OSCE and EU observer mission (ECMM) and the work that was being done by humanitarian organisations including The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR).  Danish units were very busy disarming the combatants near the northern town of Doboj in Bosnia-Herzegovina, where the Danish camp was located. It was important to gain control of the town, as this was part of the ethnic boundary between Muslims and Serbs. There was extensive focus on the prevention of conflict in the period leading up to the 14 September 1996 election of representatives to the House of Representatives for the Federation of Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Serb Republic, respectively. Due to the large presence of troops at the polling stations, high visibility and a long-term “diplomatic offensive” towards representatives of the local authorities, there were no problems.  Many resources were set aside during this entire period to provide humanitarian aid to the civilian population in and around Doboj. Other forms of humanitarian aid included support for the Danish Refugee Council and Save the Children, including aid in the reconstruction of schools and kindergartens.
Additional to these activities were the more routine duties that were performed on behalf of IFOR, as well as ongoing patrols, the collection and registration of weapons, dialogue with local authorities and surveillance etc.

missions.title: OIF Golfen
missions.subtitle: Iraqi Freedom
missions.name: OIF Golfen
missions.descriptiveName: The Submarine Sælen & the Corvette Olfert Fischer

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Opinions are divided as to the background for the conflict in Iraq and the events leading up to Denmark’s involvement. The following covers only a few of the many factors that played a role.
After the Gulf War in 1991, the UN demanded among other things that Iraq destroy its weapons of mass destruction (chemical and biological weapons and nuclear weapons) as well as missiles with a range above 150 km (93 miles). Iraq was in addition required to accept verification by UN inspectors from the UN Special Commission (UNSCOM) and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). Tensions between Hussein and the UN/US persisted through the 1990s when Hussein refused to get rid of the weapons of mass destruction believed by the UN and the US to remain in his possession or to provide proof they had been eliminated. On 11 September 2001, two planes hijacked by Al-Qaeda flew into the World Trade Center, and a third plane hit the Pentagon. After the terrorist attack on America, George W. Bush initiated the war on terror under the name Operation Enduring Freedom. This war on terror turned out to have consequences also for Iraq and Saddam Hussein. Influential elements in the US believed that Hussein might have connections to Al-Qaeda and possibly could be sheltering terrorists. It was once again relevant to know whether Hussein still had weapons of mass destruction, and the Americans wanted to launch an investigation. No weapons of mass destruction were found in Iraq, and connections between Hussein and Al-Qaeda were not verified. The Iraqis made it difficult for the investigation teams to get access to information and to enter sites. As a result, many long discussions were held in the UN Security Council. To this day, opinions are divided as to these discussions. Similarly, opinions are divided as to whether there was a clear UN mandate to invade Iraq. There were arguments for and against an invasion, but nevertheless a coalition was formed for this purpose by the US. It was joined by many countries including Denmark, the United Kingdom, and Australia. The operation was named Operation Iraqi Freedom and was launched on 20 March 2003. During the invasion, Denmark contributed the submarine Sælen, the corvette Olfert Fischer, and a medical team. The invasion of Iraq was quick and effective, and Saddam Hussein’s government was ousted. The subsequent rebuilding of Iraq – in the midst of serious internal tensions among various segments of the population – turned out to be a protracted affair. Although the Iraq War ended in 2011, international forces are still present in the country today. That includes Danish soldiers.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The initial phase of the Iraq War was led by America. Was there, or was there not, a clear mandate from the UN? There are many views on that question! Quite a few UN resolutions were made prior to the invasion. As an example, prior to the invasion, the UN had adopted Resolution 1441 of 8 November 2002 giving Iraq one last chance to meet its obligations to disarm and remove its weapons of mass destruction as it had been demanded by the UN since the end of the Gulf War. The most important part of Resolution 1441 was a demand that Iraq permit inspectors from the UN Monitoring and Verification Commission (UNMOVIC) and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to have unlimited freedom of movement and access to individuals for questioning at all times of the day or night. Although Saddam Hussein did not comply with the UN demands entirely, the work of the inspectors proceeded. However, when inspectors from UNMOVIC and IAEA were not granted unlimited and immediate access to some areas in Iraq, the US viewed it as a breach of Resolution 1441. Based on the absence of unconditional cooperation from Hussein, the US view was that the provisions in Resolution 1441 and in previous ones such as Resolutions 678 and 687 justified the use of military power against Iraq. In addition, the US view was that these resolutions could not prevent UN member nations from defending themselves against the threat from Iraq and could not – per Resolution 1441 – prevent them from using military power against Iraq. To this day, the justification for the invasion into Iraq is being debated.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On request from the US, Parliament decided to contribute the submarine Sælen, the corvette Olfert Fischer, and a medical team. This decision was regarded as being aligned with an overall Danish policy of supporting international law and eliminating threats against international peace and security. It was stressed that Iraq had neglected its obligations to disarm in compliance with UN resolutions. According to the UN arms inspectors, Iraq had likewise failed to comply with the demands in Resolution 1441 for immediate, unconditional, and active cooperation.
Parliamentary approval of proposal B118 to provide Danish military forces to a multinational operation in Iraq was given on 21 March 2003 with 61 votes in favour and 50 votes opposed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: During Operation Iraqi Freedom, Denmark supplied the corvette Olfert Fischer, the submarine Sælen, and a medical team – a total contingent of approximately 150-160 Danish personnel. Both Olfert Fischer and Sælen had a mandate to use force in self defence and to the extent necessary for execution of their orders. The primary defensive weapon on Olfert Fischer was her anti-aircraft system Sea Sparrow, and Sælen carried torpedoes and electronic equipment developed in Sweden. During the operations, Denmark collaborated with the US, Australia, and the UK among others.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The invasion dubbed Operation Iraqi Freedom started on 20 March 2003 and ended on 17 February 2010 when it was replaced by Operation New Dawn.
When the Danish contribution was approved on 21 March 2003, Olfert Fischer had already joined the NATO Operation Active Endeavour (OAE) whose mission was to prevent terrorists and weapons of mass destruction from being transported through the Mediterranean and to protect ships against piracy. When the corvette arrived at Rota in Spain a few days prior to the approval in Parliament, the crew received the order to proceed to the Persian Gulf in order to join Operation Iraqi Freedom. Olfert Fischer arrived at the naval base in Bahrain on 3 April after a very fast journey and returned to Denmark on 14 June 2003, having delivered about three months of service in the Persian Gulf. Like Olfert Fischer,Sælen had been a part of the NATO Operation Active Endeavor since the summer of 2002. The plan was for the submarine to return to Denmark in January 2003. That plan changed. The submarine was now ordered to head for the Persian Gulf. It arrived in Bahrain on 14 March and joined Operation Iraqi Freedom from 21 March to 5 June 2003. Upon the conclusion of the missions, it was transported back to Denmark from the base harbour in Bahrain aboard the cargo ship Grietje. Sælen returned to the naval base in Frederikshavn on 12 June 2003. The Danish medical team was deployed to Jordan to work at an American field hospital and was recalled on 16 April 2003.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission of the Danish corvette was to secure offshore installations and marine traffic in the northern part of the Gulf and to monitor Iraqi communications so as to provide the optimal protection against the Iraqi navy. The operations carried out by Sælen in the Gulf are classified, but the submarine’s size and equipment suggest that it was likely used in coastal areas where the coalition led by the US might have difficulty operating. As a result of operating in the Mediterranean, this submarine carried a considerable complement of technical equipment that was well suited for the Gulf. The Danish medical team consisted for the most part of surgeons who tended to injured coalition soldiers.
