missions.title: SFOR Bosnia
missions.subtitle: NATO Stabilisation Force
missions.name: SFOR Bosnien
missions.descriptiveName: Denmark Last Operation in BiH before EU took over

text.heading: Background
text.text: The conflicts on the Balkan Peninsula flared up violently in 1991 when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the Yugoslav federation. The nation of Bosnia-Herzegovina seceded as well and was recognised as independent by EU member states and other countries in 1992. Armed clashes and warlike conditions were prevalent in a situation where Bosnian Muslims and Croats fought against each other and together against Bosnian Serbs. Unsuccessful attempts were made to negotiate ceasefires. The UN therefore in 1992 established United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR) for the purpose of building peace and managing security in Yugoslavia. The force was deployed in Croatia and in Bosnia-Herzegovina and later in Macedonia as well. After three and a half years of conflict involving extensive loss of civilian lives, acts of ethnic cleansing, and expulsions, and especially after massive international pressure and an air campaign, at last a peace treaty was signed in Paris by the presidents of Bosnia, Croatia, and Serbia on 14 December 1995. The accord was named the Dayton Peace Agreement (DPA) after the city in the US where the negotiations had taken place. In order to ensure compliance with the agreement, NATO in its capacity of operator took on the implementation in close collaboration with the UN. For this purpose, NATO in 1995 set up theImplementation Force (IFOR) as a replacement for UNPROFOR. IFOR operated in Bosnia-Herzegovina for a year, from 20 December 1995 to 20 December 1996, and was successful in destroying weapons and prevent further conflict in the country. Upon expiry of the mandate, there was still a requirement for a noticeable presence in Bosnia-Herzegovina. The replacement was set up under the name NATO Stabilisation Force (SFOR). This force was to continue undertaking tasks based on the peace agreement such as support for civilian peace efforts, separation of the warring parties, security for the political process, continued collection of heavy weapons for depot storage, surveillance of the weapons, and repatriation of refugees. SFOR operated from 1996 to 2004.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for SFOR was provided in UN Security Council Resolution 1088 of 12 December 1996. The time frame for SFOR was extended several times by UN Security Council Resolutions No. 1305 (2000), No. 1357 (2001), and No. 1423 (2002). Although SFOR was subject to a major adjustment in 2002 to reduce the size of the force, the mandate was unchanged. The mandate was terminated on 2 December 2004. European Union Force Althea (EUFOR Althea) now assumed the work upon authorisation to do so by UN Resolution 1575 of 22 November 2004 formalising Althea as the successor to SFOR.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark’s decision to support the NATO operation SFOR with Danish military personnel was a logical extension of the previous engagement on the Balkan Peninsula, including the various UN contributions and IFOR. In SFOR, the Danes were to continue collaborating with the Nordic countries and Poland in the Nordic-Polish Brigade. Support from other units in SFOR, including air support, would continue to be possible.
The decision in Parliament to support NATO’s SFOR operation was made by approval of proposal B68, submitted by the Minister of Foreign Affairs, on 20 December 1996 with 119 votes in favour and 6 votes opposed.

As a result of the Danish referendum on the lifting of the defence opt-out and thereby as partners in the EU defence dimension the country returned in 2022 to the Balkans - initial with to doctors to work from Austrian helikopters.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution to SFOR was similar to the contribution to IFOR. It included an armoured infantry battalion made up of staff officers, a staff company, an armoured infantry company, a tank squadron, and a logistics company. The Jaeger Corps provided reinforcements from 1996 to 2000. Parts of the professional units handling replenishment of supplies were situated in Hungary. In addition, Denmark contributed personnel and elements for the command structure of the Nordic-Polish Brigade and joint units and for NATO command structures. In total, the contribution to SFOR numbered about 750 personnel per team. Close collaboration took place in order to provide protection and support for personnel working in the civilian UN police force, for Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe(OSCE), and for the EU observer mission European Community Monitoring Mission (ECMM). All these missions had participation from Denmark.
SFOR was reduced from approximately 30,000 to 22,000 personnel and restructured in 2000. In this restructuring, the Nordic-Polish Brigade was eliminated in January 2000. Then, Denmark took the initiative to establish a battalion-sized Nordic-Polish battle group as a replacement. This unit would continue to be under the command of Multinational Division North led by the US. The Danish contribution to the new structure included a scout squadron, a tank squadron, and a national support element plus staff personnel and national elements in the joint supply corps. A few other types of units were set up, such as a joint military police unit and a joint unit handling civilian-military relations. The Danish contribution to the battle group in early 2000 amounted to about 400 soldiers and 20 personnel for the SFOR headquarters. As progress was seen in Bosnia-Herzegovina, reductions were made again in 2002 and 2003. The Nordic-Polish battle group was eliminated at the beginning of 2003 and replaced by a Portuguese-Polish battle group. In this new situation, the Danish contribution now included a tank squadron and support personnel. The unit was moved to the American base near the airport in Tuzla. It had light vehicles as well as tanks and thus was capable of undertaking several tasks, some of them as a reserve unit for the brigade led by the US in Tuzla. The Danish force now numbered 150 personnel.

But in 2022 Denmarks returned to EUFOR Althea as a result of the Danish referendum on the lifting of the defence opt-out and as partners in the EU defence dimension. This time with two doctors for helicopters.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
SFOR was active from 20 December 1996 to 2 December 2004. Then, EU-led European Union Force Althea(EUFOR Althea) took over. Its tasks were to support security in the country, train military units in Bosnia-Herzegovina, and ensure continued compliance with the Dayton Peace Agreement.
The last Danish soldiers returned from SFOR in December 2004. Due to its EU defence opt-out, Denmark did not participate in EUFOR Althea.

But in 2022 Denmarks returned to EUFOR Althea as a result of the Danish referendum on the lifting of the defence opt-out and as partners in the EU defence dimension.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The missions varied greatly during the 8 years SFOR was active. They included e.g. seizure of weapons, patrols, setup and manning of checkpoints, vehicle inspections, and relations with the local population and local authorities. Emergency aid support, likewise, was a major task. Included were also protection of OSCE observers in the time leading up to various elections, monitoring of security at these elections, and support to the logistics of executing the elections. During work in SFOR, a new task was added in 1997: Assistance in capture of war criminals. However, this was limited to situations in which the Danes in the course of their normal operations happened to encounter the individuals in question.

missions.title: UNMIBH-IPTF Bosnia
missions.subtitle: Danish police in the Balkans
missions.name: UNMIBH-IPTF Bosnien
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission in Bosnia-Herzegovina/Int. Police Task Force

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The civil war in the former Yugoslavia had its roots in the desire for independence and in related acts of ethnic cleansing. There had been political tensions between the component states in Yugoslavia for years. Acts of war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded from the federation. A significant minority of Serbs lived in the border area in southern Croatia, near Bosnia. They were opposed to Croatia being independent from the federated structure. Armed hostilities erupted between Croat Serbs, supported by the Yugoslav army, and the Croats. The European Community attempted without success to end the fighting. In parallel, the UN had become involved in the conflict and worked to establish a foundation for a solution and, in 1991, to stop the flow of arms and ammunition to the area.  This did not bear fruit, and the next objective was a potential UN mission to bring about a ceasefire. The UN in 1992 set up United Nations Protection Force (UNPROFOR). Its task was to reinstate peace and provide security in Yugoslavia. To begin with, UNPROFOR entered Croatia, but it soon became apparent that the effort would need a larger scope if there were to be any continued hope of peace in a Yugoslavia beset by civil war. Thus, UNPROFOR was expanded to include Bosnia and Herzegovina under the name UNPROFOR II. Challenges were piling up. There were clashes and incidents of hostility between Bosnian Muslims and Croats and between these two groups and the Bosnian Serbs who enjoyed considerable support in the Serbian state within Yugoslavia, not to mention that the humanitarian situation for civilians was dire. As the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina remained critical, Denmark (and the UN) in 1994 decided for the first time to use heavy weapons, in this case a tank squadron, in a peacekeeping mission. UNPROFOR II in Bosnia and Herzegovina was terminated in December 1995 when the Dayton Agreement between Bosnia, Croatia, and Serbia was signed on 14 December 1995 in Paris. Fighting had then gone on for three and a half years in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Annex 11 to the Dayton Agreement specified the parties’ agreement on deployment of an international civilian police force,  UN International Police Task Force (IPTF), to support enforcement of civil law in the republic.

 With a view to ensuring that the agreement was adhered to, the work was transferred to the NATO Implementation Force (IFOR) and the UN Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina (UNMIBH). UNMIBH consisted of these elements:

- International Police Task Force (IPTF)
- Judicial System Assessment Programme (JSAP)
- Civil Affairs Unit
- Human Rights Office
- Public Affairs Office
- Administration

These elements were intended to shore up the weak status of the rule of law in Bosnia and Herzegovina by assisting in restructuring the police force and educating it in the methods of maintaining law and order. UNMIBH in addition was tasked with monitoring the judicial system; there had been many reports of signs of judicial corruption. The work was distributed across Bosnia and Herzegovina at eight headquarters. The mission worked out of these headquarters until 2002 when it was terminated and replaced by the European Union Police Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina(EUPM/BiH).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
When the Dayton Agreement was in hand (it was signed on 14 December 1995), the UN approved Resolution 1035 of 21 December 1995 to serve as the foundation for UN support of the objectives of the Dayton Agreement. In the case of the police work, Annex 11 to the Dayton Agreement served as the specific foundation. One of the objectives was to set up a UN police force (IPTF) at strategic locations in Bosnia and Herzegovina under UNMBIH. In the beginning, IPTF was charged with delivering education of and carrying out consultation with local police forces and with monitoring and inspecting local police entities. As the years went by, the tasks entrusted to IPTF were expanded:

- Resolution 1088 of 1996 gave IPTF the authority to investigate violations of human rights perpetrated by the police.
- Resolution 1144 of 1997 charged IPTF to set up a special educational program for local police units.
- In 1997, Resolutions 1103 and 1107 provided a mandate for IPTF to increase the size of its UN police force.
- Entities such as the Human Rights Office and JSAP were attached to the mission by Resolution 1088 of 12 December 1996 and Resolution 1184 of 16 July 1998 respectively.  UNMIBH operated in Bosnia and Herzegovina until 12 July 2002 when the UN Security Council by Resolution 1423 terminated it.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark’s decision to participate was made in Parliament in response to proposal B95 on 18 September 1992. Initially, the contribution was slated to include 10 police officers as of October 1995. With the growing scope of UNMBIH tasks, more capacity was needed. Parliament therefore on 20 December 1996 approved proposal B68 to increase the number of Danish police officers and to provide soldiers and observers. The military contribution was meant to be part of a follow-up force within the NATO Stabilisation Force in Bosnia and Herzegovina (SFOR).  The increase in the number of police officers was specifically dedicated to IPTF in order to achieve better results across a larger geographical area.
The military portion of Denmark’s contribution to the implementation manpower in Bosnia and Herzegovina was approved in Parliament via proposal B60 on 15 December 1995.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The number of persons working in IPTF under UNMIBH varied from year to year but culminated in 1997 with 2,057 police officers and remained at that level until the mission was terminated in December 2002. Other entities within UNMIBH included civilian personnel of about 1,600. Denmark provided an assistant chief constable from March 1997 to February 1998 and from May to December 2002 as well as about 380 police officers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNMIBH was active from 21 December 1995 to 12 July 2002 and was then succeeded by the European Union Police Monitors (EUPM) mission. The first Danish police officers arrived in Bosnia and Herzegovina in October 1995 and worked until the termination of UNMBIH. Twelve Danes were then attached to the initial local work of EUPM.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: IPTF, under the auspices of UNMBIH, executed an extensive program to assist the Bosnian police forces by providing monitoring, advice, and training to law enforcement entities and individuals. In the course of restructuring, it was considered important to recruit under-represented ethnic groups, to provide basic as well as specialised training, and to provide advice and support. The educational program for the police forces was a success, but UNMBIH did not succeed in recruiting ethnic minorities or in protecting ethnic minorities, refugees, and internally displaced persons to the desired extent. JSAP, with a focus on the judicial system in the country, was tasked with monitoring, supporting, and assessing the courts throughout the years of the mission. During the monitoring of the judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it was discovered that the courts were not independent and that they were not treated as such by other institutions working with the courts. The courts were influenced by powerful politicians, and this had an impact on the judgements issued by the courts against the accused. Control of the judicial entities was transferred in January 2001 to the Independent Judicial Commission (IJC). It operated until March 2004.

text.heading: Background
text.text: When the Afghan-Russian war ended in 1989, Afghanistan experienced a power vacuum in which various Afghan rebel groups feuded to gain maximum influence. One rebel group gaining influence was the Taliban. Its roots were in the southern desert – one of the least hospitable areas in Afghanistan. The Taliban did away with most of the other warlords. With their strict orthodox policies, they countered the chaos that had erupted in the country after the war against the Soviet Union. The Taliban consolidated its power and influence in Afghanistan during the 1990s, culminating in 1996 when Afghan President Burhanuddin Rabbani gave up control of the capital city of Kabul. Now, the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan was a reality. With the Taliban in power, an extremist interpretation of Islamic religious texts was imposed in legislation that oppressed women and introduced corporal punishment. Early in the new millennium, the regime was suspected of having ties to the terrorist network Al-Qaeda after the terrorist attack on 11 September 2001. In response to the terrorist attack, a coalition led by the US invaded Afghanistan and ousted the Taliban regime. However, notwithstanding that the Taliban movement was officially ousted, it had strong popular support and continued operations as a guerrilla group actively attempting to fight the coalition and the democratically elected government. To day the Taliban has retained power in Afghanistan. One of the instruments used to build up the country before 2021 was the NATO Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan (RS). It was established in 2015 as a successor to the earlier NATO mission International Security Assistance Force (ISAF). The purpose and mission for RS was to provide training, guidance, and support for Afghan security forces and military institutions. The mission ended in 2021.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The objective of RS was to train, advise, and assist Afghan security forces and institutions. The legal framework and the purposes for which RS was sent to Afghanistan were set out in the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA). It was signed in Kabul on 30 September 2014 and then ratified by the Afghan parliament on 27 November 2014. The mission was supported as well by UN Security Council Resolution 2189 of 12 December 2014. This resolution specified the remit of RS as work on these areas: Assist Afghan security forces and institutions in their efforts to fight the Taliban and the Haqqani network (an Afghan guerrilla group attempting to destabilise the Afghan government); and advise and assist Afghan military entities in the methods for building and maintaining a professional army with respect to finances, recruitment, and strategies for the future.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On request from the Afghan government and from NATO, the Danish government decided to contribute to RS. The contribution was intended to focus on training Afghan security forces to take on responsibility for security in the country. Although the overall security situation in Afghanistan had improved since the 2000s, there was still a need to improve professionalism in Afghan security related institutions such as government ministries, in military academies, in entities of specialised military capacity, and among strategic staff. This improvement was made possible through training, support, and guidance for Afghan security institutions.
Proposal B25 respecting a contribution to RS was approved by the Danish Parliament on 18 December 2014 with 100 votes in favour and 8 votes opposed.
The Danish government made the decision to participate from January 2021 and four mounth with a communication- and IT-unit after presentation 10. September 2020 for the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The mission encompassesed about 12,000 personnel from 42 nations. The US provided approximately 7,500, and Denmark in the order of 215-315 depending on the specific complement each year. Among those Danes, many were deployed as educators and advisers in the Kabul area at the Afghan National Army Officer Academy, the National Military Academy of Afghanistan and its special schools, and as instructors in the project to build Afghan capacity for C-130 transport. The staff complement in Kabul included about 10 persons, and a support unit in the Kabul area about 20 persons working transport and security for advisers and staff officers. In addition, Denmark provided a small number of medical staff to a health services facility at the Kabul airport along with about 10 military police officers. For a time, the support contribution in the city of Mazar-i-Sharif in northern Afghanistan consisted of an EH-101 transport helicopter. This contribution was an extension of the provision to ISAF of transport helicopters approved by the Danish Parliament (proposal B24) on 9 December 2008. The contribution consisted of three helicopters and about 75 personnel, including crew, logistics personnel, technical specialists, security officers, and an administrative support unit. All these contributions were and are supported by a national unit of about 20 persons offering support in logistics, administration, and technical matters.

From January and four mounth a communication- and IT-unit was deployed to Kabul.

In connection with the Taliban's attack on and offensive against Kabul, the evacuation of Danes and local embassy employees and other people who had assisted Denmark’s emissaries for a number of years was initiated ("OPN Alamo") at short notice. Special forces, military police, police officers, doctors and nurses were therefore deployed through the Danish Emergency Management Agency as well as people from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark. C-130 transport aircraft were also deployed.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
RS was active in Afghanistan since 1 January 2015. Denmark had contributed since the beginning of 2015 and as of 2019 was about 150 personnel attached to the mission. The three Danish helicopters were transferred to RS on 1 January 2015 and were recalled at the end of September.
From January and four month a communication- and IT-unit was deplyed to Kabul.
Danish participation terminated in June 2021. The Dannebrog was lowered already in April.

The Danish evacuation mission from Kabul took place in August 2021 and involved 908 people who were evacuated on Danish aircraft, with a further 80 evacuated on aircraft from other countries. Denmark also evacuated more than 100 people from countries that included the USA, Greece, France, Sweden, Norway and Iceland, as well as Afghans on behalf of a number of other nations. Among those evacuated on the two Danish Hercules aircraft were local employees of the Danish embassy in Kabul as well as their families, former interpreters who had worked alongside Danish troops, Danish citizens and evacuees from a number of allied countries. The final transport plane landed in Islamabad on 25 August 2021, after airlifting over 100 people out of Kabul. The flight was the last flight out of Afghanistan after 15 August when it was decided to deploy Danish Defence aircraft. This was ordered when civilian air traffic was halted as a result of the Taliban's entry into Kabul and the ensuing chaos at the airport.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The Danish advisers who have worked in RS have been stationed primarily at three locations: At the RS headquarters in Kabul, at the Afghan National Army Officer Academy, and at New Kabul Compound (a camp operated by the US).
The advisers at headquarters worked closely with Afghan officers in the Afghan Ministry of Defense and in the Ministry of Interior Affairs. The collaboration focused primarily on financial matters and anti-corruption and was led from time to time by a Danish commanding officer.
The advisers at the Officer Academy in Kabul were tasked with teaching and advising Afghan instructors in planning of exercises, curriculum content, and instruction methods according to the goals set out by the Academy. In addition, Danish advisers assisted in the selection of cadets.
The advisers at New Kabul Compound were tasked with advising the educational institutions of the Afghan army through planning and monitoring the soldiers’ educational programs.
The contribution in the Kabul airport consisted of two airport operators acting as advisers in matters pertaining to passengers and cargo. It also involved a Danish terminal section, the National Support Element, and DANELM (the ”public administration arm” of the mission). This was where “the operational machinery” of the mission is handled – IT, salary payments, administration, health services, supplies, media relations, logistics, chaplaincy, visits, and travel.
In the airport, Danish dog handlers assisted with the detection of narcotics and improvised bombs.
Danish military police were part of a larger international military police force, International Military Police (IMP). This police force maintained law and order, managed security for the airport, including access control, and ensured that the soldiers in the international camp in Kabul complied with security regulations. Finally, security personnel – Mobile Force Protection Teams – provided security services for transports in Kabul.

As the chaotic situation surrounding the evacuation from Kabul unfolded in August 2021, there were many different tasks of a nature that Danish personnel had not previously encountered in Afghanistan. These tasks included, among others, maintaining security at Kabul Airport, controlling access to the airport, controlling Afghans' right to evacuation (together with those sent by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the police) and protecting Danish forces. The Danish Emergency Management Agency's team, which included 2 team leaders, 8 doctors and 9 nurses, was deployed to Islamabad in Pakistan. Upon its arrival, the team received, assessed and (as needed) treated approx. 2,000 patients from countries that included Denmark, Sweden, the Netherlands, Iceland, Norway, the USA and Ukraine. They provided medical advice to officials in Kabul and corona testing of 57 officials from Denmark. The health personnel were also present on the planes to Denmark where they monitored and treated a total of approx. 850 evacuees, spread over 10 evacuation aircraft.

text.heading: Background
text.text: When the Soviet-Afghan war ended in 1989, Afghanistan lacked strong governmental leadership. In the power vacuum, various rebel groups feuded to gain influence. One of the rebel groups gaining influence was the Taliban. It was based in the southern part of the country, one of the least hospitable areas in Afghanistan. The Taliban did away with some other warlords. With its strict orthodox policies, it countered the chaos that had erupted in the country after the war. The Taliban consolidated its power and influence in Afghanistan during the 1990s, culminating in 1996 when Afghan President Burhanuddin Rabbani gave up control of the capital city of Kabul. Now, the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan was a reality. An extremist interpretation of Islam was now imposed in legislation that oppressed women and introduced corporal punishment. After the terrorist attack on the U.S. on 11 September 2001, the Taliban regime was suspected of having ties to the terrorist Al-Qaeda network. In response to the terrorist attack, a coalition led by the U.S. invaded Afghanistan and ousted the Taliban regime. However, notwithstanding that the Taliban movement was officially ousted, it had strong popular support and continued operations as a guerilla group actively attempting to fight the coalition and the democratically elected Afghan government. To day, the Taliban had retained power in Afghanistan. In an effort to help, the UN in 2003 on request from the Afghan government set up United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA). Since then, the UNAMA mission has worked to build peace in the country internally and to build peace between Afghanistan and its neighbouring countries through the use of advisers rather than combat forces.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate for UNAMA may be viewed as an extension of the previous United Nations Special Mission to Afghanistan that had operated there since 1993. UNAMA focuses on several key objectives, among them eliminating illegal drug trade, preventing illegal arms trading and educating the public about the danger posed by land mines. The decision to launch UNAMA was based on the UN Secretary-General’s report S/278 dated 18 March 2002 and on the “Agreement on Provisional Arrangements in Afghanistan Pending the Re-establishment of Permanent Government Institutions” signed in Bonn on 5 December 2001 (the Bonn Agreement).
As an aid in setting up a transitional government, it fell to UNAMA to coordinate and lead the international civilian effort in Afghanistan. Hence it was primarily a political mission.
The mandate was provided in UN Resolution 1401 of 27 March 2002. It has since then been updated every year, most recently in  September 2021,until fall 2022.
It was recognised immediately that Afghanistan needed international aid in developing, training, and advising a new Afghan police force. Germany had previously provided such aid, and therefore a bilateral agreement was made between Afghanistan and Germany that the latter would manage overall development and training along with other countries.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The UN in May 2003 sent a request to 5 countries, including Denmark, for the provision of a military adviser / liaison officer to UNAMA. Upon a government deliberation process and a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee on 26 May 2003, it was decided that Denmark could indeed meet the UN request. In addition, Denmark had provided support by sending police services advisers on request from the UN in 2002. Their remit was to serve as advisers to the special envoys deployed by the UN Secretary-General.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Each year between 2003 and 2013, Denmark contributed a military adviser to UNAMA and on rotation with the contributing countries at times held the position of chief military adviser. When Denmark’s stint as military adviser ended in 2013, the UN selected a Dane to serve from 2016 to 2017 as Special Representative in the mission. He was to assist in political matters affecting the operation.
Denmark has taken part in the police services related mission from December 2005 to March 2008 by supplying at least two Danish police officers.
By 2015, the mission had a significant scope. Approximately 2,000 civilians, 14 military advisers, and 3 police services advisers were allocated to about 10 regional offices and offices in Iran and Pakistan.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNAMA was launched on 28 March 2002 and continues to be active. Denmark contributed police services advisers from 2005 to 2008 and military advisers from 2003 to 2013 and then terminated the contribution. During 2016-2017, a Dane worked in UNAMA as a Special Representative.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The UNAMA contribution focuses on civilian affairs in the widest possible sense, such as emergency aid and support for the Afghan government(?) and the Afghan people in such matters as elections and women’s rights. UNAMA in addition assists in transferring responsibility for security in Afghanistan from the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) to the Afghan security forces. The work of the military advisers focused on providing guidance with respect to the security situation in certain regions. In addition, assistance was provided to advise ISAF with respect to the process of transfer of responsibility to the Afghans.

The police services mission was tasked with:                                                         

- advising the UN Special Representative in matters related to policing and security; coordinating the assistance provided to Afghan police forces by UN member countries and other international organisations; and advising the Afghan Ministry of Interior Affairs in matters related to police services; and

- establishing a close collaboration between German police and their Afghan peers with respect to recruiting and training Afghan police officers; and providing on-the-job guidance for local police personnel i Kabul while working closely with ISAF.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Opinions are divided as to the background for the conflict in Iraq and the events leading up to Denmark’s involvement. The following covers only a few of the many factors that played a role.

After the Gulf War in 1991, the UN demanded that Iraq destroy its weapons of mass destruction and missiles with a range above 150 kilometres (93 miles). Iraq was in addition required to accept verification of the destruction by UN inspectors from the UN Special Commission (UNSCOM) and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). Tensions between Hussein and the UN/US persisted through the 1990s when Hussein refused to get rid of the weapons of mass destruction believed by the UN and the US to remain in his possession or to provide proof they had been eliminated. On 11 September 2001, two planes hijacked by Al-Qaeda flew into the World Trade Center, and a third plane hit the Pentagon. After this terrorist attack, the U.S. initiated the war on terror under the name Operation Enduring Freedom. This war on terror turned out to have consequences also for Iraq and Saddam Hussein. Influential elements in the U.S. believed that Hussein might have connections to Al-Qaeda and possibly could be sheltering terrorists. It was once again relevant to know whether Hussein still had weapons of mass destruction, and the Americans wanted to launch an investigation. No weapons of mass destruction were found in Iraq, and connections between Hussein and Al-Qaeda were not verified. The Iraqis made it difficult for the investigation teams to get access to information and to enter sites; this did not help matters. As a result, many long discussions were held in the UN Security Council. Opinions are still divided as to these discussions. Similarly, opinions are divided as to whether there was a clear UN mandate to invade Iraq. There were many arguments for and against an invasion, but nevertheless a coalition was formed for this purpose by the U.S. It was joined by many countries including Denmark, the United Kingdom, and Australia. The coalition invaded Iraq and toppled Hussein. Then, the new Iraqi government needed help to manage the now fragile country. One of the missions set up to help the new government was The United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI). This mission was set up in 2003 by the UN Security Council on request from the Iraqi government. The objective of the mission was to support and improve democratic functions in Iraq and to help coordinate humanitarian initiatives offered to Iraq from the UN and other countries. UNAMI is still active in Iraq.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The UN Security Council set up UNAMI A significant challenge lay ahead. The UNAMI was to assist many types of political institutions in Iraq, enhance national development by strengthening the political system, provide support to election processes, and contribute to the humanitarian aid efforts. In addition, work was needed – through dialogue – to improve Iraq’s relationship with neighbouring Kuwait and Iran. The UNAMI were described in UN Security Council Resolution 1483 of 22 May 2003. Resolution 1500 of 14 August 2003 then fleshed out the final set of tasks. UN Security Resolution 2476 of 21 May 2019 extended the mandate to 31 May 2020 but will be further extended. A complement of 300-500 personnel is engaged to staff the mission.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution to UNAMI is a continuation of its engagement in Iraq as Parliament had already committed, with approval of proposal B42 of 25 November 2004, to continue making Danish military forces available. Proposal B42 articulated the government’s view that a Danish contribution in Iraq was to be maintained for as long as the UN and the Iraqi authorities requested it. When the UN then asked for reinforcement of UNAMI, the view on the part of the Danish government was that this request represented a good opportunity to continue to support the rebuilding of Iraq. The first contribution was an officer who worked as an assistant military adviser as of December 2005. By March 2006, the contribution had grown to seven military personnel. Later, in January 2007, a transport plane was added.

Proposal B63 was approved on 26 January 2006 with 102 votes in favour and 15 votes opposed. This proposal enabled the provision of six personnel to UNAMI as of March 2006.
Proposal B139 was approved on 30 May 2006 with 65 votes in favour and 53 votes opposed. This proposal enabled the provision of a transport plane.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish contribution to UNAMI was seven military personnel: Two officers working as assistant military advisers; one liaison officer; and a four-person logistics management unit dealing with transport of personnel and materiel. Later on, for a time, a C-130 Hercules transport plane and about 30 associated personnel were added.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission is still active. Danish personnel served in UNAMI as military advisers for a year starting in March 2005. The additional personnel – the liaison officer and the four-person logistics unit for transport of personnel and materiel – were dispatched for a six-month period in 2006. The C-130 Hercules transport plane and its 30 associated personnel were provided from 20 January to 30 June 2007. As a result of the withdrawal of American forces from Iraq in December 2011 and on request from the UN, Denmark concluded its work in UNAMI on 1 September 2012 when the last Danish military adviser left the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The C-130 Hercules transport plane was based in Kuwait where UNAMI had its headquarters. The plane served to move people and materiel around Iraq. The Danish military advisers and liaison officers worked on implementation and development of public administration, democracy, and security.

missions.title: UNMHA Yemen
missions.subtitle: Yemen Once More
missions.name: UNMHA Yemen
missions.descriptiveName: UN Mission to support the Hudaydah Agreement

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Arab Spring movements that unseated several dictators in the Middle East also reached Yemen, the poorest country in the region. Protracted hostilities forced President Ali Abdullah Saleh to resign after many years in his post. Per a framework agreement negotiated by Arab Gulf nations, Saudi Arabia in the lead, Saleh resigned, and Vice President Abd Rabbuh Mansour Hadi succeeded him. The plan was to hold elections for president three months later and initiate a national dialogue on the transition to a democratic system and on the drafting of a new constitution.
During that election in February 2012, Hadi was ratified as president – with no other candidates on the ballot. The election was boycotted by several groups, including the Houthi movement from the northern part of Yemen. Saleh had attempted to crush this movement several times during his last decade as president.
The national dialogue took place from March 2013 to January 2014. It enjoyed broad support among the people of Yemen and in the international community. However, not everyone was pleased with the result and with the fact that Hadi remained in the post as president, and a new federated system had several population groups feeling unfairly treated. When economic reforms sparked protests, the Houthis in September 2014 took advantage of the unrest, with support from ex-president Saleh, to take control of most of the country.  Hadi was held in house arrest for several months but managed to escape to Aden. Here he received support from several Arab states, primarily Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, and these states took an active role in the conflict in March 2015.

This civil war quickly became a massive humanitarian crisis. About 20 million out of the population of 28 million depended on aid organisations to survive. Approximately 80% of all imports, commercial as well as humanitarian, entered Yemen through the port city of Hudaydah. On the pretext that the port was being used for smuggling weapons, the Saudi-led coalition several times blocked the port and inspected all incoming ships. Arguing that it was time to end arms smuggling once and for all, the coalition and Hadi’s forces mounted an offensive against the city during the summer of 2018.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UN special envoy Martin Griffiths had attempted on several occasions to get the parties to meet and get a peace process going. However, these attempts had met with no success since 2016. As the humanitarian crisis got worse and the international community feared that a battle in the city of Hudaydah would block aid and imports from entering the country, there was mounting pressure on the parties to reach a solution before widespread famine set in.
There were skirmishes on the outskirts of the city of Hudaydah, and it appeared that it might be surrounded and besieged for a protracted period. Finally, the parties were persuaded to meet in Rimbo north of Stockholm, Sweden, from 6 to 13 December 2018. It was not expected, but a ceasefire in and around Hudaydah was indeed negotiated as a framework agreement for withdrawal by both parties and for a series of trust-building mechanisms to facilitate renewed meetings in short order to discuss a ceasefire for the entire country.
In support of the ceasefire and the peace process, the UN Security Council on 21 December 2018 unanimously approved Resolution 2451. This resolution authorised the UN Secretary-General to organise and dispatch a small group to Hudaydah for the purpose of monitoring the ceasefire and present a plan, before the end of the year, for deploying a larger group. This first team was led by a Dutch general, Patrick Cammaert.
The Secretary-General presented a more extensive plan on 31 December. Based on this plan, the UN Security Council approved Resolution 2452 on 16 January 2019. It officially launched United Nations Mission to support the Hudaydah Agreement (UNMHA) as a special political mission of 75 unarmed observers tasked with monitoring compliance with the ceasefire agreements. The parties were not permitted to send reinforcements to their positions, and they were to gradually withdraw from the city and keep it a neutral area.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: When the Dutch general Patrick Cammaert left the mission, the UN Secretary-General specifically requested that Denmark dispatch Lieutenant General Michael Anker Lollesgaard to lead UNMHA. The government agreed to this request after consultation with the Foreign Policy Committee. On 28 January 2019, Secretary-General Antonio Guterres officially appointed Lollesgaard commander of the mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: In addition to providing a commander for the mission, Denmark sent a small contingent of four staff to support the 75 unarmed observers in UNMHA. Denmark’s armed forces had not previously contributed to the work of quelling the conflict in Yemen but did participate in the United Nations Yemen Observation Mission (UNYOM) during 1963-1964. During this current conflict, Denmark is making a significant humanitarian effort in Yemen, donating large sums to UNICEF, the Red Cross, and other organisations working in the country.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The Danish element arrived in Hudaydah on 5 February 2019. The mission was slated for a duration of six months with the option of an extension.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The primary mission for UNMHA is to monitor the situation in Hudaydah and compliance with the agreements made in Sweden. In practice, this means that the 75 observers watch both parties to ensure they respect the ceasefire and refrain from reinforcing their positions in the city. UNMHA in addition hosts meetings of the Redeployment Coordination Committee (RCC). At these meetings, the parties discuss and attempt to coordinate their withdrawal from the city, the transfer to local security forces, and the organisation of these forces. As of spring 2019, some difficulties are associated with getting the parties to meet and to respect the agreements made. Still, the ceasefire has generally held. Both parties continue to accuse each other of breaching it, and shots are exchanged, but heavy weapons are not used.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1990, larger towns in particular began to see food shortages. The Russian authorities slowly began to accept that these shortages existed and eventually agreed to accept external aid. The Danish government wanted aid to take the form of gifts from the Danish State to the affected towns. On this basis, the mission was assigned to the Emergency Management Agency. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, after consultation with the city council of St. Petersburg, decided that the funds would be spent on food for children aged between 0-3 years and on providing medicines for children’s wards at 23 of the hospitals in the city.
After the Baltic States declared their independence, they requested varying forms of aid from a number of European countries, including medical aid that followed a list of specific requirements.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed in both cases. The food aid to St. Petersburg came from a decision by the Danish government at the end of 1991 which awarded DKK 40 million in food aid for the towns of St. Petersborg, Jekatarinburg and Omsk. This mission would be performed by state authorities.
Support for the Baltic States was purely transport-based. This mission was therefore assigned to the Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The aid mission to St. Petersburg took place between 15 January and 20 May 1992.
The transport mission to the Baltic States was performed between 10 March and 31 March 1992.
The first shipment was sent to Estonia between 13 -16 March, carrying a total of 8.5 tonnes.
The second shipment was sent to Latvia between 19 - 24 March, carrying a total of 9 tonnes.
The third shipment was sent to Lithuania between 26 - 31 March, carrying a total of 12.5 tonnes.

text.heading: Contribution & Mission
text.text:
St. Petersburg:

Purchasing, transportation and distribution of powdered milk as advised by the city council of St. Petersburg. In addition, purchasing, transportation and delivery of 4 tonnes of specified children's medicines to hospitals.
The first instalment of aid involved the shipment of 150 tonnes of powdered milk to Russia on 17 December 1991. The powdered milk was intended for the towns of Jektarinburg and Omsk, where it arrived at the end of December and was distributed to infants in both towns. No emergency management personnel participated in the transport mission to Russia, or in the internal powdered milk distribution.
The second component of the food aid was comprised of powdered milk and children’s medicines. These were purchased after consultation with Danish Red Cross. The food and equipment were transported by ship to St. Petersburg. Two officers from the Emergency Management Agency were assigned the mission of finding a depot for the food and were sent to St. Petersburg, where they collaborated with the city council and the Danish General Consul. The consignment arrived by ship in St. Petersburg on 28 January and distribution could commence from various premises across the city. The food aid project continued until mid-May 1992, when the funds allocated by the State had run out. A total of 600 tonnes of powdered milk and four tonnes of children’s medicines were distributed to the hospitals.

The Baltic States:

The mission entailed the purchase, transportation and delivery of medicinal equipment that had been purchased via a Danish medicine company. The aid was transported by ship to the port in Tallinn, from where it was sent on a lorry (that had also been sent) to the delivery destinations in the three countries. A total of 16,000 km (9,900 miles) was driven.

18 people from the Emergency Management Agency took part in the aid project to St. Petersburg. The aid mission to the three Baltic States was performed by an officer, a middle managers and two conscripts.

missions.title: Turkey 1992
missions.subtitle: Earthquake
missions.name: Tyrkiet 1992
missions.descriptiveName: Emergency Management Agency & Danish Air Force

text.heading: Background
text.text: During the evening of 14 March 1992, Eastern Turkey was hit by an earthquake that measured 6.5 on the Richter scale. Many people were killed or injured and the earthquake caused extensive damage. The following day, the Turkish government contacted Denmark to request immediate aid with the large number of rescue missions. The request asked for aid in the form of personnel and material to help in the search and rescue of people who were trapped inside collapsed buildings.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that it was willing to grant the Turkish request and authorised the Emergency Management Agency to perform the mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The mission involved putting together and posting a self-sufficient rescue team. The rescue team was comprised of personnel from elements of the Emergency Management Agency and totalled 38 officers, NCOs and conscripts, accompanied by an interpreter. The Royal Danish Air Force took care of transportation to and from the badly-affected town of Erzincan, which was only 20 km (12 miles) from the earthquake’s epicentre.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 15 March - 24 March 1992.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Freeing people who were trapped in collapsed buildings and providing ordinary first aid to the injured. The Danish unit was inserted in the town of Erzincan, the capital of the local province. The town had a population of 120,000. The earthquake caused numerous deaths and injuries. 60% of the buildings collapsed or were seriously damaged. The number of dead is unknown.
Night-time temperatures could be as low as -20 degrees Celsius ( -4 degrees Fahrenheit), which meant that living conditions were tough for those who took part in this mission. The sub-zero temperatures also meant that the chances of finding survivors inside the ruins were further limited.
The rescue team worked to free trapped survivors at the town’s collapsed hospital for the entire duration of the mission. After a week of rescue efforts, the team gave up hope of finding further trapped survivors inside the ruins. The team was then able to leave the disaster area and return to Denmark.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Over a two-week period, the southern and western third of Poland experienced previously-unknown levels of flooding that was the result of torrential rain and melted snow and ice from the mountains. 36 people were reported dead, 500,000 hectares of land were flooded, almost 1,500 km (930 miles) of roads were submerged and 160 bridges had been destroyed. 16 major towns and about 180 villages were also flooded. Large rural areas were cut off from the rest of the world. Energy supply lines were also out of action, which made it difficult to pump water away from low-lying areas. Industry and agricultural production were also badly affected.
On 18 July 1997, the Emergency Management Agency was contacted by the Polish government via United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs (UNDHA), requesting aid that was mostly needed in the south-west of Poland. The Danish Embassy in Warsaw had already contacted the Polish government to offer Danish aid before the official request was received from the Polish government.
There were problems once again in 2010. The river Wisla had broken its banks in central Poland and a new disaster was underway.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: After negotiations between the Danish Prime Minister's Office and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, it was decided in both instances that the aid Poland had requested would be provided as a matter of urgency. The contribution was financed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The first personnel were sent to Warsaw on 18 and 19 July 1997. Their mission was to support the Danish Embassy and coordinate the Danish contribution alongside the Polish authorities. “Team 1” left Denmark during the morning of 20 July and arrived at Nowa Sól in Poland later the same day.
The initial aid was comprised of a self-sufficient 39-strong unit with seven officers and NCOs, 31 conscripts and a civilian employee. With them, they brought 30 pumps and 15 vehicles. After a request was made by the Polish government, the scope of the mission was expanded and a total of four pump teams were posted over the 31 days. The personnel involved were 30 officers and NCOs, 85 conscripts, 25 former conscripts under contract, 28 volunteers from Greater Copenhagen’s Emergency Services and two Polish interpreters. A total of 170 personnel took part.

The Danish State also donated 60 mobile ICOM radios and accessories, 100 pairs of waders, 200 blankets, 100 sleeping bags, 50 tents and 28 Grundfos AP-12 pumps for smaller basement pumping tasks.
The 2010 pump team was somewhat smaller and consisted of 10 emergency services personnel, equipped with a bilge pump container, electricity generator, hose deployment vehicle for water transport and a rescue crane. The team was inserted in the town of Plock in central Poland, approx. 100 km (62 miles) north-west of Warsaw.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The combined contribution in 1997 took place during the period 18 July - 20 August. The 2010 mission was performed in May and June.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The 1997 mission entailed water pump tasks supporting local fire services and authorities in the Zielona Gora region surrounding Nowa Sól, including at and near the towns of Krosno Odrzanskie, Szprotawa, Ochla, Strzegom, Zielona Gora, Nowa Sól, Strzegom, Cybinka and BedowLaski, as well as a number of smaller towns.
One unusual task was the bilge pumping of a 4,600 hectare agricultural area growing important crops, that would under normal circumstances by drained by a pump station. Three of the pump station’s four pumps were destroyed by the flooding and had to be shut off for repairs. Driving on this mission involved 56,600 km (35,170 miles) by lorries, 56,570 km (35,150 miles) by car and 9,650 km (5,996 miles) by motorcycles. The pumps were in action for 11,165 hours.

text.heading: Background
text.text: See AFOR

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: When the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was contacted by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and the Danish Refugee Council (DRC), it decided to grant the request for a Danish contribution in partnership with the Emergency Management Agency. Danish financing for these projects was provided by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Various larger scale projects were financed by UNHCR.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contributions in Kosovo and Albania were extensive and had nine components:
- Transportation of emergency aid for refugees (the convoy project).
- The provision of transport capacity (the “911 project”).
- Support for the Danish Refugee Council's project in Skopje, Macedonia (emergency team).
- Assessment of damaged buildings with a view to housing (buildings team).
- Transportation of 40,000 refugees from Albania to Kosovo (the bus project).
- Loading and unloading of aircraft at Tirana Airport (Airfield Handling).
- Leasing of transport capacity to a number of emergency aid organisations.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The posted personnel operated from 3 April until 15 October 1999. The specific operations for the posted personnel were carried out as follows:
- The convoy project 9 April - 15 October 1999.
- The 911 project 9 -18 April 1999.
- The emergency team 3 - 23 April 1999.
- The buildings team 24 March - 30 September 1999.
- The bus project 1 July - 15 August 1999.
- Airfield Handling at Tirana Airport 2 - - 29 June 1999.
- The leasing of transport capacity for emergency aid shipments continued from April 1999 to the end of 1999.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The objective of the convoy project was to improve the UNHCR's ability to transport and distribute emergency aid to refugee camps in Albania. The project involved a broad range of vehicles, including ten Mercedes Benz lorries. The Danish personnel were officers, mechanics and 12 drivers, as well as a number of employees who were recruited locally. All personnel were based in Durres.
The 911 project in Albania involved the delivery of nine Mercedes Benz 911 lorries to Ankona in Italy, where they were transferred to Adventist Development and Relief Agency (ADRA) and DanChurchAid (DCA). The 14 personnel came from the Emergency Management Agency and local authority volunteers.
The emergency team would provide assistance to the DCA's project in Skopje, Macedonia in the performance of administrative and practical tasks. The team participated in the task of accommodating approximately 300,000 refugees in tent camps in the north of Macedonia. The most important tasks were the reception and housing of refugees and providing them with food. One major task was the coordination of food supplies that were sent to the camps by transport aircraft, ship and lorry. The Danish personnel were three officers and six NCOs who were stationed in Skopje.
The task of the buildings team was to assess the suitability of public and private buildings for use as temporary housing for refugees in Albania. Particular attention was paid to housing during the winter. The buildings team was comprised of five people from construction backgrounds and operated from the base in Durrès.
The mission of the bus project (also known as “the joint project”) that was operated by the Emergency Management Agency and DCA was to move approx. 40,000 refugees from Albania to Kosovo, using 40 buses. There were approx. 160 personnel from DCA, the Emergency Management Agency and civilians who had been recruited locally. The Emergency Management Agency provided command functions, convoy commanders and two mechanics. It also provided a Camp Manager and five Support Staff for camp administration and operation in Kukes, where the personnel were quartered.
Airfield Handling at Tirana Airport, performing practical tasks such as aircraft loading and unloading. The contribution was comprised of 12 people, seven of whom were from the Emergency Management Agency and five from the British Emergency Management Group/Department For International Development (ELM/DFID), a partnership that had been established from the International Humanitarian Partnership (IHP).
The leasing of vehicles involved the transportation of 19 “911” lorries to Albania, where they were transferred to various humanitarian organisations until December 1999. The project involved a total of 15 people from the Emergency Management Agency and local authority emergency services reserves.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At 3.00 on 17 August 1999, the Marmara region in north west Turkey was hit by an earthquake, the epicentre of which was in the town of Izmir. The earthquake measured 7.4 on the Richter scale and resulted in extensive devastation.
The Turkish government therefore requested international aid on 18 August via the Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Cooperation (NATO/EARDCC) and Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN/OCHA). According to estimates, over 15,000 people were killed and 45,000 injured. There was also extensive damage to infrastructure, oil refineries, energy supply lines, businesses and residential areas etc.
The Turkish government request asked for rescue teams, field hospitals, medicines, electrical generators and petrochemical fire extinguishing experts.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: Based on the Turkish government’s request for international aid, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in collaboration with the Emergency Management Agency decided to provide Danish aid to the disaster area in the form of a dog rescue team from the Greater Copenhagen Emergency Services and an Emergency Management Agency rescue specialist. Additionally, after a request from the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN/OCHA), a delegate would be sent to UN Disaster Assessment Coordination (UNDAC) with a view to coordinating the mission in the disaster area.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The dog rescue team was comprised of a team leader, three dog rescue teams each with three dog trainers and a team leader, an advisor, a logistics operative and a communications operative, i.e. 16 personnel in total.
The task of the rescue specialist from the Emergency Management Agency, in their capacity as a representative of the Danish authorities, was to analyse and describe the situation with a view to assess the need for further aid and to gather experience for use in future missions. The task of the UNDAC delegate sent by the Emergency Management Agency was to participate in the UNDAC coordination team.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The dog rescue team was posted from 18-27 August.
The rescue specialist was posted from 18-23 August.
The UNDAC delegate was posted from 21 August to 3 September.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The rescue dogs were to be inserted alongside other rescue operations in the area in an attempt to locate people who were trapped in the ruins. The rescue team was posted in the town of Sakarya in the Marmara region. The town had 220,000 inhabitants, of which 3,000 were dead and 5,000 injured. 50% of the buildings had collapsed and 80% were damaged to a greater or lesser degree.
The task of the rescue specialist was to gather data and experience from the disaster, with a view to the optimisation of future Emergency Management Agency missions at home and abroad.
The UNDAC delegate would be part of the coordination team, with a view to optimum provision of the combined contributions from donor countries.
Value information was obtained about the characteristics of towns affected by earthquakes in relation to rescue operations. These experiences were to be used in the future training of rescue personnel.

text.heading: Background
text.text: During July and August 2000, 327 large-scale fires were reported in Macedonia, affecting an area of approx. 16,000 hectares, 3,000 of which were forest. The fires were located in the following areas: Skopje, Veles, Makadonski Brod, Strumica, Prilep, Gevgelija, Gostiva, Tetovo, Stip, Bitola, Delcevo, Kumanovo and Valandovo. This affected a very large area and impacted numerous villages and the way of life of the local populations.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: In August, the Emergency Management Agency received a request from the Macedonian government via Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre (NATO/EADRCC) for aid in extinguishing the fires. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided that Denmark would provide aid in the form of a donation of four fully-equipped firefighting vehicles. Additional equipment and tools would also be purchased. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs bore the expense of this aid.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Four Mercedes Benz 911 firefighting vehicles with pumps were made ready. The unit took the form of two complete firefighting groups for putting out fires and two complete hose groups for water transportation, as well as 80 sets of extra equipment in the form of fireproof suits, work gloves, helmets, fire beaters, handles, shovels and chainsaws, as well as maintenance equipment. Most of this equipment was stored at Emergency Management Agency depots.
Transportation to Macedonia passed through the Italian harbour town of Anconda and onwards to Greece, finally arriving at Skopje. The task was performed by eight full-time employees and conscripts from the disaster management centres.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Planning and negotiation of a Danish donation to Macedonia commenced on 16 August 2000. The operation was concluded upon the return home of the transport personnel. Transportation to Macedonia via Italy took place in the period 29 August to 4 September.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission entailed gathering materials and making purchases for the Danish contribution and to deliver the materials to the Macedonian authorities in Skopje, Macedonia.

missions.title: Romania 2000
missions.subtitle: Flood
missions.name: Rumænien 2000
missions.descriptiveName: Care Equipment for People in Need

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At the beginning of April 2000, the western part of Romania was hit by extreme rainfall and large quantities of thawed snow and ice from the mountains. The volume of water resulted in large-scale flooding in the lowland areas along the rivers. The population of the affected area was evacuated on a massive scale, which left up to 10,000 people in need of emergency housing. Romania’s civil defence lacked the capacity for emergency rehousing on such a large scale. Large parts of infrastructure had been destroyed and Romanian civil defence did not possess the transport capacity that was required in the affected areas.
The Romanian government therefore requested international aid on 17 April 2000 via the Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Cooperation (NATO/EARDCC) and Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN-OCHA). The total task force numbered 30 people, split into two teams.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The decision to provide aid was determined by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, operating with an economic framework of DKK 75,000. Based on information provided by the Romanian authorities, 2,000 blankets, two field cookers and two Mercedes Benz 911 cargo vehicles were purchased and sent to Romania from the Emergency Management Agency’s depot.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The cargo vehicles and field cookers were prepared and serviced before being sent out. The vehicles were loaded onto oversize load trailers and everything was delivered to the town of Timisora.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The transport mission took place in the period 15-22 April 2000.
Preparation of the vehicles and their cargo commenced on 14 April 2000.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Purchasing, preparation and transportation of Danish emergency aid to the Romanian government as a response to flooding

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At 8.46 local time on 26 January 2001 the Indian sub-state of Gujarat was hit by an earthquake that measured 7.7 on the Richter Scale. The earthquake’s epicentre was North East of the town of Bhuj.
The official death toll was approximately 20,000 people, with over 165,000 people suffering serious or minor injuries. 330,000 buildings were damaged beyond repair and a further 700,000 buildings were damaged to some degree. Buildings collapsed as far as 275 km (170 miles) from the epicentre.
The Indian government responded with a large-scale civilian and military involvement in the rescue work. At the same time, the Indian government requested international aid in the form of SARS (Search And Rescue) teams from Switzerland, the United Kingdom, Turkey and Russia. Hospital facilities were also provided from Israel, France, the Ukraine, Japan, Red Cross and Denmark.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in consultation with the Ministry of the Interior mandated Greater Copenhagen’s Emergency Management Services and the Emergency Management Agency to provide the hospital facilities, including liaison personnel and logistics support as required.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The link personnel that were required for the administrative running of the hospital were posted. Support in the form of materials was also provided for the entire duration of the project. In logistics terms, the hospital was provided with materials, including three inflatable tents, 11 sets of air conditioning equipment, hot air tubes and thermostats, water heater, bath tent, toilet and water tanks.

The deployment of an orthopaedic hospital, with a core Danish staff team of doctors, nurses, logistics and administrative personnel. The hospital was set up near the town of Ghandidham in the middle of the earthquake zone to support Rambagh Government Hospital. The hospital buildings had been damaged by the earthquake and efforts involved attempting to keep the hospital open as a very interim measure. The interim hospital was set up in inflatable tents, with an operating theatre in an expandable container.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Commenced 30 January and ended on 10 March 2001.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission was to serve as a link for national and international units and to provide the logistical support that was required for the hospital's everyday function.

The hospital was deployed by Greater Copenhagen Emergency Services, supported by various materials and a Danish Emergency Management Agency liaison officer. It treated people who had been injured in the earthquake of 26 January, the minor aftershocks over the following weeks and more routine events such as traffic accidents. The hospital fulfilled an important role in the region’s emergency health services during the urgent period that immediately followed the earthquake until Rambagh Government Hospital was able to return to a reasonable state of readiness.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 12 August 2002, the Czech government declared a state of national emergency. On 14 August 2002, the Czech Ministry of the Interior issued an official letter requesting aid from countries in the area. The request was for powerful pumping apparatus for flooded areas, pumps for draining cellars etc. and drying/dehumidifying equipment for buildings.
The Malse, Vltava, Luznice and Bianice rivers had broken their banks because of heavy rainfall. The flooding caused extensive damage in Prague in central and southern Bohemia, Plzen, Carlsbad and Usti, were a large number of towns were flooded. Over 200,000 inhabitants were evacuated to areas that were less threatened.
The request from the Czech government was issued via the Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre (NATO/EADRCC), the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) and the EU.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided to grant the Czech government’s request by sending a pumping team for two weeks, with an initial funding grant of DKK 700,000. The contribution was eventually extended to a total of 25 days and an addition grant of DKK 400,000 was issued. Personnel and material preparations commenced on 14 August.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The establishment of a self-sufficient unit equipped with electrical submersion pumps, hoses and generators. This took two days. The total task force that was sent to the Czech Republic numbered 30 people, split into two teams.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The pump team was inserted from 16 August - 20 September 2002.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission involved draining water from flooded sections of Prague’s Metro so that trains could start running again as soon as possible.
The newly-acquired pumps were high performance submersion pumps, which were found to be very well-suited for this mission. Total pump capacity averaged 36,000 l/min. Approximately one million cubic metres of water was pumped out of the Metro over the duration of the mission.

missions.title: Indonesia 2004/2005
missions.subtitle: Tsunami
missions.name: Indonesien 2004/2005
missions.descriptiveName: A Natural Disaster with a High Death Toll

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At 7.59 local time on 26 December 2004, a Richter scale 9.1 earthquake was registered in the Indian Ocean approx. 250 km (155 miles) west of Sumatra in Indonesia. Approximately 15 minutes later, tidal waves hit the coast of Banda Aceh, Sumatra’s most western province. The tidal waves caused extensive damage on the coastline, extending 5 km (3 miles) inland.
The tsunami caused large numbers of deaths and extensive damage to infrastructure coastal areas along the Indian Ocean. The countries in the Indian Ocean region immediately requested aid from the international community.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The Danish government received a request for international aid via the EU and UN/WHO and authorised the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to lead and coordinate the Danish contribution. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is the authority with responsibility for the political authorisation and funding of Danish international aid in the event of humanitarian disasters.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: In collaboration with the Ministry of Defence and the Emergency Management Agency. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided to grant the request for a field hospital and water purification equipment for Banda Aceh. It was also decided that Denmark would make experts available in Indonesia and the Maldives when it received a request from international aid organisations.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The contribution involved:
- Deployment of the Emergency Management Agency’s mobile field hospital to Banda Aceh in Sumatra. The hospital was constructed from containers and tents. There were 100 beds, six intensive care spaces, an operating theatre and all necessary support functions. The hospital brought supplies for 8-10 days of operation. The hospital equipment was sent from Denmark. Other supplies were purchased locally.
- Sending expert support for the aid organisations operating in the Maldives.
- Sending an IHP support module to set up and operate a UN/OCHA crisis management centre in Banda Aceh.
- Sending a communications expert to set up and operate communications equipment.
- The delivery and installation of two water purification systems for Indonesia/Banda Ace and
- the donation of materials etc. when winding down the Danish mission in the region.
The Royal Danish Air Force also provided support in the form of C-130 transport aircraft.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission commenced on 26 December 2004 and ended on 9 May 2005 when the mobile hospital arrived back in Hedehusene.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The primary mission was to save as many human lives as possible to prevent the outbreak of epidemics in the disaster area. Here, Denmark was able to offer aid in the form of hospital capacity and the supply of drinking water. Support was also provided to the international organisations in the form of qualified personnel who performed coordination tasks between the inserted aid organisations and the local authorities.
The mobile hospital's operating theatre performed a total of 385 operations. The casualty section treated 5,019 injuries of varying seriousness. Local and international medical personnel were associated with the hospital, in addition to the Danish personnel. The hospital mainly treated orthopaedic patients. Other types of injuries were transferred or referred to other treatment facilities in the area. The staff off the mobile hospital also contributed to the reopening of the local hospital in Banda Aceh.
After installation and the training of local personnel, the water purification equipment was operated by Danish personnel for a few days. It was then transferred to the local authorities as a donation from the Danish state. Each water purification module had a capacity of approx. 800 litres of drinking water an hour.
The experts were posted to UN/OCHA, who had set up coordination facilities in Banda Aceh, Colombo, Sri Lanka and the Maldives.
When winding down the Danish contribution in Banda Aceh and Sri Lanka, parts of the materials were transferred to the local and regional authorities as a gift from the Danish state.
The scale of the disaster in Indonesia after the Tsunami was immense. The death toll was 131,000 people, approximately 37,000 people were missing, over 500,000 people were made homeless and 117,000 houses were destroyed or badly damaged.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At 05.28 local time on 26 December 2003, the town of Bam in the south west Kerman province of Iran was hit by an earthquake that measured 6.5 on the Richter scale. The earthquake’s epicentre was right underneath the town. More than 41,000 people were killed. A further 30,000 were injured. The earthquake destroyed 85% of houses and made 75,000 homeless.
At 15.30 on 26 December, the Iranian government requested aid via the UN in the form of rescue teams (USAR - Urban Search and Rescue), hospital equipment and emergency equipment for the homeless.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The request from the Iranian government was received by the Emergency Management Agency at 15.32 on 26 December and was passed on to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. At 16.30, the Emergency Management Agency was authorised by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to commence a USAR mission with funding of DKK 2.3 million.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Emergency Management Agency set up and readied a USAR team in accordance with the guidelines of INSERAG (International Search And Rescue Advisory Group). The rescue team was comprised of 57 personnel, six rescue dogs and 22 tonnes of rescue and camp equipment. The team was made up of a command element, four rescue teams, three search teams with dogs and technical search gear, a medical element and a camp element. The personnel were Emergency Management Agency employees, conscripts and volunteers from local authority emergency reserves.
Transport to Iran took place on 27 December on two chartered flights, carrying materials and passengers respectively. The eastern European Ilyushin 76 and Yak 42 aircraft were sourced by the shipping company and were able to transport all of the personnel and the 22 tonnes of rescue and camp equipment. They landed at Bam Airport as the thirteenth of a total of 34 international rescue teams.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The rescue team was sent out on 27 December and returned to Denmark on 2 January after the Iranian government and the UN reached an official decision to stop searching for victims on 31 December.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The unit was tasked with searching for trapped and injured people inside the ruins in the eastern part of town. The mission was performed in collaboration with local rescue teams. The rescue team found no survivors but extracted a total of 11 dead.
Buildings in Bam were primarily single-storey buildings, with walls and roofs made of sun-dried clay. This form of construction and the heavy construction materials meant that most houses had collapsed completely or partially. This meant that survival chances were low for anyone inside the buildings when the earthquake struck.
Danish Red Cross contacted the Emergency Management Agency on 29 December with a view to purchasing and taking over the running of the Danish camp in Bam after the rescue mission was over. This meant that the camp element remained in Bam after the rescue team had returned home. The Emergency Management Agency made two people available to DRC for two weeks to aid with the organising and transfer/operation of the camp.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At 7.59 local time on 26 December 2004, a Richter scale 9.1 earthquake was registered in the Indian Ocean approx. 250 km (155 miles) west of Sumatra in Indonesia. The quake triggered a tsunami that hit Indonesia, Thailand, Sri Lanka and India.
