The tsunami caused extensive damage to infrastructure and the loss of life in coastal areas to the east and south of Sri Lanka. Between 285,000 and 345,000 people perished as a result of the tsunami. There were many Danish tourists in Thailand in the areas near Phuket and Khao Lak and it soon became clear that some of the dead would be Danish citizens. A total of 46 Danes perished as a result of the tsunami.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: Via the EU and UN/WHO, the Danish government received a request for international aid, which it granted. This led to various different missions.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Most countries and international police organisations have a so-called Disaster Victim Identification (DVI) register. This register is used to identify large numbers of people who are killed in natural disasters and large-scale accidents etc.
Denmark has been a prime mover in the development of this register, which is built around an IT system. The register is located at the Danish National Forensic Centre (NKC). The centre accommodates forensic technicians, fingerprint experts, investigative experts, a documents section and a DNA register.
As soon as the disaster was announced the Danish National Police decided to set up a centre of operations at NKC. The DVI register was also manned.
39 water purification systems were set up by the Emergency Management Agency to support five areas of Sri Lanka. The material was donated to local authorities when the Danish contribution in the region was wound down.
The Royal Danish Air Force also assisted by providing a C-130 transport aircraft.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission began at the end of December 2004. It ended on 16 January 2005 (insofar as the Emergency Management Agency was concerned). The police personnel who had been deployed did not return home until mid-2005.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The Danish police were responsible for:
- gathering information about missing Danish citizens,
- helping to find the location of people who had died,
- helping to identify Danes and people of other nationalities who had perished,
- making personnel available to the international information and operations centre in Phuket.
Identification tasks were performed by teams comprised of forensic technicians, fingerprint experts, coroners, forensic odontologists etc. Police from the Danish police force’s Flying Squad were also sent out to question hotel staff and other relevant parties in an attempt to localise Danes who had disappeared.
The dog section of the Danish National Police was also sent to the area, where the dogs were able to help find hidden bodies. Psychologists were also stationed to help the other personnel to process what they experienced.
An approximate total of 180 Danish police officers and other police personnel were sent to the region.
The mission of the Emergency Management Agency was to prevent the outbreak of epidemics in the affected areas by setting up drinking water supplies as soon as possible. Each water purification module had a capacity of approx. 800 litres of drinking water an hour. The total output was therefore approx. 27,000 litres an hour.
The 39 water purification systems were set up at five different locations on the south and east coast, as advised by the Sri Lankan authorities. The systems were operated for the first few days by the Danish experts as they trained local personnel in the operation and maintenance of the systems. The materials were then transferred to the local authorities as a donation from the Danish state.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Because of the conflict in Sudan and its extent, the UN’s Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) , on 16 February 2004, made a request for aid setting up an On Site Operation Coordination Centre (OSOCC). A subsequent request was made on 27 October for the setting up of satellite offices for the UN’s Disaster Assessment Coordination – teams (UNDAC), donated by the International Humanitarian Partnership (IHP) member states). Denmark had the chair of this organisation in 2004 and was therefore responsible for coordinating this initiative.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The decision was reached by the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, with subsequent notification to the Foreign Policy Committee. In both cases, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to Danish participation in UN support, alongside donations from the other IHP member states (Sweden, Norway, Finland, the United Kingdom, Belgium and the Netherlands).

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish IHP chairmanship coordinated the joint contributions of the member states in Sudan when a UNDAC team was sent out in the spring of 2004 and when office facilities were set up at Juba, Aweil and Malakal in October of the same year.
Later in the year, planning and implementation commenced of the donation of three satellite offices to UNDAC and UN Children’s Fund (UNICEF). A Danish communications expert was assigned to the coordination centres that had been set up, whose task was to set up internal and external communications.
The UNDAC support modules were comprised of materials and personnel from Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland and the United Kingdom. Transport duties to Sudan were performed by the Netherlands and Belgium.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Operations in Sudan began in early 2004. The Danish contribution was concluded in February 2007. Denmark sent a total of 19 people during this period.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The provision of personnel and logistics support for the creation of a UDAC team.
Management and coordination of the IHP project in the form of purchasing, transportation and installation of prefabricated container facilities for the UNOCHA and UNICEF satellite offices.
The Danish IHP chair coordinated the contributions from Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Belgium. The prefabricated container buildings were delivered and installed by a Danish company.
The civil war and the Sudanese climate presented the supplier and the IHP chair with considerable challenges throughout the entire project. An additional responsibility was the collaboration with the many international organisations.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At 08.50 local time on Wednesday 8 October 2005, northern Pakistan and India were hit by a powerful earthquake that measured 7.6 on the Richter scale. This was followed by more than 10 serious aftershocks measuring between 5.2 and 6.3 Richter. The epicentre was 95 km (59 miles) north-north east of Islamabad.
The scale of the disaster was such that 23,000 people were killed and 51,000 injured. A further one million people were made homeless and had insufficient access to food and water.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
Requests for immediate aid were made via the EU Monitoring and Information Centre (EUMIC) and the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA). The Ministry of Foreign Affairs granted political authorisation and finance for the Danish contribution.
Based on the requests made by the government of Pakistan and the international organisations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided after consultation with the Emergency Management Agency that it would send a delegation to UNOCHA with a view to coordinating the international contributions in the disaster area, as well as sending a Base Camp module to the World Food Program (WFP), a complete camp for 35 people.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The delegation was assigned to UNOCHA with a view to being part of the coordination centre at Islamabad Airport, and construction and initial operation of the Base Camp module with a view to donating it to WFP.
The combined Danish contribution was as follows:
- 1 delegate to UNDAC.
- The donation of communications and IT equipment and an electricity generator to UNDAC.
- Base Camp for 35 people on behalf of WFP.
- Sleeping bags for evacuees (5,000).
- Donations to the UN and ICRC (Red Cross) totalling DKK 10 million.
The total value of the Danish donation to the state of Pakistan was DKK 115 million.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The delegation was deployed from 9-24 October. The construction and manning of the Base Camp module from the International Humanitarian Partnership (IHP) member states was performed between15-30 October in the town of Batagram. The camp module was then donated to WFP.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The delegation was part of the staff of the On Site Operation Coordination Centre (OSOCC) set up by UNOCHA and had the task of coordinating aid from national and international organisations and from donor states.
The Base Camp module served as a camp and local coordination centre for WHO employees who were deployed in the area. Danish personnel delivered the camp and assisted in the initial operations until the module was donated to the WHO for further operations.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 29 August 2005, the city of New Orleans on the south west coast of the US was hit by the hurricane Katrina, which caused extensive damage to the city. Approximately 75% of the city was flooded when the dykes broke on Lake Pontchartrain and the Mexican Gulf. Most of the city of New Orleans is below the normal water level.
Katrina cost up to 2,000 human lives, despite the fact that about 80% of the city's population had been evacuated before the hurricane hit. Katrina was the most expensive hurricane to date in the US and cost a total of 82 billion dollars.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: On 9 September 2005, the Danish government’s finance committee authorised the economic framework for the operation. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs was Denmark’s leading authority in this matter.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The provision of two Rubb Halls, 10 water purification systems, 10,000 blankets and the delivery of 3,500 First Aid Kits to the US. Denmark was assigned a very important function when it was requested to send a disaster expert under EU auspices to coordinate the Union’s combined contributions.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The material was sent by air on 18 September. The disaster delegate was sent out for the period 12 September to 5 October.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Construction and delivery of Danish emergency aid contributions as requested by the American authorities (FEMA-Federal Emergency Management Agency). This involved setting up and delivering mobile water purification modules, blankets and First Aid Kits to individuals and storage facilities in the form of Rubb Halls (portable storage halls). Each water purification module had a capacity of approx. 800 litres of drinking water an hour.
Air transport to the US was under the auspices of EADRCC (Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre), based in Ramstein, from where the Danish contribution was delivered on lorries.
The disaster delegate was part of an on-site EU team that was there to assist the American authorities in the coordination and distribution of the international aid. The team was also to obtain experience for future planning and operational procedures during natural disasters.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Lebanon has seen many armed conflicts, both domestic and in wars with Israel. In recent years, we have to look back to 1978 during the Lebanese civil war, in which the Hezbollah movement (a political party and heavily armed militia) played a major role. When the 1990 peace was declared, Hezbollah was the only involved party that did not disarm. The southern part of the country was still under Israeli occupation at this time and Hezbollah was seen by the Lebanese as the strongest element of the resistance movement. Despite the fact that Israel withdrew from Lebanon in the year 2000, there have been numerous occasions where Hezbollah and Israel were involved in armed combat.
On the morning of 12 July 2006, Hezbollah fired rockets over the border and attacked an Israeli convoy, kidnapping two soldiers for barter in hostage exchanges. This led to a major conflict between Israeli military and Hezbollah militia on Lebanese territory, initially in the form of bomb and rocket attacks across the border and eventually, during the summer, an actual invasion in the south of the Lebanon involving Israeli troops and tanks. Even though the Israeli government stated on various occasions that it considered itself only to be at war with Hezbollah terrorists in Lebanon and not with the Lebanese State, government buildings and many civilian areas were badly hit. Hezbollah rockets did not differentiate between military and civilian targets inside Israel, or between Israelis and civilians from other countries.
On 15 July 2006, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark summoned members of the International Operations Staff (IOS) to an information meeting about the situation for Danish citizens in Lebanon.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: After an IOS request and an EU mandate, the government decided to deploy the necessary Danish resources with a view to bringing Danish citizens back home from the war zone in Lebanon and to send oil pollution experts via the EU.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The evacuation
On Saturday 15 July, a Fact Finding team of seven was sent to Damascus in Syria. This team would work in close collaboration with the Danish Embassy.
On Sunday 16 July, materials were sent in the form of a scaled down office module and accommodation and rest facilities for personnel and evacuees.
The reception facilities on Cyprus were set up on Tuesday 18 July.
SAS (Scandinavian Airline System) made flights available for the evacuation from Damascus and Lamarca on Cyprus, to where evacuees had been transported from Beirut on two passenger ferries that had been hired for the purpose.
In Lebanon, Danish evacuees were transported in rented buses to the airport in Damascus and to the ferries in Beirut.
The Emergency Management Agency’s duties in relation to the evacuation were completed on 30 July. A total of 5,800 Danish citizens were evacuated from the war zone.
52 people from the Emergency Management Agency took part in the evacuation.

The oil pollution
As part of the collaboration between the Danish Defence Command and the Emergency Management Agency, an expert team of three was put together.
The main task of these experts was to lead and organise the clean-up on the coast after the bombing of an oil storage depot, where large quantities of crude oil had flowed into the sea and contaminated 30 km (19 miles) of coastline.
In addition to its command function, the team was to train local personnel in the management and collection of oil from the sea and the beaches.
The mission was carried out by three teams of experts. A total of six Emergency Management Agency personnel were deployed, as well as three people from the Royal Danish Navy.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Evacuations commenced on 15 July 2006 and ended on 28 July 2006.
The pollution clean-up took place between 3 August and 30 September 2006.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
In general terms, the mission involved:
- Setting up reception facilities for Danish citizens in Lebanon and surrounding countries.
- The acquisition of transport to move evacuees to airports and departure ports.
- Air transport back to Denmark
- The deployment of three Danish advisers as part of pollution clean-up operations.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
During the first days of May 2008, the cyclone Nargis blew over the southern region of Myanmar, at wind speeds of up to 250 km/h (155 miles/h). The flood delta near the Yangon River was worst hit by the wind and rain, which caused extensive flooding which resulted in loss of life and destroyed infrastructure and the rice harvest. The death toll was estimated as being approx. 100,000 people throughout Myanmar.
On 5 May 2008, the government of Myanmar requested international aid to re-establish the ruined infrastructure and the food supply system that had been shattered. The request was channelled to the Danish government via the UN and EU.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defence decided on behalf of the Danish government that it would supply the Danish contribution in collaboration with Myanmar’s authorities.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The contribution involved the delivery and donation of water purification equipment to aid the supply of drinking water. The mission was carried out by a total of nine emergency management officers who were deployed in Myanmar.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Planning and negotiations with Myanmar’s authorities commenced on 6 May 2008 but dragged out. It was not until 18 May that an advance guard of two set off for the area. The equipment landed in Yangon on 25 May and was immediately distributed to three geographical areas in the country. The last remaining emergency management personnel returned to Denmark on 15 June.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Sending and setting up water purification systems as advised by the authorities. Additionally, training was provided in the use and maintenance of the purification systems, with a view to the donation and subsequent local operation of the equipment.
The donation consisted of three water purification system modules, with three units each. The nine units were able to provide about 250 m3 of drinking water a day.
In addition to the transportation, installation and operation of the water purification modules, the Danish personnel trained the local authorities in how to use and maintain the equipment to produce clean and pure drinking water for the population until the normal supply lines were re-established.
The Danish experts were at the forefront of the UN Water and Sanitation Cluster for the entire duration of the mission and were therefore able to have a big impact on where the units would be located within the country. This function and advisory role was continued by the Danes through the whole of 2008 in partnership with World Vision, a global Christian aid organisation that was working in Myanmar.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
A powerful 8.8 Richter earthquake hit central Chile on 27 February 2010. The epicentre of the earthquake was approx. 35 km (22 miles) from the coast and caused a tsunami of approximately 2.5 m (16 ft). The towns of Concepcion and Valparaiso were the worst affected. The area was then hit by 121 aftershocks, measuring 5.0 Richter or more. The number of people killed was relatively limited. The destruction of infrastructure and, in particular, communication lines was relatively extensive, however. It is estimated that 500,000 houses were damaged and that the natural disaster affected 1.5 million people.
The EU asked its member states to provide experts for an EU mission to Chile.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defence decided on behalf of the Danish government that it would provide the EU with experts.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The contribution was to send an ICT (Information and Communication Technology) module and a TAST (Technical Assistance Support Team) module. The mission was performed by a total of four emergency management officers and volunteers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: From 4 March to 19 March 2010.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: Technical support to other EU teams based in the country for communications and other forms of logistical support. The ICT module was comprised of computers, satellite phones and other types of communication devices. In addition to the ICT module, the TAST module was also comprised of living quarters facilities and electricity generators etc.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Haiti was hit by an earthquake measuring 7.0 on the Richter scale at 16.53 local time on 12 January 2010. The region was hit by several strong aftershocks during the following days. The epicentre of the earthquake was 25 km (16 miles) from Port-au-Prince, the country’s capital.
The area suffered extensive casualties and damage to infrastructure. Haiti was already one of the most impoverished countries in Central America. The final death toll was about 150,000, with another 250,000 people injured. Approximately 1 million people were made homeless. Most public and private sector buildings were destroyed, as was the country’s infrastructure which also broke down. The aftermath was worsened by domestic tensions which led to looting, murders and street fighting.
Immediately after the earthquake, Haiti’s government requested international aid from the international emergency aid organisations.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defence decided on behalf of the Danish government that Denmark would provide the requested aid. Denmark’s contribution would be in partnership with the other Scandinavian countries and the international organisations.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The contribution involved setting up camp facilities for UN personnel and the donation of blankets to the homeless, the posting to Haiti of an IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership) coordinator, assigning an expert to the EU’s coordination team in Haiti and personnel support for the staff of the EU coordination centre in Brussels.
Full performance of the Haitian earthquake mission involved a total of 22 people from the Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: From 15 March to 30 September 2010.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Camp facilities were set up to house EU personnel over two sessions, under the auspices of the IHP countries. The first camp was set up around 20 January and was expanded to its full capacity (accommodation for 75 employees) after two weeks. The camp was self-sufficient and had all facilities. The camp’s logistics personnel came from Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland and Estonia. The camp was handed over to the UN-WFP (World Food Program) at the end of September 2010.
Denmark was responsible for the coordination of the IHP contribution in Haiti. Emergency aid experts were also provided by Denmark to the EU's coordination team in Haiti. An expert was also sent to the EU’s coordination centre in Brussels to support its regular personnel.
Finally, as is almost the norm for natural disasters, 2,500 blankets were donated to local authorities for distribution to the homeless.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
An extended period of rainfall in July 2010 was the cause of extreme flooding in Pakistan. A lot of the infrastructure in isolated rural areas on riverbanks was destroyed or badly damaged. According to the UN, over 17 million people were affected by the disaster. Many people also became ill from various infections.
At the end of July, Pakistan’s government requested international aid in the form of light mobile hospitals and other necessary equipment. At the same time, international aid organisations also issued requests of various types of aid via the UN and the EU.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in consultation with the Ministry of Defence decided to approve these requests.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Deployment of a Light Field Hospital, water purification equipment with personnel, IT/communications equipment and technical expertise and camp elements in partnership with the IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership) countries and WFP (World Food Program). The total Danish contribution involved a total of 60 people over its duration.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 28 August - 22 December 2010.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Setting up a “base” hospital that could service three hospitals/clinics in the provision of standard healthcare. The supply of drinking water to the hospital and surrounding towns and villages. Setting up the IHP camp alongside personnel and using equipment from Sweden and the United Kingdom, as well as setting up and servicing internal/external communications equipment for the international organisations. This form of deployment was a new type of mission for the Emergency Management Agency, in a new configuration.
After a fact finding team was deployed to take delivery of the hospital equipment and to locate a suitable destination in the Sindh province, the hospital arrived in Karachi on 7 September and was already operating approximately one week later. The hospital operated and supported three satellite hospitals/clinics in the area. 155,000 patients were treated there during the three month period. A major reason for the successful performance of this mission was contact with Danish-Pakistani doctors.
The water purification equipment supplied the hospital with clean water and was, to a limited extent, also able to provide people outside the hospital with drinking water.
The IHP camp and its Danish-donated tents was set up and operated by the Swedish contribution and then handed over to the UN system. A Danish expert participated in the construction of the camp. Danish technicians also took part in the setting up and operation of the communications equipment for an extended period.

missions.title: Japan 2011
missions.subtitle: Tsunami
missions.name: Japan 2011
missions.descriptiveName: Tsunami Near an Atomic Power Station

text.heading: Background
text.text:
On 11 March 2011, Japan was hit by an earthquake measuring 9.0 on the Richter scale. Its epicentre was out at sea, 130 km (80 miles) to the east of Honshu island in the Miyagi province. The coast was hit by waves of up to 10 m (33 ft), which caused extensive devastation and resulted in the loss of many lives and caused many injuries. The authorities estimated in the days immediately after the disaster that approximately 2,000 people had been killed and 5,000 had been injured.
The devastation on the coastline meant that 380,000 people had to be evacuated. A further 210,000 people were evacuated from the area surrounding the Fukushima atomic power station, which had been seriously damaged by the tsunami.
On 12 March, there was an explosion in reactor 1, which destroyed the building around the reactor itself. On 13 March, there was another explosion, this time in reactor 3. At this point, the Japanese government asked for international aid via the international organisations.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in partnership with the Ministry of Defence and of the Interior, decided on behalf of the Danish government that it would offer aid to Japan via the Danish Embassy in Tokyo.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
After negotiations with and authorisation by the Japanese authorities, it was decided that the Emergency Management Agency would provide the services that had been requested. In addition, material and advisory aid would be provided to the Danish Embassy in Tokyo, and a nuclear expert would assist the EU.
This mission involved the participation of eight people from the Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was a short one, running from 14 to 28 March 2011, but made an important contribution to the clean-up and provision of advice.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Material aid in the form of blankets for the Japanese authorities as requested, expert nuclear science support to the Danish Embassy in Tokyo and the gathering of knowledge for use in future disasters.
23,000 blankets were donated to help the evacuated populations. These were delivered to the authorities and distributed by the Japanese emergency services.
Two emergency management officers were stationed at the Danish Embassy in a supporting role for its personnel. The Embassy was equipped with applicable Geiger counters and dosage meters. The Embassy’s personnel was also trained in the use of this equipment. Emergency management officers were involved in the work that was done to prepare contingency plans for the Embassy and Danish citizens who were in Japan. Plans were prepared in consultation with the regional safety officer of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs about iodine table dosages, food safety plans, instruction in the use of atomic measurement equipment, the construction of a website and the use of other forms of information on Facebook etc.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In September 2017, French President Emmanuel Macron proposed an inter-state military cooperation initiative independent of existing structures (NATO and the EU). The goal of the initiative would be to strengthen the shared strategic culture among members so as to enable improved effectiveness of collaboration in future multinational military operations.
On 25 June 2018, the European Intervention Initiative (EI2) was established with 10 member countries in the EU: Denmark, France, Germany, the UK, Belgium, Estonia, Holland, Portugal, Spain, and (later during November of that year) Finland joined the initiative.
In 2019, Denmark was invited to join a maritime effort led by France, known as “Mission Clemenceau”, as part of the fight against the Islamic State in Syria referred to as Operation Inherent Resolve. The Danish frigate Niels Juel was meant to serve as an escort vessel in the French carrier strike group Task Force 473 (groupe aéronaval in French) clustered around the French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Niels Juel did not participate in an aggressive role and was permitted only to use force according to the international law principle of the right to self defence. In addition, the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea contains several provisions for unhindered navigation and unharmed passage for warships in foreign territorial waters.
The French military operations in Inherent Resolve performed against the Islamic State within Syria’s sovereign borders, are not driven by a request from the Assad regime nor an authorisation from the UN Security Council. The international law mandate derives from the principle of collective defence. This permits Iraq and its allies to defend themselves against attacks launched from Syrian territory in case Syria is unable to and/or does not wish to quell aggression launched from within its borders.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 5 February 2019, the Parliament approved (with 92 votes in favour and 15 votes opposed) the deployment of Danish navy ships in the activities of naval forces of NATO member countries for up to twelve months at a time. In the case of participation by the navy ships in armed aggression, Parliament must be consulted per proper procedure. On this basis, Danish Defence was authorised to provide the frigate Niels Juel to the French carrier strike group Task Force 473 in an operational area including the eastern part of the Mediterranean, the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden, the northern part of the Indian Ocean extending to the Seychelles, and the Persian Gulf.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: After serving for nearly two months, Niels Juel left the operation on 27 April 2019. This participation has provided the Navy an opportunity to engage in training during a complex naval military operation with several allied nations. The mission has thus strengthened the strategic collaboration with key allies of Denmark and has generated new knowledge about, insight into, and ability to perform advanced naval military operations.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
On 20 February 2019, Niels Juel set off for the Mediterranean to meet the French carrier strike group Task Force 473 and join it from 4 March to 27 April. The primary task for the frigate was to protect the 261-metre nuclear powered aircraft carrier carrying up to 40 aircraft (26 fighters in this mission) and over 2,000 crew members.
On board Niels Juel were about 160 crew members primarily from the Navy and personnel from the Air Force and the Army. The ship also carried an EH101 helicopter for use in reconnaissance, transportation of goods and personnel, and potential rescue missions. In addition to protecting Charles de Gaulle, Niels Juel was tasked with providing assistance in controlling the airspace around the carrier and the flight traffic associated with the carrier.
The carrier group included, in addition to Niels Juel, British, American, and Portuguese escort vessels, a command ship, a replenishment tanker and a nuclear powered attack submarine.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Armed conflict in neighbouring Syria had produced a massive flow of refugees in nearby countries. The UNHCR (UN High Commissioner for Refugees) assessed that there were approximately 540,000 refugees in Jordan. Existing refugee camps were unable to accommodate the large number of people. The Jordanian authorities therefore requested international aid in the management of the refugee crisis.
The EU and UN then asked their member states for aid in the construction of new refugee camps and supplementary aid in managing the large number of refugees.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: By agreement with the Ministry of Defence and with authorisation from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, this mission was assigned to the Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
In addition to participation in an EU fact finding mission in Jordan, the Danish contribution involved: the donation and delivery of blankets to the people who were housed in the refugee camps, the posting of an IT expert to the Swedish MSB (Myndigheten för Samhellsskydd och Beredskap) project and the deployment of a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear) expert to the UNWFP (UN World Food Programme), with additional participation in setting up a new refugee camp under the auspices of the Swedish-led IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership) mission.

Denmark’s total contribution during this period involved 14 employees.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: From June 2012 to March 2014.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
By agreement with Jordan Hashemite Organisation, 37,000 blankets were purchased and delivered to refugees in existing camps. Distribution of this donation was in collaboration with the Danish Embassy in Jordan.
During the period 12-18 June, EU ECHO (European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations) deployed a team of experts whose task was to gather the data that was required in order to establish refugee healthcare facilities. The team produced a report that would serve as the basis for the combined EU aid to Jordan. A Danish healthcare expert from the Emergency Management Agency was part of this team.
UNHCR (UN High Commissioner for Refugees) headquarters in Amman were being renovated and rebuilt. This project was led by Swedish MSB. Denmark made an IT expert available to the rebuilding work. The Danish expert was responsible for setting up networks and servers for the 450 employees. The expert was stationed in Amman for a seven month period, commencing on 3 September 2013.
Because of the increasing threat that chemical weapons would be deployed, WFP (World Food Programme) had requested a CBRN expert. The task of the CBRN would be to train personnel in Jordan and prepare instructions and procedures for use in the event of a chemical weapons attack. Equipment was also purchased to combat the effects of such an attack and training was provided in its use. The specialist was deployed for two months, commencing on 21 December 2012.
The IHP countries set up accommodation and office facilities in the newly-constructed refugee camp in Azraq. Denmark provided craftsmen for this project.

missions.title: Southern Sudan 2012
missions.subtitle: Refugees and Famine
missions.name: Sydsudan 2012
missions.descriptiveName: A Broad Collaboration with Aid Organisations

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Tensions in Southern Sudan escalated in December 2013 in the country’s capital, Duba. Resistance against the government spread quickly to the entire country. In January 2014, rebel groups were armed from military depots. The armed conflict between the government and rebel groups in Southern Sudan escalated further during the spring of 2014, becoming an actual civil war with elements of ethnic cleansing.
The large scale internal flow of refugees brought problems with food supplies as the season for planting life-essential crops was in March and April. Because of the civil war and the flow of refugees it created, the task of planting crops was only carried out to a lesser degree, which meant that there was a serious threat of future famine. It was estimated that approximately seven million people would be affected by food shortages and that approximately 2.2 million would be in actual life-threatening situation.
International aid organisations’ stockpiles of food, fuel, generators, medicines, vehicles etc. were fully or partly commandeered by local authorities, paramilitary groups and the military. This meant that a joint coordinated effort would be required on the part of the international aid organisations, under the leadership of the UN.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: After authorisation by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, it was decided that the Ministry of Defence and the Emergency Management Agency would coordinate and implement the Danish contribution.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Logistical and personnel support for the UN by agreement with the involved UN organisations.
Denmark sent 29 emergency management officers and volunteers to the combined mission in Southern Sudan. Other personnel came from the member states of the IHP partnership.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: From June 2012 to May 2021.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Once again, this was a broad-fronted support for the international organisations. This took the form of:

  • A Fleet Manager for the WFP (World Food Programme).
  • A specialist to build the IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership) camp for the UNHCR (UN High Commissioner for Refugees). The camp was supplied and donated by Sweden.
  • An Assessment Team to plan future UN installations in Southern Sudan.
  • The construction of facilities for UN personnel in prefabricated modular buildings.
  • Emergency aid specialist for WFP in Southern Sudan.

The Fleet Manager for the mission in Southern Sudan was posted for three months to the WFP office in Juba, Southern Sudan and was tasked with the management and maintenance of the vehicles that were available for use by the organisation in the area. The organisation's primary mission was the distribution of food to the population.

The Swedish State had donated camp facilities to the UNHCR in 2012. The camp was put together and delivered by MSB (Myndigheten för Samhällsskydd och Beredskap). When requested by MSB, Danish personnel participated in the installation and start-up operations of the camp facilities.
By midsummer 2012, the refugee situation in Southern Sudan and, notably in the Upper Nile State and Mabam Country provinces, was so bad that the UN had no qualified overview of the situation. Because of this, there was a desire to construct a number of smaller district offices with accommodation facilities for the regular staff. In June 2012, the UNHCR in Geneva contacted the IHP countries to ask for assistance. To bring about the best possible basis for providing aid to the UN organisations, a reconnaissance mission to Southern Sudan was carried out by emergency aid experts from Denmark, Norway and Finland.
Based on the long time perspective for the UN’s presence in Southern Sudan and the fact that climate would vary during the course of the year, the tent facilities were replaced by prefabricated housing with air conditioning. The entire project was implemented under IHP auspices, with Danish leadership. During the summer of 2014, camp facilities were set up in Gumuruk, Dorein, Labrab and Pibor. After being set up and commissioned, the camps were transferred to UNHCR (UN High Commissioner for Refugees) and IOM (International Organization for Migration).
In October 2013, WFP made a request to the Emergency Management Agency for a Danish emergency management expert to support the organisation’s work in Southern Sudan. This request was granted for a period of six weeks.
The contribution in 2020 was to set up three relief camps in Sudan. The camps were to support the work of receiving refugees from Ethiopia. Due to the war in the Tigray region, the situation was critical and the need to scale up emergency relief efforts was acute.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Typhoon Haiyan hit the Philippines on 8 November 2013 with destructive force. Haiyan was a category five typhoon, with winds of up to 315 km/h (196 miles/h) and an average wind speed of 160 km/h (99 miles/h). The typhoon’s passage caused extensive damage on the islands of Samar, Leyte, Cebu and Ileilo. Experts assessed that the city of Tacloban on the island of Leyte was 90% destroyed.
Generally, the affected islands had difficulty obtaining clean drinking water, food, shelter, electricity and access to telephone and Internet connections. Another issue was that the transportation of aid equipment and emergency aid to the islands’ populations was hindered by a shattered infrastructure.
4.5 million people were affected by the typhoon. Over 300,000 people were living in primitive evacuation centres. The authorities anticipated that up to 10,000 people had perished.
On 9 November, the Filipino government requested the international community for aid in dealing with the consequences of the typhoon’s passage through the area and for assistance in the coordination of national and international missions.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of the Interior, with authorisation from the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, asked the Emergency Management Agency to perform the Danish contribution in consultation with the international aid organisations.

text.heading: Contrbution
text.text:
In collaboration with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, to record and prioritise requests made by the international aid organisations and to carry out the missions that were authorised.
The total Danish contribution to the mission in the Philippines involved 18 emergency management officers and volunteers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 12 November 2013 to 28 February 2014.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The missions performed were diverse, involving logistical support to the WFP’s (World Food Programme) re-establishment of existing WFP camps, the renovation of office facilities and buildings for the UN organisations and the establishment of an OSOCC (On Site Operation Coordination Centre) for UNOCHA (UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs). Personnel support was also deployed to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' citizens’ advice service, a nurse to support UNOCHA and a kitchen manager to run the UN camp kitchen.
WFP needed to renovate and upgrade their facilities in Tacloban and Guiuan with a view to having the capacity to cope with missions in the vicinity of evacuees in the camps. Under IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership) auspices, Denmark sent a technical support team with a broad craftsmanship background and plenty of familiarity with the camp’s facilities. The team worked in Tacloban from the beginning of December 2013 to the end of February 2014.
The UN organisations on the Philippines needed to renovate and extend their facilities to better enable the organisations to cope with their many extensive missions. The IHP member states coordinated the renovation and construction of the required facilities in partnership with local advisers and contractors. The missions were led by a Danish team.
Under IHP auspices, and to support UNOCHA’s work towards the coordination of national and international aid in the disaster area, two OSOCCs were set up with three associated Base Camp Light and support modules of various types. The mission was performed using personnel and materials from the IHP member states. One OSOCC configuration was supplied by Denmark, Finland and Luxembourg. The second was supplied by Sweden, Norway and Estonia.
An emergency call-out team under the auspices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was sent to support the Danish Consulate on the Philippines. The team was comprised of personnel from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the National Police and the Emergency Management Agency.
Denmark sent a nurse to support UN personnel in the area where the mission was being carried out. The nurse’s first task was to evaluate local treatment facilities and capacity with a view to the treatment of UN personnel in the area. Another task was the preparation of an ”in case of emergency” plan for these personnel. The nurse was also responsible for the UN’s medical equipment and the purchasing/acquisition of necessary medicines. A quality assessment was then performed to evaluate the capacity at nearby hospitals in the event that UN personnel were seriously injured. The mission lasted for 42 days.
A Danish cook was posted to the UN camp in Tacloban for a period of six weeks.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The historical basis for the conflicts in the Central African Republic (CAR) was the French occupation of the country during the colonial era. The country declared independence in 1960 and the power struggles in the country began. The country’s population was primarily composed of Muslim and Christian factions divided across numerous ethnic population groups. From 1960 until the present day, there have been numerous coups d'etat. CAR’s power base has always depended on military backing. Neighbouring Libya and Chad have on various occasions been involved in these conflicts to some extent.
In February 2014, the UN reported that 900,000 people in the country had taken flight and that half of the country’s 4.6 million inhabitants were in urgent need of humanitarian aid in the form of food and medical support. There was also a flow of refugees from neighbouring countries because of a long period of drought and internal power struggles between rival groups. Increased international aid was therefore required from the international aid organisations.
In May 2014, the UN requested aid from the IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership) member states in the renovation and expansion of the UN’s facilities in the Central African Republic (CAR).

In addition a specific UN mission was established - UN Integrated Peacebuilding Office in the Central African Republic (BINUCA).

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
The Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Defence authorised the Emergency Management Agency to carry out the Danish contribution.

With background in Resolution 2121 of 10 October 2013, Resolution 2127 of 5 December 2013 and Resolution 2134 of 28 Januar 2014 the Danish Parlament voted i favour of sending af C-130 in support of BINUCA.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Emergency Management Agency would be part of a Swedish-led project under the auspices of IHP (International Humanitarian Partnership). The Danish contribution would represent 10% of the total cost. Denmark sent six emergency management officers over the entire duration of the project.

A C-130 transport aircraft was deployed in 2014 in support of BINUCA.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: From May 2014 to May 2015, during which time the personnel were withdrawn on multiple occasions to safer locations because of the precarious security situation.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission involved the renovation and extension of the former UN facility in Kaga Bandora with a view to being able to service the WFP (World Food Programme), UNICEF (UN Children Fund) and OCHA (Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs).
The Danish contribution to this project took the form of personnel to deal with necessary tasks and the renovation and expansion of camp facilities. A Base Camp was also supplied for the construction team, which included accommodation facilities, electrical and drinking water supply, technical support and equipment to put up the facilities.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
During the spring of 2014, the biggest Ebola epidemic in history broke out in Western Africa. The disease quickly spread from Guinea, where the first cases were diagnosed in March 2014, to neighbouring Liberia, Sierra Leone, Mali, Nigeria and Senegal. Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone were particularly badly affected by the epidemic. The World Health Organisation (WHO) reported that, from the beginning of March 2014 to April 2016, a total of 28,616 people had been infected in the three main countries. Of these, 11,310 died. The disease also claimed victims among healthcare personnel. According to Médecins Sans Frontières, 500 of the dead were health professionals. The deaths of these valuable professionals placed even greater pressure on the already inadequate healthcare services in the affected countries. On 8 August 2014, the WHO classified the Ebola outbreak as an international public health emergency situation. That same month the organisation requested aid from the international community.
Liberia was the worst hit of the countries affected by Ebola, with over 10,672 infected and 4,800 dead from a population of 4.3 million. The first case of Ebola was discovered on 30 March 2014 in Lofa County, which borders Sierra Leone and Guinea. The disease spread quickly from this base. On 23 August, all parts of Liberia were hit by Ebola. When transmission of the disease peaked in August and September 2014, the WHO was reporting between 300 to 400 new cases every week.
When Ebola appeared, Liberian society was still recovering from a 14-year civil war that had ended in 2003. The civil war had left the country’s healthcare service in ruins. The numerous deaths among healthcare personnel brought the already-fragile health service to its knees. Multiple hospitals closed because of personnel fatalities. Other hospitals had no option but to turn away sick patients. Without the ability to hospitalise those who were infected, the disease began to spread at a rapid pace.
After 10 months, Liberia’s government, with help from the international community, was able to beat the outbreak. By mid-January 2015, Ebola was only present in two regions of the country. During the spring of 2015, only very few new cases were diagnosed and, on 9 May 2015, Liberia was the last country that the WHO was able to declare Ebola-free, with no new cases. Isolated new cases appeared up to 2016, but these were properly treated and the disease did not spread.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: After a request made by the World Health Organisation (WHO) on 4 September to the International Humanitarian Partnership (an informal humanitarian partnership between a number of European countries, also known as IHP), the Ministry of Defence authorised the Emergency Management Agency to send personnel and equipment to Liberia. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs financed the combined contribution.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The purpose of the fact finding mission was to gather information that could be used to make decisions about the most effective way of using IHP’s resources. The mission focused, in particular, on how international healthcare personnel could be accommodated in a safe manner. The mission was performed under the auspices of IHP. One employee from the Danish Emergency Management Agency and two from its Swedish sister organisation, Myndigheten för Samhällsskydd och Beredskap (MSB) took part in the mission.
The posting of an UNDAC expert, who was part of OCHA’s 15-strong team that coordinated the aid contribution from the international community, aid organisations and Liberia's government.
Setting up the On-Site Operations and Coordination Centre (OSOCC) in Monrovia for the UNDAC team. The mission was performed under the auspices of IHP. The Emergency Management Agency initially provided an ICT (Information and Communication Technology) kit and a little extra equipment, a team leader and two technicians.
Support for WHO healthcare professionals, which involved the installation of nine so-called “prefabs” (prefabricated containers with flexible use applications, such as offices or accommodation) with offices and living areas at isolation units to which the WHO healthcare workers could return for rest and breaks while treating Ebola patients. The mission was performed under IHP auspices, in partnership with MSB. Two technicians were deployed from the Emergency Management Agency. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs provided funding of DKK 3.7 million for the mission.

The Emergency Management Agency's contribution in Liberia should be considered within the context of the mission to combat Ebola in Sierra Leone during the same period. With four missions in Liberia and six in Sierra Leone and total spending of DKK 40 million, the mission to wipe out Ebola in Western Africa was the largest international mission in which the Emergency Management Agency has participated. The mission in Western Africa involved a degree of risk. Some of the employees were suspected of having been infected by the lethal Ebola virus. Luckily, this turned out not to be the case, but the suspicion alone was very stressful to those who were suspected of being infected and to their families and colleagues.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The fact finding mission ran from 8-12 September 2014.
It was planned that an UNDAC expert would be sent to UNDAC in Liberia in the period 16 September - 11 October 2014, but this was cancelled because of illness.
Setting up OSOCC: The first team was sent from 17 September to 18 October 2014.
Support for WHO healthcare personnel: The nine prefabs were sent from Denmark in mid-October 2014 and were erected by Danish technicians up until the middle of April 2015.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Fact finding mission, the task of which was to determine potential locations for base camps or other facilities to house international aid personnel in Monrovia.
Posting of an UNDAC expert, who would be responsible for military and civilian coordination and assist in setting up a communications structure, which would be used to ensure that UN, aid organisations’ and national authorities’ resources would be used to their best potential.
The OSOCC was set up after a request made by OCHA. The purpose of the OSOCC was to establish a controlled environment for international healthcare personnel who were posted to Monrovia. This gave the WHO and OCHA a location from which they could coordinate the contributions of the international community towards eliminating Ebola in Liberia.
To support the WHO healthcare personnel, the Emergency Management Agency set up accommodation facilities and improved the working conditions of healthcare personnel who were deployed via the WHO to five treatment centres in Monrovia (nine prefabs that functioned as break areas and offices for health workers).

text.heading: Background
text.text:
A long period of heavy rain caused extensive flooding in up to a third of Bosnia-Herzegovina. It is estimated that about a million people were affected by the floods, which caused serious problems with the supply of electricity and clean drinking water. About 40,000 people were evacuated from the flooded areas.
Serbia also suffered large-scale flooding in the western and south-western parts of the country. 16 people were reported dead. Approximately 24,000 people were evacuated and about 7.2 million people were affected by the floods. The rain had led to increased water levels in larger and smaller rivers. The areas along the Sava river west of Belgrade was one of the worst-affected areas. Water levels had risen by up to 6.2 m (20 ft).

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Danish government.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Pumping floodwater and the supply of clean drinking water in the affected areas. The unit that was sent to Bosnia-Herzegovina was comprised of two emergency management officers and 24 conscripts and volunteers. 13 vehicles were also sent for transportation and day-to-day operations. The unit that was sent to Serbia consisted of two pump modules with their own electricity supply and was comprised of 26 officers and conscripts. Maximal pump capacity was about 60 m3/min and was powered with its own power supply.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 21 May - 16 June 2014 (Bosnia-Herzegovina) and 19 May - 2 June 2014 (Serbia).

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The insertion of high-performance pump teams and the supply of drinking water as agreed with the Bosnian authorities. 
The pump team in Bosnia-Herzegovina was comprised of two HCP (High Capacity Pumps) units
that were each able to pump 1,800 m3 an hour. The unit was self-sufficient in terms of electricity and means of propulsion. In both countries, the Danish contribution worked closely with THW (Technisches Hilfswerk) from Germany, under the co-ordination of a EUCF (EU Civil Protection) team. The water purification team was comprised of eight water purification modules that were deployed in the towns of Domaljevac, Odzah and Samak. Each water purification module could process between 800 and 1,000 litres of clean drinking water an hour.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
During the spring of 2014, the biggest Ebola epidemic in history broke out in Western Africa. The disease quickly spread from Guinea, where the first cases were diagnosed in March 2014, to neighbouring Liberia, Sierra Leone, Mali, Nigeria and Senegal. Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone were particularly badly affected by the epidemic. The World Health Organisation (WHO) reported that, from the beginning of March 2014 to April 2016, a total of 28,616 people had been infected in the three main countries. Of these, 11,310 died. The disease also claimed victims among healthcare personnel. According to Médecins Sans Frontières, 500 of the dead were health professionals. The deaths of these valuable professionals placed even greater pressure on the already inadequate healthcare services in the affected countries. On 8 August 2014, the WHO classified the Ebola outbreak as an international public health emergency situation. That same month the organisation requested aid from the international community.
The first case of Ebola in Sierra Leone was diagnosed in May 2014. The disease then spread very quickly. On 30 July, Sierra Leone’s government declared a state of emergency and deployed the army to enforce a quarantine that prohibited residents of areas with high infection rates from leaving the quarantined areas. Despite these government measures, the disease continued to spread and in October 2014, Ebola cases had been diagnosed in every region of Sierra Leone.
The Ebola epidemic was a bigger problem than Sierra Leone’s already-pressed healthcare system was able to deal with. There were too few beds, doctors and nurses to treat Ebola patients and there was also a shortage of equipment to protect healthcare personnel from themselves being infected.
The number of new infections continued to increase until the end of January 2015, when the World Health Organisation (WHO) reported a fall in the number of new infections for the first time since the outbreak of the epidemic. After 42 days with no new cases of infection, the WHO, on 7 November 2015, announced that the disease was no longer spreading in Sierra Leone. A few new cases were diagnosed leading up to the summer of 2016.
The Ebola epidemic had caused a high death toll in Sierra Leone. At the end of 2015, the government announced that the country, with its 6.2 million inhabitants, had had over 9.000 cases of Ebola. According to the BBC, 3,955 people had perished. The epidemic also interrupted essential food production and trade, thus creating a related humanitarian crisis for a large number of families, particularly in rural areas.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: After a request made by the World Health Organisation (WHO) to the International Humanitarian Partnership (an informal humanitarian partnership between a number of European countries, also known as IHP), the Ministry of Defence, representing the Danish government and after informing the Foreign Affairs Committee, authorised the Emergency Management Agency to send personnel and equipment to Sierra Leone. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs financed the combined contribution.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Ministry of Defence initially mandated the Emergency Management Agency to carry out a fact finding mission in Sierra Leone under the auspices of IHP. A mandate was then issued to send personnel and equipment to Sierra Leone with a view to setting up and supporting the accommodation of WHO healthcare personnel.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided on 30 September 2014 that it would fund DKK 3.9 million to support the IHP’s logistical contribution in the form of transport, IT office equipment and two medical isolation units in Sierra Leone via the WHO. During the autumn, the Danish government set various additional authorisations and aid packages in motion to combat Ebola. The Ebola epidemic progressed constantly and, because of the serious nature of the crisis, the Emergency Management Agency was authorised to take on new missions as required, on an ongoing basis.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The mission of the Emergency Management Agency in Sierra Leone was one of the most extensive international missions it had ever been involved with. The Emergency Management Agency had various tasks in Sierra Leone, all of which were performed under the auspices of IHP as requested by the WHO. The missions performed by the Emergency Management Agency were expanded as the epidemic progressed.

Missions performed by the Emergency Management Agency were:

Fact finding mission with a view to determining where international healthcare personnel could be accommodated in Sierra Leone. The mission was performed under the auspices of IHP. One employee from the Emergency Management Agency and one from the British Department for International Development (DFID) took part in this mission.

Support for WHO in the Freetown area by performing logistical tasks, including establishing and coordinating transport links as part of the deployment of international healthcare teams. The Emergency Management Agency was also responsible for the operation of medical observation units fighting Ebola and administrative and organisational support for IHP projects in Sierra Leone.

Base camp Port Loko, where the contribution involved setting up and operating a base camp for healthcare workers, mainly from the Irish NGO GOAL and British DFID. When the camp closed officially, some of the equipment was transferred to GOAL, who used it to upgrade the medical services at the nearby hotel. The rest of the equipment was donated to DFID, who stored it in Sierra Leone for use in the event of another Ebola epidemic.

Healthcare personnel training support by setting up facilities for WHO, IOM and DFID Ebola Safety Training and logistical support (including transport) so that training could be given.

Deployment of Danish healthcare personnel, the Emergency Management Agency being responsible for the accommodation etc. of the Danish personnel. Danish Defence medical services was responsible for the training of deployed healthcare personnel, who had been recruited from the Danish Healthcare Regions. The healthcare team worked in Port Loko at a healthcare centre led by GOAL, an Irish NGO.

Cold chain, where the Emergency Management Agency, in partnership with its Swedish sister organisation MSB sent a cold chain expert to Sierra Leone.

The full contribution of the Emergency Management Agency in Sierra Leone during the Ebola epidemic ran to DKK 40 million, making it the biggest international mission performed by the Emergency Management Agency. The Ebola epidemic progressed constantly and, because of the serious nature of the crisis, the Emergency Management Agency was authorised to take on new missions as required, on an ongoing basis.

The Emergency Management Agency mission enabled approximately 5,000 healthcare workers to be trained in the treatment of Ebola. When Port Loko was set up, the Emergency Management Agency established a framework that accommodated foreign healthcare workers for a total of 12,500 nights. A number of coordination and support tasks were also performed for WHO and IHP, which contributed towards assuring an effective and qualified management of the Ebola epidemic.
The mission in Sierra Leone was not without risk for those posted. Some of the employees were suspected of having been infected by the lethal Ebola virus. Luckily, this turned out not to be the case, but the suspicion alone was very stressful to those who were suspected of being infected and to their families and colleagues.
A total of 69 Emergency Management Agency employees were deployed. Denmark also sent four healthcare teams to Sierra Leone, the teams being from 14 to 25 people in size.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The fact finding mission ran from 21-28 September 2014
Support for WHO in Freetown lasted for nine months, from September 2014 to June 2015.
Base camp Port Loko opened for its guests on 21 November 2014 and was closed on 7 May 2015. Equipment for the camp was sent from Billund Airport on 12 November 2014. The last Dane left the camp after closing it down and transferring the equipment to GOAL on 10 June 2015.
Training support for healthcare personnel lasted for nine months, from September 2014 to June 2015.
Danish healthcare personnel began to be posted just before July 2014, when the first team was sent. The contribution was completed when the final team returned home in June 2015. A total of four teams were deployed, each for a six week period.
The cold chain expert was posted from 5 December 2014, for a six month period.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The purpose of the fact finding mission was to determine options with regard to assisting in the accommodation of international healthcare personnel. The mission provided coverage for Freetown and Kenema in Sierra Leone and Monrovia in Liberia.

Support for the WHO in the Freetown area: The Emergency Management Agency performed a broad variety of tasks in Freetown for the WHO, including:

  • Identifying and setting up Ebola-free accommodation facilities, primarily for the 165 Cuban doctors and nurses, but also for other Foreign Medical Teams (FMTs).
  • Setting up isolation units where international healthcare personnel could stay if there was a suspicion that they had been infected with Ebola. A total of seven isolation units were set up, at the FMTs’ hotels in Freetown and at base camps in Port Loko and Moyamba,
  • The safe transportation of FMTs between their hotels and the Ebola Treatment Centres (ETCs) where they were deployed.
  • Setting up a base to provide logistical support, offices and meeting facilities for various international stakeholders, as well as finding training premises and coordinating transportation to training facilities for the WHO, DFID and other stakeholders.
  • Performing the role of operations coordinator of all IHP projects in Sierra Leone and providing general logistical support for WHO operations.

Base camp Port Loko provided safe working and living conditions for foreign doctors and nurses, minimising the risk that they would become infected with Ebola. The camp was a fully-functional, self-sufficient “village” with laundry, kitchen, water purification, Internet, bathing and beds. It also had two isolation units in which healthcare personnel could be placed if they showed signs they may have contracted Ebola. The camp was initially set up with 80 beds. Already after two weeks it became apparent that it would be necessary to expand the camp to accommodate up to 108 beds. When it closed, the camp had “hosted” more than 12,500 overnight stays. In addition to GOAL, 12 other organisations used the camp.

Support in the training of healthcare personnel: The Emergency Management Agency set up facilities that the WHO, DFID and IOM could use when training healthcare workers and provided logistical support for this training, including in the form of transportation. During the nine months that the training facilities were open, training was received by an estimated 5,000 people.

Deployment of Danish healthcare personnel: The deployment of Danish healthcare personnel was coordinated as a cross-ministerial contribution with the participation of the Ministry of Defence, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Health under the leadership of the Danish Defence Medical Command. During its operations in Sierra Leone, the Emergency Management Agency's mission was to ensure that healthcare workers were accommodated and to provide logistical support to the base camp in Port Loko.

The cold chain expert's mission was to ensure that vaccines etc. were kept chilled during transportation between the healthcare facilities in Sierra Leone.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
At midday local time on 25 April 2015, Nepal was hit by a powerful earthquake measuring 7.8 on the Richter scale. The earthquake’s epicentre was in the town of Barpak in the Gorkha region, approximately 80 km (50 miles) north west of the capital, Kathmandu. The region was hit by several strong aftershocks during the days that followed the earthquake. The most powerful of these aftershocks took place on 12 May. The earthquakes caused extensive damage to buildings and infrastructure. 10,000 people were killed and a further 22,000 were injured. A further 3.5 million people were made homeless immediately after the earthquakes.
On 25 April, the Nepalese authorities requested aid from the international community in the management of disaster measures and aid to those injured. The Nepalese government also requested aid in the rebuilding of the country’s infrastructure.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Danish government.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Was part of the joint project for International Humanitarian Partnership (IHP) with the delivery and installation of facilities for UN Disaster Assessment Coordination (UNDAC). The Danish personnel were: a camp commandant, a camp technician and personnel who would put up and operate the camp’s facilities. Over the entire duration of this mission, Denmark provided a total of 22 disaster management experts and volunteers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: 28 April to 25 July 2015.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
This mission entailed the delivery, installation and operation of facilities for an On Site Operation Coordination Centre (OSOCC) with 10 workstations, communications and a personnel accommodation module (Light Base Camp for 36 people). The team also provided professional support for Danish representatives in Nepal during a visit by a Danish minister.
This was an IHP project, with participation from Sweden, Norway, Germany and Denmark.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
During the days surrounding 15 May 2016, Sri Lanka was hit by multiple tropical storms which caused major flooding and landslides in 22 of the country’s 25 districts. Many villages and residential areas were flooded and destroyed. An estimated 300,000 people are believed to have been affected by the flooding. The government of Sri Lanka estimated that approximately 120,000 homes had been destroyed and that emergency housing was required for 40,000 people.
On this basis, the government of Sri Lanka requested international aid in dealing with the effects of the disaster.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on behalf of the Danish government.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The provision of clean drinking water by agreement with the authorities of Sri Lanka. The Danish contribution to this mission was the participation of seven emergency management officers.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The provision of clean drinking water to the population in the flooded areas. By agreement, water purification equipment was delivered from Denmark, with a capacity of between 70,000 and 80,000 litres a day. This was sufficient to provide 10,000 people a day with clean drinking water. The equipment was installed in the town of Kahatagasdigiliya.
At the end of the mission, a large proportion of the materials used were donated to the local authorities, with a view to continued operation of the system.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Large protests erupted in Ukraine in 2013 when President Viktor Yanukovych refused to sign an association and free trade agreement with the EU. The unrest, known as Euromaidan, led to the ouster of the president and the government. Upon the installation of a new pro-European government and the signing by Ukraine of the association and free trade agreement with the EU in 2014, Russia made the decision to annex the Ukrainian peninsula Crimea. The Crimea crisis spread to eastern Ukraine where pro-Russian separatists in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions (together known as the Donbass region), supported by Russia, declared the area independent and initiated an armed rebellion against the Ukrainian army.

In 2014, the Ukrainian government decided to suspend the neutral status of the country and seek a closer relationship with the West, including NATO. In light of the ongoing civil war in eastern Ukraine, then President Petro Poroshenko asked NATO to provide more support to the effort of reforming the defence and security sectors in the country to make them compatible with NATO standards. The request was met through a series of initiatives such as guidance, education, capacity building, and training missions.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The NATO training missions were based on an invitation from the Ukrainian government. The objective was to bring the armed forces in the country up to NATO standards. The collaboration between NATO and Ukraine took place within the framework of the NATO-Ukraine Commission set up in 1997 to strengthen the relations between the two and to assist Ukraine in reforming its institutions through such means as the NATO-Ukraine Joint Working Group on Defence Reform established in 1998. After the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia in 2014, the collaboration between NATO and Ukraine has been further intensified.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Taking advantage of funds set aside by the Danish Ministry of Defence for the purpose of supporting international collaboration on security, a decision was made by the Danish government in 2015 to support the development of Ukrainian defence capacity.
The Danish Defence Agreement (an inter-party agreement) of 2018 included the intent to offer additional contributions to the NATO programme for Ukraine by providing training under the umbrella of Operation ORBITAL. The agreement transferred the Ukraine work to the Danish Peace and Stabilisation Fund. This fund is dedicated to supporting peace and stability in fragile states. 

Danish paticion in Operation ORBITAL and Operation UNIFIER was fonded by Ministry of Foreign Affairs

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Canadian-led training mission Operation UNIFIER was initiated in September 2015. Denmark contributed to it in 2016 by sending a team of five interpreter officers and two civilian-military interpreters. This contribution of interpreters assisted in the training of Ukrainian security forces.

One of the Danish interpreter officers in addition served as chief interpreter for Operation UNIFIER, having responsibility for planning and coordination of all interpretation support to the activities of the mission.
Lithuania, Poland, the UK, the US, and Sweden contributed to Operation UNIFIER as did Canada and Denmark.

The British-led training mission Operation ORBITAL was launched in November 2015. Since the end of 2018, Denmark has contributed to the training mission. This Danish contribution was meant to train the Ukrainian soldiers in basic skills such as first aid, urban warfare, defensive tactics when under fire, trench raiding, and movements in terrain. Denmark also sent a staff officer to the headquarters of Operation ORBITAL in the capital city of Kiev.
Since 2015, Danish Defence has provided a liaison officer to the NATO Professional Development Programme (PDP). The liaison officer was responsible for preparing civilian officials for service in the Ukrainian military. Civilian leadership in the Armed Forces of Ukraine is a necessity for achieving interoperability with NATO.
Finally, soldiers from the Forward Aeromedical Evacuation unit in the Danish Air Force participated in the CLEAR SKIES air exercise in Kiev in 2018 along with a presence from Estonia, Holland, Poland, Romania, the UK, and the US.

Since Russia’s attack on Ukraine, Denmark’s support contribution now takes place in the United Kingdom. One of Denmark’s roles in this context is a participation in the British-led INTERFLEX operation, which trains Ukrainian soldiers in basic military disciplines. Other training activities involve mine-clearing and NCO-training, as well as training crews on donated materials like the Leopard 1 main battle tank and CAESAR artillery systems. Denmark is also training pilots and ground crew on F-16 fighter aircraft in collaboration with other donor countries.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The conflict in Crimea and eastern Ukraine has taken more than 10,000 lives since 2014. It would not appear that the conflict will be resolved any time soon even though several attempts at a ceasefire have been made. The NATO capacity building missions are not involved with the hostilities. The missions took place in western Ukraine and in the Kiev area, partly to avoid creating any further tension with Russia.

Denmark’s contribution to capacity building in Ukraine was planned to terminated in 2022. It is the goal of the Ukrainian government that its security forces very soon meet the NATO standards.

Due to Russia´s attack on Ukraine in 2022 all personnel in the mission was withdrawn and it will remain so until there is an overview in Ukraine and its future. But part of the training is now caried out from Germany and Great Britain.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In 2014 Islamic State (ISIL) was able to gain ground in Iraq. They were able to take the town of Fallujah in January, taking Mosul (the third-largest town in Iraq) in June when the Iraqi army withdrew without offering major resistance. After a request from the Iraqi government, a new coalition was formed to fight ISIL. Participants included the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Jordan, Morocco, and Denmark. Its official launch was in October under the name Operation Inherent Resolve. The goal was not to deploy a force to fight ISIL on the ground, but to defeat them from the air, while sending a number of individuals to Iraq to advise and train its army to fight against ISIL. Some countries also sent forces to Iraq to combat ISIL more directly.
On 9 December 2017, Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared that the Islamic State was definitively defeated in Iraq and that all its territory had been retaken.
