Remnants of ISIL, however, have still been able to carry out isolated terrorist attacks, for example with suicide bombs in Baghdad in early 2018.

NATO has been involved for a number of years in the implementation of training activities and measures to increase capacity in Iraq that would allow the country to be better able to perform these tasks. In February 2018 the Iraqi government asked the coalition for additional assistance supporting the professionalisation of the military training system and building the national security structure and by providing further advice.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
It was decided at the NATO summit in Brussels in July 2018 that a capacity building mission would be launched in Iraq called NATO Mission Iraq (NMI) after the Iraqi government requested further assistance.
The mission is based on NATO's current activities within the framework of the coalition’s mission in Iraq. The mission would focus on advising officials, primarily from Iraq’s Ministry of Defence and National Security Council, as well as training and advising instructors at various institutions within the Iraqi military. The objective was to help Iraq to build the capacity it needed to be able to take care of its own internal security.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 2 October 2014, Parliament approved proposal B123 (with 94 votes in favour and 9 votes against) to support the war effort against ISIL in Iraq.
With a legal basis in B123, the Government decided in 2018 (after consultation with the Foreign Policy Committee) that it would provide up to 15 people to the new NATO training mission.
With proposal B159 of 26 March 2020 the Government decided to take over from Canada as leading nation in the same year. It was approved on 11 June with 83 votes in favour and 12 votes against. The mission continued in 2022.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark has contributed to the NATO capacity-building NATO Mission Iraq (NMI) by sending approx. 15 people to perform staffing, instructor and mentor functions, as well as medical functions if so required by the NATO mission.  The mission involved personnel from the USA, the United Kingdom, Canada, Poland, Norway and the Netherlands, all of whom have supported the use of NATO´s military structure and procedures as a framework, including political control.  Countries which are not members of NATO are also involved, including Australia, Sweden and Finland. NMI was under Canadian command until end 2020.

During the period leading up to the deployment of the Danish contribution, four Danish personnel and logistics advisers were sent to NATO’s headquarters in and around Baghdad. These were transferred to NMI when the mission was set up.
The Danish Deployable Communications Module (DCM) provides about 22 people to NMI. The DCM company is part of a multi-national signals battalion within NATO’s permanent structure and was set up in 2003 (under its NATO name DCM E). Nationally and administratively, the DCM company is part of the First Headquarters Battalion. DCM's mission is to set up and maintain communication links between NATO's new facilities in Iraq and Europe. The DCM company has been deployed to Baghdad until January 2019. The DCM company could then be deployed to NMI on an occasional basis.
When Denmark end 2020 (november) take over from Canada there will be deployed about 150 soldiers. In april 2021 three helicopters (EH-101) with about 70 soldiers joined the mission.
The contribution was further adjusted during 2022, to now be comprised of 115 personnel distributed over a staff contribution, an escort unit, communication unit/units and instructors. Security- and escortingunit  ended there mission i 2024.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The mission against ISIL in Iraq and Syria has been under way since 2014 through the American-led Operation Inherent Resolve coalition. NATO has had a non-combatant role in the coalition since 2017. Denmark has previously contributed to the training of Iraqi security forces and the war against ISIL (Operation Shader and Operation Inherent Resolve).
An unusual situation arose in January 2020, when the base (that was home to the Danish troops and personnel from other countries) was targeted by Iranian missiles during the Iran/USA crisis. Approx. 100 personnel from the OPN Inherent Resolve training mission and NMI were temporarily evacuated from the base to Kuwait. Nobody was injured during the Iranian attack and all returned safely to the base.
The contribution of three EH-101 transport helicopters as well as personnel was deployed for 12 months from April 2021.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
After the attack that was orchestrated by Al-Qaeda on New York on 11 September 2001, the USA launched a UN-mandated international coalition under the name Operation Enduring Freedom with a view to defeating the Al-Qaeda terror organisation and toppling the Taliban régime in Afghanistan.
Operation Enduring Freedom found quick success driving the Taliban out of the Afghan capital, and a number of Afghan clan leaders met in the German city of Bonn during the second half of 2001. Under UN supervision, the clan leaders agreed in December 2001 that a provisional government would be set up, led by Hamid Karzai, and that it would continue to govern until a permanent democratically-elected solution could be implemented.

The Bonn agreement included a section about the creation of an international security force that would train Afghanistan’s own security forces and help to rebuild public institutions.
Soon after the conference in Bonn, on 20 December 2001, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1386. This set out the framework for an international military force that would support the provisional government. The UN’s intent for this International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) was to put together a large scale force with a mandate in international law, that would be able to guarantee security in Kabul and its surrounding area while Afghan military and police forces were being built.

ISAF command would initially rotate every six months among the nations that were participating on a voluntary basis. This system turned out to be inefficient, however, so ISAF was assigned to NATO command in August 2003 after being invited by the UN and the Afghan government.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1510 on 13 October 2003, authorising an expansion of ISAF’s mandate, which meant that ISAF was now authorised to keep the peace in areas other than Kabul and its immediate vicinity.
In December 2003, NATO’s North Atlantic Council authorised the Supreme Allied Commander Europe (SACEUR) to implement an expansion to ISAF by assuming command of the Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) in Kunduz in northern Afghanistan, which had been under German command.  Command of Operation Enduring Freedom was thus transferred from the US-led military coalition to ISAF.
It was decided at the NATO summit in Istanbul on 28 June 2004 that a further four Provincial Reconstruction Teams would be established in northern Afghanistan, in Mazar-e Sharif, Meymaneh, Feyzabad and Baghlan. These PRTs were set up in October 2004, being the first of four expansions of ISAF’s area of operations.
The second expansion of ISAF’s area of operations commenced in May 2006. Here, ISAF assumed command of four PRTs in western Afghanistan: Herat, Farah, Chaghcharan and Qala-e-Naw. ISAF’s area of responsibility thus included both North and West Afghanistan, about 50% of Afghanistan’s total surface area.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 11 January 2002, a unanimous Parliament adopted proposal B45 to make Danish military forces available to an international security force in Afghanistan.
On 25 November 2004, the Parliament approved proposal B37 (with 96 votes in favour and 12 votes against) on an expansion to the Danish contribution to ISAF in Afghanistan. When this proposal was adopted, it allowed Danish troops to be deployed to other parts of Afghanistan as the ISAF mission broadened its sphere of operation. Danish participation in Chaghcharan together with Lithuania was perfectly in line with Denmark’s normal support in Afghanistan, as requested by the USA.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
From September 2005 to 2009, Denmark provided teams of approx. 10 soldiers: four staff officers and a mobile observation team for the Lithuanian Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) in Chaghcharan in the Ghor province of western Afghanistan, a region of difficult and very mountainous terrain. The Danes were based at Camp Whiskey, which was under Lithuanian command, alongside civilian and military representatives from countries such as Ukraine, Georgia, Croatia and the USA. The Lithuanian camp would later be renamed FOB (Forward Operation Base) SHIELD.
The primary duties for the Danish deployment were focused on civil-military co-operation (or CIMIC), which aims to strengthen collaborations between the deployed forces, local civilian authorities and local populations. The task of the CIMIC projects was not to rebuild Afghanistan, but to create conditions that were conducive towards allowing this to happen, by generating good will among the population and security in the region.

From 2009 the contribution was cut back to four staff officers, who would serve on the Lithuanian staff. The entire Danish contribution to the Lithuanian PRT in Chaghcharan was withdrawn in mid-November 2011.  A total of 12 teams were deployed.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The withdrawal of Danish troops from the Chaghcharan province in 2011 was as part of a general downsizing of the Danish contribution to ISAF forces.
In 2014 NATO’s International Security Assistance Force was shut down when Afghan security forces assumed responsibility for security throughout Afghanistan.
A new smaller-scale NATO mission was set up in its place in 2015, called Resolute Support Mission. Its purpose was to continue the training and provision of advice to the Afghan security forces and national institutions. The new mission assisted the Afghans as they fought to defeat Taliban rebels etc. but didn´t playd an active role in the engagements. Denmark contributed in the training of Afghan security forces and to the general mission of developing Afghanistan through NATO’s Resolute Support Mission untill 2021.

At its peak, ISAF numbered over 130,000 troops from 51 NATO and partner states and was therefore one of the biggest coalitions in world history and the most extensive NATO mission to date.

text.text:

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 25 November 2004, the Parliament approved proposal B37 (with 96 votes in favour and 12 votes against) on an expansion to the Danish contribution to ISAF in Afghanistan. These forces would be part of a German-led Provincial Reconstruction Team in Feyzabad in north-western Afghanistan. The contribution also included a Danish C-130 transport aircraft, a support group and a communications module.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Between January 2005 and August 2008, Denmark provided seven teams, each comprised of approx. 50 soldiers and a civilian stability adviser, to the Provincial Reconstruction Team in Feyzabad in the north-western Badakhshan province, which was under German command.

The Danish soldiers patrolled the relatively stable Badakhshan province. Because Germany had only issued a rather narrow mandate to its contingent, limiting the soldiers’ ability to carry out operations and patrols, all patrols that were not in the immediate vicinity of the base were performed by the Danish troops. The Danish contribution was thus responsible for 27 out of 28 districts in Badakhshan and ran over half of all patrols in the province.
In addition to the German and Danish contributions, 40 Czechs also served in the PRT. Their role was to provide security and inspections in the camp and the nearby landing strip, as well as night patrols of the immediate vicinity, as the German contingent was not permitted to leave the camp at this time.

The Danish troops performed civil-military collaboration (CIMIC) operations as part of the Danish strategy for Afghanistan. The force collaborated with local civilian authorities on smaller projects to generate a positive presence in the area. The task of the CIMIC projects was not to rebuild Afghanistan, but to create conditions that were conducive towards allowing this to happen. The projects were intended to generate good will and security among the local population that would benefit the patrolling forces. In practice, this was achieved by providing materials to local schools (books, small desks and chairs etc) or by providing provisions for use by the local population during the winter. These projects also supported the mission of the German PRT by stabilising and rebuilding the area.
During the period in which the Danish troops were assigned to the PRT in Feyzabad, the Afghan population saw major gains as a country. For example, in 2008 the region was the area of Afghanistan with the highest rate of schooling, with almost equal numbers of girls and boys attending schools. This was in sharp contrast to the Taliban era, during which neither girls nor boys could even hope for normal schooling.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Denmark withdrew its contribution to the Provincial Reconstruction Team in Feyzabad in 2008. This was part of an adjusted Danish strategy for Afghanistan, with an increased deployment in the Helmand province.
In 2014 NATO’s International Security Assistance Force was shut down when Afghan security forces assumed responsibility for security throughout Afghanistan.

Its purpose was to continue the training and provision of advice to the Afghan security forces and national institutions. The new mission assisted the Afghans as they fought to defeat Taliban rebels etc. but did not playd an active role in the engagements. Denmark contributed in the training of Afghan security forces and to the general mission of developing Afghanistan through NATO’s Resolute Support Mission. The mission ended in 2021.

text.text:

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish Parliament adopted decision B43 on 2 December 2004 (96 votes in favour, 12 against) to deploy a Danish C-130 transport aircraft and ground-based support group, as well as the deployment of a Danish communications group to ISAF in Kabul, Afghanistan.
The Danish Parliament adopted decision B161 on 1 June 2006 (99 votes in favour, 12 against) to deploy a 45-strong force to the ISAF mission at Kandahar airport in southern Afghanistan.

The Danish Parliament adopted decision B140 on 10 June 2008 (90 votes in favour, 16 against) to deploy a temporary helicopter detachment to the Danish military contribution to the international security force (ISAF) in Afghanistan.
On 14 March 2014, the coalition group behind Denmark’s mission in Afghanistan approved the deployment of a Danish transport helicopter contribution. This was thus an implementation of a decision that had been made as part of the Danish 2011-2012 plan for Helmand.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
On 12 May 2005 a contribution from Squadron 680 Combat Support Wing was deployed to Kabul’s International Airport (KAIA). The main specialisation of the Danish troops was logistics and IT. The troops from Squadron 680 were deployed until 15 February 2006.
When units are deployed by the Royal Danish Air Force, it is with the participation of communications specialists from 615 Combat Communication Squadron (CIS), the Royal Danish Air Force’s equivalent to the Danish Army’s DCM company (see: ISAF - Kabul). These specialists are responsible to set up and maintain military and communication links for the soldiers to call back home. The duties of the eight-strong CIS Enabling Team were to produce the best possible quarters for the Danish troops that arrived in Kabul in May 2005.

 In August 2005, two RAC-radar units and support personnel (approx. 4 people) were deployed to Kabul’s international airport from Air Control Wing Karup under the name “Danish Air Force Radar International System” (DARIS). Here, the Danish radar units would assist flight controllers in the airport’s control tower by providing radar images and air traffic information. DARIS thus made it possible to increase air traffic from 200 take-offs and landings each day in 2005 to over 400 in 2009. The Danish radar contribution therefore provided critical support for civilian and military cargo and personnel transport to and from Afghanistan.
DARIS was replaced by a US-financed radar project in November 2009.
With DARIS, the Royal Danish Air Force deployed a C-130J Hercules transport aircraft and an approx. 60-strong loading and unloading team (Air Movement and Control Element) to Kabul international airport in August 2005. Here, the Danish transport contribution would fly supplies all over Afghanistan to support the ISAF mission. The aircraft were deployed three times and recalled at the end of January 2006. On various occasions later on, Denmark deployed transport aircraft contributions in the form of C-130J aircraft and their support groups for the entire duration of ISAF, including to Kabul in 2010 and to the airfield in Kandahar in 2012.

July 2008 saw the deployment of four Fennec helicopters and support crew to Afghanistan to support Danish and British troops in the Helmand province. The helicopters were partially armoured before the mission, allowing them to fly over the dangerous Helmand province. Here, the Danish helicopters would assist ground troop patrols by acting as their eyes from above, including reconnoitring targets  and gathering intelligence. These helicopters were unarmed and operated, inter alia, as “top-cover”, supporting ground troops by reporting anything suspicious ahead on routes that were often high-risk. The helicopter detachment operated until November 2008 and flew 650 hours without being hit by the Taliban.

A 45-strong contribution from Combat Support Wing was deployed to Kandahar Air Field in 2007 as the command of the air base was transferred from the USA to NATO. The unit would be responsible for securing and monitoring fixed-wing aircraft and helicopters at the air base, as well as extending it. The unit would also service cargo aircraft arriving at Kandahar Air Field. The contribution was recalled at the end of June 2008. Another 9 people were also deployed as part of the air base’s staff. The staff contribution was recalled in August 2009. During the 2007-2008 period, multi-role dogs and their handlers were deployed from Combat Support Wing Karup to patrol the base.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The Royal Danish Air Force has contributed towards the joint effort in Afghanistan since 2002, initially through a contribution of F-16 fighters to Operation Enduring Freedom, under US command. The Royal Danish Air Force was well represented at various locations in Afghanistan from 2004 until ISAF was wound down (see also: ISAF – Royal Danish Air Force 2009-2014).
In 2014 NATO’s International Security Assistance Force was shut down when Afghan security forces assumed responsibility for security throughout Afghanistan. A new smaller-scale NATO mission was set up in its place in 2015, called Resolute Support Mission. Its purpose was to continue the training and provision of advice to the Afghan security forces and national institutions. The new mission assisted the Afghans as they fought to defeat Taliban rebels etc. but did not playd an active role in the engagements. Denmark contributed to the training of Afghan security forces and to the general mission of developing Afghanistan through NATO’s Resolute Support Mission until 2021.

At its peak, ISAF numbered over 130.000 troops from 51 NATO and partner states and was therefore one of the biggest coalitions in world history and the most extensive NATO mission to date.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
After the attack that was orchestrated by Al-Qaeda on New York on 11 September 2001, the USA launched a UN-mandated international coalition under the name Operation Enduring Freedom with a view to defeating the Al-Qaeda terror organisation and toppling the Taliban régime in Afghanistan.
Operation Enduring Freedom found quick success driving the Taliban out of the Afghan capital, and a number of Afghan clan leaders met in the German city of Bonn during the second half of 2001. Under UN supervision, the clan leaders agreed in December 2001 that a provisional government would be set up, led by Hamid Karzai, and that it would continue to govern until a permanent democratically-elected solution could be implemented.
The Bonn agreement included a section about the creation of an international security force that would train Afghanistan’s own security forces and help to rebuild public institutions.
Soon after the conference in Bonn, on 20 December 2001, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1386. This set out the framework for an international military force that would support the provisional government. The UN’s intent for this International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) was to put together a large scale force with a mandate in international law, that would be able to guarantee security in Kabul and its surrounding area while Afghan military and police forces were being built.

ISAF command would initially rotate every six months among the nations that were participating on a voluntary basis. This system turned out to be inefficient, however, so ISAF was assigned to NATO command in August 2003 after being invited by the UN and the Afghan government.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1510 on 13 October 2003, authorising an expansion of ISAF’s mandate, which meant that ISAF was now authorised to keep the peace in areas other than Kabul and its immediate vicinity.
In December 2003, NATO’s North Atlantic Council authorised the Supreme Allied Commander Europe (SACEUR) to implement an expansion to ISAF by assuming command of the Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) in Kunduz in northern Afghanistan, which had been under German command.  Command of Operation Enduring Freedom was thus transferred from the US-led military coalition to ISAF.
It was decided at the NATO summit in Istanbul on 28 June 2004 that a further four Provincial Reconstruction Teams would be established in northern Afghanistan, in Mazar-e Sharif, Meymaneh, Feyzabad and Baghlan. These PRTs were set up in October 2004, being the first of four expansions of ISAF’s area of operations.
The second expansion of ISAF’s area of operations commenced in May 2006.  Here, ISAF assumed command of four PRTs in western Afghanistan: Herat, Farah, Chaghcharan and Qala-e-Naw. ISAF’s area of responsibility thus included both North and West Afghanistan, about 50% of Afghanistan’s total surface area.
On 31 July 2006, ISAF implemented a third expansion of its area of operations, ISAF assuming command from the US-led coalition in six provinces in southern Afghanistan, including the Helmand and Kandahar provinces.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
In January 2009, five soldiers from the Royal Danish Air Force CIS Enabling Team and five soldiers from Construction Team were deployed to Afghanistan to prepare facilities for a subsequent Danish Operational Mentoring and Liaison Team (OMLT). This would be based at Camp Shorabak near Camp Bastion in the Helmand Province.  An OMLT was a team of advisers whose role was to train various Afghan units and was thus one of the capacity-building projects of the ISAF mission.
The first team arrived at Camp Shorabak at the end of January 2009. Team 1 was 12-strong, ten of whom were mentors and two were assistants. While the Royal Danish Air Force in the form of its Combat Support Wing was responsible for the OMLT contribution, this was actually a cross-service mission, the teams being composed of personnel from the entire Danish military. The mission of the Danish OMLT mentors was to support and train designated key individuals such as heads of garrison, staff commanders, logistics commanders, clinic managers and heads of maintenance.
A total of seven Royal Danish Air Force teams were deployed in an OMLT capacity up to February 2012, after which responsibility for the OMLT mission was assigned to the army. In May 2012 the mission was to advice Camp Shorabak commanders, which was being wound down by ISAF. 

Three specially-trained multi-role dogs and their handlers were deployed from Combat Support Wing Karup in 2009. The dogs were trained to track and trace a number of different types of explosives. Because the use of multi-role dogs for this purpose had produced good results, these were deployed on multiple occasions, including with Danish special forces in Task Force 7 in 2013-14.
Four members of the Royal Danish Air Force Security Force (SECFOR) were sent to Mazar-e Sharif in December 2011. Their mission was to secure the sector where local Afghans were constructing facilities for use in the forthcoming Danish Mobile Air Control Centre (MACC) radar unit. The four SECFOR soldiers were recalled in January 2012.

The mobile MACC radar unit from Air Control Wing Karup arrived at Mazar-e Sharif in February 2012.  The radar unit was comprised of an AN-TPS-77 long-range mobile radar and a smaller RAC-3D warning radar that was set up in Kunduz north-east of Mazar-e Sharif.Elements of the contribution were also deployed to Meymaneh in north-western Afghanistan. The deployment was part of the Helmand plan and involved 210 troops over the entire period, the bulk being stationed at Camp Marmal in Mazar-e Sharif. 42 Danish soldiers were stationed at Mazar-e Sharif, with three more at the German base in Kunduz, rotating every third month. The mission of the radar contribution was to monitor air traffic over north-western Afghanistan and to coordinate incoming and outward-bound flights in the region to minimise in-air accidents and generally increase air safety. The radar unit was deployed until May 2013.
In 2012 the Royal Danish Air Force deployed a 26-strong staff contribution to support operations at Afghanistan’s strategic airfields. These troops were split between Kabul’s International Airport (KAIA) and Kandahar Airfield (KAF). The six soldiers who were deployed to KAIA were part of the staff, supporting the operation of the military wing of the airport in partnership with French troops. The KAF contribution was comprised of staff for general airfield operations, Security Force (who were responsible for security) and Aerial Port Service, who were involved with base logistics support.  The contribution was recalled at the end of 2014.

In addition the Air Transport Wing many times deployed C-130J to Afghanistan in support of ISAF. They flew out of Kabul Airport and Kandahar Airfield with cargo and personel - and was essetiel in the national rotation of forces.

Three EH101 Merlin rescue and transport helicopters were deployed in July 2014 in a tactical troop transport role. They and their support personnel were deployed to the Camp Marmal base near Mazar-e Sharif in northern Afghanistan. The 76-strong team of personnel was comprised of aircrew, aircraft maintenance ground crew, logistics and other support personnel and was under the command of the German-led regional command in Mazar-e Sharif. The mission of the transport helicopter contribution was to be in a state of readiness to evacuate casualties, to rescue personnel in emergencies and, to a lesser degree, general transport duties. When ISAF was wound down in January 2015, the contribution became part of NATO’s newly-created Resolute Support Mission. The Danish transport helicopter contribution was recalled at the end of September 2015.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Parliament adopted decision B140 on 2 February 2006 (102 votes in favour, 10 against) to expand and reprioritise the Danish contribution to the international security force (ISAF) in Afghanistan. The increased contribution would involve 290 personnel and would be deployed in the Helmand and Kandahar provinces.
On 1 June 2007, the Parliament adopted proposal B161 (with 99 votes in favour and 12 votes against) to strengthen the Danish contribution to ISAF. After the augmentation to the Danish forces, the Danish contribution in Helmand would now be comprised of an independent battalion.
On 23 October 2007, Parliament approved proposal B6 (with 99 votes in favour and 8 votes opposed) to deploy a troop of tanks to the Danish military contribution in the Helmand province.
On 9 December 2008, the Parliament adopted proposal B24 (with 88 votes in favour and 16 votes against) to strengthen the Danish contribution to ISAF, focusing mainly on stabilising the Helmand province.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The first contingent of Danish troops arrived at Camp Bastion in the Helmand province on 8 April 2006, where they would be part of Task Force Helmand, under British command. Teams 1-4 were deployed to difficult and violent operations throughout the province.
The first two teams were, respectively, comprised of the First and Second Light Reconnaissance Squadrons of the Bornholm Reconnaissance Battalion, each numbering approx. 250 soldiers. In Helmand, the Danes would provide security and stability in the area so that reconstruction and development work could commence. From Team 2, Denmark also provided CIMIC officers, ARTHUR radars and a National Support Group for the Helmand mission. Other contributions were made by staff personnel, military police, munitions clearance, Jaeger Corps forces and a logistics company, including engineering and communications detachments.
CIMIC stands for “civil-military co-operation”, which aims to strengthen collaborations between the deployed forces and local civilian authorities. The task of the CIMIC projects was not to rebuild Afghanistan, but to create conditions that were conducive towards allowing this to happen, by generating good will among the population and security in the region.

ARTHUR (Artillery Hunting Radar) was an artillery beam radar that was used to register launch and impact points of incoming missile and mortar attacks. ARTHUR was initially based at Kandahar Air Field but would later be relocate to Camp Bastion in Helmand. ARTHUR has also been deployed to FOB Robinson, Price, Barakhzai, Budwan and Arty Hill. The radar was deployed from June 2006 to 11 February 2010, when it was recalled and taken out of service as part of a general phasing out of Danish Defence materials. 

Team 3’s contribution in Helmand mainly consisted of a scout squadron from the Jutland Dragoon Regiment. Team 4 would contribute a mechanised infantry company from the Danish Royal Lifeguards. With a mandate from the Danish Parliament, Team 4 would gradually be upscaled to battalion size. The Danish contingent (DANCON 4) had two rates of increase, initially involving the Scouts squadron from the Hussar Guards Regiment in August 2007, which contributed approx. 400 soldiers to Helmand. Later, in October 2007, the contribution was increased to approx. 550 men, a force that would grow to 700 soldiers over time.

In November 2007, Team 4 was the first team to be assigned a troop of tanks, in the form of three Leopard 2 A5 tanks from the Jutland Dragoon Regiment. These turned out to be highly effective against their opponents, demanding their respect because of their superior firepower and observation capabilities.

The Danish contingent from Team 5 (February 2008) was responsible for a fixed area of operations in Nahr-E Saraj. The scout squadron from Team 5 was replaced by another mechanised infantry company, using Danish Defence’s PMV M/113 G3 armoured personnel carriers. During this period, because of ISAF’s superior firepower, The Taliban would increase the intensity of asymmetrical warfare in the form of suicide bombs and improvised explosive devices.

Team 8’s mechanised infantry company would be replaced by a light reconnaissance squadron (August 2009). Team 9 (February 2010) was the first time that the new CV9035 infantry combat vehicle (ICV) would be deployed. The new ICVs were armed with 35mm auto-cannon, which meant a significant increase to the company’s firepower. The increased armour provided by the vehicle provided crews with better protection. Because the Taliban considered the ICVs to be actual tanks, they also commanded respect.

From Team 10 (August 2010), security in the Danish area of responsibility (Nahr-e Saraj and the capital, Gereshk) began to be at a level where Afghan security forces and police could take over certain duties from ISAF.  The training of local police and army forces was therefore given priority. The military security operations continued but would increasingly be performed with collaboration from Afghan Kandak battalions.

Team 12 (August 2011) was the last Danish combat group to have its own area of operations. From Team 13 (February 2012), half of the Danish troops were deployed to train Afghan security forces. After this point, the gradual withdrawal of Danish troops and the return to Denmark of materials would commence, as capacity and organisational missions began to be prioritised over combat operations. Team 17 left the province on 1 August 2014 and would thus be the final Danish ISAF contingent in Helmand.

Task Force 7, comprised of soldiers from the Jaeger Corps and Frogmen Corps was deployed to Helmand from February 2012. In addition to its special forces, Task Force 7 also included interpreters, a doctor, an engineering officer and civilian and military police, a total of approx. 50 Danish soldiers who would mentor and train a special Afghan police unit. Training would not only be provided in combat, but in staffing and administration so that the police unit would be able to operate within the boundaries of Afghanistan’s own legislation. Task Force 7 operated until February 2014.

Denmark assumed command of the field hospital in Camp Bastion, Helmand, on 20 July 2009. This was the first time that Denmark had been at the forefront of a field hospital in a war zone. 97 Danish doctors and nurses took part alongside 45 Britons and 43 Americans, treating ISAF soldiers and Afghans. The contribution was recalled in October 2009.

In 2008, the Danish Home Guard contributed a platoon of approximately 30 soldiers to the Helmand province mission. Platoons would be deployed multiple times until 2014, their main task being to assist in guard duties at the Danish camps. The main mission was at MOB Price, but periodically involved guard duties at forward bases like Armadillo and Bridzar. In 2013 the Danish Home Guard also contributed three agricultural experts to Helmand, where they would advise Afghan farmers in how to increase their agricultural yields.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Denmark’s contribution in the Helmand province between 2006 and 2014 would be its absolute largest and most concentrated contribution to the mission in Afghanistan. Helmand was already known to be a Taliban stronghold, where rebel groups had broad support among the local population. This made the province one of the most unstable and dangerous regions of the country. Already with the deployment of Team 1 there was tough fighting between Danish troops and the Taliban. This combat was intense and at a level at which Danish forces had not fought since 1864.

A new smaller-scale NATO mission was set up in its place in 2015, called Resolute Support Mission. Its purpose was to continue the training and provision of advice to the Afghan security forces and national institutions. text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
With Resolution 1386 of 20 December 2001, the UN Security Council authorised the creation of an International Security Assistance Force (ISAF), to assist the provisional Afghan government in maintaining security in the capital, Kabul, and nearby areas.
ISAF was placed under NATO command in August 2003 after requests by the UN and Afghanistan’s government.
ISAF’s initial mandate was only centred around Kabul’s security for a six month period. Over the 13 year duration of the mission, its mandate was extended and gradually expanded on various occasions to cover the whole of Afghanistan.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 11 January 2002, a unanimous Parliament adopted proposal B45 to make Danish military forces available to an international security force in Afghanistan.
The Parliament adopted decision B57 on 2 December 2003 (102 votes in favour, 9 against) to expand the Danish contribution to the ISAF international security force in Afghanistan. The expansion was at NATO’s request and involved the deployment of a Danish approximately 40-strong Deployable Communications and Information System Module (DCM). Three personnel were also deployed for the operation of Kabul International Airport, as well as a smaller team that would perform duties such as informing local populations about ISAF operations.

As part of Danish humanitarian aid support, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated DKK 8 million to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA), followed by DKK 18.2 million for the deployment to Kabul of a Danish Emergency Management Agency mobile hospital.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
In 2002 Denmark deployed forces to the Afghan capital, Kabul: a munitions clearance team, military police, communications and support personnel and a small number of staff officers. The contribution numbered about 50 personnel.
This contribution was initially assigned to the Kabul Multinational Brigade under German command. Command of this brigade was assigned to NATO in 2003.
The main duties of the first Danish contingent in Kabul (DANCON Team 1) were mine clearing (it was estimated in 2002 that approx. 11 million mines had been buried in Afghanistan as a result of 30 years of warfare). The contribution was part of a German-Dutch-Austrian-Danish battle group.
From (and including) DANCON Team 2, the Danish troops were assigned to a broader range of duties. These included advising Afghan troops through liaison officers. They also worked in the coordinating missions between ISAF forces and local police.The Danish military police unit that was assigned to the Multi-national Military Police in the Kabul Multinational Brigade, assisted in the investigation of accidents, crimes and performed patrol duties.
For periods of two months at a time, Denmark provided surgeons, anaesthetists and nurses to the field hospital at Camp Warehouse in Kabul, under German command.
The Danish Deployable Communications Module (DCM) was deployed with between 10 and 50 personnel at a time, for three month periods from 2004 until ISAF was wound down in 2014. The DCM company is part of a multi-national signals battalion within NATO’s permanent structure and was set up in 2003 (under its NATO name DCM E). The deployment to Afghanistan was the first time the DCM contribution had been deployed to set up and maintained links between NATO headquarters in Afghanistan and Europe. The DCM company was initially centred around ISAF HQ in Kabul. As ISAF operations were expanded, the military IT experts were also deployed to airfields in Kandahar and to other NATO installations in Afghanistan.
A total of nine teams were deployed to Kabul until the end of 2006. Denmark continued to be represented in the town in the form of a signals and communications unit at ISAF headquarters, a Danish staff contingent at the ISAF Joint Commands headquarters and at the NATO Training Mission, a smaller number of soldiers to operate Kabul’s international airport (deployed once airport command was reassigned from Germany to NATO in 2004) and a team whose duties included informing local populations about ISAF’s mission.

A National Support Element (NSE) was assigned to Camp Viking in Kabul. Its mission was to manage and redistribute supplies from Denmark. NSE was stationed in Kabul until 2006, after which it was transferred to Kandahar Airfield and then to Camp Bastion in Helmand. NSE moved back to Kabul in 2014.
When the Danish mission in Helmand province was completed in August 2014, Danish focus returned once again to Kabul. Here, the main role of the Danish troops was to support Afghan security forces. The force provided by Denmark numbered 60 soldiers from the army, the main component being comprised of mentor contributions to the Afghan National Officers’ School and to higher-level Afghan military training institutions. 
The army also provided staff officers, whose role was to plan, support and contribute to the development of Afghan security forces. The contribution from the First Bornholm Light Reconnaissance Squadron was also deployed to Kabul as a Movement Support Team. Lastly, a smaller intelligence unit was deployed, performing duties such as threat scenario analysis to assist the deployed troops. When ISAF was wound down in January 2015, the 2014 contribution became part of NATO’s newly-created Resolute Support Mission.

Danish Emergency Management Agency personnel and units were also deployed to Kabul. This was partly because the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) required support setting up a coordination centre in Afghanistan – and partly because hospital capacity needed to be created, as existing capacity in Afghanistan was very low. The hospital was ready to admit its first patients in Kabul on 15 August, after being set up very quickly during the summer of 2013. It was equipped as a general hospital with a surgical ward, maternity wing, medical unit, casualty department and medical centre. A total of 71,060 patients were treated over the eight months it was in service. Most patients were admitted to the medical centre with minor injuries and ordinary complaints, and for vaccination (64%). Operations were required for 9% of those injured.

The hospital deployment was financed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark and the UN Population Fund (UNFPA) and included contributions from Greater Copenhagen Emergency Services and the Danish Emergency Management Agency.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Because the Afghans were building their own capacity for the entire ISAF deployment period, the responsibility for security in Kabul and a number of other towns was assigned to Afghan security forces in 2008.  Denmark’s main focus from 2006 was thus to contribute towards establishing security in the unstable Helmand province in south western Afghanistan.

The Danish UNOCHA  support component took place in February 2002, the mobile hospital being deployed from 1 August 2002 to 31 March 2003.
In 2014 NATO’s International Security Assistance Force was shut down when Afghan security forces assumed responsibility for security throughout Afghanistan. A new smaller-scale NATO mission was set up in its place in 2015, called Resolute Support Mission. Its purpose was to continue the training and provision of advice to the Afghan security forces and national institutions. The new mission assisted the Afghans as they fought to defeat Taliban rebels etc. Denmark was contributing to the training of Afghan security forces and to the general mission of developing Afghanistan through NATO’s Resolute Support Mission.

At its peak, ISAF  numbered over 130,000 troops from 51 NATO and partner states and was therefore one of the biggest coalitions in world history and the most extensive NATO mission to date.
The hospital deployment ran from August 2002 to May 2003.

The UN’s intent for this International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) was to put together a large scale force with a mandate in international law, that would be able to guarantee security in Kabul and its surrounding area while Afghan military and police forces were being built.
ISAF command would initially rotate every six months among the nations that were participating on a voluntary basis. This system turned out to be inefficient, however, so ISAF was assigned to NATO command in August 2003 after being invited by the UN and the Afghan government.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1510 on 13 October 2003, authorising an expansion of ISAF’s mandate, which meant that ISAF was now authorised to keep the peace in areas other than Kabul and its immediate vicinity.
In December 2003, NATO’s North Atlantic Council authorised the Supreme Allied Commander Europe (SACEUR) to implement an expansion to ISAF by assuming command of the Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) in Kunduz in northern Afghanistan, which had been under German command.  Command of Operation Enduring Freedom was thus transferred from the US-led military coalition to ISAF.
It was decided at the NATO summit in Istanbul on 28 June 2004 that a further four Provincial Reconstruction Teams would be established in northern Afghanistan, in Mazar-e Sharif, Meymaneh, Feyzabad and Baghlan. These PRTs were set up in October 2004, being the first of four expansions of ISAF’s area of operations.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
After requests from the Afghan provisional government and NATO, the Parliament adopted decision B57 on 2 December 2003 (102 votes in favour, 9 against) to expand the Danish contribution to the ISAF international security force in Afghanistan. The Danish parliamentary decision allowed Danish troops to be deployed outside Kabul and its immediate vicinity.
The proposal stated that a six-strong military observer team would be part of the British Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) in the Samangan province in northern Afghanistan.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
At the end of 2003, Danish Defence deployed a smaller contribution of six soldiers to the Provincial Reconstruction Team in Mazar-e Sharif in northern Afghanistan, under British command. The contribution was comprised of a team of military observers who were deployed to the mountainous Samangan province in the town of Aybak, a 2-3 hour drive south east of Mazar-e Sharif. The teams rotated every sixth month.
As a consequence of NATO’s expanded area of responsibility, the British PMT arrived in Mazar-e Sharif together with the Danish contribution, under ISAF command. PMT Mazar-E Sharif was assigned to Swedish command in 2006.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The Danish contribution to Mazar-e Sharif was wound down in 2007. This was because Denmark planned to make a battalion-sized contribution of forces available to the mission in the Helmand province.
In 2014 NATO’s International Security Assistance Force was shut down when Afghan security forces assumed responsibility for security throughout Afghanistan.
A new smaller-scale NATO mission was set up in its place in 2015, called Resolute Support Mission. Its purpose was to continue the training and provision of advice to the Afghan security forces and national institutions. The new mission would assist the Afghans as they fought to defeat Taliban rebels etc. but would not play an active role in the engagements. 
At its peak, ISAF numbered over 130.000 troops from 51 NATO and partner states and was therefore one of the biggest coalitions in world history and the most extensive NATO mission to date.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The Danish troops patrolled in the province to support the civilian reconstruction mission.  The mission included gathering information about the local communities in the region, and mapping out where it would be necessary to set up reconstruction projects.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Four passenger planes were hijacked in US airspace on 11 September 2001. Two of them hit the two World Trade Center towers in New York – an international symbol of free trade and America. One hit the Pentagon, headquarters of the U.S. Department of Defense. The fourth plane crashed in a field in Pennsylvania when passengers had subdued the hijackers. The plane was believed to be headed for the White House or another target in the capital city of Washington, D.C. These attacks took the lives of nearly 3,000 people and shook Americans and the international community.
The attacks were masterminded from bases in Afghanistan by the international terrorist organisation Al-Qaeda led by Osama bin Laden.
US President George W. Bush in short order declared an international war on terror. The goal of this war was to defeat Al-Qaeda and similar terrorist groups and to punish states that supported them or allowed them to operate in their territories – primarily Afghanistan, where the 9/11 attacks had been planned.
These events led to the launch of the international coalition Operation Enduring Freedom Afghanistan, led by the United States. Its goal was to overthrow the Taliban regime and fight the terrorist network Al-Qaeda in Afghanistan (this effort is often referred to as the War in Afghanistan).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
On 12 September 2001, the day after the terrorist attack in New York, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1386 and later Resolution 1373. These resolutions condemned the attack on the United States and recognised the right of self defence and collective self defence against terror attacks. As the Taliban regime turned out to be reluctant to undertake the task of eradicating the terrorist networks operating within Afghanistan, the United States and the international community acquired the right to battle the threat of terror.
Operation Enduring Freedom was thus launched on the basis of Article 51 in the UN Charter, which deals with the fundamental right of nations to defend themselves against armed attacks. The operation received overwhelming international support. The EU, China, Russia, and Pakistan were among the supporters. For the first time, NATO invoked Article 5 in the North Atlantic Treaty, the so-called “Musketeer Oath”. It states that an attack on one is an attack on all.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 14 December 2001, Parliament approved proposal B37 (with 101 votes in favour and 11 votes opposed) for military participation by Denmark in the coalition led by the United States against terrorist networks in Afghanistan.
The contribution from Denmark was to include a C-130 Hercules transport plane, F-16 fighter jets, and Special Forces. In addition danish crewmembers participted on NATOs AWACS aircrafts over USA 2001-2002.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark contributed six F-16 fighter jets, along with the necessary associated support, from October 2002 to October 2003. These fighters were part of a joint Danish/Dutch/Norwegian F-16 contingent of 18 aircraft in total. The aircraft were stationed on a military air base operated by the US (unofficially named the Peter Ganci Air Base for an American fire fighter who lost his life in the terror attack in New York), situated beside the civilian Manas Airport near the capital Bishkek in northern Kyrgyzstan. In addition to the contribution of fighter jets and personnel, the air base held 1,500 personnel from Spain, South Korea, and the United States. In all 147 Danes worked here during this period.
This collaborative effort took place within the framework of the European Participating Air Forces (EPAF) that had been set up when the F-16s were purchased. The role of EPAF was to facilitate the allocation of tasks and functions across countries. On 1 April 2003, Norway withdrew its contribution, and Holland and Denmark continued to operate with a smaller number of fighter jets.
The Danish F-16s were mandated to carry out action against Taliban and Al-Qaeda forces in Afghanistan. The primary task for the Danish aircraft was to provide air support for coalition ground operations by way of armed patrols and direct use of weapons against enemy forces and cave complexes. Given that the distance between the mission area and the base in Kyrgyzstan was more than 1,000 km, the Danish aircraft needed aerial refueling several times during each mission. In total, the Danish F-16 fighter jets completed 743 sorties in 372 missions in the airspace over Afghanistan, representing approximately 4,350 hours in the air.
Denmark’s contribution of air transportation consisted of one C-130 Hercules transport plane, two air crews, one ground crew, support personnel, and an Air Movement Control Element to handle loading and unloading of the international transport planes.
The contribution was provided between February and October 2002 and consisted of approximately 75 personnel based at the Peter Ganci Air Base at Manas in Kyrgyzstan. The Danes worked with the Dutch and Norwegian contributions of C-130s.
The Danish Special Forces contribution was a unit made up of 108 personnel from all forces in the Danish Defence, but primarily from the Jaeger Corps and the Frogman Corps, organised structurally under the Jaeger Corps. This group was referred to as the Task Group Ferret/Task Force K-BAR. It received personnel support from the Army Air Corps, the Danish Defence Intelligence Service, the Logistic Regiment, and the Guard Hussar Regiment. Task Group Ferret had a mandate to participate in the full range of special operations throughout Afghanistan. The Danish Special Forces were under the operational control of US Central Command and under the tactical control of an American task force – initially Task Force K-BAR and later the Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force Afghanistan.
The operational tasks of the Danish Special Forces included Sensitive Site Exploitation (SSE), Special Reconnaissance (SR), High Value Target (HVT), and Forward Air Control (FAC). They were primarily deployed in the southern and southwestern parts of Afghanistan, often for long periods at a time under very difficult conditions as many civilians sympathised with the Taliban and Al-Qaeda. The climate presented a challenge in that members of the Danish Special Forces carried up to 60 or 70 kg (130-155 lbs) of equipment and a week’s worth of drinking water during periods when the temperature exceeded 45 degrees Celsius (113 degrees Fahrenheit).
Task Group Ferret was deployed from 9 January to 4 June 2002 without experiencing any losses.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Operation Enduring Freedom Afghanistan continued until the end of 2014 when it was transferred to a smaller American mission by the name of Operation Freedom’s Sentinel. The Danish contribution to Operation Enduring Freedom ended in 2003 when Parliament made it a priority to make a contribution from Denmark available to the parallel NATO-led International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan. The goal of Operation Enduring Freedom was to defeat the Taliban and Al-Qaeda, while ISAF on request from the Afghan government worked on providing security, rebuilding, supporting development, and providing aid to governance in Afghanistan.

missions.title: CPA & CPATT Basra & Baghdad
missions.subtitle: Police advisory and training
missions.name: CPA, Basra/Irak & CPATT, Bagdad
missions.descriptiveName: Coalition Provisional Authority og Civilian Police Assistance Training Team

text.heading: Background
text.text: When Saddam Hussein’s regime fell on 9 April 2003, the international community was faced with a number of large-scale tasks in Iraq. The main task was now to bring peace and stability to the country. Initially, it was necessary to provide the civilian population of Iraq with emergency aid, to enforce law and order, to protect cultural heritage and ensure the framework for the country’s reconstruction and the transfer process of political power.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate of the CPA police mission was issued in UN Resolution 1483 no. 1 and no. 8 (h) and (i) of 22 May 2003. It stated that the member states were encouraged to provide aid to the people of Iraq as they attempted to reform their institutions and rebuild their country, while also contributing towards bringing stability and security to Iraq. Specifically, the international community was encouraged to help rebuild Iraq’s civilian police force and to work towards legislative and legal reforms. Aid to the country would provisionally be coordinated by the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA), which was set up on 1 June 2003. Denmark was also represented in CPA.
The CPATT missions were also based on UN Resolution 1483 of 22 May 2003 no. 1 and no. 8 (h) and (i) and further defined in UN Resolution 1546 of 8 June 2004, which stressed the importance of an effective Iraqi civilian and border police force. The UN asked its member states to support Iraq in building the capacity of these institutions.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish Parliament adopted proposal B165 of 15 May 2003, with 89 votes in favour and 15 against, on the deployment of Danish military forces to the international security force in Iraq and police officers to the CPA police mission there.
The deployment of the police mission to CPA was specifically decided by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which instructed the Danish National Police Commissioner in a letter of 19 June 2003 to designate a police advisor and a police training coordinator for a posting to the Basra area.
When Danish Parliamentary proposal B 63 of 26 January 2006 was adopted with 102 votes in favour and 15 against, this authorised a continued Danish contribution to the international security force in Iraq and the deployment of Danish police advisers to the CPATT police mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Support for the CPA mission in Basra would mainly involve strengthening law enforcement, law and order and public administration at local and regional level.

The tasks of the police advisers included:
- supporting and advising the regional civilian CPA administrator and the regional administrator for the legal sector with regard to police-related management tasks and performing the duties of coordinating, administration and streamlining the work of the civilian police.
- coordinating and collaborating with local military occupying authorities about police work, advising and collaborating at a higher level with local Iraqi partners and working together with the UN and other international stakeholders and donors on police issues at regional level.
- supporting and advising about the management of police training, including working with the coordination and administration of all areas of civilian police training, preparing and implementing training programmes, as well as coordinating and collaborating on police training issues with the local military occupying authorities.

The CPATT mission in Baghdad was responsible for advising the coalition’s central coordination unit with regard to the structuring and training of a civilian Iraqi police force.
Furthermore, to monitor and advise Iraq’s foreign ministry in all aspects of building a new Iraqi police force, including legislation, duties, organisation, training and the preparation of strategic and operational goals, methods and standards in all significant areas.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Two Danish police commanders were deployed to CPA Iraq in the period 10 May - 7 June 2003 on a mission to identify areas of potential where Denmark could provide support. The first police advisers were sent to CPA in Basra on 6 August 2003. The Danish mission ended in mid-2007, after approx. 18 officers had been deployed.
The CPATT mission was launched at the beginning of 2006 and ended for the Danish contribution in September 2008. Approximately 32 officers had been deployed.
Five Danish police commanders were posted in the area during this period. The main participants in this mission came from the USA and the United Kingdom.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: An approximate total of 80 Danish police officers were deployed to the various missions in Iraq.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
From January 1993 and at Norway’s initiative, Israel and the PLO were engaged in secret negotiations that were intended to bring the armed conflict between the two parties to an end. These negotiations produced the first Oslo Accord of August 2013, which was signed by the two parties on 13 September 1993 in Washington. The Accord is also known as the Declaration of Principles and involved mutual recognition by both parties of the other respective party and laid down guidelines for a five-year transition period for the establishment of and autonomous Palestinian government for the West Bank and Gaza.
It was agreed in the Declaration of Principles that authority for a number of areas such as education and culture, health, social care, direct taxation and tourism would be transferred to the autonomous Palestinian government, which would also be responsible for maintaining law and order. As part of this accord, the Palestinians had agreed to start building a Palestinian police force.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for the Danish police contribution was found in supplement II, 3 of the Declaration of Principles, which predicted that training a Palestinian police force would require international support and presence.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 1 September 1993 the Danish Minister for Development Cooperation issued a press release, in which she stated that she intended to request a framework grant from the Danish Parliament’s Finance Committee of up to DKK 250 million towards the development of Gaza and the West Bank.
In her letter of 21 September 1993 to the Foreign Affairs Committee and the Finance Committee, the minister requested approval for a framework grant of DKK 250 million. In her application, the minister stated that she had not yet considered which projects or sectors would be the beneficiaries of the Danish aid. The application was adopted by majority in the Finance Committee on 3 November 1993.
In the police section of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark’s “National strategy for Gaza/the West Bank 1998-2000” from December 1997 it stated that Denmark had been providing bilateral support for management/leadership training to the Palestinian police and that this support would continue.
The police section of “Strategy for the Danish-Palestinian Development Partnership for 2000-2003” of August 2000 stated that the objective was to help build a professional and responsible police for for Palestine. An integral part of this mission was to promote the ability of the Palestinian police to provide its own basic management/leadership training and to help develop the capacity for advanced management/leadership training. The ultimate goal was to ensure that Palestine had the necessary expertise for the administration of a future police training school that would be set up in partnership with the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Germany.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The overall purpose of the Danish police mission was to help to build a professional and responsible Palestinian police force that would live up to what is needed from and expected of a civilian police force in a democratic society.

Danish police officers would be particularly responsible for training the Palestinian police in management and leadership, including:
- helping to encourage and consolidate the ability of Palestinian police to complete basic management training and expand their capacity for advanced management training and
- assuring that the Palestinians had the expertise they would require for the administration of a future police training school

Other countries, including Norway and Sweden ran and implemented courses in more basic police competences for non-ranked Palestinian police officers.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The Danish police mission commenced in May 1994 and ended in 2005. EUPOL COPPS was established on 1 January 2006. This mission also saw the participation of Danish police officers.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish Police have posted approximately 60 police officers to this mission, a few of whom were deployed via the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The postings varied greatly in their durations. Some of the personnel were deployed on outplacements of a year, with extensions. The vast majority were posted for shorter periods, their task being to provide training on courses.
A senior Danish police officer was posted from 4 January 2010 to 3 January 2011, serving at the office of the United States Security Coordinator in Palestine.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Eastern Africa Standby Force is part of and was set up by African Union. African Union (AU) is an African organisation for police partnerships what was set up in July 2002 in Durban, South Africa, to replace the Organisation for African Unity (OAU). AU’s role model is the European Union. AU’s purpose is to advance the cause of democracy and to support political integration and economic development in the African countries. AU should also act as a negotiating agent during crises on the continent and has also sent peacekeeping forces to crisis areas in Africa.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: EASF received legitimate legal status in the accord on the creation of the The Eastern Afrika Standby Force (EASF), that was adopted and signed on 26 June 2014. The accord was adopted and signed by a number of countries from the East African region (Burundi, Comoros, Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, the Seychelles, Somalia, Sudan and Uganda), all who were members of the African Union. EASF was originally adopted in the Memorandum of Understanding on Cooperation in the Area of Peace and Security Between the African Union, the Regional Economic Communities and the Coordinating Mechanism of the Regional Standby Brigades of Eastern Africa and Northern Africa in April 2005, amended in January 2011.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
In December 2013, the Government with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Defence recommended the posting of a police advisor to EASF headquarters in Nairobi. This decision is based on legal document 27 from the Foreign Affairs Committee on Peace and Stabilisation Contingencies of 11 December 2013, in which there is an undertaking to fund projects such as the posting of experts to the Horn of Africa. Item 2.1 of the 2014 results report for the Joint Policy Steering Group (the Ministry of the State, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs , the Danish Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Justice) states that a police adviser was posted to EASF.
From December 2015 the police adviser was posted via a bilateral agreement between EASF and the Danish Government, according to an agreement between EASF and the Danish National Police that was signed on 8 December 2015.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The police component within EASF was described in further detail in section 3.13 on page 21 of a document produced by the African Union at a meeting in Addis Ababa on15 -16 May 2003 called “Policy Framework for the Establishment of the African Standby Force and the Military Staff Committee”.
Relative to this, a number of individual police officers would be trained from the member states. Two company-size police units would also be formed that would be ready for deployment in the East African area.
The police adviser’s mission was to build capacity through advice and training in leadership/management, democratic principles of legality and human rights.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish police adviser was posted to the mission from 23 April 2014 until the beginning of 2018.

missions.title: ECOMSA South Africa
missions.subtitle: EU in South Africa
missions.name: ECOMSA Sydafrika
missions.descriptiveName: European Community Observer Mission in South Africa

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The colonial history of South Africa resembles in many ways that of the rest of Africa, but the large white population group and the discovery of diamonds and gold contributed greatly to how the country would develop in a different way, with greater industrialisation than in any other country in Africa. The black population was suppressed, both politically and economically. The white nationalist Reunited National Party came to power in 1948 and introduced a strict policy of racial discrimination that it called apartheid.
1960 saw the prohibition of black political organisations such as the African National Congress (ANC) by the white administration, after which the struggle against the régime become more violent. Because of its policy of apartheid, South Africa became increasingly isolated from the international community, which led to negotiations between the white régime and the ANC in 1989.
Leader of the ANC Nelson Mandela, who had been in prison since 1962, was released in 1990 and apartheid was officially abolished the same year. During the first democratic elections in 1994, the ANC won control of parliament and Nelson Mandela became president.
The UN adopted Resolution no. 772 of 17 August 1992 and deployed UN observers to South Africa, inviting other international organisations, including the EU, to do the same.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The EU mandate was based on UN Resolution 772 and was decided by the EU after a trojka of EU foreign ministers had visited South Africa during September 1992. The foreign ministers had offered the South African government to send a 15-strong team of observers, comprised of police officers, lawyers and economists.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish Government’s decision was on the basis of the EU decision and in compliance with the EU’s request to make Danish police observers available.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The observers’ mission was to:
- observe areas where there was violence, dangerous armaments and the role of the security forces and other armed groups, police investigations and the conduct of the prosecutions authority and political parties;
- to strengthen efforts as set out in the National Peace Accord, which was set up to bring to an end the public violence and intimidation, and to reinforce future capacity for building peace and
- perform intensive monitoring of the South African police

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was set up in October/November 1992 and was considered completed on 15 May 1994.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The mission saw participation from Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom. Six Danish police officers were posted to ECOMSA during this period. An approximate total of 15 Danish police officers were deployed to the various missions in South Africa.
