missions.title: AMIS EU Darfur
missions.subtitle: Support in Darfur
missions.name: AMIS EU Darfur
missions.descriptiveName: EU Support to the African Union Mission in Sudan

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Darfur is a region about the size of Spain in Western Sudan. At the end of the 19th century, Darfur was an independent state. The region was occupied in 1916 by British and Egyptian forces and became part of Sudan. When Sudan declared independence in 1956, Darfur continued as part of Sudan.
The conflict in Sudan has been described as a religious conflict between Christian farmers and Muslim nomads. A large proportion of Darfur's population is Christian, but the region’s population is predominantly Muslim. Others had described the conflict as being about land rights, resources and oil. The conflict has mainly been between Sudan's central government and rebels who want greater independence. The war intensified slowly in the early 2000s. Various ethnic groups in Darfur thought they were being discriminated against by the Arabic régime in Khartoum. In 2003 the various ethnic groups formed an armed opposition called Darfur Liberation Front (DFL). DFL’s objective was to avenge what they considered to be military attacks on their villages.
DFL soon changed its name to the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) which initially had a lot of momentum. In April 2003 SLM occupied Al Fashir, the capital of Northern Darfur. Many government troops were killed, and large quantities of the army’s military hardware was destroyed.
The régime in Khartoum was already engaged in a war against rebel movements in South Sudan and recruited the paramilitary Janjaweed militia from Arabic-speaking herders and nomadic tribes.  The militia attacked towns and villages populated by SLM sympathisers. Thousands of people from the non-Arab population were killed during the spring of 2004 and over a million people fled Darfur. They lacked food, water and provisions and many people died as they tried to reach refugee camps in Chad. This was a de facto humanitarian disaster. Initiatives were launched by the international organisations and the USA, among others, set things in motion to negotiate peace and ceasefires, but the fighting continued.

In 2004 the African Union (AU) was mandated by UN Resolution 1564 of 18 September 2004 to move a peacekeeping military force (African Union Mission in Sudan – AMIS I and II) into Darfur. By the end of 2005, this force was 7,000 strong and operated until 31 December 2007, when it was replaced by a UN peacekeeping force (UNAMID).
The European Union decided to support AMIS, deploying a mission of civilian, military and police personnel who would advise, support and train AU forces.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: In Council Joint Action 2005/557CFSP of 18 July 2005, the EU decided to initiate and mandate a civilian and military support mission to the African Union mission in the Darfur region of Sudan.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 30 June 2005, based on the EU decision, General Secretary of the European Council Javier Solana asked Denmark for personnel who would be at the disposal of the police mission. After presenting the request to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish Government agreed.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission was charged with ensuring fast and effective support to augment AMIS. The mission would also respect and support the AU-led contribution. The EU mission would provide particular support for the AU and its political, military and police initiatives towards bringing resolution to the crisis in Darfur.

The EU’s police mission to the civilian police group (CIVPOL) in AMIS would notably be comprised of:
- support to AMIS police command by providing experienced senior police officers to CIVPO as advisers at all levels;
- support and training of CIVPOL personnel through “in mission” training and
- support towards the development of a police unit that would be attached to the AU secretariat.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched on 18 July 2005 in accordance with decision 2005/557/CFSP and was brought to an end by Council Joint Action 2007/887/CFSP of 20 December 2007, effective from 1 January 2008.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: A total of eight Danish police officers were deployed to this mission.

missions.title: EUAM Iraq
missions.subtitle: Police reform in Iraq
missions.name: EUAM Irak
missions.descriptiveName: EU Advisory Mission in support of Security Sector Reform in Iraq

text.heading: Background
text.text: The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) terror organisation controlled large areas of central and north-western Iraq and central and eastern Syria, representing a serious threat to the security of populations throughout the Middle East and North Africa. Because of ISIL’s brutal attacks on civilian populations in the Middle East and terrorist attacks on selected targets in the West, the organisation was a serious threat. It was agreed within the coalition that further military and civilian measures were required in the war against ISIL.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: With Council Decision (CFSP) 2017/1869 of 16 October 2017, the EU decided to set up The European Union Advisory mission in support of Security Sector Reform in Iraq (EUAM Iraq).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Parliamentary decision B108 was adopted by the Danish Parliament on 19 April 2016 with 90 votes in favour and 19 against. With this decision, the Danish Parliament had decided to strengthen the Danish contribution to the war against ISIL with F-16 fighter jets, troops from the Danish Special Forces and a C-130J transport aircraft. The decision also authorised the deployment of police advisers to strengthen the Iraqi police, based on a request from the EU.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The overall objectives of the police mission were to:
- provide the Iraqi authorities with advice and expertise at strategic level, assisting in the implementation of an Iraqi National Security Strategy;
- analyse, evaluate and identify opportunities for potential further EU involvement to support a long term Security Sector Reform and
- to assist the EU delegation in Iraq in the coordination of support from the Union and its member states towards a Security Security Reform.

The underlying tasks can be described as:
- supporting Iraq's National Counter-Terrorism Committee in its implementation of the National Counter-Terrorism Strategy;
- supporting the Iraqi Ministry of the Interior in its planning of department reforms, including to the Iraqi police as part of the national security strategy;
- contributing to the development of a national strategy against organised crime and planning activities to support the civilian security sector, including border security and
- identifying (in partnership with international donors) projects where the EU member states or institutions could provide short-term assistance and to identify medium and long-term requirements and opportunities for future involvement in the area.

The mission would also ensure that human rights and gender policy were incorporated into these tasks, while also ensuring that they corresponded to international standards in these areas.
The mission was also charged with ensuring that the fight against organised crime also included combating illegal migration, narcotics and arms trafficking, cyber crime and the smuggling and destruction of objects with cultural heritage.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched on 16 October 2017, the participants arriving in Baghdad on 17 November 2017. The mandate expired on 17 October 2018 but has been extended until 2024.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Two senior Danish police officers were deployed to the mission in mid-2018, one serving as Deputy Head of Mission/Chief of Staff. The mission as a whole is comprised of 36 experts from the EU, operating from a headquarters in Baghdad. And Danish police officers are still there.

missions.title: EUAM Ukraine
missions.subtitle: Reforming the security sector
missions.name: EUAM Ukraine
missions.descriptiveName: EU Advisory Mission for Civilian Security Sector Reform Ukraine

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Ukraine has had a troubled history. Prior to World War I, the country was divided between Russia and the Habsburg Monarchy. After World War I ended, the country was occupied on various occasions by the Red Army, becoming part of the Soviet Union in 1920 and badly affected by war, famine and ethnic cleansing. World War II also inflicted immense suffering and loss of life. Upon the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ukraine declared independence in 1991, but it was unprepared for the structural implications. Repeatedly, political crises arose, and priority was given to the relationship with Russia or with the West depending on who was in power at any given time. Ukraine became a member of the European Council in 1995, but any development in the direction of democracy was hampered by a lack of supporting legislation and by frequent political crises.
The start of the new century saw the organisation of mass demonstrations against the then president, which led to an election being called in 2004. Viktor Yanukovych won the election by a slim margin in a runoff against his opponent Viktor Yushchenko. However, it was clear that this outcome had been achieved by electoral fraud. The opposition took to the streets in what became known as the Orange Revolution. As a result, the Supreme Court ordered a second runoff, which Yushchenko won by a clear majority.  Yushchenko steered the country toward the West and expressed an ambition that it should become a member of NATO and the EU. The relationship with Russia was fraught with tension. The population was not ready for entry into NATO and NATO had no particular desire for it to join, but NATO did indicate that Ukraine might at some future time become a member. At a summit between the EU and Ukraine in 2008, Ukraine was promised an association agreement but not EU membership proper.

Ukraine and Russia continued to have a difficult relationship, partly due to disagreements over the Sevastopol facilities for the Russian Black Sea Fleet. Russia pointed out that Ukraine would experience serious consequences should it become a member of NATO. In 2010, the Ukraine government decided not to seek membership in NATO. In 2012, Viktor Yanukovych decided not to enter into an association agreement that had almost been completed with the EU. That decision triggered extensive street protests, and the situation deteriorated in February 2004 with armed skirmishes and widespread unrest. The so-called Maidan II (named after a square in Kiev) revolution had erupted. A peace accord was negotiated with the help of the EU, but the protests continued, and President Viktor Yanukovych fled to Russia. An election was called. The opposition appeared to be the likely winner. Russia reacted quickly by annexing Crimea. In eastern Ukraine, fighting broke out between government forces and pro-Russian militias.
Petro Poroshenko won the election. He was inclined to collaborate with the West and to enter into a peace accord.
This was the situation in which the EU decided to offer an Advisory Mission to Ukraine.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate for European Union Advisory Mission for Civilian Security Sector Reform Ukraine was adopted in Council Decision 2014/486/CFSP of 22 July 2014. It was also decided that the mission would assist Ukraine in its civil security reforms, including the police and penal code protection.
It was decided in Council Decisions 2014/800/CFSP of 17 November 2014 it was decided to launch the mission from 1 December 2014, with a two year mandate.
Ukraine and the EU concluded an agreement on 17 November 2014 to deploy the European Union Advisory Mission for Civilian Security Sector Reform Ukraine (EUAM Ukraine).
The Civilian Security Sector is defined as meaning the following authorities: Ministry of Internal Affairs, National Police, National Anti-Corruption Bureau, Security Service of Ukraine, State Border Guard Service, General Prosecutor`s Office, local courts etc.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: A Government decision that was based on EU decisions and requests after it had been put to the Foreign Policy Committee.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The non-executive civilian mission would be to assist the commitment from Ukraine towards reforming the civilian security sector through mentor schemes and advising relevant Ukrainian authorities in the drafting of a new security strategy. To subsequently assist in the implementation of extensive, cohesive and relevant initiatives, including:
- creating a conceptual framework for the planning and implementation of reforms to produce sustainable security services that are able to administrate the penal code in a manner that contributes to augmenting their legality and boosting public confidence, while fully respecting human rights in a manner that was compatible with the constitutional reforms process,
- reorganising and reconstructing the security sector in a manner that allowed the authorities to regain control over the security sector and
- within the assigned mandate, the mission would assist in the planning of an extensive reform of the civilian security sector, supporting the speedy preparation and implementation of the reform’s measures.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched on 1 December 2014. The mission is ongoing. The mission’s headquarters was in Kiev and with offices in Liviv, Karkov and Odessa.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish police is participating in the mission and, in mid-2023, four Danish officers were deployed.
A total of 132 international observers has been deployed, from 22 EU countries, as well as Canada, Norway and Switzerland.

Due to Russia's attack on Ukraine all personnel in the mission was withdrawn and it will remain so until there is an overview in Ukraine and its future

missions.title: EUAVSEC South Sudan
missions.subtitle: Juba International Airport
missions.name: EUAVSEC Sydsudan
missions.descriptiveName: EU Aviation Security Mission in South Sudan

text.heading: Background
text.text: After decades of civil war, South Sudan declared independence on 9 July 2011. On 19 July the same year, the South Sudanese Minister of Transport requested aid from the EU to build and reinforce security at Juba International Airport.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The EU adopted its mandate for South Sudan European Union Aviation Security Mission in South Sudan (EUAVSEC) in decision 2012/312/CFSP of 18 June 2012.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Danish Governmental decision based on the EU mandate to assign personnel to the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission was charged with providing support for the construction of a sustainable and efficiently functioning Juba International Airport, and to attain a level of security under local ownership that would be compatible with international standards.  In particular, service would be offered to increase the security of air traffic and at border controls and aircraft security personnel with democratic supervision and in accordance with international human rights standards.
Specifically, the mission would assist and advise the government and other relevant South Sudanese authorities in setting up a security organisation for the country’s ministry of transport and Juba International Airport, including support with the development of programmes on behalf of the civil air traffic authority in South Sudan.
For Juba Airport in particular, tasks involved the preparation of security programmes and standard operational procedures for the airport, developing and improving the professional standards of airport personnel through training, mentoring and monitoring to allow them to operate according to Civil Aviation Authority standards and procedures and, ultimately, to develop focus on security with regard to commercial and private units that had operations in the airport.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was initiated on 18 June 2012 and ended on 17 January 2014.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: A Danish police commander was Head of Mission throughout the entire period. Another two Danish police officers were deployed to the mission. A Danish political advisor and two Danish airport security advisors were also deployed.

missions.title: EUBAM Rafah
missions.subtitle: At the borders of Gaza
missions.name: EUBAM Rafah
missions.descriptiveName: EU Border Assistance Mission at Rafah Crossing Point

text.heading: Background
text.text:
In 1906 a treaty was signed between the Ottoman Empire and Great Britain led to a border between Ottoman-controlled Palestine and British-controlled Egypt. The border extended from Taba to Rafah. Gaza was under Egyptian occupation from 1948, after which time the border ceased to exist. During the Six Days War in 1967, Israel conquered the entire Sinai Peninsula and the Gaza Strip, the border became irrelevant.
Israel and Egypt signed a peace treaty in 1979, in which the Sinai Peninsula was returned to Egypt and, after Israel withdrew from the Sinai in 1982, a buffer zone of 100 metres was set up between Gaza and Egypt. Border control was now a joint Israeli-Egyptian project. When the Fatah-dominated Palestinian National Authority was formed in 1994, it was granted control of the Gaza side of the border, together with Israeli authorities.
Israel withdrew from Gaza on 7 September 2005 and the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Sinai was closed as a result.
An agreement to reopen the border, known as the Agreement on Movement and Access (AMA), was concluded between Palestine and Israel on 15 November 2005. The agreement was facilitated by the USA and the EU. Conditions for reopening the border were set out in the “Agreed Principles for Rafah Crossing” appendix to the agreement and entailed monitoring of the border by the EU.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: Council Joint Action 2005/889/CFSP of 12 December 2005 mandated the European Union Border Assistance Mission for the Rafah Crossing Point (EU BAM Rafah).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: In November 2005, the EU asked Denmark to assign personnel to the mission. The Danish Government agreed to this request.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
EU BAM’s objective as a non-involved authority was to maintain a presence at the Rafah border crossing and to provide support in opening the border. It was also charged with providing support towards building confidence between the Israeli government and the Palestinian authorities.

EU BAM would achieve this by:
- monitoring, verifying and evaluating the efforts of the Palestinian authorities, in particular regard to the agreements that had been concluded,
- using a mentoring process to produce Palestinian capacities for the management of all aspects related to the border and
- contributing to contacts between Palestinian, Israeli and Egyptian authorities with regard to border crossing management issues.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The mission was launched on 25 November 2005, with a 12-month mandate. The mandate was extended on an ongoing basis. When Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip, EUBAM Rafah was suspended and personnel withdrawn from the mission. It was on active service in Rafah for 19 months. The mission remains in a state of readiness to be redeployed in Rafah. The mandate has been continuously extended, most recently on 30 June 2018.
EU BAM has remained in ongoing contact with the Palestinian authorities and, as recently as 2015, completed a year-long training programme for Palestinian border control authorities.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The Danish National Police deployed a vice police inspector and a vice police commissioner on 22 November 2005. About 10 Danish police officers were deployed to the mission.

missions.title: EUCAP, AMISOM, UNODC Somalia
missions.subtitle: Police instructors etc. in Somalia
missions.name: EUCAP, AMISOM, UNODC Somalia
missions.descriptiveName: EU Capacity Building Mission in Somalia & AU Mission in Somalia

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The northern and eastern coastal areas of Somalia may be the place that ancient Egyptian texts refer to as “Punt”. From approx. 600AD to 1000AD, trading posts were set up in the coastal towns, which where dominated by Islamic sultans. Their main exports were slaves and ostrich feathers. Somalia’s original population was mainly comprised of camel nomads, who would eventually convert to Islam. During the 19th Century, the country was split between Ethiopia which received the central Ogaden area, Great Britain which received British Somaliland in the North, Italy which received Italian Somaliland in the South and France which received French Somaliland (present-day Djibouti). During the Second World War, British Somaliland was occupied by Italian troops in 1940. By 1941-1942, the entire Somalian area had been conquered by the British, with the exception of Djibouti. Ethiopia’s land was returned at the end of the war. Italy was allowed to administrate the former Italian Somaliland for ten years, according to a UN mandate. British and Italian Somaliland were united and became independent in 1959. Meanwhile, there were many different political viewpoints in the new country and unrest became apparent, not least because of the clan-based factions. The president was murdered in 1969 and the military seized power in a coup d’état. The coup was led by Muhammad Siyaad Barre, who introduced a socialist single-party régime.  From1970, Somalia allied with the Soviet Union, until the Soviet Union sided with Ethiopia in the latter’s conflict with Somalia and the Ogaden region.
Barre was a brutal leader who suppressed large parts of the Somali population. The Somali military and secret police were responsible for extensive human rights violations. Several rebel factions were formed and various clans revolted. Barre was toppled from power and a fragile provisional government was formed. The capital city was divided between two different clans and civil war broke out in southern and central regions of Somalia. A drought hit the country in 1991 and it is estimated that approx. 350,000 Somalians perished in 1991 and 1992. The lack of security and conflicts between the clan militias hindered extensive emergency aid, with the UN withdrawing from the country at one point.
Unrest and conflict continued in Somalia and in 2000 the country had no central government. One rebel faction had assumed control of the bulk of north-western Somalia and declared the region independent as the Republic of Somaliland. This area has been peaceful since 1997. Other rebel factions took control of the north-western area, naming it the Somali Republic of Puntland. This part of the country has also been relatively peaceful. Puntland wants to see the reunification of Somalia, however. Central and southern regions of Somalia fell under the control of Islamic militias, after a long period of fighting. This led to intervention in the conflict by Ethiopia. Alongside Somalia’s provisional government, Ethiopian military forces were able to drive the Islamists out of the larger towns and the government was able to occupy the capital of Mogadishu. The Islamists were not defeated, however, and al-Shahib (a movement resembling the Taleban and al-Qaeda) took control of most of southern Somalia in 2008. A new president was sworn into office in 2009 and, with the support of the African Union Peacekeeping Force AMISOM, the Islamists were gradually pushed back. A new parliament was sworn in in 2012. Free nationwide elections that same year also saw the election of a new president.
Unrest and insecurity continue to be a problem in Somalia. Criminality was also flourishing.

Since the mid-90s, pirates operating from Somalia had become a serious problem in large areas of the Indian Ocean and the Red Sea. Piracy had developed into a very lucrative activity. International naval forces were deployed to combat piracy. Denmark was also represented in this deployment.
The UN has maintained a presence in Somalia since 1991 in the form of various peacekeeping missions, which have had no major impact on peace in the region. The UN has also deployed emergency and aid programmes. These contributions are still ongoing.
The EU has assisted towards building a regional naval capacity since 2012.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In Joint Council Decision 2012/389 of 16 July 2012, the EU mandated the European Union Mission on Regional Capacity Building in the Horn and Africa (EUCAP NESTOR). This decision mandated an EU contribution that would be geographically focused in Djibouti, Kenya, the Seychelles and Somalia.
The mission was renamed EUCAP Somalia in decision 2016/2240 CFSP. This mission would only be responsible for building capacity in Somalia.
On 19 January 2007 the Peace and Security Council of the African Union decided in Addis Ababa that it would set up an African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM). This decision stated that the contribution would also involve a police training team. It was agreed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark and the Danish Ministry of Defence in the 2010-2014 Defence Agreement that a coordinated Peace and Stability contribution would be established to support the work of the African Union towards brining stability to Somalia. The contribution has been extended on an ongoing basis and is still active.
The EU supported AMISOM with regard to a First Action Plan 2008-1010 for the Implementation of the Africa-EU Strategic Partnership, that was signed in Accra on 31 October 2007. This support included the deployment of police advisers from the police training sector in EU member states.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: After presenting a request from the EU for police personnel and military instructors for this mission to the Danish Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish Government decided to agree to the request.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
In accordance with Council decision 2240, EUCAP would assist Somalia towards increasing its maritime security capacity to enable Somalia to enforce maritime law more effectively.

Notably, the mission would:
- increase Somalia’s civil maritime law enforcement capacity towards effective maritime administration of its coastlines, inland and territorial waters and exclusive economic zones,
- specifically strengthen Somalia’s capacity with regard to performing and enforcing fishing inspections, ensuring search and rescue operations at sea, combating smuggling and piracy and monitoring the coastal zone from land and by water, and
- support the Somali authorities in their development of the necessary legislation and the establishment of judicial authorities by providing mentor schemes, advice and training towards Somalia’s maritime law enforcement.

The main partners of the police mission were and are: Somali Police Force Maritime Police Unit (SPF MPU) in Mogadishu, Somaliland Coast Guard and Bosasso Port Police, as well as the Ministries of Interior, Justice and Fisheries, the offices of the Attorneys General, police prosecutors and judges. The mission’s headquarters are in Mogadishu, with offices in Hargeisa (Somaliland) and Garowe (Puntland). The administrative office is in Nairobi, Kenya.
AMISOM's tasks were diverse, but generally involved training and assessment, the preparation of training materials and training plans for all AMISOM Police Components personnel and their leadership, all being related to public order and security, reforming the security sector and combating organised crime etc.

The duties of the military group that was deployed by Danish Defence and the Danish Home Guard were generally focused towards the training of instructors, officers and African forces prior to their deployment. Training has been provided in close collaboration with British instructors, primarily at the Kenyan School of Infantry, but also with activities in Uganda.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
EUCAP was launched in July 2012. The mandate was extended to the end of December 2022.
AMISOM was launched on 19 January 2007. The mission is ongoing.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark has provided EUCAP with police instructors since 2017, their task being to advise, train and mentor Somali police officers. Personnel have been deployed from 13 EU member states. The mission’s authorisation involves 125 international and 40 local employees.
The first Danish senior police officer was posted to AMISOM on 13 May 2009. The last Danish participant in the police mission was withdrawn in July 2012. A total of five Danish senior police officers were deployed. The police advisers were normally stationed in Addis Ababa in Ethiopia.
The full responsibility for this mission was assumed by the Danish Home Guard, for 2019-2020 on behalf of the military AMISOM component, after having contributed to the Danish Defence contribution for two years.

missions.title: EUJUST LEX Iraq
missions.subtitle: In Iraq with the EU
missions.name: EUJUST LEX Irak
missions.descriptiveName: EU Integrated Rule of Law Mission for Iraq

text.heading: Background
text.text: In Resolution 1483 of May 2003, the UN Security Council recognised the coalition that had fought in Iraq as an occupying force under International Law, at the same time setting up a Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) to govern Iraq during the period of transition before it would be possible to hold elections. The many sanctions that had been imposed against Iraq since 1990 were repealed and the UN required that the coalition would only use Iraqi oil revenue for the benefit of the Iraqi people.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The EU´s involvement was largely on the basis of Security Council Resolution 1483 of 22 May 2003 - and the mandate for the police EU Integrated Rule of Law Mission for Iraq (EUJUST LEX-Iraq) was partly decided at the EU´s Council of Ministers on 21 February 2005 and partly in Council Joint Action 2005/190/CFSP of 7 March 2005.
The EU had already (in decision 2004/909/CFSP of 26 November 2004) decided to send an expert team to Iraq to set up an integrated mission to deal with issues related to policing, the rule of law and civil administration. This mission would be set in motion after the January 2005 elections in Iraq.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish Parliament accepted that Denmark would participate in this mission when it adopted proposal B89 of 8 June 2005.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The purpose of the mission was to improve cohesion between judges, police personnel and prison administrators, respecting the principles of state legality and basic human rights. The general task was therefore to improve the Iraqi penal system by training 770 senior officials from the police, courts and prisons. Because of the security situation, training would initially take place in EU member states or in a country in the nearby region.

The nature of the task required that the mission:
- contributed to remedying serious deficiencies in the Iraqi penal system by training senior and middle managers in administrative leadership and criminal investigation. Training would be focused on improving capacity, coordination and cohesion between the various components of the Iraqi penal system,
- promoted collaboration between the various stakeholders that comprised the Iraqi penal system. Furthermore, while observing the principles of the rule of law and human rights, to strengthen administrative capacity of senior police officials, the judiciary and prison services, improving criminal investigations and
- developing an effective strategic and technical partnership with the Iraqis as part of the planning the intended training.

Training activities would take place in EU countries or in the region. EUJUST LEX would also set up a liaison office in Baghdad.
Because of the security situation in Iraq, the mission was located in Brussels and training activities went on in Europe. It was not until 2009 that the mission’s activities relocated in part to Iraq. The mission headquarters relocated to Baghdad in 2011, with offices in Erbil and Basra.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission became operational on 1 July 2005. Its initial mandate expired on 31 December 2007 but this was extended on an ongoing basis. The mission was brought to a close at the end of December 2013.  EU member states and Norway had taken part in the mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Seven Danish police officers have participated in the mission from its commencement until it ended. Approximately 80 Danish police officers have been deployed to the various missions in Iraq, including working as instructors in third countries and in Brussels.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When the Soviet Union fell apart it led to unrest in the Caucasus, with Georgia’s seceding from the Soviet Union in April 1991. Two other regions: South Ossetia and Abkhazia had already seen massive unrest and armed conflict. Both these regions wanted greater independence from Georgia.
Within its own borders, Georgia was also having to deal with major political problems, with numerous elections, corruption and a tense relationship with Russia because it wanted to align with the West, to join NATO and collaborate closely with the EU.
Georgia’s relationship with Russia worsened during the summer of 2008 because of the to seperatist republics, Abkhazia and South Ossetia. On 8 August 2008, Georgia initiated an invasion of South Ossetia. The Russian response came quickly, and Russian armed forces moved into South Ossetia. After a few days of fighting, Georgia withdrew from the area. Russia recognised South Ossetia and Abkhazia as independent republics at the end of August 2008.
With intervention from the EU, The Six-point Agreement was signed by Russia and Georgia on 12 August 2008. Hostilities came to an end and there was a basis for international aid and monitoring.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: With Council Joint Action 2008/736/CFSP of 15 September 2008, the EU decided to set up a civilian monitoring mission in Georgia, called European Union Monitoring Mission in Georgia (EUMM).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish Government’s decision was on the basis of the EU decision and in compliance with the EU’s request to assign personnel to the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
EUMM Georgia would be responsible for civilian monitoring of the parties’ actions and full compliance with The Six-point Agreement. It would also monitor subsequent measures that were set in motion by the UN and OSCE, as well as other EU activities towards stabilisation, normalisation and establishing a relationship of confidence between the parties. The mission would also support European policy towards a long-lasting political solution in Georgia.
Most notably, the objectives were:
- to contribute towards long-term stability throughout Georgia and the surrounding region,
- a short-term stabilisation of the situation, with a reduced risk that hostilities would resume c.f. The Six Point Agreement and subsequent measures.

The EUMM mission would undertake the following missions:
- monitoring, analysis and reporting on the situation as part of the stabilisation process, including troop withdrawals, free movement and drawing attention to factions that wanted to sabotage the various initiatives, as well as human rights violations and humanitarian international law,
- monitoring, analysis and reporting of the progress of the normalisation process, with regards to the civil administration. This was with particular focus on law and order, law enforcement structures and the necessary public order. The mission would also monitor the security of transport links, energy infrastructure and energy operators, as well as the political and security aspects related to people who had been driven away from their homes and the return of refugees to their homes,
- measures that would establish confidence by contributing towards a reduction in tension, through partnerships, promoting contact between the parties and other initiatives that would create a sense of confidence and
- a contribution towards a qualification of the policy on Europe and future EU commitments.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
EUMM was launched on 1 October 2008 with a one year mandate. The mandate has subsequently been extended several times. The mission is ongoing.
The mission’s headquarters were in Tbilisi, with regional offices in Gori, Mtskheta and Zugdidi.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The mission has been led by Danish diplomat Erik Høeg since December 2017. Danish police participated has involved the deployment of 50 personnel to the mission. From Danish police 15 officers were deployed in 2023. Officers from Danish Defence was also deployed.
The mission is comprised of a total of approx. 200 observers. All EU member states have assigned personnel to the mission.

missions.title: EUPAT Macedonia
missions.subtitle: Advisory team to the FYROM
missions.name: EUPAT Makedonien
missions.descriptiveName: EU Police Advisory Team in the FYR of Macedonia

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Within the context of the breakup of Yugoslavia, a referendum was held on 8 September 1991 which led to Macedonia declaring its autonomy and independence. The Macedonian parliament adopted a constitution for the country on 17 November 1991. After a relatively peaceful period, 2001 saw armed engagements between Macedonian armed forces and police on one side and Albanian paramilitary units on the other, as the Albanians wanted to become part of Albania.
A roadmap was agreed on 13 August 2001 by the involved parties, the EU and USA. This was named the Ohrid Framework Agreement after the town where the agreement was concluded. The agreement would assure Macedonian democracy for the future, as well as peaceful development that would respect ethnic minorities and Macedonian society. For more information read (MACCOM/UNPROFOR III).

An EU-led military mission, Operation Concordia, was deployed in 2001 to ensue that the roadmap was implemented. The military mission had completed its mission in December 2003 and was followed by the launch of the EUPOL Proxima police mission on the same date. This ended in December 2005.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: Council Joint Action 2005/826/FUSP of 24 November 2005 approved the mandate for a European Union Police Advisory Team in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (EUPAT). The mission would take over duties from EUPOL Proxima from 15 December 2005, with headquarters in Skopje.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Government decision and notification of the Foreign Policy Committee, based on the EU decision and the EU’s request for personnel for the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
In compliance with the Ohrid agreement and in partnership with the relevant authorities, the mission would provide further support for the development of an effective and professional police task force, based on European policing standards. The EU police experts would, in collaboration with the authorities of the host country, monitor and instruct its police. Instruction would particularly concern priority areas such as border police, public law and order and responsible conduct, as well as combating corruption and organised crime. EUPAT guidance would be particularly aimed at middle and senior managers.

With view to this, EUPAT would particularly emphasise:

  • overall implementation of the police reform on the streets,
  • collaboration between the police and the judiciary,
  • professional standards and internal controls.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Council Joint Action 2005/826/FUSP’s mandate for the mission ran from 15 December 2005 to 14 June 2006. The mission was deemed to have been completed in May 2006, after which it was brought to a close.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The mission personnel were 30 police advisers from mainly EU countries, including two Danes. A total of 16 Danish police officers have been deployed to the two EU police missions - EUPAT and EUPOL Proxima.

missions.title: EUPM BiH Bosnia
missions.subtitle: The first EU police mission
missions.name: EUPM BiH
missions.descriptiveName: EU Police Mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina

text.heading: Background
text.text:
War and unrest related to the breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991 first impacted Bosnia-Herzegovina after the country had declared independence, which had been recognised by the EU’s member states since 6 April 1992. Bosnia-Herzegovina’s population is primarily Muslim, but there are also large numbers of ethnic Serbs and Croats. During the 1992-1995 war, these ethnic groups were at war with each other and the conflict became the backdrop for ethnic cleansing, rape and other human rights violations.
The Dayton peace treaty was negotiated with and concluded on 21 November 1995 by Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near the town of Dayton, Ohio in the USA. The treaty was largely facilitated by the USA, but the negotiations saw participation from the EU, France, Germany, Russia and the United Kingdom. The treaty was officially signed by the parties on 14 December 1995 in Paris.

The peace treaty recognised Bosnia-Herzegovina as a republic that was split into two administrative areas, namely Bosnia-Herzegovina with Muslim and Croat dominance and Republika Srpska which is Serb-dominated.
In annex 11 of the Dayton treaty, the parties agreed to the deployment of a civilian UNMIBH International Police Task Force, IPTF, to support the enforcement of civil law in the republic.
The mission was active until 31 December 2002, after which date the mission was taken over by an EU police task force from 1 January 2003, after planning that commenced on 1 April 2002.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
With Council Joint Action 2002/210/CFSP of 11 March 2002, the EU decided that it would deploy a police unit.
An agreement on the deployment was concluded between the EU and Bosnia-Herzegovina in Council Decision 2002/845/CFSP of 30 September 2002. This agreement set out the more detailed conditions for the presence of the EU police taskforce named EU Police Mission in Bosnia Herzegovina (EUPM BiH)

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Government authorised Danish participation in accordance with the EU decision.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
With support from other EU programmes, EUPM BiH’s mission at strategic/political level was to:
-establish Bosnia-Herzegovina-controlled police institutions that satisfy international and European standards, including the retention of existing competences that had already been attained by police institutions and personnel,
-reinforce police command and operational capacities through mentor schemes, monitoring and inspections, particularly with regard to the delegation of authority and good leadership principles, and improving operational planning,
-strengthen levels of professionalism within ministries and of senior police offers by providing advice and performing inspections,
-monitoring political control of policing.

EUPM BiH’s objective at operational level was that the police in Bosnia-Herzegovina would, by the end of 2005, be able to:
-perform their duties in a professional manner that is compliant with legislation and regulations in a transparent, objective manner within an adapted organisational framework,
-be free of directly political involvement and under the command of non-politicised, qualified and responsible leadership,
-display professional conduct at ministerial and senior police officer levels based on a quality internal leadership/management structure, i.e. adapted to an internal system of checks and balances, with a leadership/management structure that exercises a healthy HR policy for recruitment, training and promotions etc.
-take into consideration a multi-ethnic societal composition and gender-related issues,
-develop data collection and analysis systems for use in planning and investigations (criminal statistics system),
-develop a mechanism for collaboration,
-launch investigations into corruption cases,
-research and accommodate criminal activities, including organised crime and terrorism, while being part of an administration that is based on law and order in collaboration with the state prosecutor,
-develop an information exchange system at government and local/regional authority level in close partnership with the Multinational Stabilisation Force (SFOR),
-have the capacity to react to public unrest while following modern policing standards, without being influenced by political or ethnic factors.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched on 1 January 2003 and was brought to an end on 30 June 2012. This was the first police mission to have been launched by the EU.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark participated by providing 11 police officers until the end of 2005, after which the contribution was reduced to three officers.
A Danish police inspector was the first Head of Mission.
A total of approx. 380 Danish police officers were deployed to the two missions, under UN and EU auspices.
There was participation from all EU member states, as well as third countries Canada, Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Turkey and Ukraine. The mission’s headquarters were in Sarajevo. At the end of the mission there were four regional offices in Sarajevo, Banja Luka, Mostar and Tuzla.

missions.title: EUPOL in Afghanistan
missions.subtitle: EU police task in Afghanistan
missions.name: EUPOL Afghanistan
missions.descriptiveName: EU Police Mission in Afghanistan  etc.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The conflict in Afghanistan has been the subject of large amounts of international attention since the autumn of 2001. All involved states and international partnerships have, to a greater or lesser degree, taken the stance that Afghanistan would need help to get back on its feet.  Many stakeholders have taken action in this regard in a number of initiatives. This also includes the European Union.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
Council Joint Action 2007/369/CFSP of 30 May 2007 mandated the European Union Police Mission in Afghanistan (EUPOL AFGHANISTAN).
The EU was already involved prior to 2007, however. With Council Joint Action 2001/875/CFSP of 10 December 2001, the EU appointed a Special Representative for Afghanistan, for whom the mandate would be extended on an ongoing basis. When this mandate was extended, security sector reforms would be outlined.
It was concluded at a meeting of the European Council on Foreign Affairs on 12 May 2016 that the EU was determined to support the civilian police mission in Afghanistan after the EUPOL mission ended at the end of 2016. The mandate for this mission is found in Council Joint Action 2017/289/CFSP of 17 February 2017.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish decision to participate in EUPOL was based on the EU resolution and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs strategy for the Afghanistan mission. The EUSR decision was made by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Justice after the EU’s February 2017 request that Denmark provide a police adviser to the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
EUPOL Afghanistan’s objective was to contribute towards establishing sustainable and effective civilian policing under Afghan administration and ensuring the necessary cohesion with the criminal system. The mission would be in line with the work that was being done by the EU, member states and other international stakeholders with regard to political advice and setting up institutions. The mission would also support a reforms process that aimed towards a trusted and effective police force that would operate within the framework of international standards and the principles of law and order, while also respecting human rights.

To achieve this objective, the mission would:
-work on the development of strategies, emphasising the collaboration with the international community for a joint overall police reform strategy that was based on the Afghanistan agreement, thus working towards improving the cohesion and coordination of its international stakeholders,
-support the Afghan government’s implementation of a cohesive strategy and
-support the day to day relationship between the police and a law and order-based state.

The mission would be performed through monitoring, mentor schemes, advice and training.
EUPOL Afghanistan would also work with the co-ordination, dissemination and provision of advice about projects that are being implemented by EU member states and other countries in areas that affect the EUPOL mission and support its objectives.
The mandate specifically stated that the police mission would coordinate the mission with the international community and collaborate with key partners, including the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) and the NATO training mission. It was also intended that the police mission would conclude technical agreements with ISAF and the leading states in the regional commands/province reconstruction teams (PRTs) with regard to the exchange of information and medical, security and logistical support, including the provision of accommodation by the regional commands and PRTs.

The mission of the special envoy to EUSR Afghanistan was to:
-reform the security sector, including strengthening judicial institutions and law and order, the national army and police and, specifically, civilian police force developments.
The various assignments are described in further detail in decision 289 from 2017 and include:
-monitoring and advising the Afghan authorities at strategic level to improve the long-term development of command and decision-making capacity with a view to improving civilian policing within the Afghan police.
-to monitor and advise the Afghan ministry of the interior about selected aspects related to ministry of the interior reforms and the professionalisation of the Afghan police, as well as improving guidelines for community policing and intelligence-led policing and criminal investigations, and
-to monitor and advise Afghanistan’s ministry of justice’s anti-corruption centre with a view to developing its capacity and ability to combat high level corruption within the public sector.

The mission built upon the results that had already been achieved by the EUPOL mission.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
EUPOL Afghanistan commenced operations on 15 June 2007, with a provisional three-year mandate to 30 May 2010. The mandate would be extended on an ongoing basis, ending on 31 December 2016.
EUSR Afghanistan was launched on 1 January 2017 at the end of the EUPOL mission.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Danish police officers took part in EUPOL Afghanistan from September 2007, when a contribution was made to building up the capacity of a central team. The contribution of police training personnel would later be expanded to the Kabul, Helmand, Uruzgan and Kunduz provinces. Approximately 90 Danish police officers (with a few more for training missions of shorter or longer duration) took part until the mission was brought to a close at the end of December 2016.
A senior police officer has been stationed with EUSR Afghanistan since February/March 2017. His job description is that of Senior Police Advisor to the Afghan vice home minister, with responsibility for criminal investigations. The advisor should provide particular instruction and advice about organised crime and human trafficking.

missions.title: EUPOL COPPS Palestine
missions.subtitle: Police support
missions.name: EUPOL COPPS Palæstina
missions.descriptiveName: EU Co-ordination Office for Palestinian Police Support

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Israel and Arabic countries have been fighting wars ever since the state of Israel was established in 1948. The Palestinian population would be particularly affected, as they had no cohesive national state at their disposal.  This situation has not only led to wars, but to a continual armed conflict between the Palestinians and the state of Israel. With the aid of the international community, the Palestinians have been able to establish self-rule on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip.
Establishing peace in the Middle East has been an important task for the EU. A priority mission for the EU has been to strengthen law and order. EUPOL COPPS was an important element in this regard towards increasing security in the Palestinian territories. EUPOL COPPS builds on the foundations that had already been established by the EU Coordination Office for Palestinian Police Support.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The EU adopted the mandate for European Union Police Mission for the Palestinian Territories (EUPOL COPPS) in Council Decision 2005/797/CFSP of 14 November 2005.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Government decision in accordance with the EU decision.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The objective of the mission was to help establish sustainable and effective policing in accordance with the best European standards under Palestinian authority. The mission assignments would be performed in close collaboration with the EU’s other development programmes and the missions of other international organisations towards increasing security in the area. Assistance would also be provided towards a reform of the criminal law system.

The mission of EUPOL COPPS included:
-assisting Palestine's civilian police in the implementation of a specific development programme for the police, through close-up advice and a mentor scheme, with particular focus at district, headquarters and ministerial level,
-coordinating aid from the EU and member states and other international aid to the Palestinian civilian police and
-advising on police-related elements of the criminal law system.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The mission was launched on 1 January 2006, initially with a three-year mandate until 31 December 2008. The mandate was extended on an ongoing basis, most recently to June 2020. Danish police participation ended in September 2014.
21 EU countries and Canada, Norway and Turkey provided personnel to this mission. The mission’s headquarters is in Ramallah.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: A Danish police inspector was assigned to the mission on 1 December 2005, with the task of planning and coordinating on behalf of EUPOL COPPS. Only one Danish officer was deployed to the mission at a time. An approximate total of 12 senior Danish police officers have been assigned to the mission.

missions.title: EUPOL Congo
missions.subtitle: Police officers in Kinshasa
missions.name: EUPOL Congo
missions.descriptiveName: EU Police Mission in Kinshasa, Congo.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
As part of the democratisation of Congo it was necessary to set up an integrated Congolese police unit that would help to protect the provisional government and its institutions.
The EU had made a major contribution with its ARTEMIS military operation towards re-establishing security in Congo and had reaped the benefits of partnerships, and in particular with the UN.
On 20 October 2003, Congo’s government sent an official request to the EU for assistance setting up an integrated police unit that would help to ensure that state institutions were protected and to strengthen the internal security apparatus.

(For further information about Congo, see MONUC (United Nations Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo)

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: In EU decision 2004/847/FUSP of 9 December 2004, the EU decided to set up an EU police mission in Congo (EUPOL ”Kinshasa”) from the beginning of January 2005.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: After being presented to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Government decided to agree to the EU’s request to assign personnel to the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission’s assignment was to monitor, instruct and advise in the creation of the Integrerated Police Unit (IPU). As the unit was phased in, it would ensure that IPU’ s conduct would be in accordance with police academy training principles and good policing practices. The mission would also focus on IPU organisation, with a view to the management of its administrative capacity. The mission would also monitor, instruct and advise IPU operational units in the performance of their duties.

The EU decided on 23 March 2006 that it would agree to a UN request for additional personnel within the context of the elections in Congo. 29 police officers from the EU and invited third countries were deployed for a five month period, including Danish police personnel. Their mission was to support security and stability in Kinshasa, including by coordinating the activities of the National Congolese Police units that were deployed and by providing technical assistance, monitoring activities and supervision, including an advisory role when planning deployments.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was officially launched on 12 April 2005 and ended at the end of June 2007. The mission was followed by EUPOL RD CONGO, which was launched on 1 July 2007.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Two Danish police officers have been deployed to the mission.

missions.title: EUPOL Proxima Macedonia
missions.subtitle: Police in Macedonia
missions.name: EUPOL Proxima Makedonien
missions.descriptiveName: EU Police Mission in the FYR of Macedonia

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Within the context of the breakup of Yugoslavia, a referendum was held on 8 September 1991 which gave Macedonia sovereign independent status. The Macedonian parliament adopted a constitution for the country on 17 November 1991. After a relatively peaceful period, 2001 saw armed engagements between Macedonian armed forces and police on one side and Albanian paramilitary units on the other, as the Albanians wanted to become part of Albania.
A roadmap was agreed on 13 August 2001 by the involved parties, the EU and USA. This was named the Ohrid Framework Agreement after the town where the agreement was concluded. The agreement would assure Macedonian democracy for the future, as well as peaceful development that would respect ethnic minorities and Macedonian society.
An EU-led military mission, Operation Concordia, was deployed in 2001 to ensue that the roadmap was implemented. The military mission had completed its mission on 15 December 2003 and was followed by the launch of the EUPOL Proxima police mission on the same date.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for an EU-led police mission was adopted in Council Joint Action 2003/681/CFSP of 29 September 2003, as a natural follow-up to the Ohrid Framework Agreement.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Danish Government decision after presentation to the Foreign Policy Committee, based on EU decisions and a request from the EU to provide personnel for the mission

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The council decision described the tasks of the mission as being to follow up on the intentions set out in the Ohrid Framework Agreement, whereby the mission would, in close collaboration with relevant local authorities through monitoring, mentor guidance and instruction, focus on the following issues:
- strengthening law and order, including by combating  organised crime,
- a practical implementation of an extensive reform of the Macedonian ministry of the interior, including the police,
- operational reinforcement and construction of a border police that would be part of the EU’s moves towards integrated border controls,
- strengthen local policing to establish confidence within the population and
- increased policing partnerships with neighbouring countries.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched on 15 December 2003, with a planned end date of 14 December 2004. The mandate was extended by a further year, ending on 14 December 2005. A new mission, EUPAT, European Union Police Advisory Team in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, was launched from 15 December 2005.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The mission was comprised of a deployment that involved approx. 150 police officers, mainly from EU countries and third nations Turkey, Norway, Iceland, Canada, Russia, Ukraine, Switzerland and the USA.
Denmark sent approx. 16 officers to the two EU missions.

text.heading: Background
text.text: In March 2014 the conflict in Syria entered its fourth year and led to the most serious humanitarian and security crisis in many years. Over 140,000 people had lost their lives. 6.5 million people had had to flee to elsewhere in Syria. Over 9 million Syrians were in need of emergency aid and 2.5 million had fled the country. The fighting and hopeless situation caused immense destruction and public and administrative structures broke down completely in several areas. This was even more the case in opposition-controlled areas, where the populations were unable to access even the most basic services.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
In May 2014, pursuant to a document called “Syria - Strategic Framework (2014-2015) issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark, the Parliament adopted the strategic framework for a temporary programme of aid to Syria. More specifically, the Danish Minister of Trade and Development requested DKK 100 million on 9 April 2014 from the Finance Committee to support a transitionary programme for Syria. DKK 25 million of this sum was earmarked for the Integrated Community Security Programme. This programme would contribute to rebuilding the Syrian police and supporting law and order in opposition-controlled areas of Syria.
Act no. 87 was adopted by the Finance Committee on 9 May 2014 by all 17 members. Other donor countries were and continue to be the USA, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Justice, in an email dated 28 March 2014, asked the Danish National Police to provide a police adviser for the programme.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The envoy would serve as an adviser and be part of a collaboration at strategic level with advisers from the other donor countries that was located in Istanbul in Turkey.
The task itself was broadly formulated and was briefly stated as “participating in the partnership with other donor countries towards the training of the Syrian Free Police.”
The training itself was designated to private companies, including through the EU and was performed in practice in south-west Turkey, in the towns of Adana, Gaziantep and to some extent in Syria, in the towns of Idlib and Aleppo.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: A senior Danish police officer was deployed in May and June 2014 to a fact-finding mission in the area. The police adviser was deployed on a permanent basis from approx. 1 August 2014. The mission is still ongoing.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: A senior police officer has been deployed to the mission for its entire duration. A total of three Danish police officers have been deployed, one of whom is still serving as part of the mission.

missions.title: ICTY
missions.subtitle: Genocide and war crimes
missions.name: ICTY Ex-Jugoslavien
missions.descriptiveName: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

text.heading: Background
text.text: The war in the former Yugoslavia in 1991 and 1992 and the 1992 war in Bosnia-Herzegovina led to massive human rights violations and breaches of conventions by all parties in the war. Notably, it was the reports of mass executions, rapes and ethnic cleansing that led to revulsion in the international community and condemnation by its organisations, especially because those responsible for these war crimes were brought to prosecution by none of the involved parties.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
In Resolution 827 of 25 May 1993, the UN Security Council decided to set up an international court to prosecute the people responsible for war crimes committed after 1 January 1991.
At the same time, the UN asked all member states to assist in the form of funds, materials and experts; including judges, prosecutors and investigators etc.
The Netherlands offered to be the venue for the courts, which were set up in the Hague.

The courts were set up as
-                     three courts/chambers, each with three judges and a court of appeal with five judges, as well as the appointment of a number of “reserve judges”, interpreters, office staff etc.
-                     a prosecutor comprised of lawyers, investigators, analyst, interpreters and office staff and
-                     a records office that would perform administrative duties for the courts, the prosecutor and the accuseds’ defence attorneys. There was also a superintendent for the court prison department, which was situated in part of the Dutch state prison in Schevenningen.

With Act no. 1099 of 21/12/1994, Denmark amended legislation to allow people encompassed by the statute and procedural regulations of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia could be prosecuted in Denmark and that individuals could be handed over to the tribunal upon request.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Government decided to participate on the basis of the UN resolution after a request from the UN to provide police investigators for the project.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The task of the assigned Danish investigators was to investigate possible war crimes in the former Yugoslavia, including:
- breaches of the 1949 Geneva convention and infringements of the rules of war.
- genocide, as well as crimes against humanity, including ethnic cleansing.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The International Court was set up by the UN Resolution of 25 May 1993 and was wound down at the end of 2017.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish Police had been sending investigators to the court since 1 October 1994. A total of five Danish investigators were deployed until 1 October 1999, up to two at a time.
Two Danish investigators were employed by the UN directly from 1999 to the end of 2006 as court investigators, but not at the same time.
Approximately 10 Danish forensic technicians and investigators were deployed to assist the Court for about a month at a time in relation to the excavation of mass graves. Experts were also deployed to serve as forensic pathologists etc.
Denmark also sent lawyers to the court.
The investigators’ headquarters were in the Hague, the investigators being deployed to Belgrade, Zagreb, Sarajevo and Pristina.

missions.title: POMLT, LKGTC, CPAC Afghanistan
missions.subtitle: Police missions in Afghanistan
missions.name: ISAF politimissioner i Afghanistan POMLT m.fl.
missions.descriptiveName: Regional Training Center, Task Force 7 ect.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When Soviet forces withdrew from Afghanistan in 1989, the country continued to be plagued by instability. The various Mujahadin factions occupied different geographical areas, which led to internal power struggles between the many factions and commanders. It was therefore not possible for the central government to establish a representative form of government. The period leading up to 1996 was characterised by anarchy and administrative breakdown.  Approximately 1/3 of Kabul lay in ruins. Thousands of civilians had been killed and hundreds of thousands of people had taken flight.
The Taliban movement appeared in 1994. Its goal was to bring the civil wars to an end, and to conquer the entire country. This took place in September 1996, when the movement occupied Kabul, with the exception of areas in northern and central Afghanistan. The Taliban were initially welcomed by the population, as they brought peace and physical security with them. This would change, as the movement began to intensify its moves towards an islamification of the country. Women were not permitted to leave their homes unveiled or unaccompanied by a male member of their family. Schools for girls were closed. Men were not permitted to trim their beards etc. The movement was also responsible for the massacre of civilian populations and ethnic religious minorities.

In January 2001 the UN Security Council condemned the Taliban régime as a centre of international terrorism, including Osama bin Laden who the USA suspected of being behind terrorist attacks on American targets. Responsibility for the attacks on the World Trade Centre in New York and the Pentagon in Washington was attributed to bin Laden’s al-Queda organisation and the USA and United Kingdom carried out extensive bombing attacks against the Taliban régime and Al-Qaeda. Comprehensive military aid was channelled to the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan, who had been resisting the Taliban for several years. The Taliban gave up their final stronghold in Kandahar on 7 December 2001.
UN Security Council resolution 1368 of 12 September 2001 was generally interpreted as a mandate for military actions in response to the 11 September attacks.
The basis for a provisional government was established at a meeting in Bonn in December 2001. Extensive international economic and military aid was contributed and the international community provided extensive advisory support towards rebuilding the country.

NATO assumed command and responsibility for the international peacekeeping forces in August 2003. Elections were held and a new constitution was adopted.
Adopted in London on 1 February 2006, the Afghanistan Compact was an agreement between the international community and Afghanistan, setting out the strategy and vision for future initiatives. The Afghanistan Compact highlights three areas in particular:

  1. Security
  2. Government, penal code and human rights, as well as
  3. The economy and social development

The Afghanistan Compact replaced what was envisaged at the 2001 Bonn meeting.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The ”Summit Declaration on Afghanistan” mandate to train the Afghan National Police was decided at the NATO summit on 3 and 4 April 2009 in Strasbourg, France and Kehl in Germany.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The background for this mission can be found in Danish parliamentary decision B24 on increasing the Danish contribution to the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan, which was adopted on 9 December 2008. Denmark decided that it would focus its initiatives on security, capacitating Afghan security forces, building the state, education and improving living conditions.  Women’s rights and conditions and combating a narcotics-based economy were considerations across the board.
The Danish Government’s strategy for the political, civilian and military missions in Afghanistan from 2008-2012 states, inter alia, that the Danish initiative should focus on capacity and capability, including increased police training.

text.id: POMLT Police Operation Mentoring and Liaison Team Gereshk
text.heading: POMLT – Team Gereshk
text.text:
Policing is described in further detail in a joint publication by the Danish Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark titled “The Danish Mission in Helmand 2010 (the 2010 Helmand Plan).  Denmark wanted to focus on building police capacity to enable Afghan police to assume greater responsibility for security in Afghanistan.  Setting up a Police Operational Mentor and Liaison Team (POMLT) in the Helmand area would be one of the ways to achieve this. A team would be comprised of civilian and military police personnel, as well as regular combat troops.

Mission
A training team was comprised of a commander from the military, two civilian police officers, three military policemen and 16 soldiers. The mission mainly involved advising and mentoring local Afghan police commanders. Afghan police officers were also trained in basic patrol skills and other basic policing competences. The escort soldiers were responsible for the team’s security, as well as providing practical self-defence training to Afghan police officers.

Duration
The first POMLT team to include Danish police officers was set up in August 2010, the final training team being recalled at the beginning of 2014.

Contribution
A significant number of Danish officers were deployed to the training mission in Gereshk during this period. The aforementioned training team was exclusively Danish, but corresponding teams were set up by the USA and the United Kingdom.

text.id: LKGTC Afghanistan. Regional Training Center i Lashkar Gah.
text.heading: LKGTC - Lashkar Gah
text.text:
Policing is described in further detail in a joint publication by the Danish Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark titled “The Danish Mission in Helmand 2010 (the 2010 Helmand Plan).  Denmark wanted to focus on building police capacity to enable Afghan police to have greater responsibility for security in Afghanistan. Setting up a Police Operational Mentor and Liaison Team in the Helmand area and deploying police trainers to the Lashkar Gah Training Centre i Helmand (LKGTC) for police officers would be one of the ways to achieve this.

Mission
The police trainers assigned to the Lashkar Gah Training Centre would provide training in basic policing skills in:
-raid procedures, investigation and evidence management and
-good police conduct.

In collaboration with British police authorities and EUPOL, the police trainers would prepare a course programme for mid-level officers in the Afghanistan National Police and provided their training. The police trainers would also participate in the implementation of a specific leadership course for police officers.

Duration
The first Danish police officers were deployed to the Lashkar Gah Training Centre in Helmand i April 2011, the mission being wound down in March 2013.

Contribution
Four Danish police officers were deployed at a time during the aforementioned period. They were stationed in Lashkar Gah for nine weeks at a time, returning to Denmark for seven weeks and rotating back to Lashkar Gah afterwards. Personnel was replaced on a gradual ongoing basis.

text.heading: LKGTC - Task Force 7
text.text:
Policing is closely described in a joint publication by the Danish Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark titled “The Danish Mission in Helmand 2010 (the 2010 Helmand Plan).  Denmark wanted to focus on building police capacity to enable Afghan police to have greater responsibility for security in Afghanistan.  Setting up a Police Operational Mentor and Liaison Team in the Helmand area and deploying police trainers to the Lashkar Gah Training Centre for police in Helmand and providing training to Afghan police special services personnel would be one of the ways to achieve this.

Mission
Task Force 7’s task was to train an Afghan ”Provincial Response Companies” (PRC) police unit in the Helmand province, enabling it to perform high-risk operations. The objective was that the unit, which could be compared with a western SWAT team, would have autonomous capabilities to lead and execute missions such as anti-narcotics and anti-corruption measures, as well as making high-risk arrests within the framework of Afghan legislation.

Duration
The first training team was set up in February 2012. The Afghan PRC unit attained autonomous status in February 2014 and the Danish training mission, or Task Force 7, was brought to a close.

Contribution
A Danish training team was comprised of Danish special forces from the Jaeger Corps, Frogmen Corps, and military and civilian police personnel. A training team would be deployed for four months at a time, each team including a Danish police officer.

The three aforementioned missions (POMLT, Lashkar Gah and Task Force 7) involved a total personnel deployment of approx. 86 officers, several of who were deployed on multiple occasion to shorter duration training missions.

text.heading: CPAC - Police Advisor Kabul.
text.text: In 2013-2014 a senior Danish police officer was assigned as policing advisor to the American general who was supreme commander of the ISAF forces. A total of two Danish senior police officers were deployed to the mission.
