missions.title: JIPTC Jordan
missions.subtitle: Training Iraqi police officers
missions.name: JIPTC Jordan
missions.descriptiveName: International Police Training Center in Amman

text.heading: Background
text.text: See the missions pertaining to Iraq.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
UN Security Resolution 1483 of 22 May 2003 was the mandate for this mission.

Further details of the mandate were provided in a “Letter of Agreement Between the Government of the United States of America and the Government of Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan Concerning the training of Iraqi Police in Jordan”, which was signed on 24 September 2004. This document is an extract from the “Contractual Agreement between the Coalition Provisional Authority in Iraq and the Government of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan Concerning Access to and Use of the Facilities in Jordan for Iraq Police Training”, which was signed on 13 October 2003.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 8 October 2003 the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs put forward proposal B1, concerning increasing the Danish contribution to the multi-national security forces in Iraq. This proposal also included contributions to strengthen the training missions that were being provided to Iraqi police. The parliamentary proposal was adopted on 10 October 2003, with 94 votes in favour and 15 votes against.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The mission’s objective was to provide 35,000 Iraqi police personnel with eight weeks of basic training in general policing competences, human rights, reporting etc. before taking up service in Iraq. Training was also provided to superintendents etc.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched in mid-2003 and is still active. Over 50,000 Iraqi police officers have completed eight weeks of training.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
A total of five Danish police instructors were deployed to the mission, from 11 February to 9 August 2004. These were deployed over multiple postings. In 2018 there were two officers participating in this mission.
Instructors from the various coalition member states have served as instructors, most coming from the USA, the country that was the initiative behind and main sponsor for the training programme.

missions.title: Border project in Lebanon
missions.subtitle: Border Control
missions.name: Grænseprojekt Libanon
missions.descriptiveName: Danish Advisory Team to the Lebanon Border Project

text.heading: Background
text.text: See UNIFIL

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The basic mandate was in the creation of the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) in Security Council Resolutions 425 and 426 of 19 March 1978. After the war and unrest of the summer of 2006, the UN adopted Resolution 1701 of 11 August 2006, requiring the Lebanon to secure its national borders and mandating UN member states to assist the Lebanon in this task.
By invitation from Lebanese authorities, Germany sent a team of experts to the Lebanon on a bilateral basis to provide technical and advisory assistance to Lebanese border authorities. The UN also sent (on the basis of the UN’s General Secretary’s S/2006/730 report of 12 September 2006) a team of expert representatives comprised of military, police, customs and border experts to advise about future border security measures.
Lebanon Independent Border Assessment Team I and Team II were deployed by the UN on two occasions to assess requirements, from 27 May to 15 June 2007 and from 15 July to 31 July 2008, both teams under the command of a senior Danish police officer.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Danish Government decision to provide support to the German project on the basis of Resolution 1701. Denmark supported the project in the form of the Danish Advisory Team to the Lebanon Border Project until December 2010, when the Lebanese government asked Denmark to continue the programme under Danish leadership. A bilateral agreement was concluded between the Lebanon and Denmark, financed by Denmark.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Northern Border Pilot Project was a German-led project to which Denmark provided financial and practical support. Its task was to coordinate the initiative for the four Lebanese institutions (Lebanese Armed Forces, Internal Security Force, General Security and General Customs) with responsibility for border security.
The mission of the Danish police was to provide advice and training to relevant Lebanese border authorities, hereunder:
-training in general border control policing, including routine document inspections,
-training in combating cross-border crime such as arms, narcotics and human trafficking,
-training relevant police authorities in self-defence, first aid, personal development and international collaborations and
-training Lebanese police dog handlers and dogs in the use of dogs in policing.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched when Resolution 1701 was adopted in August 2006. The Danish Advisory Team to the Lebanon Border Project was funded by Denmark to the end of 2018.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Approx. 20 Danish police officers took part in the project from its very beginning, alongside personnel from Germany, Canada, the United Kingdom and the USA. The Danes worked mainly in Beirut and Tripoli.

missions.title: Police with OSCE on the Balkans
missions.subtitle: Police Monitoring Group
missions.name: Politi med OSCE på Balkan
missions.descriptiveName: Police Work in Croatia, Albania etc.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The civil war in the former Yugoslavia arose from a desire for independence and involved extensive and violent acts of ethnic cleansing After several years of political strife between the states making up the country, war broke out when Croatia and Slovenia seceded. Ten days of fighting ensued in Slovenia, but the extent would not have lasting impact on the Balkan nations In Croatia, the Serbian minority opposed independence from Yugoslavia and also opposed inclusion of Serbs in a Croatian state. Fighting erupted between Croats and those Serbs living in the border area between Croatia and Bosnia. The Yugoslavian army actively supported the Serbs in this war. The European Community undertook several initiatives to end the fighting, but to no avail. In parallel, the UN in 1991 arranged for the introduction of a number of restrictions on transport of arms and ammunition to Yugoslavia. At the same time, discussions took place regarding a potential UN mission with the aim of reaching an initial ceasefire. In getting involved in the Balkans, the international community made extensive use of police personnel to inform and report on humanitarian aspects and provide surveillance, monitoring, and training. Some of these were provided by the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (CSCE/OSCE). Danes took part in these activities. The task was challenging due to the many conflicts between various population groups and the resulting violent confrontations. During the 1990s and 2000s, Danish police personnel were sent via OSCE to all of the Balkan Peninsula. This report focuses on Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, and Albania.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The sending by OSCE of personnel on a mission to Albania was based on a UN Resolution, 1101 of 28 March 1997, that had come about as a result of the violent popular protests in the country. These protests complained about the dictatorial government and the so-called pyramid investment schemes being foisted on the people. Many lost their money, and a popular uprising began. With the looting of arms depots, it developed into a civil war. The opposition asked OSCE to intervene. In March, the government requested military assistance as it had lost control of large parts of Albania. The mandate was adjusted over time to suit the situation and the evolving events in Albania. It has been extended several times.
One year after the adoption of Resolution 1101, another OSCE mandate was established. This one had to do with Croatia. OSCE set up a Police Monitoring Group in the Croatian Danube region. The mandate was created by Permanent Council Decision No. 239 of 25 June 1998. This mandate was intended to take over the missions that had been initiated three years earlier. A peace agreement pertaining to Eastern Slavonia had been entered into on 12 November 1995 between the Croatian government and Serbian negotiators. The agreement was entitled ”Basic agreement on the region of Eastern Slavonia, Baranja, and Western Sirmium”. One of the stipulations in the agreement was that the UN set up an administrative apparatus to govern the region in a transition period. As the upshot of all this, the OSCE Police Monitoring Group mission assumed what had originally been the remit of the UN operation UNTAES. By Permanent Council Decision No. 373 of 21 September 2000, it was the plan that the OSCE Police Monitoring Group would cease activities as an independent unit in the Danube region as of 31 October 2000.
In Macedonia, an OSCE mandate with support from the Danish Police was established by OSCE Permanent Council Decision No. 439 of 28 September 2001 on request from the Macedonian government. The mandate was based on the goals stated in the “Ohrid Agreement”. The intent of the agreement was to put an official end to the armed conflict between the National Liberation Army and Macedonia’s military and police forces. One of the goals of the mandate was to assist in and ensure a phased and coordinated transformation and installation of the local Macedonian police and to develop policing related projects in various police districts. It has been extended several times.
A few years after the OSCE provided support to Macedonia, the organisation became involved in conflicts between Serbia and Montenegro. When Montenegro became an independent nation in 2006, OSCE established, by Permanent Council Decision No. 732 of 29 June 2006, a separate mission exclusively focusing on the challenges experienced by Montenegro as a sovereign country. With respect to police work, the areas in which OSCE were to assist were in particular training and development, professional responsibility and internal controls, organised crime control, forensic medicine, border police activities, and local police activities. The mandate was extended several times and ended upon its expiry in December 2018.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Denmark’s decision to provide police personnel for the above OSCE missions was primarily made by the Foreign Affairs Council as a natural consequence of the desire to build peace and democracy in the conflict-ridden Balkan nations.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Number of Danish police made available for the various OSCE missions:
- Albania: Five police officers 1997-2001.
- Croatia: Approximately 300 police officers through to the end of the mission on 31 October 2000.
- Macedonia: Police officers acting as teachers and instructors 2001-2004. A further contingent was sent 2006-2007. About 10 Danish police officers were provided.
- A handful of Danish police officers were sent to Montenegro 2006-2007.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
In Albania, OSCE had the overall task of working with the Albanian authorities to offer advice and guidance in the following key areas:
- Democracy building and media development;
- Legal rights, human rights, and efforts to combat corruption and trafficking;
- Guidance and assistance in reforming administrative and judicial functions and in training police and customs departments; and
- Guidance, assistance, and monitoring associated with future elections.
With a view to building professionalism and introducing international standards, the OSCE police services mission was tasked with:
- Organising management skill building and training for the police force, the inspection services unit, border police and border migration police;
- Providing guidance and assistance to local police initiatives aimed at reducing domestic violence; and
- Providing guidance and assistance to the police in developing strategies, threat assessment, and a shared centre for information exchange by border officials.

In Croatia, the key tasks were:
- Surveillance and monitoring of Croatia police in the Danube region, especially in the work with refugee resettlement and displaced persons.
In Macedonia, the work was based on the ”Ohrid Framework Agreement”. The plan was to deploy the Danish police advisers in the sensitive areas at the same time local police forces were reorganised and deployed.
The police advisers were tasked with:
- Assisting in and ensuring a phased and coordinated restructuring and deployment of local police forces.
The police instructors were tasked with:
- Assisting in the implementation of a plan for a police academy project.

In Montenegro, the OSCE police mission was tasked with:
- Assisting in, developing, and implementing OSCE principles plus developing the collaboration with Montenegro in such areas as political and military efforts, the economy, and the environment.
In a “Memorandum of Understanding” dated 8 July 2008 between OSCE and central authorities, it is stated that the mission in particular is intended to assist Montenegro in education and development:
- Local police forces and border police;
- Professional responsibility and investigational capacity in general and in areas related to organised crime and antiterrorism.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Troubled History of Ukraine Prior to World War I, the country was divided between Russia and the Habsburg Monarchy. After the war, the country was occupied several times by the Red Army, and as of 1920, Ukraine became a part of the Soviet Bloc. In the Soviet era, the country was beset by war, famine, and ethnic cleansing. Also World War II, inflicted immense suffering and loss of life. Upon the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ukraine declared independence in 1991, but it was unprepared for the structural implications. Repeatedly, political crises arose, and priority was given to the relationship with Russia or with the West depending on who was in power at any given time. Ukraine became a member of the European Council in 1995, but any development in the direction of democracy was hampered by a lack of supporting legislation and by frequent political crises.
In the years after 2000, mass demonstrations were staged in protest against the then president. In the 2004 election, Viktor Yanukovych won by a slim margin in a runoff against his opponent Viktor Yushchenko. However, it was clear that this outcome had been achieved by election fraud. The opposition took to the streets in what became known as the Orange Revolution. As a result, the Supreme Court ordered a second runoff, and Yushchenko won it by a clear majority. Yushchenko steered the country toward the West and expressed an ambition to have it become a member of NATO and the EU. The relationship with Russia was fraught with tension. The population was not ready for entry into NATO, and NATO had no particular desire for the entry – but indicated that Ukraine might at some future time become a member. At a summit between the EU and Ukraine in 2008, Ukraine was promised an association agreement but not membership proper.
Ukraine and Russia continued to have a difficult relationship, partly due to disagreements over the Sevastopol facilities for the Russian Black Sea Fleet. Russia pointed out that Ukraine would experience serious consequences should it become a member of NATO. In 2010, the Ukraine government decided not to seek membership in NATO. In 2012, the president decided not to enter into an almost completed association agreement with the EU. That decision triggered extensive street protests, and the situation deteriorated in February 2004 with armed skirmishes and widespread unrest. The so-called Maidan II revolution had erupted (it is named for the Maidan Square in Kiev). With the help of the EU, a peace accord was negotiated, but the protests continued, and President Viktor Yanukovych fled to Russia. An election was called. The opposition appeared to be the likely winner. Russia reacted quickly by annexing Crimea. In eastern Ukraine, fighting broke out between government forces and pro-Russian militias.
Petro Poroshenko won the election. He was inclined to collaborate with the West and to enter into a peace accord.
OSCE then decided to deploy an observer mission to Ukraine.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: By Permanent Council Decision No. 1117 of 21 March 2014, OSCE decided to send international observers to Ukraine.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: A decision was made by the Danish Foreign Affairs Council upon submission from OSCE and consideration of its dispositions.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The tasks in the mission included:
- Gather intelligence and report on the security situation in the area, including information about and factual descriptions of violations of fundamental OSCE principles;
- Monitor and support efforts to build respect for human rights and fundamental rights of freedom, including the rights of national minorities;
- Establish contact with local, regional, and national authorities, civil society, ethnic and religious groups, and members of the local community in order to use dialogue for the purpose of easing tensions and foster normalisation.

Rather than being a policing effort, the mission focused on civilian observer activities.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was initiated on 21 March 2014 and was extended several times. The mission is ongoing with Danish participation. Due to the situation in Ukraine after the russion attack no danish police people are deployed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Danish observers have worked in the mission ever since it was initiated. By the end of February 2018, the mission had a total of 614 observers of whom 10 were from Denmark. Two of those were police officers; the rest were from the armed forces.
Mission headquarters are in Kiev. Observers are stationed in 10 of the largest cities in Ukraine, and mobile teams are deployed.

Due to Russia´s attack on Ukraine all personnel was withdrawn and it will remain so until there is an overview of the situation and the future for Ukraine.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Having been a British colony by the name of Ceylon since 1802, Sri Lanka became an independent nation on 4 February 1948.
For the first 30 years after becoming independent, Sri Lanka could be proud of its progress, unusual for a third world country, featuring social welfare and a well-functioning democracy. Right leaning and left leaning governments alternated, with moderate right leaning United National Party and left leaning Sri Lanka Freedom Party, respectively, in power most of the time. But there were simmering ethnic and religious tensions all along. Nationalism in Sri Lanka was very much based on the culture of the Sinhalese Buddhist majority, and over time, political leaders have increasingly adopted a nationalist platform to the detriment of Sri Lankan and Indian Hindu Tamils. In 1948, Tamils of Indian descent had their civil rights revoked, and efforts were made to send them back to India. The ethnic tensions flared up in the 1970s with the emergence of the Tamil freedom movement Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) and the eruption of frequent anti-Tamil riots, the most violent ones taking place in 1983. A bloody civil war ensued, plaguing the country ever since. The Indian government for a time attempted to perform mediation and in 1987-1990 deployed troops on the island. Nationalist policies were evident in the new official name of the state, in constitutional reforms that departed from the British model, and in nationalisation of private interests. During the 1990s, the economy saw growth as a result of reforms and more liberal policies.
A constitutional reform was to provide greater autonomy for Tamil regions, but it was shelved for the time being in 2001. A ceasefire agreement was brokered by Norwegian officials in 2002, but the parties did not adhere to it. Since 2006, clashes between government forces and LTTE have erupted to include attacks close to the civilian airport and attacks on tourist destinations. The army mounted an offensive against LTTE bases in eastern Sri Lanka as of 2007. A minister was killed in 2008 by a roadside bomb, and the government then formally withdrew from the ceasefire agreement. The Sri Lanka army managed, after heavy battles, to conquer LTTE in 2009 and to kill the leaders of the movement. It is estimated that close to 70,000 people were killed during the civil war.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate for the mission is set out in ”Agreement on a Ceasefire between the Government of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam”. The parties entered into this agreement on 22 February 2002 as a result of mediation by the Norwegian government.
Article 3 of the ceasefire agreement contains a stipulation that an international mission led by Norway with personnel from Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, and Iceland is to be set up for the purpose of monitoring the ceasefire.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government made the decision to take part based on the ceasefire agreement and on the overall collaboration between Nordic countries.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The mission included these tasks:
- investigate any instance of violation of the conditions of the ceasefire;
- resolve any conflict instigated by the respective parties in the ceasefire;
- respond to complaints from the parties; and
- assist the parties in resolving any dispute or disagreement.

In particular, the mission was to monitor that the parties in the ceasefire refrained from actions against civilians, especially actions such as torture, intimidation, abductions, blackmail, and harassment.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was established in February 2002. By June 2006, the Tamil Tigers wanted mission participants from EU countries gone; hence personnel from Denmark, Sweden, and Finland were recalled. When the ceasefire failed, the remaining participants from Norway and Iceland were withdrawn in January 2008, and the mission was terminated.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Seven Danish police officers took part in the mission between 2002 and 2006 at the headquarters in Colombo, at district offices in Jaffna, Mannar, Vavuniya, Trincomalee, Batticaloa, and Ampara, and at a liaison office in Kilinochchi.

missions.title: SAPS South Africa
missions.subtitle: Police Missions in South Africa
missions.name: SAPS Sydafrika
missions.descriptiveName: South African Police Service, Goldstone Commission

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The colonial history of South Africa is similar in many ways to that of the rest of Africa, but the large white population and the discovery of diamonds and gold were instrumental in its unique development characterised by industrialisation that was more pervasive than in any other nation in Africa. The black population was oppressed in terms of political rights and economic opportunities. The white nationalist Reunited National Party came to power in 1948, introducing a strict racial discrimination policy known as apartheid.
Black political organisations such as the African National Congress (ANC) were declared illegal by the white regime in 1960, and the struggle against the white regime became more violent. Due to its policy of apartheid, South Africa was increasingly shunned by the international community. Therefore, negotiations were initiated in 1989 between the white regime and the ANC.
The leader of ANC, Nelson Mandela, had been in prison since 1962 and was released in 1990. Apartheid was officially abolished that year. In the first democratic election in 1994, ANC gained control of the parliament, and Nelson Mandela became president.
Danish Police has participated in several smaller missions in South Africa.

text.id: SAPS – Strategi for ledelsestræning i South African Police Service
text.heading: Leadership Training
text.text:
Since 1994, DANIDA and the Danish Police School have supported the delivery of several courses to instructors at the police academies in South Africa. In addition, they have supported an educational program designed for sergeants and supervisors of constables at police stations.
The Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 17 March 1999 requested that the National Police of Denmark provide a senior officer to take on an advisory role in an educational program for senior police officers in South Africa.
The task of this Danish senior officer was to build a more cohesive and more consistent curriculum of higher quality at the police academies.
He worked on this task from 1 April 1999 to 31 March 2002.

text.heading: Goldstone Commission
text.text:
As a result of the passage in the Parliament of South Africa of “The Prevention of Public Violence and Intimidation Act No. 139 of 1991”, then President F.W. de Klerk on 24 October 1991 established “The Commission of Inquiry regarding the Prevention of Public Violence and Intimidation” under the leadership of Judge Richard Goldstone. It was referred to as the Goldstone Commission.
The mandate of the commission, among other things, was to investigate events that had taken place after 17 July 1991 (the date of promulgation of the Act). In October 1992, the Commission set up five independent investigation teams. These teams were staffed by 13 police officers from the South African Police Service, 5 police officers from outside South Africa, and 10 lawyers. The investigation teams worked in Johannesburg, Cape Town, Port Elizabeth, Durban, and East London.
On request from Goldstone, Denmark provided a police officer. This officer was to work with and monitor the investigation teams.
The Goldstone Commission was terminated at the time of the election in 1994.Two Danish police officers were provided to the mission during its work.

text.id: Valgobservatører ved det første demokratiske valg i Sydafrika
text.heading: Election Observers
text.text:
For the election in April 1994, the EU set up an observation unit to monitor and observe it. In all, 307 election observers were sent from the EU. In addition, the UN and other international organisations sent election observers.
On request from the EU and upon a decision made by the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, a few Danish police officers were sent to work as election observers.
The head of the European Union Elections Unit has described the mandate and the election process in a 2 May 1994 document entitled “South Africa’s 1994 National and Provincial Election Statement”.

missions.title: TIPH Hebron
missions.subtitle: Agreement PLO - Israel
missions.name: TIPH Hebron
missions.descriptiveName: The Temporary International Presence in Hebron

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Jewish Purim celebration on 25 February 1994 fell during the Muslim Ramadan holy month. At 5 pm that day, about 800 Muslims were gathered for prayer in the Ibrahimi Mosque in Hebron when an American Jewish man started firing into the crowd with an automatic firearm. This resulted in the death of 29 Muslims; about 120 were injured. The perpetrator was caught and beaten to death by the crowd.
During the subsequent riots in the occupied territories, an additional 20 Palestinians were killed, and 120 were injured. In the next days, 21 Palestinians were killed by the IDF (Israel Defence Forces).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The UN Security Council in Resolution 904 of 18 March 1994 condemned the massacre. In this resolution, the Security Council called for increased security for the civilian Palestinian population. This would include a temporary international presence as provided in the “Declaration of Principles on Interim Self-Government Arrangements” signed by the PLO and Israel on 13 September 1993.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish government decided, on the basis of UN Resolution 904 and upon a submission to the Foreign Policy Committee, to take part.
PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat refused to participate in the peace negotiations in Oslo unless Israel accepted an international observation mission in Hebron. On 31 March 1994, representatives from the Israeli government and from the PLO signed a statement to request that Norway, Italy, and Denmark set up the TIPH mission with the objective of providing security and stability in Hebron.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The main objective for TIPH was to observe and report on the situation in Hebron, the operational area. The mission was to assist in monitoring and reporting on efforts to maintain ordinary life in the town of Hebron and to foster a sense of security among Palestinians. Reports were to be made about violations of international human rights and conventions and about episodes related to the Hebron agreement. These reports were to be shared with Palestinian and Israeli authorities as well as with authorities in the participating countries.
According to the agreement, TIPH was to handle the following specific tasks:
- Foster a sense of security among Palestinians in Hebron;
- Help build stability and an appropriate environment to facilitate better conditions for the Palestinians in Hebron and for the economic development of the area;
- Make observations as to enhanced peace and prosperity among the Palestinians;
- Provide assistance in facilitating and executing projects initiated by the donor countries and in fostering economic development and growth in Hebron; and fostering economic development and growth in Hebron.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The agreement encompassed three months of presence starting 8 May 1994. The mission was terminated on 8 August 1994. Following on negotiations between the parties, the mission was restarted on 1 February 1997. It now included observers from Turkey, Sweden, and Switzerland as well as from Norway, Italy, and Denmark. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu in January 2019 decided not to renew the mandate of TIPH.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark participated in the mission since its inception but withdrew from it in February 2016.
A total of about 105 Danish police officers have served in the mission. In addition, personnel from other government departments and civilians have served in the mission.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The colonial history of South Africa is similar in many ways to that of the rest of Africa, but the large white population and the discovery of diamonds and gold were instrumental in its unique development characterised by industrialisation that was more pervasive than in any other nation in Africa. The black population was oppressed in terms of political rights and economic opportunities. The white nationalist Reunited National Party came to power in 1948, introducing a strict racial discrimination policy known as apartheid.
Black political organisations such as the African National Congress (ANC) were declared illegal by the white regime in 1960, and the struggle against the white regime became more violent. Due to its policy of apartheid, South Africa was increasingly shunned by the international community. Therefore, negotiations were initiated in 1989 between the white regime and the ANC.
The leader of ANC, Nelson Mandela, had been in prison since 1962 and was released in 1990. Apartheid was officially abolished that year. In the first democratic election in 1994, ANC gained control of the parliament, and Nelson Mandela became president.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The mandate for the Truth Commission was approved by the Parliament of South Africa on 19 July 1995.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon a request from the South African government to provide investigators, the Danish government decided to take part in the mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The tasks of the Truth Commission were to:
- Investigate and shed light on gross violations of human rights in the period 1 March 1960 to 15 December
1993 and describe the circumstances and factors leading up to them;
- Seek out and identify the victims of such crimes and propose reparations and reinstatement of the dignity of each person; and
- Give amnesty to persons admitting to having perpetrated such violations for political purposes and propose ways to prevent such violations in future.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Upon approval in the Parliament of South Africa on 19 July 1995, the Truth Commission was established and initiated on 1 December 1995. The work of the Commission was considered complete by October 1998.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Danish police officers participated as investigators as of March 1996, and the last investigator was recalled in June 1999. At least 5 Danish investigators were sent to serve in the mission.
Participants from Ireland, Germany, Switzerland, Norway, Sweden, and Holland took part in the mission as well.

missions.title: UNDP and ONSA Iraq
missions.subtitle: Security Sector Reform
missions.name: UNDP & ONSA Irak
missions.descriptiveName: UN Development Program and Office of the National Sec. Adv.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Many arguments were made for and against action in Iraq, however in the end a coalition was formed, led by the U.S., for this purpose. Many other countries took part, including Denmark, the UK, and Australia. The coalition invaded Iraq and toppled Hussein. Then, the new Iraqi government needed help to rebuild the now fragile nation. One of the instruments used to assist the new government was the UN mission The United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI). This mission was set up in 2003 by the UN Security Council on request from the Iraqi government. The purpose of the mission was to support and improve the democratic systems in Iraq and to help coordinate humanitarian initiatives from the UN and other organisations working in Iraq. UNAMI is active in Iraq to this day.
The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) was approved in the UN General Assembly on 22 November 1965 and executed as of 1 January 1966. The objective of UNDP was and still is to eradicate poverty and reduce inequality and marginalisation. UNDP has a presence in over 170 countries, among them Iraq (from 1976). It assists these countries in developing policies, building leadership skills, setting up partnerships, and improving institutional capacity and resilience, with the overall goal of retaining development gains.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The impetus for the mandate is set out in UN Security Council Resolution 1483 of 22 May 2003. Here, the UN strategy for Iraq is described in general terms. Based on that resolution, the Security Council approved Resolution 1500 on 14 August 2003, establishing the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq (UNAMI).
The Secretary-General’s report S/2015/82 dated 2 February 2015 states in paragraph 35 that his special envoy to Iraq has had discussions with the Iraqi prime minister, the minister of justice, and several other ministers about a reform of the judiciary and of security functions. The ministers were presented with a draft reform prepared by UNAMI.
The Secretary-General’s report S/2016/77 dated 26 January 2016 states in paragraph 71 that UNDP has assisted the Iraqi government in preparing a national strategy for security. In the report, the Secretary-General commits that the mission will assist in the development of a security sector reform.
Since April 2015, UNDP in Iraq has collaborated at a high level with the Iraqi Office of the National Security Advisor (ONSA) on the planning for a security sector reform.
On 3 September 2015, support for phase II of the security sector reform was rolled out in Baghdad with financial contributions from Denmark, Holland, and the UK.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government made the decision to participate on the basis of proposals B8 of 10 November 2015 and B108 of 19 April 2016. In official comments on proposal B108 it is noted that plans are to dispatch a police adviser from the National Police of Denmark. In a government document entitled “The Fight against Terror” dated May 2016, it is noted (page 115) that funds were set aside in 2015 to support a reform of the security sector in Iraq.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Denmark took part in the project during phase II as a financial donor along with Holland, the UK, and later Japan. UNDP and ONSA had jointly prepared a program and timetable for this phase including short term, medium term, and long term priorities for building an effective security sector in Iraq.
In this program, the police mission was to focus on these areas:
- Supervision and allocation of responsibility with respect to democracy;
- A national structure for security;
- A criminal justice system and civilian police work; and
- A law enforcement system.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The UNDP mission has been active since April 2016 and is still ongoing in Iraq.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Since April 2016, Danish Police has provided a Senior Police Adviser to the Office of the National Security Advisor (ONSA) in Baghdad. So far, two senior police officers from Denmark have worked in the mission.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Columbus discovered the island of Hispaniola in 1492. It was populated primarily by indigenous people. Over time, Spaniards took over the island. They settled on the eastern part of the island while French pirates gradually settled on the western part. In 1697, the western part officially became a French colony by the name of Saint-Domingue. France operated sugar and cotton plantations by the use of slave labour, and at the end of the 1700s, African slaves made up 90% of the population. After the French Revolution in 1789, an insurrection by slaves broke out, and France lost its dominion over the area. British and Spanish troops now invaded, and slavery was abolished in 1794.
The British were expelled in 1798 by in an insurrection led by an African who also took control of the Spanish part of the island, Santo Domingo.  France again attempted to take control of the island, but in 1804, the western part of the island declared independence under the name Haiti. Now came tumultuous times of rebellions, revolutions, counter-revolutions, and battles between blacks and people of mixed race. The Spanish part of the island declared independence in 1843 under the name The Dominican Republic. The United States invaded Haiti in 1915 to restore stability. This occupation lasted until 1934. The U.S. retained considerable influence in the country through its connection with the mixed-race population. A powerful black nationalist movement arose in reaction and brought François Duvalier, Papa Doc, to power in 1957. He set himself up as dictator and president for life. He was succeeded in 1971 by his son Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc. He was overthrown in 1986 as a result of a massive popular uprising. It took until 1990 for free elections to be held. Jean-Bertrand Aristide came to power. He was ousted in 1991 in a coup led by General Raoul Cédras. Strong international pressure brought about negotiations under the auspices of the UN between Cédras and Aristide. American troops were deployed, and the negotiations resulted in Aristide returning from exile to resume his presidency. In the 1995 presidential election, a candidate supported by Aristide won. Aristide could not run in this election due to provisions in the constitution.

The agreement between Cédras and Aristide was named the Governors Island Agreement of 3 July 1993 after the island in New York Harbor where it was signed.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: UN Security Council Resolution 867 of 23 September 1993 created the mandate for United Nations Mission in Haiti (UNMIH).

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The Danish government responded to a request from the UN, made on 25 October 1994, for police officers to serve in this mission.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
Paragraph 5(c) of the Governors Island Agreement set out an expectation that international assistance would be forthcoming to modernise the armed forces and build a new police force, and paragraph 7 dealt with adoption of a law establishing the new police force.

Per the UN mandate, the UN was to provide assistance as follows:
- Advice, guidance, and training for all levels of the Haitian police force; and
- Monitoring the implementation of this process and handling other tasks arising from any decision made by the UN.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission was launched in September 1993 and ended in June 1996. It was followed in December 1997 by a new mission, United Nations Civilian Police Mission in Haiti (MIPONUH), with the same remit. This mission ended in March 2000.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Initially, the UN planned for 567 UN police officers to work in the mission. Later, the mandate was raised to 900 police officers. At its largest, the force numbered 847 officers. A total of 20 nations sent police officers.
Denmark contributed three police officers to this mission. They served from 2 December 1994 to 2 February 1995.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The government of Croatia and Serbian negotiators on 12 November 1995 reached a peace agreement entitled ”Basic Agreement on the Region of Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Syrmia”.
This agreement stated that the UN would install an administration to govern the region during a transition period. UN Security Council Resolution 1037 of 15 January 1996 provided for the United Nations Transitional Administration for Eastern Slavonia, Baranja and Western Sirmium (UNTAES) mission. An international military force and a civilian police force were to be deployed during the transitional period to keep the peace and keep the area secure. At the end of this period, the mission would become a police mission only.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: UN Security Council Resolution 1145 of 19 December 1997 contains the mandate for United Nations Civilian Police Support Group (UNPSG) sent to Eastern Slavonia, Baranja, and Western Sirmium. This mission was to replace the previous one, UNTAES.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Upon a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee with respect to UN resolutions and upon request from the UN, the Danish government decided to offer personnel.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
UNPSG was to undertake the same tasks that UNTAES (q.v.) had carried out, especially:
- Monitoring of Croatian police in the Danube region; and
- Assisting with the return of refugees and displaced persons.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mandate for UNTAES expired on 15 January 1998, and UNPSG assumed responsibility on 16 January. Personnel and other UN assets were transferred from UNTAES to this new mission. The mission was slated to last 9 months until 15 October 1998 when OSCE Police Monitoring Group would take over as of 16 October 1998.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Danish Police has participated during the entire mission. The exact number of participants in UNPSG cannot be determined as they are part of the larger group of about 700 Danish police officers who have been deployed to Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Macedonia in various police missions performed by the UN, EU, and OSCE.
Police officers from the following countries participated: Argentina, Austria, Denmark, Egypt, Fiji, Finland, Indonesia, Ireland, Jordan, Kenya, Lithuania, Norway, Poland, Russia, Sweden, Switzerland, Ukraine, and USA.

missions.title: UNSCO West Bank and Gaza
missions.subtitle: Police assist peace process
missions.name: UNSCO Vestbredden og Gaza
missions.descriptiveName: Office of UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process

text.heading: Background
text.text:
When the state of Israel was proclaimed in Tel Aviv on 14 May 1948, a war erupted between this new state and the neighbouring Arab states. The latter were supported by other Arab nations. The 1948-49 war had a huge impact on the Arab residents in Palestine. When a ceasefire was reached in 1949, Israel was larger than the area specified in the UN partition plan. The West Bank had been taken by Transjordan and in 1950 became a part of Jordan while Gaza was occupied by Egypt until 1967. Nothing came of the Arab Palestine state that had been planned, and more than 700,000 Palestinians became refugees as a result of the war and were housed in refugee camps in Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, and Syria.

A nationalist Palestinian movement emerged during the 1950s. Financial assets left behind by Palestinian refugees in Israel were nationalised in the early 1950s, and the remaining Palestinians were under surveillance although they became Israeli citizens with full political rights. The Palestine Liberation Organization, PLO, was established in 1964 on the instigation of the Arab League. As of 1968, the Palestinians took control of the organisation. During the 1970s, PLO was recognised by the Arab world and most of the Third World as the legitimate representative of the Palestinian people, and through the 1980s, the organisation achieved a certain level of recognition in Europe. The U.S. refused to recognise PLO, and the Israeli view was that it was a terrorist organisation with which negotiations could not be undertaken. As a result of the impact of the Palestinian uprising, the Intifada, in 1987 and the Gulf War in 1991, a group of Palestinians and Israelis negotiating in Oslo reached an agreement in which the to parties recognised each other as legitimate representatives of the Palestinian and Israeli people and committed to the creation of a future Palestinian state made up of Gaza and the West Bank. These areas are now the Palestinian National Authority.

On 10 September 1993, Israel and PLO formally acknowledged each other. PLO acknowledged Israel’s right to exist as a nation, and Israel acknowledged PLO as the representative of the Palestinian people.
On 13 September 1993, the Oslo agreement was signed in Washington by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat with U.S. President Bill Clinton and Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrei V. Kozyrev in attendance.
In March, the UN appointed a Special Coordinator for the peace process in the Middle East.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: Based on the Oslo agreement, the UN approved Resolution A/RES/48/213 on 15 March 1994. It provided the Secretary-General a mandate to take on an active role in the efforts to implement the Oslo agreement and tasked him with coordinating donations for the rebuilding process in Palestine.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: After a briefing to the Foreign Policy Committee and upon request from the UN, the Danish government decided to make available some police advisers.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The role of the police advisers, per plans from 1997, were many and varied. Their work included:

- Facilitating and assisting in the preparatory work to establish a Police Academy in Jericho;
- Coordinating donor countries’ contributions and identifying new donors to support training and materiel for the Palestinian Police Force and
- Identifying requirements for training, planning and prioritising the work, monitoring activities, and evaluating the training of police.

 Specifically, the Danish advisers were to:
- Coordinate guidelines for training and materiel for the Palestinian Police Force (PPF), handle coordination with the Palestinian authorities and with donors, and represent the Resident Coordinator in the donor countries’ coordination committees and
- Assist the Palestinian Police Academy in determining educational requirements and advise regarding planning and organisation of the educational program for the Palestinian police in the donor countries or in Gaza or in the West Bank.

 The Resident Coordinator was an envoy from the UN. From his office in Gaza, he was responsible for coordinating the donor countries’ donations and direct them toward suitable projects benefiting the Palestinian people.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: UNSCO was established in June 1994. The mission has been extended several times and is still active in the occupied areas of Palestine.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Between 1998 and 2001, senior police officers from Denmark worked in this mission as advisers for the UN Special Coordinator/Resident Coordinator in matters related to the education of Palestinian police and to the coordination of financial and material assistance from donor countries.
In all, five senior police officers worked in the mission. The police advisers were stationed in Gaza City.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Following on hundreds of years of ethnic tensions in Cyprus, a minor civil war broke out on 21 December 1963 between Greek and Turkish Cypriots. The conflict was rooted in fundamental disagreements as to the implementation of the constitution of newly independent Cyprus. These disagreements included the diametrically opposed national aspirations of the two groups.
The situation in Cyprus was dire. The UK, former colonial ruler of the island, therefore called the parties to the negotiating table. Here, it was decided to create a neutral zone by withdrawing Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot units to a ceasefire line in Nicosia referred to as the ”Green Line” (it had been drawn on the map with a green pen).
Still, the hostility between the two population groups was deep, complicating the British effort at conflict resolution. An international solution was called for. This solution was found on 4 March 1964 in the form of a UN-organised peacekeeping mission named United Nations Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP).
Nevertheless, the mission was unable to contain the ethnic tensions on the island while at the same time, Greece and Turkey actively resisted a solution to the conflict.

On 15 July 1974, with support from Greece, Greek Cypriot resistance group EOKA B and parts of the Greek Cypriot National Guard carried out a coup against the Cyprus government.  Turkey viewed this coup as an attempt at annexation on the part of the military junta in Athens. In response, Turkey on 20 July 1974 initiated an invasion of the northern part of Cyprus.
The Greek Cypriot National Guard immediately mobilised a battle-ready army of almost 40,000 men, and fighting broke out in and around the many enclaves on both sides of the Green Line. The peacekeeping UN forces were caught in the middle without a mandate to do anything about the military action.
After just under a month of heavy fighting, the Turkish force had conquered and now controlled about 40% of Cyprus. The invasion sent nearly 160,000 Greek Cypriots fleeing toward the southern part of Cyprus. Many of them had been forcibly evicted by the invading Turkish forces. Conversely, many Turkish Cypriots left their homes in the Greek area.
With Turkey’s military gains, the parties entered into a ceasefire on 16 August 1974. The demilitarised zone controlled by UNFICYP, known as the Green Line, was expanded to cover the area between the two fronts across the entire island (referred to as the status quo). This line is still a de facto border between Northern and Southern Cyprus.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
On 4 March 1964, the UN Security Council issued Resolution 186 exhorting the government of Cyprus to use any means necessary to end the terrible bloodshed and demanding restraint from the parties. The Security Council in the resolution called for a UN-administered peacekeeping mission (with consent from the government of Cyprus).  The composition and size of the mission were to be determined by the UN Secretary-General in consultation with the governments of Cyprus, Greece, Turkey, and the UK.
The mandate of the mission was limited; it was to prevent further armed conflict and if necessary contribute to the reinstatement of law and order in Cyprus. The mission could use armed force only in self defence.
Upon Turkey’s invasion into Cyprus in June 1974, the UN Security Council issued Resolution 353 as a follow-up. In it, the Security Council demanded that all foreign powers immediately withdraw their military forces from Cyprus. In addition, the Security Council called for peace negotiations between Greece, Turkey, and the UK. The Turkish invasion led to several other resolutions that condemned the unilateral invasion of Cyprus and expressed concern about the fate of the many refugees.
As of August 1974, UNFICYP was tasked with monitoring the recent ceasefire between the two parties and with assisting in the maintenance of status quo.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
On 30 April 1964, a unanimous Danish Parliament approved the formation of a permanent Danish UN emergency force that could be deployed upon request from the UN and upon an assessment of the overall situation. With this approval, the government authorised deployment of Danish soldiers in peacekeeping missions executed by the UN. In practice, however, such deployments take place once discussions have been held in the Foreign Policy Committee and once legislated funding has been sought.
Shortly thereafter and upon consultation with the Foreign Policy Committee, the Danish government decided to send a Danish contingent to the UN peacekeeping mission in Cyprus.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contingent, DANCON, worked in the Green Line area in Nicosia from 1964 to 1970. The contingent at first numbered 1,000. The assignment was to keep the two parties from engaging in any further armed clashes.
In 1968, UNFICYP succeeded in arranging political negotiations between the two warring parties. As a result, UNFICYP was reduced in size; DANCON now numbered 300. At the same time, a reorganisation of the overall UN force took place. DANCON assumed responsibility for the Lefka District, a mountainous area in the northwestern part of the island. In the area were several larger Turkish enclaves and smaller Turkish villages.
Upon the Turkish invasion in August 1974, the total manpower of UNFICYP was increased from about 2,300 to about 4,400. The Danish contingent, DANCON, was increased from 220 to 430 men in the course of a few days. Now, the maintenance of status quo was performed by constant surveillance and patrolling in the demilitarised buffer zone.
Since 1975, the number of shooting incidents and advances between Turkish and Greek Cypriots has been decreasing significantly. Therefore, UNFICYP and DANCON were cut in size in 1976.
From 1990 to 1992, the Chief of Staff position was held by a Danish brigadier general. A Danish staff officer worked at UNFICYP from 1993 to 1994. Then, the mission was over for Denmark.
The position of UNFICYP Head of Mission, the diplomatic chief of the mission, was held by a Dane from 2006 to 2008.

 

The UN Secretary-General in April 1964 decided to establish a UN police force in Cyprus (UNCIVPOL). This police force was to assist Cypriot authorities in carrying out the many police related tasks arising out of the civil war such as matters related to murder, hostage taking, and missing persons. Initially, Denmark contributed DANCIVPOL, a police contingent of 40. The Danish police contingent was recalled in 1975 after having served for over ten years. This peacekeeping police mission was the first one in which Denmark supplied nearly 500 personnel.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
To begin with, it was DANCON’s job to monitor the military forces of the two parties by manning a series of UN observation posts and performing patrols in vehicles. The unit in addition handled communications between Greek and Turkish Cypriots and took care of many civilian assignments such as dealing with problems related to water and power, ensuring farmers could access their own fields in the buffer zone under surveillance by the enemy, and facilitating the return of Turkish and Greek Cypriot refugees to abandoned villages.
The situation changed significantly after the ceasefire in 1974. In particular, the Danish camps in Kokkina, Limnitis, Lefka, and Xeros were now in an area controlled by Turkey.
As an extension of the mandate from 1964, the UN Secretary-General issued a directive that UNFICYP was to: Monitor troop deployment on both sides; maintain status quo in the demilitarised zone; monitor the ceasefire; facilitate activities across the ceasefire line; provide humanitarian assistance in all areas of the island; and collaborate with the Turkish-Greek Cypriot police, the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), and the UN Development Programme (UNDP).
During the retaking of the observation posts after the ceasefire, a Danish UN forces van hit an anti-tank mine. Two Danish UN soldiers were killed, and two were wounded.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
In 1992, Denmark decided to recall its contribution to UNFICYP in light of an assessment that recent conflicts in the former Yugoslavia had a higher priority. In total, about 23,000 Danish soldiers have served in 57 teams in Cyprus from 1964 to 1992.
On 15 November 1983, the northern part of Cyprus declared independence as the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. Turkey approved the declaration of independence the same day. The UN Security Council responded by issuing Resolutions 541 and 550 in which it stated that the declaration was illegal and requested that no other sovereign states recognise the Turkish-Cypriot declaration of independence.
Without success, several attempts on the part of the EU and the UN to solve the conflict have been made since the Turkish invasion in 1974. Ever since, any solution to the conflict has been stranded politically. However, there have been changes on the island since 2003 when border crossings between Northern and Southern Cyprus were opened for the first time since 1974.
The UNFICYP mission has not succeeded in resolving the underlying ethnic tensions driving the conflict. That said, the mission was justified as it curbed aggressions between Turkish and Greek Cypriots and maintained the key provisions of the ceasefire. Thus, UNFICYP has created the preconditions for reaching a long term peace accord between the two parties on the island.

The UNFICYP mission is still active. All told, 183 UN soldiers lost their lives in Cyprus, primarily due to illness and not due to military action.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
FRONTEX is based on the Schengen agreement, which is an inter-governmental partnership between various EU member states. The partnership began in 1985, when Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and West Germany concluded an agreement on free movement, i.e. the removal of border controls. The agreement applies to persons crossing land borders between states that have signed the Schengen Agreement, as well as at airports and ports in participating countries. Denmark signed the Schengen Convention in 1996 and has, in practice, taken part in the partnership since 26 March 2001.
In counterpoint to the free movement of people between participating countries, border controls have been tightened at the external borders of the Schengen countries.
The Schengen Convention includes various agreements about policing and legal partnerships on criminality, the fight against narcotics and setting up the Schengen Information System (SIS), which grants member states access to information about certain categories of people and objects.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders was formed when the EU adopted Council Regulation 2007/2004 of 26 October 2004 and named FRONTEX. Its purpose is to assist EU member states and associated Schengen participants in the protection of external borders around EU territories.
Regulation (EC) No. 863/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council established a mechanism for the creation of a standing corps of personnel for rapid deployment to intervene at operational level on behalf of individual member states requiring support.
Regulation (EC) No. 1168/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2011 established an agency for the management of operational cooperation at the external borders of the member states of the European Union.
Regulation (EU) No 656/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 established rules for the surveillance of the external sea borders of member states of the European Union.
Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 September 2016 repealed regulations 2007/2004 and 863/2007. This regulation also renamed the agency “the European Border and coast Guard Agency.”
Regulation (EU) 2019/1896 of the European Parliament as published in the official journal of the European Union L 295/1 on 4 November 2019 outlines the currently applicable regulations pertaining to FRONTEX. This regulation replaces and supersedes all other relevant regulations, with the exception of regulation 656/2014 on the surveillance of external sea borders. In addition regulation 1052/2013 (EU) and 2016/2016 outlines tasks and country.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
In a decision report from the 11th session of the Danish Parliament’s Europe Committee on 21 November 2003 (c.f. item 36), a majority of parliamentary parties mandated the Danish Government's endorsement of the EU Commission's proposal to set up an independent border control agency.
Because of Denmark’s opt-out, Denmark does not take part in supra-national legislation in this sector, doing so only on the basis of an inter-governmental partnership.
Members of the Danish Parliament’s Europe Committee were informed in a memo of 31 March 2005 that Denmark would shortly inform the European Council about its intention to implement the regulation (No. 2007/2004 of 26 October 2004) by incorporating it into Danish Law.

text.heading: Missions
text.text:
The duties of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency are described in Article 10 of Regulation (EU) 2019/1896.
Duties that are of relevance to the police component of the agency include:
-monitoring of migration and the preparation of risk assessment analyses insofar as concerns all aspects of integrated borders management,
- monitoring of member states’ operational requirements with regard to repatriation,
- analysis of vulnerabilities, including assessment of member states’ capacities and readiness to deal with challenges and threats to the external borders,
- monitoring external border administration and compliance with basic rights at the external borders with regard to repatriations,
- technical and operative support when deploying joint rapid deployments at high load external borders which involve humanitarian situations of serious nature. The support also includes sea rescues and aid to member and third party states with regard to search and rescue operations involving people in danger at sea,
- the deployment of the standing corps to assist in border management, migration control and repatriations,
Duties related to migration control support in hotspots include:
(a) the deployment of personnel and technical equipment to assist in the screening, reporting, identification and recording of fingerprints;
(b) establishing a procedure for providing initial information to persons in need of or wishing to apply for international protection, including a procedure for the identification of vulnerable groups, in cooperation with the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and national authorities,
- assistance in all phases of the repatriation process, including support for coordination and organisation, the creation of observer pools in scenarios involving forced repatriations and the establishment of repatriation teams,
- cooperation with Europol and Eurojust and support to member states where technical and operational assistance is needed at the external borders to combat cross-border crime and terrorism,
-collaboration with EASO and the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) to ensure that rejected asylum seekers are treated in accordance with current EU legislation on fundamental rights, and
- assistance to member states and third countries in the training of personnel such as border guards and repatriation experts, through the establishment of common training standards and joint programmes.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The agency commenced operations on 1 May 2005, pursuant to Article 34 of Regulation (EU) 2007/2004. Article 121 of the most recent EU regulation (2019/1896) requires an evaluation of operations by 5 december 2023, with subsequent evaluations every four years.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Danish police officers have been deployed to FRONTEX since 2008. So far, these have been continued deployments. Because of the current (2020) pressure from migrants and asylum seekers at the EU’s external borders, Danish police officers will continue to be deployed to FRONTEX missions in coming years.
Danish police officers have been deployed to a variety of missions and functions, including:
-A First Line Officer, who is authorised to carry out border controls at airports and border crossings,
-A Second Line Officer, who performs actual case processing,
-Fingerprint experts, who perform identity checks,
-Debriefing experts, whose role is to debrief migrants and asylum seekers, gather intelligence and update the EU’s information system,
- Personnel to accompany rejected migrants and asylum seekers who are to be forcibly repatriated to their country of origin,
- Dog handlers for cross-border deployment, including at the border between Greece and Turkey,
-Contributions in the form of seagoing vessels. Danish officers have been deployed to two patrol boat contributions in the Mediterranean since mid-2019. Each patrol boat crew is comprised of two Danish police officers with executive authority and four Danish Defence personnel, who are responsible for the technical operation of the two patrol boats.
- Three Danish officers are continually deployed to the FRONTEX headquarters in Warsaw.
Regulation 2016/1624 authorised the EU to assist third countries with border controls. Danish police officers have been deployed to the airport in Georgia as documentation advisers. Personnel have also been deployed to airports in Riga, Brussels, Amsterdam and Athens.
Danish police officers have maintained a continual presence as part of Operation Poseidon in Greece, including on the islands of Lesbos, Chios, Kos and Samos.
Danish officers are mainly deployed for shorter duration postings, i.e.up to four months at a time. Joint Operation Indalo has the aim of to combat illegal immigration from North Africa and Sub-Sahara, resulting from a cyclical seasonal increase as well as protracted crisis in Mali.
In Februar 2022 Frontex launched a new operation at EU’s external land border. The activity – Joint Operation Terra 2022 – will take place across 12 EU Member States and cover 62 border crossing points. 
The joint operation with Albania marks a new phase for border cooperation between the EU and Western Balkan partners. Similar agreements were initialled with North Macedonia (July 2018), Serbia (September 2018), Bosnia and Herzegovina (January 2019) and Montenegro (February 2019)

missions.title: EMASoH Hormuz
missions.subtitle: Maritime Awareness In the Strait of Hormuz
missions.name: EMASoH Hormuz
missions.descriptiveName: European Maritime Awareness In the Strait of Hormuz

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The USA and Iran have had no formal diplomatic relations since the Iranian Revolution of 1979.
The relationship between the two countries has been largely based on conflict, and has been characterised by mutual hostility and economic sanctions. In 2003, the International Atomic Energy Agency reported that Iran possessed the prerequisite capabilities for the enrichment of uranium. This prompted the United States to accuse Iran of developing a nuclear weapons program, which is a violation of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty to which Iran is a party.
The UN Security Council ordered Iran to stop enriching uranium, which it refused to do, claiming that the enriched uranium was for peaceful use in their nuclear reactors. Nevertheless, the Security Council implemented extensive international sanctions against Iran in 2006, the EU following suit later on. These sanctions had major consequences for the Iranian economy. In 2015, the US, China, Russia, France and the United Kingdom (within the UN Security Council), as well as Germany and the EU, managed to negotiate a long-term nuclear deal with Iran. According to the terms of this deal, Iran would destroy its medium-grade enriched uranium, 98% of their low-grade enriched uranium and, over a 13 year period, 2/3 of the centrifuges used for uranium enrichment. In return, US, UN and EU sanctions were lifted.

When Donald Trump was elected as president of the United States, there was a shift in the USA’s policy on Iran. Even before the election, Trump had criticised the nuclear deal, calling it a bad deal. The USA protested that Iran would be able to build an atomic bomb within 12 months, before the end of the agreement. Trump tried initially to negotiate a new deal, but this failed. Therefore, in May 2018, the USA chose to withdraw from the nuclear deal, and US sanctions were thus resumed. At the same time, Trump threatened to sanction European states and companies that continued to trade with Iran. This meant that the sanctions against Iran were now an international reality.
In May-June 2019, Iran was accused of deliberately disrupting commercial shipping after several tankers were sabotaged in the Gulf of Oman. Iran shot down a US surveillance drone over the Strait of Hormuz on June 20, further escalating the situation. On July 4, British Royal Marines attacked an Iranian oil tanker, Grace 1, near Gibraltar on suspicion that the ship was carrying crude oil to Syria in violation of EU sanctions. On July 19, following threats and an earlier failed attempt, Iran successfully confiscated a British-registered oil tanker, Steno Impero, as it sailed through the Strait of Hormuz. This strait links the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman and is extremely important for global oil exports.
To secure international shipping traffic in the area, the USA created the multinational International Maritime Security Construct (IMSC) mission, with participation by the United Kingdom, Albania, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates. A European mission led by France was also launched to complement the US-led efforts in the area.
European Maritime Awareness In the Strait of Hormuz (EMASoH) was created on 20 February by nine European countries (France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Finland, Greece, the Netherlands, Portugal and Denmark).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The EMASoH mission is governed by international law, including the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, which contains a number of provisions on free navigation and harmless passage for, among other things. warships in international straits like the Strait of Hormuz. The EMASoH mission’s area of operations is the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz and the Arabian Sea.
The Danish contribution will thus have the right to use force in self-defence, as well as to defend other EMASoH and IMSC military units (based on the principle of collective self-defence). Because international law does not grant states the right to acts of self-defence on behalf of commercial ships, EMASoH will only be mandated to assist such vessels if the attack comes from a non-state actor (such as pirates or paramilitary units with no insignia).
Since it is considered to be highly unlikely that Iran would use its own military troops with insignia to sabotage tankers, a construction under international law of this nature will also be sufficient to provide security for commercial shipping traffic in the area.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
As the world's fifth largest maritime nation, the right to free navigation is crucial to Danish economic interests. Therefore, on 11 June 2020, the Danish Parliament decided in resolution B160 (86 votes in favour and 9 against) to contribute to the EMASoH mission by participating in operation AGENOR by deploying an Iver Huitfeldt class frigate. A staff contribution of up to approx. five people will also be deployed.
A staff contribution of two personnel has already been deployed to the mission’s headquarters in Abu Dhabi, on the basis of a consultation on 12 December 2019 with the Danish Foreign Policy Committee.
In the event that the mission falls under Danish command, an addtional staff contribution of up to approx. 20 personnel could be additionally deployed.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish contribution was comprised of Royal Danish Navy frigate Iver Huitfeldt with associated Seahawk helicopter and a maritime intervention unit. The total contribution  consisted of up to approx. 170 personnel including the maritime intervention unit, hereunder mine divers, military police and naval special forces.
The frigate’s mission was to create security in the area of operations by maintaining a presence, monitoring and the establishment of a maritime situational overview in the area.
Two personnel have been posted in advance as a staff contribution to the mission’s headquarters in Abu Dhabi. The staff contribution supports the overall mission's combined mission fulfilment, for example by performing planning and coordination duties.

Denmark was responsibel for the European Maritime Operation AGENOR from the 13th of January 2021 until July 2021. Denmark manned the positions chief of operations, chief of the international staff and a number of other key functions in the staff of all in all 20-25 persons. The staff was co-located with the France Mission’s headquarters in Abu Dhabi where staff officers still are deplyed.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The Danish contribution to EMASoH was deployed from the beginning of August 2020 until December.

The Danish contribution to AGENOR was deployed from the middle of January 2021 until July.

American and European surveillance missions are closely linked to the general level of conflict between Iran and the USA. Iran's aggression towards commercial shipping during May-June 2019 has led to a further escalation of the conflict between the two sides.
Two proxy attacks against US positions in Iraq were conducted at the end of December 2019. Here, Iranian-backed militias carried out a rocket attack on an Iraqi base that housed personnel deployed as part of Operation Inherent Resolve. The attack wounded several members of the Iraqi security forces, four American soldiers, and killed one American citizen. A few days later, the US embassy in Baghdad was attacked by Iranian-backed militias.
The USA responded on January 3, 2020, when Major General Qassem Soleimani, of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard, was assassinated in an American drone attack on the Iraqi capital, Baghdad. Soleimani was a powerful political and military figure in Iran and the broader Middle East, and was considered the architect of Iran's activist policy in the region, for example by providing support to various militias and terrorist organisations in countries such as Iraq, Yemen, the Lebanon and Afghanistan.
The killing of Soleimani was a significant escalation of the conflict. In a revenge attack on January 8, 2020, Iran fired several ballistic missiles at the Al Asad Airbase in Iraq. The attack wounded 120 American soldiers. 130 Danish soldiers were also present at the base as part of the Operation Inherent Resolve training mission. The Danish soldiers were subsequently evacuated to Kuwait until the situation was back under control.
It was in the immediate aftermath of the rocket attack that Iran accidentally shot down a Ukrainian passenger plane, killing all 176 people on board.

The situation has de-escalated slightly since the tense crisis in January 2020, . American positions in Iraq were, however, regularly attacked by Iranian-backed militias between February and March 2020.
As long as Iran and the USA have opposing interests in the region, the relationship between the two countries will be one that is based on conflict. This has been so since the Iranian Revolution of 1979.
