missions.title: ERCC - the EU civil protection mechanism
missions.subtitle: Fast, efficient and coordinated assistance
missions.name: ERCC - EU-civilbeskyttelsesmekanismen

text.heading: Background
text.text:
This mechanism was first set up in 2001 and underwent a reform in 2013 to focus more on disaster prevention and preparedness. The EU civil protection mechanism (commonly referred to as the European Emergency Response Centre (ERCC)) includes a European emergency response capacity. It is a voluntary pool of resources which the EU countries have already earmarked for immediate deployment in or outside the EU. One of its elements is the European medical corps. This is a pool of doctors and public health experts that can be quickly deployed to emergency or intervention operations. A centre called “the European Emergency Coordination Centre” (ERCC) has been set up to coordinate the activities and is the civil protection mechanism’s operational core: It is open around the clock and coordinates the EU's disaster response.

The Council decided to amend the EU civil protection mechanism on 7 March 2019. The aim of the new rules was to:

  • create a complementary pool of resources for situations where overall existing capacities are insufficient,
  • strengthen the existing voluntary pool of national capacities,
  • improve risk prevention by obligating member states to further develop their assessment of their risk management capacity and risk management planning and
  • promote education and knowledge sharing.

On 8 February 2020, the Council reached a provisional agreement with the European Parliament on a proposal to strengthen measures. The new rules include a total of €1,263 million in funding for 2021-2027 and up to €2,056 million to implement civil protection measures as defined in the EU recovery instrument to address the effects of the COVID-19 crisis.

In a joint declaration by the members of the European Council of 26 March 2020 and in the resolution of the European Parliament of 17 April 2020 on a coordinated EU action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences, the Commission was encouraged to propose a more ambitious and comprehensive crisis management system in the Union.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The EU civil protection mechanism, which is regulated by decisions of the European Parliament and of the Council, strengthens cooperation between the Union and the Member States and promotes coordination in the field of civil protection in order to improve the response to natural and man-made disasters. There are a number of documents from the European Parliament and the Council of Europe which have generally mandated an established standing Civil Protection Group, which is responsible for discussing issues related to civil protection, making decisions about interventions and addressing Member States.

The Civil Protection Group is responsible for

  • disaster prevention, preparedness and response in scenarios such as floods, forest fires and earthquakes (inside and outside the EU);
  • matters involving EU countries’ mutual emergency assistance;
  • collaboration in the protection of critical European infrastructure and
  • increased chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear safety in the EU.

The group contacts Member States on the Council’s behalf about aid in the event of disasters and related collaborations.

While the primary responsibility for prevention, preparedness and response to natural and man-made disasters lies with the Member States themselves, the EU mechanism and in particular rescEU shall, in accordance with Article 3(3) of the Treaty on the European Union, promote solidarity between Member States. With rescEU, a new European reserve was set up, comprising, among other things, fire-fighting aircraft and helicopters, evacuation aircraft, stocks of medical equipment and emergency hospitals. This will strengthen the collective response in the event of natural disasters and man-made disasters by creating a reserve of capacities that complement Member States’ existing capacities.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: The decision about the Danish contribution will be made by the Danish Ministry of Defence, in collaboration with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark where appropriate. Funding of these deployments will come from within the Danish Ministry of Defence budget or from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark’s flexible pool.

text.heading: Contribution and Mission
text.text:
The protection that the EU mechanism covers involves, in particular, the protection of human beings, but also the environment and property (including cultural heritage) against all kinds of natural and man-made disasters, including the consequences of terrorism, technological disasters, radiation disasters, environmental disasters, marine pollution; hydrogeological instability and acute public health crises arising in or outside the Union. With regard to the consequences of acts of terrorism or radiation disasters, the EU mechanism can only cover emergency and response measures.

Danish efforts have, over the years, included a number of minor deployments to disaster areas both within the EU and outside (Albania, Sweden, Greece, Syria and the Philippines). This has included among other things

  • forest fires,
  • earthquakes,
  • epidemics (COVID-19),
  • transport tasks,
  • the establishment of smaller-scale facilities for staffs and
  • the deployment of healthcare personnel

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The Gulf of Guinea is important to Danish and international shipping. As the world's fifth largest maritime nation, the right to free navigation is crucial to Danish interests. An average of 30-40 Danish-operated ships sail through the Gulf of Guinea every day. The Danish presence is not only an important source of jobs and prosperity for Denmark, but for the countries of this region too. 
The maritime security situation in the Gulf of Guinea has deteriorated considerably over the last year, which has had a significantly negative impact on Danish shipping companies. Danish-operated ships were attacked by pirates in these waters during both 2020 and 2021.
In 2020, about 40% of all globally reported incidents of piracy took place in the Gulf of Guinea, the vast majority of these off the Nigerian coast, with a smaller number off Ghana, Togo, Benin, Cameroon and Gabon. Furthermore, almost 95% of all maritime abductions in 2020 took place in the Gulf of Guinea. Simultaneous to this, pirates seem to be increasingly willing to attack all types and sizes of trading and fishing vessels, including large container ships at distances as far away as 200 nautical miles from the coast. 
Denmark has had a close collaboration and ongoing dialogue about maritime security with, notably, Nigeria, Ghana and several regional collaborative forums, including the regional security architecture – Yaoundé Code of Conduct, which brings together 25 West African coastal states. Denmark is also part of the G7++ friends of the Gulf of Guinea, which has a number of international partners, including the USA, Canada, France, Germany, Norway, the Netherlands and a number of international organisations.
Denmark's involvement in this region also includes collaborations with stakeholders such as the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC).

text.heading: Mandate
text.text: The basis in international law for the Danish military contribution is the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, Chapter VIII of which, among other things, contains general provisions on the access of naval vessels to take measures to combat piracy in international waters. If the Danish military contribution is to operate within the maritime and land territory of coastal states, consent from the relevant states is sought to the extent necessary. Danish military contributions have a mandate for the use of force pursuant to the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, including combating piracy against ships flying Danish and non-Danish flags in the region, as well as in self-defence. It cannot be ruled out that, as part of the ship contribution's performance of its duties, certain persons might be deprived of liberty in connection with the deployment.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: Proposal B 295 on a decision of the Danish Parliament on a Danish military contribution in the Gulf of Guinea was put forward by the Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs on 25 May 2021, and a broad majority of parties in the Danish Parliament voted to adopt the proposal, with 86 MPs voting in favour and 9 against. There were no abstentions. Following a submission to the Danish Foreign Affairs Committee on 18 February 2022, the decision was made to recall the frigate as a consequence of an escalated situation in Europe.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
A frigate contribution had been deployed, which consisted of ABSALON class frigate Esbern Snare, sailing under national command. Aboard the frigate were precondition-creating contributions, including a special operations contribution, a helicopter contribution, a surgical team, etc. totalling approx. 175 crew members. In addition to the frigate contribution, the total contribution also consisted of a maritime logistical support element as well as staff and liaison officers.  In total, Danish Parliament approved the deployment of approx. 195 people.
But it must also be emphasised that Denmark has been making contributions to the building of regional capacity in West Africa since 2016. One such contribution has been in Ghana where the Danish Frogmen Corps has been operating since 2020 to help establish a maritime special force, which must have a force at full capacity of about 250 soldiers by 2026. This force must be able to be deployed in all types of maritime special operations in the Gulf of Guinea, including combating piracy and preventing drilling platforms attacks. The force is financed by the Danish Peace and Stabilisation Fund.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The contribution to the operation in the Gulf of Guinea (which was named “Operation Meridian”) was provided from November 2021 – early February 2022. The contribution was "recalled" as part of the escalated situation in Ukraine, after a request from NATO for it to join one of NATO's standing naval forces.

Denmark has had personnel deployed to Ghana since 2016 with the aim of training maritime task forces to combat maritime threats.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The task of the frigate contribution was to prevent and combat piracy, including the establishment of a maritime situational awareness to underpin the right to free navigation.
The frigate's tasks included surveillance and reconnaissance, area protection, accompanying or escorting ships, as well as search and rescue operations. The helicopter contributed to the frigate contribution's overall mission execution, including the establishment of maritime situational awareness, monitoring, reconnaissance, escorting ships, deployment of the maritime task force and so on.
In some cases, the maritime task force could be deployed to higher risk missions, such as the deployment of boarding teams on hijacked ships, rescue operations and special reconnaissance missions.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
A new threat from a seriously infectious disease led to a worldwide state of alarm on 5 January 2020. In 2019, the World Health Organisation, WHO, announced the possible outbreak in China of a form of pneumonia, the cause of which was unknown. The outbreak was related to a fish market in the city of Wuhan. Just six days later, China saw the first recorded death from Covid-19. Information about the new “corona” virus was then published, and the progress of the disease quickly began to accelerate. There were positive Covid-19 tests in Germany, France and Italy before the first Dane tested positive on 26 February.
Respiratory infection in humans caused by the Corona virus had, however, already been reported in 1966, which was followed up by a detailed description the following year. It was already known by 1968 that respiratory infection from the Corona virus was more frequent during the winter, and that children were less prone to becoming seriously infected. It also became apparent that people were already familiar with the virus in the 1930s but did not understand its extent and potential for contagion.
It therefore did not take long after the outbreak in China for the rate of infection to spread rapidly. It then became a pandemic, which was particularly virulent in certain communities and countries. Very many countries were entirely unprepared for the pandemic, with healthcare systems that found the increased workload difficult to cope with, some even being unable to cope with the task and do anything whatsoever to help their populations. The development of vaccines gained momentum; the first vaccines becoming ready by the end of 2020, which meant that the process of vaccination could begin.
All affected nations did the best that they could with their existing healthcare systems and stockpiles of protective equipment, masks and hospital equipment. A number of countries found themselves having to recognise, however, that they needed external support in terms of both materials and healthcare personnel.
It is estimated that approx. 60% of the world's population was affected to some extent by the Covid-19 Corona virus; and that approximately six million people or more have died of the disease.

text.heading: Mandate and Decision
text.text:
The request for Danish contributions originated from and was coordinated by the EU's civic protection mechanism; the Emergency Response Coordination Centre (or ERCC), as part of the EU's joint measures. The Danish government set up a taskforce to handle the entire Covid-19 situation, including any inquiries from abroad about support.
The first deployment of healthcare personnel as part of the Danish government's taskforce was approved in March 2021 with two teams being deployed to Slovakia, which was followed at the end of the year by the deployment of health personnel to Romania. Both countries had requested support via the EU.
Following a taskforce recommendation in May 2021, the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Danish Ministry of Defence and the Danish Ministry of Health approved requests (via the EU) from North Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, Iraq and Nepal for the donation of protective equipment and medical equipment.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The first deployment of healthcare personnel as part of the Danish Government's Taskforce was to Slovakia in March 2021 to relieve local healthcare personnel, and involved 12 nurses, 4 doctors, a staff doctor and two liaison officers, spread over two teams.
The Danish Emergency Management Agency supported Romania later in the year, with several small deployments of a total of 9 doctors, 13 nurses and 5 emergency team leaders.
On 23 April and 26 April 2021, India asked the EU for help in the form of medicine and medical equipment, including ventilators. India’s healthcare system was in a very precarious situation at this point, with a daily infection rate of over 350,000. A large number of countries, including Norway, Ireland, Germany, the United States, Canada, Australia, Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates, as well as the European Union all offered to provide various forms of support to India. 53 unused COPAC Boaray 5000D respirators were donated from the Capital Region of Denmark’s stockpiles.
Iraq had similarly requested support via the EU, and Denmark sent equipment provided by the regions in the form of 15 ventilators, 22 BiPAP, 148 infusion pumps and 31 patient monitors.
150 pulse oximeters and 200 humidifiers were donated to North Macedonia.
Medical equipment (patient monitors, defibrillators) as well as protective equipment consisting of masks, visors and smocks (from the Capital Region of Denmark) were donated to Montenegro.
Serbia and Nepal had requested protective equipment in the form of masks, medical equipment and protective equipment.

Donations in 2021 had a total value of approx. DKK 44 million.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The personnel who were sent to Romania were deployed during November. The healthcare personnel that were deployed to Slovakia performed duties during March 2021.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The doctors and nurses deployed to Romania were sent to an existing Covid-19 intensive care unit at the Matei Bals hospital in Bucharest. The team that was sent to Slovakia worked to relieve local healthcare staff at a newly established Covid-19 ward in the town of Banska Bystrica.
The numerous transports to beneficiary states took place from May to July 2021.

text.heading: Background
text.text: June and August 2022 saw inclement precipitation and the melting of glacier water that caused the most extensive flooding in Pakistan’s history. According to a UN assessment at the end of August, the flooding had cost the lives of more than 1,000 Pakistanis and impacted the lives of 33 million people. The Sindh province in south-east Pakistan was particularly badly effected with up to 10 million people displaced internally, more than 750 mortalities and consequential effects that included shortages of clean water and outbreaks of cholera. On 25 August 2022, the government of Pakistan declared a state of emergency as a consequence of the flooding.

text.heading: Mandate and Decision
text.text: As authorised by both the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark and the Danish Ministry of Defence, Denmark offered to provide aid to the Pakistani authorities on 2 September 2022. The proposed aid comprised of a water purification module and a team of 10 personnel (employees and volunteers) from the Danish Emergency Management Agency. The contribution was planned to continue for 30 days. The offer was accepted by the Pakistani authorities on 3 September 2022. The first team of personnel to be deployed departed for Islamabad on 6 September.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The mission’s goal was to produce and distribute as much water as possible under the circumstances. It was planned that the team’s deployment would take place at three tempos: Preliminary command – followed by the remaining deployment spread over two teams (one of which would accompany the cargo from Billund to Karachi).
In collaboration with the Pakistani authorities, the team was deployed to the small town of Khipro in the Sindh province, approximately a six-hour drive to the east of Karachi. The area had suffered serious flooding that had left many villages and wells submerged underwater, which meant that a very large number of displaced persons no longer had access to drinking water. At this site, they set up a water production facility linked to an old waterworks and a decentralised distributions system. Water tanks and tanker trucks were used to ensure that water was transported as close to the population as possible.
The government of Pakistan requested that the mission be extended. The Danish Emergency Management Agency therefore reached out to colleagues in other Scandinavian countries and were granted support in the form of personnel from Sweden, Norway and Iceland. When the mission came to an end, it had been manned by a rotating total of 25 personnel deployed from the Scandinavian countries.

When the mission was wound down, the team had produced and distributed 2,722,500 litres of clean drinking water to local people and had also renovated two local waterworks.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: Planned to run for 30 days, the mission was launched on 6 September 2022. Support from Sweden, Norway and Iceland made it possible to extend it until 4 November 2022.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The flooding had caused contamination of wells and other sources of drinking water in the region, which meant that there was a considerable risk of an outbreak of an epidemic. The production and distribution of clean drinking water, the testing of local wells and the renovation of waterworks meant that the risk of contagion was reduced.

text.heading: Background
text.text: At 04:17 local time on 6 February 2023, Türkiye was hit by a violent earthquake measuring 7.8 on the Richter scale. The earthquake’s epicentre was in south-eastern Türkiye, close to the towns of Nurdagi and Gaziantep. The initial quake was followed by several aftershocks measuring between 5.6 and 7.5 Richter. The impacted zone covered approx. 110,000 km2, from Türkiye to Syria. More than 45,000 people were reported dead, with more than 100,000 injured. A further two million people are believed to have been evacuated from their homes.

text.heading: Mandate and Decision
text.text:
The authorities of Türkiye quickly reached out to the international community for aid. It was decided on 6 February, after authorisation by the Danish Ministry of Defence, that Denmark would provide a contribution to disaster aid.
Because the European Commission was sending its EUCPT coordination team to Türkiye to coordinate the international humanitarian contribution, there would be a need for IT and logistical support to the coordinated effort in the form of a so-called Technical Assistance and Support Team (TAST).
The Danish Emergency Management Agency therefore reached out to Scandinavian colleagues in Sweden and Finland, who showed a willingness to provide personnel and material for a Danish-led TAST mission. It was jointly decided that the contribution would initially be comprised of a deployment of 12 ICT and camp technicians, together with two light tent facilities. Denmark and Finland would each provide one such facility.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
The Danish Emergency Management Agency’s preliminary command travelled to Ankara on 7 February for a meeting with EUCPT and then continued to the earthquake zone where Gaziantep had been selected as the EUCPT base of operations. The rest of the combined Scandinavian team and materials arrived in Adana by plane on 10 February. From there, personnel and material were transported to selected locations with the assistance of the AFAD emergency management authority of Türkiye.
During its mission, the team was simultaneously deployed to the base in Gaziantep and several other locations. Some team members were thus assigned to the airports in Adana and Gaziantep, with a view towards supporting the coordination of arrivals and departures from the international contribution. The vast majority of the team was, however, deployed to Adiyaman and Malatya, respectively, where they set up and operated the camps that had been brought to support EU and UN humanitarian aid personnel.
The Scandinavian team would also gradually assume the task of providing support to United Nations UNDAC humanitarian aid personnel and would, in this context, incorporate personnel and material provided by Sweden and Norway. This meant spreading the team over a broader area as the team now had a presence in Kharamanmaras and Hatay.
In addition to its contribution to the Scandinavian TAST team, Denmark also donated 90 prefabricated housing units to the authorities of Türkiye. It was agreed that some of these units would be loaned to UN personnel in Hatay with a view to supporting humanitarian aid efforts. Two Danish Emergency Management Agency technicians were also deployed to help our Scandinavian colleagues set up the units for the UN.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
The EU (and thus the Scandinavian) contribution was extended twice, which necessitated several personnel rotations and a gradual downscaling of the contribution. The bulk of the Danish material was transported to Denmark by lorry, departing from Adiyaman on 8 March. The last Dane from the deployment returned to Denmark on 25 March. The Danish Emergency Management Agency deployed a total of 14 employees and volunteers to Türkiye while the mission was ongoing, from 7 February to 25 March.
When the mission came to an end on 25 March, a mission led by Finland took over the task of providing support to UN humanitarian aid personnel in the earthquake zone.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The TAST team was assigned the task of supporting the EU coordination team in the form of communications material and logistics. Infrastructure in an earthquake zone can be seriously damaged so humanitarian aid stakeholders need to have access to safe accommodation and the working lines of communication that are essential to their ability to carry out their mission. During its mission in Türkiye, the Scandinavian TAST team performed a variety of tasks associated with this requirement, by setting up light tent camps and coordination centres with internet and satellite connections, arranging transport and several other services required to support the EU – and later, UN – coordination team.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
2022 saw a challenge to European security in the form of Russia’s military attack on Ukraine, which continues to this day. The situation has developed into a crisis that has serious consequences, not only for Ukraine, but also for the security of NATO and the Kingdom of Denmark.

NATO is maintaining its double-pronged approach to Russia that involves deterrence and defence, combined with a willingness to engage in dialogue. Since Russia’s illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula in 2014 and its destabilising activities in Eastern Ukraine, NATO has launched a number of defensive initiatives to ensure a credible deterrence and defence profile against the East. In the light of this current security crisis, NATO has launched various additional defensive measures that are proportionate and non-escalatory. This includes NATO's activation of the alliance’s defence plans, which are intended to ensure that NATO’s military supreme command (SACEUR) has the necessary military contributions at its disposal.

As part of NATO’s increased state of readiness, Denmark needs to be able to make a number of military contributions available, with a view to deployments in relevant military interventions as part of the collective NATO defence. The aim here is to demonstrate the solidarity of the countries that form the NATO alliance and to highlight the willingness to protect NATO's population and territory against any form of aggression.

The Danish Parliament (in its decision B127 of 24 February 2022) adopted the stance that Denmark would make certain military contributions available to NATO's collective defence. The Danish Government wants Denmark to be able to make further contributions at short notice to NATO’s collective defence, with a view to reinforcing its Eastern allies and ensure NATO's profile of deterrence.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The mandate under international law for the Danish military contribution will be the right to collective self-defence, as set out in Article 51 of the UN convention, the consent of the states concerned where the contributions will be deployed and the Law of the Sea, including the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, which includes rules on the freedom to sail international waters. The Danish contribution will be in accordance with international law, including international humanitarian law.
By adopting the proposals, the Danish Parliament has agreed that the Danish Government, through its representation in Brussels, accepts the activation of NATO's defence plans.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
The Danish Parliament (in its decision B127 of 24 February 2022) expressed its consent that Denmark could make certain military contributions available to NATO's collective defence. In its proposal B194 of 21 April 2022, the Danish Government again expressed its willingness that Denmark should be able to make further contributions at short notice to NATO’s collective defence, including with a view to reinforcing its Eastern allies and ensure NATO's profile of deterrence.

Proposal B127 was adopted on 24 February 2022 with 99 votes in favour and 8 votes against. There were no abstentions. Proposal B194 was adopted on 21 April 2022 with 90 votes in favour and 9 votes against. There were no abstentions.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
B127 concerned Danish military contributions to support the NATO collective until the end of 2022. This involved Denmark’s agreed contributions to NATO’s Very High Readiness Joint Task Force (VJTF) for 2022, which involved a frigate and a transport aircraft. It also involved Denmark’s ongoing contribution to NATO headquarters and NATO-operated units, including staff and liaison officers and a new Danish contribution to NATO’s combined air forces. Finally, Danish fighter planes could be deployed to enforce sovereignty in the airspace over the territory of the NATO countries. In connection with the rotation, establishment and recall of the contributions, it may be necessary to deploy up to approximately 200 people on a temporary basis.

The frigate contribution would be either a Iver Huitfeldt or Absalon class vessel, including a helicopter and a total crew of up to approx. 150 personnel. The frigate Niels Juel sailed on 27 February 2022 from Naval Station Korsør to join NATO's naval Task Group 441.01. This is part of NATO's Very High Readiness Joint Task Force (VJTF).
The transport aircraft contribution would be a C-130J transport aircraft with air and ground crew of approx. 50 personnel. Depending on the location, it would also be possible to deploy a national logistical support element and a national communications unit with up to approx. 30 personnel. Additional to these would be a drone surveillance system (AGS), which can perform land and maritime surveillance in support of NATO operations, and a communication unit of up to approx. 70 personnel.

The Danish contribution to the enforcement of sovereignty in the airspace over the territory of the NATO countries would consist of up to 20 F-16 combat aircraft with up to approx. 250 air and ground crew. It would be possible to transfer personnel and material for NATO's enforcement of sovereignty in the airspace over Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania as part of NATO's integrated air defence, as adopted in Danish Parliament decision B210 of 2 June 2004.

The right to deploy the units to perform missions would be delegated to SACEUR in accordance with established command and control. Any Cyber capacity that might be deployed would be under the exclusive control of Danish command and instruction authority.

The area of operation for the Danish contributions would be the geographical area of responsibility of the NATO countries as well as international waters and airspace. The area of operations for the Danish units was mainly expected to be the alliance's easternmost countries, e.g. Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania and Bulgaria and associated waters and airspace.

B194 enabled further contributions to NATO's defence plans. It was decided that these contributions would continue until the end of 2023. The total contributions consisted of both a land military contribution, a naval contribution, an air force contribution, a support force contribution and a staff contribution as well as the existing Danish contribution to NATO's advanced presence (eFP) in the Baltics and Poland.

The land military contribution on the ground would consist of a battalion battle group of up to approx. 1,000 personnel. The contribution entailed combat units (tank and infantry units), combat support units (engineering and fire support units) and support units (logistics and communications units).
The naval contribution consisted of an Iver Huitfeldt or Absalon class frigate, with up to approx. 175 personnel.

The air force contribution was comprised of a CL-604 surveillance aircraft with air and ground crew of up to approx. 35 people, an operator contribution specialising in airspace surveillance and control with up to approx. 85 personnel and a mobile air defence radar unit with up to approx. 45 personnel.

A further Danish contribution of up to approx. 225 people would be able to be deployed in the form of a company-sized unit with necessary support functions, including staff officers for relevant staffs, for NATO’s enhanced Forward Presence (eFP) in the Baltics and Poland, as adopted in Danish Parliament decision B150 of 23 May 2017.

text.heading: Duration
text.text:
Denmark has been part of NATO’s eFP since 2017 and deployed its first company of infantry from January 2018. An armoured unit has been deployed most recently (2022-2023).

As a result of Danish Parliament decision B194 of 21 April 2022, two combat battalions have been deployed from the spring of 2022, each for a six-month period. The unit was comprised of approx. 820 persons from actual combat units, staff contributions, military police and supply units, etc. The last unit returned to Denmark in early spring 2023.

text.heading: Mission
text.text:
The Danish contributions would be authorised to use force in self-defence and to defend allied forces and territory. The deployment is for defence and deterrence purposes, but the use of force to perform missions assigned by NATO remains an option under certain circumstances.
The tasks of the Royal Danish Navy will include all military maritime tasks, including contributing to the establishment of local supremacy at sea as well as securing maritime routes and the right to free navigation. A frigate would also be able to provide naval support to the military on the ground and in the air.
The tasks of the Royal Danish Air Force could include a wide range of air force transport tasks, such as the transport of personnel and material, troop deployments, airdrops of supplies and evacuations by air. There would also be a deployment of actual combat aircraft to repel airspace violations and to engage in actual combat if necessary. A deployed radar unit would be able to establish situational awareness of the airspace and support the deployment of Danish and allied combat aircraft.
The tasks of the Royal Danish Army would include a wide range of military tasks on the ground, ranging from participation in training and exercises to actual deployment in defensive combat. The battalion battle group would be able to contribute to deterrence and the defence of Denmark’s NATO allies. Communications units would support, as necessary, the establishment of signal links between units and headquarters.

missions.title: OPG – Yemen
missions.subtitle: Securing the right to free navigation
missions.name: OPG – Yemen

text.heading: Background
text.text:
The maritime security situation in the Red Sea, Bab al-Mandab Strait and the Gulf of Aden had been deteriorating since November 2023 as the Houthi movement in Yemen carried out a series of attacks and attempted attacks against civilian shipping and international military naval vessels. The attacks varied in nature and included hijackings and missile and drone attacks. Since December 2023, several ships with Danish interests have been exposed to attacks and attempted attacks, including Danish-owned and Danish-operated ships.
The Red Sea is a central hub for international trade, including for the world's energy supply.
In light of the Houthi movement's attacks against shipping in and around the Red Sea, the United States took the initiative to establish a maritime operation, Operation Prosperity Guardian (OPG), under the auspices of the existing international maritime coalition Combined Maritime Forces (CMF). The operation aims to secure the right to free navigation through the Red Sea, the Bab al-Mandab Strait and the Gulf of Aden. The intention is to use an increased international presence to deter the Houthi movement against further attacks and to protect civilian shipping traffic. The operation was announced on 18 December 2023 and gained support from a wide range of countries, including the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands and Norway.

Combined Maritime Forces is an international maritime coalition that is currently comprised of 39 countries, including Denmark. The naval coalition aims to promote maritime safety and stability, including by combating terrorism and violent extremism, crime and smuggling, strengthening regional maritime cooperation and providing assistance in connection with natural disasters, humanitarian disasters and accidents at sea. Its tasks include the collection and sharing of information and intelligence with a view to maintaining safety at sea. Denmark’s current contribution (2024) to the CMF is staff officers for the coalition’s headquarters in Bahrain, as set out in B 56 of 9 February 2017. The CMF is divided into a number of task forces, including CMF Task Force 153, which covers the Red Sea.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2722 on 10 January 2024, in which it condemned attacks by the Houthi movement against shipping in the Red Sea since 19 November 2023 (when the Houthis attacked and seized the ship Galaxy Leader and its crew) as a threat to international peace and security, and demanded that the attacks be ceased immediately. The resolution also recognises the right of member states to defend their ships against attack.
The contribution was mandated to use force to counter threats to free navigation. The Danish contributions included a mandate to use force in self-defence and to defend civilian ships and units in OPG as well as other units deployed in the area, for example in the context of other maritime operations or under a national mandate.
The Danish contributions were subject to international law, including the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, and, to the extent relevant, international humanitarian law. The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea includes, among other things, rules on free sailing.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 16 January 2024, the Minister for Foreign Affairs put forward proposal B 103 on a Danish contribution to strengthening maritime security in and around the Red Sea. The proposal was approved on 6 February 2024 with 92 votes in favour, 16 votes against and 1 vote undecided.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Specifically, a frigate of the Iver Huitfeldt class was deployed and up to approx. 175 people, including partial contributions in the form of military police, a sanitary element, interpretation capacity, an intelligence element, a maritime helicopter and a maritime support element.
Frigate Iver Huitfeldt sailed from Denmark at the beginning of February, so as to be at a state of readiness in the operational area when the mission was approved by the Danish Parliament.
The Danish contribution’s zone of operations included the Red Sea, the Bab al-Mandab Strait, the Gulf of Aden and adjacent areas, including relevant staff facilities in the area. As part of CMF, the Danish contribution can also operate in the Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The frigate contribution was deployed for an approximately two month period, starting in February 2024. The proposal made it possible to deploy additional staff officers to CMF. The maritime support element and the additional staff contribution were expected to be deployed for approximately three months during the same period.

text.heading: Tasks
text.text: The frigate contribution was tasked with monitoring the area and protecting the free navigation of civilian shipping traffic and international naval vessels in the area of operations. Surveillance of the area partly involved use of the frigate's radar systems and sensors to collect and exchange radar images and data with other units that were part of the operation and with relevant partners. The frigate also participated in escort and escort voyages for civilian shipping traffic in the operational area. OPG’s tasks, including those of the Danish frigate contribution, were defensive in nature and did not include conducting offensive operations against Houthi units or facilities. The same would also apply in the event of a possible new EU mission.

missions.title: Houthi movement – Yemen
missions.subtitle: The threat to maritime security in areas like the Red Sea
missions.name: Houthi-bevægelsens - Yemen
missions.descriptiveName: The threat of the Houthi movement – Yemen

text.heading: Background
text.text:
A US-led coalition had been carrying out a series of military precision strikes since 12 January 2024, which targeted the Houthi movement’s military capabilities used for attacks on civilian shipping and international military naval vessels in and around the Red Sea. The operation was a response to repeated attacks by the Houthi movement in the area since November 2023. The aim was to reduce the Houthi movement's ability to threaten maritime security in the area.
The United States asked Denmark to contribute support functions to the offensive coalition. Denmark had already expressed its political support for the offensive coalition. On 12 January 2024, Denmark was part of a joint declaration which expressed support for the US-led military contribution. Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Netherlands, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, South Korea, Germany and the United States also signed the declaration.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The UN Security Council adopted Resolution 2722 on 10 January 2024, in which it condemned attacks by the Houthi movement on shipping in the Red Sea since 19 November 2023 as a threat to international peace and security, and demanded that the attacks be ceased immediately. The resolution also recognises the right of member states to defend their ships against attack.
The basis in international law for Denmark’s contribution to the US-led offensive coalition is the right to collective self-defence of the United States against the Houthi movement in accordance with Article 51 of the UN Charter. In a letter of 12 January 2024 to the UN Security Council and in accordance with Article 51 of the UN Charter, the United States notified its intention to use armed force against the Houthi movement in implementation of its right to self-defence.

text.heading: Decision
text.text: On 23 January 2024, Denmark’s Minister for Foreign Affairs put forward a proposal for parliamentary resolution B 104 on Danish participation with staff personnel. After consideration, the proposal was approved by the Danish Parliament on 24 January with 90 votes in favour, 15 votes against and two votes undecided.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: Specifically, the resolution involves the deployment of a Danish staff contribution comprised of a single person.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The staff contribution was initially deployed for approximately three months, starting at the end of January 2024.

text.heading: tasks
text.text: The staff contribution’s role is to act in support of possible future coalition attacks against Houthi military capabilities located in and on Yemen's sea, air and land territory, as well as in international airspace and international waters, and being used to threaten maritime security in and around the Red Sea. The staff contribution’s tasks can, for example, involve planning and providing basis for decision-making for the offensive operations.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Conflict and vulnerability undermine development and the fight against poverty, contribute to humanitarian crises and serve as a basis for instability which, in turn, brings with it a flow of refugees, organised crime and violent extremism. Denmark is therefore playing an active role through its cross-ministerial Peace and Stabilisation Fund (FSF) in fragile and conflict-impacted countries and regions such as Afghanistan, Syria and Iraq, Sahel, the Horn of Africa, the Gulf of Guinea and Ukraine. The Peace and Stabilisation Fund commitments focus on development, stability, peace and state building as well as the prevention and management of conflict through integrated considerations of diplomacy, developmental aid and increasing capacity.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text:
The initiative concentrated on providing aid to countries where action needs to be taken to improve their military and civil state of readiness and to ease internal unrest as a way to improve their ability to withstand external threats.
The support for Georgia is a clear continuation of Denmark’s involvement in previous missions in Georgia, including as part of UN and EU operations.

The Danish Government adopted the new peace and stabilisation program for Georgia for 2023-2026 on 7 February 2023.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Danish Defence is helping to establish long-term stability at various places in the world, including by helping countries to build their military capacity, i.e. by helping beneficiary countries to improve their ability to look after their own security interests. This can take the form of deployments of Danish military advisors or the deployment of Danish units to provide training support to armed forces in the various beneficiary countries.
Danish Defence is currently providing contributions in countries like Ukraine, Georgia and the Gulf of Guinea with a view to augmenting the ability of these countries to make a contribution to stability and security.

As regards Georgia, the first four advisors were deployed in 2023. The current program in Georgia is expected to continue on a provisional basis up to and including 2026.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission commenced in 2023 and is expected to continue up to and including 2026, at least to start with.

text.heading: Background
text.text: The Danish Emergency Management Agency and the Danish Home Guard launched a civilian crisis management project in Georgia within the framework of the Substantial NATO-Georgia Package (SNGP) on 1 November 2019. The project aimed to strengthen and further develop Georgia's civil crisis management system and increase their resilience. This initiative will also help Georgia to achieve EU and NATO membership at some point in the future.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The contribution aims to help Georgia strengthen its civil defence mechanisms and make them more resilient. Denmark's contribution in Georgia takes place in collaboration with NATO and the UN under the Peace and Stabilisation Fund, which is a cross-ministerial fund with participation from the Danish Ministry of Defence, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark and the Danish Ministry of Justice. Its purpose is to make NATO stronger by also strengthening NATO's neighbours.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: The contribution entails improving Georgian civil defence towards becoming better prepared for future incidents. This includes training Georgian National Guard and Emergency Management personnel. In addition to training personnel, the contribution also focuses on providing materials to ensure that Georgian National Guard has relevant material and equipment at its disposal that is compatible with equipment used by its Emergency Management Service.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: The mission is still ongoing and has been running since 2019.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The tasks include strengthening Georgian National Guard and Emergency Management through courses such as “Train the Trainer”. This involves training instructors to train National Guard reservists in civil defence duties. There have also been seminars to familiarise relevant personnel with the roles, responsibilities, plans and procedures associated with the performance of critical functions and the provision of critical services. This is essential as Georgian civil defence is kept afloat by relatively few people. The contribution’s third track is to achieve greater alignment with UN Security Council Resolution 1325 for women peace and security. This takes place as a collaboration with the Georgian Ministry of Defence, which aims to achieve a significantly better balance between the sexes.

text.heading: Background
text.text: Russia has waged war against Ukraine since 24 February 2022, which has partly resulted in the capacities of Ukraine's national emergency services (State of Emergency Services of Ukraine, SESU) being stretched to the limit. This is mainly due to the complexity of the war that involves attacks on the civilian population and on civilian and critical infrastructure. Significant material donations from various EU countries arrived as the war went on, which unfortunately sometimes suffer from a lack of quality control and strategic coordination. In some cases, the donations have been quantitatively insufficient or required significant resources before they could be put to good use. This has meant that SESU has sometimes been unable to make maximum use of the donations. Because of this, a team from the Danish Emergency Management Agency travelled to Ukraine to find out how Danish aid could be more useful.

text.heading: Mandate & Decision
text.text: The Danish Ministry of Defence worked together with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark and the Danish Emergency Management Agency to come up with a method that would allow Denmark to provide aid that made a real difference. This basically involved a clarification of what Ukraine actually needed, with particular focus on capacities and education. This mission was conducted in close cooperation with SESU.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text: In addition to meetings with SESU, the Danish Emergency Management Agency also met up with the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency, visited the mobile hospital donated by Denmark and visited other local organisations. These meetings constituted the basis for the preparation of an analysis of how Denmark could provide support to Ukraine in the future within the context of the war Russia had started.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: This mission had a duration of around two weeks in 2023. It will serve as the basis for the planning of future support initiatives.

text.heading: Mission
text.text: The occasional lack of control and low quality of donations means that SESU is not always able to use the material that is donated. The difficulty of repairs and the unavailability of spare parts are also problematic. Furthermore, materials are not always intuitive to use, but instead require some form of training before they can be used. In collaboration with other authorities, the Danish Emergency Management Agency is therefore in the process of preparing combined donation packages in the form of equipment and training.

text.heading: Background
text.text:
Russia’s annexation of Crimea turned out not to be the only attack on Ukrainian sovereignty. The Crimea crisis quickly spread to eastern Ukraine where pro-Russia separatists in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions (collectively known as the Donbass), supported by Russia, declared the region independent and launched an armed rebellion against the Ukrainian army. In 2014, the Ukrainian government decided to suspend its neutral status and seek a closer relationship with Western partners, including NATO. In light of the ongoing civil war in eastern Ukraine, then President Petro Poroshenko asked NATO to provide more support to the effort of reforming the defence and security sectors in the country to bring them into compliance with NATO standards. This request was accommodated through a series of initiatives such as advisory, training/education, capacity building, and training missions.

Russia’s attack on Ukraine on 24 February 2022 brought about the need for an altogether different kind of initiative to support Ukraine. Massive donations of material and very focused training programs were adopted by NATO, with countries also providing their own bilateral and multilateral contributions.

text.heading: Mandate
text.text:
The NATO training missions in and on behalf of Ukraine are based on an invitation from the Ukrainian government, with the end goal that Ukraine’s armed forces should achieve NATO standards. The collaboration between NATO and Ukraine takes place within the framework of the NATO-Ukraine Commission, which was set up in 1997 to strengthen the collaboration between the two parties and to assist Ukraine with institutional reform.

International joint efforts to provide military support to Ukraine are broadly centred in the American-led Ramstein-format Ukraine Defense Contact Group (UDCG), which is the central political and military forum for western support to Ukraine.

text.heading: Decision
text.text:
Using funds that had already been set aside by the Danish Ministry of Defence towards supporting international security partnerships, the Danish Government had already decided in 2015 that it would support the development of Ukrainian defence capacity. The Danish Defence Agreement (a cross-party agreement) of 2018 included the intent to provide additional contributions to the NATO programme for Ukraine by providing training under the umbrella of Operation ORBITAL and UNFIER, which would be financed by the Peace and Stabilisation Fund of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark.
After the Russian attack in 2022, the Danish Ministry of Defence was authorised on 7 August 2022 to provide educational and training activities to Ukrainian personnel. These involve a wide range of different training programs, ranging from qualifications for individuals to the training of pilots and tank crews, etc.

Within this context, Denmark is supporting the British-led INTERFLEX training project in the United Kingdom by providing about 130 Danish soldiers a year and also offering to train Ukrainian soldiers in Denmark. It is also expected that support will be provided towards the training of NCOs and in relation to the Ukrainian Home Guard.

text.heading: Contribution
text.text:
Denmark is working together with allies and partners to take on a large degree of responsibility towards supporting Ukraine. Part of our combined support involves a Danish contribution of soldiers and instructors to the British-led INTERFLEX training project, which is being operated in the United Kingdom. Ukrainian recruits are trained in basic military disciplines.  The ambition is to train a total of up to 10,000 Ukrainians every four months. The Danish soldiers and instructors are broadly appointed among Danish Defence authorities and include the provision of commanders and trainers from the Royal Danish Army. Danish Defence has also completed an NCO training program in Denmark. Approximately 70 soldiers have been deployed each year since 2022.

During 2023, Denmark trained 1,500 soldiers by the end of October. Other countries are also providing instructors. These include Sweden, Norway, Finland, the Netherlands, Germany, Latvia, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

text.heading: Duration
text.text: INTERFLEX began in 2022 and is expected to continue to be active.
